name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: The first item on the agenda is the report by Mr K. Noti Marias on the European Ombudsman's Annual Report on the activities of 2015 [2016/2150 (INI)] (A8-0331/2016)

name: Νότης Μαριάς
text: rapporteur. — Mr President, I, too, would like to welcome the European Ombudsman, Mrs O'Reilly, to congratulate her on the work she has done, which is really very important. I would, of course, like to welcome Mr Timmermans, the Vice-President of the Commission, who also contributes with his activity to tackling maladministration in the context of the operation not only of the Commission but of the European Union as a whole. Allow me to thank the shadow rapporteurs, who, through their intervention, contributed to drafted this report. I would also like to thank the members of the Secretariat of the Committee on Petitions for the effort they have made. I think that the procedure we are discussing today is a very important one. It is a process of democratic accountability, a process in which we will listen and be able to judge the activity of the European Ombudsman. The institution of the European Ombudsman is very important, it started in 1996 - if I am not mistaken - and this institution is appointed by the European Parliament itself. Let me point out that the main element concerning the activity of the European Ombudsman comes from Article 24 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which states that citizens have the right to report cases and instances of maladministration to the European Ombudsman. By “maladministration” we mean poor and inadequate administration, an administration that violates the law, violates human rights, violates the principles of good administration, including transparency and conflict of interest. We have, therefore, raised a number of issues in our report which we need to look at. First of all, how does the Ombudsman deal with a conflict of interest or a possible conflict of interest in the context of the The European Central Bank, because the European Central Bank, as you know, participates in the troika, while at the same time being a lender to the Member States, is a banking supervisory authority and is an independent monetary authority. How does it reconcile all these roles and under what conditions do we control transparency in the decision-making process? The same applies to the Eurogroup, which is an informal but meaningful instrument, as it makes important decisions that affect the social and economic life of European citizens. Questions are also asked about ESM, the institution which gives loans to the Member States, but also imposes memoranda. This grey area, therefore, must be tackled, and I think that the remarks we make in the report raise these issues. We come to the activities of the Commission itself, which really checks on the way in which it has handled the issue of TTIP negotiation. There have been criticism from the citizens, there has been an intervention by the European Ombudsman for more transparency, and I think that the way in which the Commission subsequently provided information on this important issue has paved the way for substantive discussions and remarks. Another important issue that we have discussed is: what are the limits of the Commission's operation when it acts as guardian of the Treaties? Is it obliged to refer all Member States or does it retain any discretion? At the same time in our report we also refer to the way in which the European Citizens' Initiative should work, what are the rights of people with disabilities, what is the operation and control of Frontex, what we do in the case of “revolving doors”, under what conditions and The conditions are controlled by former Commissioners who have taken up positions in other organisations, the main thing being Mr Barosso, who has taken up an important position in Goldman Sachs. These are the key issues that we have raised in our report, Mr President, and I look forward to the comments of my fellow Members, to make my concluding speech and to conclude a debate.

name: Emily O’Reilly
text: Ombudsman. – Mr President, good morning and thank you Mr Marias and all the shadow rapporteurs for your work on this report. The text before the Chamber today expresses strong support for the work of the Office of the European Ombudsman, for which I am profoundly grateful. I would like to thank in particular the Committee on Petitions, and its Chair, Ms Wikström, for its engaged cooperation and support over this past year. In our separate but complementary roles, we work directly with European citizens who seek our help. Honourable Members, this is my third time addressing you in plenary since 2013. Each time I have benefited from your expertise, your advice and support and that has fed directly into my work. My Office is driven by the complaints we receive and, as today’s report notes, over 22% of complaints concern access to document requests. Transparency and the Treaty-based right of access to documents must continue to play a crucial role in our EU democracy. The EU does indeed set higher standards than many Member States, and given its role and its global reach in many areas, so it should. The Juncker Commission is, I recognise, working to improve standards in this regard and I welcome the proposal made just yesterday to revise the Commissioners’ Code of Conduct, as both I as Ombudsman, and this Parliament, have urged. This is a positive step, although I do think that there are other possible future improvements to the Code on how this challenging issue is handled. In addition, the Juncker Commission, through Vice—President Timmermans, has proposed earlier this year a revised Transparency Register, which I welcome. Many Member States do not have a register, while others have been unsuccessful in introducing them. However, a register is only as good as its capacity to give citizens assurance that lawmaking is not being inappropriately or unduly influenced – and so I look forward to seeing the outcome of the negotiations with Parliament and Council on this Commission proposal. Much EU lobbying of course focuses either on the Permanent Representative offices of the Member States in Brussels, or in the national capitals, and so I hope the Member States will reflect on how this can be made more transparent for all European citizens. I am currently working on this issue with my colleagues in the European Network of Ombudsmen, both to raise awareness of lobbying transparency and to show the very real way in which lobbying directly affects people’s lives. Last June, I hosted a network conference in Brussels at which we discussed the refugee and migration crisis, lobbying transparency, and the rule of law. I was very pleased that my Ombudsman colleagues were able to have engaged and spirited conversations with EU officials, and I believe it was a valuable learning experience for both groups This report recognises the work of my Office in several areas in cooperation with the EU administration, and with the support of Parliament, to seek and achieve real improvements. These include: transparency and balance of Commission Expert Groups; Commission efforts to make the TTIP talks more transparent; Commission efforts to implement Article 16 of the Staff Regulations; whistleblowing rules to protect EU staff; how fundamental rights are upheld in EU cohesion policy; the UN Convention on the Rights of People with Disabilities; and the European Citizens’ Initiative.  I also wish to mention three other areas which I know are of interest to this House. Frontex became a particularly critical EU agency in 2015 during the refugee crisis. I welcome its efforts in implementing the Special Report I sent to Parliament concerning a Frontex complaints mechanism, but also the recommendations I made in relation to joint return flights.  The European Central Bank has also become a much more familiar institution to EU citizens and I thank it for working with my Office and boosting the transparency of its administration as also noted in today’s report. Given the heightened citizen awareness of EU institutions and agencies in the wake of the financial crisis, and now of Brexit, none of us can work in the shadows or resist citizen demands for greater transparency and accountability.  In 2015, I also launched an inquiry into the transparency of the Trilogues negotiation process and made several proposals concerning transparency, while respecting the legislators’ need to negotiate in confidence. I thank the three institutions for their good cooperation, and I look forward to their responses next month. Today’s report also notes the correspondence we have had with President Dijsselbloem in relation to boosting the transparency of the Eurogroup. I welcome his focus on that issue, particularly given the increased importance of this group in the lives of citizens within the eurozone. The Dutch Presidency, which ended this summer, also worked hard to boost transparency in the Council. This is an area I will continue to focus on, as it is important for citizens to be able accurately to disentangle, and understand, the separate lines of decision making at EU and Member State level.  But let me also mention some examples of the everyday cases my Office deals with, which assist in improving the experience of the EU for its citizens. A German citizen complained that the Commission had not properly explained why it was not investigating his infringement complaint about the E-Privacy Directive. I found that the Commission had not provided sufficient reasoning about why it was not taking action on the issues raised by the complainant, and the Commission has agreed to take my analysis into account when it reviews the Directive. Another important individual case involved a Parliament employee, who has a daughter with severe and irreversible brain damage. The employee came to me after Parliament’s administration had sought to revoke a derogation it had granted her from having to move from her place of work under mobility rules. Happily, Parliament agreed to my recommendation to maintain the derogation for as long as the daughter needs her mother’s presence and care. Another case concerned the Education Audiovisual and Culture Executive Agency. A small community group had claimed that the agency had unfairly shortened the deadline for funding applications for town-twinning projects. Following my intervention, the agency clarified its actions and the complainant will be able to participate in a future twinning project. Before I finish, I wish to note again the high standards of the EU civil service, of the thousands of dedicated people who work in the EU institutions and agencies all over Europe. Europeans want to see positive change for their families in their daily lives. This is mainly a political challenge, but a strong and ethical public administration is a hallmark of a strong democracy. To recognise the work of EU staff and share best practice across the institutions, I recently launched the Award for Good Administration to acknowledge examples of good service, transparency and ethical behaviour. This award is open to staff in all EU institutions, agencies and bodies and nominees may be proposed by anyone up until the end of January of next year. I welcome of course any nominations from Members of this House. Honourable Members, we live in challenging and even frightening times. We must, however, not be afraid to ‘connect the dots’ in this new wave of citizen unrest manifested in increasing populism and nationalism, and we must examine at a deeper level our political and administrative governance structures in Europe. We must also detach our views of the personalities involved in some of these movements from the genuine citizen concerns and distress that sometimes fuel them. The power and responsibility to do that at EU level lies mainly within the hands of this Parliament, the Commission, and the governments of the Member States, and those are onerous and solemn responsibilities. Those of us who value and support our pluralist European democracy must now redouble our efforts and demonstrate clearly that we serve the public interest and the public interest alone. Thank you again to the rapporteur, the shadow rapporteurs, their staff and the secretariats for all the work on this year’s report. (Applause)

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: Thank you, Mrs O'Reilly, for all the important and interesting things you have told us, both about democracy and transparency and for your cooperation with the European Parliament.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I want to congratulate Mr Marias on an excellent report on the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2015. The work of the European Ombudsman in fighting maladministration by EU institutions and bodies is of the utmost importance. Our citizens have a right to good administration; they expect and deserve high quality service. It is our joint responsibility to live up to these high standards. I would like to take this opportunity to say that the Commission is very pleased with the consistently good cooperation with the Ombudsman and her services. We also welcome the recent adoption by the Ombudsman of the new implementing provisions governing inquiry procedures.  The report puts emphasis on the importance of the Ombudsman’s work on transparency as a guarantee of good administration. Transparency has been from day one a key priority of this Commission, and of me personally, and we have taken important steps in that regard. Since December 2014, all bilateral meetings with those who seek to influence our decision-making have been made public. In September this year we proposed to make the new transparency register mandatory, based on a new and binding interinstitutional agreement covering the European Parliament, the Commission and, for the first time, the Council. I would like to underscore all the remarks Ms O’Reilly made on the need to have the same standards applied everywhere in the EU, including in places where we do not have direct responsibility but which fall under the direct responsibility of our Member States.  All of us who serve in European public office have a duty to respect the highest standards of integrity and ethics. In the light of recent developments concerning members of the Barroso Commission, the Commission has this week backed President Juncker’s intention to revise the Code of Conduct for Commissioners. He will consult the President of Parliament, in line with a framework agreement between our two institutions, on proposals to increase the cooling-off period for members of the Commission to two years, and for the Commission President to three years.  I am also pleased that the report acknowledges the Commission’s efforts to follow up on the Ombudsman’s recommendations in various areas. This includes the publication of numerous TTIP documents, the increased information on senior officials leaving the Commission to work outside the institutions, the new rules on the composition and functioning of expert groups, and the introduction of a complaints mechanism for fundamental rights in the new European Border and Coast Guard. The Commission always takes the Ombudsman’s remarks very seriously. We take swift action to address cases of maladministration and comply with her recommendations whenever possible. From time to time there may be cases where the Commission and the Ombudsman disagree but this only concerns a very limited number of cases. In 2014, the Commission’s compliance rate was 86%.  Let me conclude by stressing that the Commission will continue to cooperate fully and loyally with the Ombudsman in her inquiries and to build upon the existing very good work relations with the Ombudsman and her services.

name: Julia Pitera
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — Mr President! In 2015, the office of the European Ombudsman dealt with many complaints and dealt with a number of important issues, including transparency of trade negotiations between the European Union and the United States or cooling-off period (grace period). Undoubtedly, work should be undertaken on amending the Code of Conduct of EU Cooling-Off Officers. The period of 18 months that must elapse between stepping down from office and taking up a new function is too short. By contrast, it is the foundation of democratic states, and citizens' access to documents is an important pillar of the system of disclosure. However, its limits must be determined. Do the intercessors of full transparency in trade negotiations, access for everyone to these documents and negotiations in their own countries have systems to allow everyone such access to knowledge of international relations, financial, monetary or economic policy? Do they really want documents from Member States classified as confidential to be overt on every request? After all, only these categories were included in the 2001 Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council and should be respected in the course of the work on documents in the European Parliament. Because, after all, the knowledge available could be used not only by concerned citizens, but also those who would like to use the information obtained for self-interest or to the detriment of the public interest. Idealism is extremely socially carrying. However, the question is whether the implementation of such solutions would be safe for this society. I therefore call for a prudent vote on the amendments tabled to the report on the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2015.

name: Miriam Dalli
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, First Vice-President Timmermans, Ombudsman O’Reilly, the report we will be voting on today proves what an essential asset the role of the European Ombudsman is for Europe and also for the European institutions.  As Socialists and Democrats, we positively welcome the Ombudsman’s efforts to ensure greater transparency in her work, and ensuring also the rights of the most vulnerable. The European Ombudsman is there to ensure that Europe’s institutions maintain the highest standards for all of our citizens and her efforts to remove the shadow of secrecy surrounding the TTIP negotiations have proved this. I urge her to be vigilant and to help us in ensuring that citizens will have full information when it comes to all trade agreements, including CETA. This is why I and other colleagues are insisting that the European Ombudsman should be given the power to issue a statement of non-compliance should our institutions refuse to release public documents which do not endanger public safety or security or put the privacy and the integrity of individuals at stake. Furthermore, we called for the European Ombudsman to be further empowered to take decisions, if the need arises.  Another important measure we are calling for is stronger rules on the protection of whistleblowers, together with legal safeguards at all levels for the individuals involved. It is all about trust. The EU needs to take greater measures to entrust its citizens with the power of information and to allow our citizens to play an active and engaged role in policy making. I believe that in doing so we will be strengthening our societies and I have no doubt that the Ombudsman and her office can be at the forefront to ensure such empowerment.

name: Ryszard Czarnecki
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — Mr President! Mr President of the Commission! The Group of European Conservatives and Reformists will be in favour of this report. We point, after all, to several elements. First of all, of course this is political office, there's nothing to hide it. Since he deals with the TTIP treaty on trade and investment between the Union and America, it has a political dimension, and let's not pretend it isn't. I think the very relevant thing is the issue of the code of clerical conduct, the conduct of officials. This is the thing that is expected by public opinion — maybe not all citizens — but the public in our Member States. Here, EU officials should be like Caesar's wife — beyond suspicion. Finally, I think that sometimes disputes between individual institutions — the Ombudsman, the Commission and sometimes the Parliament — add credibility to the real debate that should be going on in the European Union, if the European Union is to be credible for citizens, for taxpayers.

name: Cecilia Wikström
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Vice-President Timmermans, Ombudsman O’Reilly, I am happy to have you here in plenary this morning and I am sure that I speak on behalf of the whole Committee on Petitions when I say I am sure that all of us appreciate our mutual good cooperation. The European Ombudsman is doing an excellent job, especially in constantly using the possibilities to initiate own-initiative inquiries. It is important for democracy in general, and for the perception of the European institutions in particular, that the Ombudsman raises sometimes very difficult and sensitive questions and also investigates our own working methods and procedures. I am very pleased that the Ombudsman keeps pushing the European institutions to improve transparency in all different fields and bodies. Especially in these days of populism and euroscepticism it is crucial that the institutions live up to the expectations of EU citizens concerning transparency and good conduct. I therefore believe that the EU needs to take the issue of revolving doors much more seriously, otherwise the reputation of the European Commission and the European Union itself is put at risk. Therefore I welcome that Commission President Juncker yesterday proposed to tighten the Code of Conduct for Commissioners. However, I agree with the Ombudsman that some positions will not cease to be problematic simply because two or three years have passed. The rules therefore need to be made more explicit and possibly also include a range of sanctions for any breaches of the rules.  Something that I would like to have seen more strongly reflected in the report is to ensure that the European Ombudsman is able to order documents to be released from the Commission when needed. To be able to perform her duties with regard to maladministration of the European institutions, the Ombudsman needs to be able to act on her own behalf and not to be dependent on the goodwill of the European institutions. It is in all our interests if we want to be perceived as credible in these difficult days. Once again, I thank you very much for an excellent cooperation.

name: Ángela Vallina
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank the Ombudsman for the work of the Ombudsman and for presenting this annual report. Thank you very much. Thanks to his work, we can see how complaints of lack of transparency by the Union institutions remain the main concern of citizens, and we can speak with many examples. We can talk about revolving doors, such as that of former Commission President Durão Barroso, now working for Goldman Sachs; conflicts of interest existing between the Commissioners themselves, such as the former Commissioner for Competition or current Commissioner Arias Cañete; the lack of information on the meetings of the Eurogroup, where budget cuts agreements are decided for euro countries; lack of transparency among Commission expert groups, i.e. lobbies with which Union policies are negotiated behind closed doors; lack of transparency in infringement files opened by the Commission to the States where they violate Union law; and, of course, the lack of information concerning the TTIP negotiations. I would like to denounce once again that MEPs are going to the reading rooms without being able to make copies of the information provided to us, of the little information. By the way, it is also quite offensive that the Commission has overturned the citizens' initiative against the TTIP, which received more than three million signatures. Finally, we would like to congratulate the Ombudsman for her investigation into the Frontex agency. Hot returns and mass expulsions are contrary to international humanitarian law. Although efforts are being made to reform, the establishment of a border police is not the solution to the humanitarian drama we are experiencing. In short, we hope that the Commission and the Council will take note of the Ombudsman's contributions. In them there is the credibility of the European project right now.

name: Margrete Auken
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — Mr President! First of all thanks to Emily O'Reilly, but I would also like to take this opportunity to thank Commissioner Timmermans. I seize every little bit of a chance I have to say thank you and praise him, and here I have an opportunity, so of course it has to be taken. It's not so often that happens, so thank you very much for a good reply from the Commissioner too. We are pleased that we have a real ombudsman, that we have succeeded in this House to ensure that no party politics has passed in our ombudsman, but that we have a credible, independent ombudsman. All three of our Ombudsmen have helped to strengthen the institution and trust of citizens. Your work has shown so brilliantly, and so has Marias' report. We are, of course, backing it up. I'll look at some of the hefty points. This is a matter of good governance practice. Here, several colleagues have mentioned openness and transparency. It's not good enough yet. We're going to make more of it. I am very pleased that we have got the desire for a directive to protect whistleblowers into the report. That will be one of the important things to go here. But we still also have administrations nationally thwarting openness, so this is a battle that is far from won. Let me also mention the other important side of good governance practice: conflicts of interest. It is strange that there are still many in the administration who believe that it is enough to make a 'declaration of conflict of interest'. No, that's not enough! They must not be there at all! We need to have that system properly incorporated, including in our agencies, including in the pharmaceutical agency, including in the food agency, EMA and EFSA, be clear that if citizens are to have confidence in the decisions that are made, then there must be no conflicts of interest. I think we should help each other strengthen this. Finally, I would ask that we get a majority in here to get rid of the excruciating reading rooms where you almost have to sit with your fingers in ears and almost blindfolded. So our citizens' confidence in us is not helped by these reading rooms, so I am also appealing to the Socialists to support our amendments so that we can become clear on that point in our vote.

name: Eleonora Evi
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — (IT) (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the cases of maladministration found by the European Ombudsman in the actions of the institutions and bodies of the Union mean fully the serious democratic limits of the current governance model. The annual report we are discussing today, which analyses the Ombudsman's activity, appears satisfactory in bringing this out. But the European Union is far from ensuring full transparency in its work. This is clearly deduced from the persistence of a situation in which full access to documents held by the European institutions is denied and there remains heavy opacity in the relationship with the powerful lobbies of the European institutions. private sector. It is not surprising to see, therefore, how a multiplicity of decisions taken by the European institutions appear immediately oriented to satisfy the special interests of the economic-financial elites. The worst is to see at the same time how serious the socio-economic and environmental implications of the same are to the detriment of the fundamental rights of citizens. Barroso's affair, who at the end of his term as President of the European Commission, accepts a summit post at Goldman Sachs International, appears emblematic in confirming the perverse union between European institutional summits and economic-financial elites. Much more stringent rules should have been adopted for some time to avoid not only cases of revolving doors, as in the Barroso affair, but also all those small and large conflicts of interest at the institutions, agencies and bodies of the Union which have passed down and continue to transmit the credibility of decision-making processes on a technical and political level at European level. Because of the existing situation, it is no coincidence to verify how the ICE instrument, the European citizens' initiative, which should have increased the direct participation of the citizens in the definition of the Union's policies, continue to be mortified by those glittering procedural deficiencies which affect their effectiveness. A marked change in the political and moral paradigm of the European Union must be put in place to regain the trust of citizens. So I thank the Ombudsman again for her excellent work.

name: Sylvie Goddyn
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Mr President, Mr Marias' report provides a comprehensive overview of the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2015, focusing more on victories, often symbolic, than on defeats. Thus, the number of requests processed increased from 23,000 in 2014 to 17,000 in 2015, demonstrating that Europeans are not very convinced by this institution. However, it is not for fault of knowing her. Indeed, 83% of European citizens are aware that they can lodge a complaint before the Commission, Parliament or the European Ombudsman. What is the cause of this disaffection for the Ombudsman? The results are not good. The first example is transparency. The Ombudsman welcomes the Commission's publication of documents on the transatlantic treaty, but it was mainly the NGO Greenpeace that allowed transparency against the very will of the European institutions. As for whistleblowers, the European institutions are not credible either. The best known, Snowden and Assange, did not even get asylum in Europe. The only small victory in terms of transparency is that the European Central Bank will publish the minutes of its Management Board this year. The balance sheet is therefore very modest. On the other hand, it becomes harmful when one examines its action in favour of illegal immigration. The European Network of Ombudsmen conducted a survey on the human rights of deported migrants. Following this investigation, the Ombudsman recommended that Frontex give migrants the opportunity to lodge complaints against border guards. He also reoffended in 2015 by launching a strategic initiative on immigration and the Asylum Integration Fund. This aid to illegal persons in itself disqualified the Ombudsman's action, because the financial and human cost of this immigration is unbearable for Europeans. The Ombudsman's activity in 2015 It is therefore not such as to give Europeans confidence in this institution. We will therefore not vote in favour of this report.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI). — Mr President, despite many problems and cases of lack of transparency and maladministration, Mrs O'Reilly has an excellent job to do, as a result of her tireless efforts to improve the quality of services provided to citizens by European administrations. The issues and areas in which the Ombudsman should place particular emphasis are: ensuring impartiality in the Commission's competitive decision-making processes; increasing transparency in the negotiations on the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership through the making proposals to the Commission; Member States comply with the Charter of Fundamental Rights when implementing actions financed from Union funds; continuing its investigations into “revolving door “cases in the Commission; the work of the European Central Bank; the establishment of a fully mandatory and legally binding register of lobbyists with the aim of closing all loopholes and making registration in the Register compulsory for all lobbyists; on the lodging of complaints establishing appropriate channels and procedures for reporting all forms of maladministration; ensuring administrative cooperation and coherence between the Union's administrative bodies; continuing efforts to establish transparency in the Union's decision-making process and trialogues; strengthening it in the work of the European Council, as well as preventing conflicts of interest for the special advisers. Finally, the Ombudsman must protect European citizens from bad decisions taken by the institutions, which have a direct impact on their daily lives, such as decisions on economic and tax matters.

name: Peter Jahr (PPE).
text: Mr President! Thank you to the Ombudsman. The collaboration was very good. I think we — the Committee on Petitions and the Ombudsmen — have found our common role: we are both here to make the European Union a little better — not for ourselves, but for European citizens. One could also say that sometimes it is also about making the European Union somewhat more understandable. I can only give this selective thanks to Parliament's rapporteur here. The rapporteur could not resist the temptation to politically overload the annual report on the Ombudsman. Nor is it fair to the Office to unsolve politically unresolved problems with the Ombudsman. This means that we in Parliament must first come to an agreement and discuss what we actually want at the major construction sites. The construction sites are called: ECB, Europe Group, ESM, transparency offensive, whistleblower protection, revolving door effect and conflicts of interest. As coordinator of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, I also offer you and ourselves, together with the relevant technical committees, to discuss these points with the aim of giving the Commission political recommendations for action. We also see that the Commission — as Mr Timmermans said this morning — is also moving. But it would be good if we agreed in Parliament first before we simply try a quick shot in the Ombudsman's annual report. My group appreciates the Ombudsman's work and we will continue to work together constructively. Mrs O'Reilly, do not fail to continue to represent the interests of European citizens! We will support you in this. To another good cooperation!

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D).
text: Mr President, Mrs Ombudsman, when populisms end up denosting politics and, therefore, democratic institutions, we need a clear response that will strengthen European citizens' confidence in the European project. I believe that your office, with you at the head, has been able to echo this priority by giving priority to the issue of transparency and responding to this 22% of complaints by European citizens in this area. I would therefore like to convey to you my congratulations and encourage you to continue on this path and, furthermore, I ask you to involve even a little more and to promote, together with other competent persons, a coherent, shared and clear and transparent code of conduct across the European institutions, including European agencies, to including avoiding possible doubts as to conflicts of interest. Therefore, transparency does; but also regulating the behaviour of people — politicians and workers — who are within the European institutions.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR).
text: - Mr President! Mrs Ombudsman! Mr President of the Commission! I would like to acknowledge the action of the Ombudsman and support the Marias report. Indeed, this transparency accent deserves very strong support; I am delighted that the new EU institutions, the three most important institutions working together and the actions of the Eurogroup will also be covered by transparency. As always in public action, the key is whether we are unequivocal and whether we operate systemically. I am very much counting on the interinstitutional agreement proposed by Commissioner Timmermans to be put into force. But I also want to draw attention to the Giegold report, which goes very precisely and unequivocally towards transparency, demanding, for example, the introduction of a legislative footprint in all reports, the lengthening of the period in which former EU officials cannot receive employment in business. I am very much hoping that the Commission will support this approach, which is present in the Parliamentary Transparency Report, and that there will indeed be synergies of transparency.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the Ombudsman very much for the remarkable work she does. Ombudsman, given your relentless, persistent efforts in making all the EU institutions more accountable, I would like to ask you to investigate, in cooperation with Parliament’s Bureau and the European Anti-Fraud Office, the conduct of Mr Farage MEP in the past days. On 9 November, during committee week, Mr Farage flew on vacation to the United States, stating on camera that he was just a tourist. At the same time, he stated on a popular radio show that he was hoping to be offered a new job by President-Elect Trump. Just two days ago, Trump proposed that Mr Farage should become UK Ambassador to the United States. Whether it was a tourist visit, a job application tour or just a photo opportunity, please investigate whether Mr Farage’s private trip to the US was actually paid for by European taxpayers, or whether he received any parliamentary allowances during his absence from the European Parliament.

name: Κωνσταντίνα Κούνεβα (
text: GUE/NGL). — (EL) Mr President, the report on the activities of the European Ombudsman is a good opportunity to identify the problems in the functioning of the European institutions. It is an opportunity to see what issues European citizens are concerned about. Most of the complaints appear to be about transparency and access to information, the policies of the Union and the role of the Commission. Over 55% of the cases investigated by the Ombudsman concern the European Commission. Citizens remain suspicious of its action and call for control, as they are suspicious of the discussions behind closed doors. We all understand that suspicion. For this reason, I support the report. We need a stronger European Ombudsman who listens without discrimination to the voices of citizens and fights maladministration.

name: Michèle Rivasi (Verts/ALE).
text: — Mr President, I would like to congratulate the Ombudsman on the work she is doing. I wanted to ask you two things: access to documents and the problem of the links of interest of the Commission's experts, particularly the Euratom Treaty. As regards access to documents, you know that the Commission refused to give the documents, either to Greenpeace or PAN Europe, concerning glyphosate, the active substance of Roundup. The Court of First Instance and in particular the Court of Justice of the European Union had said that access should normally be given to these documents. The Commission had appealed. Yesterday — and it is for this reason that this report is timely — the Court of Justice of the European Union won the case for the associations. This shows that when you are referred to you, you would like to have even more power in terms of access to Commission documents, but also agencies like EFSA. The second point concerns the links of interest between experts. Madam Ombudsman, I asked you to obtain the names of the experts and the links of interest of the experts of the Euratom Treaty who had been at the origin of the maximum permissible limits in the event of a nuclear accident. I got the names, but not the links of interest, and you told me that it is up to the panel to decide whether or not they communicate those links. Therefore, I really ask you, the Commission and the States, to ensure that you have more power to ensure that we have access to this information.

name: Laurenţiu Rebega (ENF).
text: — Mr President, in the current context, the Ombudsman's efforts should focus primarily on the abuse of power of the European administration. Recently, the institutions created precisely to ensure stability, security and economic growth, through the exaggerated powers they have gradually assigned, have only prevented the resolution of urgent problems such as migration and exit from the economic crisis. The worst abuse of power, however, is the failure to comply with the demands made by citizens. The public consultation procedure is not just a formal step in the legislative process. This consultation should be reflected in the final political decision. Referral of deficiencies within the European Commission is a serious alarm signal. I strongly recommend the European Ombudsman to make use of the prerogatives it enjoys under Article 228 of the Treaty and to have as many activities as possible on its own initiative, in particular to verify how the European institutions comply with their own regulations.

name: Heinz K. Becker (PPE).
text: Mr President, Mr Vice-President, Madam Ombudsman. Ms O'Reilly — successful in her role as European Ombudsman — is the direct point of contact for 500 million EU citizens when it comes to complaints about the management and functioning of the institutions and authorities, and thus the natural partner alongside the European Parliament. In the context of the annual report to be voted on today, I appreciate Mrs O'Reilly's efforts to make the establishment of the Ombudsman as accessible to people as possible. With new strategic studies on concrete problems in EU institutions and bodies, it has clearly helped to further improve the high levels of transparency and management in EU public authorities. It is unfortunate here in this House that some groups and Members — especially the rapporteur responsible — are trying to ideologize important dossiers, abuse them for party-political purposes and not be accessible to important compromises at all. In this report, for example, Commissioner Arias Cañete explicitly refers to people and does not mention any evidence. As far as is known, he has always acted precisely within the Code of Conduct, and even went beyond it. There can be no talk here of a breach of the code of conduct. This reporting is unqualified. I am still confident that reason will ultimately win among those responsible in the political groups and that we, as the European People's Party, will be able to vote in plenary. Ombudsman Emily O'Reilly deserves it.

name: Jude Kirton-Darling (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like to say to the Ombudsman that her work has really been invaluable for us in increasing transparency in the European Union. In the face of rising populism, transparency is vital for the long—term legitimacy of the European Union. Coming from the UK, that is something which is very dear to my heart.  Ombudsman, I strongly support your work in opening up the black boxes of EU decision—making, but to do this we need to go further. I would like to highlight three areas. We should ensure that the transparency that has been achieved around the TTIP negotiations is replicated for all EU trade negotiations. We should see the publication of all documents both from trialogues between the Parliament, Council and Commission on proposed legislation, and from Commission expert groups. Transparency is crucial to rebuild trust in the European project. Democracy is a fragile flower and transparency and public debate are its water and feedstock. So going into a new year, I would plead that you remain a good gardener.

name: Anneli Jäätteenmäki (ALDE).
text: — Mr President, I would also like to agree with the thanks offered to the Ombudsman. Your work is not easy and your resources are very limited. Plus, when you do your job well, you have to step on pretty big toes as well, and that's not always certainly easy. Secondly, I would like to say that the European Union needs a law on good governance, clear regulations on different levels of government, what are rights and what responsibilities. Through it, the rights of an official to define precisely, but also the rights of a citizen to complain come out clearly. Commissioner Timmermans, you are accustomed to knowing the job as a man. The Treaty of Lisbon has defined that there will be a law on good governance in the EU. It is the only point that this Treaty of Lisbon has not yet been put into action, which is that the Commission should now get to work. The preparation of this good governance law must be injected into practice.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the repeated scandals involving European Commissioners have to stop. The anger over Barroso’s plum new role in Goldman Sachs extends right across the political spectrum. More importantly, it extends far beyond this Chamber to the millions of citizens who have borne the brunt of the austerity policies which he imposed. Add Juncker and LuxLeaks, Arias Cañete in the Panama Papers, and Kroes in the Bahamas Leaks, and we see the corrosive impact of corruption in the European institutions. We are not talking about conflicts of interest – it is full—blown corruption. Barroso shows that the 18—month cooling—off period in the Code of Conduct is entirely inadequate. It should be five years at least. Sanctions must apply for breaches of the Treaty obligation on Commissioners to act with integrity. But we need more. I urge the Ombudsman’s office to take a lead on closing the Commission’s revolving door. Ombudsman, there is a lot faith in this Chamber in your ability to do that.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Madam Ombudsman, Mr Vice-President, we are pleased to note that since the appearance of the Ombudsman at European level, 20 years ago, the institution has shown many positive points. In one of her speeches, the Ombudsman spoke aptly about their duties. He said that they stand between the small citizens and the great state trying to narrow the power ditch between them. This is very important. In my brief speech, I would like to draw attention to four elements that, in my opinion, have contributed to a better European public administration. I welcome the fact that the European Ombudsman started reforming the European Network of Ombudsmen in 2015. This created a new opportunity to conduct parallel investigations at national and European level. I am also pleased that you have followed the issue of European citizens' initiatives and that the Commission is trying to do more for a better functioning, which is also important. I appreciate that you have also examined whether the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights is respected by Member States when using resources from the Cohesion Fund. Finally, I also welcome the fact that we are revising the Code of Conduct, which is necessary. And, Mrs Ombudsman, at the end of my speech, I would like to draw your attention to something that has already been mentioned earlier. Please remember how important it is for EU citizens to know as many details as possible of your activities in their native language. Thank you for your cooperation.

name: Edouard Martin (S&D).
text: — Mr President, Madam Ombudsman, I will go outside the box. I want to make you aware of a topic that has never been discussed, yet there is a lot to say and do. I am talking about the European Parliament. Hundreds of parliamentary attachés work in this institution, and the precariousness of their employment contracts means that they do not have too much interest in complaining. Indeed, they can be thanked on a simple statement of breach of confidence, at the discretion of the parliamentarian. It calms! Yet sexual harassment is a reality, and there is no listening, counselling or alert structure here. It's a lack, it's suffering! Sexual harassment has no color, has no smell and no political color. It is therefore urgent to put in place monitoring tools to help victims so that omerta is no longer needed here. A genuine status of the parliamentary attaché is needed so that he can better defend his rights. We cannot be here the lesson givers to the whole earth without putting our house in order. The victims are therefore counting on you, Madam Ombudsman, and I wish a strong initiative on your part.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the Office of the European Ombudsman deals with instances of maladministration in the activities of the European institutions, bodies, offices and agencies. In 2015, the Ombudsman helped over 17 000 Europeans, mostly from Spain, Germany, Poland and Belgium. In addition, the Ombudsman launched 17 own-initiative inquiries regarding major issues on the EU agenda, such as TTIP transparency, whistleblowing or the European Citizens’ Initiative. It is also important to mention that the activities of the European Network of Ombudsmen has been increased to include the national and regional ombudsmen, aimed at fostering cooperation and conducting parallel investigations in important subjects such as the forced return of illegal immigrants.  I would also like to congratulate the Ombudsman on the initiative of the Award for Good Administration that was inspired by the examples of exemplary administration carried out by civil servants. The Ombudsman wants to underline the fact that useful work for citizens goes sometimes unnoticed because of distance and that good practice is not shared within the administration. I hope that this award will help to refocus the situation and I firmly support this reinforcement. It is a good way to show our appreciation for these good practices. I wish the Ombudsman further success and dedication in everyday work and I wish her good luck because her work has been exemplary. I wish her all the best in continuing the work.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D).
text: - Mr President! In 2015, the Office of the European Ombudsman helped more than 17,000 citizens, of which almost 14,000 cases were settled by providing advice through an interactive guide on the Ombudsman's website. More than 2,000 cases were handled as complaints, more than a thousand as requests for information. Compared to the previous year, the number of complaints remained at similar levels, however, the proportion of complaints in the total number of cases was higher than in 2014. The leading position, in terms of the countries from which the complaints came, was taken by Spain, further places — Germany, Poland, Belgium, the United Kingdom. Unfortunately, we do not have information on how much the handling of these complaints has satisfied citizens, but the statistics themselves look optimistic. Wishing further success, Mr Emily O'Reilly, I hope that the institution of the European Ombudsman will not cease to improve its actions to guarantee the full enjoyment of their rights by citizens. Marias, a job well done.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I congratulate the European Ombudsman on his activity and the annual report; I do the same with Mrs Dalli for her thorough report, which highlights how the relationship of citizens has changed with the institutions and how citizens finally enter, even through complaints, in the heart of debates on European policies, in the heart of our debates There is It was a great demand for transparency: I think, for example, for the negotiations on TTIP and other international agreements. Through the Ombudsman but also through the Committee on Petitions, which I want to remember, citizens have direct access to the institutions and thus have been able to express concerns and have answers, as in the conflict of interest, for example, of former European commissioners taking up posts in the private sector. European policies have a strong impact on the lives of our citizens and move multi-million euro turnovers: protecting the interests of citizens is our priority. The credibility of the European Union will gain this.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Ombudsman is a point of reference for what is called the management of conflicts over the rights of European citizens, individuals, companies and associations, which clash with problems of maladministration by an institution of the European Union. Your Ombudsman is a key role in reducing the gap between citizens and the institution of the Union and essential that you continue to assert the fundamental rights of European citizens, promoting, in the face of cases of maladministration, good governance and the culture of legality. I am pleased that the report arose the institutions to adopt specific procedures for the regulated reporting of irregularities by whistleblowers, but I believe should be protected more effectively. But I am convinced that more must be done in terms of communication with citizens and businesses, to inform about the role of the Ombudsman and the possibility of making complaints of irregularities through her office.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: Mr President, Vice-President Timmermans, European Ombudsman, this Parliament plays a role in the fight against the spectrum of populism that is going through Europe, which emphasizes as never before the need for transparency and accountability. That is why we recognise his work in promoting a European figure for the protection of the complainant, the whistleblower; in denouncing the absurdity of that reading room, which is so disreptised by the European Parliament's decision-making procedure; and, above all, in the requirement of a maximum level of compliance with ethical rules for the European Parliament. members of the Commission, the Permanent Executive of the European Union. We have denounced the unacceptable counterexample that former Commission President Barroso has signed Goldman Sachs, who contributed so much to the financial bubble disaster. But above all, it must also be said that what we have known about Commissioner Günther Oettinger, who travelled to Hungary on a private plane of a lobist who is at the same time the Moscow consul in Baden-Württemberg, the Commissioner's Land, which has also been dispatched with unacceptable comments of nature racist or stigmatizers of homosexual marriage. This is also part of the accounting rule which is required of the members of the Commission.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you Madam Ombudsman for what you are doing to bring the European institutions closer to civil society. I would like to stress the sensitivity shown in the proposition of the guidelines for improving the functioning of the European citizens' initiative, especially as regards the need for the Commission to make solid reasons for rejecting a popular initiative. I take advantage of the Ombudsman's presence in the House to raise the thorny issue of so-called “revolving doors” cases, namely of senior officials who have left the Commission to work in the sector private. These are now very frequent episodes. I was one of the signatories of the letter addressed to you in which she was asked to intervene — which she actually did — following the appointment of former Commission President Barroso to adviser and non-executive chairman of Goldman Sachs International. What steps it intends to take to ensure that the Commission has an appropriate and effective code of conduct to prevent its officials from subsequently occupying roles in the private sector conflict of interest with the position they previously held in the Commission?

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, observing principles of good administration in all our relations with citizens is not only an obligation on EU institutions, it is an imperative if you want to earn citizens’ trust. The Ombudsman’s work is essential in making sure we live up to the high standards of public service that citizens rightly expect from all of us, and this was underlined by every single one of you.  I want to reiterate this Commission’s strong political commitment to the highest standards of transparency and ethics, and I signalled already before that President Juncker has addressed a letter to the President of your Parliament to have a discussion on the Code of Conduct.  But let’s not forget that in the eyes of our citizens, we are all Brussels, regardless of the institution we have the honour to represent. It is therefore essential that together, the three EU institutions involved in lawmaking move to the next stage. This means delivering on the mandatory transparency register we have proposed earlier this summer and hopefully also adopting the Giegold report in the European Parliament that will help us move forward in that respect.  Some issues pertaining to the internal workings of the European Parliament were also raised this morning. But of course I will leave that entirely to Parliament. It is not the Commission’s role to comment on the behaviour of Ambassador-Elect Farage.

name: Emily O’Reilly
text: Ombudsman. – Mr President, I would like to thank all the honourable Members for their contributions. This is always a very important meeting for me because it gives me confidence in what I am doing, that the strategy that I am applying and the way in which I am dealing with complaints conform generally to your particular wishes and the values that you wish to see upheld through the work that I do. Of course, it also gives me new ideas about particular new areas that I should concentrate on, or about reinforcing the areas that I am working on, and thank you for that. I just want to stress a few things in relation to some of the comments that were made. First of all, my greatest strength as an Ombudsman is my independence: my political independence and also my independence from the complainants. In order to work, I need both the confidence of the citizens who come to me for help, but also the confidence of the institutions that I am independent and impartial. I would ask you to continue to support me in that, because it is very important for the work that I do.  Very briefly, in relation to three particular matters that were raised: there was a question in relation to a particular MEP. I just want to stress that it is not part of my mandate to investigate individual MEPs. If there are particular issues concerning MEPs that concern some of their colleagues, it is obviously Parliament that has to deal with that in the first instance. In relation to the questions on glyphosate and the court ruling, of course I will analyse what the final court ruling is and take guidance from that. The issue of expert groups is something that my office has done a considerable amount of work on, including conflict of interests, where we have made certain proposals in relation to that. Of course, I am always willing to hear or receive any complaints in that regard, because it is certainly an area which we take very seriously. In relation to MEPs’ assistants, I am very aware that some of them do have difficult and challenging work to do in a sometimes very stressful and political environment. We do, and we can, take complaints from them, but generally those complaints would be against the European Parliament administration in relation to how they have handled their complaints. Obviously that is something I am more than willing to discuss. Just to sum up, obviously once again a lot of your focus has been on transparency and I do acknowledge the work that has been done, particularly by Vice-President Timmermans, in promoting greater transparency. I think there is a particular urgency now, given what has happened, both here in Europe and also in the US, to really address citizens’ concerns and to listen to their demands for a greater awareness of what the institutions are doing on their behalf. The conflicts of interest, particularly in relation to the recent high-profile case, has also forced us all to join the dots between things that happen like that and the wider concerns of citizens and how, ultimately, they are expressed at the ballot box.  Once again, thank you all very much, thank you to Mr Maris for his report and thank you, Mr President.

name: Νότης Μαριάς
text: rapporteur. — Mr President, I would like to thank the Ombudsman, Mr Timmermans and colleagues for their positive comments. I would like to respond to anguish and remarks from colleagues by saying that in the report we do not refer to Mr Cañete first. The only reference is to Mr. Barroso. Secondly, the petitions that have been made are intended to demonstrate the position of the European Parliament and also to make it clear that there is a great deal of concern about how 'Revolving doors' work. And it is important that Mr Junker has now taken an initiative. It recognises the problem and considers that the code of operation of the Members of the Commission themselves should be changed. So, ladies and gentlemen, that is what you have to bear in mind. Thirdly, I think that the comments we made about the lack of transparency in TTIP have paid off. We made the same remarks last year and saw the Commission respond. We also all raise the following issue: it is not possible to go to closed rooms, to reading rooms, to read the documents. And this is something that we have to deal with and see next year. There are no 'sacred cows' in the European Union today. They're all under review. There must be transparency everywhere and everything, including in the Eurogroup, which adopts decisions affecting the social and economic life of millions of citizens, which are only available in English. Watch out for that. We cannot leave the European Central Bank out of our criticism, which also takes important decisions. So these are the issues that we are discussing. I think it is important that there is a very good cooperation between the Committee on Petitions and the Ombudsman. I have raised this point in my book on the European Ombudsman, which I published in 1994, and I stressed that the basis for the institution of the European Ombudsman to work is for the proper cooperation of the Committee on Petitions with the European Ombudsman. It is on this basis that the European Parliament can operate. Our aim is to empower the Ombudsman to move forward, to proceed with impartiality and independence. If we here do not guarantee this independence and the possibility of action, I do not think that we will deliver any significant results. Control of lobbies, rights of people with disabilities, access to documents and information, even greater protection for complainants, improvement of the functioning of the European Citizens' Initiative - a matter of great importance, because citizens take matters into their own hands -, control also to the European Chemicals Agency to avoid animal testing: all these issues have been raised. In conclusion, Mr President, I would like to emphasise that we have the opportunity to vote on a report which gives the European Ombudsman even more power to act, because it acts on behalf of all the citizens of the European Union.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: Discussion is over. The vote will take place today, Thursday 24 November 2016, at 12.00 noon. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: in writing. — I would like to welcome the commitment of the European Ombudsman to protect the rights of persons with disabilities and to play an active role in the EU framework established pursuant to Article 33 (2) of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities which is responsible for protecting, promoting and controlling the implementation of the Convention. Personally, I represent the European Parliament in the EU framework so I can see closely how the European Ombudsman works side by side with the European Parliament to protect the rights of persons with disabilities and ensure that the EU administration is aware of these rights in relation to its responsibilities. I encourage the European Ombudsman to continue his valuable activity for the benefit of people with disabilities.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. — I congratulate Emily O'Reilly for her excellent work and continuous efforts to improve the quality of services offered by the EU to citizens. It is necessary to be aware of transparency as a central element for trust gain and good administration, which is also demonstrated by a high proportion of transparency complaints. The European Ombudsman has a very important function as it is authorised to accept complaints about irregularities in the activities of the Union's institutions, bodies, offices or agencies. And also any citizen of the Union and any natural or legal person resident or registered office in one of the Member States shall have the right to contact the European Ombudsman regarding irregularities in the activities of the Union's institutions, bodies, offices or agencies. In 2014, the European Ombudsman achieved that 90% of her conclusions and/or recommendations were taken into account, 10 percentage points higher than in 2013. I welcome and support the continued efforts of the European Ombudsman to increase transparency in the negotiations on the TTIP Agreement by submitting proposals to the Commission. I believe that international agreements such as TTIP and CETA require enhanced transparency, which is called for by many concerned citizens. The work of the Ombudsman is important as it improves and maintains the confidence of European citizens in the functioning of the EU institutions.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing — The European Ombudsman's Office performs an irreplaceable role in controlling compliance with European Union legislation. It is regrettable that there are cases where the European institutions ignore the Ombudsman's office, circumvent whether or not they supply it with the comprehensive information needed to investigate individual cases. Namely, it is the EMIS committee investigating the emissions scandal and where I am the sole representative of Slovakia. The Commission did not deliver all the documents requested to us or the Ombudsman, thereby slowing down our work. Similar situations do not contribute to the smooth operation of the institutions or to increasing citizens' confidence. In the future, we should strengthen the powers of the Ombudsman's Office and introduce sanctions against non-cooperating institutions or specific officials.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: in writing. — Mr President, the activities of the European Ombudsman have a very significant impact on the citizens of the European Union. The report submitted by Emily O'Reilly for 2015 is very detailed, transparent and factual, so we can more easily analyse the actions of this institution. I am pleased that in this report, on behalf of Parliament, several important issues have been raised, which the Ombudsman should take more account of in the future. For example, complaints from the population about the intrusion of senior officials or politicians into corruption scandals. More account should also be taken of the rights of national minorities, which are not always respected in EU countries and which are provided for in the acts of the Treaty of Lisbon and in international conventions. I welcome the sincere and positive work of the Ombudsman in developing EU legal frameworks for people with disabilities on the basis of the UN Convention, the aim of which is to improve the protection of such people and promote their rights in society. In addition, these rights must be respected by both EU and EU administrative authorities. I am pleased that the Ombudsman stressed the importance of making more efficient use of the support of the European administration, which will help to tackle problems that are relevant to all citizens more quickly and efficiently.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: The next item on the agenda is discussions on cases of violations of human rights, democracy and the rule of law pursuant to Rule 135 of the Rules of Procedure: — The case of imprisoned publisher Gui Minhai in China (2016/2990 /RSP))

name: Jakop Dalunde
text: author. — Mr President! Swedish book publisher Gui Minhai is jailed since October last year, without trial, after Chinese authorities looked after him in Thailand. Formally, he stands accused of a road accident, but in reality his only crime is that he owns a publishing house and a bookstore that gives out and sells books not appreciated by the Chinese regime. Minhai was born in China but is a Swedish citizen and thus also a European Union citizen. Minhai has now been jailed for more than a year. He has extremely limited access to contact with his family. His daughter has not received any life signs from her dad since June. It's a terrible situation. Swedish authorities have not yet been given access to Minhai. Despite repeated efforts, the Chinese counterparties refuse to cooperate, which is completely unacceptable. We condemn any human rights abuses in China, such as arbitrary arrests, forced confessions and secret custody. We strongly condemn the lack of freedom of expression in China and the means of repression used. China must release all peaceful regime critics — anti-corruption activists, lawyers and journalists, including Gui Minhai.

name: Bas Belder
text: Author. — “Who will remember my father Gui Minhai?” , the title of an opinion article in the Washington Post of October 17. A touching declaration of love by Angela Gui to her abducted father, until autumn last year a free man in Hong Kong, publicist, bookseller and publisher. Who wants, who will remember my father? Today we in the European Parliament recall, in any case, aloud and on paper with a resolution, the unprecedented illegal deprivation of Gui Minhai by the Chinese authorities. What drives the leaders of the global superpower China to this brutal, cruel act? What fear do they have of civilians like Gui Minhai? The German author Jan-Philipp Sendker, who has been around China for more than 20 years, gives a plausible answer in his contribution to the weekly magazine Die Zeit of 17 November. Outwardly, China's leaders behave very self-conscious, but inwardly they are driven by fear of their own people. The result is a huge gap of confidence between government and citizens. As a result, many Chinese people want to leave their own country, according to Jan-Philipp Sendker. Or that they're making plans for this for their own children. I will end, Mr President, with a bright spot. The Chinese authorities can offer a start of a counter-proof of the confidence gap: the immediate release and rehabilitation of Gui Minhai and countless peers.

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: Author. — Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, Gui Minhai was last seen in Thailand on 17 October 2015. He has since been in jail in China without legal and consular assistance. Other than that, no information about his state of health or where he is concretely was given to his family, nor to the Swedish authorities. I would like to point out the fact that he was kidnapped by the Chinese authorities while living in Thailand, on his property. Enforced disappearances violate a range of other basic human rights, since they include torture and other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment. Here, in addition to the gross violation of human rights, we also have the violation of international law. For the second time in a year, the European Parliament is speaking out with a resolution on human rights in China. I reiterate that the European Union should only deepen its economic and trade ties if there are visible and tangible improvements in the human rights situation, which is not to date happened. The Union must ensure that democracy, the rule of law, independence of the judiciary, transparency and freedom of expression are strengthened. We must avoid being indifferent, colleagues, especially after these events concerning Gui Minhai.

name: Lars Adaktusson
text: author. – Mr President, we are debating a significant urgent resolution regarding the case of the Swedish book publisher, Gui Minhai. Mr Minhai has been imprisoned without trial and without legal assistance since last autumn after being abducted in Thailand. Thanks to three of Mr Minhai’s colleagues, who were detained as well, we now know how the Chinese regime treats publishers who dare to criticise the system. They arrest them, keep them in solitary confinement and force them to appear in front of TV cameras. This is unacceptable. It is against international conventions. Freedom of speech and freedom of expression are fundamental human rights. China persistently violates these rights. It is time for the EU to speak out against the communist regime in Beijing. It is time for the immediate release of Mr Gui Minhai. (Applause)

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri
text: Author. — (IT) (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, nine months after Parliament's urgent resolution on the case of missing publishers, the mystery remains as to the fate of Gui Minhai. This case brings to the fore the issue of freedom of expression in China, which is once again harmed by the latest rules introduced in the country. The entry into force of the new rules on the management of foreign NGOs, scheduled for January 2017, will ban all organisations that will not be registered with the Ministry of Security public, while the cybersecurity law, promulgated in early November, will only give greater legitimacy to the well-known network censorship policy pursued by Chinese authorities. The Beijing government employs every means available to prevent the Internet from being used as an information channel and to hinder the work of international NGOs. With today's resolution we appeal to the Chinese authorities for the release of Gui Minhai and an invitation to reconsider current legislation in order to ensure an appropriate space for expressions of civil society.

name: Malin Björk
text: author. — Mr President! Gui Minhai has been jailed for over a year now, and Swedish authorities have only been allowed to meet him on two occasions. The Swedish authorities have asked for the full support of Chinese authorities for our Swedish citizens, as well as other missing persons, to have their rights protected. Neither Gui Minhai's family nor the Swedish government have been informed of any formal charges against him or where he is formally held in detention. My thoughts also go today to Minhai's daughter Angela who is working to get her dad released and home safe. Not knowing what has happened and not being allowed to have contact with one's family is itself a crime. The disappearance of Gui Minhai, like several others, is part of a pattern in which media freedom, freedom of expression and the free word are violated. Political prisoners have other speakers mentioned. The UN Committee Against Torture has raised serious concerns about consistent reports from various sources about continued unlawful detentions in unrecognised and unofficial detention facilities. The EU has said they will hold another round in human rights dialogue with China soon. I would like to say this: It is not possible to be a trading partner and not have respect for human rights. I think the EU should become much clearer and stop hypocritical. The human rights clause must be able to be activated when countries violate these rights so blatantly. With this resolution, which almost every political group in this House has endorsed, we want to be clear that we are now calling for Minhai's immediate release. We are calling for the strengthening of freedom of expression and the freedom of the media and the free word.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský
text: for the PPE Group. — I would like to say on this case that respect for human rights in China is considered by the EU, and also the European People's Party, to be as important as excellent trade relations. Kidnapping people from any other state back to China is absolutely unacceptable and will always be absolutely unacceptable to the EU. The EP demands that all Chinese, including publishers, editors-in-chief, journalists and bloggers, be given room to express their views without fear of any recourse. Freedom of speech is the basis of all healthy societies and there is a need to debate fairly hard with China in this sense. Resolving this case will certainly improve relations between the EU and China, but this case is certainly not the end of our interest in human rights in China.

name: Jo Leinen
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, the kidnapping of booksellers by the Chinese enforcement agencies is a clear violation of international law. I am the Chair of the China Delegation in this House, and my political Group, the S&D, fully supports the ‘one China, two systems’ principle, but we cannot accept this arbitrary intervention. What does China fear about the booksellers? Stories about corruption and misbehaviour by high-ranking officials in Beijing? Okay, but freedom of expression should not be compromised. This kidnapping of booksellers is a symptom of the generally miserable situation with regard to freedom of expression, and of the intimidation of journalists and bloggers in mainland China. It is of a piece with the NGO law, which restricts civil society enormously, and the censorship in cyberspace on the grounds of combating terrorism. The European institutions need to engage with China’s counterparts to address these issues: we cannot accept this restriction of freedom of opinion. But unfortunately, to my knowledge, China is downplaying the next human rights dialogue in Brussels: I heard that they are sending only a very low-ranking official. This is not a good sign. I hope that trust and cooperation between the EU and China can be increased, even on these difficult questions.

name: Mark Demesmaeker
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — (NL) Of course, we know the numerous cases in China where human rights defenders, writers, dissidents face threats, arbitrary arrest, detention in unknown places, unfair trials, house arrest and even torture. New Chinese legislation gives the authorities virtually unlimited powers to arrest, detain citizens in unknown places and sentence them to long-term prison sentences based on vague descriptions. China goes very far and haunts people beyond its borders. We're worried today about publisher Gui Minhai, a Hong Kong citizen who was kidnapped from his apartment in Thailand and smuggled to China. And who then appeared on Chinese state television with a bizarre confession. Four other missing colleagues of his have now been justified. There are many questions, but few or no answers. Where and how is he being held? Did he have access to a lawyer or a visit, and if not, why not? Are Chinese police forces operating against the agreements on Hong Kong territory? We call for clarification and a commitment from the EU to engage in a genuine and clear human rights dialogue with China.

name: Urmas Paet
text: for ALDE. — The European Union's external communication must be clearly based on human rights and international law, and of course also in relations with China. The disappearance of Gui Minhai, a Swedish citizen, is yet another example that the use of free word leads to repression in this country. The European Union has a responsibility to address the subject of human rights consistently in relations with China, both at European Union level and countries in bilateral relations.
