China should ratify the Agreement on Civil and Political Rights and also sign and ratify the International Convention on the Combating Unsolicited Disappearances of All Persons. China wants to be one of the most influential countries in the world. Yes, he has the potential for that, but political and economic influence also comes with responsibility. Responsibility for ensuring human lives and human freedoms and respect for human rights. In order for China to actually harness its potential in the world, it is imperative that respect for human rights also reaches an adequate level in this country.

name: Diane James (NI).
text: – Mr President, Gui Minhai, also known as Michael Gui, is a Chinese—born Swedish scholar and, importantly from my point of view, a Hong Kong—based book publisher. He was a prolific author, and probably still would be but for his current situation, of books regarding Chinese politics and political figures. He went ‘missing’, presumed abducted, 13 months ago. As a British MEP, I am citing his case today given the relationship between the United Kingdom and China following the handover of Hong Kong. Gui Minhai appears – and I emphasise ‘appears’ – to have been the subject of an unlawful rendition by Chinese law enforcers. If so, international law has been violated by his kidnappers. This abduction and that of his colleagues represents enforced disappearance, which violates a range of fundamental human rights. No country has the right to snatch people and then hold them against their will, seemingly with the involvement and connivance of a national government.  I today call upon China to release Gui Minhai and his colleagues and, in doing so, to demonstrate to the world its adherence to human rights legislation. In doing so, China will gain international respect and acclaim for such action. I would be delighted to initiate such appreciation and acknowledgment in this parliamentary chamber as soon as Guy Minhai is released.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE).
text: — Unfortunately, today we must appeal again to China to adhere to basic human rights, fair trial principles and even its own norms applicable to Hong Kong. The case of Swedish citizen Kuei Min-chai, who is still detained unknown where for carrying out legal activities in Hong Kong, reminds us again that in efforts to comply with basic human rights must not be relieved, even in order to improve business relations. This is especially speaking of a country that practices the forced removal of organs from the bodies of prisoners. We must constantly convince China that compliance with its own regulations and international standards is not a manifestation of weakness but, on the contrary, a manifestation of healthy self-esteem and a prerequisite for respect on the part of of the international community.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in January five publishers, critical of the Chinese Government, disappeared into thin air. The history of Hong Kong booksellers began to bounce on sites around the world, arousing outrage and concern. Questions about the fate of the missing booksellers are many. Concerns arouse reports of the Chinese government's arrest of 51-year-old Swedish citizen Gui Minhai, owner of Hong Kong's Mighty Current publishing company. Human rights activists believe Gui Minhai, who has been missing since last October, is in detention because of a book not yet published about the Chinese President's private life. All this happens in an atmosphere of great disquiet. Agnes Chow, one of the most active figures of the Occupy movement, had recorded a video message in which she asked, for these facts, help from the whole world. And it is this appeal, again this time, that I want to turn to the House.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: — Kuej Min-chaj is another citizen of Sweden living in Hong Kong who was kidnapped and is imprisoned unknown where. It is this case and many others that we mention in our resolution. China has committed, in the case of Hong Kong, to respect the principle of one country two systems, including respect for the personal freedoms of the inhabitants. By now, China is positioning itself in the role of an implausible partner for EU countries. I therefore welcome the EP's apel to make the release of Kuei Min-chai and other missing persons a topic in the next official negotiations between the EU and China leaders. China needs to know that we care about human rights, that respect for human rights and transparency is part of modern trade agreements. Adherence to rights and the rule of law is in the interests of our entrepreneurs operating in China as well.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). — (EL) Mr President, China has an open economy, an open market, and this has helped it to develop economic growth. But it must also have an open society. It must respect democracy, freedom, the rule of law and international law. The case we are discussing today of Gui Minhai, who is a Chinese citizen, but also has Swedish citizenship, is shocking because according to the allegations he has disappeared, kidnapped and imprisoned. This raises enormous questions and, at the same time, agony for his fate. I would like to point out that at the beginning of the year thousands of citizens gathered on the streets of Hong Kong, protested at the disappearance of five booksellers and against the attacks that journalists had suffered because they expressed their views. We therefore call for the immediate release of Gui Minhai and ask for detailed information on his whereabouts and his condition.

name: Neven Mimica
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, since his disappearance from Thailand in October 2015, the EU has closely followed the case of the Hong Kong resident and Swedish citizen Gui Minhai, associated with the publishing house Mighty Current. Immediately after he resurfaced, in an attempt to ensure his well-being and whereabouts the Swedish Government started working on his case. In a concerted effort the European Union expressed its concerns about his case to Hong Kong and Chinese authorities at high-level political meetings and through written statements. The head of the EU office to Hong Kong made numerous inquiries to the Chief Executive, Secretary of Justice and Ministry of Foreign Affairs Commissioner. Additionally, the head of the EU delegation to China inquired with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Beijing. Consequently, the EU has seen reports that Sweden succeeded in securing consular access to Mr Gui, who remains in detention in China.  The European Union is not in a position to publicly comment on the consular contacts and the efforts of the Swedish Government. However, given certain aspects of this consular case, most notably Mr Gui’s disappearance from Thailand and his publicly broadcast statement after resurfacing in China, the European Union remains deeply concerned. The European Union finds the practice of public broadcasting of so-called ‘confessions’ by Chinese and EU citizens unacceptable. The European Union believes that this case is a serious challenge to Hong Kong’s Basic Law and the ‘one country, two systems’ principle, as it raises serious concerns about the application of China’s criminal law to acts that are not punishable under Hong Kong law.  Gui Minhai’s case is also part of a worrying trend that calls into question China’s respect for the rule of law and for its international human rights obligations, not least freedom of speech. The European Union expects that Mr Gui will be released immediately after serving his traffic-related crime sentence. The European Union continues to be concerned at the case of Gui Minhai and stands ready to work together with all actors and authorities concerned.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place after the debate. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. – The EU and China are two of the biggest traders in the world. China is EU’s second largest trading partner and world’s second fastest growing economy. Despite its huge economic success, China continues systematically to violate a wide range of fundamental human rights, including freedom of expression, association, assembly, religion and minority rights. The ongoing illegal detention of Mr Gui Minhai (Swedish and EU citizen) is another proof that China continues to criminalise freedom of expression and to target peaceful government critics, anti-corruption activists, lawyers and journalists. Therefore, I call on Chinese authorities to release immediately Mr Minhai and all Chinese citizens who dare to express themselves freely despite repression and intimidation by Chinese authorities. Furthermore, I call on the EU to put preservation and protection of human rights as a top priority in its relations with China.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on the situation of Guarani Kaiowá in the Brazilian state of Mato Grosso do Sul (2016/2991 (RSP).

name: Molly Scott Cato
text: author. – Mr President, it is 20 years since we last debated an urgent resolution on the situation in Brazil so our consideration of the plight of Brazil’s indigenous communities is long overdue. The Brazilian Constitution recognises the right of indigenous peoples to maintain their cultural traditions. The basis of our resolution today is to remind the current Government of Brazil to live up to its clear obligations as enshrined in that Constitution. Our motion is focused on the urgent situation facing the Guarani—Kaiowá in the State of Mato Grosso do Sul. As is the case for all Brazil’s indigenous people, the Guarani—Kaiowá have the right to their ancestral territory guaranteed in the Constitution. But this right in theory is not adequately defended in practice. A full demarcation of their lands is still pending, although it is crucial to their survival. Information from Brazil’s Ministry of Health indicates that, over the past 14 years, at least 400 indigenous people have been assassinated defending their land rights. The interests of large landowners, agribusiness and mining corporations have always taken precedence in Brazil, and armed groups attack and kill indigenous people who legitimately oppose those interests. Far from defending their rights, the state offers such powerful interests impunity. Brazil’s National Indigenous Foundation (FUNAI) is tasked with defending indigenous rights but it has never been adequately resourced, and the current President, who holds his position as the result of a judicial coup, has reduced its funding to the lowest level in the past 10 years. There is wide support in this House for our motion, which strongly condemns the violence perpetrated against the indigenous communities, and calls on the Brazilian authorities to investigate the murders of indigenous people. I would also strongly appeal to my colleagues in the Brazilian Parliament to re-examine constitutional amendment PEC 215, as it threatens the legitimate land rights of indigenous people.

name: Mark Demesmaeker
text: Author. — It is one of the dramas of the history of mankind. All too often indigenous peoples were confronted with injustice and violence in a dramatic way. They were driven out, hunted, persecuted by newcomers or colonists who were looking for fortune or who thought they were bringing civilization. It is not the phenomenon of one country or one continent. It's happened in a lot of places. Unfortunately, we cannot correct historical errors, but we can and must support the indigenous peoples who are struggling to survive today, who are working for recognition and fundamental rights. Like the Guarani-Kaiowà, people who, in the Brazilian state of Mato Grosso do Sul, had to give way to large-scale agriculture. They were so gradually expelled from their habitat. It leads to conflict, unfortunately also to violence. They need protection, a guaranteed habitat and they must be able to invoke their constitutional rights. We're asking the Brazilian government to take responsibility. Brazil, the country that invested so much to organise the Olympic Games, must now also put into practice the Olympic idea of fraternity and guarantee the rights of this beautiful people.

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: Author. — (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, around 51 000 Guaraní live in Brazil today, divided into three groups, including that of the Kaiowá, which means 'people of the forest', which is the largest. It is an intensely spiritual people: for hundreds of years the Guaraní have traveled great distances in search of the ancestral land, seeking immortality and infinite rest. The descendants of our ancestors, in the name of development, now considered sustainable, deprived the Guaraní of their land, and therefore of their reason for life, causing suicides, even among children. We must take action to put an end to the unsustainable development, implemented by giving bribes to politicians and state officials, and the atrocities committed by paramilitaries. We talk about activities financed by unscrupulous speculators and multinationals, including Europeans: anachronistic dams, intensive cultivation and livestock, exploitation of mining and fossil deposits are leading to the death by starvation of hundreds of Guaraní children and the extinction of our guardians of biodiversity, of the first human race, the most important, the most sustainable. We hope that the High Representative will claim the countries hosted by the Indios people the demarcation of lands considered ancestral.

name: Sofia Ribeiro
text: Author. — (PT) Mr President, our position is very clear: we would prefer the European Parliament not to follow this path. He's unfair and counterproductive. The Brazilian authorities, in recent decades, with governments of various political colours, have made tremendous progress in protecting human rights on all fronts and, in particular, in the defense of indigenous peoples and also the Guarani-Kaiowá people. It is enough to know Brazil's detailed response to the UN Special Rapporteur's report, a response which, apparently, many parliamentarians are unaware of. No one denies that there is a human rights problem here and that we need to do more and better, but it is not a problem that justifies this position which, I quote, is extremely condemned. This situation has nothing to do with others we have here, and well, condemned. We have made our contribution to addressing the issue on the strict ground of human rights. If so, we will support the motion with reservations, but if it wins the radical version and the mentions of Brazil's domestic policy, which we see in the original text and especially in amendments, we cannot endorse it. Colleagues, this is not the kind of help the Guarani-Kaiowá people need. I hope Parliament will understand that in time.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Thank you! Mr Benito Ziluaga, you have time to speak yourself. That's why there's no “blue card”. You're next on the list. Yeah, I know. But if you have speaking time, then we usually don't.

name: Francisco Assis
text: Author. — (PT) Mr President, the Guarani-Kaiowá of Mato Grosso do Sul do not have enough land to provide for their livelihoods and the existing indigenous reserves are overcrowded. This leads to living in conditions of great poverty, often in precarious camps along motorways. This situation is aggravated by the fact that, in recent years, the demarcation of new indigenous territories has been paralysed. Despair leads the Guarani to try to reoccupy ancestral territories that have not yet been approved by the authorities. It is especially in these attempts at reoccupation that they are on a collision course with interests linked to agribusiness and the extraction of raw materials, suffering reprisals by private and mercenary security guards. Many end up murdered, others are victims of sexual abuse, forced evictions and other forms of violence. According to several entities, including the Indigenous Missionary Council and the UN Special Envoy for the Rights of Indigenous Peoples, there has been an increase in violence against Guarani in recent years and a regression in the protection of their human rights. According to a report by the Indigenous Missionary Council, 33 indigenous people were murdered in 2015 alone in Mato Grosso do Sul. In the light of this scenario, I will conclude now, this resolution calls on the Brazilian authorities to take urgent measures to protect the physical integrity of the Guarani-Kaiowá, to properly guarantee their constitutional rights and to conclude pending demarcation processes, which are absolutely fundamental to safeguarding their legitimate interests.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga
text: Author. — Mr President, the situation of the Guaraní-Kaiowá indigenous community in Brazil is dramatic: four hundred murders since 2003. That is why it was urgent for this European Parliament to take a decision. Guaraníes-kaiowá do not die of old or rare diseases, but are murdered. And I say well, they're murdered. Who murders? Multinational corporations that constantly violate human rights. Their ancestral lands, to which they are entitled under Brazilian international and national legislation, are ultimately occupied by the soy industry, a soy industry and European multinationals. And how do they do it? Through impunity — the Brazilian authorities do not commit to the delimitation of their land — and also through increased repression by illegitimate President Temer towards social movements, students, the trade union movement Sin Tierra. And if anyone dared to stand in Temer's antisocial reforms to the Brazilian Constitution, you're assaulted with gunshots. But for the European Union and for the People's Party, Brazil is now opening up to the world and to the free trade business.

name: António Marinho e Pinto
text: Author. — (PT) Mr President, my first idea is that this motion is not a gesture of hostility towards the government of Brazil. It aims above all to encourage the authorities of this country to put an end to a situation that shocks the international community and, I am sure, Brazilian society itself. It is not possible that in a country that has one of the most progressive legal orders in the world in the field of human rights, see Article 5 of the Brazilian Constitution, acts that recall the worst moments of Portuguese and Spanish colonialism in Latin America can be practiced. Physical violence against an indigenous community fighting for its ancestral lands, in addition to an unspeakable violation of human rights, suggests that there can be far more serious crimes, that is, ethnic crimes against a people, which the international community condemns severely. Brazil is an immense country that has enough land for all Brazilians. Share it with respect for the law.

name: Stanislav Polčák
text: for the PPE Group. — According to the United Nations Special Rapporteur on Indigenous Rights, virtually no greater progress has been seen during the past 8 years in implementing UN recommendations on key solutions to the long-lasting problem of the rights of indigenous peoples in Brazil. On the contrary, we observe a retreat from protecting these rights We are reminded that the Federal Brazilian Ministry has signed clear concrete commitments along with the National Foundation for the Support of Indigenous People. Among other things, to demarcate 36 territories of the Guaraní-Kaiowá Community in Mato Grosso Do Sul until 2009. That goal has not yet been met. Conversely, we are watching the violence we are witnessing in recent times that is escalating dramatically. The partnership between the EU and Brazil is built on mutual trust and respect for democratic principles and values, among which the protection of human rights is staunchly. We should remind the representatives of Brazil unequivocally of this.

name: Carlos Zorrinho
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (PT) Mr President, as Vice-President of the Parliamentary Delegation for Relations between the European Union and Brazil, I have on several occasions been confronted and contacted by the Guarani-Kaiowá Indians. The life context to which those indigenous peoples have been subjected to is untenable. The Brazilian authorities cannot fail to take into account the recommendations included in the resolution under discussion, promoting respect for the most elementary human rights and respecting the identity and dignity of Indians in the current constitutional framework. The constitutional framework must not be changed so as not to allow the forces and economic interests, which dispute indigenous people for the power of demarcation of land, the abuse of the law to block decisions in favour of the claims of their millennial occupants. As a great multicultural and multi-racial nation, the Federative Republic of Brazil must guarantee indigenous peoples their rights within the framework of the democratic process, while fulfilling, at the same time, the commitments to the Millennium Goals and with the sustainability goals set out in the Paris Agreement.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (FR) Mr President, the Guarani-Kaiowá people are one of the symbols of the struggle of indigenous peoples. For decades, they have been fighting against the spoliation of their ancestral lands and have paid it at a high price. The demarcation of their territory recognized in 1988 is still not a reality. Amazonian lands attract a lot of appetite. Deforestation, land grabbing for the benefit of agri-food, energy, forestry and mining industries, intensive farming and huge dams have destroyed one-third of the Amazon forest. While they are a bulwark against climate change, they are the first victims of it via the frenzy on agrofuels. The European Union is an important trading partner of Brazil — its first partner — and therefore has responsibilities. It cannot turn a blind eye to the human and environmental costs of the policies it promotes and the products it imports, nor can it clear itself of the responsibility of European multinationals. It's time to act.

name: Josef Weidenholzer
text: Mr President, on behalf of the S&D Group. One of the most elementary human rights is the right to live in accordance with traditional customs in its ancestral settlements. This right is denied to Indogenous peoples in many parts of the world, despite the fact that their rights are guaranteed by international treaties and states have undertaken to comply with them. Time and again they become victims of short-sighted, mostly economic interests. People who oppose it, rebel, are persecuted, threatened, killed, as in Brazil in the specific case of the Guarani Kaiowá in the state of Mato Grosso. Brazil is an important partner and ally of Europe. We therefore expect Brazil in particular to stand by its obligations in practice and to do everything it can to protect people's rights.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, at the time of the discovery, the territory that now corresponds to the Brazilian was inhabited by about 2 to 5 million Indians. Since then, the indigenous population has declined dramatically in the same proportion as their rights have been withdrawn, on the pretext of assimilating a culture that is not, and has never been, theirs and whose only reason is the greed of vast territories belonging to these populations. This reality is clearly visible in the State of Mato Grosso do Sul, which leads the number of murders of Indians in the country, which take place with impunity in the beards of the Brazilian authorities. Ladies and gentlemen, as proposals for amendments to the Brazilian Constitution are approved, which aim to change the rules for the demarcation of indigenous lands and also make it possible to revise indigenous lands already demarcated, the Brazilian Indian once again sees its rights as a millennial nation threatened. Dear colleagues, we must remind the Brazilian government of this sad reality and reexamine the proposals for amendments to the Brazilian Constitution, reminding the Brazilian ethnologist and defender of the indigenous cause Darcy Ribeiro who said “the Brazilian nation will never exist, in dignity and shame, if it lets the few die Indians who still survive.”

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL).
text: — Mr President, with the expansion of soya and sugarcane monocultures, the indigenous Guarani-Kaiowá people have been relegated to very limited areas. He suffers extreme poverty and has no access to land. The government's commitment to demarcate its 36 territories has not been achieved and attacks on this community continue. After the coup against President Dilma Rousseff, criminalization, repression and violence against community leaders, native peoples and social movements increased. In the context of this repression of the popular movement throughout Brazil, I would also like to bring here the case of the Landless Movement, criminalized and repressed by its tireless struggle for land reform, social justice and against agribusiness violence. I want to highlight the invasion, on November 4th, by the police, of the Florestan Fernandes National School in São Paulo, without a judicial mandate and shooting at MST students and militants. I would like to ask the European Union to draw attention to Brazil to the imperative need to end repression, criminalisation and demand respect for human rights.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). — Mr President, the Guarani-Kaiowá are indigenous people who have been living in Brazil for many centuries and indeed in the state of Mato Grosso. They have already developed a serious movement because they are claiming to remain on their ancestral lands, which have been transformed into industrialized agriculture by the numerous multinationals that have settled there, including European multinationals. They therefore force the Guarani-Kaiowá to be trapped in poor settlements and work under inhumane conditions. According to data from the Brazilian Ministry of Health, for 14 years we have had indigenous murders, at least 400, and 700 supposedly suicides. At the same time there are constant attacks against them. Therefore, there must be recognition of the territorial rights of Guarani-Kaiowá.

name: Neven Mimica
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, the European Union follows closely the situation of indigenous people’s rights in Brazil. Together with Member States’ embassies, the European Union is in regular contact with the Brazilian authorities, as well as with indigenous people’s representatives and civil society. The EU also implements several projects in support of indigenous people in Brazil. Although the Brazilian Constitution establishes an exemplary framework for indigenous people’s rights, and a series of measures has been taken to implement and protect those rights, access to basic social services, especially in certain parts of the country, remains problematic, as does violence in the context of land disputes. This was highlighted in the report by the UN Special Rapporteur on the rights of indigenous peoples on her mission to Brazil. Indigenous people’s rights are regularly discussed in the framework of the EU-Brazil Human Rights Dialogue, including at the last dialogue, co-chaired by the EU Special Representative for Human Rights, Mr Lambrinidis, in September 2015. The EU has called for enhanced efforts to ensure the protection of indigenous peoples, such as the Guarani-Kaiowá, and their representatives, and for the effective investigation of murders and other crimes against them. Our cooperation on human rights will also be on the agenda of the next high-level political dialogue in Brasilia on 25 November 2016, which is tomorrow. In the context of the EU’s work on human rights, the EU delegation in Brazil, together with EU Member States’ embassies, organises regular visits to various regions in Brazil to get first-hand information on the situation of indigenous people. The last visit, in April 2016, was to Campogrande, in the State of Mato Grosso do Sul, to the Guarani-Kaiowá community. The EU implements several projects, to a total value of EUR 2.5 million, in support of the human rights of indigenous peoples in Brazil. These projects offer legal aid, education on human rights and indigenous people’s rights, access to basic social services, support for the autonomy of indigenous peoples and support to their leaders, including those of the Guarani-Kaiowá people. To conclude, let me assure you that the European Union will continue to support indigenous people’s rights in Brazil, using all the available channels in its bilateral relations with Brazil.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place after the debate.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on six motions for resolutions on the case of non-violent political prisoner Ildar Dadin in Russia (2016/2992 (RSP). Mrs Hautala is not present here as the author at the moment. I would therefore perhaps ask Mr Demesmaeker to be the first to speak for two minutes. He is also the author — so that would be helpful.

name: Mark Demesmaeker
text: Author. — “I am not afraid to die. Above all, I fear that I can no longer bear the torture”. Let those words penetrate to you, Commissioner. Dramatic words with which Ildar Dadin from prison number 7 in Karelia, north-west Russia, concludes a letter to his wife. He was sentenced to two and a half years in prison for criticizing the Putin regime and organizing street protests. He was severely abused, like so many other political and conscientious prisoners in Russia and in occupied territories, such as the Ukrainian Crimea. By the way, it is striking and unusual that his story even made the news on Russian state television. The Kremlin promised to investigate the case. We'll see. We explicitly mention the name of Ildar Dadin today, and we ask for his release. But we do not forget that he is one of the many victims of a series of special laws by which the Kremlin wants to stifle all opposition, paralyze civil society and restrict freedom of expression. The law on unwanted organisations, the demonstration law, the law on homosexual paganda among minors, the law on foreign agents, the slander law, the high treason law, the blasphemy law, the Internet law, the anti-Magnitski law, and so on. It is particularly cynical and disturbing that Russia has simply legalised human rights violations. We want Russia to become a real and reliable partner again, and most Russians want the same thing. And that will also happen if the Kremlin refulfils its international obligations. That is why the European Union must continue to send the message to Moscow with one voice that respect for human rights and international law is a prerequisite. In order to support that message, we must take targeted sanctions against those responsible for the abuse of Ildar Dadin and other human rights activists, journalists or opponents.

name: Heidi Hautala
text: author. — Mr President, Ildar Dadin's case is yet another example of how Russian laws oppress peaceful civic activities. Indeed, it is shocking that he has received a sentence of three years in the penal institution for such a one-person demonstration — which, as far as I am aware, are still permissible in Russia. It is perfectly placed that the European Parliament again reminds Russia that the legislation under which civic actors are punished in this way is unacceptable, and it does not comply with any international standards, nor does it comply with the Council of Europe standards. Secondly, the case of Ildar Dadin highlights the extremely disturbing nature of prison conditions and conditions in penal institutions in Russia. I would like to see the Russian prison authorities and, for example, the authorities of the Republic of Karelia in question in this case, come to Finland, just across the border, to get to know what kind of way we have in prisons. Of course, it is the case that prisons can also commit further human rights violations if prisoners are denied the right, for example, to meet their relatives or lawyers, and if torture and other inhumane treatment are also carried out as in this case. Indeed, Russia's prison conditions are such that they are a major human rights issue.

name: Jaromír Štětina
text: Author. — The case of Ildar Dadin symbolizes for me 3 fundamental issues of today's Russia: the flagrant trampling of the right to peaceful assembly, the alarming state of the judiciary and prison, including inhuman treatment and torture, cases of those arrested on false or baseless charges or because they were exercising their right to free speech and assembly. Ildar Dadin is the first citizen of the Russian Federation to be deprived of his liberty under the scandalous Article 212.1 of the Penal Law adopted by the Russian Duma in 2014. It's an article according to which anyone who participates in peaceful public protests can be put into prison for up to 5 years, even one who peacefully holds a protest poster in public. This article thus pregnantly violates even the Constitution of the Russian Federation itself. If it continues to apply, it may set off an avalanche of repression against the otherwise minded. Thus, the case of Ildar Dadin becomes a new symbol of trampling on human rights in Russia.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri
text: Author. — (IT) (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Ildar Dadin was sentenced by the Moscow Court on 7 December 2015 to almost three years in prison for demonstrating his dissent against the streets. government. He complained last month that he was subjected to mistreatment and beatings, and even forms of torture, by correctional staff. And despite the ECHR having taken note of the request made through its lawyer and imposed on the Russian Federation to launch an effective investigation in this regard, Dadin was transferred to a different location and a few days ago he was denied the chance to meet his lawyer. Dadin's case is not isolated but goes alongside similar criminal proceedings, opened by the Russian authorities, such as the case of Vladimir Ionov, convicted of criticizing Russia's recent policy in Eastern Ukraine. The European Union must, of course, keep the official channels for an inclusive and constructive dialogue with Moscow open, and it must speak with one voice, demanding full respect for international law and rights binding Russia as a member of several international bodies.

name: Petras Auštrevičius
text: author. –  Mr President, Commissioner, colleagues, Ildar Dadin is a courageous citizen of Russia, has been repeatedly tortured, beaten and threatened with murder in a Russian jail. For what? For holding a banner saying, I quote: ‘if you keep silence today they will come to you tomorrow and others will keep silence’. Ildar Dadin is the first person in Russia sentenced under the new Article 212.1. Now peaceful protest will bring up to five years in jail. There are 102 political prisoners today in Russia, with this draconian law in place, how many will there be tomorrow? Colleagues, to keep power, Putin chose to withdraw from the civilised community of the rule of law, like the Rome Statute of ICC, just recently. Moscow no longer obeys the rulings of the European Court of Human Rights. I call on Russia to repeal Article 212.1 and immediately release Mr Ildar Dadin.

name: Cristian Dan Preda
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — Mr President, as my colleagues have said, Ildar Dadin is a Russian citizen who has been protesting since the 2011 legislative elections against the way politics is done in Russia. She was arrested for allowing herself to go before the Moscow Secret Police. The painting seems taken out of the times of the USSR and not from a normal country. She's being tortured right now in prison, and the authorities have admitted that fact, they haven't been hiding. It's absolutely unacceptable. Unfortunately, with this regime, some of the European parties want, and I saw in the debate that we had a few days ago on the Fotyga report, normalise relations. It is absolutely unacceptable what the far left and the far right want to do in the contempt of freedoms.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — Mr President! Once again at the European Parliament we discuss the situation in Russia, especially in the context of the crackdown on activists criticising authorities. Ildar Dadin was convicted of taking part in peaceful demonstrations, including against Russian aggression in Ukraine and defending political prisoners. Last December, he was convicted of repeatedly violating public assembly rules to three years' imprisonment. Through the convict's lawyer, we now learn about beatings and torture taking place against those convicted in the penal colony in Siegha, Karelia, where Ildar Dadin is staying. As a member of many international organizations, such as the Council of Europe and the UN, Russia is committed to protecting and promoting human rights, fundamental freedoms and the rule of law. In this context, we call on the Russian authorities to conduct a thorough investigation without delay into allegations of inhumane treatment in the abovementioned penitentiary unit. In addition, we call on authorities in the Kremlin to continue and deepen reform of the penitentiary system and the penal code to implement standards set by international conventions.

name: Monica Macovei
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — It has been a thousand days since Russia annexed the Crimea. In the Kremlin, Putin courts the last dictator, the president of Belarus, Lukashenko. In parallel, he is planning the establishment of a common army together with the separatist region of Abkhazia. We are now talking about the closure and torture of the opposition leader for organizing demonstrations, demonstrations for peace, democracy and anti-war, a man who is in prison and who is being tortured, Ildar Dadin. Of course, we ask for the immediate release of Ildar Dadin, but we need to think about talking about the Soviet system, the Russian system, because it's still Soviet, and what Putin wants. Little what he does is take the lead, be someone and take the lead in the world we live in. He started down this road and will not stop. At the Kremlin people's lives don't matter anymore.

name: Marietje Schaake
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, with all the focus needed to stop Russia’s army and its role in the killing of people in Syria or in the illegal annexation of Crimea, I am glad that the Russian population is at the heart of our debate today.  Ildar Dadin faces the same repression so many Russians face on top of difficult economic circumstances. In particular, opposition voices, human rights defenders, people working in NGOs and civil society, journalists and bloggers have faced stricter laws increasingly applied with political motives in Russia. This has created a climate of fear and repression. Of course, we recall the murder of Boris Nemtsov, the systematic torture in prisons and intimidation that is met with impunity.  Prison conditions are awful. The murder of Sergei Magnitsky shows that people are not safe in the hands of the State. It is important that Ildar Dadin is released, and we urge Putin to lead Russia, not away from the rule of law, but back towards respecting it, back in the direction of the international community.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Ildar Dadin is sentenced for illegal demonstration for the first time in situations which were indeed not respectable. Russian police are condemned by the Russian authorities. He reoffends and goes to jail. On 2 November 2016, he was examined by a medical commission of the Segueja District Hospital, which found that there had been no abuse. On 12 November 2016, the Russian service of the BBC, at the request of human rights organizations, informed about Dr. Vasily Generalov's examination of Mr. Dadin. Again, we see that he is not abused. I would like to recall, at the same time, what has happened in my country. For organizing a legal protest against same-sex marriage, for wearing the T-shirt, some found themselves in jail. For demonstrating for a month, some also found themselves in jail. This is the case of Nicolas Buss. I hope that my country will also be condemned in this case!

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE).
text: — The Russian Federation is a state that does not comply with international law and does not respect either its own right or modify its own right as if it were not a right, but only an instrument empowering the state authorities for arbitrarily dealing with their own citizens. I personally lived in totalitarianism under the domination of the Russians, so I know what I'm talking about. The case of Ildar Dadin and other political prisoners who are imprisoned and tortured for daring to express their opinion freely is proof of this. A state which in the 21st century systematically tortures its own citizens while also being a member of the Council of Europe and a signatory to the Convention on the Protection of Human Rights is not a credible partner in international relations and the EU should make it clear to him.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: — Ildar Dadin stood on the pavement holding a transparent in his hand. I don't know what he really could have committed against Russian law if Article 31 of the Russian Constitution says “Citizens have the right to peacefully assemble without arms, hold rallies, meetings and demonstrations, marches.” According to Article 29 (1) of the Russian Constitution, everyone must be guaranteed freedom of ideas and expression. Pursuant to paragraph 4, everyone has the right to freely search and receive, produce, disseminate information in any lawful manner. I really have no idea how Mr Dadin can be held in prison in this situation. I am very pleased that the Council of Europe and its court have taken this case as one of the priorities and will be hearing it. We should find some connection to the Committee of Ministers of the Council of Europe in the framework of our EU policies, so that their decisions are respected by Russia as well.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: — I am very happy to discuss Mr. Dadin's story here today at the plenary. I am from the Czech Republic, Central Europe, where there is a very open debate in the public area about how much the Russian regime is accepting and how much it is not acceptable. This particular story shows what the Russian regime is really like. It sets the face of all those still adoring and defending the ideas of the Russian regime and Mr Putin's regime in former post-communist states. Dadin is the story of how in Russia not only is freedom of assembly, freedom of expression restricted, but if you gather there and express your opinions, not only is it forbidden, but you will go yet to jail for several years. They'll torture you in that prison. It's really a case that shows the monstrosity of the Putin regime. It's a good thing he's here today, it needs to be said in our countries, where unfortunately at times various propaganda forces relativise Putin's regime. Everything needs to be done to get Dadin out of prison.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Ildar Dadin is a Russian activist, the first to have been convicted of violating the rules on public demonstrations. Dadin, 34, had been tried in December 2015 and sentenced to two and a half years in detention. The ruling had caused great clamour. The case was later reignited after an NGO reported that the activist had been violently battered in jail. Dadin himself complained in a letter, made known by his lawyer, that he had suffered violence. The case sparked outrage not only in Russia: Amnesty International, Human Rights Watch and Nobel Literature Prize laureate Aleksievič launched an appeal for Dadin's release and called for a immediate inquiry into allegations of torture. A call with which Europe and the whole international community should also be associated. Despite the joint work carried out by the Council of Europe and the Russian Federation to reform the Russian penitentiary system, we still have to go a long way for them to be fully in this country respected civil rights.

name: Neven Mimica
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the European Union watches with grave unease the developments in the Ildar Dadin case. Mr Dadin, who is serving a two-and-a-half-year prison term in the Russian Federation for peaceful acts of protests, has allegedly been tortured and mistreated in prison. He described being subjected to appalling instances of torture, including being suspended for long periods of time and being threatened with rape and murder. The European Union has been vocal about its concern with this case. We have raised this issue at high-level political meetings with the Russian authorities, and through a statement at the OSCE Permanent Council on 10 November. Torture is a detestable violation of human rights and its universal prohibition is absolute and unconditional. The case of Mr Dadin has rightly received attention in Russia and internationally. We welcome the initial steps the Russian authorities have taken to investigate the claims, while continuing to urge the Russian authorities to carry out a swift, thorough and impartial investigation of Mr Dadin’s torture allegation. We are disturbed by frequent reports of torture in Russian prisons, and we believe that steps need to be taken to eliminate the use of torture and other ill-treatment in Russian penitentiary facilities. In this regard, we are worried to learn that there have been attempts to weaken the existing oversight mechanisms, the public monitoring commissions, in charge of investigating claims of abuse in prison.  The European Union will continue to monitor this case. We call on the Russian authorities to release Mr Dadin and to review the law on public assemblies that has been used to send him to prison. Indeed, this law, which criminalises anyone found to have violated it more than twice within 180 days, is not in line with Russia’s international obligations. Mr Dadin’s case is another worrying example of the ongoing restrictions on fundamental freedoms and civil society by the Russian authorities. We urge Russia to ensure an open and safe environment for civil society activity and peaceful dissent.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place after the debate. (The session will be suspended for a few minutes.)

name: President. –
text: The next item is the vote. (For the results and other details of the vote: see Minutes).

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I just want to really thank all the co-authors. We have today joined forces across political groups to give a voice to the many, many women that are victims of violence in Europe. Thank you. (Applause)

name: Νότης Μαριάς
text: rapporteur. — Madam President, I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs for the cooperation we have had. I would also like to thank the House for the large majority with which it adopted the resolution, which now gives great strength to the European Ombudsman, to continue to fight for greater transparency in favour of European citizens.

name: President. –
text: That concludes the vote.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: — I supported this resolution because I believe the need to support Jordan as a country that contributes significantly to stability in the Middle East. It is a country where human rights are respected in principle. It's a country where there are a whole host of refugees. And most importantly, it is an ally of Europe and in general Western democracies, which is why I believe that there is a need to support this country and possibly provide some funding. That is why I supported this proposal and I am pleased that this resolution will also contribute to the partnership between the EU and Jordan.

name: Jan Zahradil (ECR).
text: — I think it's a good thing that this report has been approved. I think Jordan remains kind of in the shadow of other countries affected by the refugee crisis, while itself having to contend with a large onslaught of migrants from Syria. I think the EU has and needs to make clear in this way that it will look after Jordan and that in some way it reflects on the ineasy situation that has formed there. So even this macro-financial aid is one such step. I think we should reflect that Jordan is one of the countries in the region that we can still consider an ally, that it is a country that exhibits political stability in which they are suppressed elements of religious radical Islamic fundamentalism, and that it is a country whose politicians, especially the head of state, enjoy great respect abroad. That is why I am pleased that this report has passed, and I have, of course, supported it.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: – Mr President, certainly Jordan is a beleaguered state struggling in a difficult neighbourhood. I wonder though whether we shouldn’t look at the origins of a lot of the problems in that region. It is a hundred years since the Sykes—Picot Agreement and the creation of states which were effectively synthetic. Reality has imposed itself in Iraq in the sense that there is now, to all intents and purposes, an autonomous Kurdish entity, and something very similar is happening in Syria. How long before the de jure recognition of the world follows the de facto lines on the ground? It is bizarre that we remain wedded to this idea that multi-ethnic states must be superior to what people democratically choose for themselves on the ground.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: — Jordan is indeed a country that needs our support. I think they fully deserve it, and I am pleased to have been able to support this resolution. Jordan is a country that lies in the shadow of those events, but by just being linked to the shadow of events in the Middle East, all the effects and events that are in place occurs. It should be very important for us to support this country because it honors human rights, we don't have reports of violations of fundamental rights there. For this reason, I believe that it actually fulfils all the attributes for allowing EU support to be granted, and I was therefore happy to support it.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ Since 2011, the Union has allocated more than EUR 500 million to Jordan under the guise of bilateral cooperation programmes under the auspices of the European Neighbourhood Policy. Even so, in June the European Commission proposed an additional €200m in the form of macro financial assistance (MFA). Jordan is one of the countries that has most suffered negative effects from the Syrian crisis, witnessing a reduction in tourism, foreign investment, as well as having suffered the blocking of trade routes and various disturbances imposed by Egypt concerning access to natural gas. Economic growth consequently slowed by 2.4% in 2015 and unemployment reached an alarming rate of 14.6% in 2016. In addition to the economic crisis, the situation in Syria has led to a high migration flow to Jordan: to date there are in fact more than 650 thousand Syrian refugees in the Jordanian urban centers, which subject the Jordanian administration to significant efforts in transport, health and education. Although I am aware that these funds are borne by the national authorities of the target States, with the consequent requirements of control, I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The 'macro-financial aid' to Jordan is nothing other than the Union's intermediation in a private credit of up to EUR 350 million as a counterpart to an IMF adjustment programme, which will impose further cuts on labour rights and the public budget of Jordan's fragile economy. I believe that the imposition of new neoliberal policies will only increase instability in the region politically. That is why I voted against.

name: Martina Anderson Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This report calls on the EU to provide support to Jordan to help it deal with the significant effects of the conflict in Syria and Iraq on its economy. Jordan’s economy has suffered from losses of its natural export market and trade routes, lower levels of tourism and direct foreign investment, and has welcomed a huge number of refugees from the neighbouring conflicts. The EU has already granted Jordan EUR 180 million in Macro-Financial Assistance (MFA). In February, the international community pledged to undertake a comprehensive support plan for Jordan, and the EU pledged EUR 2.39 billion, including a EUR 200 million loan, for a second MFA operation under the EU-Jordan Compact. Sinn Féin fully supports providing assistance to the Jordanian economy, especially given the burden it has taken in helping refugees, but the MFA is linked to IMF loans and programmes that impose a neoliberal agenda and ‘structural reforms’ – in other words, austerity. It requires Jordan to sign a Memorandum of Understanding to implement these IMF neoliberal reforms. For this reason, and because the EU could easily have provided this assistance under other programmes, including the European Neighbourhood Initiative, we abstained on the final vote.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this text and I would like to congratulate my colleague Emmanuel Maurel on the quality of this report. We must provide Jordan with the most effective assistance possible, as soon as possible, recognizing its role in the refugee crisis and as a long-standing reliable partner of the European Union.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on macro-financial assistance to Jordan. Due to its geographical location, Jordan is one of the most affected countries of the Syrian crisis. Since 2011, its economy, mainly based on services and industry, has been heavily affected by the unrest affecting the region. Reduced flows of tourists and foreign direct investment, blocked trade routes and constant disruptions in the supply of natural gas from Egypt hamper the economic growth of Jordanian economy and negatively affect the country's budget. However, even in such difficult conditions, Jordan is characterised by the fact that, together with Lebanon, it is the host country in the world of the largest number of refugees compared to its population, and it has committed to facilitating access to employment for Syria — 650 000 Syrians are currently registered as refugees, and the Jordanian authorities mention as many as 1.4 million refugees on its territory. The total number of non-Jordanian citizens living in the country has doubled over five years. Most of them live in cities, which is why Jordan's public services sector is under great pressure, particularly in the field of health and education. Jordanian debt amounted to 93.4% of its GDP at the end of 2015. I agree with the rapporteur that, in the face of Jordan's economic difficulties, the European Union must demonstrate that it supports its partner, whose refugee reception policy respects. It is important that the macro-financial assistance be launched immediately so that Jordan can benefit from it at this critical time.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council providing further macro-financial assistance to the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan, as Jordan is a credible partner of the European Union having play a key role in tackling the refugee crisis.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: Jordan and its economy are affected by the war in Syria: falling tourism, foreign investment, blocking trade routes, problems importing gas from Egypt, slowing growth and weighing on the budget. Jordan suffered an influx of 1.3 million Syrian refugees. The fee would be $6.6 billion since 2011. Despite the establishment of an adjustment programme with the IMF and a loan of $2 billion, problems persist. The Commission proposes to the European Parliament a loan of EUR 200 million over the medium term. These loans will help Jordan deal with Syrian refugees, which is legitimate for a country that takes a large share of the burden in the migration crisis. However, the IMF and the EU are calling for structural adjustments. The Jordanian economy is in serious financing difficulties, but nevertheless needs this assistance. These loans are subject to the establishment of rules imposed from the outside in contradiction with the current state of Jordanian society. If these rules are applied too rigorously and without measure, this is potentially dangerous to the stability of that country. So I abstained.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution as I do not believe that British taxpayers’ money should be used to fund Jordan through EU institutions.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this macro-financial assistance because Jordan is one of the countries hardest hit by the crisis. Its economy has been heavily impacted by tensions at the regional level. Despite this, Jordan is distinguished by the hosting of a very large number of displaced populations. In fact, the European Union must show its support for this State in response to its reception policy.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: in writing. - I do not object to the provision of macro-financial assistance to Jordan; on the other hand, the assumptions and conditions laid down are not the right ones.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report, which proposes that the Union make available to Jordan macro-financial assistance of up to EUR 350 million. Jordan, faced with a decline in economic growth in particular as a result of the conflicts in Iraq and Syria, is home to hundreds of thousands of Syrian refugees and substantial assistance should be given to help it in this considerable effort.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of the Mauriel report on macro-financial assistance for Jordan. Because of its geographical position, the Arab country has been suffering from the backlash of the Syrian crisis and instability in the entire region since 2011, events that have caused in addition to major challenges linked to humanitarian aid, major economic losses, especially in the tourism and foreign investment sector. Today Jordan is a host country hosting 650 000 Syrians officially registered within its borders, although the Jordanian authorities declare the presence in the territory of more than 1.4 million refugees. These are huge figures, especially in relation to the total population of the country, which pose a considerable challenge to the very public services that the state today finds itself offering in conditions completely mutated. Public debt reached 93.4% of GDP in 2015 and continues to rise. In this context, the European Union has a duty to economically support Jordan, a key partner in the Middle East which is progressing in affirming democratic principles and which demonstrates a generous and meritorious commitment with its policy of welcoming refugees.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted abstention because the initiative itself seems positive and necessary, but it has been approached from an angle which makes it very unlikely to achieve its objectives, and which implies a significant risk that aid will indeed have a counterproductive effect. The aim of this aid is to provide an oxygen balloon to Jordan in view of the fact that its economy has been one of the major victims of the war in Syria. The decline in income, coupled with the massive influx of refugees, has contributed to a significant increase in external debt. Hence the macro-financial aid initiative we have voted on. The reason why I doubt whether this aid will provide real support for the Jordanian economy and society is that the instrument is linked to IMF lending programmes which, as a condition, impose the implementation of neo-liberal structural reforms. These reforms, together with a possible increase in debt, can have long-term negative consequences and were not the best available option.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I would like to thank Mr Maurel for his work on this report on macro-financial assistance to Jordan. It is one of the countries most directly affected by the Syrian crisis, and recently we have established an increasingly close partnership with the Hashemite country. At the Donors' Conference, which took place on 4 February in London, the international community pledged to implement a genuine global support plan for London, and I think it pertinent to vote in favour of this report.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: I preferred to abstain on the vote in favour of granting macro-financial assistance to Jordan, which has been and remains greatly affected by the war in Syria. It should be recalled that Jordan has already hosted more than 1.3 million Syrian refugees, representing a financial burden of $6.6 billion since 2011. With unemployment at 14.6%, a budget deficit of 3.5%, as well as a current account deficit of 11.7% of GDP, Jordan is also experiencing a full decline in tourism, foreign investment and problems of importing gas from Egypt. The €200 million loan proposed by the European Commission seems to me, in these circumstances, legitimate, especially since Jordan is taking more than its part in the management of Syrian refugees. However, I am concerned about the conditions set by the IMF and the European Union for Jordan for receiving financial assistance. Once again, it is the blackmail race for structural reforms, as if the European Union could not accept that there could still be other models of political and economic organisation.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: In writing. ‒ This intervention is intended to provide in the form of a loan, macro-financial assistance to Jordan. Despite the reassurances of the European Commission, I believe that all the monitoring instruments at our disposal should be put in place to monitor the correct and transparent use of the loan dispensed. However, given Jordan's commitment to the fight against ISIS and the fact that it is in the front row in assisting Syrian refugees, despite not having enjoyed favourable treatment from the EU as it is I have been for Turkey with much greater amounts, I wanted to support this text in my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report providing macro-financial assistance to Jordan. The Union has long maintained prosperous relations with Jordan and the effort it is making in providing shelter and assistance to people coming from Syria must be recognized. Since the beginning of 2011, Jordan's economy has been severely deteriorated by a sharp loss of income and the decline in foreign investment, further exacerbated by events in Syria. It was therefore necessary to provide assistance to Jordan as quickly and effectively as possible to alleviate its economic situation.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report because Parliament expressed its position on further provision of macro-financial assistance to the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan. Due to its geographical location, Jordan is one of the countries most affected by the Syrian crisis. Since 2011, its economy, mainly based on services and industry, has been most exposed to unrest affecting the region. The reduced flow of tourists and foreign direct investment, the blocked trade routes and the constant disruptions in the supply of natural gas from Egypt have prevented Jordan's growth and have had a negative impact on the budgetary situation. The conflict in Syria and Iraq for Jordanian products closes their historical market. In such difficult conditions, Jordan still accepts a large number of displaced people. Together with Lebanon, it is the world's host country of the largest number of refugees compared to its population and has committed itself to facilitating the employability of Syria refugees — 650 000 Syrians are currently registered as refugees, and the Jordanian authorities mention as many as 1.4 million of its the number of refugees in the territory. In order to help Jordan cope with the crisis and cover the residual need for external financing, the European Union has already provided macro-financial assistance and must continue to assist Jordan so that it can cope with the challenges facing it.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: in writing. — Due to its geographical position, Jordan is one of the countries most directly affected by the Syrian crisis. Since 2011, its economy, based primarily on services and industry, has been affected by the war incentives in the region. However, in this difficult situation, Jordan shows that it accepts a significant number of displaced people. Conflicts in Syria and Iraq deprive Jordanian products of their traditional markets. Continuous conflicts in neighbouring countries continued to disturb Jordan's foreign trade in 2015: growth slowed down (2.4%) and the remaining external financing needs for 2016-2017 were estimated at USD 3.2 billion. Extreme high unemployment affects 14.6% of the active population (33% of active youth and 23.7% of active women). In order to overcome economic difficulties, the European Union must provide its support to its partner, whose policy on the reception of refugees is worthy of recognition. The aim is for the macro-financial assistance programme to enter into force as soon as possible so that Jordan can effectively benefit from it during this crucial period. In my opinion, assistance should be provided to those who are actually in need and to the surrounding states in which they are to escape as a result of the war. In the light of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: in writing. - I agree with the macro-financial assistance to Jordan and I also support the aforementioned document, since it is one of the countries most affected by the Syrian crisis by its geographical position. Since 2011, its economy, based primarily on service activities and industry, has been heavily influenced by unrest roaking the region. The decline in tourism and a smaller influx of foreign direct investment, closed trade routes and ongoing disruption to the supply of natural gas from Egypt have rejected growth in Jordan and caused its budget situation to deteriorate. The conflict in Syria and Iraq has been left without markets where it has so far sold its products. It is also facing a refugee flurry, so it is right that we show some solidarity as these are extraordinary circumstances.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: written. - I support this Report which seeks to provide the most effective assistance to Jordan as soon as possible, recognising the role they have played in helping address the refugee crisis and the need to help their economy that is in a difficult situation.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I endorsed this resolution on further macro-financial assistance to Jordan mostly because the Syrian conflict still impacts Jordan’s economy by disrupting trade and causing an inflow of around 1.3 million refugees into the country since the beginning of the war.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: ‒ Jordan is one of the countries most directly affected by the Syrian crisis. Decreased tourism and foreign direct investment, blocking trade routes and disruptions to the flow of natural gas from Egypt have slowed growth, burdening the situation financial, and increased the remaining need for funding. Despite this context, Jordan is notable for welcoming a considerable number of displaced people, who mostly stay in urban surroundings. This puts considerable pressure on Jordanian public services, especially in health and education. In the face of the crisis and to cover the remaining external funding needs, the European Union has already granted Jordan macro-financial assistance of EUR 180 million. As part of the major Donor Conference in London, the international community has committed itself to implementing a genuine comprehensive plan to support Jordan. Promised donations have reached $10 billion. In the face of Jordan's economic difficulties, the EU must show its support for its partner, whose refugee reception policy deserves respect. It is therefore hoped that the macro-financial assistance programme will be effective as soon as possible so that it can concretely benefit Jordan.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. Given its geographical location, Jordan is one of the countries directly affected by the crisis in Syria. Since 2011, its economy, mainly based on services and industry, has been clearly affected by the turmoil that shakes the region. Due to conflicts in Syria and Iraq, Jordanian products are no longer being sold in these traditional markets. In 2015, still unsettled conflicts in neighbouring countries continued to disrupt Jordan's foreign trade. As a result of the crisis and to cover its residual external financing needs, the European Union has already provided EUR 180 billion macro-financial assistance to Jordan (2013 decision, 2015 payments). However, the European Union must continue to help Jordan cope with the challenges it faces. Jordan is engaged in a recent but ever closer partnership with the European Union, which is its second trading partner. Following the Association Agreement, concluded in 1997 and entered into force in 2002, Jordan committed in 2010 to an 'advanced status' partnership with the EU. I voted in favour of this report, given that the European Union must demonstrate support for its partner, whose refugee reception policy requires respect.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the granting of further macro-financial assistance to the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan because we are facing the greatest migration crisis of our time for which an exponential increase in global solidarity is needed. It is necessary to alleviate the burden of countries hosting large numbers of refugees. Jordan is one of the countries that makes a significant contribution compared to the size of its population, 670 thousand settled in refugee camps and one and a half million assimilated in the country. These people need humanitarian help right away. In the face of the economic difficulties which Jordan is exposed, the European Union must demonstrate its support for a partner such as Jordan who is experiencing such a critical moment.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report as given the economic difficulties facing Jordan, the EU must show support to its partner, whose policy of welcoming refugees is commendable. I agree that the macro-financial assistance programme is put into effect as soon as possible in order to provide tangible benefit to Jordan at this critical juncture. Overall, the number of non-Jordanian residents has doubled in five years. The vast majority of them are not in camps but in urban areas, which is putting great pressure on Jordan’s public services, including health and education. Jordan’s debt rose to 93.4% of GDP at the end of 2015. The macro-financial assistance will be provided in the form of loans.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ Jordan, due to its geographical situation, is one of the countries most affected by the Syrian crisis resulting in a reduction of tourism, foreign investment and blockade of trade routes. To date, more than 650 thousand Syrian refugees are registered in the country, all of whom are borne by the Jordanian administration. Economic growth slowed by 2.4% in 2015 with an unemployment rate of 14.6% in 2016. While hesitant about the use of macro financial assistance (MFA) and the effective control of funds on the spot, given the circumstances in which Jordan is located, I voted in favour of allocating funds of the MFA instrument.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: in writing. - We support the report because we believe that, in the face of the economic difficulties facing Jordan, the European Union must support its partner, whose policy of receiving refugees is commendable.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — We voted on the report on the granting of further macro-financial assistance to the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan. Although I agree with the prospect of supporting States in need, I believe that the proposed procedure is unclear and does not guarantee positive results for Jordan. Therefore, I have decided to abstain.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ Given the countless difficulties present both on the practical and human level because of the huge migration flow experienced by my country at this time, I can only vote in favour of the report and express my closeness and gratitude to the Hashemite kingdom of Jordan for its commitment to the refugees welcomed. Jordan, indeed, was not only violently affected by the Syrian crisis, which led to the arrival of 650 thousand refugees (despite unofficial sources speak of 1.4 million people migrated to the kingdom), but, as if that were not enough, since 2011 it is plagued by the decline of tourism and foreign direct investment. Added to this is the blocking of trade trades and repeated disruption to the flow of natural gas from Egypt. Unemployment currently stands at 14% and debt is 93.4% of GDP. Accordingly, the EU will provide a maximum assistance of EUR 350 million for support for economic stabilisation. This fund is conditional on the adoption of structural reforms and the soundness of the public finances including a timetable for their fulfillment. The conditions to be met are negotiated by the Commission and should they not be met, the payment will be suspended or temporarily cancelled.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the Report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council providing further macro-financial assistance to the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: ‒ I voted in favour of this measure because Jordan is one of the countries most directly affected by the Syrian crisis. Since 2011 the Jordanian economy, founded mainly on services and industry, has been significantly suffering the turmoil shaking the region. Despite this critical financial situation, Jordan is standing out for the reception of a considerable number of displaced people. I therefore believe it is correct for the EU to help this country with a loan in order to help it, at this difficult time, to rebalance its balance of payments.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The 'macro-financial aid' to Jordan is nothing other than the Union's intermediation in a private credit of up to EUR 350 million as a counterpart to an IMF adjustment programme, which will impose further cuts on labour rights and the public budget of Jordan's fragile economy. I believe that the imposition of new neoliberal policies will only increase instability in the region politically. That is why I voted against.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Jordan is one of the countries that has suffered most from the effects of the Syrian crisis due to the arrival of Syrian refugees. Since the onset of the Syrian crisis, the Union has allocated almost €1.30 billion to Jordan. However, the Jordanian government stressed that the costs of the emergency were particularly large, due to the impact on the labour market, tourism sector, trade and the school system . In addition to this, the financial support provided so far by the countries of the Gulf Cooperation Council has decreased. Therefore, I voted in favour of this resolution which reaffirms the Union's commitment to supporting Jordan's efforts to address current economic and social problems and to implement the necessary reforms. As a country covered by the European Neighbourhood Policy, Jordan was admitted to receive an additional round of macro-financial assistance from the Union, amounting to EUR 200 million in the form of loans. EU macro-financial assistance aims to restore the sustainability of Jordan's external financial situation and support the country's structural reform programme, in a way complementary to the resources already allocated by the agreement with the IMF to cover balance of payments needs.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. Given its geographical location, Jordan is one of the countries directly affected by the crisis in Syria. Since 2011, its economy, mainly based on services and industry, has been clearly affected by the turmoil that shakes the region. The decline in tourism and foreign direct investment, the blocking of trade routes and the repeated disruptions in the supply of natural gas from Egypt have hampered Jordan's economic growth and have had an impact on its budgetary situation. Over the past five years, the number of foreign residents has doubled. Jordan authorities talk about some 1.4 million Syrian refugees in the country, with public services barely coping with the number of people. I voted for the macro-financial assistance agreement to enter into force as soon as possible, so that Jordan can take advantage of it at these decisive times.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: in writing. — Due to its geographical position, Jordan is one of the countries most directly affected by the Syrian crisis. Since 2011, its economy based primarily on services and industry has been affected by the riots in the region. However, in this difficult situation, Jordan shows that it accepts a significant number of displaced people. Conflicts in Syria and Iraq deprive Jordanian products of their traditional markets. Continuous conflicts in neighbouring countries continued to cause significant disturbances in Jordan's foreign trade in 2015. In the framework of the major donor conference entitled 'Assistance to Syria and the area' held in London on 4 February last year, the international community committed itself to implement a real global plan to support Jordan. The amount of the pledges reached $10 billion. Of this amount, the Union offered EUR 2.39 billion, including a loan of EUR 200 million for the second macro-financial assistance operation to Jordan. In order to overcome economic difficulties, the European Union must provide its support to its partner, whose policy on the reception of refugees is worthy of recognition. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the most effective thing is to provide assistance on the ground to those who are actually in need who are forced to escape as a result of the war and to the surrounding states that host them.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing. — I supported macro-financial assistance to the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan. The continuing conflicts in Jordan's neighbors, in Iraq and Syria, have a very big impact on the country's economy. Negative in effect hostilities leave the Kingdom in poor economic shape.
