Providing support will allow for a priority partnership for the future. The rationale for support for the appropriation is the efforts of the Kingdom of Jordan in terms of migration policies expressed in accepting refugees from Syria, as well as tackling the challenges of providing support to them. It should be emphasised that an important aspect in this case is the creation of instruments to oversee the proper use of funds by the beneficiary State. As a result of the above, I voted yes.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Jordan is playing an important role by assisting in the refugee crisis and is also a long-standing reliable partner to the EU. I am in favour of the report that makes macro financial assistance (MFA) available to Jordan for a total maximum amount of EUR 200 million, provided in the form of a medium-term loan, as I believe the EU must support such a valuable partner.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. - The neighbourhood conflict has led to an increase in the economic difficulties facing Jordan lately: the decline in tourism and foreign direct investment, the blocking of trade routes and the repeated disruption of the supply of natural gas from Egypt, on part, and the increase in unemployment - which affected only in the first half of 2016 14.6% of the working population (33% of active young people, 23.7% of active women) - on the other hand. In parallel, 650 000 Syrians are officially registered as refugees, and the authorities in Jordan even speak of 1.4 million. Under these circumstances, the European Union must demonstrate support for its partner. I support the rapporteur's position, who wants the macro-financial assistance programme to enter into force as soon as possible, so that Jordan can actually take advantage of it at these decisive moments.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Because of the difficult economic and financial situation in which the Kingdom of Jordan has been compounded by important flows of refugees who, fleeing war and violence raging in the vicinity of Syria, they seek protection within the country, the European Parliament has decided to proceed to a rapid adoption of the proposal for EU macrofinancial assistance in favour of Jordan. In particular, the settlement consists of two installments of 100 million euros each, to be paid in two tranches between the end of 2016 and the second quarter of 2017, whose operations will be managed and monitored directly from the European Commission. By virtue of the important role Jordan has played and continues to play in dealing with the Syrian refugee crisis, as well as the difficult economic time in which its economy is pouring, I expressed myself favourably for the adoption of this measure, against a country that is at the forefront of facing, together with Europe, an unprecedented migration crisis.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: This codecision report follows the European Commission's proposal to provide Jordan with macro-financial assistance of up to EUR 200 million to support the national economy in the context of military conflicts in Syria and Iraq. Considering that the European Union is suffering, through the flows of refugees, the disastrous consequences of Syrian and Iraqi conflicts, just like Jordan, and that the European Union must support its partners in a logic of co-development, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the decision granting further macro-financial assistance to Jordan. The instability of the Near and Middle East has undermined Jordan's economy, an important ally in the fight against ISIS, and a key partner in welcoming refugees fleeing conflicts in the region. That is why I am in favour of increasing the maximum amount of macro-financial assistance to EUR 200 million. In order to ensure the optimal use of these funds, it is important that the Commission agree with the Jordanian authorities on the conditions under which the Union's macro-financial assistance must be contingent.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: in writing. — Due to its geographical position, Jordan is one of the countries most directly affected by the Syrian crisis. Since 2011, its economy based primarily on services and industry has been affected by the riots in the region. However, in this difficult situation, Jordan shows that it accepts a significant number of displaced people. Conflicts in Syria and Iraq deprive Jordanian products of their traditional markets. Continuous conflicts in neighbouring countries continued to disturb Jordan's foreign trade in 2015: growth slowed down (2.4%) and the remaining external financing needs for 2016-2017 were estimated at USD 3.2 billion. Extreme high unemployment affects 14.6% of the active population (33% of active youth and 23.7% of active women). In order to overcome economic difficulties, the European Union must provide its support to its partner, whose policy on the reception of refugees is worthy of recognition. The aim is for the macro-financial assistance programme to enter into force as soon as possible so that Jordan can effectively benefit from it during this crucial period. As a member of the Fidesz-KDNP EPP delegation, I voted in favour of the report, since it is in line with the Hungarian Government's efforts to provide on the spot to those who are actually in need and to the neighbouring states who are forced to escape as a result of the war. help.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing. — I abstained on this report. Jordan and its economy are affected by the war in Syria: falling tourism, foreign investment, blocking trade routes, problems importing gas from Egypt, slowing growth and weighing on the budget. A financing agreement is in the process of being concluded with the European Union and the IMF. We support this assistance to a heavily destabilized State, subject to the structural reforms demanded by Jordan by the above-mentioned institutions.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. - I supported the report on the provision of macro-financial assistance to Jordan worth EUR 200 million. The country and its economy have been significantly affected by the ongoing conflicts in neighbouring Iraq and Syria. The Commission will submit its assessment next year and decide, if it deems it necessary, whether this aid should be extended and increased. It is indisputable that the Kingdom of Jordan is making efforts to receive Syrian refugees, unlike some of the other countries in regions, such as Saudi Arabia, but in the situation of crisis in which the EU is in, it must carefully monitor whether the funds it allocates are being used correctly by the receiving side of them. I believe that if this condition is met and if Jordan continues to accept refugees, aid to the country should not stop.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: in writing. - Faced with the economic difficulties facing Jordan, the European Union must support its partner, whose policy of receiving refugees is commendable. However, the 350 million proposed by the report as European Union macro-financial assistance to Jordan is simply a mob and I propose that it be tripled by deducting corresponding amounts from the funds earmarked for Turkey.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: in writing. — Due to its geographical position, Jordan is one of the countries most directly affected by the Syrian crisis. Since 2011, its economy based primarily on services and industry has been affected by the riots in the region. However, in this difficult situation, Jordan shows that it accepts a significant number of displaced people. Conflicts in Syria and Iraq deprive Jordanian products of their traditional markets. Continuous conflicts in neighbouring countries continued to disturb Jordan's foreign trade in 2015: growth slowed down (2.4%) and the remaining external financing needs for 2016-2017 were estimated at USD 3.2 billion. Extreme high unemployment affects 14.6% of the active population (33% of active youth and 23.7% of active women). In order to overcome economic difficulties, the European Union must provide its support to its partner, whose policy on the reception of refugees is worthy of recognition. The aim is for the macro-financial assistance programme to enter into force as soon as possible so that Jordan can effectively benefit from it during this crucial period. As a member of the Fidesz-KDNP EPP delegation, I voted in favour of the report, since it is in line with the Hungarian Government's efforts to provide on the spot to those who are actually in need and to the neighbouring states who are forced to escape as a result of the war. help.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the granting of macro financial assistance to Jordan from the International Trade Committee. Successful policies and agreements on trade are in the interests of Wales as of the rest of the EU.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This report deals with macro-financial assistance to Jordan. The proposal is to increase the value of this assistance by 150 million. It is proposed to grant a total value of EUR 350 million, which “must include a timetable for compliance” with financial conditions. However, this type of assistance typically involves demands for 'structural and macroeconomic reforms', which we know well what they mean and which we repudiate: deregulation and liberalisation of various sectors of the economy, attacks on the role of the State and its social functions, privatisation, all under pretext the conformation of the State to the rules of the “market economy”. Alternatively, we support the principle of cooperation and genuine development aid, which must be deepened, while respecting the sovereign will and choices of each State, free from the conditions or impositions of 'reform', aimed primarily at imposing a model based on the total liberalisation of the economic life of the countries.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because it will allow tax authorities access to anti-money laundering information as part of the correct application of the Directive on Administrative Cooperation (DAC). In particular, through this amendment, we will seek to create greater homogeneity in the field of anti-money laundering at EU level, thus ensuring access to the actual ownership information, how appropriate customer verification procedures.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing. - Jordan is facing serious economic and financial problems as a result of the situation in Syria. The proposal contains a macro-financial commitment of the European Union to Jordan of EUR 200 million, which should be provided as a medium-term loan to help Jordan finance the country's external needs in 2016-2017. In the future, the European Commission is considering an agreement with Jordan, which should commit itself to carrying out the necessary structural reforms that should bring sustainable economic growth to the country.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: In writing. ‒ I am voting in favour of the report helping Jordan, one of the few stable countries in the Middle East that welcomes Syrian refugees and fighting Isis.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: in writing. - Faced with the economic difficulties facing Jordan, the European Union must support its partner, whose policy of receiving refugees is commendable. That is why I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council providing further macro-financial assistance to the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Kingdom of Jordan both needs and deserves substantial financial help from the EU. The chaotic regional context massively impacts Jordan’s economy, social systems and public services, which makes its debt ratio barely sustainable. Meanwhile, its continued commitment in dealing with the refugees’ crisis with dignity (it welcomes around 1.3 million Syrians) ought to be praised. Thanks to our work in the European Parliament the Commission will have to propose, in addition to this year’s EUR 200 million, an extra macro-financial assistance operation of at least the same amount in 2017. The second macro-financial assistance package will help the country to cover part of its external financing needs in 2016-2017, while supporting reforms aimed at alleviating the balance of payments and budgetary needs, improving the investment climate and strengthening economic integration with the EU. It is also intended to support efforts to boost economic growth and job creation.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report, bearing in mind that Jordan, due to its geographical location, is one of the countries most directly affected by the Syrian crisis, as it hosts a large number of refugees. Similarly, we must bear in mind that the decline in tourism and foreign direct investment inflows, the blockade of trade routes and repeated disruptions in the supply of natural gas from Egypt have slowed down the country's growth. The conflict in Syria and Iraq continues to disrupt Jordan's foreign trade, resulting in economic growth slowed (2.4 per cent), with unemployment affecting 14.6 per cent of the active population (33 per cent of active youth and 23.7 per cent of active women). Given the economic difficulties facing Jordan, the Union must support its partner, and we must therefore support the macro-financial assistance programme so that Jordan can make use of it at this crucial moment.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Jordan is one of the countries most affected by the Syrian and migration crises; it is a key partner to prevent the ever-increasing violence from continuing its soaring. Its stability is important for both the region and Europe. The economy of this country has been affected, in particular, in tourism, foreign investment, and international and domestic trade. Due to these factors Jordan has faced a slowdown in economic growth and annual growth now stands at 1.9% of GDP. The country is also facing a rising unemployment rate, with the official unemployment rate now at 15.8 per cent. Jordan is the second largest country in the world by number of refugees and there are currently more than 650 000 Syrians and 58 000 Iraqis officially registered in the country. Finding economic and social stability is therefore important for Jordan, for the region and for Europe.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the EP legislative resolution of 24 November 2016 on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the granting of further macro assistance -financial in favour of the Hashemite kingdom of Jordan because since the outbreak of the conflict in Syria in 2011 the Union has undertaken explicitly to help Jordan deal with the economic consequences and social issues of the Syrian crisis, especially the presence of a large number of Syrian refugees on Jordanian territory, and increased financial support for the country, strengthening cooperation in many areas, including civil society, the electoral system, security, regional development and social and economic reforms. Since the onset of the Syrian crisis, the Union has allocated almost EUR 1,130 billion to Jordan in various ways (financial assistance, under the normal bilateral cooperation programme for the Jordan, humanitarian aid). In addition, since 2011 the EIB has made available loans amounting to EUR 264 million. I welcome the right to information on the implementation of the assistance which the EP has claimed. By 30 June each year, the Commission shall submit to the EP and the Council a report on the implementation of the Decision during the previous year.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: in writing. - The Kingdom of Jordan is doing incredible things in the current refugee crisis. Although only 6.5 million inhabitants live in Jordan, more than 1.5 million refugees have found refuge there. Against this background alone, I welcome the continuation of macro-financial assistance.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: in writing. - Due to the conflicts in Syria and Iraq, the Jordanian Government and the Jordanian economy face significant challenges. In recent years, massive flows of refugees have come to Jordan. Tourism to Jordan remained largely unavailable and foreign direct investment declined massively. The European Union should assist Jordan in the reception of refugees from Syria and Iraq and should provide financial assistance to Jordan.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as I don’t believe that tax payer’s money should be used in this way.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which concerns EU financial assistance to Jordan. This support is vital given Jordan is struggling with an unsustainable level of debt due to conflicts in its neighbourhood. Meanwhile, the country is an important partner in addressing other consequences of the regional crises, welcoming around 1.3 million Syrians. I therefore welcome that the Commission will propose, in addition to this year’s EUR 200 million, an extra macro-financial assistance operation of at least the same amount in 2017.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted abstention because the initiative itself seems positive and necessary, but it has been approached from an angle which makes it very unlikely to achieve its objectives, and which implies a significant risk that aid will indeed have a counterproductive effect. The aim of this aid is to provide an oxygen balloon to Jordan in view of the fact that its economy has been one of the major victims of the war in Syria. The decline in income, coupled with the massive influx of refugees, has contributed to a significant increase in external debt. Hence the macro-financial aid initiative we have voted on. The reason why I doubt whether this aid will provide real support for the Jordanian economy and society is that the instrument is linked to IMF lending programmes which, as a condition, impose the implementation of neo-liberal structural reforms. These reforms, together with a possible increase in debt, can have long-term negative consequences and were not the best available option.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on financial assistance to the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan. Jordan, due to its geographical location, has been in a difficult position because hostilities in Syria and Iraq have had a major impact on the country's economy. Jordan is currently one of the countries most affected by the Syrian crisis — the decline in tourism and foreign direct investment receipts, the blocking of trade routes and the repeated disruption of natural gas supplies from Egypt have stunted economic growth in Jordan and hampered the growth of Jordan. negative impact on her budgetary situation. In my assessment, Jordan's efforts in accepting refugees and providing support should be supported.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which concerns EU financial assistance to Jordan. This support is vital given Jordan is struggling with an unsustainable level of debt due to conflicts in its neighbourhood. Meanwhile, the country is an important partner in addressing other consequences of the regional crises, welcoming around 1.3 million Syrians.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Although we fully share the need to strengthen the Jordanian economy, which is also being tested because of the hospitality offered by the country to millions of Syrian refugees, we have nevertheless voted abstention since the European Union's macro-financial assistance under consideration is linked directly to IMF programmes that impose neoliberal structural reforms and are already being implemented in the country.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support giving further aid to Jordan. Jordan has had to handle the effects of the war in Syria, including hosting more than one million Syrian refugees. As a result, I believe that the EU should provide assistance to the Jordanian authorities on clearly defined economic policy and financial conditions, focusing on structural reforms and sound public finances.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour since I have no objections.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: in writing. - This report sets out the financial assistance under the EU Association Agreement with the Kingdom of Jordan through a loan of EUR 200 million. The liberal-conservative reformers support this against the backdrop of the crisis in Syria and the importance of Jordan's achievements in the refugee problem. This assistance is an important part of the geopolitical stabilisation of the region. The Jordanian royal family is also internationally recognised and the country has demonstrated its willingness to reform in the past. Thus, despite the high debt ratio of 93.4% of GDP (as of 2015), the loan makes sense and I was able to endorse the report.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written. — I voted for the Report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the provision of further macro-financial assistance to the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan (COM (2016) 0431 — C8-0242/2016 — 2016/0197 (COD)), since it is an EU partner country which has been extremely severely affected in recent years state of the environment, because of which it lost a considerable part of its traditional market. Nevertheless, Jordan is a state that has preserved stability and has made certain democratic advances. In addition to the direct economic damage caused by the war in Iraq and Syria, it is especially important to emphasize the humanitarian role of Jordan in which there are 650,000 refugees and unofficially and over a million refugees. All this puts a burden on the economic and social stability of this country and it is necessary to create prerequisites for activating EU aid as quickly as possible.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: events in the Middle East have led to an influx of more than one million Syrian refugees into Jordan, resulting in a burden of several billion dollars. It is natural that we would help this country in the turmoil of migration, although I do not associate myself with the IMF and the EU's requests for structural adjustments. I abstained.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report by my colleague Emmanuel Maurel on financial support for Jordan. Widely supported by parliamentarians, this assistance will take the form of a €200 million loan on behalf of the EU. As the Union's partner in the fight against terrorism in the Middle East, the Jordanian economy has been heavily impacted by the conflict in Syria: the decline in tourism and massive reception of refugees on its territory. This aid will enable the Hashemite Kingdom to implement the structural reforms necessary to revive its economy. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution in order to allocate macro-financial assistance of EUR 200 million to Jordan, a country badly affected by the conflicts in Syria and Iraq.

name: Εύα Καϊλή (S&D)
text: in writing. - Jordan's macro-financial assistance is an issue that we must address not only in economic terms but above all in geopolitical and strategic terms. Jordan is in a process of strengthening its partnerships with the European Union and has an economy which, as a result of geographical proximity, has been greatly damaged by the Syrian crisis. In addition, Jordan, along with Lebanon, has the largest influx of Syrian immigrants in relation to its population worldwide. It is therefore a strategic priority to strengthen at this stage Jordan, which is becoming our strategic partner in the region due to the circumstances.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: in writing. - In this report, the rapporteur presents the significant financial losses and burdens that Jordan currently has to bear as a result of regional conflicts. In view of this fact, and due to the fact that Jordan can contribute to a more effective fight against the migration crisis in the future, financial assistance to that country cannot be refused. That is why I am voting in favour of this report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report providing finance support to Jordan. This support is vital given Jordan is struggling with an unsustainable level of debt due to conflicts in its neighbourhood.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: in writing. - This report sets out the financial assistance under the EU Association Agreement with the Kingdom of Jordan through a loan of EUR 200 million. The liberal-conservative reformers support this against the backdrop of the crisis in Syria and the importance of Jordan's achievements in the refugee problem. This assistance is an important part of the geopolitical stabilisation of the region. The Jordanian royal family is also internationally recognised and the country has demonstrated its willingness to reform in the past. Thus, despite the high debt ratio of 93.4% of GDP (as of 2015), the loan makes sense and I was able to endorse the report.

In order to overcome economic difficulties, the European Union must provide its support to its partner, whose policy on the reception of refugees is worthy of recognition. The aim is for the macro-financial assistance programme to enter into force as soon as possible so that Jordan can effectively benefit from it during this crucial period. As a member of the Fidesz-KDNP EPP delegation, I voted in favour of the report, since it is in line with the Hungarian Government's efforts to provide on the spot to those who are actually in need and to the neighbouring states who are forced to escape as a result of the war. help.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained from voting on macro-financial assistance to Jordan since while I highly appreciate the huge efforts of Jordanian society and government in hosting millions of Syrian refugees and I recognise the necessity to assist Jordan, I am in principle against the ‘structural reforms’, adjusted to any macro-financial assistance agreement.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: in writing. I support the EU to provide macro-financial assistance to Jordan. Jordan is one of the countries most directly affected by the crisis in Syria. The macro-financial assistance programme must be effective because Jordan is the country that has accepted the highest number of displaced persons.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: I abstained on this report because it certainly has the merit of helping Jordan, a courageous country fighting ISIS. But it conditional its financial aid on respect for parliamentary pluralism, without wondering whether it is legitimate to impose a “western” democracy in this way.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: in writing. - It is normal to help Jordan, which is taking a large share of the burden on Syrian migrants. The EU loan of €200 million is legitimate. These loans are, however, conditional on the establishment of externally imposed rules in contradiction with the current state of Jordanian society, with objectives that could undermine the stability of Jordanian society. I therefore abstained on this vote.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour because since the beginning of 2011, Jordan's economy has been severely affected by domestic developments related to the Arab Spring and by the turmoil in the region, mainly in neighbouring countries Iraq and Syria. In a deteriorated global environment, Jordan is experiencing a loss of revenue and strong pressure on its public finances. The situation in Jordan has recently been aggravated by the conflict in Syria, which has led to the entry of approximately 1.3 million refugees into the country, according to estimates by the European Commission. In this context, the Commission has proposed the granting of macro-financial assistance to the country in the form of medium-term credit. The objective is to offset the need for external financing for 2016-2017, based on IMF estimates. The aid shall be managed by the Commission and is accompanied by provisions for the prevention of fraud and other irregularities, in line with the Financial Regulation.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Jordan, a country with the Union's “advanced partner” status, is facing a number of economic difficulties. Indeed, it is one of the countries most affected by the Syrian crisis, due to the decline in tourism and the blockade of trade routes. However, a large number of displaced persons have been welcomed by Jordan, pledged to facilitate access to employment by Syrians who have arrived. I am voting in favour of the granting of this macro-financial assistance, since the Union must support its partner, which has so severally welcomed so many refugees.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: in writing. - This report sets out the financial assistance under the EU Association Agreement with the Kingdom of Jordan through a loan of EUR 200 million. The liberal-conservative reformers support this against the backdrop of the crisis in Syria and the importance of Jordan's achievements in the refugee problem. This assistance is an important part of the geopolitical stabilisation of the region. The Jordanian royal family is also internationally recognised and the country has demonstrated its willingness to reform in the past. Thus, despite the high debt ratio of 93.4% of GDP (as of 2015), the loan makes sense and I was able to endorse the report.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: written. — The Kingdom of Jordan is one of the countries directly affected by the Syrian crisis. Jordan's economy has not evolved for years, but regardless of the difficult situation it finds itself in, Jordan is among those states that have received the most refugees. Since Jordan received the status of “advanced partner” of the European Union back in 2010, the EU decided to provide macro-financial assistance in the amount of 200 million euros due to a highly necessary programme of reforms and economic stabilisation. In order to ensure key stability in the region, and given that there is always the possibility for the European Commission to suspend or terminate payment in the event that Jordan fails to meet all the conditions set, I supported this report.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support Parliament’s position that the European Union should make macrofinancial assistance of a maximum amount of EUR 350 million available to Jordan instead of the EUR 200 million that the Commission has proposed. Jordan is now in a very difficult situation because of the war in Syria. But Jordan remains a stable state that manages to help a lot of Syrian refugees.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing — I support the proposal to provide EUR 350 million macro-financial assistance to Jordan in order to support economic stabilisation and the reform programme. Jordan is directly affected by the conflict in Syria, weakening a service-industrial-based economy. Nevertheless, this country accepts a fairly high number of displaced persons. This contributes to tackling the refugee crisis. The provision of macro-financial assistance is conditional on respect for democratic mechanisms, including a pluralist parliamentary system, the rule of law and respect for human rights.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing. - I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council providing further macro-financial assistance to the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan for the reasons I explained in detail in my speech to the European Parliament plenary Parliament in Strasbourg on 23 November 2016, as well as because this report is complete and documented.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the proposal providing further macro-financial assistance to the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan. Jordan has shown great levels of stability amidst conflict and tension in neighbouring Syria, which have had their impact in the country. Jordan is suffering from lower levels of tourism and foreign direct investment, blocked trade routes and disruptions to the flow of natural gas from Egypt. Since the EU considers Jordan an effective ally for maintaining excellent relations with the Gulf countries, it is important that the EU continues supporting the country. Without further ado, my vote was positive since macro-financial assistance shows signs of benefitting both the European Union and Jordan’s critical position in the Middle East.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: Jordan is currently facing enormous economic challenges exacerbated by the solidarity response of a very large number of refugees from the Syrian conflict. In this sense, it has turned to the EU for a financial aid package. Since this is fundamental, the sums involved - which fall far short of what is needed - and the conditionality imposed by the European institutions will lead to massive doses of austerity which will penalise the Jordanian people. For these reasons, I abstained.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: Jordan is facing a number of crises: economically - because of the blockade of its traditional trade routes -, financially - with a bloody budget - and socially - its unemployment rate has reached historic highs. Yet the Jordanian authorities and people face humanely the challenges facing them, such as the best way to welcome the million refugees displaced in Jordan by the deadly conflicts in the Iraq-Syrian area. The European Union has already taken several steps to support Jordan in this difficult period: it has issued various technical, financial and humanitarian aid; has flexibilized the “rules of origin” for exported Jordanian products; and will soon begin negotiations for an asymmetrical trade partnership . However, my report was interested in the proposed new macro-financial assistance: I welcome the fact that the European Parliament has taken up the urgency by agreeing with my suggestion to approve, in addition to the EUR 200 million planned for this year, the principle of a new operation for Jordan of at least 200 million. additional during the year 2017.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: in writing. - I agree with macro-financial support for Jordan, which is facing significant losses and burdens due to regional conflicts.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of granting financial support to Jordan. Jordan, together with Lebanon, is the world's host country of the largest number of refugees compared to its population and has committed itself to facilitating access to employment for Syria — 650 000 Syrians are currently registered as refugees and the Jordanian authorities mention as many as 1.4 million . the number of refugees on its territory. The total number of non-Jordanian citizens living in the country has doubled over five years. Most of them live not in camps, but in cities, so Jordanian public services are under great pressure.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. — The Union proposes macro-financial assistance to Jordan of up to EUR 200 million in the form of a loan. Under the guise of “assistance” it is actually a matter of subjecting the country to the IMF requirements, coupled with a “memorandum” with the EU. Everything is said very clearly about this. Financial assistance has no other purpose than “to support the implementation of an action programme involving strong adjustment and structural reform measures” with a 'fiscal consolidation 'objective. Already, with the EU-Jordan Euro-Mediterranean free trade agreement in 1997, the EU had no complex to congratulate King Hussein on his reforms, without questioning the autocratic and retrograde nature of the Jordanian regime. With his son, the Arab Spring was soon forgotten. I am voting against this unjust agreement. A fortiori when other types of aids and dialogues could and should have been faveorised.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: Jordan and its economy are affected by the war in Syria. There was an influx of 1.3 million Syrian refugees. The fee would be $6.6 billion since 2011. It is normal to help Jordan, which is taking a large share of the burden on Syrian migrants. The EU loan of EUR 200 million therefore seems to us legitimate. The only difficulty for us, the IMF and the EU are asking for structural adjustments. These loans are then conditional on the introduction of several measures potentially dangerous to the balance of the country. This aid should not be conditional on the wishes of the EU. As a whole in favour of the text, I voted in favour.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: Jordan is one of the countries most directly affected by the crisis in Syria because of its geographical situation. Since 2011, the country's economy, mainly based on services and industry, has been affected by the instability in the region. The decline in tourism revenues and foreign direct investment flows, the blockade of trade flows and repeated disturbances in the supply of natural gas from Egypt have halted the growth of Jordan's economy and weighed on its budgetary position. The conflict in Syria and Iraq prevents Jordanian products from continuing to be disposed of to their historic markets. In view of the economic difficulties facing Jordan, the European Union must support its partner, whose refugee reception policy should be praised. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of macro-financial assistance to Jordan because it is one of the countries most directly affected by the war in Syria due to its geographical proximity to the conflict.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing - Jordan is one of the countries most paying for the war in Syria and Iraq, from the point of view of the country's economy. Yet, along with Lebanon, it accepts the largest number of refugees in proportion to the world's population and has promised to make it easier for Syrians to access employment. Officially 650,000 Syrians are registered as refugees, but Jordanian authorities report up to 1.4 million, understandably putting huge pressure on both the country's public services and the economy and infrastructure. The EU has already provided Jordan with macro-financial assistance worth €180 million, but assistance needs to be continued to deal with the problems. Jordan is a partner of the EU with an enhanced status and the intensity of this partnership is growing. Due to its geographical location, it is a strategic country in terms of stability and security in the region, but also in the coalition against ISIS. The provision of aid is conditional on Jordan's respect for democratic mechanisms. At the same time, it will be a fulfilment of the EU's commitment made at the International Conference of Major Donors in February 2016, when the international community pledged $10 billion in aid to the country. The EU will provide its adequate amount through available instruments such as the European Neighbourhood, Humanitarian Aid, Development Cooperation and Others. I support the proposal to provide assistance to Jordan.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report because it is important to provide the most effective assistance to Jordan as soon as possible, recognising the role they are playing assisting in the refugee crisis and as a long-standing reliable partner to the EU.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. — The Commission has proposed to the European Parliament and the Council a decision on further macro-financial assistance to the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan. In its report, the Committee on International Trade proposed that Parliament adopt the Commission's proposal at first reading with three amendments. I voted accordingly.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: Jordan faced an influx of 1.3 million Syrian refugees. The fee would be $6.6 billion since 2011. It is therefore not absurd to help Jordan, which is taking a large share of the burden with regard to Syrian migrants. However, the IMF and the EU are calling for structural adjustments. The Jordanian economy is in serious financing difficulties, which promises to destabilize it even further. I therefore abstain from this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, it is important that the EU provides the most effective assistance to Jordan as soon as possible bearing in mind the role they are playing assisting in the refugee crisis and the need to help their ailing economy.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this macro financial assistance to Jordan of up to EUR 200 million. The country, which has been suffering from crises in the Middle East since 2011, plays a key role in welcoming people fleeing conflict zones and who can come to Jordan in structured camps. By helping these people stay close to their living pool, Jordan avoids these people coming to Europe with the conviction that we will be able to offer them work, housing, care, and ultimately find themselves in jungles like the one that existed in Calais.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In Jordan unemployment is very high affecting 14.6% of the active population (33% of young people and 23% of women due to the conflicts in neighbouring Syria and Iraq. Despite its internal problems, Jordan has taken in a large number of displaced persons and it is estimated that around 1.4 million Syrians are present in their territory. I have voted for this report that will provide Jordan with a macro-financial assistance in order to support its economic stabilisation and substantive reform agenda.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I voted for this report which is extremely necessary for the continuation of good cooperation relations between the European Union and Jordan. I would like to stress that both the financial and economic policy conditions provided for in the Memorandum of Understanding are in line with EU practices in this area, but also with the macroeconomic adjustment and structural reform programmes implemented by Jordan with the help of the IMF. Despite the economic difficulties Jordan faces, the EU shows its support for its partner, whose refugee reception policy was flawless, Jordan being the country that received the most refugees in terms of population. Another positive aspect is that Jordan has committed itself to facilitating access to the labour market for more than 700 000 Syrian refugees on its territory, a gesture of generosity and tolerance that we have not seen in any other country.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report because Jordan is currently experiencing significant financial losses due to regional conflicts.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported. Jordan has faced an extremely high number of refugees. Due to the difficult situation, external direct investment and tourism have fallen, parts of trade routes have been closed and natural gas supplies coming from Egypt have been repeatedly cut off. Jordan's economic growth has also slowed as a result of the refugee crisis, so EU support is needed.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report which provides for the implementation of a programme of macro-financial assistance so as to be of the real benefit of Jordan at this crucial moment. Due to its geographical location, Jordan is one of the countries most directly affected by the crisis in Syria. Since 2011, its economy, which is principally based on services and industry, has been suffering severe consequences from instability in the region. At the same time, along with Lebanon, Jordan is the country that welcomes the largest number of refugees in the world in relation to the size of its population and has undertaken to facilitate the employment of Syrians. Jordan participates in a partnership with the European Union, which is its second trading partner. It is therefore logical, given the economic difficulties facing Jordan, that the European Union should support its partner, whose policy of receiving refugees is commendable.

name: Gilles Pargneaux (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this macro-financial assistance to Jordan. The country hosts hundreds of thousands of Syrian refugees who are in addition to Palestinian refugees who have historically settled in the country awaiting return. In this exceptional geopolitical context, it is urgent for the European Union to assist this country, a rare example of stability in the region. €200 million will be granted under emergency aid. The European Commission has also committed itself to introduce, in 2017, a new proposal for macro-financial assistance of a similar amount. Proposal I support!

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ I would vote in favour of the proposal from my colleagues because I believe that it is more than suitable to guarantee Jordan, a country most affected by the Syrian crisis, a macro-financial assistance which is more than appropriate. provides for a maximum amount of EUR 350 million, in order to support both its economic stabilization and a reform programme in the country. It should not be forgotten that Jordan, together with Lebanon, is the nation that accommodates the largest number of refugees in proportion to the number of the population and also seeks to facilitate employment of the Syrians themselves. Furthermore, I believe that it is appropriate for the Commission to oversee the exploitation of this financial assistance, helping Jordan to establish policy and, on the other hand, strategies better to adopt. Therefore I would vote upvote.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: written. - I support the intention of the European Union to assist Jordan in the amount of an additional $200 million. It is necessary that the European Union is financially supported by countries that are its important foreign policy partner in crisis areas. Jordan has done much during the Syrian conflict and refugee crisis and it is important to solidarize itself to minimize and remedy the damage caused by the geographical element. Receiving refugees is a great act and it is necessary that the European Union honors the move and do as much as possible to ensure the development stability of the country and help the faltering economy. The assistance provided to Jordan will be a clear signal and sign to all EU allies that there is serious, planned and purposeful foreign policy action. The burden borne by all states in the environment of Syria must also be distributed to other states and organisations to achieve uniformity. The European Union has experienced an enormal refugee wave over the past year and a half and it is necessary to develop from the learned strategies for countries where the refugee wave is continuous and have received millions of refugees since the start of the Syrian conflict. Financial assistance, however, needs to be accompanied by a strong incentive to institutional stabilisation and the construction of an effective state apparatus.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: written. - Since early 2011, Jordan's economy has been destabilized by unrest in the region. The weakened performance of the overall world economy has further strained the country's public finances. Regional conflicts have not only eroded trade in the region, but also meant an influx of large numbers of refugees for Jordan. At a donor conference held in London in February this year, the international community committed to implementing a global support plan for Jordan. The European Union is aware that Jordan must remain stable for the future of the region. It is also an important partner with whom we have strong economic ties. The bloc was Jordan's second-largest trading partner in 2014. I welcome the proposal for a second macro-financial assistance package as well as the fact that it would be part of the so-called EU-Jordan pact, an important initiative containing the exact commitments of both parties. A closer partnership needs to be established between the European Union and Jordan. A prerequisite for granting macro-financial assistance is Jordan's obligation to respect effective democratic mechanisms, including the multi-party parliamentary system and the rule of law, and to guarantee respect for human rights. I would like to emphasize Jordan's strategic role in the coalition against the so-called. Islamic State and the great efforts he has made in the security and intelligence field, and how important it is therefore to provide adequate support to the Kingdom of Jordan and to continue the political, security and economic dialogue between the European Union and Jordan.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: The proposal is to increase the value of macro-financial assistance to Jordan by 150 million, that is to say a total value of 'EUR 350 million', which 'must include a timetable for the fulfilment of financial conditions'. This type of assistance typically has associated demands for 'structural and macroeconomic reforms', which we repudiate. Instead, we support the principle of cooperation and genuine development aid, which must be deepened, while respecting the sovereign will and choices of each State, free from the conditions or impositions of reform, aimed primarily at imposing a model based on the liberalisation of economic life. and the social and social of countries.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ For its geographical location Jordan is one of the countries most directly affected by the Syrian crisis. Falling revenue from tourism and foreign direct investment, blocking trade routes and repeated disruptions to the flow of natural gas from Egypt have slowed economic growth of Jordan burdening heavily on its financial situation. I believe that in the face of the economic difficulties which Jordan is exposed, the European Union must show solidarity. In order to ensure the stability of Damascus and the whole region, I deem it essential to provide adequate economic support by continuing the political and economic dialogue between the EU and Jordan. The Commission proposes distributing a loan of 200 million to Jordan for the rebalancing of its balance of payments. The Committee on International Trade proposes by a large majority to increase the size of the loan to a maximum of EUR 350 million. Following this substantial amendment, the trilogue was made with the Council and the Commission. The successful outcome of the trilogue confirmed the loan of 200 million with the commitment to verify the possibility of an increase over the next year, should conditions in Jordan require it. I voted in favour of approving this report.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: in writing. — The conflicts in Jordan's neighbours, Iraq and Syria, have had a major impact on the country's economy. At a conference on support for Syria and surrounding regions held in London on 4 February 2016, the EU pledged to donate EUR 2.39 billion to countries affected by the refugee crisis in Syria, as well as to provide a loan of EUR 200 million for the purposes of the second operation to provide macro-financial assistance to Jordan. The payment of EU macro-financial assistance will be dealt with by the Commission and will implement it in accordance with agreements or agreements concluded between the International Monetary Fund and Jordan, as well as on the basis of the main principles and objectives of economic reforms set out in the Association Agreement between The EU and Jordan, the Single Support Framework for 2014-2017, as well as the Partnership Priorities for the Future. I support the operation to provide macro-financial assistance.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. - Since 2011, the Jordanian economy has been significantly affected by the conflict in Syria and Iraq. That is why a second package of macro-financial aid amounting to EUR 200 million, in the form of loans, was granted to the country by the Commission. I voted in favour of granting this aid. Our political group wanted to increase the amount of aid to EUR 350 million, especially given Jordan's task to deal with the thousands of refugees from Syria, we have succeeded in guaranteeing additional aid for 2017.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Taxpayers’ money should not be used this way.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: We all recognise the role played by Jordan in assisting the refugee crisis (650,000 Syrians registered as refugees, but the authorities guarantee that they reach 1.4 million) and the need to help its weakened economy. The decline in tourism revenues and foreign direct investment flows, the blockade of trade flows and repeated disturbances in the supply of natural gas from Egypt have halted the growth of Jordan's economy and weighed its budgetary position. The conflict in Syria and Iraq prevents Jordanian products from continuing to be disposed of to their historic markets. In 2015, the persistence of conflicts in neighbouring countries continued to disrupt Jordan's external trade: growth slowed (2.4%) and residual external financing needs in the period 2016-2017 are estimated at around $3.2 billion. In the first half of 2016, extremely high unemployment affected 14.6% of the active population (33% of active young people and 23.7% of active women). Assistance will be 200 million between 2016 and 2017. Nevertheless, S&D is of the opinion that it could have gone further.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report providing macro-financial assistance to Jordan. The Union has long maintained prosperous relations with Jordan and the effort it is making in providing shelter and assistance to people coming from Syria must be recognized. Since the beginning of 2011, Jordan's economy has been severely deteriorated by a sharp loss of income and the decline in foreign investment, further exacerbated by events in Syria. It was therefore necessary to provide assistance to Jordan as quickly and effectively as possible to alleviate its economic situation.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of EUR 200 million in macro-financial assistance to Jordan to contribute to the economic stability of Jordan, with which the European Union intends to lead a close partnership. This amount, allocated in the form of loans for the next two years, is also intended to support the country's substantial reform programme to recover, as well as Jordan's balance of payments needs.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — Jordan is one of the biggest victims of the conflict in Syria. It was this country that a very large proportion of refugees attracted. And it is Jordan that, unlike many other Arab countries, has accepted these refugees and is trying to help them in every possible way. In addition, Jordan is one of the few democratic and well-managed countries in the Middle East and is actively involved in the European Neighbourhood Policy. Despite the relatively high level of prosperity, this country is facing huge financial challenges as a result of the conflict in Syria, particularly in order to balance its macro-financial flows. Therefore, both for security in the European neighbourhood and for comrade human aspirations, we must try to help Jordan survive. The decision under consideration will provide relatively low support for the EU, but this will be primarily an investment. Investment not only in strengthening one's own security, ensuring stability at the EU border, but also in investing in the development of humanity and mutual understanding.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. - Given its geographical position, Jordan is one of the countries most affected by the Syrian crisis, and the economic sector has been severely torn by instability in the region. For this reason, and because it is also the country in the world that, together with Lebanon, is welcoming the most refugees in relation to its population, I believe that sufficient conditions are met for the EU to provide macro-financial assistance to that country quickly to alleviate the burden of public debt in the Jordan and contribute to the implementation of the reforms necessary for democratic stabilisation and the implementation of a true rule of law, respecting human rights. Alongside this macro-financial assistance, it should be borne in mind the importance of the negotiations on the Comprehensive and Deep Free Trade Agreement in order to intensify trade relations between the EU and Jordan and bring mutual benefit to both sides.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this text, which concludes the institutional negotiations on granting macro-financial assistance to Jordan. The Jordanian economy is affected by unrest in the region, particularly in Iraq and Syria. Jordan was hosting 1.3 million Syrian refugees on its territory, and this situation is putting pressure on its public infrastructure. At the same time, rising unemployment and public debt exacerbate the economic crisis in the country. Following the international conference “Supporting Syria and the Region” held in London on 4 February 2016, the European Union pledged to continue to provide significant support to Jordan. This new macro-financial assistance of EUR 200 million is thus granted in the form of loans and remains conditional on Jordan's prerequisite for respect for effective democratic mechanisms, the rule of law and human rights.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted abstention because the initiative itself seems positive and necessary, but it has been approached from an angle which makes it very unlikely to achieve its objectives, and which implies a significant risk that aid will indeed have a counterproductive effect. The aim of this aid is to provide an oxygen balloon to Jordan in view of the fact that its economy has been one of the major victims of the war in Syria. The decline in income, coupled with the massive influx of refugees, has contributed to a significant increase in external debt. Hence the macro-financial aid initiative we have voted on. The reason why I doubt whether this aid will provide real support for the Jordanian economy and society is that the instrument is linked to IMF lending programmes which, as a condition, impose the implementation of neo-liberal structural reforms. These reforms, together with a possible increase in debt, can have long-term negative consequences and were not the best available option.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted to provide Union financial assistance to Jordan. Along with Lebanon, Jordan is the country that has received the most refugees compared to the number of inhabitants and has committed itself to facilitating access to the labour market for Syrians located on its territory. Currently, 650 000 Syrians are officially registered as refugees, and the authorities in Jordan even speak of 1.4 million. Jordan is facing a significant economic deficit, and it is therefore crucial for the EU to show its solidarity with the Jordanian people and to support the country's government in managing the wave of Syrian refugees.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The 'macro-financial aid' to Jordan is nothing other than the Union's intermediation in a private credit of up to EUR 350 million as a counterpart to an IMF adjustment programme, which will impose further cuts on labour rights and the public budget of Jordan's fragile economy. I believe that the imposition of new neoliberal policies will only increase instability in the region politically. That is why I voted against.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I do not wish to see the EU spend money on foreign aid so I voted against this.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of providing the most effective assistance to Jordan as soon as possible, recognising the role they are playing assisting in the refugee crisis and the need to help their ailing economy. I believe that the EU is in a position to provide greater financial assistance to Jordan than the EUR 200 million proposed.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing. - I fully support the provision of macro-financial assistance to the Kingdom of Jordan. Jordan is one of the countries most directly affected by the Syrian crisis. Despite this difficult situation, Jordan accepts a significant number of displaced persons. Together with Lebanon, it receives the largest number of refugees in proportion to the world's population. At the same time, Jordan has pledged to make it easier for Syrians to access employment — 650,000 Syrians are officially registered as refugees, and Jordanian authorities report a figure of even 1.4 million — found on its territory. I voted in favour.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: written. - I voted positively for this report, but this rationale of voting is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEPs solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the real quality and the amount of work, efficiency and most of all the success of the advocacy.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing. - Jordan is currently most affected by the Syrian crisis because of its geographical location. Since 2011, its economy has been based mainly on services and industry, marked by the unrest that has rocked the region. The weakening of tourism, blocked trading routes, repeated natural gas supplies from Egypt have hampered Jordan's growth. The conflict in Syria and Iraq is preventing Jordanian products from reaching their historically given outlets. Despite this difficult situation, Jordan accepts a significant number of displaced persons. Together with Lebanon, it receives the largest number of refugees in proportion to the world's population. The partnership between Jordan and the EU, its second largest trading partner, is only at the beginning, but its intensity is growing. In 2010, Jordan was granted EU partner status with enhanced status. The European Union has already provided Jordan with macro-financial assistance amounting to EUR 180 million, but in view of the challenges it currently faces, Jordan needs further EU financial assistance.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: in writing. - This report sets out the financial assistance under the EU Association Agreement with the Kingdom of Jordan through a loan of EUR 200 million. The liberal-conservative reformers support this against the backdrop of the crisis in Syria and the importance of Jordan's achievements in the refugee problem. This assistance is an important part of the geopolitical stabilisation of the region. The Jordanian royal family is also internationally recognised and the country has demonstrated its willingness to reform in the past. Thus, despite the high debt ratio of 93.4% of GDP (as of 2015), the loan makes sense and I was able to endorse the report.

name: Jaromír Štětina (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of granting macroeconomic assistance to Jordan in the form of loans, the maximum amount of which was set at EUR 200 million. This is a continuation of already begun aid to the country, which needs to be given a helping hand in a crisis situation. The international community, including the EU, committed in 2016 to financial support for Jordan worth a total of US$10 billion. The EU itself has already provided Jordan with nearly €1130m worth of funds since the crisis began in Syria. Assistance is conditional on respecting democratic mechanisms, adhering to the principles of the rule of law and guaranteeing respect for human rights. At the same time, the emphasis is on economic stabilisation and sustainable growth of the country. Jordan is contributing in the fight against IS and fighting for stability in the region in which it occupies a strategic location. It is now deeply affected by the crisis in Syria. Fewer tourists travel to the country as a result of the Syrian conflict and its associated migration crisis, and with this less foreign investment is flowing into the country. Jordan's debt was in excess of 90% of GDP at the end of last year. However, despite the adverse situation, Jordan accepts, together with Lebanon, the most refugees per population, with a total number of more than 1.3 million people. This represents roughly a two-fold increase over 5 years. Jordan is a strategic and trusted partner who fully deserves our support.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: in writing. - I did not agree with the European Parliament resolution on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on further macro-financial assistance to the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan. The Union shall provide Jordan with macro-financial assistance of up to EUR 350 million to support the economic stabilisation of the country and to implement a comprehensive reform programme. The financial assistance shall contribute to Jordan's balance of payments needs as identified in the IMF programme. Macro-financial assistance is wrong. The idea itself is missed. States must finance themselves independently. They are supposed to keep their households in order independently. Macro-financial assistance prevents budgetary discipline by eliminating the pressure created by the need for financing on the capital market. Moreover, irrespective of my aversion to macro-financial assistance, it is not at all the EU's task to fund other states so that these reform programmes can be implemented. The EU itself is unable to reform itself. Therefore, it seems cynical to believe that it can help other states.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: written. - Jordan has been hit very hard by the Syrian crisis. Its economy, which is primarily based on services and industry, has been significantly hit by unrest in the region since 2011. Despite the difficult situation, Jordan accepted the largest number of refugees in terms of the size of its population, alongside Libya. Refugees are not found in camps but in cities, which puts a strain on Jordanian health care and education. The European Union has committed to providing Jordan €200 million under its macro-financial assistance programme. The Council accepted the proposal by the EPP and other political groups to raise the amount of macro-financial assistance to EUR 350 million, taking into account the specific needs of Jordan related to the disposal of such a large number of Syrian refugees. I support this Report because, despite its economic hardship, Jordan accepted a large number of Syrian refugees and gave them access to its labour market. It's a huge burden for Jordan and he needs to be helped as much as possible.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Although we fully share the need to strengthen the Jordanian economy, which is also being tested because of the hospitality offered by the country to millions of Syrian refugees, we are voting abstention, since the European Union's macro-financial assistance under consideration is directly linked to IMF programmes that impose neoliberal structural reforms and are already being implemented in the country.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: in writing. - Faced with the economic difficulties facing Jordan, the European Union must support its partner, whose policy of receiving refugees is commendable. However, the 350 million proposed by the report as European Union macro-financial assistance to Jordan is simply a mob and I propose that it be tripled by deducting corresponding amounts from the funds earmarked for Turkey.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: in writing. — Due to its geographical position, Jordan is one of the countries most directly affected by the Syrian crisis. Since 2011, its economy based primarily on services and industry has been affected by the riots in the region. However, in this difficult situation, Jordan shows that it accepts a significant number of displaced people. Conflicts in Syria and Iraq deprive Jordanian products of their traditional markets. Continuous conflicts in neighbouring countries continued to disturb Jordan's foreign trade in 2015: growth slowed down (2.4%) and the remaining external financing needs for 2016-2017 were estimated at USD 3.2 billion. Extreme high unemployment affects 14.6% of the active population (33% of active youth and 23.7% of active women). In order to overcome economic difficulties, the European Union must provide its support to its partner, whose policy on the reception of refugees is worthy of recognition. The aim is for the macro-financial assistance programme to enter into force as soon as possible so that Jordan can effectively benefit from it during this crucial period. As a member of the Fidesz-KDNP EPP delegation, I voted in favour of the report, since it is in line with the Hungarian Government's efforts to provide on the spot to those who are actually in need and to the neighbouring states who are forced to escape as a result of the war. help.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. - The European Union has a stable and long-term relationship with the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan, a reliable partner in a very complicated region. In recent times, Jordan has been affected by the internal conflict in Syria and the refugee crisis, which has led to an additional influx of immigrants, to the Palestinian communities already existing on the territory of the country as a result of the Israeli-Arab conflicts. Under these circumstances, the stability of the Jordanian state is critical to avoiding the expansion of crises in the Middle East. In this respect, the EU, through the Commission, has decided to provide macro-financial assistance worth EUR 200 million for the period 2016-2017, in order to support the vulnerable Jordanian economy. This assistance is subscribed to international support for the region in the context of the Syrian conflict. Jordan has made significant progress in recent years towards democratising political and social life, making it compatible with this kind of aid. The EU is also Jordan's second trading partner and is expected to conclude a Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Agreement (DCFTA) with the country. In these circumstances, I believe that this is a necessary measure to support democracy in the Middle East, and I support the adoption of this resolution.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the text of my colleague Maurel. In the face of the economic difficulties facing Jordan, the European Union must demonstrate its support for its partner, whose refugee policy forces respect. We therefore hope that the macro-financial assistance programme will be effective as soon as possible, so that it will effectively benefit Jordan at this decisive moment. Finally, we suggest that the European Commission demonstrate flexibility and intelligence when negotiating the “Memorandum of Understanding” with the Jordanian authorities and working, in relevant international forums or through concrete actions, to find solutions that would alleviate the Jordanian debt burden, in full explosion.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Recently, Jordan has asked for international support in order to cope with the economic and financial consequences of the crisis in Syria and the 1.3 million Syrian refugees Jordan has absorbed. I voted in favour of the proposal for new Micro-Financial Assistance to Jordan of up to EUR 200 million, in the form of loans. I believe the MFA to Jordan is necessary and is much needed in order to assist Jordan on its path to reform, as well as to handle the effects of the war in Syria. Jordan remains one of the last stabilising factors in the region and an EU ally, and the EU must do everything in our power to assure that this status quo does not change.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Jordan is one of the countries bordering Syria, which is bearing the greatest burden for the influx of migrants and the management of the ongoing humanitarian crisis. In the country, according to November estimates, there are roughly 1.3 million Syrian refugees. This extraordinary influx of migrants is straining the economic and social fabric of the country. The vast majority of migrants are in fact not allocated in refugee camps but in Jordanian cities. In recent months there has been a significant worsening of living conditions of welcoming communities that are no longer able to access essential goods and services such as water, electricity and services sanitary ware. Also, the school system is collapsing. As the European Union we have a duty to assist Jordan by guaranteeing it funds to manage the emergency. Clearly, the provision of this economic aid must correspond to respect certain democratic guarantees such as the rule of law, respect for democracy and respect for human rights.

name: Ivica Tolić (PPE)
text: written. - I support the Report on the Proposal for a Decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the provision of further macro-financial assistance to the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan. Unrest in the region has significantly hit Jordan's economy based on services and industry. Growth has slowed (2.4%), the unemployment rate is 14.6%, and the decline in tourism and the inflow of foreign direct investment continued. Despite the above, Jordan, alongside Libya, accepted the highest number of Syrian refugees who were guaranteed easier access to jobs. Since the agreement was concluded in 1997. Jordan became the trading partner of the European Union, and in 2010 received the status of “advanced partner”, the Union has a duty to provide macro-financial assistance. The more so if they take into account their policy of accepting refugees. For these reasons, I voted for the above report.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - I have supported the draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council providing further macro-financial assistance to the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan. By its geographical position, Jordan is one of the countries most affected by the Syrian crisis. Since 2011, its economy, based primarily on service activities and industry, has been heavily influenced by unrest that has shaken the region. Despite internal problems, Jordan has taken in many refugees and pledged to help Syrians to easier employment. This is respectful and the EU must give its partner all the support. Jordan recently entered into an even closer partnership with the European Union, its second trading partner. The desire is for financial assistance to begin to be implemented immediately, since Jordan is really in crisis and difficult times.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted abstention because the initiative itself seems positive and necessary, but it has been approached from an angle which makes it very unlikely to achieve its objectives, and which implies a significant risk that aid will indeed have a counterproductive effect. The aim of this aid is to provide an oxygen balloon to Jordan in view of the fact that its economy has been one of the major victims of the war in Syria. The decline in income, coupled with the massive influx of refugees, has contributed to a significant increase in external debt. Hence the macro-financial aid initiative we have voted on. The reason why I doubt whether this aid will provide real support for the Jordanian economy and society is that the instrument is linked to IMF lending programmes which, as a condition, impose the implementation of neo-liberal structural reforms. These reforms, together with a possible increase in debt, can have long-term negative consequences and were not the best available option.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR)
text: in writing. - This report sets out the financial assistance under the EU Association Agreement with the Kingdom of Jordan through a loan of EUR 200 million. The liberal-conservative reformers support this against the backdrop of the crisis in Syria and the importance of Jordan's achievements in the refugee problem. This assistance is an important part of the geopolitical stabilisation of the region. The Jordanian royal family is also internationally recognised and the country has demonstrated its willingness to reform in the past. Thus, despite the high debt ratio of 93.4% of GDP (as of 2015), the loan makes sense and I was able to endorse the report.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: Jordan faces an influx of 1.3 million Syrian refugees. The costs covered would amount to $6.6 billion since 2011. It is normal to help Jordan, which is taking a large share of the burden on Syrian migrants. The EU loan of EUR 200 million is legitimate. Only black dots: the IMF and the EU are calling for structural adjustments. The Jordanian economy is in serious financing difficulties, but nevertheless needs this assistance. These loans are subject to the establishment of rules imposed from the outside in contradiction with the current state of Jordanian society. If these rules are applied too rigorously and without measure (Amendments 1-3 or 4), this is potentially dangerous to the stability of that country. I therefore abstained on this joint resolution.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: in writing. — Conflicts ongoing in Jordan's neighbours, Iraq and Syria have had a major impact on the country's economy. At a conference on support for Syria and surrounding regions in London, the EU pledged to donate €2.39 billion to countries affected by the refugee crisis in Syria, as well as provide a €200 million loan for macro-financial assistance to Jordan. The payment of EU macro-financial assistance will be dealt with by the Commission and will implement it in accordance with agreements or agreements concluded between the International Monetary Fund and Jordan, as well as on the basis of the main principles and objectives of economic reforms set out in the Association Agreement between The EU and Jordan, the Single Support Framework for 2014-2017, as well as the Partnership Priorities for the Future. It is worth recognizing the efforts of the Kingdom of Jordan in accepting refugees from Syria, as well as tackling the challenges that providing support to them. We have also repeatedly stated that such support is conditional on the proper use of funds by the State. That's why I voted yes.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted abstention because the initiative itself seems positive and necessary, but it has been approached from an angle which makes it very unlikely to achieve its objectives, and which implies a significant risk that aid will indeed have a counterproductive effect. The aim of this aid is to provide an oxygen balloon to Jordan in view of the fact that its economy has been one of the major victims of the war in Syria.
