The decline in income, coupled with the massive influx of refugees, has contributed to a significant increase in external debt. Hence the macro-financial aid initiative we have voted on. The reason why I doubt whether this aid will provide real support for the Jordanian economy and society is that the instrument is linked to IMF lending programmes which, as a condition, impose the implementation of neo-liberal structural reforms. These reforms, together with a possible increase in debt, can have long-term negative consequences and were not the best available option.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council providing further macro-financial assistance to the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan. Owing to its geographical location, Jordan is one of the countries most directly affected by the Syrian crisis. Since 2011, its economy, based mainly on services and industry, has been significantly affected by the ongoing regional unrest. Lower levels of tourism and foreign direct investment, blocked trade routes and repeated disruptions to the flow of natural gas from Egypt have put a drag on Jordan’s growth and weighed on its fiscal position. Despite the difficult circumstances, Jordan has taken in a large number of displaced persons. Together with Lebanon, it has welcomed more refugees in proportion to its population than any other country in the world. Jordan has a young but increasingly close partnership with the European Union, its second largest trading partner. I voted in favour because I believe that the EU must show support for its partner, whose policy of welcoming refugees is commendable.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Jordan has been severely affected by the Syrian crisis. In recent years, regional turmoil and the disruption of various commercial routes, there has been a massive influx of refugees that has caused great imbalances in its economy, already surprised by the obvious security risks that the country has been forced to deal with. Jordan currently hosts some 1.3 million Syrians and, despite the efforts of its authorities, the persistence of conflicts in the region had resulted in an escalation of their situation. In view of this scenario, the Union has turned to support Jordan, granting it a first macro-financial assistance package of EUR 180 million in 2013. This proposal now includes the loan of EUR 200 million under a second macro-financial aid operation. As a member of the Delegation for Relations with the Mashreq Countries and being fully aware that, in view of the effects of the Syrian crisis, Jordan requires clear support from the Union, with my vote I supported this proposal for a decision to grant it that support.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The 'macro-financial aid' to Jordan is nothing other than the Union's intermediation in a private credit of up to EUR 350 million as a counterpart to an IMF adjustment programme, which will impose further cuts on labour rights and the public budget of Jordan's fragile economy. I believe that the imposition of new neoliberal policies will only increase instability in the region politically. That is why I voted against.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: — I voted in favour because less tourism and lower inflow of foreign direct investment (FDI), blocked trade routes and repeated disruptions in the supply of natural gas from Egypt have put a brake on growth and weighted on the budgetary position of Jordan.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: The proposal is to increase the value of macro-financial assistance to Jordan by 150 million, that is to say a total value of 'EUR 350 million', which 'must include a timetable for the fulfilment of financial conditions'. This type of assistance typically has associated demands for 'structural and macroeconomic reforms', which we repudiate. Instead, we support the principle of cooperation and genuine development aid, which must be deepened, while respecting the sovereign will and choices of each State, free from the conditions or impositions of reform, aimed primarily at imposing a model based on liberalisation, economic life. and the social and social of countries.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: in writing. — Due to its geographical location, Jordan is one of the countries most directly affected by the crisis in Syria. Jordan assumes disproportionate responsibility in the region and is suffering major losses in tourism. The proposal now before us provides macro-financial assistance to Jordan amounting to EUR 350 million. I believe that this financial aid should be provided to the Kingdom and that is why I have supported this report.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on macro-financial assistance to Jordan, which, because of its geographical position, is one of the countries most directly affected by Syrian crisis. In this difficult context, however, the country is distinguished by important welcoming policies towards refugees and recent progress at the democratic level (introduction of a constitutional court and the an independent electoral commission). That is why the European Union must demonstrate its support for its partner, through the appropriation of a medium- and long-term loan managed by the Commission of EUR 200 million (of which 100 million at the end of 2016 and 100 million in Q2 2017).

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Jordan has taken on the enormous task of hosting hundreds of thousands of refugees from Syria and Iraq. I welcome the fact that the EU is now issuing financial assistance to Jordan to support these efforts. While we support this current move, the Socialist and Democrats believe that this financial assistance should be even greater than that which has been proposed, and we await the Commission and Council proposals regarding a substantial increase.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted for the report on EUR 350 million macro-financial assistance to Jordan, which aims to stabilise the country's economic stabilisation and a consistent reform agenda. Jordan is one of the countries directly affected by the crisis in Syria, and since 2011 its economy, mainly based on services and industry, has been clearly affected by the turmoil that is shaking the region. In its difficult context, Jordan is distinguished by the fact that it hosts a large number of displaced persons. Along with Lebanon, Jordan is the country that has received the most refugees compared to the number of inhabitants and has committed itself to facilitating access to the labour market for Syrians located on its territory. Jordan is engaged in a partnership, recently but ever closer, with the European Union, which is its second trading partner.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ Since 2011, the EU has allocated more than 500 million euros to Jordan in bilateral cooperation programmes that fall within the sphere of European Neighbourhood Policy. In addition, the Commission has provided an additional EUR 600 million to meet the challenge of Syrian immigrants and refugees. Despite the sums mentioned above, in June the European Commission proposed an additional €200 million in the form of macro financial assistance (MFA). Surely Jordan, due to its geographical situation, is one of the countries most touched by the Syrian crisis resulting in a reduction of tourism, foreign investment, blocking of trade routes and upheaval on access to natural gas imposed by Egypt. Economic growth slowed by 2.4% in 2015 with an unemployment rate of 14.6% in 2016. To date there are more than 650 thousand Syrian refugees who are in the urban centers charged by the Jordanian administration both in terms of transport, health and education. Although I am hesitant about the use of the MFA instrument and the effective control of the funds on the spot, I thought it appropriate to cast a positive vote, giving a signal of support to the Jordanian Government.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: in writing. — Jordan is our long-term strategic partner in the fight against terrorism and, above all, a stable country in an otherwise unstable region. Moreover, Jordan has borne the huge burden of the refugee crisis in recent years, even though it is itself in severe economic problems. Despite this fact, I consider Jordan to be a country that is setting its policy of accepting refugees by example to others. I therefore support this report because I believe that Jordan is more than deserving of financial assistance from the European Union. Personally, I had the opportunity to visit Jordan a few months ago, and I was able to get acquainted with the conditions that prevail in the camps and towns there. I was surprised above all by the poverty of what refugees live in. Essential things like food, hygiene supplies and clothing are missing. Given all the problems Jordan is exposed to, the European Union should demonstrate its support to its partner.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing. - I supported the resolution on providing further macro-financial assistance to the Kingdom of Jordan. Jordan is a country that deserves our admiration for many reasons. Although Jordan's economy is significantly marked by conflict in Iraq and Syria, Jordan has been able to accept and care for a number of refugees from conflict areas. That is why he was provided with financial assistance to cope with the situation. This assistance is tied to meeting the conditions set out, such as achieving the objectives of key reforms. Since Jordan has been an important partner of the European Union for a long time, and since 2002 it has established a free trade area with the EU, followed by other agreements, I think that providing macro-financial assistance is the right step. It will not only support the country's democratic direction, but also make it clear that the European Union appreciates Jordan's efforts to help refugees.

name: Željana Zovko (PPE)
text: written. - I support the report on the Proposal for a Decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the provision of further macro-financial assistance to the Kingdom of Jordan in the amount of $200 million, because I believe it is a responsible decision to financially assist a state that has expressed willingness to accept a large number of refugees from war-affected areas. The European Union must build quality partnership relations with all countries in a closer, further and interested neighbourhood. Jordan received a large number of refugees during the refugee crisis, according to the latest United Nations data, as many as 650,000 registered persons, and estimates point out that there are only one million and 400 thousand Syrians who are not registered. Jordan is a small state dependent on international aid that even before the refugee crisis was in a difficult financial situation, lack of resources and water that is important for farmland farming. According to statistics, Jordan belongs to the 10 driest countries in the world. The European Union has an obligation to this country and is obliged, at least financially, to try to depreciate and eliminate the damage arising from Jordan's accommodation on the world map. However, assistance should be focused on concrete development projects and incentives, as well as institutional construction.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted for the Report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council providing further macro-financial assistance to the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan. Jordan's economy has suffered extensive damage from ongoing unrest in the region. Along with the deteriorating global environment, these regional unrest had an extremely negative impact on external revenues and depleted public finances. In addition, the Jordanian economy is also affected by a large influx of Syrian refugees, increasing pressure on its fiscal position, public services and infrastructure. Since Jordan is a country covered by the ENP — European Neighbourhood Policy, it should be considered a beneficiary of the Union's macro-financial assistance. For the above reasons, I support the granting of macro-financial assistance in the form of loans of up to EUR 200 million to support economic stabilisation and reform implementation.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, firstly I want to say that I supported this proposal and I would like to compliment my Irish and EPP colleague, Brian Hayes, the rapporteur, who did an excellent job on this report. His belief that the directive would promote the development of safe and adequate occupational pension provision systems across the Member States is correct. There is no doubt that the ensuing innovation and good governance will contribute towards ensuring sufficient retirement provisions for all, which they need and deserve. This report outlines the ways and means by which pension schemes may move to another Member State so that the funds can get a better return for their beneficiaries. From an Irish perspective, I can appreciate the number of citizens that the directive stands to benefit, given the many Irish citizens who work elsewhere within the EU. Such efforts are essential in facilitating the development of occupational retirement savings. I therefore welcome the recommendations offered in this report and congratulate my colleague, Mr Hayes, once again.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ This revision of the Pension Funds Directive (IORP II) aims to eliminate the current prudential barriers to promote the creation of a single European market for funds private pension. It is therefore proposed to remove the restrictions under national social security and labour legislation in order to ensure that these funds have greater freedom to invest in the whole of the territory of the Union, resulting in risks and complications in terms of the safety of savings and the protection of the rights of beneficiaries. The aim is therefore to encourage further expansion of private funds to replace the public pension system, which is made unsustainable by the policies of rigour and the effects of the crisis over the public finances. To avoid the risk of citizens” retirement savings being endangered by speculative finance, I voted unfavourably.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal for a directive because it aims to improve the transparency and governance of institutions providing employment pensions for retirement (Pillar 2), normally linked to social and common partners in countries such as Germany and the Netherlands. The Commission proposal also seeks to create cross-border funds, which is positive within the framework of a genuine internal market within the Union.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because, although it contains positive points which improve the present transnational functioning of pensions, it maintains the approach of treating them as mere financial products. There are many problems for cross-border pensions which this directive seeks to solve, especially those linked to the financial risk to which this type of funds may be subject. This report addresses many of these problems; it improves transparency and mandatory information to beneficiaries, includes environmental risks in the scope of application, etc. However, the report maintains the focus of financing pensions, including the possibility of financing and participating in risky financial mechanisms, such as the EFSI bonds. It is because of this basic approach, and despite sharing the need for some of the improvements developed, I have not been able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Martina Anderson Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We abstained in the vote on this report, the Commission proposal and the legislative resolution. The report is on the Commission’s proposal to review the Institution for Occupation Retirement Provision Directive (IORPs) to create IOPRsII, which aims to improve the cross-border activities of the pension funds and ensure mobility for workers. The report amends the Commission’s proposal to integrate new requirements on risk, transparency and governance. There are positive aspects to the report, including criticism of the level of control responsibilities assigned to Member States; a call for a bigger role of the risk analysis on an investment decision; and calls for social and environmental risks to be included in the risk analysis carried out by pension funds. However, the underlying premise of both the Commission proposal and this report is that pension funds are financial products that should be treated as market goods in the EU financial markets instead of treating them as people’s retirement savings that should be carefully protected. The key aim of the proposal is to enhance the mobility of these products in order to ensure a more mobile market for trade in these financial products. For these reasons we abstained.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on the activities and supervision of bodies regulating the directive in charge of occupational retirement provision. It should be noted that, in order to further facilitate the mobility of workers between Member States, the aim of this Directive is to ensure good governance of the occupational pension scheme, the provision of information to members of the scheme, transparency and the security of occupational retirement provision. This Directive should facilitate the development of new and innovative pension products in collective schemes aimed at ensuring adequate pensions for all. It is important that the procedures enabling institutions to carry out cross-border activities should be clarified and that unnecessary obstacles to such cross-border activities should be removed. By facilitating cross-border activities under the relevant Union prudential framework, a positive impact on the undertakings concerned and their employees, irrespective of the Member State in which they are employed, since occupational retirement activities would be led centrally. I believe that this is the right step towards greater protection of the interests of EU citizens, which will also contribute to the creation of an even closer internal market.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the activities and supervision of institutions providing occupational retirement provision services, as this recast was and represents an essential step towards the direction of an internal market for occupational retirement provision organised on a European scale.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In response to the financial crisis, the ageing of the population, the increase in the amount invested in capitalised occupational retirement, and the ability of the sector to invest in long-term assets, the Commission proposed a redesign of IORP1 in 2014 which presents several dangers: the establishment of a single market for the Occupational retirement which will allow IRPs to offer their products in all Member States by removing regulatory barriers that hinder border activities. This will give a definite advantage to European countries with long experience with pension funds, particularly the Benelux, whose financial centres have already anticipated the benefits that this new European market could offer; new rules for the placement of dangerous assets that will promote risk-taking for institutions that do not have the financial and human means to make these investments; introduction of rules allowing the creation of European pension funds on the American model, with the risks that the latest financial crisis has uncovered; desire to gradually replace pensions by breakdown pensions by capitalisation pension schemes rejected by the French. I therefore voted against it.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution because it aims to consolidate and increase the powers of the European Commission and impose new requirements on Member States.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this text, which provides for continued efforts towards the establishment of an internal market for occupational pension schemes at European level. This directive is of the interest of proposing minimum harmonisation in this area in order to further facilitate the mobility of workers between Member States.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: in writing. — The proposal concerns the coordination of activities and supervision of IORPs at European level. 'IORP' means an institution which, irrespective of its legal form, operates on a funded basis, is set up separately from any sponsoring undertaking or professional organisation and whose purpose is in relation to the gainful activity provision of retirement benefits. This is part of the so-called three-pillar pension system, the introduction of which, in particular due to the funded part of the present proposal, the International Monetary Fund sought to impose on all countries to which it granted loans in the 1990s. The essence of this pension system is the reduction of state liability (less public pensions), the compulsory provision of self-care through private insurers (that is, the diversion of pension payments from the state to private insurers). What the report wants is to generalise the funded system in such a way that any private pension fund can provide services anywhere in this hedging scheme — of course, under EU security legislation. The whole point is, of course, that most of the pension payments, apart from a minimum amount paid to the state, can be included in international financial speculation, as the report clearly shows. In view of all this, I voted against this motion.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: This revision of the directive proposes to support the development of a European occupational retirement market and deregulate existing standards to copy the so-called American model of pension funds. The text also supports the creation of a single market for occupational retirement, and there are many risks: advantageous regulation for large investment funds, rules for investing too risky assets or promoting capitalization pensions. I voted against it.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Commission's proposal to improve the governance and transparency of occupational pension institutions in Europe, promote cross-border activities and encourage long-term investment. The Commission has struck the right balance between strengthening national regimes and respecting national discretion. The development of cross-border ones. The IRPs (Institute for Occupational Retirement) will continue to be based on national social and occupational standards recognising the specificities of national schemes. They will be monitored at national level and no European supervision is created. At the same time, the text encourages the development of cross-border arrangements that must be coupled with provisions preventing regulatory arbitration.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: ‒ Today I voted in favour of the Hayes report on the activity and supervision of occupational pension institutions. The approved text sets out new measures to optimise the savings mechanisms for occupational pensions, promoting cooperation between Member States and the social partners. The overall objective of the proposal is to facilitate pension savings within the Union by strengthening the contribution it makes to pension income. A nodal point is the definition of clear and transparent procedures to enable pension institutions to carry out cross-border activities, while improving their discipline and transparency and strengthening the internal market. The proposal increases the ability of the European economy to funnel long-term savings into growth-boosting investments and enhances the role of EPAPs as institutional investors in the economy real. The text also sets out structural actions to ensure equality of pension levels between women and men across the EU, while also promoting intergenerational balance in pension schemes.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I abstained from this report, as it is Parliament's contribution to the process of recasting the directive on the second pillar of pensions. These pensions are those resulting from an agreement between the company and the employees, with the employer contributing to a fund created specifically for it. It is therefore a system halfway between the public pension system and private pension funds, a system that is more widespread in countries such as the United Kingdom and the Netherlands. While we understand that in some cases these funds are a trade union conquest, and that it is positive for consumers that progress is made towards greater standardization and the possibility of transferring rights from one country to another, we are opposed to the fact that pension funds are considered as a mere financial service. We also find it worrying that the creditworthiness requirements in these funds are relaxed compared to others.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported this report by Mr Hayes on the activities and supervision of employment pension funds. The agreement provides that the scope of application shall be employment pension funds. Where, in accordance with their national legislation, they do not have legal personality, Member States shall apply the Directive to the funds, or to the authorised entities responsible for managing them and acting on their behalf.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: in writing. — I opposed this report, as well as the Commission's proposal, which support the creation of a single market for occupational retirement. I am certainly aware of the stakes surrounding occupational retirement institutions, since there are currently 125,000 occupational pension funds throughout the European Union, which hold EUR 2 500 billion in assets on behalf of 75 million Europeans. I note some good ideas on the part of the Commission, such as the obligation to control remuneration, a better assessment of risks and the improvement of information for savers. However, behind his good intentions is the real desire to deregulate existing standards in favor of the emergence of an “American” model, which will have the real consequences of giving preference to large investment funds and rules for investing too risky assets, but also, and above all, this will lead to the promotion of capitalization pension systems and thus ultimately a challenge to national segregated pension systems. It is a debate that we are entitled to have, but at the national level, and not imposed by Brussels in order to realize its dream of Americanization of Europe.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: In writing. ‒ The text of the Hayes report analysing the proposal for a directive on the activities and supervision of occupational pension institutions, is poorly balanced and not shareable. I believe that this measure will pave the way for new private entities from foreign countries who will be able to enter our internal market, adding a further piece to the dismantling of national welfare programmed and orchestrated by the EU. For all these reasons I voted against this measure.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. - With my vote I supported this proposal for a directive in order to improve the transparency and governance of institutions providing employment pensions for retirement, normally linked to social and common partners in countries such as Germany or the Netherlands. The proposal also facilitates cross-border activities of employment pension funds and the transfer of pension schemes to remove unnecessary obstacles to them.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report because it expressed Parliament its position on the directive on the activities and supervision of institutions responsible for occupational retirement provision. The general objective of this Directive is to facilitate occupational pensions. During the economic and financial crisis in previous years, many Member States have been under great pressure on first-tier pension systems in particular. Therefore, pension benefits have to be reduced in different countries. In addition, societies in all Member States are ageing. At the same time, the number and birth rate of the working age population decreases, young people study longer and integrate into the labour market for older age. In this context, more Member States should consider creating additional postgraduate pension schemes which should contribute to greater security of pension benefits. However, given the experience of the economic and financial crisis, good rules of supervision and governance really give people great confidence in their pension system and encourage them to participate in such a system. The recast of this Directive should therefore be useful in encouraging Member States to develop occupational pension schemes in which people can trust.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: in writing. -I think it is important that older people and people with disabilities are not at risk of poverty and that they can live at a decent standard of living. An important element in the fight against poverty and uncertainty among older people is that occupational pensions provide adequate protection against biometric risks. When setting up a pension scheme, employers and employees or their representatives should consider the possibility of encompassing the achievement of a high age and the risk of work-related disability and surviving also to provide a relative's pension. I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: in writing. - I agree with the proposal for a directive on the activities and supervision of institutions for occupational pension insurance, and I also supported it at the plenary session, since I believe that in the internal market institutions should be able to operate in other Member States and at the same time ensure a high degree of protection of occupational insurance pension plans. It is necessary to ensure minimum harmonisation which Member States can upgrade. I welcome the action on the way to the internal market to provide occupational pension insurance organised on a European scale, as it is crucial for economic growth and job creation in the European Union, as well as tackling the challenges arising from an ageing European society.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: written. - I support this Report, as it is a step forward towards creating a single market for the EU pension scheme, which is not the case today.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution on activities and supervision of institutions for occupational retirement provision because it represented a more straightforward codification of the existing legislative acts and did not add any changes in substance. This better codification is important because the issue of the national pension systems concerns many Europeans due to the average age of our society.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Across the EU it is necessary to adapt pension systems to ensure adequate, safe and sustainable pensions. The proposal for revision of Directive 2003/41/EC on the activities of EPAP will ensure better discipline and transparency of institutions, as well as an increase in their cross-border activity, strengthening the internal market. Some occupational or occupational pension institutions are large financial institutions and their failure could affect financial stability. Cross-border occupational or occupational pension institutions are currently rare; however cross-border EPAPs can account for an increasing share of corporate pension schemes and professional. The revision of the directive is intended to enhance the ability of EPAPs to invest in long-term activities and to support the financing of sustainable growth in the real economy. Without an updated regulatory framework at EU level, Member States are likely to continue to develop different solutions, exacerbating regulatory fragmentation. The overall objective of the proposal is to facilitate pension savings, thereby strengthening the contribution that savings earmarked for supplementary pensions makes to retirement income. The proposal will also improve EPAP as institutional investors in the real economy and strengthen the ability of the European economy to funnel long-term savings into investments that stimulate growth.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. - The sector of institutions for occupational retirement provision is developing in many Member States where occupational pensions played a limited role to date, including regulatory frameworks. Higher standards of governance are needed, reflecting national best practices following the economic and financial crisis, to protect the members and beneficiaries of schemes and facilitate safe cross-border provision of pensions. Regulatory divergences, overlapping requirements and excessively burdensome cross-border procedures must be reduced. These elements are barriers to the development of cross-border occupational pension markets. Reducing these obstacles will help businesses, including SMEs and multinational firms, organise their European pension provision activities more effectively. I voted in favour of this report, bearing in mind that safer and more efficient occupational pensions will contribute to the adequacy and viability of pensions by increasing the contribution of complementary pension savings to pension income.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal for a directive because it aims to improve the transparency and governance of institutions providing employment pensions for retirement (Pillar 2), normally linked to social and common partners in countries such as Germany and the Netherlands. The Commission proposal also seeks to create cross-border funds, which is positive within the framework of a genuine internal market within the Union.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: On 27 March 2014, the Commission proposed a recast of Directive 2003/41/EC on the activities and supervision of occupational retirement institutions (pension funds). The objective of this revision is to modernize the legislation on pension funds to make it more accurately in line with demographic changes and, in particular, to the ageing of the population. In addition, pension funds were severely affected by the economic and financial crisis of 2008. It was important to put in place a regulatory framework that strengthens their resilience. A pension fund is an investment fund that invests the retirement savings of many employees to make it fruitful. It is essential to ensure their good governance. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of this report because it encourages Member States to need regulation at national and EU level for the safe provision of pensions professional or corporate. It is important that Member States pursue the objective of ensuring intergenerational balance in pension schemes and to increase the protection of the rights of European citizens which for reasons jobs are located in another member country. The report indicates the need for appropriate measures to optimise savings for occupational pensions and proposes the adoption of measures to support Member States' cooperation with the Parties social and structural actions to ensure equality of pension levels between women and men across Europe. The functioning of the internal market in this sector must be improved through clear procedures enabling institutions to carry out cross-border activities as well.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this Report as I believe that this directive will facilitate the development of new and innovative pension products that aim to guarantee adequate retirement provisions for all. It aims to clarify the procedures enabling institutions to carry out cross-border activity and remove unnecessary obstacles which hinder cross-border activity. It also increases transparency of information to pension scheme members and beneficiaries and improves the supervision of pension funds and lays down new rules for cross-border activities and transfers.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ The implicit objective of the revision of the Pension Funds Directive (IORP II) is clearly to promote the further expansion and profitability of private funds so that private funds can be taken progressively the place of the public pension system, made unsustainable by the policies of rigour and the effects of the crisis on public finances. Finding strong concerns about the impact of the new rules on citizens' pension savings, which would be heavily exposed to systemic risks related to speculative finance, I expressed down vote.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: in writing. - We support the report aimed at facilitating the development of savings for occupational retirement.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted on the report on the activities and supervision of institutions providing occupational retirement provision services. This is an attempt to specialize specific conditions governing pension provision services. As I consider that the report does not focus sufficiently on strengthening the public pension scheme, I have decided to abstain.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: In writing. — Since demographic developments in the Union and the situation of national budgets require it, I express my favour for the report. In fact, occupational or occupational pensions are a valuable integration of the social security pension system, but they cannot replace them given their fundamental importance to the provision of adequate, safe and sustainable pension benefits. Member States should ensure the social protection of workers with regard to pensions by providing public pensions enabling them to maintain a decent standard of living and to be protected from poverty in old age and by promoting supplementary pension schemes related to employment contracts as supplementary coverage. The directive is not subject to substantial changes and aims not only at establishing strict prudential rules to provide and protect adequate and comprehensive information to be provided to members and beneficiaries of funds, but also to the implementation of cross-border activities. In the future, we will therefore be able to talk about pan-European pension funds thanks to minimal harmonisation, which will not prevent Member States from adopting further prudential provisions.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the activities and supervision of institutions for occupational retirement provision.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. - Institutions for occupational retirement provision (IORPs) play an important role in the long-term financing of the European economy. Europe is faced with an ageing population in all Member States. Life expectancy varies throughout Europe, but the trend towards an increase in life expectancy is general, as well as an increase in the number of pensioners living longer and in good health. In view of this situation, countries should consider setting up supplementary pensions under the second pillar. However, these plans should be developed without jeopardising the importance of social security pension schemes in terms of safe, lasting and effective social protection. I support the Hayes report, as I agree with the need to clarify the rules applicable to the activity and transfers of cross-border pension schemes, and between Member States, with the aim of providing security to the institutions that intend to manage such pension schemes. I support the need to ensure good governance and risk management, provide clear and relevant information to members and beneficiaries and ensure that supervisors have the necessary tools to oversee IORPs.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this measure because the text provides for minimal harmonisation in this matter and should therefore not prevent Member States from maintaining or adopting provisions supplementary to protect members and beneficiaries of occupational or occupational pension schemes, provided that these provisions are consistent with the obligations of Member States in virtue of EU law. The measure then addresses correctly the issue of worker mobility between Member States by aiming to ensure sound governance and proper information of the members of the scheme pension.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the call for Member States to be equipped with sufficient flexibility to implement and regulate the requirements set out in this directive in a way that reflects the wide variety of pension systems in Europe. We need to ensure that our national systems are organised, all in the best interest of members and beneficiaries. I am in favour of minimum harmonisation which does not preclude Member States from maintaining or introducing further provisions to protect members and beneficiaries, if such provisions are consistent with Member States’ obligations under Union law. I believe we need to look more at the human element in such instances whereby institutions would not be treated as purely financial service providers as they serve an important social function due to the central role played by social partners in the running of the institutions. Hence a national minimum pension which does not fall below the risk-of-poverty threshold would be in line with this principle. Therefore, a recast of this directive under the condition that it has the right focus and does not introduce unnecessary burdens is a step in the right direction.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because, although it contains positive points which improve the present transnational functioning of pensions, it maintains the approach of treating them as mere financial products. There are many problems for cross-border pensions which this directive seeks to solve, especially those linked to the financial risk to which this type of funds may be subject. This report addresses many of these problems; it improves transparency and mandatory information to beneficiaries, includes environmental risks in the scope of application, etc. However, the report maintains the focus of financing pensions, including the possibility of financing and participating in risky financial mechanisms, such as the EFSI bonds. It is because of this basic approach, and despite sharing the need for some of the improvements developed, I have not been able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the text of a directive on the activities of occupational institutions, pension schemes and supervision of such institutions (IORPs). The drafted text takes into account the principle of proportionality and emphasises that pensions are the competence of the Member States. The directive focuses on provisions relating to the cross-border aspect of IORP. The Directive covers the protection of IORP members and eligible persons who must be sufficiently informed of the rules of the pension scheme. The provisions of the current directive are designed to ensure the protection of future pensioners, members of pension schemes and eligible persons and to safeguard the role of Member States in the actions taken.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ European society is ageing and pension systems across the European Union have to adapt in order to ensure sustainable pensions. The report identifies the complexity of the matter and seeks to address the challenges by a closely coordinated action by Member States and seeks to ensure safer and more efficient occupational pensions while reinforcing the capacity of the European economy to channel long-term savings to growth-enhancing investment. For this reason, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. - I consider it beneficial for Member States to grant prior authorisations to those institutions which decide to manage a scheme in another Member State on the basis of authorisations enabling institutions to collect contributions from undertakings established in any Member State. The management of pension schemes with members from several Member States must be carried out in full compliance with the provisions in force of the host Member State's social and labour legislation relating to occupational pension schemes, such as the establishment and payment of benefits pension and conditions for the transferability of pension rights. In order to ensure legal certainty for the cross-border activities of institutions, the scope of the prudential rules should be clarified.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: This codecision report aims to facilitate the development of occupational retirement savings. Considering that this new regulation improves the governance of pension funds, increases the transparency of information for pension plan members and beneficiaries, improves the supervision of pension funds and sets new rules for transfer activities and transfers, I have decided to support this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: I voted in favour of the proposal for a directive on the activities and supervision of occupational retirement institutions. With the ageing of populations, institutions, known as occupational retirement institutions, are developing which use financial markets to provide pension benefits. Since this phenomenon affects all the Member States of the Union, it is essential that we update the European regulatory framework for the supervision of these institutions. By achieving minimal harmonisation, in particular by clarifying the procedures for these institutions to carry out cross-border activities, we are increasing the protection of European citizens and promoting the development of the activities of these institutions throughout Europe.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. — The report sets out our proposals for non-harmonised EU solvency requirements and a lighter financing regime rather than the existing fully funded model. The text now allows for pre-financing periods, which is important because there are cases, such as mergers, which would prevent funds from being fully funded at any time. I therefore support the report on the Activities and supervision of institutions for occupational pension supervision.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: in writing. - It is a fact that in Greece the economic and financial crisis has resulted in a reduction in pensions paid. Countries applying a pay-as-you-go system, where pensions are paid from the current budget, face and will continue to experience particular difficulties in financing adequate pensions. We are therefore voting against the report by the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the activities and supervision of institutions providing occupational retirement provision services.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Hayes report on the Activities and Supervision of Institutions for Occupational Retirement Provision. I was satisfied with the content of the report in terms of the situation in Wales where we have had a number of instances of people losing the pension to which they have contributed for years. I was glad to see the obligation to include environmental and social assessments in the investment and risk management procedure, as well as increased transparency.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: in writing. ‒ Vote against: this directive may be part of a desire to gradually replace pensions by dividing pension by capitalisation schemes, which has always been rejected by the French.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The report states that 'the directive should ensure that institutions enjoy an appropriate level of freedom to invest', and institutions carrying out occupational retirement provision can invest in shares, multilateral trading systems, organised trading systems. It is also assumed that risk management is limited by quantitative requirements, and therefore it is essential to ensure an effective governance system. This means that pensions are at the mercy of the suitability of the manager and the performance of the products in which pension money is invested. In a scenario where the number of occupational pension schemes under defined contributions is increasing, this becomes potentially problematic and dangerous. On the other hand, the text put to the vote states that the investment rules imposed by Member States should allow the development of individual pension products within a collective system and should not impede the free movement of capital. Pension funds are not a banal financial product for us. We are against the creation of a single pension market and the establishment of European pension schemes.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal for a directive because I believe that facilitating retirement savings of a business or occupational nature helps to improve and ensure security of pension benefits. The text also provides adequate provisions on governance, supervision and transparency and ensuring pensioners have a regular informative consultation on the state of their systems pension schemes may help encourage individual Member States to define occupational or occupational pension systems (EPAP) that citizens can trust.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing. - The European Commission proposal aims to improve the governance and transparency of institutions which are tasked with providing occupational pensions, promoting cross-border activities and long-term investment in Europe. It is very important that the European Commission, in its proposal, think about maintaining a balance between strengthening national systems, respecting national discretion, while at the same time trying to encourage cross-border systems. The IORP will continue to build on national social and labour standards that recognise the specifics of national systems. They will be checked at national level and no European supervision is created.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: I vote against the report, a further piece for the dismantling of national welfare by the EU.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: in writing. - It is a fact that in Greece the economic and financial crisis has resulted in a reduction in pensions paid. Countries applying a pay-as-you-go system, where pensions are paid from the current budget, face and will continue to experience particular difficulties in financing adequate pensions. I am therefore voting against the report by the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the activities and supervision of institutions providing occupational retirement provision services.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the report, as it will improve the protection of members of occupational retirement schemes and will encourage the development of stable cross-border schemes. Member States should take into account the objective for all institutions of ensuring the intergenerational balance of occupational pension schemes, by aiming to have an equitable spread of risks and benefits between generations. I support, especially, the national social and labour provisions that focus on the protection of scheme members and introduce, at the same time, the concept of duty of care in order to avoid a regulatory race to the bottom through cross-border schemes.  For the first time in EU legislation, environmental, social and governance factors have been introduced concerning investment decision, by also avoiding stranded assets due to social and environmental risks through an ex-ante risk assessment. Last, but not least, taking into account that the gender pension gap in the Union is 39% on average, I am of the opinion that an extensive study is needed on the impact of different pillars, pensions systems and their structures on both women and men; to ensure equal levels of pensions for both women and men across the Member States.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report bearing in mind that employment pension funds vary significantly between the different Member States of the Union. It is therefore not appropriate to adopt a one-size-fits-all approach to employment pension funds. The Commission and the European Supervisory Authority (European Insurance and Retirement Pensions Authority) should take into account in the context of their activity the various traditions of the Member States, without prejudice to national social and labour legislation, when deciding on the organisation of employment pension funds.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal for a directive because it aims to improve the transparency and governance of institutions providing employment pensions for retirement (Pillar 2), normally linked to social and common partners in countries such as Germany and the Netherlands. The Commission proposal also seeks to create cross-border funds, which is positive within the framework of a genuine internal market within the Union.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal for a directive because it aims to improve the transparency and governance of institutions providing employment pensions for retirement (Pillar 2), normally linked to social and common partners in countries such as Germany and the Netherlands. The Commission proposal also seeks to create cross-border funds, which is positive within the framework of a genuine internal market within the Union.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This is an important report as IORPs (institutions for occupational retirement provision) play an important role in the long-term financing of the EU’s economies and in securing of retirement benefits. The financial importance of IORPs cannot be overstated as they have holding assets worth around EUR 2.5 trillion on behalf of around 75 million members and beneficiaries, a large percentage of the EU population. This directive aims to ensure that IORPs need to have the possibility to operate in other Member States while ensuring a high level of protection and security for their members and beneficiaries. It is important that this directive ensure that Member States shall make sure that members and beneficiaries are correctly informed about their respective pension scheme operated by an IORP. This is essential so that members of pension schemes have information on, for example, their financial risks, their investment profile, guarantees for the scheme and the options available to them.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of Parliament's resolution on the proposal for a EP and Council directive on the activities and supervision of occupational pension institutions (EPAP) ) — recast — because I believe that in the light of demographic trends in the EU and the situation of national budgets, EPAP pension institutions constitute an important integration of pension systems public. For this reason, these institutions should be given the opportunity to operate in other Member States, while ensuring a high degree of protection and above all safety of acceding entities to EPAP schemes. The cross-border operation of the same requires minimal harmonisation and above all European supervisory rules, while preserving the possibility for Member States to determine their organisation, according to different traditions and within the framework of their activities, respecting national law and social security and employment. I agree with the need for appropriate regulation and supervision at Union and national level, because these activities are of paramount importance if the rights of beneficiaries are to be protected. As I agree with the need for occupational or occupational pension schemes to take into account the intergenerational balance by aiming to ensure a fair sharing of risks and benefits in the pension benefits between generations.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: in writing. — For many people in Germany, occupational retirement provision is an indispensable part of their retirement provision. The effective supervision of the relevant facilities is all the more important. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: in writing. — In order to further advance the completion of the European internal market, it is also necessary to establish and open occupational pensions across Europe. This implies enabling cross-border occupational pension institutions that are subject to risk management. This also means the possibility of being able to pay off his age entitlements throughout Europe.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the IORP II Directive because it is essential that we have a properly functioning pensions system in place – including state pensions, workplace pensions and private provision – to ensure that people are well looked-after in retirement. The directive ensures that pension schemes are well-run and well-regulated, and that ordinary members of pension schemes have vital information about how their money is being spent and what they can hope to receive after they retire. And pension schemes will now have to make sure they are investing for the long term, considering the social and environmental implications of their investments, which is a major step forward.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI)
text: It is probably not innocent that a text on occupational pension funds was voted at the same session and another calling for the promotion of a European retail financial services market, including voluntary personal retirement savings. That is two of the three possible levels of old-age insurance, with public systems. The aim is to create a European occupational retirement market and to modify existing standards based on US pension funds, in particular by facilitating cross-border activities and international portfolios transfers within the Single Market, despite the diversity of social and labour rights. Of course, some concessions are made regarding prudential or governance rules, or information to savers. But all this does not compensate for the shortcomings of the text, especially the expansion of the asset classes in which these funds could invest, increasing risk. Nor fails to hide its underlying philosophy: the promotion of capitalisation pensions to the detriment of public systems by distribution. It is true that the sums at stake are huge and awaken many appetites. It is up to States, and States alone, to define the nature, extent, organization and functioning of their social protection.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I abstained from this report, as it is Parliament's contribution to the process of recasting the directive on the second pillar of pensions. These pensions are those resulting from an agreement between the company and the employees, with the employer contributing to a fund created specifically for it. It is therefore a system halfway between the public pension system and private pension funds, a system that is more widespread in countries such as the United Kingdom and the Netherlands. While we understand that in some cases these funds are a trade union conquest, and that it is positive for consumers that progress is made towards greater standardization and the possibility of transferring rights from one country to another, we are opposed to the fact that pension funds are considered as a mere financial service. We also find it worrying that the creditworthiness requirements in these funds are relaxed compared to others.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this directive because it ensures that pension schemes are well-run and well-regulated, and that ordinary members of pension schemes have vital information about how their money is being spent and what they can hope to receive after they retire. Pension schemes will now have to make sure they are investing for the long term, considering the social and environmental implications of their investments, which is a major step forward.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal for a directive because it aims to improve the transparency and governance of institutions providing employment pensions for retirement (Pillar 2), normally linked to social and common partners in countries such as Germany and the Netherlands. The Commission proposal also seeks to create cross-border funds, which is positive within the framework of a genuine internal market within the Union.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We abstained in the vote on the report since, although our group's amendments were not taken into account, the report was clearly better than its original form, particularly with regard to issues such as information given to beneficiaries, the environmental risk of investment, transparency and restriction of portfolio investment.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on the activities and supervision of institutions for occupational retirement, which is a redraft of the 2003 IORPS Directive to facilitate the development of occupational retirement pensions in the EU. A satisfactory report has been developed in terms of the key policy areas. In particular, I am pleased with the new structures for risk management and the removal of obstacles to cross-border provision of pension services and facilitation of cross-border transfer of schemes. All or part of the assets and liabilities of occupational pension schemes can now for the first time be transferred from one Member State to another

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour since I have no objections.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: in writing. - The proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the activities and supervision of institutions for occupational retirement provision aims to ensure a minimum level of harmonisation. The Directive aims to encourage Member States to develop occupational pension schemes and to remove prudential barriers for cross-border institutions for occupational retirement provision. This is, in my opinion, a step in the right direction. The activities of cross-border pension systems will be redefined. This creates more legal clarity. The possibility of transferring pension schemes across borders will increase efficiency. As the information and installation rules of the country of origin are to apply, administrative costs will also be reduced. For these reasons, I agree with the report.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that the EU should work on protecting the members of occupational retirement schemes and encourage the development of stable cross-border schemes.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written. - I voted in favour of a draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the activities and supervision of occupational pension institutions on the grounds that the proposal does not contain material changes but is limited only to codification without important modification. However, I consider that cross-border aspects of the pension system and the exchange of best practices between Member States and the availability of clear and relevant information for members and beneficiaries of the vocational pension scheme are extremely important. On top of that, it is necessary to ensure that supervisors have the necessary control instruments at their disposal, and therefore I support this report.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. — This revision of the directive proposes to support the development of a European occupational retirement market and to deregulate existing standards to copy the American model of pension funds. Naturally, there is a danger of advantageous regulation with respect to investment funds, rules for investing too risky assets and the promotion of capitalization pensions. The latter is obviously a first step towards challenging national pensions by breakdown. So I voted against it.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report by my colleague Brian Hayes on occupational retirement institutions. These institutions are organizations that provide employment-related pension benefits in parallel with public pension and social security systems. Benefiting from the principles of free movement of capital and freedom to provide, this report seeks to supervise these entities in order to guarantee a safe occupational pension system for citizens. To this end, the rapporteur calls for a healthier remuneration policy, the reduction of the pension gap between men and women and more transparency towards members. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report, which aims to facilitate the development of occupational retirement savings with a twofold objective of modernization and transparency. This legislation improves the governance of pension funds, increases the transparency of information to pension plan members and beneficiaries, improves the supervision of pension funds and sets new rules for transfer activities.

name: Εύα Καϊλή (S&D)
text: in writing. - Pension providers are not just financial institutions, but mainly actors serving an important social objective: ensuring the economic living conditions of people in old age. With demographic pressure and growing life expectancy, Member States are trying to find ways to ensure the sustainability of insurance schemes in the long term. Moreover, in view of the circumstances of the crisis that has affected Member States to varying degrees, leaving some of them in a more unfavourable comparative position, it is important that this directive ensures the greatest possible flexibility for each Member State in its specific circumstances.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: in writing. - This report relates to a revision of the Directive on the activities and supervision of institutions for occupational retirement provision. This will help to achieve minimum harmonisation of European pension systems in order to ensure the pension rights of European workers who have been employed in the meantime in EU countries other than their home country. Since a large number of workers also fall under this category and must be guaranteed an adequate, secure and sustainable pension, I am voting in favour of this report.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: in writing. - The proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the activities and supervision of institutions for occupational retirement provision aims to ensure a minimum level of harmonisation. The Directive aims to encourage Member States to develop occupational pension schemes and to remove prudential barriers for cross-border institutions for occupational retirement provision. This is, in my opinion, a step in the right direction. The activities of cross-border pension systems will be redefined. This creates more legal clarity. The possibility of transferring pension schemes across borders will increase efficiency. As the information and installation rules of the country of origin are to apply, administrative costs will also be reduced. For these reasons, I agree with the report.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: in writing. - If anything, pension systems are a typical case of a veterinary horse. While employees are expected by governments to plan their self-care for life, pension rules are constantly being changed, in some countries with some delay mechanisms, in others quite roughly. However, it would be legitimate and moral if the agreement between the individual and the state could be changed from the first working day of the employee only with his consent or, in the absence of it, for his benefit. No retirement age raising and trickery. The objective pursued in the report to include most of the pension payments in international financial speculation other than a minimum portion paid to the State is totally unacceptable. Moreover, trade unions rightly protested against the introduction of the three-pillar pension system in 1997.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: in writing. - I support the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the activities and supervision of institutions for occupational retirement provision. Given the demographic changes in the Union and the state of national budgets, occupational pension provision is an integral part of social security pension systems. A sustainable pension system includes a wide range of products, diversity of institutions, as well as effective and efficient supervisory practices duly mentioned in this Directive. The directive will strengthen the ability of occupational pension funds to invest in financial assets with a long-term economic profile and thus support the financing of growth in the real economy. The adoption of the directive will further facilitate the mobility of workers between Member States, ensuring good governance through transparency and safety.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour because the proposed directive will facilitate the development of occupational retirement savings. The EU and its Member States need to develop occupational retirement pension systems in which EU citizens can have confidence and which will function effectively in times of economic and financial crisis, ageing population, youth unemployment and shrinking population across Europe. Therefore, I call on the EU and in particular Member States to set up complementary second-pillar pension systems which should lead to more secure pension benefits and a more secure future for EU citizens.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted against this report because it proposes to support the development of a European occupational retirement market and to dismantle the retirement sector of social security to copy the American model of pension funds. Such a system would undoubtedly please François Fillon, and his LR MEPs who voted on it, but not to me.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted against the report on the activities and supervision of occupational retirement institutions. The Commission's objective is to establish a single market for occupational retirement which will allow all IORPs to offer their products in all Member States. The aim is, therefore, to remove regulatory barriers to border activities, which will give a definite advantage to countries with long experience in pension funds. In addition, the new asset investment rules are also dangerous because they encourage risk-taking for institutions that do not have the financial and human means to make such investments. And the quantitative prudential requirements requested are insufficient to insure the beneficiaries of supplementary pension plans. In the end, the aim of this revision of the directive is to introduce rules to allow the creation of European pension funds on the American model, with the risks that the latest financial crisis has uncovered. This directive can also be part of a desire to gradually replace pensions by dividend pensions by capitalization schemes, which has always been rejected by the French.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: This revision of the directive proposes to support the development of a European occupational retirement market and deregulate existing standards to copy the American model of pension funds. The text also supports the creation of a single market for occupational retirement, and there are many risks: advantageous regulation for large investment funds, rules for investing too risky assets or promoting capitalization pensions. I voted against it.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal for a directive because it aims to improve the transparency and governance of institutions providing employment pensions for retirement (Pillar 2), normally linked to social and common partners in countries such as Germany and the Netherlands. The Commission proposal also seeks to create cross-border funds, which is positive within the framework of a genuine internal market within the Union.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this proposal for a directive because it aims to improve the transparency and governance of institutions providing employment pensions for retirement (Pillar 2), normally linked to social and common partners in countries such as Germany and the Netherlands. The Commission proposal also seeks to create cross-border funds, which is positive within the framework of a genuine internal market within the Union.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: in writing. - The proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the activities and supervision of institutions for occupational retirement provision aims to ensure a minimum level of harmonisation. The Directive aims to encourage Member States to develop occupational pension schemes and to remove prudential barriers for cross-border institutions for occupational retirement provision. This is, in my opinion, a step in the right direction. The activities of cross-border pension systems will be redefined. This creates more legal clarity. The possibility of transferring pension schemes across borders will increase efficiency. As the information and installation rules of the country of origin are to apply, administrative costs will also be reduced. For these reasons, I agree with the report.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: written. - The report highlights that pension funds benefit from the free movement of capital within the EU, and the main objective of this proposal is to enable the development of professional pension savings. This proposal for the Directive aims to remove barriers to cross-border pension insurance, ensure good management and risk management, provide clear and relevant information for users the availability of the necessary tools to effectively monitor supervisors. In order to further facilitate the mobility of workers among Member States, this Directive seeks to ensure good governance, informing programme members, transparency and security of vocational pension insurance. This Directive should facilitate the development of new and innovative pension schemes within collective systems in order to guarantee everyone the right pension, and I have therefore supported this report.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The institutions for occupational retirement provision play an important role in the long-term financing of the Union’s economy and in providing secure retirement benefits for citizens of the Union. Member States should take into account the objective for all institutions of ensuring the intergenerational balance of occupational pension schemes, by aiming to have an equitable spread of risks and benefits between generations.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing - I supported the codification of the EP and Council Directive on the activities and supervision of occupational pension institutions, which sets out procedures for their cross-border activities. The aim of the Directive is to establish a minimum uniform harmonised legislation for all Member States. Systematic unification and adaptation of legal ratios in this area will increase clarity and clarity and thus simplify their application and interpretation.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing. - I am voting against the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the activities and supervision of institutions offering occupational retirement provision services for the reasons I explained in detail in my speech in plenary session European Parliament in Strasbourg on 23 November 2016, and also because this report is not complete and documented.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I expressed a favourable vote for the report on activities and supervision of institutions for occupational retirement provision. The report shows a list of benefits, which include, but are not limited to: improving pension funds’ governance, increasing transparency of information, enhancing supervision of pension funds, and creating a new set of rules. All of this plays a crucial role, as it will encourage the Institutions for Occupational Retirement Provision to serve as key long-term institutional investors. On the other hand, it is important to stress that the report positively looks forward and aims at ensuring a high level of protection for future pensioners while guaranteeing efficient investment at the same time.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: in writing. - I support the possibility for workers who have been in employment and service across borders to obtain pension rights through simplification and safeguarding.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour. The amendments to the Directive aim to ensure good governance of the occupational pension scheme, the provision of information to members of the scheme, transparency and the security of occupational retirement provision. This Directive should facilitate the development of new and innovative pension products in collective schemes aimed at ensuring adequate pensions for all.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. — Pension schemes (first public pillar, second and third private pillars) and in particular those in the second and third pillar constitute an important part of the financial sector.The proposal aims to use these available resources to stimulate investment. It takes into account the functioning of pension funds following the “Deepwater Horizon” case, when the US authorities asked BP and Shell to compensate for environmental damage. This has had an impact on the investment of pension funds in these companies. The proposal therefore takes environmental and social risks into account in the risk analysis. It promotes the establishment of an effective information system for all beneficiaries... However, the responsibility of private institutions remains very little questioned.
