Similarly, pension funds are treated as financial products to be treated as market goods in the EU's financial markets. Finally, the proposal does not maintain a clear separation between the private system and the public pension system, as my group requested. As the report nevertheless improves the Commission's proposal, I am abstaining.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission proposal concerns a recast of Directive 2003/41/EC on occupational pension institutions, known as IORP1. In response to the financial crisis, the ageing of the population, the increase in the amounts invested in occupational retirement by capitalization, and the ability of the sector to invest in long-term assets, the Commission proposed a redesign of IORP1 in 2014 with the following objectives: improving governance, improving information on the savers through the implementation of the PBS, facilitate cross-border activities and international transfers of portfolios within the single market, encourage long-term investment by allowing IORPs to invest in more asset classes. This overhaul of the directive proposes to support the development of a European occupational retirement market and deregulate existing standards to copy the American model of pension funds. The dangers are: advantageous regulation for large investment funds, rules for investing too risky assets and the promotion of capitalization pensions. I voted against the Commission proposal and the legislative resolution.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: - This Directive provides for minimum harmonisation and should not prevent Member States from maintaining or incorporating other provisions in order to protect members and beneficiaries, provided that those provisions are consistent with Member States' obligations under Union law. This Directive does not concern issues relating to national social and labour, fiscal and contractual legislation, or the adequacy of pension provision in Member States, other than the rules on occupational retirement provision as provided for in this Directive. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because institutions for occupational retirement schemes should be managed safely, transparently and following principles of good governance. Retired workers should be able to rest assured that their occupational pension schemes are safeguarded.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this legislation which aims to improve the protection of members of occupational retirement schemes and will encourage the development of stable cross-border schemes.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. — The Commission has proposed to the European Parliament and the Council a directive on the activities and supervision of institutions for occupational retirement provision. The Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs states in its report that, according to the advisory working group of legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, the Commission's proposal does not contain any substantive amendments other than those indicated therein, but only the existing legislation unchanged provisions and consolidation of these amendments. The committee therefore proposes that Parliament adopt the consolidated legislation at first reading with amendments to take account of the recommendations of the Advisory Working Group composed of the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. — The reform of the IORP Directive would introduce a large amount of funding pension schemes. The risk for a country like France is to prepare for the abandonment of the distribution model, to which citizens are attached. The aim is once again to encourage financial markets and players established in professional savings products, mainly in Luxembourg or Belgium. The risk on funded pensions, at a time of negative rates and strong market volatility, is too strong to be encouraged further. Unfavourable vote.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission proposal concerns a recast of Directive 2003/41/EC on occupational pension institutions, known as IORP1. This directive raises concerns about a desire to move a little more towards a privately funded pension system. I am therefore voting against it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the IORP II Directive because it is essential that we have a properly functioning pensions system in place – including state pensions, workplace pensions and private provision – to ensure that people are well looked-after in retirement. The Directive ensures that pension schemes are well-run and well-regulated, and that ordinary members of pension schemes have vital information about how their money is being spent and what they can hope to receive after they retire. And pension schemes will now have to make sure they are investing for the long term, considering the social and environmental implications of their investments, which is a major step forward.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report on the directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the activities and supervision of institutions for occupational retirement. The aim of the text is to modernize the legislation so that it is fairer and that it corresponds more closely to demographic changes and, in particular, to the ageing of the population. In particular, it plans to clarify procedures for institutions to carry out cross-border activities and remove unnecessary obstacles to that activity, in order to improve the functioning of the internal market in this area.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that aims to further facilitate the mobility of workers between Member States by ensuring good governance, transparency and safety of occupational retirement provision.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I voted for this report, which aims to create a legal framework at European level to develop savings for occupational pensions. The economic and demographic crisis we face directly affects the income that out-of-business people will have in the future. I consider very important the principle that Member States will have sufficient flexibility to apply and regulate the requirements laid down in the directive in a way that can reflect the wide variety of pension systems in Europe.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report and I am in favour of simplifying and safeguarding workers who have worked across borders.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — Pension schemes constitute a significant part of the financial resources available within the Union and the purpose of this Directive is to use these resources to motivate investment. In order to ensure worker mobility, the Directive seeks to unify pension systems in order to facilitate workers' mobility in the EU. While significant progress has been observed in the evolution of the text, such as the inclusion of environmental and social data in investments made by the fund aimed at greater transparency and information to beneficiaries, the nature of the pension fund remains and the requests of Parliament, which sought to restrict the benefits of the Fund. advantage investment opportunities to ensure its security have not been heard. In fact, despite positive progress, the result is not satisfactory, hence my abstention.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported. The aim of the Directive is to improve the cross-border pension system so that citizens can move between Member States in a way that they are insured for an equal pension.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: in writing. - The proposal aims to improve the governance and transparency of institutions providing occupational retirement provision in Europe, to promote cross-border activity and to facilitate long-term investment. It also seeks to strike a fine balance between strengthening national systems, respecting national discretion and encouraging the development of cross-border systems. At the same time, the text promotes the development of cross-border programmes to be carried out in conjunction with the provisions to prevent regulatory arbitrage. Through this proposal, for which I voted in favour, references to national-social and labour provisions have been strengthened, focusing on the protection of insured persons, while introducing the concept of duty of care in parallel, in order to avoid a regulatory race down through cross-border programmes.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ I would vote in favour of the proposal from my colleagues because I believe that recasting this directive would allow occupational or occupational pension institutions to play a key role within the European Union, as it would improve the system of occupational and occupational pensions, without sex discrimination between individual EU citizens, allowing them to have a style of life that also took place at the end of their working life. Moreover, with the establishment of these institutions, cross-border barriers would be broken down in order to enable the internal market to function better, and facilitate the living conditions of those, who for work reasons live seconded to another Member State. This directive also wants to develop new prudential provisions aimed at ensuring a greater level of security for future pension recipients. This directive would not override the sovereignty of the individual Member State, but rather encourage it in order to allow, on the one hand, the provision of secure occupational and occupational pensions and, on the other hand, the facilitation of cross-border activity. Therefore, I would vote in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: written. - I support the revision of Directive 2003/41/EC aimed at facilitating the development of professional pension savings. The European society is getting old. Pension schemes across the European Union must be adjusted to ensure adequate, safe and sustainable pensions. Vocational pensions institutions play an important role in the long-term financing of the Union economy and providing a secure pension for citizens of the Union. Revision of Directive 2003/41/EC on the activities and supervision of vocational pensions institutions is necessary to protect members and beneficiaries and to enable secure cross-border provision through higher standards managed at national level while monitoring the economic and financial crisis. There is also a reduction in barriers to the development of the cross-border pension market, which helps companies, including SMEs, organise their pension scheme more efficiently in line with EU rules. There is evidence of significant differences in the level of information of pension system users across the EU. This proposal complements and builds on a series of initiatives launched in recent years, such as the White Paper on Pensions and a Green Paper on the long-term financing of the European economy.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: written. — A resilient pension scheme encompasses a diverse range of products and effective supervisory practices. In light of demographic developments and the state of national budgets, vocational pension insurance is a valuable addition to social security pension schemes. They are under pressure and we are increasingly relying on vocational pensions to supplement other forms of pension insurance. Vocational pension institutions play an important role in long-term financing of the economy. On behalf of roughly 75 million members and beneficiaries, they manage assets worth 2.5 trillion euros. Despite the entry into force of Directive 2003/41/EC, cross-border activity is limited due to differences in national, social and labour law. The new Directive seeks to achieve minimum harmonisation and does not prevent Member States from retaining or introducing additional provisions to protect members and beneficiaries, provided that those provisions are consistent with the obligations imposed by Member States under EU law. In accordance with the principle of subsidiarity, Member States should retain full competence to organise their pension systems. This Directive intends to encourage Member States to build sustainable occupational pension insurance and to facilitate cross-border activities. It is important to ensure that elderly and disabled people are not at risk of poverty and that they can have a worthy standard of living.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The report adopted states that 'the directive must ensure that institutions enjoy an appropriate level of freedom to invest', and institutions for occupational retirement provision can invest in shares, multilateral trading systems, organised trading systems. It is also assumed that risk management is limited by quantitative requirements, and therefore it is essential to ensure an effective governance system. This means that pensions are at the mercy of the manager's suitability and the performance of the products in which pension money is invested (i.e., in a scenario where the number of occupational pension schemes under defined contributions is increasing, it becomes potentially problematic and dangerous). On the other hand, the text put to the vote states that the investment rules imposed by Member States should allow the development of individual pension products within a collective system and should not impede the free movement of capital. Pension funds are not a banal financial product for us. We are against the creation of a single pension market and the establishment of European pension schemes.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ The general objective of this directive is to facilitate retirement savings of a business or occupational nature. The Commission proposal does not contain substantial amendments to current legislation. It is a recast. However, I would like to stress that in all the states of the Union it is necessary to carefully monitor the soundness of pension systems, while safeguarding the acquired rights of low- and middle-income groups. I voted in favour of approving this report. I voted in favour of the proposal for a directive.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: in writing. — The first IORP Directive was introduced in 2003 and proposals for a second IORP Directive began to emerge in 2014. Employee pension schemes (IORPs) manage private collective pension schemes for employers so that their employees were able to benefit from a share pension including contributions made by the employer. IORPs have no relation to state pensions, which fall under national competence (first pillar), and private pensions (third pillar). The report covers issues of governance, risk management, transparency and information provision by IORP. It stresses that pensions belong to the competence of Member States, puts more emphasis on cross-border IORPs than national IORPs and abolishes all delegated acts originally proposed by the Commission. Provides information to participants (employees) and pensioners about all relevant features of their pension scheme in the form of a customised annual statement of pension benefits, as well as consultations in the case of decisions affecting their payments pensions. The form of the juxtaposition is less prescriptive than the one originally proposed by the Commission. I hereby supported the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report, which provides protection, transparency, information and security on the way in which occupational pension funds are managed. Now providers of occupational pension schemes wishing to move their operations across national borders will have to receive the approval of a majority of their members and the support of regulators, both in the country of origin and in the beneficiary country.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. - With my vote I supported this proposal for a directive in order to improve the transparency and governance of institutions providing employment pensions for retirement, normally linked to social and common partners in countries such as Germany or the Netherlands. The proposal also facilitates cross-border activities of employment pension funds and the transfer of pension schemes to remove unnecessary obstacles to them.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the legislative resolution on the proposal for a directive on the activities and supervision of occupational retirement institutions. This Directive aims to ensure minimum harmonisation and should not prevent Member States from maintaining or introducing other provisions to protect members and beneficiaries of occupational pension schemes. But as far as pensions are concerned, my position is clear: I am arguing in favour of strengthening the first pension pillar.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. - The resolution for assessing the activities of institutions providing occupational retirement provision and supervision is well prepared and balanced. It is also important that the EP resolution under discussion also includes advanced changes that are linked to a responsible approach to the environment. I therefore support this document.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. - The gradual ageing of European society means that the EU needs to adopt measures providing for an adequate, safe and sustainable pension level for its social security schemes and facilitating the development of occupational retirement savings. The absence of an updated Community regulatory framework has enabled Member States to maintain divergent and independent solutions. This proposal, which I voted for, therefore considers that a revision of Directive 2003/41/EC on the activities and supervision of institutions, occupational retirement provision, the need to reduce obstacles to the development of cross-border pension markets and the address some gaps in the information provided to members and beneficiaries across the EU. The proposal is based on a series of initiatives launched over recent years, such as the White Paper on pensions and the Green Paper on long-term financing of the European economy. I consider this debate and the existing sustainability proposals to be extremely important, especially for younger generations.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I abstained from this report, as it is Parliament's contribution to the process of recasting the directive on the second pillar of pensions. These pensions are those resulting from an agreement between the company and the employees, with the employer contributing to a fund created specifically for it. It is therefore a system halfway between the public pension system and private pension funds, a system that is more widespread in countries such as the United Kingdom and the Netherlands. While we understand that in some cases these funds are a trade union conquest, and that it is positive for consumers that progress is made towards greater standardization and the possibility of transferring rights from one country to another, we are opposed to the fact that pension funds are considered as a mere financial service. We also find it worrying that the creditworthiness requirements in these funds are relaxed compared to others.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on the proposal of Parliament and of the Council for a directive on the activities and supervision of occupational pension schemes. The aim of the report is to simplify the development of occupational pension schemes. This will be achieved by removing the remaining regulatory and cross-border barriers and by creating good governance and risk management of occupational pension institutions. In addition, members should receive sufficient information and supervisory authorities should make effective use of the necessary tools for effective monitoring.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because, although it contains positive points which improve the present transnational functioning of pensions, it maintains the approach of treating them as mere financial products. There are many problems for cross-border pensions which this directive seeks to solve, especially those linked to the financial risk to which this type of funds may be subject. This report addresses many of these problems; it improves transparency and mandatory information to beneficiaries, includes environmental risks in the scope of application, etc. However, the report maintains the focus of financing pensions, including the possibility of financing and participating in risky financial mechanisms, such as the EFSI bonds. It is because of this basic approach, and despite sharing the need for some of the improvements developed, I have not been able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I do not wish to see the EU involved in this area so I voted against this.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: written. - I voted positively for this report, but this rationale of voting is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEPs solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the real quality and the amount of work, efficiency and most of all the success of the advocacy.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the resolution because I think it is a good proposal that will ensure high protection and safety of members and recipients of occupational pension schemes. I am aware that the way in which institutions for occupational retirement provision are organised and regulated differs significantly between Member States at present, so I agree that the proposed directive achieves a minimum level of harmonisation and should not prevent Member States from maintaining or introduce additional provisions to protect their members and recipients. I am also in favour of allowing institutions in the internal market to operate in other Member States as well. I believe that, too, thanks to the directive on the table, which sets out the procedures necessary for carrying out cross-border activities, we will guarantee adequate pension provision for all. As a result of demographic developments in the Union, I expect Member States to ensure better protection for workers in terms of pensions by providing public pensions that are sufficient to maintain a decent standard of living and to protect against poverty in old age.

name: Μαρία Σπυράκη (PPE)
text: in writing. Social security systems are under heavy pressure and therefore citizens may increasingly rely on occupational pension benefits to supplement their pension savings in the future. The rules laid down in this proposal for a directive aim at ensuring a high level of safety for all future pensioners by imposing strict standards of supervision within the European Union, in order to ensure prudent management of the schemes. occupational retirement. At the same time, they enhance transparency, effective information for Member States and the development of new and innovative pension products, without, however, calling into question the fundamental importance of social security.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: in writing. - The proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the activities and supervision of institutions for occupational retirement provision aims to ensure a minimum level of harmonisation. The Directive aims to encourage Member States to develop occupational pension schemes and to remove prudential barriers for cross-border institutions for occupational retirement provision. This is, in my opinion, a step in the right direction. The activities of cross-border pension systems will be redefined. This creates more legal clarity. The possibility of transferring pension schemes across borders will increase efficiency. As the information and installation rules of the country of origin are to apply, administrative costs will also be reduced. For these reasons, I agree with the report.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the IORP II Directive because it is essential that we have a properly functioning pensions system in place – including state pensions, workplace pensions and private provision – to ensure that people are well looked-after in retirement. The Directive ensures that pension schemes are well-run and well-regulated, and that ordinary members of pension schemes have vital information about how their money is being spent and what they can hope to receive after they retire. And pension schemes will now have to make sure they are investing for the long term, considering the social and environmental implications of their investments, which is a major step forward.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: in writing. - I did not agree with the European Parliament resolution on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the activities and supervision of institutions for occupational retirement provision (recast). This Directive lays down rules for the taking-up and pursuit of the business of institutions for occupational retirement provision. This involves, in particular, minimum harmonisation of international transport. I oppose harmonisation of rules. The EU should move back to a free market instead of developing uniform regulations for all Member States. These prevent competition from regulatory systems, rather than promoting it. One of the shortcomings of the directive is also that it is not a general law, but, in certain cases, it is differentiated by gender and even demands gender sensitivity. In a free state, the law does not differ according to gender.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: written. — The EU pension scheme does not act as a single market. Problems are defined: 1. complexity of cross-border operations, 2. risk management and management requirements, 3. communication with members and 4. Supervisory powers. The report encourages Member States to create safe and appropriate professional pension insurance. The operational objective is to modify the legislation, which will lead to the abolition of additional requirements for cross-border operations and the creation of a single insurance market. The expected benefits are streamlining the business, increasing competition and creating a better deal for pension scheme beneficiaries. It will also strengthen private vocational pension insurance. I accept the Report because vocational pension insurance will become more efficient and safer, customer confidence will increase, which will lead to reduced prices and increased demand for their financial services.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This is a directive which fully promotes the privatisation of pension systems. However, the European Parliament's report stresses that there must be no interference with the sovereign right of Member States to lay down the provisions of their pension funds. This improves the directive, albeit to a minimum, as the principle that governs it does not change. That is why we abstained.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: in writing. — This legislative process will improve the protection of occupational pension members and encourage the development of stable cross-border programmes. I therefore voted in favour of this report. With this proposal, the Commission aims to improve the governance and transparency of IORPs. This is done by encouraging improvements in addition to respecting national competences. Retirement institutions continue to operate according to national social and labour standards, so the proposal recognises the specificities of national systems. For example, national control is retained, it does not establish supervision at EU level. However, the text facilitates cross-border programmes, which, in turn, should be assigned provisions that prevent possible arbitrage, i.e. opportunities resulting from market mispricing. The report has given strong emphasis on national social and labour provisions, in particular on the protection of programme members, and introduces a concept of the obligation to provide care to avoid competition between cross-border cooperation programmes. This is perhaps the first EU pension legislation to take into account both environmental, social and governance factors when making investment decisions.

name: Claudiu Ciprian Tănăsescu (S&D)
text: in writing. - In order to ensure the equilibrium between generations and because social security systems are under increasing pressure, it is necessary to develop safe and stable occupational pensions in all Member States in order to supplement existing pension sources, the fact that a viable pension scheme includes diversification of products and institutions, as well as effective and effective practices. Thus, Member States will be able to protect their citizens from poverty when they are old and helpless, as is not the case today in some Member States. As such, this initiative to encourage Member States to create adequate, sustainable and safe occupational pension schemes provided through institutions for occupational retirement provision is welcomed. The IORP, long-term investors, must carry out activities in accordance with European law and under the full responsibility of Member States for their role and functions, thus ensuring a high level of protection and safety for members and beneficiaries occupational pension schemes. In order to achieve this goal, IORPs must implement corporate governance systems, taking responsibility towards all those interested.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the legislative resolution on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the activities and supervision of institutions for occupational retirement provision (recast). In the internal market, institutions for occupational retirement provision (IORPs) should have the possibility to operate in other Member States while ensuring a high level of protection and security for members and beneficiaries of occupational pension schemes. Thus, IORPs play an important role in the long-term financing of the Union’s economy and in the provision of secure retirement benefits. They are a vital part of the Union economy, holding assets worth EUR 2.5 trillion on behalf of around 75 million members and beneficiaries. In line with the EU law, I welcome the provisions in order to protect members and beneficiaries of occupational pension schemes, provided that such provisions are consistent with Member States’ obligations under Union law.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the text. This Directive aims to ensure minimum harmonisation and should not prevent Member States from maintaining or introducing other provisions to protect members and beneficiaries of occupational pension schemes, provided that those provisions comply with the obligations of Member States under the Union law. This Directive does not address issues of national social, tax, labour or contract law or the adequacy of pension benefits in the Member States, apart from the rules on occupational pension benefits established by itself.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the legislative resolution on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the activities and supervision of institutions for occupational retirement provision. This directive is aimed at minimum harmonisation and therefore should not preclude Member States from maintaining or introducing further provisions in order to protect members and beneficiaries of occupational pension schemes, provided that such provisions are consistent with Member States’ obligations under Union law. This Directive does not concern issues of national social, labour, tax or contract law, or the adequacy of pension provision in Member States.

name: Ivica Tolić (PPE)
text: written. - I support the Motion for a resolution on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the activities and supervision of occupational pension institutions. I consider it necessary to protect recipients of pensions and benefits from the pension scheme, as well as to establish high standards of pension management at Member State level. It is also necessary to overcome obstacles in order to develop a single cross-border and common pension scheme to make pension payments as effective as possible. Finally, there is evidence that there are currently pronounced gaps in the Member States' information system on the actual situation in pension schemes to which it will be necessary to act in the common policy of the Member States.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - I have supported the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the activities and supervision of occupational pension institutions (2014/0091 (COD)). European society is aging. Pension schemes need to adapt to this in order to provide safe and sustainable pensions. Member States have to deal with this issue. The proposal for a directive will help national institutions improve transparency, better governance, better cross-border activity, which will strengthen the internal market. The proposal aims to facilitate the development of occupational pension insurance.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I abstained from this report, as it is Parliament's contribution to the process of recasting the directive on the second pillar of pensions. These pensions are those resulting from an agreement between the company and the employees, with the employer contributing to a fund created specifically for it. It is therefore a system halfway between the public pension system and private pension funds, a system that is more widespread in countries such as the United Kingdom and the Netherlands. While we understand that in some cases these funds are a trade union conquest, and that it is positive for consumers that progress is made towards greater standardization and the possibility of transferring rights from one country to another, we are opposed to the fact that pension funds are considered as a mere financial service. We also find it worrying that the creditworthiness requirements in these funds are relaxed compared to others.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR)
text: in writing. - The proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the activities and supervision of institutions for occupational retirement provision aims to ensure a minimum level of harmonisation. The Directive aims to encourage Member States to develop occupational pension schemes and to remove prudential barriers for cross-border institutions for occupational retirement provision. This is, in my opinion, a step in the right direction. The activities of cross-border pension systems will be redefined. This creates more legal clarity. The possibility of transferring pension schemes across borders will increase efficiency. As the information and installation rules of the country of origin are to apply, administrative costs will also be reduced. For these reasons, I agree with the report.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: This revision of the directive proposes to support the development of a European occupational retirement market and deregulate existing standards to copy the American model of pension funds. However, the pitfalls are: regulation too advantageous for large investment funds, rules for investing too risky assets, and promoting capitalization retirement (as opposed to the apportionment model). I voted against this report.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: in writing. — By allowing trans-border transfers of pension liabilities, the regulatory authorities of both Member States must base the authorisation on a strict set of criteria. Subsequently, the transfer will have to be approved by participants and beneficiaries of the pension scheme. It's a proposition that can properly improve the workings of this issue. I voted positive.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I abstained from this report, as it is Parliament's contribution to the process of recasting the directive on the second pillar of pensions. These pensions are those resulting from an agreement between the company and the employees, with the employer contributing to a fund created specifically for it. It is therefore a system halfway between the public pension system and private pension funds, a system that is more widespread in countries such as the United Kingdom and the Netherlands. While we understand that in some cases these funds are a trade union conquest, and that it is positive for consumers that progress is made towards greater standardization and the possibility of transferring rights from one country to another, we are opposed to the fact that pension funds are considered as a mere financial service. We also find it worrying that the creditworthiness requirements in these funds are relaxed compared to others.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: in writing. — In order to ensure the smooth functioning of the internal market for organised occupational retirement provision at European level, the Commission, after consulting EIOPA, should review the application of this Directive, draw up a report and submit it to the European Parliament and the Council.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the activities and supervision of institutions for occupational retirement provision. The report notes that institutions for occupational retirement provision play an important role in the long-term financing of the Union’s economy and in providing secure retirement benefits for citizens of the Union. It equally underlines that Member States should take into account the objective for all institutions of ensuring the intergenerational balance of occupational pension schemes, by aiming to have an equitable spread of risks and benefits between generations. I voted in favour because I believe that Member States shall ensure that members are sufficiently informed of the conditions of the pension scheme, in particular concerning the risks borne by members and beneficiaries associated with the pension scheme.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This text aims to promote the development of occupational retirement savings schemes, in a context determined by the latest economic and financial crisis which has caused pensions to be subjected to intense pressure in many Member States. By assessing demographic indicators (European society is aging, life expectancy is increasing and the labour force is decreasing), it is estimated that intergenerational solidarity does not give more of itself. With all this in mind, more countries should consider the establishment of supplementary second pillar pension schemes, which would entail safer pension benefits. In addition, it is pointed out that good oversight and governance rules are crucial in providing citizens with a high degree of confidence in their system, as well as encouraging them to participate in it. I therefore considered it appropriate to vote in favour of this document.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. — I voted against this revision of the Pension Fund Directive because rather than focusing on strengthening the regulation of the investment activities of these funds, which they carry out a very delicate social function, is to remove prudential barriers to the protection of social security and labour, which now rightly restrict its cross-border activity and certain types of investment. The aim of the new directive is to encourage the creation of a true European single market and further expansion of these private funds, so that they gradually take the place of the system public pensions increasingly in difficulty, while not providing adequate safeguards. We had called for measures to be introduced to prevent life savings from ending up in the zero-sum game of casino finance. Our proposals have been ignored, so pension funds today remain free to operate in unregulated markets and invest in hedge funds or risky and complex instruments such as derivatives, securitizations or subordinated bonds. It is even preventing Member States from introducing tighter restrictions on investment than those authorised by Europe. I think it is deeply immoral and irresponsible to incentivise financial speculation about a fundamental right, such as that to pension.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because, although it contains positive points which improve the present transnational functioning of pensions, it maintains the approach of treating them as mere financial products. There are many problems for cross-border pensions which this directive seeks to solve, especially those linked to the financial risk to which this type of funds may be subject. This report addresses many of these problems; it improves transparency and mandatory information to beneficiaries, includes environmental risks in the scope of application, etc. However, the report maintains the focus of financing pensions, including the possibility of financing and participating in risky financial mechanisms, such as the EFSI bonds. It is because of this basic approach, and despite sharing the need for some of the improvements developed, I have not been able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The report to be voted on in plenary states that 'the directive should ensure that institutions enjoy an appropriate level of freedom to invest', and institutions for occupational retirement provision can invest in shares, multilateral trading systems, organized negotiation. The limitation of risk management through quantitative requirements is also assumed, and therefore it is essential to ensure an effective governance system; this solution implies that pensions are at the mercy of the suitability of the manager and the performance of the products in which pension money is invested (i.e., in a scenario in that the number of occupational pension schemes under defined contributions is increasing, it becomes potentially problematic and dangerous). On the other hand, the text put to the vote states that the investment rules imposed by the Member States must allow the development of individual pension products within a collective system and should not prevent the free movement of capital. Pension funds are not a banal financial product for us. We are against the creation of a single pension market and the establishment of European pension schemes.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: in writing. — In the face of an ageing European society, there is a need to adapt pension systems in the European Union to ensure an adequate, safe and sustainable pension for all citizens. In order to achieve these challenges effectively, it is called for closely coordinated action by the Member States. The proposed revision of the Directive on the activities and supervision of institutions for occupational retirement provision will help to ensure the intergenerational balance of occupational pension schemes. This Directive aims at minimum harmonisation and should not prevent Member States from maintaining or introducing further provisions for the protection of members and beneficiaries. It also deals with national social, labour, tax and contract law on the adequacy of pension provisions in the Member States. This is not a question of migrant pension payments, nor is it a harmonisation of national pension schemes, but a simplification for workers who have worked across borders to maintain their pension rights. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the IORP II Directive because it is essential that we have a properly functioning pensions system in place – including state pensions, workplace pensions and private provision – to ensure that people are well looked-after in retirement. The directive ensures that pension schemes are well-run and well-regulated, and that ordinary members of pension schemes have vital information about how their money is being spent and what they can hope to receive after they retire. And pension schemes will also now have to make sure they are investing for the long term, considering the social and environmental implications of their investments, which is a major step forward.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ The revision of this directive aims to eliminate the persistent prudential barriers that today limit its cross-border activity to encourage the creation of a true single market European private pension funds, at the heart of the capital markets union project. In particular, the directive considers the restrictions provided for by national social security and labour legislation as obstacles to be struck down in order to ensure that these funds have the broadest freedom of investment throughout the European territory, with worrying risks and complications in terms of safety of savings and adequate and effective protection of the rights of beneficiaries. The implicit objective is clearly to foster the further expansion and profitability of private funds so that these funds gradually take the place of the public pension system, rendered unsustainable by the policies of rigour and the effects of the crisis on public finances. For these reasons, while having worked constructively on some important aspects regarding transparency obligations and the requirement to take account of environmental, social and governance risks in my own investment activities, I considered it appropriate to strongly oppose this directive, because of the strong concerns it raises about the impact of the new rules on pension savings of the citizens.

name: Željana Zovko (PPE)
text: written. - I support the report on activities and supervision of vocational pension institutions. The general objective of this Directive is to facilitate the development of a pension system for employees in vocational professions. During the last economic and financial crisis in recent years, first-tier pensions have come under intense pressure in a number of Member States, and the result has made it difficult to pay pensions in some countries. General demographic trends in Europe are worrying — the population is aging, there is low fertility rate, there is a lack of large numbers of workers in key labour market niches such as medicine, finance, banking, the IT sector and construction. The development of vocational pension insurance is necessary in order to increase the confidence of citizens and their participation in pension funds. Good supervision and management of such a system is a prerequisite for trust in the pension system. This Directive should not create additional aggravating regulations and circumstances for Member States, but should instrumentalise support for States in their efforts to develop a vocational pension scheme.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted for the Report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the activities and supervision of occupational pension institutions. The purpose of this Directive is to minimise the harmonisation of occupational insurance between Member States and to ensure good governance, informing members of pension plans and transparency and security of occupational pension schemes in order to further facilitate the mobility of workers between Member States . Taking into account the demographic developments in the Union and the situation on national budgets, when social security systems are under increasing pressure, occupational pension provision is a valuable addition to social welfare pension schemes.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR).
text: – Mr President, the situation in Syria is still far from what we want or what we expect. Many people are dying every day because of the fighting. So—called ISIS, Islamic State or Daesh, al-Nusra, the Syrian Government and many other groups are engaged in daily clashes victimising the Syrian people – the civilian population. Unfortunately, as the European Union, we are still not able to resolve this conflict. We remain divided, not able to find a solution or to help the millions of people who are suffering and fleeing. However, there is a solution: a solution that comes from the Syrian people themselves. There is regional, democratic self-governance. Syria needs to be turned into a federal state in which all groups can have their share in the regional governments. The Rojava region is a very good example of this. We need to support them. As this motion for a resolution is a first step on the way, highlighting the importance of democracy and calling for an end to the continuing fighting, I was happy to support it.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: — I supported this resolution. It is good that on the floor of the EP as part of the debates about the international situation, we are also debating the tragic situation in Syria, that we are here debating the tragedy that occurred in the city of Aleppo. It is good that we have adopted this resolution, although unfortunately the resolution itself may not have an impact on dealing with this tragic international situation. The resolution describes well the problems we are encountering in Syria. He describes the role of the Assad regime there. The role that unfortunately Russia also has there today. What is important, what I quote about the resolution, is that there is clearly talk that the war crimes that are committed against the population in Syria should not be forgotten and that in the future — hopefully as soon as possible — when the war conflict in Syria passes, those who commit war crimes should be driven to international justice and be for war crimes convicted.

name: Jan Zahradil (ECR).
text: — It's certainly not the first time we've dealt with Syria in an EP, it's also not the last time. I think it's a good thing. I think we should be watching the situation there very closely now. We should also prepare for the fact that when the new US administration takes office early next year, so that the US policy on Syria can change, at least they can amend some of the surges. The EU, individual Member States should be able to respond to this, they should be able to prepare for it. Similarly, we should be careful not to fight the so-called Islamic State have not gone so far as to support forces seeking the territorial disintegration of another state. I mean Turkey. Of course, we should also be careful not to tape Iran too much in its pursuit of regional hegemony, because that is another risk factor that is now well evident in Syria.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: — Mr President, honourable Members, I supported and voted for this resolution because the truth about the situation in Syria must be told as it is. The aggressive policies of neighbouring Saudi Arabia, which supports Islamist gangs that enforce extreme, radical, Salafitic Islamism in Syria, must be damned. The hypocrisy of some European leaders who pretend not to see the criminal role of Saudi Arabia must also be exposed. The role of the Republic of Turkey, which has already illegally invaded the territory of the Republic of Syria, leading illegal military action there and seeking to annexe part of the territory of that country, must also be clearly marked. The role of dictator Erdogan, who assists, funds, heals, trains ISIS fighters, must also be exposed. All these things need to be said and they find a place in this resolution. That's why I supported her.

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE).
text: - Mr President! The conflict in Syria shows most emphatically how much the world has changed in recent years. The tragedy endured by the people of this state is difficult to describe: death and suffering can come on any side at any point, and the world, including Europe, looks at it helplessly. No rules are respected, all parties carry out war crimes and crimes against humanity, international humanitarian law is not followed, humanitarian convoys are attacked and hospitals treating injured civilians, despite being clearly marked. You can see that the goal of all parties is to intimidate the civilian population, which is meant to help defeat the opponent. More than 400,000 people have died since the start of the conflict, with nearly 14 million requiring humanitarian support. Specialists point out that the conflict in Syria would have long ended if it had not turned into a so-called proxy war. On the territory of this country is Iran with Saudi Arabia, Russia with America, and Turkey is running a multilateral game. All of these countries are trying to support each other's forces and thus make it difficult to end the war. One must be clear: it is the outside world that is stoking this tragedy. The European Union should first try to persuade all parties to stop engaging in this conflict, later a peace plan for Syria can be discussed. At the same time, we should prepare for post-war action, because the very end of the fighting will not improve the situation of ordinary people. Already, initiatives should be planned to support the reconstruction of this country, both infrastructure and economy and social trust. Especially the latter will be very difficult to achieve, because civil wars like no other create intractable internal divisions. For this reason, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE).
text: — I voted for this resolution, because it is obvious that the situation in Syria is more dramatic with each passing day and requires our attention. This resolution contains many elements of this that we can think of. Above all, I think it encourages us for a more active role for the European Union in finding a solution to this war. In particular, the European Union must also strive to ensure that all stakeholders of current conflicts and complex problems are involved in finding a solution at all stages. I voted against some of the amendments that, in my view, represent a simplification of the problem that express our brief memory, especially when it comes to where the causes of the crisis are in Syria, in Iraq and the whole area of the Middle East. I think it's wrong if, in our resolutions on the Middle East, we try to carry in some way there the rhetoric of Cold War intensification that we are creating in Europe. At least on the third ground we have to try to speak with the same language and be objective. Above all, we must give back to the unhappy Syrians their homeland and the perspective of staying in it.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, vótáil mé le mo ghrúpa sna vótaí go léir sa tuarascáil seo agus glacadh leis le móramh mór. The situation in Syria continues to represent an area of grave concern for all of us here in the European Union. Faced with escalating hostilities and civilian casualties, I obviously voted for this motion for a solution. It is an outright condemnation of such activities. The role of Russia is deeply worrying, and indeed the role of Turkey is an area which we must also seriously explore, as their support of opposition groups gives rise to warranted concerns as to the likelihood of a lasting political settlement. Furthermore, I am deeply sorry to learn of an increase in supposed chemical gas attacks being carried out against civilians. The humanitarian aspect of this conflict must henceforth guide our engagement with Syria. Along with my colleagues in the PPE Group, I would urge participants in the Syria Support Group to continue their good work in the crucial negotiations as we endeavour to move towards a stable truce in this most troubled part of the world.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ In this resolution there is once again the utmost concern about the continuation of the conflict in Syria, condemning in the strongest terms the atrocities and widespread violations human rights and international humanitarian law committed by the forces of both deployments, therefore calling, once again, for the immediate cessation of bombing and the adoption of all appropriate measures to protect civilians, in accordance with international law. However, the condemnation of Russia's role — even considering possible sanctions — is also not accompanied by a censorship of the US conduct, which, although it has the same weight, does not come for nothing considered. So I abstained.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ My vote was clearly against this resolution, as I frontally reject the qualification of the terrorists, the same Al-Qaida terrorists who attacked the 11M in Spain as opposition. In addition, the report 'welcomes the review of EU restrictive measures against Syria' and argues that the Union 'should consider all available options, including a no-fly area', even though this measure is widely criticized and became classified as illegal. In addition, we oppose sanctions as a measure of coercion for mainly affecting peoples. In addition, the report argues that the main responsibility for the conflict and massacres of the Syrian population is the Assad “regime” backed by “Russia and Iran,” when it is precisely the Syrian government and the Russian Federation that most effectively fight terrorism that Europe claims to be so threatened. The report also totally evident the Syrian Government's efforts to achieve a just peace through dialogue, as shown by the establishment of the Reconciliation Committee and the reform of the Constitution. Peace will only come through dialogue between the government and the non-terrorist opposition.

name: Martina Anderson Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted against the joint motion for resolution on Syria for a number of reasons. The resolution was particularly one-sided, rightly condemning Assad and Russia, but failing to address US, Saudi and EU involvement in the conflict. Its biggest fault comes from its calls for the EU to intervene directly and indirectly in Syria. The resolution called for the EU to impose 'restrictive measures' on Syria and for the EU to implement a no-fly zone over Aleppo (which would put it in direct conflict with the Russian and Syrian air forces). It continued to call for a common EU strategy on Syria. Whilst aspects of the resolution are positive, as a whole we could not support it, as its proposals would not advance the cause of peace in Syria. Internal dialogue and lasting ceasefires, coupled with the disengagement of international military actors, including the USA, Britain, France, Russia, Turkey and Saudi Arabia, are the only avenues to peace in Syria.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution. The European Union must not and cannot remain silent in the face of the current massacre in Syria. It must act collectively through its High Representative and take the lead in international efforts to find an early diplomatic solution to the Syrian civil war. There's an emergency!

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the resolution on the situation in Syria. I want to draw attention to Russia's role in the Syrian conflict. After pushing Russia into a military conflict in Syria, where civilians are massively killed, V. Putin is trying to prove that Russia is the force of more than one region, as US President B. Obama. True, it is no longer possible to resolve the Syrian conflict without the participation of Moscow. Becoming a serious player in Syria and all the Middle East, the Kremlin has its own price. Never, even in the years of the Cold War, the world was as close to the verge of a serious uncontrolled military conflict as it is now, and this is the result of the Kremlin policy. The situation is so fragile that the clash between the United States and Russia can be provoked by even the slightest human error. And here it is not necessary to forget that the United States Kremlin considers the most important contestant in the world. I agree that those who are guilty of war crimes and crimes against humanity should feel the consequences and be brought to justice. I believe that the Syrian case should be referred to the International Criminal Tribunal (ICC). Therefore, November 16. V. Putin's decision to withdraw from the ICC is clear, and this decision leads to the conclusion that Russia, a permanent member of the UN Security Council, is refusing its commitment to international justice. This behaviour of Russia questiones the legitimacy of it as a member of the UN Security Council and the guarantees of fulfilment of its commitments.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the situation in Syria because I believe that the EU must not and cannot remain silent in the face of the ongoing massacre in Syria and that it must take a leading role and initiatives to find a diplomatic solution to the Syrian civil war.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: in writing. — The war in Syria continues with undiminished severity. Every day we receive new horror news and cruel images that testify to inhuman suffering. Parliament's report, which I support, strongly condemns what is happening. Parliament expressed its deep concern at the continuing fighting, bombing and the deterioration of the humanitarian situation in Syria. It called for an immediate end to attacks on civilians and condemned the atrocities committed by the Assad regime with the help of Russia and Iraq, as well as by ISIS and other jihadist groups. Parliament also welcomed HR's efforts to develop a common EU-Syria strategy and called on Member States to honour their commitments to provide financial assistance to Syria's neighbours.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted against the misleading joint resolution on the situation in Syria. Once again the European Parliament wants to send back to back the various Islamist militias and Syrian loyalist troops, their Russian and Iranian allies. Once again, it maintains unfounded and politically disastrous accusations against the Syrian regime and its Iranian and Russian allies, thereby contributing to amplifying the disorder and humanitarian disaster on the spot, as well as dramatically damaging the interests of the Member States.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst I commend aspects of this resolution in the fight against ISIS and aiding in improving the stability of Syria, I believe a number of points in this resolution misunderstand the conflict and therefore I voted to abstain.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this joint resolution because I wish to reiterate my deepest concerns over the prolonged fighting and bombardment of Syrian territory. Atrocities and widespread violations of human rights must be denounced in the strongest possible terms. I hope that these crimes will not go unpunished because the protection of civilian populations must be the first priority in a conflict of this magnitude.

name: Francisco Assis (S&D)
text: This resolution on the situation in Syria once again warns of the state in which Syria is in after six years of a conflict that has already caused more than 400 000 deaths and left 13 million people in need of humanitarian aid. My vote in favour is a sign of support for a text which seeks once again to point out the atrocities and extremely serious violations of human rights that occur daily in Syria, while urging the various actors to resume negotiations that might lead to the establishment of a real truce in this bloody conflict. I would also like, as stated in this resolution, to reiterate my support for the European Union's humanitarian initiative for Aleppo and call on all parties involved to allow it and assist in its implementation.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: I voted against this resolution, which upholds unfounded and politically catastrophic accusations against the Syrian regime and its Iranian and Russian allies. By referring terrorist groups and legal authorities back to back, it helps to amplify the disorder and humanitarian disaster on the spot and undermine the economic interests of the Member States.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: in writing. - I endorsed this resolution, which once again strongly condemns all attacks targeting civilians and civilian infrastructure. Deputies also strongly condemn the atrocities and widespread human rights violations committed by Bashar al-Assad's troops with the support of Russia and Iran. Welcoming the efforts of humanitarian workers, the resolution urges all participants of the Syria Support Group to resume negotiations with a view to establishing a solid truce and to intensify their efforts towards a lasting political settlement of the situation in Syria.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the situation in Syria. I endorse the conclusions adopted and support the AR/VP Mogherini in its efforts with key actors in the conflict. Cooperation with all of them is essential to achieving a lasting and balanced political solution to the conflict. In this regard, I endorse the text in its condemnation of the indiscriminate suffering of innocent civilians due to bombing and other military actions, as well as the deprivation of humanitarian aid, and I believe that the use of incendiary and other ammunition against civilian targets and infrastructure amounts to a war crime.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: ‒ Syria has been living a state of internal conflict for six years in which violence and brutality are on the agenda. There are 4.8 million people who have already fled the country while it is estimated to amount to nearly nine million internally displaced people. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on Syria because I think it is essential to bring Europe's attention to a dramatic situation, which continues despite the fact that it has been over time calls for negotiations to resume negotiations to facilitate the conclusion of a stable truce. The approved text condemns atrocities committed by the Assad regime, Da'esh, al-Nusra and other terrorist organisations; illegal detentions, torture, mistreatment, forced disappearances and killings of inmates in regime prisons and secret detention centers that constitute real crimes against humanity. Europe must ensure that all those responsible for these violations are brought to justice and must, above all, step up its efforts to finally reach a lasting political solution for the Syria.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against this resolution on the situation in Syria, considering it partial and warmongering, because it calls for the establishment of a no-fly zone, and by not addressing elements which I consider necessary to achieve a just and lasting peace, such as a call for a ceasefire by all parties, for dialogue effective and constructive — without external interference — among all parties to the conflict, and to propose just and human-rights solutions to refugees.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution on the situation in Syria to condemn the humanitarian emergency in the country and especially in cities like Aleppo. The persistence of fighting and shelling is worsening the already very poor situation of civilians who are directly affected by them. The international community must do everything possible to bring this situation to an end. It's unacceptable.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: in writing. — While I supported the resolution tabled by the ENL Group, which rightly emphasises Turkey's ambiguous role in the Syrian crisis, I voted against the joint resolution of the main political groups in Parliament which will only aggravate the diplomatic relations of the European countries with Russia or Syria, which are yet at the forefront of the fight against the Islamic State. I take this opportunity to denounce the scandalous amalgam made in this text between terrorist forces and sovereign states: here we reach the zero degree of diplomacy, confusing arbitrary morality and strategic interests. But it is, moreover, a true lie on a European scale, since the abuses committed by terrorists in the area are attributed mainly to Russia. Finally, the request for the establishment of a no-fly zone over Aleppo is not only a matter of strategic ignorance but also to the admission of the European Union's incompetence and total helplessness in the conflict.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: In writing. ‒ The resolution does not propose any concrete solutions to the conflict in Syria and does not analyse important aspects such as Turkey's ambiguous role in this war scenario. So I did not intenD to support it with my vote.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: I voted in favour of the resolution. I believe that the dictatorial Assad regime bears primary responsibility for the war in Syria, and I condemn Russia's bombing war. However, I believe that the resolution lacks a self-critical EU perspective. Several EU countries export quantities of weapons to different countries in the Middle East and thus contribute to continued conflict. Several EU countries also actively supported the US assault on Iraq which contributed greatly to the formation of IS/Daish, bringing a deepening and deepening conflict in the region. This should also have been included in the resolution. On the question of the demand for a “no-fly zone” over Aleppo, I voted against, because I believe that only the UN Security Council should be able to take a decision on such a zone. If the EU itself takes such a decision, with the wide interpretations that can be made of the concept of a no-fly zone, then the conflict would escalate significantly. I am making these short clarifying additions to clarify my yes vote to the resolution.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The situation in Syria is dramatic and complex. The complicated reality on the ground, difficult international circumstances and the endless atrocities committed make it necessary to support efforts for a new ceasefire and ensure that humanitarian aid reaches those in need. The Union must play a more important role and support the efforts of the United Nations, on the idea that there can be only a political solution, where all parties are convinced that it is the only way forward. The European Union must maintain its commitment to a lasting solution to the conflict in Syria, where a definitive military solution could not be expected. It must continue and continue its diplomatic and humanitarian work. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution because it expressed Parliament on the situation in Syria. Over the sixth year of conflict, more than 400 000 people died due to extreme violence and brutality in Syria and more than 13 million people need humanitarian aid. In 2016, 8.7 million people are expected to be relocated in Syria itself and 4.8 million fled. There are no battles and bombings in the country, and the humanitarian situation has deteriorated even more. There is a continuous health crisis throughout Syria; whereas according to UNICEF, more than two-thirds of the Syrian region do not have permanent access to water and almost 6 million children need emergency life-saving assistance. Parliament therefore calls for an immediate cessation of bombing and reckless attacks on civilians. Notes also that all countries must focus on the protection of civilians, regardless of their ethnic origin or religious beliefs, and to this end take all appropriate measures and strongly condemns armed opposition groups not targeted by numerous civilians inhabited rocket firefighters in the western Alepo suburbs. Stresses the wounding and deaths of many civilians, including children; calls on all parties to the conflict to take the necessary action to protect civilians, in accordance with international law, including civil facilities. Parliament notes that the main responsibility for protecting the Syrian population lies with the Syrian regime.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I think it is important that everyone respects the right of all ethnic and religious minorities, including Christians, to continue to live in dignity, equality and security in their historical and traditional homeland and to exercise fully and freely their religion and faith without having to endure any constraint, violence or discrimination. In order to promote mutual understanding and combat fundamentalism, I support interreligious dialogue. I supported the adoption of this report.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: in writing. — I agree that the situation in Syria is unsustainable, so I support a resolution in which the EP notes that over 400,000 people have died in the six years of conflict, extraordinary violence and brutality in Syria, and more than 13 million in need of humanitarian aid. Also worrying is the fact that, according to 2016 figures, 8.7 million people are expected to be displaced in this country, while 4.8 million immigrated from the country. The dangers to the population left in their homeland, however, are not abating as fighting and bombings in Syria continue on an unabated scale and the humanitarian situation worsens. All parts of the country suffer severe shortages of basic foods and medical care.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: written. —the first part of the text is missing... by the massacre occurring in Syria, but should act collectively through its High Representative and take the lead in international efforts for a diplomatic solution and end the bloody war.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the situation in Syria because it firmly condemned the atrocities and violations of human rights and international law by Assad, Russia and Iran, as well as by jihadist groups. In addition, it demanded, first of all, an immediate end to bombing attacks on civilians and, secondly, a resumption of the negotiations of the International Syria Support Group in order to establish a stable truce.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ The Syrian civil war is becoming the most dramatic humanitarian catastrophe since the post-war period and is on our doorstep. The priority now is to save Aleppo's civilians. The Syrian regime and Russia must stop aerial bombardment and allow humanitarian aid to arrive. There has been a European plan for weeks to get aid to the eastern part of the city under siege and to transfer the most serious sick but it cannot be carried out without a truce between the parties. But the path of resolution of the Syrian conflict cannot be limited to isolated relief interventions, however noble and important. The way out of the conflict is diplomatic. Only when we have an agreement on the future of the region will the causes of war cease. We Europeans have been reborn in the ruins of the world war: we are reborn thanks to a long-lasting project, looking to the future, giving concrete follow-up to a serious path of diplomacy and reconstruction. This is the way forward for Syria's future, to put an end to this ruthless war.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the resolution on the situation in Syria. Parliament expressed its deepest concern at the worsening humanitarian situation in Syria. It condemns any attacks targeting civilians and civilian infrastructure. The inability to deliver humanitarian assistance to the Syrian population aggravates the humanitarian situation, which is why agreement by the parties on permanent access to humanitarian assistance remains essential, especially in besieged and hard-to-reach areas. It is essential to condemn the atrocities committed by ISIS and to call for respect for religious and ethnic minorities in Syria, including Christians, and to be able to continue to live safely and freely practise their religion without being subjected to any form of coercion, violence or discrimination.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: ‒ Today I voted in favour of the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Syria because this country is at the heart of a humanitarian tragedy for a conflict that goes through, in this very period, perhaps the most gory, delicate and decisive stages. Humanitarian organizations operating in the territory have appealed for a complete cessation of the conflict by declining the numbers of the dramatic humanitarian framework. I voted in favour of Mogherini's statement because there is no possibility of resolving the Syrian crisis with arms alone. The military solution does nothing but provoke greater suffering and pain to people. It is necessary to make, today more than ever, a diplomatic effort. This option remains, in my view, the only path out of the Syrian crisis and stop the horror that this war is carrying behind.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. – The situation in Syria has deteriorated even further since the EP’s last resolution. Relentless efforts need to be made in order to bring the plight of the people in Syria to an end, especially in the city of Aleppo. I believe that the EU should consider all options to set out consequences for the most heinous human rights violations and abuses by all perpetrators if the atrocities and disrespect of humanitarian law continue.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ This resolution, while condemning all parties who may have carried out human rights violations in the Syrian conflict, points the finger more at Russia by not mentioning the responsibility of the other actors in play. I cannot agree with phrases like this: “Whereas all parties involved in the conflict have carried out serious violations of international humanitarian and human rights law, more serious of which were nevertheless committed by the Assad regime with the support of Russia.” For these reasons I preferred to abstain.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: in writing. - We are deeply shocked by the violence in Syria and strongly condemn all attacks on civilian infrastructures and civilians, the continuation of all sieges in Syria and the lack of access by humanitarian organisations to the suffering Syrian people. We also express our deepest concern about human suffering and suffering in the besieged areas of Aleppo and throughout Syria, which affect many women and children who do not have access to basic humanitarian goods and desperately need food, clean water and medical supplies.
