We therefore call on all participants in the International Support Group for Syria to resume negotiations in order to facilitate the establishment of a stable ceasefire and to step up work towards a lasting political solution in Syria.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The motion for a resolution on the situation in Syria could be an opportunity to show Europe's support for the citizens of the region, who have been suffering for years by the battles and atrocities recorded. However, I do not agree with the references to foreign policy issues, which is why I have decided to vote against the motion for a resolution.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ Ten years ago, among the many favorite destinations of European tourism there was one in particular, where one could perceive a Middle Eastern culture open to Western influences, that place it was Syria, today it is a land devastated by the horrors and atrocities of war. Six years of conflict have produced over 400 thousand deaths and 13 million people live, or rather, survive in a state of ongoing humanitarian crisis. My vote in favour of the resolution is sadly plagued by the consideration that the situation in Syria remains almost unchanged, subject to the growing number of deaths. The internally displaced people are expected to amount to 8.7 million in 2016, while they are deemed to have managed to escape from the state over 4.3. In conjunction with this, humanitarian assistance has no access to besieged areas since July 2016 and the whole area is plagued by a permanent health crisis in addition to a severe shortage of food and medical supplies. Through the resolution, Parliament proposes to increase the sending of aid to the Syrian population, especially with regard to medical materials.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the motion for a resolution on the situation in Syria.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. - The situation of conflict and violence in Syrian territory reaches levels of authentic humanitarian scourge every day, with an estimated 400 000 people have lost their lives and more than 13 million need humanitarian aid. Notwithstanding calls from the EU and the international community in general, fighting and bombing are continuing and serious violations of human rights and international humanitarian law are committed by all parties, including the use of chemical weapons with a particular focus on civilian areas, schools, hospitals and refugee camps. I support the resolution in question because I once again believe that we must end the atrocities committed by both Assad forces and non-state armed terrorist groups by ceasing the bombing, taking the necessary measures to protect civilians and by holding criminals accountable for the acts perpetrated. I reiterate the need to extend the OPCW investigation mechanism in order to ascertain responsibilities in the use of chemical weapons, and that the case of Syria be referred to the ICC. I also urge respect for ethnic and religious minorities including Christians to practice their faiths in freedom and security and to continue their lives with dignity.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this measure because the situation in Syria continues to worsen especially on the humanitarian front. It is therefore necessary for the EU to condemn again strongly all attacks against civilians and the impossibility for aid workers to reach the population in need. All stakeholders must allow continuous and unrestricted humanitarian access which also allows emergency products to be delivered.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ I abstained on the sensitive Syrian situation as the relationship is too unbalanced in favour of the United States rather than Russia. While the Russian role is highlighted in negative until possible sanctions are considered, the US one, despite having the same weight, is not analysed at all. The polarization of the relationship therefore, inficiates the value of the ratio itself.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ My vote was clearly against this resolution, as I frontally reject the qualification of the terrorists, the same Al-Qaida terrorists who attacked the 11M in Spain as opposition. In addition, the report 'welcomes the review of EU restrictive measures against Syria' and argues that the Union 'should consider all available options, including a no-fly area', even though this measure is widely criticized and became classified as illegal. In addition, we oppose sanctions as a measure of coercion for mainly affecting peoples. In addition, the report argues that the main responsibility for the conflict and massacres of the Syrian population is the Assad “regime” backed by “Russia and Iran,” when it is precisely the Syrian government and the Russian Federation that most effectively fight terrorism that Europe claims to be so threatened. The report also totally evident the Syrian Government's efforts to achieve a just peace through dialogue, as shown by the establishment of the Reconciliation Committee and the reform of the Constitution. Peace will only come through dialogue between the government and the non-terrorist opposition.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Syria's humanitarian drama is before everyone: 400,000 people who have died since the beginning of the conflict, more than 13 million people without humanitarian assistance, 4.8 million people fled the country. The situation in Aleppo is particularly dramatic, being the crossroads of clashes between rebel-controlled neighborhoods and those under government siege. Currently, Aleppo and the whole of Syria are the scene of a permanent health crisis. The population is the victim of multiple atrocities carried out by the government and Daesh, and the country is increasingly divided among many fronts that do not dialogue with each other in view of a peaceful political transition. In this scenario, I cannot but support, with my vote in favour of the resolution, the EU's efforts in Syria as a mediator calling for an immediate halt to bombing and attacks indiscriminate against civilians and facilitates the delivery of humanitarian aid to civilians trapped by the conflict. Finally, in the near future the EU could play a decisive role in the process of releasing all persons detained arbitrarily, as well as in bringing all those responsible to international justice of war crimes and crimes against humanity.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing. — I support the call for an urgent resolution to the conflict in Syria, which is leading to a tragic situation in this country. The death toll exceeds 400,000 people and 12m people have been forced to leave their homes. After such a prolonged and so tragic in the effects of the war, steps must be taken at international level as soon as possible to end this conflict. As an MEP, I also call for an urgent resolution of the conflict at international level and condemnation of barbaric attacks on civilians and workers of aid organisations. I consistently believe that all possible action and steps should be taken to end this brutal conflict and terror in which civilians suffer most.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The situation in Syria is worsening – and the EU cannot stay silent in the face of such an on-going massacre. I am in favour of this resolution as I believe the EU needs to take a leading role in international efforts for a diplomatic solution to the Syrian civil war and push for a stronger political solution. Furthermore, the resolution calls for a no-fly zone over Aleppo, as the situation within the region has reached a catastrophic level and has led to the deaths of thousands of civilians, including children. For this reason I have voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ This new resolution on the Syrian question, after the one already approved during the session last month, is necessary because of the latest events that have contributed to the deterioration of the situation in the country. Through this text, Parliament intends to reiterate its position. In particular, it condemns all atrocities committed during the conflict; calls on the international community not to abandon its commitments in order to support Syrian civilians - who pour into a very serious state of emergency - as well as highlights the need for a more purposeful role of the European Union in a conflict whose resolution can only be political, as pointed out by the High Representative Federica Mogherini. In the hope that a diplomatic and peaceful solution will come as soon as possible, I have strongly supported the resolution.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: in writing. — The situation in Syria is dramatic. I voted in favour of this text, although no resolution we shall vote will really mention the horror and chaos that prevail in Syria. European powerlessness in the face of the conflict and the terrorist organisations developing there is unbearable. With this vote, we have once again condemned in the strongest terms the violence and indiscriminate attacks against civilians, particularly in Aleppo. I also reiterate my full support for the persecuted minorities, especially Christians, in the face of the atrocities they suffer.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR)
text: — Today, the N-VA delegation voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the situation in Syria. In this way, we condemn the attacks on civilians and aid convoys carried out by the Syrian Government with the support of other foreign powers such as Russia. We also express our disapproval of all atrocities committed by the regime, by IS and by all other terrorist organisations. We also call on the moderate opposition to be expressly distanced from fundamentalist ideologies. Finally, we are calling for a political solution to the conflict.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: We voted against all of these resolutions, which are a scandalous amalgam between the rebel militias and the Syrian state forces, as well as the Russian armed forces. The ENF Group has tabled an alternative motion for a resolution.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: in writing. - Negative as a whole. The whole issue focuses only on the events in Aleppo and no concrete solutions are proposed to solve this serious issue. There are only accusations against Russia and Assad, and of course there is no mention of Turkey and its role.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the joint motion on Syria, which condemns the attacks and calls for several non-military measures to help stop the fighting, as well as for humanitarian assistance. I voted in favour because of the strong points in the motion, despite my opposition to a no-fly zone over Aleppo city, which would in all likelihood mean further military escalation.

name: Laura Ferrara (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ The resolution on the situation in Syria, although broadly shared in its intentions and content, however, appears unbalanced in the selection of those responsible to condemn. That is why I abstained.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: This resolution clearly reveals what the European Union's fundamental policy has been in relation to this conflict: interference, disregard for sovereignty, international law and the independence of the country, and the promotion of aggression and war. The resolution goes even further than the European Parliament had done before in warmongering and the escalation of the conflict in Syria, provoking forces supporting the Syrian Government against the external aggression that the country suffers, namely Russia, when it advocates the establishment of a no-fly zone about the city of Aleppo. Remember: the same expedient used when the attack against Libya - with the results that are known today. This means opening the door to sending troops to secure this no-fly zone, in a clear confrontation with the Syrian army. Let us remind you of the disaster that NATO's imposition of a no-fly zone for the Libyan people meant, consequences that NATO still suffers today. Only this enormous irresponsibility would be enough to reject this resolution altogether. But there are other negative aspects, and many, which converge towards our roundly vote against.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because the text condemns attacks on civilians and aid workers in Syria and, at the same time, stresses the need to adopt a urgent solution, internationally, to end ongoing conflict in the country.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing. - The European Union should not and cannot remain silent and turn a blind eye to the ongoing massacre in Syria. It is necessary to act collectively through the High Representative and take the lead in international efforts to tackle the Syrian civil war diplomatic. In view of the rapidly deteriorating situation in Syria and in view of the long-lasting fighting, we want to follow up on the resolution adopted during the October session. The aim of the new resolution is to name and more clearly and reflect the current picture and situation on the ground, as well as recent international developments in the field. We reiterate the unconditional condemnation of atrocities across Syria, the lack of humanitarian aid and the need to step up efforts to reach a new ceasefire in the area.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: In writing. - I vote against the report, it does not propose anything new and concrete to end the conflict in Syria.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: in writing. - I am voting against the motions for resolutions in their entirety. The issue focuses only on the events in Aleppo and no concrete solutions are proposed to solve this serious issue. There are only accusations against Russia and Assad, and of course there is no mention of Turkey and its role.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The situation in Aleppo is dramatic. In spite of the agreement of 9 September 2016 on the cessation of hostilities, the Assad regime, supported by Russia, is continuing to deliberately target civilians, a humanitarian convoy last week, doctors and hospitals. The water supply have also been cut off. Those actions must be strongly condemned, as they are an unacceptable breach of international humanitarian law and could be qualified as war crimes. I would therefore like to express my deepest concern for the human suffering in the besieged areas of Aleppo and throughout Syria, including many women and children, who do not have access to essential humanitarian goods and desperately need food, clean water and medical supplies. I support the call on HR/VP Federica Mogherini, on the international community and on the United Nations to use all necessary diplomatic instruments and pressure to end the indiscriminate aerial bombardment of civilians and for the cessation of hostilities to be implemented, respected and prolonged in order to allow full humanitarian access to the besieged areas.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution in view of the continuing deterioration of the situation in Syria. It is estimated that as of April 2016, as a result of the Syrian civil war, 400 000 people had lost their lives, 13.5 million people in need of humanitarian aid, 8.7 million internally displaced persons, and 4.8 million people have fled the country. However, despite the human tragedy we are witnessing, the lack of unity at the international level makes it much more difficult to reach a negotiated solution to the Syrian war. From the Union, we must urge all participants in the International Support Group for Syria to resume negotiations to facilitate the establishment of a stable truce and to intensify work towards a lasting political solution for Syria.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the joint resolution of the European Parliament on the situation in Syria because I believe it is inadmissible to carry out violent attacks that the Syrian population is suffering particularly in the towns of Aleppo and Zabadani, stormed by rebel groups, continued Russian attacks from above and raids by Assad's armed forces. I am indignant and horrified at the images of violence and torture to which thousands of children, women and men are subjected daily and I hope that soon the responsible for continuing violations of international humanitarian law. I firmly believe that there cannot be a resolution of the conflict with other violence and that it is essential to stop the conflict in fire and proceed with the resumption of negotiations through actions specific diplomatics. I fully support the work that the High Representative of Foreign Policy, Federica Mogherini, who aims to bring the parties involved in the conflict back to the negotiating table and relaunch the Geneva political process. I hope that EU intervention will not be limited to the mere function of mediator but that it is soon actively committed to providing humanitarian aid to populations in serious food shortages and medical supplies of base.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: in writing. - The situation of the people of Aleppo and some other regions of Syria is unbearable — and the international community is called upon to make every effort to prevent further blind killing and another humanitarian catastrophe. I also condemn the behaviour of Turkish troops, which are taking offensive action against Kurdish-Christian troops in northern Iraq, which are proving to be a constructive partner. That is why I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: in writing. - The European Parliament reiterates its call on all warring parties in Syria to stop fighting and to ensure humanitarian aid access to the regions affected by the civil war. Crimes against humanity and crimes against international humanitarian law must also be punished and those responsible must be held accountable. In this regard, all parties to the conflict must return to the negotiating table without delay and negotiate a permanent ceasefire.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, which condemns the heavy aerial bombardment by the Assad regime and Russia on Aleppo. The heinous attacks against civilian infrastructures, schools and hospitals cannot be tolerated. The EU needs to step up efforts to ensure accountability for crimes and call out Russia and China for blocking progress on accountability in the Security Council by vetoing a mandate for the ICC to investigate the crimes committed in Syria. If the UNSC is blocked we need to push proactively for alternative ways to break the deadlock. We need to voice support for the International Commission of Inquiry on Syria to conduct a special inquiry into the attacks against civilians and hospitals in Aleppo. We should also take the lead in the UN General Assembly to call for the creation of the post of special Syria War Crimes Rapporteur and push for the establishment of a Syrian war crimes court. Atrocities cannot go unpunished.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because the European Union must act towards the stabilization of Syria and the whole region by not giving up the call for the termination of the conflict armed and respecting the humanitarian duties that international law requires. When we talk about Syria we face an emblematic discussion not only for the foreign policy of our Union, but for its projection in a broad sense, also on our national communities. The EU has already mobilized internationally for the peaceful resolution of the conflict, for diplomatic mediation between the parties, for economic support for the country and to try to get there as soon as possible humanitarian assistance to the populations of the most affected areas, in accordance with the obligations taken with the United Nations. However, the consequences of that conflict are directly impacted on the reaction capabilities also on the internal front of the Union and which call into question the foundations of the joint project of the continent. Today's debate is more important not only for the future of Syria, but also for the shared choices we will make at EU level.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against this resolution on the situation in Syria, considering it partial and warmongering, because it calls for the establishment of a no-fly zone, and by not addressing elements which I consider necessary to achieve a just and lasting peace, such as a call for a ceasefire by all parties, for dialogue effective and constructive — without external interference — among all parties to the conflict, and to propose just and human-rights solutions to refugees.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, which condemns the heavy aerial bombardment by the Assad regime and Russia on Aleppo. The heinous attacks against civilian infrastructure, schools and hospitals cannot be tolerated.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. — For six years, not a single day has passed in Syria without its lot of misfortunes. Around the country, fighting and bombardment continue, increasingly targeting civilian populations and infrastructure. Hindred, humanitarian aid no longer reaches the terrorized and bloody Syrian population. This is, of course, not the first time that the European Parliament has sounded the alarm, but the intensification of the war and the tragedy in Aleppo called for a new strong and unequivocal reaction from our House. In this context, where outrage is no longer enough, one can only welcome the recent diplomatic initiatives of the VP/HR Federica Mogherini to urge all parties to the conflict to resume and intensify political negotiations. However commendable they may be, these efforts must be accelerated and strengthened. The role that the European Union must perform is threefold: to increase diplomatic efforts to achieve an immediate ceasefire and lasting peace; to enable continuous and unimpeded humanitarian access; to ensure that all those responsible for violations of international humanitarian law and human rights are brought to justice for lay the solid foundation for post-conflict reconciliation.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted against the joint resolution on the situation in Syria because it is clear that the aim of the resolution was not to highlight the current tragic situation, but once again to attack Russia and Assad. Syria is a country that has been thrown into the current state of the policies of the United States and Member States, but the dominant groups in the European Parliament are pretending not to see this.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The humanitarian situation in Syria has worsened in the last year. The actions of ISIS/Daesh in the region are deplorable and the international community, including the European Union, should work together in order to find a peaceful solution to this conflict, which has claimed countless innocent lives. I support the calls for an immediate cessation of hostilities in the area so that desperately needed humanitarian aid can be provided. The European Union should seek to take a leading role as a peacemaker in the region and aim to assist Syrian civilians in need of help.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour since I have objections.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The ECR supports calls for an urgent international political solution to the conflict and has condemned attacks on civilians and aid workers.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written. - I voted for the Motion for a Resolution on the State of Syria, primarily by motivating that it is necessary as soon as possible to end the conflict that has been going on for too long and which causes the innocent population to suffer tragic consequences. I agree with the position of High Representative of the Union for Foreign and Security Policy Mogherini that Europe should make maximum efforts to find a solution and stop the conflict, and I believe that the EU has the credibility to participate in peace talks. Sustainable peace needs to be achieved as soon as possible to stop the suffering of the innocent. The region can only stabilize itself in a way that there is a permanent solution in which one side of the conflict would not emerge as a big winner. A Bosnia and Herzegovina-like solution mentioned, which still generates political instability, should be avoided. Not only would Syria be a dysfunctional state, but the area would become a constant source of new possible war conflicts.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: This resolution unfortunately fuels unfounded and politically clumsy accusations against the Syrian State and its Iranian and Russian allies. By establishing a dubious parallel between terrorist groups and legitimate and recognised States, it contributes to increasing the scale and humanitarian disaster on the spot and dramatically damaging the interests of the Member States. I voted against it.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the resolution on the situation in Syria, which notes the deteriorating humanitarian situation. The parties involved are called upon to respect international humanitarian law by putting an end to the bombing of civilians and civilian infrastructure. With the assistance of the Member States, the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs, on behalf of the EU, must play a greater role in the negotiations of a peace agreement in Syria.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution because it is balanced and seeks answers to the situation in Syria which is worsening from day to day. Condemning all attacks against civilians, she stressed Turkey's ambiguous role, condemned the supply of arms to jihadist groups and called for a resumption of negotiations with a view to establishing a solid truce.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: in writing. — This motion for a resolution concerns the war situation in Syria and the refugee crisis caused by this conflict. Although the Islamist terrorist organizations are involved and the war as such is condemned, the resolution repeatedly emphasizes Russia's guilt for the scale of destruction and violence in Aleppo. That is why I abstain from this motion for a resolution.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The situation in Syria is very complex and at times I have the impression that everyone except the European Parliament is aware of this. I find the joint motion for a resolution unbalanced and counterproductive. While I appreciated that the text again calls on the Vice-President of the Commission, the High Representative to renew efforts to develop a common EU strategy for Syria, she welcomes and fully supports the recent diplomatic initiatives by the Vice-President of the Commission, High Representative Federika Mogherini, in line with the mandate of the European Council to bring the parties to the conflict back to the negotiating table and restore the political process in Geneva, notes with interest the regional negotiations that conducted jointly with Iran and Saudi Arabia, and considers its activities to be an added value and useful contribution to the efforts of UN Special Envoy Staffan de Mistura, urges all parties involved in the conflict to, in anticipation of a new and stable ceasefire, which should include arrangements ensuring a transitional judicial system in Syria for the post-conflict period, resuming and intensifying political negotiations as soon as possible, stressing that such peace negotiations should lead to cessation of hostilities and a political transition that will be led and controlled by the Syrians themselves, but even so I could not support the text in the vote.

name: Илхан Кючюк (ALDE)
text: in writing. — Unfortunately, the situation in Syria remains extremely worrying and tense. After the talks in Damascus, the U.N. special envoy for Syria confirmed that the Assad regime rejected an offer of a truce that would allow the opposition to administer an eastern part of Aleppo. At the same time, the shelling of residential areas and civilian sites does not stop. Since July, there has been no delivery of any humanitarian aid, and there has been no functioning hospital left in eastern Aleppo since the past week. This situation prolongs the suffering of the Syrian people, and more than four million people continue to fight for their lives in besieged cities and hard-to-reach areas. I therefore call on the European Union to insist on establishing a no-fly zone over Aleppo as soon as possible, which will facilitate the work of humanitarian workers and allow the delivery of emergency assistance. We also need to provide full support to the UN in its efforts to restore political dialogue between warring parties, but also to continue the investigation into chemical weapons use in Syria in order to hold those responsible for this crime against humanity to account.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: I voted against this resolution because it maintains unfounded and politically disastrous accusations against the Syrian regime and its Iranian and Russian allies. By sending back to back terrorist groups and legitimate states, it contributes to amplifying the disorder and humanitarian disaster on the spot, and dramatically damaging the interests of EU Member States.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted against the resolution on the situation in Syria. By sending back to back the terrorist groups and the Syrian army and its allies, this resolution contributes to exacerbating the disorder and humanitarian disaster on the spot, as well as dramatically undermining the interests of the Member States. The ENF Group tabled amendments highlighting Turkey's ambiguous role, the links between the Syrian crisis and the migration crisis, and the risks of using chemical weapons by terrorist groups. These three amendments were rejected.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: I voted against this resolution, which maintains unfounded and politically catastrophic accusations against the Syrian regime and its Iranian and Russian allies. By sending back to back terrorist groups and legitimate states, it helps to amplify the disorder and humanitarian disaster on the spot, as well as undermine the economic interests of the Member States.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The situation in Syria remains bad. Let’s ask ourselves the question what we, the European Union, can do to stop the bloody war in this state. We don’t have any instruments at all! We don’t have influence on the key players on the ground like the USA, Russia, Iran, Turkey and Saudi Arabia have. We don’t have military forces that we are ready to deploy. Our diplomatic possibilities to stop this conflict are very small. Let’s be frank, we can’t solve this conflict with resolutions.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing — The fight in Syria is not only a conflict between the two largest powers, but also a global fight against terrorism and non-respect for fundamental rights. EU diplomacy is falling short of the results people expect. This situation is a breeding ground for propaganda, an increase in racism, xenophobia and the spread of conspiracies. Work needs to be intensified to create a ceasefire so that time and a peaceful environment can be created for a peaceful resolution of the conflict. At the same time, humanitarian aid must be continued for the population suffering from the inability and reluctance of the powerful to resolve the conflict in a peaceful way.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing. - I am voting against the joint motion for a resolution on the situation in Syria, for the reasons I explained in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 22 November 2016, and because this joint motion for a resolution is not complete and documented.

name: Michał Marusik (ENF)
text: in writing. ‒ Has the situation in any of the countries where the reigning “regime” was overthrown and “democracy” been introduced improved? Russia and Assad's “regime” are said to be responsible for the situation in Syria. We know from journalistic accounts that in the part where Assad's “regime” was overthrown, ISIS and Daesh militias were raging, civilians were slaughtered and only ruins remained from the development. And where Assad has failed to drive through, there is still infrastructure left, and there are still people alive who are trying to survive. Independent right-wing media reports that Assad is the guarantor of the survival of those left. There was talk during the session that the EU could not remain silent on Syria. Well, let him force Russia, Turkey and, above all, the United States to leave Syria immediately and leave both the population and Bashar El Assad alone. They will cope. Without us.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: in writing. - I firmly condemn war and Islamist terrorist organizations. I disagree with the statement of the resolution that Russia is to blame for the extent of the destruction and violence in Aleppo. That is why I am abstaining from the vote.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the resolution. I strongly condemn all attacks on Syrian civilians and civilian infrastructure, the continuation of all sieges in Syria. All conditions must be made available to the Syrian population as soon as possible to provide humanitarian aid, essential goods, in particular to devastated and hard-to-reach areas. I also condemn all the atrocities, violations of human rights and international humanitarian law committed by non-state armed terrorist groups, in particular Da'esh and Jabhat Fateh al-Sham and other jihadist groups. I contribute to calling for all participants in the International Support Group for Syria to resume negotiations, facilitate the declaration of a stable ceasefire and work more actively towards a lasting political solution in Syria.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. — The situation in Aleppo and more broadly in Syria remains dramatic, on the one hand, because of the abuses committed by Daesch and other jihadist groups, and on the other hand the resulting military escalation with the Damascus regime. But this resolution is only a pretext to tackle Russia once again. In the same sentence, she condemns Bashar al-Assad, Russia and Daesch. As if they could be put on the same plane! The resolution envisages the creation of a no-fly zone over Aleppo, along the lines of what had been done in Libya to facilitate NATO's air invasion. This would amount to granting impunity and even protection to jihadists who fire missiles (often American) every week from East Aleppo to the rest of the city. I am voting against this text, which only expresses the EU's warlike vision against Russia, without proposing any useful path for peace in Syria.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: The joint resolution maintains unfounded and politically disastrous accusations against the Syrian regime and its Iranian and Russian allies. By putting terrorist groups and legitimate states back to back, it helps to amplify the disorder and humanitarian disaster on the spot and dramatically undermine the interests of the Member States. I therefore voted against this joint resolution as well as those of the other political groups, except that of the GUE/NGL Group, from which I abstained.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. - The European Union makes one of the greatest contributions to humanitarian aid for populations fleeing historical violence and destruction in Syria. The lack of international unity compromises the prospects for a negotiated solution to the war in Syria. The EU must continue its efforts and take a greater role in mediating a peace agreement in Syria. We must regret everything that is happening in Syria and try to find a peaceful solution to this conflict. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. The conflict in Syria has claimed hundreds of thousands of lives and requires our immediate and urgent attention.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution because I am in agreement that the EU should not and cannot stay silent in the face of the ongoing massacre in Syria. It needs to act collectively through its High Representative and take the lead in the international efforts for a diplomatic solution to the Syrian civil war.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. — All eight political groups have tabled motions for a resolution on this subject. Five of them, the ECR, the PPE, the ALDE, the S&D and the Verts/Alea groups, reached agreement and developed a joint compromise motion, which I voted in favour.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this text, which once again calls for an end to the massacres in Syria, resulting in the death of many people, including many civilians. An end to the massacres can only be done on the day when all the countries determined to eradicate the Islamic State will find themselves in a single and effective coalition.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this motion for a resolution regarding the situation in Syria that strongly condemns all atrocities and widespread violations of human rights and international humanitarian law, and attacks on civilians and civilian infrastructure.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: in writing. The tragedy unfolding in Syria along the events in Aleppo is unfortunately nothing new against the backdrop of what has been happening in this country over the past half a decade. A part of the international community is also responsible for this dramatic situation, and the question of which of all the countries involved in the conflict is most to blame is unfruitful. A lasting solution to the military conflict in Syria, as well as its derivative refugee crisis, requires intensive cooperation between countries with significant political and cultural differences, such as EU countries, Russia, USA, China, Turkey, Egypt, Iran and Saudi Arabia. The continuation of the war in Syria suffer mainly Syrian citizens who are directly affected by the conflict, as well as countries that will have to deal with increased refugee pressure, such as my country Bulgaria. It is for this reason that I have refrained from giving my support to the resolution on the situation in Syria.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I voted for this resolution expressing the European Parliament's concerns about the situation in Syria, blocked by an endless war, in which political pride no longer takes into account the loss of innocent human lives. MEPs insist that the Syrian regime must take responsibility for protecting the Syrian population and strongly condemns the disproportionate and excessive attacks by the regime and its allies. Many of these attacks have been directed against the civilian population, particularly children and medical and humanitarian personnel, and the report states that these attacks have been committed deliberately. The European Parliament is also calling for the rights of religious minorities in Syria to be respected, including Christians, in order to ensure a climate of tolerance, which is so necessary at this time.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: in writing. - I abstained on this resolution. Russia's fault for the scale of destruction and violence in Aleppo is repeatedly stressed. Nevertheless, Islamist terrorist organizations are involved and the war as such is condemned.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported. The humanitarian situation in Syria is paramount critical. Peace negotiations must be resuscitated again and full protection of civilians and humanitarian aid workers must be ensured. The EU needs to agree on a Syria strategy that would address concrete measures to end the bombings and help the Syrian people. The premise for some sort of workable solution to end the war in Syria is nothing but cooperation, not satisfying Russian global confrontational ambitions at the expense of the Syrian people. In fact, the goal of Russia, the EU and the Western world in Syria must be common - to end the war, remove ISIL and allow people to return to their homes.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: in writing. — The world has repeatedly been shocked by the atrocities against civilians carried out in Syria by ISIS and other terrorist groups, as well as by the Assad regime. I strongly condemn the widespread violations of human rights and international law and the indiscriminate air bombardment by the Assad regime, Russia and others in Aleppo in recent weeks. With this resolution we call on all armed groups for an immediate cessation of hostilities, so as to pave the way for the resumption of negotiations and to ensure that humanitarian aid reaches all people in need throughout Syria.

name: Gilles Pargneaux (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution, which calls for, inter alia, that those responsible for war crimes and crimes against humanity in Syria be prosecuted by international justice. I also condemn the deliberate and ongoing attacks on civilians, humanitarian workers and health facilities in Aleppo by the regime of Bashar al-Assad supported by Russia and Iran. I ask the High Representative, Federica Mogherini, to use all the diplomatic tools at our disposal to put pressure on the Syrian regime and its supporters. It is crucial that the European Union plays a leading role in reconciliation and reconstruction of Syria.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ I would vote in favour of proposal B8-1250/2016 because I believe that the European Union should condemn the atrocities that are happening in Syria, in fact in six years of conflict we have seen 400 thousand dead, 13 million are those in need of humanitarian assistance. The epicenter of the conflict is represented by Aleppo, which undergoes continuous bombardment by enemy forces, but the worst aspect and that since July 2016 it is no longer possible to access the eastern area of Aleppo , to provide humanitarian aid, since it is under siege. To date, the Syrian people suffer atrocities from different armed groups, not just Assad, with support from Russia and Iran, but particularly from other terrorist groups such as Da'esh, Jabhat Fateh al-Sham/ front al-Nusra and other jihadist groups, reported protagonists of the violation of human rights and international community rights. The European Union cannot and should not stand by, it must protect those rights of which it protects and condemn the terrorist groups who violate them. Therefore I would vote upvote.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: written. — It is important to reach an urgent agreement on the delivery of humanitarian aid to Aleppo and the provision of humanitarian corridors to evacuate wounded civilians and those who wish to withdraw from the city while fighting lasts. It is necessary to ensure that the assistance the world sends to Syria and the victims reaches those who really need that assistance. In this regard, I support the efforts the High Representative makes to reach agreement from all parties involved in the conflict. The establishment of a humanitarian break is a prerequisite for ensuring the transport of humanitarian aid to the war-torn city and providing first aid to the injured soldiers and civilians. Conflicted in battle should stop shelling buildings marked with a hospital sign, otherwise they severely violate international law. I express my hope that this conflict will soon end and that the exiled population will return to their homes. The European Union must continue to be persistent in providing humanitarian aid. It must do so during the conflict, but also after the conflict itself to ensure the reconstruction of the city, the construction of demolished infrastructure, clearing the city from explosive devices and other backlogs from the conflict.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ The humanitarian situation in Syria continues to deteriorate. Six years of conflict have caused the deaths of more than 400 000 people and more than 10 million displaced people. Bombings on densely populated areas, particularly Aleppo continue, deliberate attacks on civilian infrastructure such as schools, hospitals and refugee camps, sieges on numerous cities and Arbitrary detentions, the torture, the forced disappearances. All serious violations of international humanitarian law, committed by both the Assad regime and Da'esh, Jabhat Fateh al-Sham, al Qaeda's affiliate in Syria, and other jihadist groups. The destruction of essential water and power infrastructure has caused a permanent health crisis, with nearly six million children urgently needing vital assistance. I subscribe to the firm condemnation of all violations of human rights and international humanitarian law, and the call for a definitive cessation of hostilities and bombings and immediate release of all persons detained arbitrarily and the guarantee of access for humanitarian organizations. I also support the initiative of High Representative Mogherini to bring the parties back to the negotiating table in order to achieve a final diplomatic solution to the crisis.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: written. — The skirmishes on the territory of Syria continue, as well as constant human rights violations committed by all parties to the conflict. The population has faced serious shortages of food and medical supplies in cities across the country. Schools, hospitals, as well as other civilian infrastructure and aid workers were not spared the attack. Responsibility for these acts must be established. While this state of lack of responsibility persists, it encourages further violations of human rights in the conflict, further contributing to the suffering of people in this conflict. The EU and member states must more actively support the special investigation into the outrageous events in Aleppo of October 2016. All parties to the conflict must take the necessary measures to protect civilians, regardless of their ethnicity or religious affiliation. All parties to the conflict must also ensure passage for humanitarian aid across Syria and allow the evacuation of those in urgent need of medical assistance. A military solution to this conflict is not possible. I urge all parties to stop fighting as soon as possible and return to the negotiating table. Local actors in Syria must be convinced of the necessity of breaking the conflict. I expect influential regional and world powers to play a positive role in this. I welcome the High Representative's recent initiatives to revitalise the process in Geneva and hope for an even more successful role for the EU in stopping the conflict and subsequent reconstruction and reconciliation of Syria.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This resolution deepens the EU and EP's approach to interference, disregard for Syria's sovereignty and territorial integrity. It opens the door to an even greater escalation of direct military aggression against the Syrian people, making an explicit appeal for the violation of international law, namely the proposal to impose a no-fly zone over the city of Aleppo. Examples such as Libya confirm this formulation as an instrument that justifies the intervention and external aggression of European powers against a sovereign country, in this case, promoting a clear confrontation with the Syrian Army and the forces that collaborate with it in the fight against terrorism and in the self-defense of integrity territorial area of Syria. For over six years Syria and its people have been victims of systematic interference, a cruel war of aggression imposed and promoted by the United States, France, the United Kingdom, Israel, Turkey, Saudi Arabia, among others, carried out by groups of mercenaries who have created, financed and armed, which are responsible for the brutal violation of the rights of the Syrian people, of human rights, for the most heinous crimes, by millions of displaced persons and refugees, for the destruction of this country. We voted against it.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: I support this resolution which condemns the atrocities committed by the regime of Bashar al-Assad, but also by the Islamic State and terrorist organizations against the Syrian people. The actors in the conflict must immediately halt the bombing of the civilian population and public infrastructure. It is essential that people have access to humanitarian assistance. The Syrian people are now victims of serious war crimes and crimes against humanity that will not go unpunished.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this non-legislative and non-binding report. We are committed to seeing a long lasting and stable peace develop in Syria. However, we do not support the development of EU foreign policy or expenditure. Concerning 14/2 military action, including the enforcement of a no-fly zone, is a sovereign decision taken by the British Government in compliance with international law and not something at the EU level.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. - Once again, we express our concern about the situation in Syria. The fight continues and the humanitarian situation has worsened. At the initiative of the European Socialists and with the support of all the other major groups, Parliament today adopted a resolution underlining the need to ensure that all those responsible for war crimes and crimes against humanity in Syria do not get away with it. We call on all actors involved in this conflict to allow the immediate cessation of hostilities and resume negotiations, ensuring that humanitarian assistance reaches all people in need in Syria.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The situation in Syria is dramatic and complex. The complicated reality on the ground, difficult international circumstances and the endless atrocities committed make it necessary to support efforts for a new ceasefire and ensure that humanitarian aid reaches those in need. The Union must play a more important role and support the efforts of the United Nations, on the idea that there can be only a political solution, where all parties are convinced that it is the only way forward. The European Union must follow the commitment to a lasting solution to the conflict in Syria, where a definitive military solution could not be expected. It must continue and continue its diplomatic and humanitarian work. The Union has also extended sanctions to several members of the Syrian government and responsible for various State agencies. In addition, 69 entities are subject to asset freezing, including, inter alia, the oil embargo, the freezing of Syrian Central Bank assets in the Union and restrictions on the export of equipment and technology that may be used for internal repression. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted for the resolution on Syria, calling for access to humanitarian aid throughout the country, even though it is currently blocked. Moreover, I cannot tolerate the bombing of civilians, and the ongoing violations of human rights and international humanitarian law. Those responsible for these acts will have to be tried for their abominable crimes. The situation in the country, particularly in Aleppo, is catastrophic. The people, hungry, are struggling to access humanitarian aid and feel totally neglected. It is the responsibility of the Syrian government to ensure the protection of the population and to carry out evacuations from areas where fighting is raging. The EU and its Member States must fully support the UN and the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW) in order to continue the investigation into the use and destruction of chemical weapons by all parties to the conflict in Syria and advocate, through all possible diplomatic means, a peaceful resolution of the conflict.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. - The situation in Syria is a world-wide concern. The draft EP resolution prepared on this issue is exhaustive, seeking to provide a unified EU approach. I support the project provided. At the same time, I would like to see more concrete proposals for crisis resolution measures, including potentially military ones. Unfortunately, for the time being, it seems that the EU is inclined, above all, to combat the consequences of the crisis, not the causes.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. - Six years of extreme conflict, violence and brutality in Syria have already caused the deaths of more than 400 000 people, and currently 13 million are in need of humanitarian aid. According to 2016 estimates, 8.7 million people are displaced within Syria and 4.8 million have fled the country. But fighting and bombing are continuing at an overwhelming pace and the humanitarian situation continues to deteriorate day by day. The EU continues to show deep concern about the whole situation and maintains its efforts to call for facilitating humanitarian aid, emergency products and an immediate ceasefire. Atrocities and human rights violations must be urgently neutralised, and it is therefore imperative that indiscriminate attacks against the civilian population be stopped and the perpetrators of these heinous acts be held accountable, through appropriate, impartial and international criminal justice mechanisms. intransigent. Because it is urgent to resolve this devastating disaster and because it is necessary for the EU and its Member States to act inflexibly in order to stop hostilities and peace in that territory, I voted in favour of this resolution of which I am one of the proposers.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: I voted in favour of this resolution, which condemns the indiscriminate bombardment and attacks on civilians and civilian installations in Syria, particularly in the city of Aleppo. This text calls on all parties to the conflict in Syria to ensure access to humanitarian aid for Syrians throughout the country. The siege of Aleppo is a critical example of the willingness of some parties to the conflict to starve people. This is an intolerable violation of international humanitarian law. People must have access to humanitarian aid, and that access must be ensured by the forces present in Syria. Those responsible for these crimes will have to face international justice. It is urgent that negotiations for a political solution resume and that all parties to the conflict be involved. The European institutions and Member States must fully support the UN in order to achieve a viable solution in Syria that puts an end to this human and humanitarian tragedy. It is no longer tolerable for civilians, especially children, to be targets of aerial bombardments and the first victims of lack of humanitarian assistance.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against this resolution on the situation in Syria, considering it partial and warmongering, because it calls for the establishment of a no-fly zone, and by not addressing elements which I consider necessary to achieve a just and lasting peace, such as a call for a ceasefire by all parties, for dialogue effective and constructive — without external interference — among all parties to the conflict, and to propose just and human-rights solutions to refugees.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ My vote was clearly against this resolution, as I frontally reject the qualification of the terrorists, the same Al-Qaida terrorists who attacked the 11M in Spain as opposition. In addition, the report 'welcomes the review of EU restrictive measures against Syria' and argues that the Union 'should consider all available options, including a no-fly area', even though this measure is widely criticized and became classified as illegal. In addition, we oppose sanctions as a measure of coercion for mainly affecting peoples. In addition, the report argues that the main responsibility for the conflict and massacres of the Syrian population is the Assad “regime” backed by “Russia and Iran,” when it is precisely the Syrian government and the Russian Federation that most effectively fight terrorism that Europe claims to be so threatened. The report also totally evident the Syrian Government's efforts to achieve a just peace through dialogue, as shown by the establishment of the Reconciliation Committee and the reform of the Constitution. Peace will only come through dialogue between the government and the non-terrorist opposition.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report, it is not for the EU to involve themselves in foreign conflicts.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. – Today I voted in favour of this resolution as the EU should not and cannot stay silent in the face of the ongoing massacre in Syria. It needs to act collectively through its High Representative and take the lead in the international efforts for a diplomatic solution to the Syrian civil war.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: written. - I voted positively for this report, but this rationale of voting is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEPs solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the real quality and the amount of work, efficiency and most of all the success of the advocacy.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing. - I supported the motion for a resolution on the situation in Syria in the vote, but I also signed up for the resolution. In six years of conflict, extreme violence and brutality in Syria, more than 400,000 people have led to the deaths, with more than 13 million people in need of humanitarian aid. Fighting and bombing continues with unchanged intensity and the humanitarian situation has deteriorated again. All sides of the conflict commit serious violations of international human rights law and international humanitarian law. In the resolution, we call for an immediate end to bombing and reckless attacks on civilians, we appreciate the efforts of humanitarian workers to provide the necessary assistance, food, water and medicines to those affected by the conflict, and we called on all parties involved in the conflict to provide organisations with safe, unrestricted access to civilian populations affected by war. We again ask that those guilty of committing war crimes against humanity bear the consequences of their actions and be accountable for them. Persons who commit crimes against religious, ethnic and other groups and minorities should also be brought to justice. An effective solution to the conflict, nor a lasting peace in Syria, cannot be achieved without taking responsibility for the crimes committed.

name: Jaromír Štětina (PPE)
text: in writing. — Even six years since its beginning, the conflict in Syria is still not taking its end, and the civilian population continues to be — or even perhaps increasingly — the victim of war atrocities and massive human rights abuses. The current situation is characterized not only by continued fighting, bombing, attacks on civilian populations and civilian infrastructure, but also by deteriorated access by aid workers to Syrians. This is a deliberate denying of humanitarian aid to civilians, which is completely contrary to international humanitarian law. Assad's forces, supported mainly by Russia, but also by Iran, are responsible for the happening in Syria, but also non-state actors in the form of armed terrorist groups. Their doing can be unequivocally considered war crimes and crimes against humanity. It is very important that the situation in Syria is given due attention by the EP, so I clearly support the resolution. As stated in it and with what I am completely congruent, the events in Syria should not be forgotten, and after the end of the war conflict in Syria, the perpetrators of war crimes should be brought to justice, and they should be judged for their doing.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: in writing. - I abstained from the vote on Syria. The situation is far too complex for the European Parliament to be able to adopt a clear position here.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: written. - The Council stresses that the EU is appalled by the deterioration of the situation in Syria, especially in Aleppo. It calls for an emergency ceasefire. The EU will continue intensive humanitarian diplomacy and calls on the Syrian government to provide corridors for delivering aid to Aleppo. The Syrian regime needs to protect its people. The EU strongly condemns its attacks on its own population. The Council calls on Russia to make utmost efforts to halt military actions by Syrian regime forces and allow aid deliveries. The EU strongly condemns the use of chemical weapons and atrocities committed by Da'esh and other terrorist groups. I support this Resolution because the Syrian people are in a very difficult humanitarian situation, particularly in Aleppo. It is necessary to do everything to stop military operations, stop suffering and to deliver humanitarian aid to the starving people.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: in writing. - The whole issue focuses only on the events in Aleppo and no concrete solutions are proposed to solve this serious issue. There are only accusations against Russia and Assad, and of course there is no mention of Turkey and its role.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the adoption of the parliamentary resolution because I am convinced that the European Union, and above all the EP, as a political body, cannot leave without sharp protest the developments in Syria in recent months, the systematic manslaughter and torture in the sphere of war and devastation. The retaliatory actions or bombings carried out by the troops of the Assad regime and their support against the innocent civilian population in Aleppo and elsewhere cannot be explained by any military or political interest. I agree with our call for a resolution to stop violence against civilians without delay and allow for humanitarian aid from the international community as a precondition for a negotiated political settlement. This Decision is also suitable for supporting the constructive engagement of the EEAS and the High Representative for Foreign Affairs in Syria with a view to promoting peace as soon as possible. I also consider it important that the European Parliament is already referring to the inevitability of prosecuting war crimes and homicide perpetrators in the future.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The situation in Syria has escalated to an ongoing massacre, with numerous civilian casualties and a serious shortage of food and medical supplies in areas such as Aleppo. Six years of conflict and extreme violence in Syria have led to the deaths of more than 400 000 people, with more than 13 million people in need of humanitarian assistance. Our group has requested a new resolution that would reflect a more comprehensive picture of the situation and recent developments, and work toward the aim of a ceasefire and a potential peace deal. I support the need for a new resolution, as the European Union through its role as a meditator should bring all major parties back to the negotiating table and lead the focus to the humanitarian aspect of the conflict.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: in writing. - We strongly condemn all attacks against civilians and civilian infrastructure. The European Union focuses primarily on the humanitarian aspects of the conflict, but we are concerned that humanitarian aid will be diverted to terrorist groups. The European Parliament wants to highlight Turkey's ambiguous role in the Syrian conflict, which seeks primarily to stop the expansion of Kurdish militias rather than fighting the Islamic State group on Syrian territory.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the situation in Syria.  Regarding the humanitarian crisis in Syria, the resolution calls on all actors to urgently resume talks in the aim of a cessation of hostilities. The resolution equally calls on the Assad regime and Putin to immediately end all attacks against civilians and civilian infrastructure, to discontinue all sieges and to allow humanitarian access to the Syrian people. Further, the resolution asks that sanctions be imposed on Putin’s regime if it continues committing war crimes in Syria. I voted in favour of the resolution because I believe that the EU and its Member States have to play an important role in planning for the long-term recovery and reconstruction of Syria.

name: Ivica Tolić (PPE)
text: written. - I support the motion for a resolution submitted following a statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy pursuant to Article 123 (2). Rules of Procedure on the State of Syria (B8 1250/2016) I strongly condemn all attacks on civilians and civilian infrastructure, the continuation of all sieges in Syria and the fact that there is no humanitarian access for the needy Syrian people. I ask that all respect the rights of religious minorities in Syria, especially Christians, in order to continue living with dignity, in equality and security, in areas historically and traditionally their homeland, and to freely practice their faith and beliefs, without being victims of coercion, violence or discrimination.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - I have supported the European Parliament's resolution on matters in Syria. Europe's situation in Syria has been worrying from the outset. Conflict has not only regional dimensions but turns into global proportions. Europe has already felt the consequences through mass migration of Syrian refugees, as well as some terrorist actions. Syria has emerged the biggest humanitarian crisis since the end of World War II, with as many as 13 million Syrians needing humanitarian aid. We need to be aware that children and women do not have access to basic consumes such as drinking water, health care, food and the rest. It is necessary to condemn the constant bombardment of areas where the civilian population lives (say the western part of Allep) and expose that many innocent children and women die as a result. Condemn all human rights violations, war crimes and crimes against humanity. Everything needs to be done to suspend the flow of material and financial resources to terrorist military groups and, at one time, to provide assistance to United Nations troops. It is necessary to believe that the EU and member states can play an important role in resolving the political conflict in Syria.

name: Yana Toom (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The resolution includes numerous correct statements and criticism concerning the situation in Syria in general and the humanitarian crisis in Aleppo and other places. Nevertheless, I cannot agree with the statement that the most serious violations of international human rights and humanitarian law were committed by the Assad regime. We all are aware of the atrocities of ISIS and other terrorist groups operating in Syria. The resolution is hardly a constructive message to all parties involved that could motivate them to reach a peace agreement. Therefore, I decided to abstain.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against this resolution on the situation in Syria, considering it partial and warmongering, because it calls for the establishment of a no-fly zone, and by not addressing elements which I consider necessary to achieve a just and lasting peace, such as a call for a ceasefire by all parties, for dialogue effective and constructive — without external interference — among all parties to the conflict, and to propose just and human-rights solutions to refugees.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. — The proposed resolutions merely send back to back the various Islamist militias and Syrian loyalist troops and their Russian and Iranian legal allies. This is unacceptable and contrary to international law. I voted against it.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: in writing. — In September, a partial truce was negotiated, with the participation of the US and Russia, ending airstrikes on rebel-controlled territory and allowing both sides access to humanitarian aid. Unfortunately Syrian government forces with Russian backing have recently stepped up attacks on part of areas seized by rebels in the country's second-largest city, Aleppo. In intense and prolonged aerial bombardments, including on humanitarian convoys, thousands have been killed, almost all of them civilians. The U.S. and its allies rated these attacks as war crimes and accused Russia of “barbarism.” Moscow vigorously denied the allegations and criticized this “rhetoric unacceptable.” I voted for the motion for a resolution.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against this resolution on the situation in Syria, considering it partial and warmongering, because it calls for the establishment of a no-fly zone, and by not addressing elements which I consider necessary to achieve a just and lasting peace, such as a call for a ceasefire by all parties, for dialogue effective and constructive — without external interference — among all parties to the conflict, and to propose just and human-rights solutions to refugees.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I welcome the efforts made by humanitarian workers to provide much-needed support, food, water and medicines to those trapped in the conflict.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ In recent months the war in Syria has intensified. The continued attacks on civilians undermine the credibility of the international community to end the suffering of millions of Syrian men, women and children. It is therefore urgent to find an urgent political solution which, first of all, requires an immediate ceasefire so that humanitarian aid can be effectively distributed and the sick can be cared for. In order to achieve this solution, the role of the European Union must take on more weight at the negotiating table. That is why I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ My vote was clearly against this resolution, as I frontally reject the qualification of the terrorists, the same Al-Qaida terrorists who attacked the 11M in Spain as opposition. In addition, the report 'welcomes the review of EU restrictive measures against Syria' and argues that the Union 'should consider all available options, including a no-fly area', even though this measure is widely criticized and became classified as illegal. In addition, we oppose sanctions as a measure of coercion for mainly affecting peoples. In addition, the report argues that the main responsibility for the conflict and massacres of the Syrian population is the Assad “regime” backed by “Russia and Iran,” when it is precisely the Syrian government and the Russian Federation that most effectively fight terrorism that Europe claims to be so threatened. The report also totally evident the Syrian Government's efforts to achieve a just peace through dialogue, as shown by the establishment of the Reconciliation Committee and the reform of the Constitution. Peace will only come through dialogue between the government and the non-terrorist opposition.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because it demands an immediate end to bombing and indiscriminate attacks on civilians; it underlines the need for all parties to pay maximum attention and to take all appropriate measures to protect civilians, irrespective of their ethnic identity or religious or confessional beliefs. It also calls on all parties to the conflict to take all appropriate steps to protect civilians, in compliance with international law, including by ceasing attacks directed against civilian facilities, such as medical centres, schools and water stations, by immediately demilitarising such facilities, by seeking to avoid establishing military positions in densely populated areas and by enabling the evacuation of the wounded and all civilians who wish to leave besieged areas; it underlines that the Syrian regime has the primary responsibility for the protection of the Syrian population.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: — I voted in favour because six years of conflict, extreme violence and cruelty in Syria have killed more than 400 000 people and more than 13 million people need humanitarian aid.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: This is the seventh resolution on Syria that we have adopted since the beginning of this mandate. Many serious issues are raised. But this resolution once again bears the mark of double standards. While all parties to the conflict are condemned, the only States parties to the conflict named as such are Bashar al-Assad's Syria, Russia and Iran. ISIS, Al Nostra and other jihadist groups are also mentioned, but no word is said to denounce those who armed or financed them. Nor is it a word about our duty of solidarity with refugees fleeing the conflict. Nothing about humanitarian visas yet absolutely necessary. Nothing, except for self-satisfaction that the Union is one of the main providers of humanitarian aid for the people on the spot. The parties are also called upon to grant permanent and unimpeded access to humanitarian assistance to victims and an immediate end to the bombing and attacks against civilians. I chose to abstain out of solidarity with the victims regretting that the European Parliament is not able to go beyond it.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The situation in Syria is unacceptable in all respects and represents an eloquent example of the inhumanity of the EU's foreign policy. It is unacceptable for the EU to deny full respect for the independence, sovereignty and territorial integrity of states such as Syria. Respect for the multicultural nature of their societies is the only way to prevent the expansion of ISIL and the perpetuation of the suffering caused to its populations. Instead of turning a blind eye to ISIL's multiple funding and armaments channels, we call for the EU to strengthen humanitarian aid, invest more effort in treating refugees and promote a political peace solution while respecting international legality and the integrity of the Syrian state and its government legit.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: in writing. — I abstained from voting on this motion for a resolution because, on the one hand, Russia's blame for the scale of destruction and violence in Aleppo is repeatedly stressed, but on the other hand, the war is condemned in the strongest way.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the situation in Syria. I believe that the EU cannot and should not remain silent in the face of the ongoing massacre. On the contrary, the European Union must act collectively through the High Representative and take the lead in international efforts to find a diplomatic solution to the Syrian civil war.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I join my colleagues in condemning and deploring the grave human rights violations, war crimes and crimes against humanity currently taking place in Syria. My heart goes out to all those affected by the conflict, and all those humanitarian aid activists working on the ground in impossible conditions. I support the call in this resolution for the international community to do more to bring the perpetrators of these war crimes to justice. We must find the most adequate available means to do so at international level. The EU and its Member States must do more to accommodate and welcome Syrian refugees fleeing from conflict. National governments must urgently implement EU decisions and legislation on refugees, including providing aid and support to those Member States most affected. We must engage in a more compassionate and tolerant conversation about how to meet our moral obligations towards human beings that are fleeing war and suffering. We must also pay particular attention to the dramatic situations faced by child migrants and refugees, especially unaccompanied minors. Children must be provided with adequate care and health (including mental health) services, and must be able to access education in their host countries.

name: Lieve Wierinck (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution since I believe that the situation in Syria is very dramatic. Apart from the human tragedy of this war, it is also causing thousands of refugees to flow to Europe, incrementing an already huge problem for the European Union. There is a need to act because IS is trying to influence the region more and more. I support the call on all armed groups to cease collaboration with the former Al-Nusra. A no-fly zone over Aleppo should be established.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: in writing. - I supported the joint resolution on the situation in Syria because I consider it important that we do not stop talking about the ongoing serious humanitarian crisis in this country. Almost continuous struggles, lasting more than 6 years, have taken their toll not only on infrastructure, but mainly on the population. The conflict has so far claimed around 400,000 casualties and has caused one of the biggest humanitarian crises at the moment. 13 million people have found themselves dependent on humanitarian aid, not to mention more than 4.8 million people who, for fear of war, were forced to leave the country. Continuous bombing and military clashes make it impossible for humanitarian workers to access the areas hardest hit by the war. I strongly condemn all attacks on civilians and infrastructure. At the same time, I highlight the efforts of humanitarian workers who risk their lives daily to help the most needy. It is important for the EU to take the side of the civilian population and ensure that all those responsible for breaches of international humanitarian law are punished. At the same time, I support all diplomatic efforts that will lead to an immediate end to violence and return to the negotiating table.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing. - I have, of course, supported the resolution on the situation in Syria. The conflict, which has been going on for the sixth year, has hundreds of thousands of lives, millions of people in a situation where they urgently need access to humanitarian aid, and not least a few million refugees. In the country, the education system, health or social assistance systems are not working, and neighbouring countries are exhausted from the constant influx of people fleeing for conflict. The worst thing about the situation is that the parties to the conflict absolutely do not respect international law and thereby contribute to this humanitarian disaster.
