Violations of international law, as well as violations of agreements to ensure humanitarian access, which was ultimately not allowed, have been strongly condemned in the resolution. I appreciate the fact that the European Parliament is monitoring the situation in Syria closely, and although I do not think Parliament's resolutions will improve it, it is important that such treatment is strongly rejected on the part of Parliament as a moral authority.

name: Željana Zovko (PPE)
text: written. - I support the resolution that the European Parliament wants to warn of the situation in Syria. The worrying developments urge the entire world public to focus special attention on the unacceptable suffering and suffering of thousands of inhabitants in the war-torn country. Since the beginning of the counter-offensive conducted by the regime and its allies, the intensity and frequency of air strikes on Aleppo has increased, and facilities protected by international humanitarian law (hospitals, shelters, schools) are not spared in the attack. The state of total war and mutual struggle to exhaustion is certainly not the solution to the complex political situation in Syria. It is necessary to begin negotiations as soon as possible, accompanied by the establishment of a humanitarian cease-fire across the country, especially in large cities, so that the population can be delivered with the necessary resources and humanitarian assistance and to allow them to safely leave the conflict zone through humanitarian protected corridors. Syrian society, and especially the political system, must go through a peaceful transition, and all relevant actors on the international stage must help rebuild Syria, infrastructure and institutional.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the European Parliament's Resolution on the situation in Syria. Reports of extraordinary violence and brutality in Syria and the deteriorating humanitarian situation in Syria and attacks on civilians and civilian facilities are alarming and demand immediate action from the international community. I therefore join my calls for all parties to allow unimpeded and uninterrupted humanitarian access and delivery of emergency goods to the civilian population and for an immediate cessation of hostilities, which must be controlled through a strong and transparent mechanism. In this regard, I urge the EU and the Member States to ensure that all who have violated human rights and international humanitarian law will be held judicial liable for their actions through appropriate impartial international mechanisms of criminal law or national courts and applying the principle of general judicial decency.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: — I supported this resolution, which I personally welcome. I also supported the point concerning the further negotiation of Turkey's accession to the EU, i.e. that this should be suspended at this stage. Unfortunately, I am afraid, as a small part of my colleagues here in the hall, that Turkey, after the so-called putsch, has embarked on a path where the state of Turkey is moving away with its parameters to how we in Europe perceive the principle democratic rule of law. Significantly strengthened in this country by the authoritative government of the president. It's good to draw attention to that. I think it needs to be said, and I very much welcome that this resolution clearly says, among other things, that Turkey does not meet the conditions for the introduction of a visa-free regime at this time. The EP does not encourage there to be a visa-free regime with Turkey. I also want to draw attention to the strange detention of two Czechs in Turkey, when the circumstances are not yet clear as to why this happened, and I hope the whole thing becomes clear soon.

name: Jan Zahradil (ECR).
text: — Of course, I am sorry that there has been a resolution calling for a freeze in accession talks with Turkey. On the other hand, it's a very strong signal. I certainly have to say that Turkey deserves support when it comes to fighting Islamic terrorism, but also against the terrorism of Kurdish separatists seeking territorial disintegration of Turkey. It certainly deserves support when it comes to fighting a so-called parallel state in state structures and trying to neutralize various manifestations that could lead to a repeat of military coup attempts. On the other hand, it is necessary to admit that what takes place primarily in relation to media, what takes place in academia, in justice, in the armed services, in the civil service — purges and arresting or detaining a number of persons, today it goes into the tens of thousands — so that's really unacceptable and should be the subject of our increased attention.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (
text: NI). — (EL) Mr President, the Communist Party of Greece voted in favour of freezing the accession negotiations between the European Union and Turkey. However, the Communist Party of Greece, based on popular interests, opposes over time the accession of Turkey as well as Greece and every country of the coalition of capital. The European Parliament has now hypocritically recalled the authoritarianism of the Turkish authorities. It pledges to keep Turkey tied to the European Union, leaves pre-accession funding and visa waiver open, declares readiness to revise its position. The Communist Party condemns the wave of persecution of those who oppose the anti-grassroots policy of the Turkish government. We condemn the dangerous declarations of Erdogan, statements of questioning the Treaty of Lausanne, the borders of Greece and other countries. The European Parliament, with a last-minute amendment, is critical of these statements, while the Council, the Commission, the governments of other states remain silent, as is the systematic Turkish challenges in the Aegean. Imperialist bazaars, in which the Syriza-ANEL government is also involved on behalf of the Greek plutocracy, pose great risks for the people of the region. Their interest is to fight together against imperialism, capitalist barbarism that generates wars, crises, poverty and fugitions.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: — Dear Mr President, honourable Members, I voted for this resolution because someone in this House finally had to say clearly and unequivocally what the nature of Turkish President Erdogan's dictatorial regime is. It had to list all human rights violations, all media closings, attacks of edits, arrests of journalists, murders of journalists, ethnic cleansing of the Kurdish population, illegal invasion of the territory of the neighboring Arab Republic of Syria, territorial threats, which Mr Erdogan addressed to neighbouring Member States of the European Union and NATO, such as Bulgaria and Greece, his three speeches with which he wants to revise treaties and does not recognise our territorial borders. It is quite obvious that this man is turning his presidential institution into a dictatorial one. That is why I am pleased that, at last, the proposal that I have been making a year now, two years here, namely to freeze them, to suspend the negotiations on Turkey's accession to the European Union, has finally been heard. Today is a historic day. Turkey has no place in the European Union because it is not a European state.

name: Peter Jahr (PPE).
text: Mr President! We once had a TV show called “In all friendship”, which means that friends should and must tell each other the truth. Of course, we are working with Turkey in a joint military alliance, and of course I would also like to see deeper economic cooperation in the interests of a privileged partnership, and of course we are also pleased that compliance with the so-called Asylum Agreement by both sides — the European Union and the European Union, the European Union and the Republic of Turkey. But it must also be allowed — and it is important — to address things that are not right. And while the Democratic Republic is in the process of working out a coup undemocratically, we cannot just watch. That is why it was right and good to express a balanced opinion in this resolution. That is why it was also important to tell the Republic of Turkey very clearly to say to the people, especially to the President: what you are doing here is not right and is incompatible with European fundamental rights. It is quite more than appropriate and appropriate to at least suspend accession negotiations.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE).
text: — I regret that Turkey is moving away from the democratic regime it had and as we have known over the past decades. Still, regardless of the breadth of this resolution, I fenced myself and abstained in the vote. I condemn authoritative violations of fundamental human rights, suppression of media freedom, interference with the judiciary, persecution of intellectuals, MPs and civil servants. This has to be condemned and it is precisely that we have clearly fenced ourselves from such doing Erdogan and his authority. All of this, in my own terms, does not condone our thinking that the best response and the best route is to break talks and freeze negotiations. In fact, we have never conducted these negotiations, honestly, and we have not clarified within Europe what our real attitude towards Turkey is as, possibly, potential members of the European Union. We have left too many things open and that may be one of the reasons for the situation we are in today in relations with Turkey. I continue to believe in diplomacy and in conversations.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I supported the proposal to freeze Turkey’s talks on joining the EU, on the basis that the need to protect human rights and uphold democratic values is imperative. Ireland has always been a strong supporter of human rights, which makes the situation in Turkey a great concern for my country. The EU must send an unequivocal message that democratic values, due process and free speech are essential preconditions for EU membership, and while they are absent in Turkey it makes sense to freeze talks. More than 110 000 people, in academia, the military and the legal sector, have been dismissed from their posts as part of a government crackdown in Turkey since the attempted coup. Not to take a stance would be to undermine the EU’s credibility as a strong global player. Building on this, it is my belief that we must overcome the challenges of this watershed moment in our relations with Turkey by continuing to encourage Turkey’s advancement towards higher standards of democracy and human rights. Europe needs to lead by example and we are happy to continue to engage with Turkey. However, we must also take a strong stance on continued breaches of human rights.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution condemns the disproportionate repressive measures implemented in Turkey after the failed military coup attempt in July 2016 but rather than proceed with a Formal interruption of negotiations, blocking the disbursement of European pre-accession funds and the cancellation of the migrant agreement, the Commission and the Member States are invited to proceed only to one temporary suspension of ongoing accession negotiations with Turkey. I therefore abstained.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that we are facing a turning point in relations between the Union and Turkey. The last plenary session dealt with the situation of journalists in Turkey and the lack of press freedom, as well as the arrests and imprisonment of journalists. Erdogan's response has been to close one of the few independent newspapers and the arrest of more journalists. Add to that the arrest of the HDP party leader Demirtas, the country's third party, as well as other deputies. There is no point in continuing to negotiate Turkey's accession to the Union on Chapters 23 and 24 on justice, freedoms and fundamental rights, while the post-coup state of emergency allows for derogation of rights and purge. The government has embarked on the path of regression rather than progress. In turn, it marks a red line, if Turkey reintroduces the death penalty, it will result in the final suspension of the accession negotiations.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — In this case, a resolution on relations between the Union and Turkey was voted on, which talks about revising the European Instrument for Pre-Accession and calling on the Commission and the Member States to temporarily freeze Turkey's pre-accession negotiations. Moreover, the resolution begins with a “strong condemnation of Turkey's disproportionate repressive measures since the failed military coup attempt”, which I consider very positive. While the document also contains some elements that I do not agree with, such as the call for increased contribution through the European Instrument for the Promotion of Democracy and Human Rights, it also has very positive points, such as the reference to the arrests of members of the Kurdish HDP party. That is why my final vote was in favour of this resolution.

name: Martina Anderson Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This JMR was balanced and included support from a diverse range of delegations and groups. It rightly criticised Turkey for breaches of human rights and which is very critical of the Erdoğan regime’s post-coup purge and which calls on the Commission and Member States to freeze the accession negotiations until certain conditions are met.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution calling for the freeze of Turkey's accession negotiations. The continuing purges carried out since the attempted coup d'état in Turkey are of great concern to us: progressively, all the principles of the rule of law are being dismantled by Mr Erdogan. Violations on the independence of the judiciary and freedom of expression are unacceptable both within and outside the European Union. Turkey's role in managing migration flows cannot keep us silent on Mr Erdogan's repeated attacks on democracy. We are also considering the suspension of pre-accession aid. We must do everything we can to ensure that Mr. Erdogan respects the rule of law and human rights. This is true of our credibility. But the door to the Union remains open. That is why we blocked the offensives of Members who wanted to suspend negotiations. Such a suspension would amount de facto to a halt of the negotiations, since their resumption would require unanimity in the Council. Our condition for a return to discussions is clear: the return of a Turkish government that respects the rule of law and human rights.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the motion for resolution on EU-Turkey relations. Turkey’s long journey towards the EU has rather been a bumpy road of twists and turns. I recall voting in this hemicycle in December of 2004 on whether the EU should start accession negotiations with Turkey following an unusually heated debate. Ever since its accession talks with the EU, that started in 2005, only one out of 35 chapters has been closed. And that could be all that Turkey achieves on its path towards the EU if the current situation in the country will not change. More than one hundred thousand people have been sacked or suspended, thousands arrested, including 10 lawmakers from the opposition party in parliament, also journalists. This situation is simply not compatible with the status of the EU candidate country. Our position, reaction and our message to Mr Erdoğan should be clear: fundamental principles like the rule of law, human rights, freedom of speech and freedom of the press are crucial and non-negotiable. Enlargement negotiations with Turkey should be frozen immediately.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on Turkey-EU relations because I believe that the current accession negotiations should continue only when the Turkish Government returns to respect the rule of law and human rights.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: in writing. - The situation in Turkey has deteriorated further in recent months. While human rights such as freedom of the press and freedom of expression were already restricted before the failed coup attempt, the government is now taking even greater harshness against alleged opponents of the regime and dissenters. President Erdoğan has enforced mass layoffs and arrests and is turning Turkey into an autocratic state. In the light of these extremely worrying developments, the European Parliament's resolution calls on the Commission and the Member States to temporarily suspend accession talks with Turkey. I voted in favour of the resolution because I believe that suspending the talks is the least that the EU can do to clearly condemn the human rights situation in Turkey, even if, in my view, an even stronger signal would be desirable by breaking off the talks.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the resolution calling for the freeze of negotiations on Turkey's accession to the European Union. Since the start of these negotiations in 2005, this is the first time that Parliament has called for sanctions against this country, which does not meet the criteria for EU membership. The National Front supports the definitive halt of negotiations on Turkey's accession. Not only is Turkey not a European country, but fundamental rights are constantly and systematically violated. Arrests of MPs, magistrates and journalists are unacceptable, as are media and social media censorship. Turkey must also stop the persecution of religious minorities, in particular. Between 2005 and 2016, the European Union contributed nearly 10 billion to Turkey under the Instrument for Pre-Accession Assistance (IPA). It is inadmissible to continue to pay for Turkey. Neither by its history, nor by its culture, nor by its geography, let alone since the authoritarian and Islamist takeover of Erdogan, Turkey cannot claim to become European.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst this resolution is critical of Turkey in a number of places it also calls to ‘keep Turkey anchored to the EU’. I believe this resolution does not go far enough in halting Turkish accession therefore I voted to abstain.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this joint resolution because I believe it is our duty to strongly condemn the disproportionate repressive measures implemented in Turkey since July 2016. In fact, the freeze on the current accession negotiations is a good measure, since deviations relating to the rule of law and human rights are not tolerable.

name: Francisco Assis (S&D)
text: in writing. - The state of relations between the European Union and Turkey has recently deteriorated due to the extreme positions of its President and, as stated in this resolution, the Turkish Government's lack of political will to remain on the path set for its accession to the European Union. This text deserves my vote in favour, because it strongly condemns the repressive measures of the Turkish Government following the coup attempt and calls on the European Commission to temporarily freeze Turkey's accession negotiations to the European Union until the Turkish authorities return to respect the rule of law and human rights. It should be remembered that this accession process is something different from diplomatic relations between that country and the European Union and that we must remain committed to keeping Turkey 'anchored' to the European Union, and it is also clear to me that the place of a democratic Turkey will be within the European project.

name: Johannes Cornelis van Baalen (ALDE)
text: in writing. — (NL) The VVD voted in favour of the resolution on EU-Turkey relations because Turkey is increasingly moving away from the democratic rule of law and therefore cannot qualify for accession to the EU. The call for the freezing of accession negotiations is a clear signal to Turkey. The VVD attaches to the agreement between the EU and Turkey on the control of refugee flows. The VVD will endeavour to maintain this agreement. Turkey is also an important NATO member, which is important for our security.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution which, while it still does not call for an end or even the suspension of negotiations, which would allow the cessation of pre-accession aid, is the first since 2005 to call for a sanction against Turkey.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: in writing. — I abstained on this joint resolution because I am firmly convinced that we must go beyond speeches and actions which only increase tension and, on the contrary, start a genuine structured dialogue between Turkey and the European Union

name: Bas Belder (ECR)
text: — Since 1999, as a member of the European Parliament's competent Committee on Foreign Affairs, I have opposed accession negotiations with the Republic of Turkey. The deepening of the customs union in force between the Member States of the European Community and Turkey considered, and my party considered the SGP sufficient for relations between the Member States of the European Community and Turkey. The EP resolution on which we are voting today only calls on the Commission and the Council to put in place a temporary freeze on the current accession negotiations. In this way, the EP is giving the accession process, the outcome of which is very uncertain because at the moment both sides certainly do not give the impression that they want to continue Turkish membership of the EU, despite everything they want to do. The question arises: who takes hostage who or who torments who on this impassable political path? I am therefore voting against this Turkey resolution!

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Following the failed coup d'état in Turkey, the government of the country decreed a state of emergency, initiating a series of repressive measures in order to prosecute those responsible for trying to coup. However, the international community has been able to see how government policy has translated into particularly disproportionate actions, genuine violations of those fundamental rights and freedoms, which are protected the Turkish Constitution, which also constitute the founding values of the European Union. I voted in favour of the resolution tabled in Parliament today because I agree with the need to ask the Commission and the Member States to carry out a temporary suspension of accession negotiations in course with Turkey, in accordance with Article 5 of the negotiating framework. The introduction of the death penalty and serious and persistent violations of the principles of freedom, democracy and respect for human rights cannot be ignored. The text commits Parliament to review its position if the disproportionate measures taken in the context of the state of emergency in the country were lifted.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution agreeing to temporarily suspend Turkey's accession agreements to the Union, at least until the state of emergency is lifted. The resolution clearly condemns the disproportionate repression of the Erdogan government and specifically the repression of HDP. It leaves the door open, however, for negotiations to be resumed later.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported this resolution on EU-Turkey relations, which strongly condemns the disproportionate repressive measures taken in Turkey since the failed military coup attempt in July 2016. I share that there must be a relationship with Turkey, but I agree that the Commission and the Member States should be asked to initiate the procedure for the temporary suspension of the ongoing accession negotiations with Turkey.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: I preferred to abstain on this joint resolution concerning the freeze of Turkey's accession negotiations to the European Union. In my view, this resolution does not go far enough and should propose a definitive halt to negotiations. Not only is Turkey far from meeting European demands in terms of “values”, particularly in terms of freedom of expression or respect for pluralism, but also, its more than troubled role in the Syrian crisis may cause us to question whether Turkey can continue to consider Turkey as an ally in the fight against the terrorism. On the other hand, for questions of democratic legitimacy, it must be remembered that a majority of the citizens of the EU Member States are against this accession. It is also worrying that, through some statements, Turkey seems to want to call into question the Treaty of Lausanne, which had set the borders of modern Turkey. This could pose a threat, particularly to Cyprus, which, it seems necessary to recall, is a Member State of the European Union.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: In writing. ‒ The resolution rightly condemns President Erdogan's decision to reintroduce the death penalty in Turkey, as it is clearly contrary to the EU Acquis and respect for rights humans. Consequently, I would have expected this text to call for the immediate suspension of negotiations on Turkey's accession to the Union. Lacking the text of this clear stance, I could not support it with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that we are facing a turning point in relations between the Union and Turkey. The last plenary session dealt with the situation of journalists in Turkey and the lack of press freedom, as well as the arrests and imprisonment of journalists. Erdogan's response has been to close one of the few independent newspapers and the arrest of more journalists. Add to that the arrest of the HDP party leader Demirtas, the country's third party, as well as other deputies. There is no point in continuing to negotiate Turkey's accession to the Union on Chapters 23 and 24 on justice, freedoms and fundamental rights at the same time as the post-coup state of emergency allows for derogation of rights and purging. The government has embarked on the path of regression rather than progress. In turn, it marks a red line, if Turkey reintroduces the death penalty, it will result in the final suspension of the accession negotiations.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution because it advocated Parliament on EU-Turkey relations. The European Union and the European Parliament strongly condemned the failed military coup in Turkey and recognised the legitimate duty of the Turkish authorities to prosecute those responsible for and related to the attempt to commit this coup. However, the repressive measures taken by the Turkish Government following the declaration of emergency are disproportionate and violate the fundamental rights and freedoms protected by the Turkish Constitution, the democratic values on which the European Union is founded. There is a strong concern about the conditions for detention and arrest of persons following the collapsed coup attempt, as well as the strict restrictions on freedom of expression and the press and media in Turkey. Parliament noted that it remains committed to maintaining Turkey's links with the EU, but calls on the Commission and the Member States to initiate a temporary freezing of the ongoing accession negotiations with Turkey. Parliament also reiterated that if the Turkish Government returns the death penalty, the accession process would be formally suspended.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Turkey is an important strategic partner of the European Union. As a candidate country, it has made a commitment to the highest enforcement of democracy, human rights, the rule of law and fundamental freedoms. Point five of the negotiating framework provides that in the event of serious and persistent infringements of the principles on which the European Union is founded in Turkey, the Commission shall, on its own initiative or at the request of one third of the Member States, recommend the suspension of negotiations and propose the conditions for the possible resumption of negotiations. I think it is important to emphasise that the political will for cooperation in the Turkey-EU partnership must be on the part of both sides.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: in writing. - I believe that relations between the EU and Turkey began to cool as early as 2014 and the failed military coup made matters worse. The European Parliament condemned the military coup and affirmed legitimate authority in Turkey, but also condemned the disproportionate repressive measures that are subsequently being implemented. I therefore agree that accession negotiations should be frozen until disproportionate measures are eliminated. It should be said bobu bob, the absolutist situation, which is now being introduced by the Turkish president, do not fall within the framework of the European Union. Going on in Turkey does not currently follow the values on which the EU is based, so Turkey needs to come forward or want to participate in our society at all, otherwise it is better not to play the blind mice. Negotiations, of course, can be renewed again to the extent that the situation would change for the better.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this important resolution on the EU-Turkey relations bearing in mind the recent political developments that led to the arrest of many opponents to the Turkish Government. In this regard, we strongly condemn the disproportionate repressive measures taken by Erdoğan and we call on the Commission and the Member States to initiate a temporary freeze of the ongoing accession negotiations with Turkey.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: ‒ Turkey concerns us because it has not yet been able to establish an adequate economic strategy to keep public finances under control, curb inflation and stabilise the currency, while ensuring sustainable economic growth, but above all the human rights situation is worrying because the process of democratisation of the country has made vigorous steps back in the last two years. Turkey is now a country further away from the European Union than it was a decade ago: an unbalanced domestic economy with structural criticalities, is accompanied by a political, cultural and religious situation illiberal, undemocratic and incompatible with the values of a modern country. Until the government in Ankara starts seriously respecting freedom of thought, expression and religion, protecting minorities and not persecuting political dissidents there will be no possibility that Turkey could join the European Union. The EU — let us never forget — is first and foremost a community of freedom, respect for individual rights, democracy, solidarity and progress.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: in writing. — This motion for a resolution calls for the freeze of negotiations on Turkey's accession to the European Union. This is the first since discussions began in 2005. Certainly, we are in favour of a definitive halt of negotiations on Turkey's accession. Countries in which fundamental rights are regularly violated. Neither by its history, its culture, its geography, let alone under the authoritarian presidency of Erdogan, Turkey cannot claim to join the European Union. I still voted in favour of this text, which wishes, at least, to freeze these negotiations.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. - The European Union and the European Parliament strongly condemned the failed military coup in Turkey and recognised the legitimate responsibility of the Turkish authorities to bring all those responsible for this attempt and those involved to justice. However, repressive measures by Turkish authorities targeting opposition parties, including the arrest of opposition leaders and members of the Grand National Assembly of Turkey, journalists and others, are deeply disproportionate and contravene Turkish domestic law, violating commitments undertaken by a Member State of the Council of Europe and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. I voted in favour of the resolution, appreciating that it is emphasised that the reintroduction of the death penalty is blatantly contrary to the values of the European Union and, of course, would lead to the interruption of negotiations between the EU and Turkey on any level. Moreover, Turkey has so far failed to meet 7 of the 72 benchmarks of the visa liberalisation roadmap, some of which are particularly important. The Commission must establish clear benchmarks for the resumption of accession negotiations, taking into account the conditions laid down in the Copenhagen criteria and the obligations of Turkey as a member of the Council of Europe.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that we are facing a turning point in relations between the Union and Turkey. The last plenary session dealt with the situation of journalists in Turkey and the lack of press freedom, as well as the arrests and imprisonment of journalists. Erdogan's response has been to close one of the few independent newspapers and the arrest of more journalists. Add to that the arrest of the HDP party leader Demirtas, the country's third party, as well as other deputies. There is no point in continuing to negotiate Turkey's accession to the Union on Chapters 23 and 24 on justice, freedoms and fundamental rights at the same time as the post-coup state of emergency allows for derogation of rights and purging. The government has embarked on the path of regression rather than progress. In turn, it marks a red line, if Turkey reintroduces the death penalty, it will result in the final suspension of the accession negotiations.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the resolution on EU-Turkey relations calling for the freeze of accession negotiations with Turkey. Turkey is not intended to be a member of the European Union and accession negotiations lie with the Turkish people. Parliament is particularly concerned about the repression and threat of President Erdogan who wishes to reintroduce the death penalty. The democratic deficit and the consideration of the reintroduction of capital punishment were measures that violate human rights. Turkey must respect the acquis of the Union and stop challenging international treaties. However, the strategic partnership between the European Union and Turkey is very beneficial to both partners and the European Parliament will continue to defend the deepening of economic and customs relations between the European Union and Turkey.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on EU-Turkey relations because Our concerns over Turkey's domestic situation persist. Disturbing episodes, such as the arrest of opposition MPs, indiscriminate newspaper closures, the plan to reintroduce the death penalty into the judicial system, ultimately the proposal for law that decriminalizes sexual abuse against minors, (a proposal temporarily withdrawn for vibrant protests), arouses disconcertment inside and outside the country. My vote in favour of this statement because it is now clear that for the EU, respect for human rights from a practical point of view remains vital also for the functioning of the agreement between the EU and Turkey on migratory flows. It is more necessary than ever for the European Union to continue to work to ensure that European standards of democracy are guaranteed, without compromise.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution calling for a freeze in Turkey’s membership talks in protest of the massive crackdown of opponents of the Turkish Government. I find the disproportionate repressive measures taken in Turkey since the failed coup attempt in July 2016 very worrisome. It is important to highlight that a failed military take-over cannot be used as a pretext for the Turkish Government to further stifle legitimate and peaceful opposition and to prevent journalists and the media in their peaceful exercise of freedom of expression through disproportionate and illegal actions and measures. Mr Erdoğan’s authoritarianism has been creeping in slowly but surely for some years now, silencing and jailing his critics. Surely, by President Erdoğan advocating for a referendum on the death penalty is not quite the right signal for future EU membership.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ Democracy in Turkey no longer exists, and this is a fact that we must take note of and react accordingly. The abstention of the 5 Star Europe Movement on the resolution on the temporary freeze of negotiations for Turkey's accession to the European Union is a very first step towards recognizing the failure to meet the criteria necessary for negotiations, but more needs to be done. In fact, we call for the formal suspension of negotiations, the blocking of European pre-accession funds and the cancellation of the migrant agreement signed with Erdogan.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution as I believe it is a right time to send a strong political message to Turkish authorities that we are deeply concerned by recent developments in their country. There are signs of Turkey drifting away from democratic principles which it has endorsed as a candidate country to the EU accession. We need to keep the dialogue with Turkey, but have to also make clear that there are rules both sides have to respect.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: in writing. - The complaints from all groups in the European Parliament against Turkey for the violation of human rights, for the disregard of the principles of international law and the complete violation of the principles and values of the European Union are not a recent case. We have to admit that Turkey has been tolerated over time, impunity and gratuitous treatment of Turkey by the European Union. Human rights are being violated by Turkey and in a member country of the European Union, Cyprus, which has been invaded and occupied for 42 years. Despite the intense effort of the President of the Republic, Nicos Anastasiades, and his willingness to resolve the problem peacefully, Turkey again led the negotiations to Switzerland, to no avail, because the attacker continues to cling to provocatively unacceptable positions. Turkey is the occupying power that created the Cyprus Problem and is the only one that can solve it immediately. The European Union and the other forces must really put pressure on Turkey. I keep hearing that Turkey is a reliable and strategic partner. In practice, it turns out that Turkey has never been credible and cannot be presented as a strategic partner. That is why we must withdraw such false and untrue assessments that are being heard in the European Parliament.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The motion for a resolution on relations between the European Union and Turkey is an attempt to illustrate the disappointment of MEPs over the aggressive behaviour of officials of the Turkish state. As Europe cannot watch the violation of the fundamental rights of citizens, the challenges and the expansive rhetoric of the Turkish leadership, I voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ I strongly support the resolution in its contents: if on the one hand it is in me firm the will to condemn the failed military coup d'état of 15 July last, it is equally vigorous that of censor the behaviour followed by the Turkish state following the attempted coup. Underogably, I recognise Turkey's legitimate responsibility to punish those who have been plotting against its political framework, but the adoption of repressive measures, disproportionate use of the force and political arrests are not acceptable. We must not, of course, leave out how 36,000 people have been held since July 15 and 110 thousand suspended or raised by military, political, academic and judicial posts. Therefore, in line with what the PPE advocates, I evoke the suspension of access to negotiations until the Turkish Government returns to the path of respect for the rule of law and human rights. Moreover, we could consider a temporary suspension of funds without less support for refugees and migrants. In parallel with what is said, Turkey is not ready for visa liberalisation because it is not meeting as many as 7 of the 72 requirements required.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the motion for resolution on EU-Turkey Relations.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. - In March of this year, right after the EU-Turkey declaration on the so-called refugee crisis, I warned of the dangers of such an agreement. Not only did I express reservations about the effectiveness and legality of what we were asking of Turkey, but about the feasibility of the compensatory measures we offered. In fact, I doubted whether the billions promised would be raised, and today only a small part has actually been handed over to Greece; I doubted whether it would be possible to liberalise visas with that country, and today that possibility remains at least as far away as then and, finally, I doubted that it would be prudent nod with the adhesion. Today, it is clear that membership will be impossible in the near future. What we have seen in Turkey is contrary to the values that are essential for any member of the Union. While we cannot ignore the fact that Turkey is a natural partner of the Union, for obvious geostrategic reasons, it is also true that there are principles on which we cannot pass over. I therefore support this resolution and stress its main message: to suspend accession negotiations with Turkey.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: in writing. — I supported the resolution because, under the circumstances, accession negotiations with Turkey must be suspended. Since the failed coup attempt last July, thousands of officials have been dismissed, freedom of the press has increasingly been restricted, media stations have been closed and freely-elected Members have been arrested. This approach is contrary to all fundamental values of the EU. I hope that Turkey will change its course as soon as possible so that the existing partnership can remain in place.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the measure because I believe that it is necessary, by the legitimate Turkish government authorities, to ensure respect for human rights, the rule of law, fundamental freedoms and the universal right to a fair trial within Turkey consistent with the values on which the EU is founded.

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE)
text: in writing. - I share the concern and criticism of developments in Turkey and take a clear stand for human rights and freedom of the media. Freezing membership negotiations is the wrong way to go. We need to engage more in dialogue, not less. The negotiations are our most important tool to influence Turkey in the right direction and push for reform of the rule of law. I don't see any way that aborted membership negotiations would lead to a more democratic Turkey. Freezing negotiations instead undermines the liberal forces that want to modernize Turkey. They see the EU as an anchor that prevents Turkey pushing further away from democracy. The people of Turkey already traumatised by the coup attempt would feel we are turning our backs on them even more. Governments come and go. We need to look to the future and look at the strategic interest in an EU-Turkey relationship. If the EU were to freeze negotiations unilaterally now, it would strengthen the nationalists and Erdoğan's attempts to centralize power, contrary to what we want. It is also the wrong time and would jeopardize final negotiations in Cyprus and the migration agreement with Turkey. Against that background, I was convinced to vote against the demand for a freeze in negotiations and abstained in the final vote.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — In this case, a resolution on relations between the Union and Turkey was voted on, which talks about revising the European Instrument for Pre-Accession and calling on the Commission and the Member States to temporarily freeze Turkey's pre-accession negotiations. Moreover, the resolution begins with a “strong condemnation of Turkey's disproportionate repressive measures since the failed military coup attempt”, which I consider very positive. While the document also contains some elements that I do not agree with, such as the call for increased contribution through the European Instrument for the Promotion of Democracy and Human Rights, it also has very positive points, such as the reference to the arrests of members of the Kurdish HDP party. That is why my final vote was in favour of this resolution.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution calling on the Commission and the Member States to temporarily suspend ongoing accession negotiations with Turkey. Although it considers Turkey to be a key strategic partner for Europe and although the Turkish authorities' reaction to the coup is legitimate, I am convinced that the repressive scope of the measures taken From July onwards it is disproportionate and violates the freedom of expression recognised by the European Convention on Human Rights, to which Turkey is a signatory. I am particularly concerned about statements in favour of the reintroduction of the death penalty in Turkey, and I believe that such a step is not justified by the emergency situation and, indeed, it can represent a dangerous authoritarian drift for Turkish civil society and for the geo-political balances of the region. In line with the resolution, I believe that the EU should only revise its position when Turkey revoys a state of emergency and restores the rule of law and human rights across the country.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Turkey is an important strategic partner of the European Union. As a candidate country, it has made a commitment to the highest enforcement of democracy, human rights, the rule of law and fundamental freedoms. Point five of the negotiating framework provides that in the event of serious and persistent infringements of the principles on which the European Union is founded in Turkey, the Commission shall, on its own initiative or at the request of one third of the Member States, recommend the suspension of negotiations and propose the conditions for the possible resumption of negotiations. In the Turkey-EU partnership, the political will for cooperation must be on the part of both sides. However, the report points out that Turkey has not demonstrated this political will recently. The report strongly condemns the disproportionate repressive measures taken since the failure of the military coup attempted in Turkey in July 2016. It expresses grave concern about the living conditions of the arrested persons, as well as the restrictions on freedom of expression, the press and the media. Since the July coup attempt, the government's actions have increasingly diverted Turkey from the road towards Europe. With all this in mind, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing. — I abstained from voting on a resolution to freeze negotiations on Turkey's accession to the EU. The rationale for my vote is the situation that has been taking place in Turkey since the July coup. I think Turkey is an important partner in geopolitical terms in terms of building a strategic security system for Europe. However, problems concerning both internal destabilisation and external relations with the EU have led to the deterioration of Turkey's situation on its way to membership of the community structures. Taking action to unequivocally freeze Turkey and the EU relations could lead to a cooling of the relationship, which could in turn result in irreversible political consequences.

name: Peter van Dalen (ECR)
text: ‒ All representatives of Christian Union SGP in the European Parliament have always opposed Turkish accession to the EU. They have therefore also opposed accession negotiations and the many billions of subsidies given to Turkey in this context in recent years. Turkey is not and never will be a European country geographically, culturally and politically. Until recently, the majority in the European Council, in the European Parliament and in the House of Representatives considered that Turkey could best join. This view is now crumbling at a rapid pace: fine! The European Parliament resolution on EU-Turkey relations is not perfect. There is no mention of the definitive cessation of accession negotiations, and unfortunately the accession funds cannot be stopped immediately. Yet, for the first time in history, the European Parliament calls for a freeze on accession negotiations with an official candidate country to the European Union. An historic moment and a giant step towards our position on Turkey. So I am counting my political blessings: for the first time in its existence, the EP is clearly moving towards our views on Turkey. That is why I support this joint resolution.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as I am concerned about the ongoing situation in Turkey following the military coup that occurred in July of this year. The worsening of the situation of media freedom in Turkey and the disproportionate repressive measures being taken by the Turkish Government mean that the EU should suspend accession negotiations until such violations are addressed. Turkey’s partnership with the EU must be encouraged in a way which is mutually beneficial for both parties; however, the EU cannot make any exceptions when it comes to human rights violations.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. — This resolution calls for the temporary freeze of Turkey's accession negotiations to the EU, given the political developments in Turkey. This resolution clearly shows that the positions of the French delegation on this issue are gaining ground. For my part, I reaffirm that Turkey is not intended to become a member of the European Union. However, I consider Turkey to be an indispensable partner of the European Union, although at present Turkey is in a worrying drift with regard to the violation of fundamental rights. For these reasons, I therefore voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: I voted in favour of this text, which calls for a freeze on accession negotiations with Turkey. I would have liked us to go further and make a clear decision to put an end to these negotiations. Turkey is not intended to enter the European Union. The serious concerns raised by the repressive measures put in place following the attempted coup d'état are another blatant illustration of this. However, the freezing of negotiations is today the most realistic approach, and a strong signal sent to halt any progress in these negotiations.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution on relations between the European Union and Turkey. We must send a clear message to Turkey, no negotiations can take place under such conditions. Moreover, an immediate freeze of negotiations as proposed in that resolution is the most realistic solution at the international level. The European Union and Turkey are intended to be economic partners and to cooperate on their security policy, which is why we must not completely break the dialogue. But under no circumstances does it have a place as a Member State, because of its geographical location and political instability.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Turkey is an important strategic partner of the European Union. As a candidate country, it has made a commitment to the highest enforcement of democracy, human rights, the rule of law and fundamental freedoms. Point five of the negotiating framework provides that in the event of serious and persistent infringements of the principles on which the European Union is founded in Turkey, the Commission shall, on its own initiative or at the request of one third of the Member States, recommend the suspension of negotiations and propose the conditions for the possible resumption of negotiations. In the Turkey-EU partnership, the political will for cooperation must be on the part of both sides. However, Turkey does not demonstrate this political will, the report emphasises. Since the July coup attempt, the government's actions have increasingly diverted Turkey from the road towards Europe. In the report, the European Parliament strongly condemns the attempted coup in Turkey and, no less, the subsequent disproportionate measures taken during the state of emergency, violating the fundamental rights and freedoms imposed by the Constitution. Furthermore, Parliament expresses its grave concern about the living conditions of the arrested persons and the restrictions on freedom of expression, the press and the media. With all this in mind, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D)
text: Democracy and accession to the European Union have been a means for Turkish President Erdogan to assume responsibility. Today, the mask falls. In a position of strength — particularly with regard to the refugee crisis and the rise of the terrorist threat — Recep Erdogan puts in place all the powers of a dictatorship: despotism, personality worship, enrichment of his relatives... The situation is extremely worrying, which I am regularly seized by academics and journalists. Strategically, Recep Erdogan has an interest in pushing for a break... he wants to be able to rely on EU decisions to justify his choices, including building other alliances with Central Asia and Russia. However, we must ensure respect for European values and not sacrifice them on the altar of political realities. The reinstatement of the death penalty is a red line. The freeze on negotiations with a budgetary freeze on pre-accession payments — which I wanted to add to the original text — is a first formal answer that I support.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this text. Finally, this text calls for a freeze on accession negotiations with Turkey, a country which does not meet any of the criteria for accession to the European Union: in addition to non-belonging to the European continent, Turkey has recently distinguished itself by its savage repression of journalists, magistrates and MEPs, in addition to breaches of fundamental rights frequently reported in that country (including the oppression of religious minorities). In addition, between 2005 and 2016, the European Union contributed nearly 10 billion to Turkey under the Instrument for Pre-Accession Assistance (IPA), which is unacceptable.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Turkey is an important strategic partner of the European Union. As a candidate country, it has made a commitment to the highest enforcement of democracy, human rights, the rule of law and fundamental freedoms. Point five of the negotiating framework provides that in the event of serious and persistent infringements of the principles on which the European Union is founded in Turkey, the Commission shall, on its own initiative or at the request of one third of the Member States, recommend the suspension of negotiations and propose the conditions for the possible resumption of negotiations. In the Turkey-EU partnership, the political will for cooperation must be on the part of both sides. However, Turkey does not demonstrate this political will, the report emphasises. Since the July coup attempt, the government's actions have increasingly diverted Turkey from the road towards Europe. In the report, the European Parliament strongly condemns the attempted coup in Turkey and, no less, the subsequent disproportionate measures taken during the state of emergency, violating the fundamental rights and freedoms imposed by the Constitution. Furthermore, Parliament expresses its grave concern about the living conditions of the arrested persons and the restrictions on freedom of expression, the press and the media. With all this in mind, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution, which calls for the freezing of accession negotiations with Turkey. It was passed with a substantial majority, indicating the strength of feeling on this issue. The prospect of Turkey joining the EU was used as a scare tactic in the referendum campaign in Wales. This resolution shows clearly that the European Parliament will not allow any country that allows violations of human rights to continue negotiations. Communication channels remain open but progress will not be made on EU membership until there is progress in Turkey in the interests of its people.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Turkey is an important neighbouring country and an important partner of the EU. Turkey has been negotiating with the EU for many years to become a member country in the future. All along, the Centre Party has been favourably committed to these negotiations. For quite some time and especially since the failed coup d'etat this summer, Turkey has evolved in a direction that goes entirely towards fundamental values in the EU. Journalists have been detained, media houses have been shut down and MPs have been arrested on unclear grounds. In troubled times and in such a position, standing up for liberal and libertarian principles is extra important. I have therefore chosen to vote in favour of this report, which calls on the Commission and the Council to freeze membership negotiations with Turkey until negative developments have been reversed.

name: Markus Ferber (PPE)
text: in writing. - Suspising the accession negotiations between the EU and Turkey is not a sufficient step. In view of the serious violations of human rights and freedom of the press in Turkey, a complete and irrevocable discontinuation of accession negotiations with Turkey is the only logical and honest approach. This step must be taken immediately.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: in writing. — FN-RBM MEPs in the European Parliament voted in favour of the resolution calling for the freeze of negotiations on Turkey's accession to the European Union. Since the start of these negotiations in 2005, this is the first time that Parliament has called for sanctions against this country, which does not meet the criteria for EU membership.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - In this resolution, what is not there, namely the shameful EU-Turkey agreement. Turkey's role in NATO and the conflicts in Syria and Iraq is not addressed. There is no reference to the situation in Cyprus. The situation in Turkey justifies great concern. The arrest of HDP leaders, communists and other democrats who are fighting in the country deserves denunciation, condemnation and all solidarity with the victims of the repression. However, the immense cynicism of those who — like the EU, which negotiates Turkey's accession — pretend to have discovered in the aftermath of the failed coup the repressive and authoritarian character of the policy of Erdogan and the AKP, thus seeking not only to influence the immediate development of the situation in Turkey, but cover up its broad collusion with the Turkish authorities and their policy, such as the illegal occupation of Cyprus, the repression of the Kurdish population, the restriction of fundamental freedoms, rights and guarantees, the aggression and looting of Syria and Iraq, promoting and protecting terrorist groups and supporting their bloody action, or the exploitation of the dramatic situation of millions of refugees and the denial of their most elementary rights.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing. - The European Union and Turkey have historically complicated relations not only because of Turkey's constantly delaying accession process to the European Union. Nor has the attempt at a military coup that took place in Turkey this year and whose reverberations are still heard in Turkey today in the form of a massive appeal not only in the state administration, but also in the police, military, but also in education, for example. However, the European Union and Turkey have shown that they can also work together in a refugee agreement, for example. The European Union supports the will of Turkish citizens who demand the preservation of democratic institutions and freedoms. Turkey must also strive to safeguard the rights of minorities in the future and seek not to jeopardise media freedom.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: In writing. - I am voting against the report, I have always been against Turkey's entry into Europe and this report appears weak.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: in writing. - I am voting in favour of the motions for resolutions as Turkey has no place in the European Union for the simple reason that it does not belong to Europe at all levels, such as culture, customs and history.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. - I believe that it is in the interests of both parties - both Turkey and the European Union - that Turkey's accession process to the EU should continue on the basis of compliance with the agreed conditionalities. According to the recent publication, on 9 November 2016, by the European Commission of the Annual Enlargement Package, I share the message it reconfirms, namely that the firm prospect of accession to the European Union continues to exert a transformative effect and constitutes an anchor of stability and security in the countries of southeastern Europe, including Turkey. This perspective is all the more important in the context of the complex crises that the Union has been facing lately. The European Commission's report on Turkey is a comprehensive one, highlighting the particular complexity of the EU-Turkey relationship. With regard to the latest developments in Turkey, I believe that unity at EU level is essential.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Turkey is an important strategic partner of the European Union. As a candidate country, it has made a commitment to the highest enforcement of democracy, human rights, the rule of law and fundamental freedoms. Point five of the negotiating framework provides that in the event of serious and persistent infringements of the principles on which the European Union is founded in Turkey, the Commission shall, on its own initiative or at the request of one third of the Member States, recommend the suspension of negotiations and propose the conditions for the possible resumption of negotiations. In the Turkey-EU partnership, the political will for cooperation must be on the part of both sides. However, Turkey does not demonstrate this political will, the report emphasises. Since the July coup attempt, the government's actions have increasingly diverted Turkey from the road towards Europe. In the report, the European Parliament strongly condemns the attempted coup in Turkey and, no less, the subsequent disproportionate measures taken during the state of emergency, violating the fundamental rights and freedoms imposed by the Constitution. Furthermore, Parliament expresses its grave concern about the living conditions of the arrested persons and the restrictions on freedom of expression, the press and the media. With all this in mind, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution bearing in mind the failed coup d'état in Turkey, recognizing the legitimate responsibility of the Turkish authorities to bring to justice those responsible and the participants in the coup attempt. However, the repressive measures taken by the Turkish Government under the state of emergency are disproportionate and violate the fundamental rights and freedoms protected by the country's Constitution, the democratic values on which the Union is founded. Therefore, as long as these democratic deficiencies persist, it is not possible to open new negotiating chapters for accession to the Union. From the institutions of the Union, we must call on the Turkish authorities to restrain and fulfil their obligations towards democracy and the rule of law.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that we are facing a turning point in relations between Turkey and the Union. At the last plenary session, the situation of journalists in Turkey and the lack of press freedom were addressed. Recep Tayyip Erdogan responded with the closure of one of the few independent newspapers and the arrest of more journalists. In addition, several Kurdish deputies were arrested, including Selahattin Demirtas, leader of HDP, the country's third party. There is no point in continuing to negotiate Turkey's accession to the Union (through Chapters 23 and 24 on justice, fundamental freedoms and rights) if, at the same time, the post-coup state of emergency allows the suspension of rights. The Turkish government has embarked on the path of democratic regression. If Turkey reintroduces the death penalty, it will result in the final suspension of the accession negotiations.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that we are facing a turning point in relations between the Union and Turkey. The last plenary session dealt with the situation of journalists in Turkey and the lack of press freedom, as well as the arrests and imprisonment of journalists. Erdogan's response has been to close one of the few independent newspapers and the arrest of more journalists. Add to that the arrest of the HDP party leader Demirtas, the country's third party, as well as other deputies. There is no point in continuing to negotiate Turkey's accession to the Union on Chapters 23 and 24 on justice, freedoms and fundamental rights at the same time as the post-coup state of emergency allows for derogation of rights and purging. The government has embarked on the path of regression rather than progress. In turn, it marks a red line, if Turkey reintroduces the death penalty, it will result in the final suspension of the accession negotiations.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: in writing. - The European Parliament has advocated by a large majority that the accession negotiations with Turkey should be terminated in the circumstances. We are basically responding to a rather inappropriate question from the Turkish President, who wanted us to know exactly that. Now he has the answer — which is why I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: in writing. — On the basis of current developments in Turkey, I have spoken in favour of freezing the accession negotiations.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ EU-Turkey relations have become increasingly strained since the attempted coup. The biggest source of tension is the crackdown in the aftermath of the coup, including the persecution of journalists and the possible reintroduction of the death penalty. The viability of the migration deal has been called into question with Erdoğan becoming increasingly frustrated at the lack of progress towards EU accession. He has issued an ultimatum to the EU on this issue and suggested that Turkey may give up its ambitions to become an EU member.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution urging the Council and the European Commission to temporarily freeze accession negotiations with Turkey. We can no longer stay silent on the disproportionate repression measures taken by Erdoğan in the wake of the recent coup attempt. The freeze should be maintained as long as the Turkish authorities continue to neglect and undermine democracy and the rule of law.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ The news of the last few days, and among all I mention the arrest for political reasons of national parliamentarians and the commissioning of thirty municipalities in the Kurdish majority territories, not let us hope for the willingness of the Turkish authorities to ensure the normal conduct of political life in that country with responsibility. The inflection had in respect of human rights in reaction to the attempted coup d'état in July does not seem to stop. We therefore face a necessary and inevitable debate today, which cannot but have an impact on mutual relations between the Union and Turkey. However, I believe that dialogue should remain open: only in this way will we continue to have a partner in Turkey to call for a reversal of the trend on respect for human rights. If we cut relations we will no longer have a say in the international political life of this country. Dialogue with the Turkish authorities is the only way that will allow us to continue to denounce the attack on freedom of the press, of expression and the free exercise of civil and political rights to the detriment of populations in Turkey. Yes, therefore, to dialogue, but we do not cease to ask our Turkish partners for the restoration of democracy and the release of political prisoners.

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI)
text: This joint resolution, which is reduced to a minimum compared to the texts it compiles and replaces, some of which were much better, is a good surprise. This is the first time that Parliament itself has called for a freeze on negotiations. This would also be a great first: accession negotiations have been opened although the prerequisite criteria, in particular the “Copenhagen criteria”, have been far from met. It is only time to note that they are still not, more than 10 years later, and even that the situation has deteriorated. I regret, however, that this late and lacunar access to the resolution on Syria, dominated by your unhealthy hatred of Russia and the Syrian regime. This resolution persists in sending back to back the protagonists of the Syrian conflict, terrorist groups or legitimate governments, believing in the existence of “moderate” rebels, and overshadding the direct or indirect responsibilities of countries such as Qatar or Saudi Arabia. And even, precisely, Mr Erdogan's Turkey. Consistency is not your strong.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution agreeing to temporarily suspend Turkey's accession agreements to the Union, at least until the state of emergency is lifted. The resolution clearly condemns the disproportionate repression of the Erdogan government and specifically the repression of HDP. It leaves the door open, however, for negotiations to be resumed later.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this this resolution urging the Council and the European Commission to temporarily freeze accession negotiations with Turkey. We cannot continue relations as normal with Turkey all the while that Erdoğan continues to repress human rights and the rule of law.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. — The message is clear: this morning the European Parliament voted in favour of the temporary freeze of EU accession negotiations with Turkey. I welcome this vote, which I hope is a first step before the final halt of the discussions. We need to go further, remove ambiguities and say loud and loud that Turkey is not intended to be part of the EU. His provocative attitude and its retrograde and authoritarian policy calls for firmness... Moreover, the bad faith of its leader, Tayyip Erdogan, and his contempt for Europe makes Turkey an unreliable partner at present. The door to negotiations must definitely close!

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. — The situation in Turkey is deteriorating day after day; freedom of expression flouted, muzzled press, arrests of political opponents, human rights defenders, journalists or teachers; this must stop. That is why I voted in favour of the resolution on the freeze of negotiations on Turkey's accession to the European Union. It is not a question of abandoning these negotiations but of sending a clear message to President Erdogan: the direction taken by the Turkish authorities is neither acceptable nor compatible with entry into the European Union. These negotiations can resume as soon as the rule of law is restored across the country and the defence of democracy becomes the priority of the Turkish government.

name: Jytte Guteland Olle Ludvigsson Jens Nilsson och Marita Ulvskog (S&D)
text: in writing. — It is with great concern we have been following developments in Turkey since the attempted military coup in July this year. The extensive detention of journalists, judges, prosecutors and elected representatives (including 10 members from the HDP opposition party) as well as the severe restrictions on freedom of expression that have occurred under the current state of emergency are completely unacceptable. We Swedish Social Democrats believe that when democratic principles, respect for human rights and the rule of law are overridden as they have been done in Turkey in recent times, it is important that the European Parliament clearly marks against this. That is why we chose to support the resolution which calls for a temporary break in the country's accession negotiations with the EU. However, we would like to emphasise that we believe that this should only be a temporary measure, and therefore it is also important to clearly define the criteria Turkey must meet in order for a rapid resumption of accession negotiations to be possible. The Copenhagen criteria should be indicative of this assessment.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that we are facing a turning point in relations between the Union and Turkey. The last plenary session dealt with the situation of journalists in Turkey and the lack of press freedom, as well as the arrests and imprisonment of journalists. Erdogan's response has been to close one of the few independent newspapers and the arrest of more journalists. Add to that the arrest of the HDP party leader Demirtas, the country's third party, as well as other deputies. There is no point in continuing to negotiate Turkey's accession to the Union on Chapters 23 and 24 on justice, freedoms and fundamental rights at the same time as the post-coup state of emergency allows for derogation of rights and purging. The government has embarked on the path of regression rather than progress. In turn, it marks a red line, if Turkey reintroduces the death penalty, it will result in the final suspension of the accession negotiations.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted in favour and endorsed the resolution on EU-Turkey relations and the situation in the country. It is another strong resolution by Parliament which shows that this country is not heading in the right direction. The state of emergency imposed on the country with all this entails, along with the imprisonment of the HDP leaders, forced Parliament to move forward with this resolution. Among other things, the resolution calls on the Council and the Commission to suspend accession negotiations with Turkey.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution on the temporary freeze of the ongoing accession negotiations between the EU and Turkey. This resolution is based on the serious concerns and state of emergency currently in Turkey. The Turkish Government are in breach of the principles of liberty, democracy, respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms. I strongly condemn the disproportionate repressive actions taking place there and call for President Erdoğan and members of the Turkish Government to restore the rule of law and human rights throughout the country.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: in writing. - This motion for a resolution rightly points to the very problematic situation in Turkey regarding respect for fundamental rights, the persecution of journalists and the repression of the political opposition. In order to give a signal, I voted accordingly in favour of the freezing of the EU accession negotiations with Turkey, that is to say this resolution.

name: Gunnar Hökmark (PPE)
text: in writing. — Political developments in Turkey are causing great concern. In several areas, Turkey is going in the wrong direction, both in terms of human freedoms and rights and the other criteria applicable to membership of the EU. At the same time, it is important to provide, as far as possible, opportunity and space for the forces wishing to modernise Turkish society to be able to point to Europe as an obvious partner. Against that background, it is not necessary to call for a freeze on negotiations between the EU and Turkey today, while at the same time the criticism directed at current developments is warranted. Hopefully it can be turned to a direction that is for the benefit of both Turkey and Europe. I still have hopes that such a turnaround can happen and see continued negotiations as an important basis for this. Against that background, I voted today against the call for a freeze in negotiations and chose to abstain in the vote on the resolution as a whole.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: relations between the European Union and Turkey have always been delicate because our messages to this strategic partner have been blurred for decades. We must reaffirm our commitment to close cooperation with Turkey, whether it be trade relations, security policy in the Mediterranean region or migration policy. However, Turkey is a country of 80 million inhabitants bordering countries as volatile as Syria and Iraq, of which only 3% of its territorial surface is in Europe. Turkey is not intended to enter the European Union. We must be clear on this point and close all the negotiating chapters which are just a masquerade. The purges carried out in Turkey are a cause of great concern in Europe and rightly so. President Erdogan's authoritarian drift and threats to force Europeans' hand on the issues of accession and visa liberalisation must prompt us to come together because if we give in to these pressures or hold an inaudible message, Europe will definitely have no credibility and will no longer represent this screed which she is already struggling to defend today.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written. - I voted for the Motion for a Resolution on EU-Turkey Relations, since it is a delicate relationship with a country that is a partner of the EU on the one hand, in terms of reducing the pressure of the migrant crisis, participation in NATO and economic cooperation, and a country that has been located for many years in the process of negotiations for EU accession. Unacceptable on the other hand is the democratic deficit and the growing repression against opponents of power that intensified after the failed coup.
