It is necessary to find a solution to develop partnership relations and create conditions for political and security stability in the environment, but serious reservations should be set in one part of the relationship, particularly with regard to further accession negotiations and visa liberalisation until they are reached for the EU acceptable democratic criteria.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. — Negotiations are currently frozen, but it is not yet a formal suspension to put an end to pre-accession aid payments. However, it is the first time since 2005 that the European Parliament has called for a real sanction against Turkey, further away from the catastrophic prospect of accession. I voted in favour.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of my colleague Renate Sommer's report on the EU-Turkey resolution. Since the coup attempt last July in Turkey, arrests and purges of pro-Kurdish journalists and MEPs have risen alarming, asking serious questions about the future of relations between the European Union and Turkey. Against this background, and in keeping with my constant position on the subject, I voted in favour of freeze accession negotiations with Turkey, which is — more than ever — not intended to enter the European Union. Although Turkey must be an important partner of Europe, Turkey has embarked on a path incompatible with European values, so it was time to send a strong signal to President Erdogan calling for an end to accession negotiations. Turkish authoritarian drifts must definitively put an end to the hypocrisy of the Member States, which irresponsibly suggest to Turkey the prospect of accession, knowing full well that this accession is not unanimous and therefore cannot take place. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: I voted in favour of this resolution because it calls for the immediate freeze of Turkey's accession negotiations. If this country is a strategic partner of the EU, it should in no way become a member of it. We must put an end to this false hypocritical suspense. This is a first step, and it is now up to the States to put a definitive end to any prospect of Turkey's accession.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: in writing. — I abstained from this resolution. This resolution addresses Erdoğan's disproportionate and repressive measures following Erdoğan's attempted military coup in July 2016, and Erdoğan must condemn the measures taken by Erdoğan in the strongest possible terms. A simple, temporary suspension of accession negotiations is not enough here.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: in writing. — At the plenary session of the European Parliament in Strasbourg, I voted against the resolution on relations between the European Union and Turkey, as the main message or call for this resolution is the freezing of Turkey's accession negotiations to the European Union. I consider such a decision to be short-sighted given Turkey's importance in stopping the flow of uncontrolled migrants. While there are still human rights abuses in Turkey, I believe the move was not strategically correct anyway. The European Union and Turkey have an agreement that Turkey will help stop and control illegal refugee flows, but the European Union will speed up Turkey's accession negotiations, so I believe that this resolution does not give the right signal and incentive for the Turkish side to comply with this agreement.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: in writing. - This motion for a resolution rightly points to the very problematic situation in Turkey regarding respect for fundamental rights, the persecution of journalists and the repression of the political opposition. Dealing with minorities such as the Kurds, the debate on the possible reintroduction of the death penalty in Turkey and Turkey's dubious role in northern Syria are also reasons for deep concern. Accordingly, I voted to freeze the EU accession negotiations with Turkey, that is to say this resolution. In addition, I believe that the EU accession negotiations with Turkey should be terminated immediately. Instead, a new basis for sound relations between EU Member States and Turkey, in the spirit of a strategic partnership, is needed. However, this position, which is currently not capable of majority in the European Parliament, must continue to be promoted.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The European Parliament's resolution on EU-Turkey relations is above all a wake-up call to the European Union and Turkey leaders that we cannot turn a blind eye to the fact that in Turkey after the attempt coup d'état tens of thousands of people are locked up, another hundreds of thousands of people have been thrown out of work. And all this without the courts ruling that they committed anything wrong. It is up to Turkey to prove that it wants to respect European values, which are a necessary condition for joining the European Union. While Turkey is an important partner for the EU, the political will for cooperation must come from both sides of the partnership, and I believe that Turkey does not show this political will, since government action is increasingly moving him away from his European path. I voted in favour of the proposal as it calls on the Commission and the Member States to give an incentive to temporarily suspend the ongoing negotiations on Turkey's accession to the EU.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Turkey is an important strategic partner of the European Union. As a candidate country, it has made a commitment to the highest enforcement of democracy, human rights, the rule of law and fundamental freedoms. Point five of the negotiating framework provides that in the event of serious and persistent infringements of the principles on which the European Union is founded in Turkey, the Commission shall, on its own initiative or at the request of one third of the Member States, recommend the suspension of negotiations and propose the conditions for the possible resumption of negotiations. Furthermore, Parliament expresses its grave concern about the living conditions of the arrested persons and the restrictions on freedom of expression, the press and the media. With all this in mind, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: in writing. - I support the European Parliament resolution on EU-Turkey relations. I support the work on visa liberalisation being undertaken once Turkey has adequately met all the conditions set out in the visa liberalisation timetable. I am of serious concern about the conditions in which detainees and persons arrested have been held since the coup, with allegations of torture and ill-treatment, the large-scale dismissals of civil servants who are still awaiting a fair trial, and the extremely strict restrictions imposed on freedom of expression and in respect of the press and media in Turkey.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution. Of course, it is only asking for a freeze on negotiations with Turkey. It is not yet a formal suspension that would stop IPA payments (pre-accession aid), but it is the first time since 2005 that the European Parliament has asked for a real sanction against Turkey.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: In writing. — From day to day, the signals are multiplying and prove Turkey's growing distance from the values advocated by the European Union: alarming dismissals among civil servants, magistrates and the military, arrests of politicians and journalists, possible reintroduction of the death penalty... The latest provocation is the introduction of a bill that proposes to abolish the conviction for sexual assault on minor if the author marries the victim — bill finally sent back to committee but still not withdrawn! I therefore supported this resolution in which we call for the immediate freeze of accession negotiations between the European Union and Turkey. For many years, this country has been engaged in a process of discussion and negotiations with a view to possible accession to the European Union, but in view of such violations of human rights, the rule of law and freedom of expression, we cannot continue to act as if nothing happened. We also strongly oppose any liberalisation of entry visas for Turkish nationals on the territory of the Union. Turkey is certainly a strategic and essential partner, but we cannot remain silent in the face of these anti-democratic actions.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the resolution on relations between the European Union and Turkey, because it calls for the freezing of negotiations on Turkey's accession to the European Union. Since the start of these negotiations in 2005, this is the first time that Parliament has called for sanctions against this country, which does not meet the criteria for accession to the Union. The National Front supports the definitive halt of negotiations on Turkey's accession. Not only is Turkey not a European country, but fundamental rights are constantly and systematically violated. Arrests of MPs, magistrates and journalists are unacceptable, as are media and social media censorship. Turkey must also stop the persecution of religious and other minorities. Between 2005 and 2016, the European Union contributed nearly 10 billion to Turkey under the Instrument for Pre-Accession Assistance (IPA). It is inadmissible to continue to pay for Turkey. Neither by its history, nor by its culture, nor by its geography, let alone since the authoritarian and Islamist grip of Erdoğan, Turkey cannot claim to become European.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution which, while it still does not call for a formal suspension of negotiations, which would stop the payment of pre-accession aid, is the first since 2005 to ask for a sanction against Turkey.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that we are facing a turning point in relations between the Union and Turkey. The last plenary session dealt with the situation of journalists in Turkey and the lack of press freedom, as well as the arrests and imprisonment of journalists. Erdogan's response has been to close one of the few independent newspapers and the arrest of more journalists. Add to that the arrest of the HDP party leader Demirtas, the country's third party, as well as other deputies. The government has embarked on the path of regression rather than progress. In turn, it marks a red line, if Turkey reintroduces the death penalty, it will result in the final suspension of the accession negotiations.

In turn, it marks a red line, if Turkey reintroduces the death penalty, it will result in the final suspension of the accession negotiations.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: in writing. - This motion for a resolution rightly points to the very problematic situation in Turkey regarding respect for fundamental rights, the persecution of journalists and the repression of the political opposition. Dealing with minorities such as the Kurds, the debate on the possible reintroduction of the death penalty in Turkey and Turkey's dubious role in northern Syria are also reasons for deep concern. Accordingly, I voted to freeze the EU accession negotiations with Turkey, that is to say this resolution. In addition, I believe that the EU accession negotiations with Turkey should be terminated immediately. Instead, a new basis for sound relations between EU Member States and Turkey, in the spirit of a strategic partnership, is needed. However, this position, which is currently not capable of majority in the European Parliament, must continue to be promoted.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: written. - Given the current situation, Turkey remains an important partner of the EU and the political will to cooperate must exist with both sides in partnership. For this reason, I did not support this resolution because I believe it is not in the interests of neither the EU nor Croatia to suspend negotiations with Turkey at this time.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Since the attempted coup the Turkish authorities have arrested ten members of the Turkish Grand National Assembly belonging to the opposition party HDP and some 150 journalists; 2 386 judges and prosecutors and 40 000 other people have been detained, of whom more than 31 000 remain under arrest; 129 000 public employees either remain suspended (66 000) or have been dismissed (63 000), according to the Commission’s Turkey 2016 report. But we are very polite and careful. Why? Because Erdoğan can open the doors and allow millions of migrants to go to the EU, but the EU still cannot adopt a common position about migration policy.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing - Every country interested in joining the EU has clearly and clearly defined conditions. Failure to comply is a fundamental obstacle to membership in the EU. The EU needs to have reliable partners on its borders who adhere to democratic principles, where women and men have equal rights, where the judiciary is functioning, where the economy operates, where they effectively fight corruption. It is the responsibility of Turkey's leaders as to how they will approach and fulfil these conditions.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing. - I am voting in favour of the joint motion for a resolution as it requires the temporary suspension of the ongoing accession negotiations with Turkey, as well as for the reasons I explained in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 22 November 2016.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: in writing. — I am abstaining from voting on this resolution because, on the one hand, the call for an end to the accession negotiations and, on the other hand, the end of pre-accession aid were rejected by Parliament and is aimed only at a temporary suspension of accession negotiations.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the resolution. The European Union and the European Parliament strongly condemn the failed military coup in Turkey, but the repressive measures taken by the Turkish government following the state of emergency are disproportionate and violate fundamental rights and freedoms protected by the Turkish Constitution and democratic values.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. - The human rights situation in Turkey has been worsening for several years and especially since 2009, even more so since the parliamentary elections. Following the alleged coup attempt in July 2016, thousands of people were arrested. The State closed 112 media outlets, including 45 newspapers, 26 television channels, 23 radio stations, 3 news agencies, 15 magazines and 29 publishing houses. More than 620 press cards were cancelled, and at least 200 journalists arrested. The resolution strongly condemns the repressive measures implemented in Turkey. It also recalls that the reinstatement of the death penalty would result in the suspension of the accession process. I am voting in favour of this resolution.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: in writing. — This is a freeze on negotiations on Turkey's accession to the European Union. It is not yet a formal suspension that would allow the IPA payments to be stopped, but it is the first time since 2005 that the European Parliament has called for a real sanction against Turkey. So I voted in favour. As a reminder, we are in favour of a definitive halt of negotiations on Turkey's accession.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. - Turkey's possible accession to the European Union continues to give rise to the greatest reservations. The persistent occupation of part of Cyprus, the refusal to open ports and airports in that area, the violation of the rights of political, religious and ethnic minorities, the negative discrimination against women, the decision to exclude parties and the annulment of legislation limiting the jurisdiction of the Military Courts are some demonstrative examples of this. In addition, fundamental issues are: most of Turkey is not geographically Europe; Turkey has an Islamic identity quite different from the Judeo-Christian identity of most EU countries; transit of people from what would become the most populous EU country would ensure strong market imbalances Labor. All this does not prevent the recognition of Turkey's efforts in recent years to meet certain EU requirements criteria, and it even points out the invaluable role of this country within NATO. The important question will be to consider whether it would not be preferable to grant Turkey the status of a privileged and preferential partner of the EU, much more than creating false expectations and hopes for membership, which facts and circumstances will hardly allow.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion because the political situation in Turkey is becoming more tenuous with every passing day. There have been disproportionate measures taken by the Turkish Government in reaction to a coup attempt earlier on this year.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The situation of journalists, media freedom and human rights abuses has been constantly deteriorating in Turkey. Already before the coup d’état attempt of 15 July, there were numerous journalists and political activists imprisoned. Turkey is, and will remain, one of our most important partners for the EU. However, the resolution sends a clear message that we want Turkey to be anchored to Europe and to democracy, but if nothing happens to restore the rule of law and human rights, than the EU should continue its dialogue with Turkey while temporary freezing the accession talks. I support this approach and therefore I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. — All eight political groups have tabled motions for a resolution on this subject. Six of them, the Verts/ALE, ALDE, GUE/NGL, ECR, PPE and S&D groups, reached agreement and developed a joint compromise motion, which I voted in favour

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: in writing. — The resolution proposed a freeze on negotiations for Turkey's accession to the European Union. We are totally opposed to this idea, but this formal suspension is insufficient. In particular, it does not allow the so-called “IPA” (pre-accession aid) payments to be stopped. We want a complete halt to the negotiations. Abstention.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this text proposing the freeze of Turkey's accession to the European Union. For my part, I have always considered that this country has no place in the European Union, whether it be geographically, historically or culturally.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Despite the fact that the European Parliament sees Turkey as a very important partner, we cannot leave what has happened in recent months unspoken. I supported the motion for a resolution proposing a temporary suspension of accession negotiations. The measures introduced as a result of a state of emergency are simply disproportionate and violate fundamental human rights. We are also hearing more and more about the possibility of reinstating the death penalty, which would lead to a permanent suspension of negotiations. I am very confident that order will soon be restored in Turkey, and then we will be able to talk again about possible EU accession. In the meantime, however, we are sending a clear signal to Turkey that compliance with European values is the only way for a country to become a part of the European Union.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this motion for a resolution regarding EU-Turkey relations that condemns the military coup in Turkey and recognises the legitimacy of the Turkish authorities to prosecute the persons responsible and involved in this attempt. The resolution also condemns the disproportionate repressive measures undertaken by Turkey and stresses that the political will to cooperate should come from both sides in order for progress to be achieved.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I have decided to abstain from voting on this report, as I have always supported diplomacy as a solution to any disagreement and I believe that aggressiveness is to be avoided in the field of external relations. Turkey is an essential partner of the European Union in energy, military, commercial, cultural security, etc. However, a statement of interruption of the accession negotiations, coming in a political and security context in which these negotiations are not topical for either party, I consider it a subject which does not belong, and I therefore prefer to abstain.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: in writing. — I abstained because I do not believe that calling for a temporary suspension of the ongoing negotiations on accession of Turkey would be the right answer to the current situation in Turkey. There is no doubt that the measures against civil service employees and media applied since the failed attempted military coup are unduly punitive and that Turkey is moving away from the state of affairs today, which corresponds to the values on which the Union stands. However, I consider that this must be emphasized to Turkey in the ongoing dialogue at a wide variety of levels, but not to allow Turkey's leadership today to turn that criticism against the Union itself. Unacceptable repression is, of course, an obstacle to making any progress in accession negotiations, but suspending them would allow Erdogan to pull out a new and strong anti-European card and still reduce the hopes of a large part of the society there for a better and free functioning of this country.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported. Turkey is an important partner for the EU, but in the current situation where the coup attempt in Turkey has been followed by repressive measures against the media, journalists and MPs, accession talks with Turkey must be halted. Financing assistance and visa abolition policies between the EU and Turkey can only be developed if Turkey is ready to adhere to the principles of democracy and fundamental freedoms.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: in writing. - Four months after the failed coup attempt in Turkey, the deteriorating state of democracy in the country is causing crunches in EU-Turkey relations. Accession negotiations with Turkey began in October 2005. Of the 35 chapters that need to be completed in order to proceed with the accession process, only 16 have been opened and only one of them has been closed, the one for science and research. Accession talks with Turkey must be temporarily frozen. At the initiative of the Socialist and Democrat Group, where I am a part, the European Parliament emphasises in this resolution that there is no alternative as long as the Turkish authorities continue to neglect and undermine democracy and the rule of law. Dialogue with Ankara should be maintained, but Erdogan must understand that in Turkey, as a candidate country, the rule of law, democracy, freedom of the press and minority rights must be intact pillars. The EU must send out a strong political message by freezing accession talks until the Turkish Government returns to the path of respect for the rule of law and human rights.

name: Gilles Pargneaux (S&D)
text: I voted in favour of this resolution calling for a temporary freeze on Turkey's accession negotiations to the European Union. The disproportionate repressive measures adopted by Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan since the failure of the coup have led to a decline in the rule of law and democracy. While we are to continue the dialogue with Turkey, with the horizon of the restoration of the rule of law and respect for human rights, it is not credible at this time to continue these negotiations. We hope that the Council, which will meet in December, will hear our message.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ I would vote in favour of this proposal because I believe that the Turkish Government has taken repressive measures that violate fundamental human rights protected by the Turkish Constitution and values Democrats on which the European Union and ICCPR is founded and hold in a worrying situation those who were arrested during the coup d'état. But I am sure that despite the Turkish government having been guilty of serious conduct, the European Union should consider increasing support for Turkish civil society and offer the authorities Turkish additional legal assistance. Therefore I would vote upvote.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: written. - The latest progress report showed Turkey's serious regression in the field of rule of law and fundamental rights, especially if it takes into account both the functioning of the judiciary and freedom of expression. Turkey, if it wants to become a member of the European Union one day, must respect the highest standards in human rights protection and cherish key European values. I undoubtedly express my support for the already known position of the European Union, which condemned the coup attempt by characterizing it a direct attack on democracy in Turkey. However, the actions taken by the Turkish leadership regarding the persecution of journalists, Kurds, military officials and their families are inadmissible in terms of understanding and respecting the fundamental democratic postulates and availability and fairness of the judicial process. The defense of democracy must not and cannot be done by undemocratic methods. It is necessary that the European Union continues to support the reform process in Turkey, and through joint work and cooperation it should monitor all processes and changes and insist on consistent, sincere and full compliance with all the requirements that the European Union puts before Turkey with the aim of ensuring that it the state respects the legacy that has been created for decades.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ The repressive measures implemented by the Turkish Government in the context of the state of emergency, declared as a result of the failed coup d'état, are disproportionate and violate fundamental rights and freedoms protected by the Turkish Constitution and the democratic values on which the European Union is founded. The arrest of opposition MPs, journalists, judges and prosecutors, are just some of the most serious examples of such violations. Similarly, Erdogan's statements on the reintroduction of the death penalty and the strong restrictions placed on Turkish freedom of expression, press and media, put Turkey in a position objectively incompatible with a forthcoming accession to the Union. For these reasons, I agree with the report's request for the Commission to suspend negotiations on Turkey's accession to the EU, providing as a condition for their resumption full compliance with the principles of freedom, democracy, the rule of law, human rights and fundamental freedoms on which the Union is founded. I remain convinced that Turkey is an important partner for Europe and that its future lies in joining the common European house. The policy put in place by Erdogan in recent months, unfortunately, goes in a completely different direction, though.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: written. — The European Parliament strongly condemned the attempted coup in Turkey and acknowledged the legitimate responsibility of the Turkish authorities to sanction those involved in the coup. However, the repressive measures taken during the declared state of emergency are an overreaction by Ankara and are a violation of the basic rights and freedoms guaranteed by the Constitution of the State. They do not fit a country that is considered a candidate for membership of our Union. I am particularly concerned by the statements of the head of state about the reintroduction of the death penalty, and I am also concerned about the conditions in which they are detained. Rumors of torture and other serious forms of human rights violations cannot be ignored, as it is not possible not to notice the serious violation of freedom of expression in Turkey. The decisions taken by Turkey will have to reflect on the overall status of its negotiations with the EU and progress in the negotiations will not be possible until Turkey abolished the state of emergency. There can be no talk about visa liberalisation until Turkey really begins to fulfil the previously agreed conditions. I call on the authorities of Turkey to renew their duty to respect the rule of law and human rights and successfully return to deep and mutually beneficial relations with the EU. To a democratic and stable Turkey, the EU is wide open, our strategic partnership is the key to a more peaceful and prosperous region.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The resolution deliberately takes a more moderate tone than so many other resolutions voted on in the EP. The EU's geostrategic and political interests, such as Turkey's involvement in the Syrian conflict, its role as a member of NATO and the economic interests in that country overlap with this restraint, while maintaining the stance of interference and interference. Clearly absence in the text is the reference to the criminal EU-Turkey agreement on the humanitarian refugee crisis, which the EU wants to maintain at all costs. Of course, there is also no reference to resolving the illegal occupation of Cyprus. It refers to the temporary freezing of the accession process, coupled with a series of criticisms of arrests, persecution and repression after the coup. We are attentive and concerned about the situation in Turkey, particularly with regard to the brutal oppression and repression of the working classes and parties, class organisations and other progressive forces fighting on the ground for freedom and democracy. A repression and authoritarianism of the Turkish government's policies that did not begin in the coup d'état, as the European leaders and this parliament now seem to have discovered, trying to wash their faces of the complicity they have always had with the forces in power.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution, which aims to temporarily freeze negotiations with Turkey. I strongly condemn the actions and attitude of President Erdoğan's administration, which regularly violates fundamental rights and freedoms by totally disproportionately repressing opponents of the regime, and threatens to re-resort to the death penalty. I would like to reiterate my total opposition to Turkey, which remains a key partner of the Union, entering our community of destiny.

name: Laurenţiu Rebega (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted for the resolution on EU-Turkey relations. This resolution must be a strong signal to the European Union, the Commission and the Council, in order to adopt immediately a firm attitude that will lead Turkey to return to respect the rule of law. At the same time, taking into account the close bilateral relations between Romania and Turkey, I supported the introduction in the text of the resolution of the point whereby EU Member States can define their own relationship with Turkey for the future. At the moment, there is no longer a functioning democracy in Turkey, and the European Union must not legitimize this situation through concessions to the regime. Democratic values and freedom of expression are mandatory prerequisites for EU membership.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this non-legislative and non-binding report. We support the elements of the report criticising the crackdown by Erdoğan’s government following the attempted coup under state of emergency laws. The report however does not go far enough. It only calls for a temporary freeze of accession negotiations. We want a permanent end to talks on Turkey joining the EU and an end to all pre-accession payments.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. - The European Parliament today adopted a strong resolution on the EU-Turkey relations process, urging the Council and the European Commission to temporarily freeze accession negotiations with Turkey. At least as long as the Turkish authorities continue to neglect and undermine democracy and the rule of law. The European Parliament has also warned the Turkish authorities that the reintroduction of the death penalty is incompatible with the continuation of the accession process. This resolution is a clear political message to Erdoğan which must not be misunderstood: we want to strengthen Turkey's link with Europe, democracy and the rule of law, but we will never give up our values. We hope that the rule of law and human rights will be restored as soon as possible. Until then, the dialogue continues, but the accession talks must be frozen.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that we are facing a turning point in relations between the Union and Turkey. The last plenary session dealt with the situation of journalists in Turkey and the lack of press freedom, as well as the arrests and imprisonment of journalists. Erdogan's response has been to close one of the few independent newspapers and the arrest of more journalists. Add to that the arrest of the HDP party leader Demirtas, the country's third party, as well as other deputies. There is no point in continuing to negotiate Turkey's accession to the Union on Chapters 23 and 24 on justice, freedoms and fundamental rights at the same time as the post-coup state of emergency allows for derogation of rights and purging. The government has embarked on the path of regression rather than progress. In turn, it marks a red line, if Turkey reintroduces the death penalty, it will result in the final suspension of the accession negotiations.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. — One cannot stand with your arms whilst the Turkish government violates the most basic rights. Not only do I support the freeze on accession negotiations, as my vote today indicates, but, more broadly, I am convinced that the time is more for the internal strengthening of the European Union than for enlargement plans. The European Union must, of course, establish a privileged relationship with Turkey, but on condition that its leaders respect democratic values, which is clearly not the case.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. - It is very unfortunate to see the recent deterioration of EU-Turkey relations. The main reason for this is not on the EU side. Increasingly growing autocratic President T. Erdogan's style of governance is difficult to match with the values promoted by the EU and Turkey's ambition to become a member of the EU. Suspension of membership negotiations therefore seems to be a forced but necessary measure. At the same time, in the report, I miss the measures and proposals on what the EU can do to ensure that relations with Turkey do not deteriorate.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. - I was in favour of the adoption of this motion for a resolution which voted to freeze negotiations with Turkey with a view to its accession to the European Union (EU). It is true that Turkey is a friendly country and an important strategic partner of the EU, but the recent events of unequal repression adopted by the Turkish government under the state of emergency cannot leave us indifferent, given their seriousness, disproportion and even violation of constitutional rights and the democratic values on which the EU is rooted and governed. To that extent, I condemn all the repressive measures taken by the Erdogan government which have been carried out since the attempted military coup in July. Such actions suggest that there is also no equal political will on the side of the current Government of Turkey and committed to maintaining a privileged relationship with the EU, following the government on a different path. In any case, the current situation must not fail to safeguard the important support for Turkish citizens and civil society and does not, of course, prevent a surpassing change in circumstances from creating the necessary conditions for the resumption of negotiations.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution agreeing to temporarily suspend Turkey's accession agreements to the Union, at least until the state of emergency is lifted. The resolution clearly condemns the disproportionate repression of the Erdogan government and specifically the repression of HDP. It leaves the door open, however, for negotiations to be resumed later.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — In this case, a resolution on relations between the Union and Turkey was voted on, which talks about revising the European Instrument for Pre-Accession and calling on the Commission and the Member States to temporarily freeze Turkey's pre-accession negotiations. Moreover, the resolution begins with a “strong condemnation of Turkey's disproportionate repressive measures since the failed military coup attempt”, which I consider very positive. While the document also contains some elements that I do not agree with, such as the call for increased contribution through the European Instrument for the Promotion of Democracy and Human Rights, it also has very positive points, such as the reference to the arrests of members of the Kurdish HDP party. That is why my final vote was in favour of this resolution.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this as the report does not go far enough into saying that Turkey should never join the EU.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. – Today I voted in favour of the resolution on Turkey which calls on the EU to freeze accession talks with Turkey in response to Ankara’s recent crackdown on political opposition and freedom of press, until the Turkish Government returns to the path of respect for the rule of law and human rights. The EU needs to send a strong signal to the Turkish Government that what is going on there is not acceptable. This is necessary for the EU to retain a credible foreign policy.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: written. - I voted positively for this report, but this rationale of voting is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEPs solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the real quality and the amount of work, efficiency and most of all the success of the advocacy.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing - Turkey is an important partner of the EU and is expected as a candidate country to promote the highest standards of democracy, including respect for human rights, the rule of law, fundamental freedoms and the universal right to a fair trial. The European Union and the European Parliament strongly condemned the failed military coup in Turkey and recognised the legitimate responsibility of the Turkish authorities for the prosecution of those responsible for and involved in it. However, the Turkish Government's repressive measures during the state of emergency are disproportionate, contrary to the fundamental rights and freedoms protected by the Turkish Constitution, the democratic values on which the European Union is founded and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. For this reason, with the resolution, we called on the Commission and the Member States to initiate a temporary freeze on the ongoing accession negotiations with Turkey. Reintroducing the death penalty by the Turkish government would lead to a formal halt to the accession process. Even if Turkey is an important EU partner, the political will for cooperation must be on both sides of the partnership. The government's current measures are moving Turkey away from its European direction.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ It is sad to witness how Mr Erdoğan’s attempts to handicap the democratic process in Turkey continue to intensify and there are ever fewer pillars of democracy left unscathed. He started with freedom of speech a while ago, with mass imprisonment of journalists and his latest destruction is that of non-discrimination and human rights by labelling the opposition HDP party leaders as terrorists and lodging a criminal complaint against the CHP party. Particularly since the 2016 coup attempt, prospects for restoration of democratic structures in Turkey seem to be gravely dim; Erdoğan intends on using all the tools of power at his disposal to wipe out the system of checks and balances. Despite all the progress that was once made by Turkey which could be largely attributed to the positive effects of the enlargement process, at the moment, it is difficult to see how it is possible to continue enlargement negotiations with such an autocratically-ruled country.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: in writing. — I supported the European Parliament resolution on EU-Turkey relations, which I co-signed. Turkey is dealing with a number of problems, yet for us it remains a key partner in many ways. But President Erdogan's policy development is very upsetting. As an example, the EU - Turkey parliamentary delegation has not met for a year and a half, due to the reluctance of the Turkish side. In doing so, both parliaments, European and Turkish, discuss fundamental issues for both sides and should have a joint debate on them. I agree that the appropriate response to current developments is to temporarily freeze negotiations on Turkey's accession to the EU and suspend payments from pre-accession aid. We need time to tell ourselves what the form of future cooperation is supposed to be. I am not a supporter of Turkey's full membership of the EU, but I believe that a privileged partnership or associate membership may be the appropriate form. Today we have made it clear to Turkey that the developments that are taking place are moving Turkey away from the EU. Although we recommend that we suspend the entry negotiations, we are certainly not calling for an end to the dialogue. It is up to Turkey whether to choose a path of definitive diversion from the values on which the European Union stands and towards which it has been until recently.

name: Bart Staes (Verts/ALE)
text: — (NL) A majority of MEPs rightly believe that the negotiating process for Turkey's possible accession to the European Union should be frozen. The Green Group would also like to reverse visa liberalisation, Erdogan's hobbyhorse. By continuing dialogue with Turkey, we can try to prevent an ultimate alienation from each other, but we must not close our eyes to what is happening in Turkey today. I think it is important that the rule of law be respected and that the coup armies in Turkey are persecuted. But the violations of human rights, the suppression of the opposition and the criminalisation of journalistic activities do not have much to do with the rule of law anymore. Resisting President Erdogan seems to be a reason in itself to end up in prison, prosecuted or dismissed. Against this, Europe must speak clear language. This is no longer possible and legitimises the freezing of negotiations on possible accession. This message is also intended for Erdogan: in the event of a possible reintroduction of the death penalty, negotiations will be suspended.

name: Сергей Станишев (S&D)
text: in writing. With this resolution, the EP gives a clear political signal that we are not compromising on our values and principles, that we cannot trade freedom of speech, the rule of law and citizens' rights, that we do not turn a blind eye to what is happening in the country after the failed coup attempt. The EU should temporarily freeze Turkey's membership talks and carefully assess how pre-accession assistance is used. At the same time, the resolution proves that the EU stands firmly behind the Turkish people and their right to free, democratic development. I believe that Turkey belongs to the large family of democratic European countries. We are ready to reconsider our position as soon as we are convinced that the repressive, disproportionate measures put in place with the state of emergency have been lifted. It is unacceptable for thousands of people, including legitimately elected opposition leaders and lawmakers, to be imprisoned without any legitimate charges and due process. All these actions, the attacks on Europe as a whole, revisionism, the return of the death penalty, etc. must be seen in the context of seeking to secure the support of extreme nationalists for a strong presidential republic. In all the meetings I held in Turkey recently, the appeal of all the pro-European powers was united: do not leave us to arbitrary.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: in writing. - This motion for a resolution rightly points to the very problematic situation in Turkey regarding respect for fundamental rights, the persecution of journalists and the repression of the political opposition. Dealing with minorities such as the Kurds, the debate on the possible reintroduction of the death penalty in Turkey and Turkey's dubious role in northern Syria are also reasons for deep concern. Accordingly, I voted to freeze the EU accession negotiations with Turkey, that is to say this resolution. In addition, I believe that the EU accession negotiations with Turkey should be terminated immediately. Instead, a new basis for sound relations between EU Member States and Turkey, in the spirit of a strategic partnership, is needed. However, this position, which is currently not capable of majority in the European Parliament, must continue to be promoted.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: in writing. - Decades of dishonesty in dealing with Turkey today explains the EU's disorientation in the face of the massive human rights violations by Merkel friend Erdoğan. Although the Strasbourg Assembly loudly complains about Turkey's domestic development, it refuses to cancel accession negotiations. CSU man Manfred Weber openly calls for the continuation of accession negotiations with Turkey, in unison with the Greens. The CSU vice vice just wants to suspend the negotiations for a while in order to be able to continue them later. I say quite clearly: if you expose, you are already thinking about moving on. That is why accession negotiations must be terminated. The discontinuation of negotiations with Turkey can be transmitted by the EU institutions through a simple “verbal note”. Turkey's accession has been under negotiation since 1963 and Turkey officially became a candidate country in 2005. As a result, it has so far received more than €10 billion from the EU budget as accession aid. While the Bosporus despot continues to be Merkel, Schulz and Juncker's best friend, Turkish soldiers are requesting political asylum in Germany. Stop Turkey's accession! That is why, together with colleagues on behalf of our Group, the Europe of Freedom and Direct Democracy (EFDD), I tabled a motion for a resolution. In it, we call on the Council to close the accession negotiations with Turkey with immediate effect.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: written. — President Erdogan and the Turkish government are moving away from the rule of law and using aggressive communication towards the EU and will propose to freeze negotiations and pre-accession assistance to Turkey, which will be a clear signal that we do not tolerate the current situation in that country. For the last ten years, the EU has supported Turkey's European path and its transition to modern democracy and market economy. Turkey has been seen as a bright example of democracy in the Islamic State, opposite Arab states gripped by unrest and military conflict. The authoritarian regime that began to be introduced in 2013 by the then prime minister, and now President Erdogan, has moved Turkey away from the EU, and especially after the coup of July this year and repressive measures in place then. I do not support this Resolution because I believe that Turkey must change its political direction and return to the path of democracy so that it can move again to Europe. The EU will continue to maintain good relations with people from Turkey living within Europe.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: in writing. Turkey has no place in the European Union for the simple reason that it does not belong to Europe at all levels, such as culture, manners, customs and history.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: in writing. — In order not to contradict myself because of my duty as Vice-President, in cases where the group votes differently than the Hungarian Members during roll button voting, I will not participate directly in the vote. In other words, I will not press the voting button, but I will hand up to the EPP group the voting position that was previously decided jointly. That's what I've done in this case.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: in writing. − I supported the resolution because I see that the European Parliament should point out that the undemocratic policy and recent civil and human violations of the Turkish Government — under the pretext of the showdown of the attempted coup go beyond all international legal standards and, in particular, the values and rights of the EU. I acknowledge that Turkey is a particularly important partner and candidate for membership of the EU, which has a key role to play in tackling the international migration crisis and in the fight against terrorism, but this should not be a reason for the Erdogan regime to be subject to political blackmail with the EU and its Member States affair. Mass unlawful retaliation affecting tens of thousands, the persecution of representatives of the press and many other professions, and the reign of political willingness cannot remain without consequences in the accession process. I believe that the Copenhagen criteria apply equally to all EU members and candidates, and I therefore agree, in this situation, that accession negotiations should be temporarily suspended on the part of the EU until certain conditions are met.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ An attempted coup that took place in Turkey on 15 July 2016 resulted in the deaths of hundreds of people. More than 2,000 people were injured. Days later, Turkish authorities established a state of emergency that now gives power almost unlimited control over society. In its earlier resolution, the European Parliament strongly condemned the coup in Turkey, but also stressed the importance of protecting democracy. This, by contrast, in our friendly state seems to be broken. For these reasons, the European Parliament should send an unequivocal message that accession negotiations with Turkey should be frozen and cannot continue in the current situation. A state that does not follow the principles of democracy and the rule of law, considers the use of capital punishment, persecute hundreds of thousands of citizens, restricts freedom of speech, the activities of unhinged orchards and independent media cannot become part of the European community. Both sides should engage in dialogue for a peaceful and democratic solution to the tense situation in Turkey. For it should be remembered that freezing the negotiating process will have adverse effects on both sides.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. - The situation in Turkey has become very complex following the failed military coup attempt at the end of July this year. The measures taken by the Turkish Government to punish those involved lie beyond the limit of respect for the fundamental rights underlying the values of the European Union. At the same time, Turkey is an important EU partner in the Middle East region, particularly in the context of responding to the refugee crisis and the fight against terrorism caused by civil conflicts in Syria and Iraq. Given that Turkey is a candidate for membership of the European Union, the Member States and the European institutions must look very carefully at the measures taken by the Ankara regime. Disproportionate measures taken by the authorities are not such as to normalise the situation at country level and can decisively degrade the quality of democracy in Turkey. We must give priority to the fundamental rights of Turkish citizens, regardless of political guidelines or ethnic origin, and support civil society in this country to help strengthen democracy. However, we cannot accept the democratic slippages of the Ankara regime, if we are considering Turkey's possible accession to the EU. I support the adoption of this extremely important resolution.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. — With this text of which I am a co-signatory, we strongly condemn the disproportionate repressive measures applied in Turkey since the failed military coup attempt in July 2016 and reaffirm our commitment to maintaining Turkey's anchorage to the European Union. However, we call on the Commission and the Member States to initiate a temporary freeze on the ongoing accession negotiations with Turkey.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Recent developments in Turkey since the failed coup of July 2016 have pointed to the worsening human rights situation in the country, including the muzzling of free press and the detention of thousands of Turkish journalists and political opponents. As a result, the motion for a resolution on EU-Turkey relations calls for a temporary freeze of the ongoing accession negotiations with Turkey. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution, because I believe that the EU has a responsibility to honour its commitments to protecting human rights and freedom of expression, and it needs to do more to pressure Turkey to reconsider its aggressive measures against its political opposition.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ The situation in Turkey is quite complex and worrying. Since the coup attempt a few months ago we have been seeing a dangerous advance towards an increasingly authoritarian form of state and democracy appears in danger. This is an unacceptable thing for a country that has ambitions to become part of the EU. In Turkey, more than 140,000 people have been arrested, in recent months alone, and 11 MPs from the Kurdish HDP party have been jailed. A democratic Turkey that puts respect for human rights at the top of its action would be a key ally for the European Union in a complicated scenario like the Middle East. Unfortunately we are a long way from achieving this. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution which states that there are all the conditions for a temporary freeze on talks on Turkey's accession to the European Union.

name: László Tőkés (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Turkey is an important strategic partner of the European Union. As a candidate country, it has made a commitment to the highest enforcement of democracy, human rights, the rule of law and fundamental freedoms. Point five of the negotiating framework provides that in the event of serious and persistent infringements of the principles on which the European Union is founded in Turkey, the Commission shall, on its own initiative or at the request of one third of the Member States, recommend the suspension of negotiations and propose the conditions for the possible resumption of negotiations. The political will for cooperation in the Turkey—EU partnership must be on the part of both sides. However, Turkey does not demonstrate this political will, the report emphasises. Since the July coup attempt, the government's actions have increasingly diverted Turkey from the road towards Europe. In the report, the European Parliament strongly condemns the attempted coup in Turkey and, no less, the subsequent disproportionate measures taken during the state of emergency, violating the fundamental rights and freedoms imposed by the Constitution. Furthermore, Parliament expresses its grave concern about the living conditions of the arrested persons and the restrictions on freedom of expression, the press and the media. With all this in mind, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Ivica Tolić (PPE)
text: written. - I do not support the European Parliament's proposal for a resolution on EU-Turkey relations. I respected the decision taken by the Croatian foreign minister and voted in accordance with it.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - I have supported the European Parliament's proposal for a resolution on EU-Turkey relations. The EU has rigorously condemned the military coup that took place in Turkey and stands behind the need to find the people responsible and to punish them appropriately. Yet not in as oppressive a way as Turkey does - a referendum on reimposing the death penalty. Europe must send a clear signal that a country that wants to reintroduce the death penalty cannot be part of the European Union. The signal must also be understandable in Turkish eyes. To seize a military coup to violate human rights is inadmissible. Thousands of civil servants have lost their jobs, media freedom is limited, some media houses/outlets are closed, some members of Turkey's parliament are jailed. Such developments are really worrying. Sovereignty must not be built on the basis of fear. We must take Turkey as a friend and partner. For the good of its citizens, Turkey needs to change the course of events. Any further negotiations on Turkey's accession to the European Union must be frozen.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution agreeing to temporarily suspend Turkey's accession agreements to the Union, at least until the state of emergency is lifted. The resolution clearly condemns the disproportionate repression of the Erdogan government and specifically the repression of HDP. It leaves the door open, however, for negotiations to be resumed later.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR)
text: in writing. - This motion for a resolution rightly points to the very problematic situation in Turkey regarding respect for fundamental rights, the persecution of journalists and the repression of the political opposition. Dealing with minorities such as the Kurds, the debate on the reintroduction of the death penalty in Turkey and Turkey's dubious role in northern Syria are also reasons for deep concern. Accordingly, I voted to freeze the EU accession negotiations with Turkey, that is to say this resolution. In addition, I believe that the EU accession negotiations with Turkey should be terminated immediately. Instead, a new basis for sound relations between EU Member States and Turkey, in the spirit of a strategic partnership, is needed. However, this position, which is currently not capable of majority in the European Parliament, must continue to be promoted.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because a suspension of membership talks is necessary. Turkey and the Erdogan Government are systematically breaching the rule of law and basic democratic principles. These behaviours are incompatible with EU values. Our citizens would not understand if we wouldn’t take such stance.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the resolution calling for the freeze of negotiations on Turkey's accession to the European Union. Since the start of these negotiations in 2005, this is the first time that Parliament has called for sanctions against this country, which does not meet the criteria for accession to the Union. The National Front supports the definitive halt of negotiations on Turkey's accession. Not only is Turkey not a European country, but fundamental rights are constantly and systematically violated. Arrests of MPs, magistrates and journalists are unacceptable, as are media and social media censorship. Turkey must also stop the persecution of religious minorities. Between 2005 and 2016, the European Union contributed nearly 10 billion to Turkey under the Instrument for Pre-Accession Assistance (IPA). It is inadmissible to continue to pay for Turkey. Neither by its history, nor by its culture, nor by its geography, let alone since the authoritarian and Islamist control of Erdoğan, Turkey cannot claim to become European.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Social and political chaos is deepening in Turkey following the alleged coup of July last year. The aim of the putsch was to overthrow President Erdogan, accused of an authoritarian style of governing and undermining fundamental rights and freedoms. The April 2016 European Parliament resolution on Turkey expressed deep concern over the regress in the area of democracy and the rule of law and the decline in the overall pace of reform in the country. Since then, the risk of freezing the accession negotiations with Turkey has been steadily growing by the Commission and the Member States. I abstained due to the lack of new threads in the relationship between both entities.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution agreeing to temporarily suspend Turkey's accession agreements to the Union, at least until the state of emergency is lifted. The resolution clearly condemns the disproportionate repression of the Erdogan government and specifically the repression of HDP. It leaves the door open, however, for negotiations to be resumed later.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I am concerned about the rule of law, democracy and human rights.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution because of the seriousness of the Turkish Government's action by limiting freedoms to the extreme in Turkey. Arbitrarily, without trial, thousands of civil servants have been separated from the civil service; thousands of teachers have been expelled or detained. Closed media. Almost two hundred deputies have been deprived of their rights. The leaders of Turkey's third party, Social Democrat HDP, have been imprisoned. For those of us who want a Turkey closer to the Union, it is very sad to call for the freezing of the accession negotiations. But a clear message must be sent to the Turkish government that the Union cannot accept the manipulation of justice and violations of fundamental freedoms and rights on charges without judicial support. The state of emergency is being the alibi for a real purge.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — In this case, a resolution on relations between the Union and Turkey was voted on, which talks about revising the European Instrument for Pre-Accession and calling on the Commission and the Member States to temporarily freeze Turkey's pre-accession negotiations. Moreover, the resolution begins with a “strong condemnation of Turkey's disproportionate repressive measures since the failed military coup attempt”, which I consider very positive. While the document also contains some elements that I do not agree with, such as the call for increased contribution through the European Instrument for the Promotion of Democracy and Human Rights, it also has very positive points, such as the reference to the arrests of members of the Kurdish HDP party. That is why my final vote was in favour of this resolution.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour because the repressive measures taken by the Turkish Government in the context of the state of emergency are disproportionate and violate the fundamental rights and freedoms enshrined in the Turkish Constitution and with the democratic values on which the European Union is founded.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. — Following the unanimously condemned attempted coup d'état in Turkey, Recep Tayyip Erdoğan's regime has embarked on a repression affecting all sectors of society. The repression is estimated to affect nearly 130,000 people today. The state of emergency was proclaimed on 20 July 2016 and renewed for three months from 19 October 2016. Thousands of civil servants in the army, the police, as well as justice, education and health have been removed from office. NGOs have warned about ongoing human rights violations. Many local and national elected officials of the Progressive Party HDP have been dismissed or arrested. This resolution strongly condemns the disproportionate repressive measures implemented in Turkey. Above all, it calls on the Commission and the Member States to provisionally freeze the current accession negotiations. The resolution also makes it clear that the reinstatement of the death penalty would ipso facto lead to the suspension of Turkey's accession to the Union. Still, it must be followed by effects on the other European institutions, and in particular the Council, which is the sole competent to take a decision in this area. This position of the European Parliament is important for all Democrats and Progressive Members of Turkey. I obviously voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The repressive measures taken by the Turkish Government under the state of emergency are disproportionate and violate the fundamental rights and freedoms protected by the Turkish Constitution, the democratic values that the European Union proclaims. Since the coup attempt, the authorities have arrested 10 members of the Turkish Grand National Assembly and about 150 journalists (the largest number of such arrests worldwide). 2386 judges and prosecutors and 40 000 other people have been arrested, of whom more than 31 000 are still in custody. According to the Commission's 2016 report on Turkey, 129 000 civil servants remain suspended (66 000) or have been dismissed (63 000), most of them without any charges to date. This situation naturally deserves our repudiation, but it does not prevent us from considering the need for the EU, in the field of human rights, to look within its borders where austerity policies attack the most basic social and human rights every day. At the same time as European millionaires grow, millions of human beings live without work, incomes and often homeless. This is the sad reality.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: in writing. - As my group's amendments (call for complete termination instead of mere suspension of accession negotiations; call for the abolition of pre-accession aid (around €1 billion per year)) were unfortunately not adopted, I had to abstain. The fact with regard to Erdoğan's statement to sign the introduction of the death penalty would be presented to him by the Turkish Parliament, and the absence of any sanction on the part of the EU suggests that the joint resolution is not even taken seriously at home.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the measure which provides for the freezing of negotiations between the European Union and Turkey. I believe that we cannot remain indifferent to Turkey's ongoing violations of fundamental rights and basic rules guaranteeing the rule of law.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I continue to express my strong concern for the grave human rights violations going on in Turkey, which I have witnessed first-hand, especially in the Kurdish regions. The mass arrests and crack down on media outlets and journalists must stop. I therefore welcome the freezing of EU-Turkey accession talks, a step which must be followed by harsher and more determined measures, unless the Turkish Government restores full democracy and upholds human rights and the rule of law. Turkish authorities must also stop committing atrocities in the Kurdish regions, and must allow the world’s media to access the area in order for the true situation to be reported on. I reiterate my call that all imprisoned HDP MPs must be released immediately.

name: Lieve Wierinck (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution. However, I condemn the disproportionate repressive measures taken in Turkey after the failed military coup attempt. The ongoing accession of Turkey to the EU should be temporarily frozen. I believe that Europe’s approach towards Turkey right now should only change in case the rule of law and human rights are restored throughout the country.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: in writing. - I supported the resolution because the situation in Turkey remains serious and there are recurrences of fundamental human and civil rights. EU-Turkey relations have changed fundamentally since the failed military coup. Turkey is starting to move significantly away from the pro-European direction, as evidenced by the effort to reimpose the death penalty in the country. Turkey is aware that such a move would definitely bury accession negotiations with the EU. I support the call for a freeze on accession negotiations until the Turkish Government withdraws from the disproportionate punitive measures taken following the failed coup attempt. Turkey is at the notional crossroads of relations with the EU. Turkey's decision on which path to choose can fundamentally redefine our relations with each other.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: in writing. — I supported this joint resolution of the European Parliament because I consider the EU's relations with Turkey very important, especially in dealing with the current migration crisis, when cooperation just with Turkey plays a vital role. Therefore, I voted against the proposal, which, given the current political developments in Turkey, is asking for a temporary suspension of the ongoing negotiations for Turkey's accession. In no way must we turn a blind eye to what is happening in Turkey. But let us look for other tools that will clearly reflect our disapproval of President Erdogan's policies. Suspending negotiations will not resolve the situation and certainly will not help in addressing the movement of refugees.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing. - I supported the joint motion for a resolution on relations between the European Union and Turkey. The main theme of this resolution was the assessment of the situation in Turkey following the failed coup attempt in July and the punitive measures that followed it. Although I believe that Turkey is an important partner of the European Union, we cannot turn a blind eye to the wave of persecutions that it has acceded following a failed coup attempt. Many journalists, opposition politicians, judges or academics have been arrested or persecuted. The situation has escalated to such an extent that, in my view, it is impossible to continue accession negotiations until Turkey abolishes these disproportionate punitive measures. Measures of this nature, and in particular attempts to reintroduce the death penalty, are clearly contrary to the fundamental values of the European Union, which every country seeking to join the EU must comply unconditionally.

name: Željana Zovko (PPE)
text: written. - I do not support the proposal for a resolution seeking to stop negotiations with Turkey for two very important reasons. First, Turkey, due to its exceptional geostrategic and geopolitical position, represents a pivotal country in the Middle East and the European Union's cooperation with Turkey in addressing all security issues in this area is crucial. Turkey is an important partner to the European Union in the management of refugee waves and has made significant efforts by receiving large numbers of refugees from war-torn areas. Turkey's active involvement in the war conflict in Syria reflects a willingness to conduct foreign policy responsibly in line with European attempts to end the state of permanent war. On the other hand, the point of accession negotiations is to spot irregularities and understatement of the system, its weak points and attempt to establish a framework that will be a prerequisite for future development and progress in all areas, as well as the protection of human rights and democratic values. Stopping accession negotiations at this point would only undo efforts so far in reform and change and is not a good message to Turkey, but also to other candidate countries because it does not reflect the consistency of the enlargement policy.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted for the European Parliament's Resolution on EU-Turkey relations. Turkey is an important partner of the EU and, as candidate countries, is expected to respect the highest standards of democracy, including respect for human rights, the rule of law, fundamental freedoms and the general right to a fair trial. Turkey is a member of the Council of Europe and is therefore committed to respecting the European Convention on Human Rights. However, since the repressive measures taken by the Turkish Government in emergency situations are disproportionate and contrary to the fundamental rights and freedoms guaranteed by the Turkish Constitution and the democratic values and principles of the rule of law on which the European Union is founded, the freezing of negotiations is in in accordance with paragraph 5 of the negotiating framework for accession negotiations with Turkey, a necessary and necessary measure until the Turkish Government ceases these violations.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, EU accession to the Istanbul Convention on Preventing and Combating Violence against Women would again emphasise our clear condemnation of gender inequality. By setting legally binding standards in this sphere, we would hope to prevent gender-based violence, protect victims, identify and punish perpetrators and raise awareness across the EU. In the light of considerable disparities across the EU, in both the reporting and handling of reports of violence against women, I believe it to be essential that we speed up negotiations and the signing of this Convention. The implementation and coordination of more proactive policies would therefore represent a marked step towards the protection of human rights for all. In conclusion, I would like to compliment the rapporteurs, my colleagues Anna Maria Corazza Bildt and Barbara Matera, for their good work and I look forward to the day when motions like this will not be necessary and when women do not suffer violence as they are unfortunately continuing to do.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ This resolution welcomes the Commission's proposal to sign and conclude the EU's accession to the Istanbul Convention, as this will be able to provide us with a framework coherent European legal in order to prevent and combat violence against women and gender-based violence, as well as to put further political pressure on Member States to ratify themselves such a tool. For these reasons I voted in favour.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. - 33% of European women have suffered some form of violence, family, sexual, harassment at work, etc. A society where half the population, women, is still at risk of being the victim of gender-based violence requires us all to assume responsibility and work to eliminate this injustice. I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that it is very important for the Union to accede to the Istanbul Convention as soon as possible, because it is the first legally binding instrument adopted and constitutes the most far-reaching international treaty to address violence against women as a grave violation of human rights. That is why it is also urgent for all Member States to ratify it. A Union legal act enabling legislative, preventive and corrective measures of the Istanbul Convention to become part of the legal system of the Member States is also necessary in order for the Court of Justice of the Union to have the power to deliver judgments. I am aware that legislating is not the only solution but the way to compromise and compel public institutions in the fight against violence against women.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution, as it urges the Union and its Member States to accede to the Istanbul Convention on Prevention and Combating Violence against Women. Unfortunately, despite the fact that all the Member States of the Union have signed it, only 14 have ratified it. This is very serious, since a decisive reaction from the Union is essential to end sexist violence once and for all. Every second account, and, we need the European Commission and the States to agree and take this problem seriously with real political will. The Convention recognizes violence against women as a violation of human rights and is undoubtedly an enormous step that the Union must take to take political and judicial measures against sexist violence, in the face of the very serious events as in the Spanish State where 39 women have been murdered at the hands of their abusers that we have been this year.

name: Martina Anderson Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The accession to the Convention is an important step forward and can be built upon to go further, but there is more support needed from Member States and the Parliament. The resolution highlights the request for a European framework directive against violence against women, which is very important. It is hoped that this resolution will implore Member States who have not ratified the Convention to do so as a matter of urgency.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution to make combating violence against women and girls a priority for all! 45% of women in Europe have been dealing with gender-based violence at least once in their lives. Due to the lack of harmonisation of policies in this area at European level, they are not protected in the same way depending on the country in which they live. A tool exists to better protect women, prevent violence and prosecute those responsible: it is the Council of Europe's Istanbul Convention, the first legally binding international instrument on the issue. While all the Member States have signed the Convention, only 14 of them have ratified it, including France. It is for this reason that the European Commission proposed in March 2016 that the European Union be able to accede to the Istanbul Convention. This would be a very important step forward in further standardization of measures to combat this unacceptable gender-based violence that continues today in Europe.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the resolution on the EU's accession to the Istanbul Convention on Prevention and Combating Violence Against Women. I regret that violence against women is too often regarded as a personal matter and is too easily tolerated, although in fact it is a violation of fundamental rights and a serious crime that must be punished. The impunity of criminals must end in order to break through the vicious circle of silence and loneliness of women and girls who are victims of violence. Unfortunately, EU citizens and citizens are not equally protected from gender-based violence because there is no coherent system and differences in Member States' policies and laws, inter alia, in terms of the definition of crimes and the scope of legislation, so that they are less protected from violence. I agree on 4 March 2016. The Commission's proposal for EU accession to the Istanbul Convention is the first legally binding instrument for preventing and combating violence against women at international level.
