I also support the call for an accelerated debate in the Council on this issue, and for Member States that have not yet done so to ratify the Istanbul Convention without delay.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: in writing. - The Istanbul Convention contains a large number of measures to prevent and combat violence against women. These include, for example, the obligations to raise public awareness of this issue, to collect data on violence against women and to legislate that criminalise different types of gender-based violence. On a proposal from the Commission, the EU has decided to accede to the Convention and all Member States have signed it. However, ratification in the Member States is waiting. I therefore support the joint resolution tabled by the political groups, which calls on the Member States to speed up the ratification process. It also calls for a coherent European legal framework to combat violence against women and gender-based violence in general.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: in writing. — The Council of Europe Convention on Preventing and Combating Violence against Women is an international treaty adopted in Istanbul in 2011. It aims to eradicate all gender-based violence that leads to physical, sexual, psychological or economic harm or suffering for women. It imposes a binding legal framework prohibiting forced marriage, female genital mutilation, coerced sterilization and sexual harassment. It should also be noted that the Convention includes more questionable objectives, particularly on abortion. As of August 2016, 42 countries had signed it, including all Member States, and 21 countries had ratified it, including 14 Member States, including France. The joint motion for a resolution calls on the Council and the Commission to speed up negotiations with a view to acceding to this Convention and calls on the Member States to ratify it. The text also emphasizes the protection of refugee women as well as women seeking asylum. The EU has no diplomatic legitimacy to ratify such a convention. This is once again an attack on the sovereignty of the Member States which will now be forced to ratify it. So I voted against it.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst I fully support the aims of the convention I do not believe I should legitimise the European Union in signing international conventions. The United Kingdom is well on the way to ratifying this convention as a Member State. I voted to abstain on this resolution.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: Ensuring and promoting equality between women and men is an undeniable objective of the European Union, guaranteed by the Treaties. The Union's accession to the Istanbul Convention will help the Union ensure a coherent legal framework for preventing and combating violence against women. For this reason, I therefore welcomed the Commission's proposal to sign and conclude accession, and therefore voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: in writing. — Although the objective of this resolution is commendable, I consider that the European Union has no diplomatic legitimacy to ratify such a convention that it would impose on the Member States, to whom the decision should be taken. The European Union would once again override its rights and undermine the sovereignty of States, which is why I voted against the resolution.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: I obviously endorsed this joint resolution, which strongly condemns all forms of violence against women or girls and is concerned about the extent of violence against women and girls within the Union. In particular, the report urges Member States to work together to share good practices and effective methods for preventing violence and protecting men and women from gender-based violence. Finally, the resolution notes that the 28 member states have signed the Council of Europe Istanbul Convention on Preventing and Combating Violence against Women and Domestic Violence, highlighting the political will of the Member States to stop violence against women.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution, because it advocates the ratification and early accession of the Union to the Convention. I would also like to express my unrest with the Council, as negotiations are not progressing at the same rate as in the rest of the European institutions. The accession of the Union will ensure a coherent European regulatory framework to prevent and combat violence against women and gender-based violence. It is necessary for the Union to have, once and for all, a binding instrument to harshly prosecute this type of violence. It was not understandable that countries such as Germany or the United Kingdom, whose women at the head of the respective governments were among the most important on the planet, still did not ratify the Convention. The Convention recognizes violence against women as a violation of human rights and as a form of discrimination, holding States accountable if they do not respond adequately. It is the first binding instrument at European level on violence against women and domestic violence.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Gender violence represents an extreme form of discrimination, a violation of the fundamental rights and freedoms of victims, which is both the cause and consequence of further inequality. Violence does not exclusively breed physical, sexual, emotional or psychological harm, but has strong repercussions for family members and society as a whole. I strongly supported the resolution tabled in Parliament today because I consider the EU's accession to the Istanbul Convention on Prevention and Combat Violence in the Istanbul Convention as an important step comparisons of women. The approved text calls on the Council and the Commission to speed up negotiations on the signing and conclusion of the Convention, asking all Member States which have not yet done so to ratify the treaty as soon as possible and ensure its proper implementation. No single intervention can eliminate violence against women and gender-based violence, which is why we need a set of infrastructural, legal, judicial, cultural and social actions that break the vicious circle of silence and loneliness, helping victims and raising awareness of society. Europe can do a lot in this direction.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ 25 November was marked by the United Nations as the International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women, which remains a widespread phenomenon in the Union. So far, the Istanbul Council of Europe Convention is the largest international agreement addressing violence against women and girls and gender-based violence from a holistic perspective. In March 2016, the Commission proposed that the Union accede to the Istanbul Convention. All Member States of the Union have signed it, but only 14 have ratified it. The oral question addressed to the Council and the Commission, as well as the JMR, aims to accelerate accession to the Convention and to convince Member States that have not ratified it as soon as possible, to know the status of the negotiation of the signature, the actions that the Presidency has taken to expedite the signature, the time required to conclude the accession of the Union to the Convention and the role of the European Parliament in monitoring the Convention. I think these are positive proposals and I therefore voted in favour.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: in writing. - I have decided to vote against this motion for a resolution on the accession of the European Union to the Istanbul Convention on the Prevention and Combating of Violence against Women. In my view, the signing of international conventions and treaties must remain a prerogative of sovereign States, the only States able to play an efficient and legitimate diplomatic role at the international level. I would like to remind you that France has already ratified the Istanbul Convention. Of course, some violent practices, mainly targeting women, are unbearable, including female genital mutilation or forced sterilization. I am surprised, however, that other types of violence are not being placed in the same bag, such as subjection to veil and religion in certain community-based neighbourhoods on European territory, or the impossibility, for some women who wish to do so, to have access to alternative solutions to abortion. Finally, I had difficulty seeing how refugee women and asylum seekers would have the right to protection and consideration higher than those of European women, as appears to be the case in this resolution.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. ‒ The Istanbul Convention on the prevention and fight against violence against women is a very important text, which entered into force in 2014, of which the resolutions presented well they explain the contents. For these reasons I wanted to support these texts with my vote.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution because it called on the Council to ratify the Council of Europe Convention on the Prevention and Elimination of Violence Against Women and Domestic Violence (Istanbul Convention) as soon as possible. It would be a strong impulse to act even more actively, bringing this shameful phenomenon out of our daily lives. Physical, psychological and sexual violence against women still remains one of the most severe and common phenomena in Lithuania and throughout the European Union. It is estimated that every fourth woman is experiencing physical abuse in the European Union. Therefore, we must act immediately at both EU and Member State level.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: in writing. — I consider that the EU's efforts to eliminate violence against women and girls should be part of a comprehensive plan to eliminate all forms of gender inequalities, so I ask you to develop an EU strategy for violence against women and to combat gender-based violence. In this hope, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: in writing. - I strongly support the approach to and fight against the Istanbul Convention on the Prevention of Violence Against Women and Domestic Violence. Violence against women remains widespread in the EU, according to data, and research by the Agency for Fundamental Rights confirms this data. The survey reveals facts that we don't need to ignore, with a third of all women in Europe at least once in their adult life victims of physical or sexual violence, of which 20% of girls between the ages of 18 and 29 were exposed to sexual harassment online, with every fifth woman being a victim pursuit, every twenty was raped. That survey also explains that most cases of violence are not reported to authorities, meaning that perpetrators are not punished. I therefore agree with the invitation to the Council and the Commission to speed up the course of negotiations on the signing and conclusion of the Istanbul Convention.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: ‒ Violence against women and gender-based violence are still a widespread phenomenon within the EU: in Europe one in three women has suffered physical or sexual violence at least once in adulthood. In line with the principles of the Charter of Fundamental Rights, the EU has made gender equality and the right to non-discrimination key values of the Community system. Parliament calls for the EU's accession to the Istanbul Convention on the prevention and fight against violence against women with this resolution. As the first legally binding instrument, the Convention defines violence against women as a violation of human rights and a form of serious discrimination. EU membership will help establish a coherent European legal framework, through zero-tolerance criminal law rules in respect of violence against women applicable in all its states members.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: written. - There is no strategy yet at European level, let alone a law condemning such violence. In the EU, seven women die from the consequences of violence every day. We can't wait a day! In March this year, the European Commission launched the process of ratifying the Istanbul Convention of the Council of Europe, a comprehensive international agreement on combating violence against women and domestic violence. But despite this, the Council is braking the progress of the process, and most states have not adopted the Convention justifying themselves to the high cost of implementation. The cost of violence against women at EU level is 1.8 percent of EU GDP, or 228 billion a year. But I don't need figures to know that human life and dignity are most valuable.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the resolution on the EU accession to the Istanbul Convention on preventing and combating violence against women because even if they would vote it, they would never fully respect it.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: in writing. — The Istanbul Convention on the Prevention and Combating of Violence against Women is intended to eradicate all acts of gender-based violence that results in physical, sexual, psychological or economic harm and suffering. Laudable objectives include the prohibition of forced marriage, female genital mutilation and forced sterilization in signatory countries. This joint motion for a resolution recommends that the Council and the Commission ratify this Convention and allocate sufficient financial resources to effectively combat such violence. We consider that the European Union has no diplomatic legitimacy to ratify such a convention. This is a further attack on the sovereignty of the Member States. Let the European Union begin by guaranteeing women their first rights: the right to security. However, the development of fundamentalism in Europe and the current migratory submersion, reinforced by the compulsory distribution mechanism of migrants, directly threaten women's freedom and physical integrity. This is evidenced by the explosion in the number of sexual assaults, particularly in Cologne and Sweden. I therefore voted against this text.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the accession of the European Union to the Istanbul Convention. Accession to this Convention will ensure a coherent European legal framework to prevent and combat violence against women and gender-based violence to protect victims of such violence. The aim is not only to combat this violence, but also to equip oneself to prevent it, in particular through the implementation of relevant Union legislation, programmes and funds for monitoring. The Convention allows for better collection of violence against women and gender-based violence at Union level. Accession reinforces the responsibility of the Union at international level and exerts political pressure on the Member States to ratify this instrument.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the accession of the EU to the Istanbul Convention on the prevention and fight against violence against women because it is necessary to relaunch the commitment to overcome, prevent and defeat all forms of violence and harassment against women in every sphere of personal, family and social life, including workplaces. I voted in favour because we now need an effort of everyone on a cultural level, to abandon sexist and offensive attitudes towards women, and educate all citizens about respect for every person. It is necessary for the EU to join the Convention in order to ensure greater efficiency and coherence of its policies for preventing and combating violence against women and violence domestic.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted in favour of the first ECR resolution and abstained on the second compromise resolution. Both were non-legislative and non-binding. The Istanbul Convention is a (non-EU) international convention that will create some legally binding and non-legislative measures which countries who ratify will have to bring in to national law. The UK is in the process of ratifying the Convention in its own right. UKIP voted in favour of the first ECR resolution as the wording was much better than the compromise resolution because it stressed: ‘that it is the sovereign right of a Member State to ratify and implement the Convention and its provisions’. UKIP abstained on the second compromise resolution because although on the one hand it called on the EU to sign up to Convention in its own right (UKIP cannot legitimise the EU signing up to international agreements in its own right) – on the other hand we don’t want to appear opposed to fighting violence against women.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. – I join the other MEPs in calling on all EU Member States to ratify the Istanbul Convention, which is a binding Convention to fight sexual violence against women. Violence against women van never be justified. Too often, violence against women is tolerated and it is our responsibility to act in order to combat violence against women. Too many innocent lives and their families are scared or lost as a result of such violence. To fight against this scourge, the European Commission proposed in March 2016 the EU’s accession, within its competences and alongside the Member States, to the Istanbul Convention. It requires amongst others for parties to improve the protection of victims of violence and ensure the prosecution of offenders in several respects such as criminalising violence against women (psychological or physical) and empower the police to remove a perpetrator of domestic violence from the home.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: In the vicinity of the International Day for the Elimination of Violence Against Women, the Commission on Women's Rights and the European Parliament have decided to address a Oral question to the Commission and the Council to ask for account of the state of the art negotiations for the signing and ratification by the EU of the Istanbul Convention. The latter is a Council of Europe Convention against Violence on Women and Domestic Violence which was passed on 7 April 2011 with the purpose of preventing violence, protecting victims and prevent impunity of the perpetrators. To date it has been signed by 32 countries, including Italy, but only 14 have ratified it. Since it is the first binding international document for states to define a social definition of gender, which is outside the context and subject of the Convention itself, many States I am reluctant to ratify it because, being legally binding, its ratification would automatically result in the extension of that definition to their national laws. My vote was positive.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as it addresses the extremely important issue of the fight against violence on women and other types of gender-based violence. We should do everything we can to make sure our strict stand on this issue is heard and visible also on the international level. Therefore, I fully share the views expressed in the resolution and call on the Council and Commission to speed the process of negotiations on the signing and conclusion of the Istanbul Convention.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: in writing. Unfortunately, violence against women is very often seen as a private issue with excessive tolerance. In fact, this is a violation of fundamental rights and a serious crime which must be punished accordingly. The impunity of the perpetrators must be stopped in order to break the vicious circle of silence and loneliness for women and girls who have been victims of violence.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The motion for a resolution on the accession of the European Union to the Istanbul Convention on Preventing and Combating Violence Against Women is an additional effort to strengthen the protection of women, which we must continue by establishing concrete European framework in the coming period, as has already been proposed. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ On the International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women, I symbolically welcome the Union's accession to the Istanbul Convention on the Prevention and Combat Against Violence on women and, likewise, I hope for prompt ratification by the Member States in order to provide an irreproachable implementation of what has been established. Together with this, adequate financial and human resources are required to be allocated to the prevention and fight against gender-based violence. In fact, it is not acceptable that, to this day, our civilization can still admit or hide such human dramas. By virtue of this, I welcome the decision to establish a coherent European legal framework to prevent and combat violence against women and to protect victims of violence by increasing coherence and efficiency of internal and external policies, as well as collecting comparable and unbundled data on the subject under consideration. The fear and loneliness that frequently afflict those who are victims of violence prevent an end to devastating phenomena, so it is essential to implement to the fullest efforts to disseminate information on the Convention, EU programmes and related funding available. It only takes one hand to save a life or change the tide, but it must be the right one.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the motion for a resolution on EU accession to the Istanbul Convention on preventing and combating violence against women.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. - Violence, domestic or otherwise, on the grounds of gender, unfortunately remains a very present reality for too many women, including in Europe, where about one in 20 women have already been raped. Despite the fact that equality between men and women is a core value of European societies, millions of women are still victims. The fight against this scourge will not be made instantly, nor will it result from an isolated action. On the contrary, only constant and multi-level work will yield results. That is why adhering to the Istanbul Convention is essential. On the one hand, to ensure at least a minimum level of protection throughout the European continent and, on the other, to ensure that the mobility of European women does not translate into less protection or double victimization. I therefore support this resolution.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this measure because, on the eve of the International Day against Violence against Women, the European Parliament notes that few still have been made progress in combating this phenomenon. It is therefore necessary to proceed more quickly to the EU's accession to the Istanbul Convention, which will ensure a coherent European legal framework and also ensure greater policy efficiency internal and external of the Union ensuring a more adequate and detailed collection of comparable and unbundled data on violence against women and gender-based violence at European Union level thereby strengthening its responsibility at international level.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ The Istanbul Convention is a Council of Europe convention against violence against women and domestic violence. It was approved on 7 April 2011 with the purpose of preventing violence, protecting victims and preventing impunity of perpetrators. The signatory states therefore undertake to adopt a number of legislative measures and not to combat the phenomenon of violence. To date it has been signed by 32 countries including Italy as well. However, several countries are reluctant to ratify the Convention, in particular because its ratification would automatically result in the extension of this definition to their national laws. The oral question is aimed at obtaining greater clarity regarding the state of negotiations and proceedings, what moves are planned to tackle gender-based violence, whether it is possible speed up the procedure to reach ratification more quickly and whether it is possible to activate the so-called “walkway clause” through which to give a transnational dimension to gender violence thereby allowing a tightening of the penis in this area. What is said seems to me more than enough to demonstrate my full support and therefore justify my vote in favour.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution, as it urges the Union and its Member States to accede to the Istanbul Convention on Prevention and Combating Violence against Women. Unfortunately, despite the fact that all the Member States of the Union have signed it, only 14 have ratified it. This is very serious, since a decisive reaction from the Union is essential to end sexist violence once and for all. Every second account, and, we need the European Commission and the States to agree and take this problem seriously with real political will. The Convention recognizes violence against women as a violation of human rights and is undoubtedly an enormous step that the Union must take to take political and judicial measures against sexist violence, in the face of the very serious events as in the Spanish State where 39 women have been murdered at the hands of their abusers that we have been this year.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing. — I voted against EU accession to the Istanbul Convention on the Prevention and Combat of Violence Against Women. The subject matter is extremely important. Action should be taken to protect women by violence. I wouldn't want to be seen as a person with violence against women. Such a decision was prejudiced by fears of provisions of the resolution which violate the principle of subsidiarity. These provisions transpose the provisions of the Convention into national law and the criminal law system. Protecting women from violence cannot have an indological basis in gender ideology, and must be based on effective laws and actions. The proposed resolution is ideological in nature. In order to ensure the best possible system for protecting women from violence, it is necessary to work on alternative motions for resolutions that have been drafted to obtain consensus.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ 45% of all women in Europe have been subject to and suffered from gender-based violence. It is estimated that the total cost of domestic violence within the 28 Member States could be as high as EUR 16 billion. These percentages and figures are a wake-up call to all Member States that they need to ratify the Istanbul Convention. I am in favour of this resolution, which calls for the first legally binding instrument in Europe on violence against women as a serious violation of human rights to be ratified in all signatory countries. We need to act on this silent suffering now and stop all violence against women.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. - Violence against women and gender-based violence is a violation of fundamental rights and an extreme form of discrimination, constituting both the cause and the consequence of gender inequality. I believe that the accession of the European Union to the Istanbul Convention will benefit everyone. Firstly, a mandate for better data collection at EU level (currently not enough data to show the size and nature of violence against women), thus requiring Member States to collect and report accurate and comparable data to Eurostat . A better understanding of the phenomenon will help prevent and approach it.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: on 4 March 2016, the Commission proposed that the European Union accede to the Istanbul Convention, the first legally binding international instrument to prevent and combat violence against women and domestic violence. Thus, the European Parliament has been called upon to vote on this accession. Considering that it is the duty of the European Union to be exemplary in defending women's rights, so as to pave the way for its international partners, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: I voted in favour of this resolution, of which I was a co-signatory, for the accession of the European Union to the Istanbul Convention on Preventing and Combating Violence against Women. The numbers are more than alarming. One in three women has experienced at least one experience of physical or sexual violence in her adult life. It is essential for the European Union to become more involved in the fight we are fighting by establishing this legally binding instrument at international level. Only 14 of the Member States of the European Union have ratified this Convention. I regret it. Violence against women is a real scourge affecting each of the Member States. No one can afford to close their eyes in the face of this brutality. I therefore call on the Council to conclude negotiations in this direction as soon as possible.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution, which calls on the European Union and its Member States to ratify rapidly the Council of Europe Convention on preventing and combating violence against women. The Convention establishes minimum standards for protection against violence against women, for example by introducing legislation to improve the protection of victims and condemn aggressors. The resolution we have voted for is a real awareness of this issue, and I think it is essential that the European Union should be heavily involved in the fight against violence against women.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Violence against women is unfortunately still a plague of society. It represents a form of discrimination and a violation of women's fundamental rights and freedoms. One form of violence that must be fought is the domestic one that often goes unreported. I voted in favour of joining the European Union to the Istanbul Convention because I believe that gender equality is a pivotal value of the EU and that we should never let our guard down when one deal with this problem.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution, aimed at urging Member States to ratify as soon as possible the Council of Europe Convention signed in Istanbul in 2011 to further combat violence against women. Indeed, despite the fact that all the Member States of the European Union have signed this Convention, only 14 of them have ratified it. Missing the call: Germany, the United Kingdom, Ireland, Luxembourg, Hungary, the Czech Republic, Slovakia, Bulgaria, Croatia, Greece, Cyprus, and the three Baltic States (Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania). This is all the more regrettable given that it is in fact the first legally binding instrument on preventing and combating violence against women at the international level. Like many of my colleagues, I believe that violence against women is too often considered a private issue and is too easily tolerated. This is, above all, a violation of fundamental rights and a serious offence which I believe must be punished as such.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. — This international convention, signed on 11 May 2011 in Istanbul, prohibits, inter alia, forced marriage, female genital mutilation, forced sterilization and sexual harassment, but also deals with abortion, which is more questionable. This joint motion for a resolution calls on the Council and the European Commission to speed up negotiations with a view to acceding to this Convention. We believe, for our part, that it is up to the Member States to decide on it. It is in this spirit that we supported the ECR Group's alternative resolution.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. — In voting on the EU's accession to the Istanbul Convention on the Prevention and Combating Violence Against Women, I abstained, but not because I believe that we should not fight this violence, but because I believe that the resolution prepared by the ECR was much better than the general one that was voted by the majority in parliament, and doubts about a breach of the principle of subsidiarity in it were obvious. Yet violence against women, as well as domestic violence, must be fought by any means.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: in writing. The Istanbul Convention recognises violence against women as a violation of human rights, which cannot be called into question. Alongside information and awareness raising in a national and EU context, measures aimed at preventing violence, protecting victims and prosecuting perpetrators are needed.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the EU joining the Istanbul Convention to combat violence against women and girls and back the calls for the Council to do so. The UK is one of fourteen Member States that have signed but not ratified the Convention and I have called on the National Assembly for Wales to do so to put pressure on the UK Government to keep its promise.

name: Laura Ferrara (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ Every human being has the right to live free from violence in the public and private spheres, which is still widespread in the EU towards women, the main victims of gender-based violence. A comprehensive and integrated framework which aims to combat such forms of violence cannot be irrespective of the adoption of legislative and other measures relating to the prevention and detection of criminally prosecutable offences, to protection and support to victims. A key role are the appropriate measures to promote socio-cultural campaigns aimed at eliminating prejudice and customs that encourage or justify the violation of rights against women human and fundamental freedoms.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Violence against women remains a widespread reality and with dramatic figures in the EU. The resolution recommends the EU's rapid accession to the Istanbul Convention as an important instrument in combating and preventing violence against women. It also calls on Member States to ensure their proper implementation and to allocate adequate financial and human resources for preventing and combating violence against women and protecting victims. It is no wonder that this resolution does not link what are right-wing policies, attacks on social and labour rights or the 'austerity' policies that the EU has imposed, and the increase in inequalities, poverty and social exclusion, high levels of unemployment, insecurity and how these phenomena affect women particularly, and contribute to the increase in sexual and domestic violence, or to the increase of prostitution networks and trafficking in human beings. This is a reality that simply signing a Convention will not result in results unless it is also accompanied by social policies at other levels of intervention, namely concrete policies to combat poverty and social exclusion. Notwithstanding these reservations, we voted in favour.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the following motion for a resolution. I welcome the possibility that individual Member States will transpose into national law the provisions relating to the Istanbul Convention. I also believe it necessary that measures concerning the prevention and fight against violence against women, including domestic violence, should be applied in national legislation individual Member States and in their criminal systems.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing. - Although the European Union has done a great deal of good work in preventing violence against women over the past 20 years, it is still very far away to the finish. The latest statistics report that 45% of all women in Europe were subject to and suffered gender-based violence. It is estimated that the total cost of domestic violence across the 28 Member States could amount to up to €16 billion. Violence against women has a huge impact on victims and also imposes significant costs on the whole of society. The Istanbul Convention on the Prevention and Combating Violence Against Women is the first legally binding instrument in Europe and, in terms of scale, it is the most important international treaty in this area. It may not be possible during the Slovak Presidency, but we should jointly do everything possible so that the signing can already be done during the Maltese Presidency.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: In writing. - I am voting for the resolution: I support the fight against violence against women and this text is an aid in this direction.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: in writing. — I am voting against the accession of the European Union to the Istanbul Convention on Preventing and Combating Violence Against Women. The Istanbul Convention recognises violence against women as a violation of human rights, which cannot be called into question. In addition to information and raising awareness in a national and EU context, measures are needed to prevent violence, protect victims and prosecute perpetrators.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Violence against women has a huge impact on victims and also imposes a significant cost on society. In the framework of the international day of combating violence against women, the Commission and Member States should take steps towards its ratification, and the procedure for EU accession should accelerate. Through this Convention, states will be obliged to change their laws to zero tolerance towards violence against women, and preventing and combating violence becomes legally binding. Finally, violence against women will not be considered as a private matter, but states will be obliged to prevent violence, protect victims and punish the perpetrators. Considering the fact that the Convention does not have a jurisdictional guaranteeing body, but only a conventional one, it is not guaranteed by a court but by a committee, and I support the call for an EU directive.

name: Мария Габриел (PPE)
text: in writing. — I supported the adoption of a resolution on the EU's accession to the Istanbul Convention, as it will be a decisive step in preventing and combating violence against women and gender-based violence. In this resolution, we call for the negotiations to be stepped up for the signing and conclusion of the EU accession agreement to the Istanbul Convention, as well as for its ratification by more Member States. Efforts to eradicate violence against women should form part of a comprehensive plan to combat all forms of gender inequality. This implies the coherence of national provisions with those of the Istanbul Convention and the provision of adequate financial and human resources to eliminate violence against women. The resolution also recognises the key role of NGOs. Cooperation between them and national institutions shall contribute to raising public awareness of this important problem, as well as to the signing of the Convention by Member States. Bulgaria is a concrete example in this regard, where the national campaign I initiated “Violence against women: Open our eyes and break the silence” encouraged victims to speak so that the public can hear them and the institutions to be more actively involved in preventing and combating violence over women, as well as with the protection of victims.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution considering that, as recognized by the Treaties and the Charter of Fundamental Rights, gender equality is a central value of the Union. However, violence against women and gender-based violence remain a widespread phenomenon in the Union, and this is something we cannot tolerate in any way. The Union's accession to the Istanbul Convention, the first legally binding instrument on preventing and combating violence against women at international level, is therefore essential.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. - 33% of European women have suffered some form of violence, family, sexual, harassment at work, etc. A society where half the population, women, is still at risk of being the victim of gender-based violence requires us all to assume responsibility and work to eliminate this injustice. I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that it is very important for the Union to accede to the Istanbul Convention as soon as possible, because it is the first legally binding instrument adopted and constitutes the most far-reaching international treaty to address violence against women as a grave violation of human rights. That is why it is also urgent for all Member States to ratify it. A Union legal act enabling legislative, preventive and corrective measures of the Istanbul Convention to become part of the legal system of the Member States is also necessary in order for the Court of Justice of the Union to have the power to deliver judgments. I am aware that legislating is not the only solution but the way to compromise and compel public institutions in the fight against violence against women.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. - 33% of European women have suffered some form of violence, family, sexual, harassment at work, etc. A society where half the population, women, is still at risk of being the victim of gender-based violence requires us all to assume responsibility and work to eliminate this injustice. I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that it is very important for the Union to accede to the Istanbul Convention as soon as possible, because it is the first legally binding instrument adopted and constitutes the most far-reaching international treaty to address violence against women as a grave violation of human rights. That is why it is also urgent for all Member States to ratify it. A Union legal act enabling legislative, preventive and corrective measures of the Istanbul Convention to become part of the legal system of the Member States is also necessary in order for the Court of Justice of the Union to have the power to deliver judgments. I am aware that legislating is not the only solution but the way to compromise and compel public institutions in the fight against violence against women.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted strongly in favour of the Joint Resolution on the accession of the EU to the Istanbul Convention on the prevention and fight against violence against women because battle to end this horrific phenomenon increasingly takes on a European dimension and the EU must act strongly to stop the different forms of violence. The latest data on the phenomenon of femicide in Italy, after more than 1 year after the passage of the national law, are shocking and show how violence against women is a very difficult phenomenon to eradicate. Domestic violence, violence on sentimental grounds, violence related to slavery, violence on women migrants: 2016 leaves us in dowry images and stories that we would soon like to erase. EU accession to the Istanbul Convention would accelerate the ratification process of the first binding international instrument against violence against women, currently at 14 Member States , enshrining for the whole EU the principle that domestic violence is not a private matter but a hateful offence. Finally, I strongly agree with the S&D Group's call for a European directive on gender-based violence, which would solve the problem of sanctions on those states that violate the Convention by not complying with the obligations contained therein.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: in writing. - As members of the ECR Group, we are firmly and resolutely opposed to all forms of violence against women and also support the positions of the Istanbul Convention in this regard. We are pleased that Germany is one of the EU Member States that signed the Convention. We have expressed all this in our ECR resolution, which I voted for. My abstention for the joint resolution is due to the fact that I respect national sovereignty and subsidiarity on this very important issue. It is not up to the EU to sign such an agreement on behalf of its Member States, irrespective of the accuracy of its content.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: in writing. — Gender equality is an unavoidable European asset. In order not to limit this, I did not support the motion for a resolution.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the first ECR resolution and abstained on the second compromise resolution. The UK is in the process of ratifying the convention in its own right. I voted in favour of the first ECR resolution as the wording was much better than the compromise resolution because it stressed: ‘that it is the sovereign right of a Member State to ratify and implement the Convention and its provisions’. I abstained on the second compromise resolution because it called on the EU to sign up to Convention in its own right (I cannot legitimise the EU signing up to international agreements in its own right).

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, which calls on the EU to step up its actions on combating violence against women through the adoption of EU legislation to strengthen our response and classify violence against women as a particularly serious crime within the EU Treaties. It is simply unacceptable that a third of all women in Europe have suffered physical or sexual violence.

name: María Teresa Giménez Barbat (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The fight to eliminate violence against women and domestic violence is a noble and inalienable purpose that is rooted in fundamental European values, starting with the right to equality between men and women. I therefore supported this resolution on the Union's accession to the Istanbul Convention. At the same time, I regret that the present resolution does not reflect at any point that men also suffer domestic violence, as recognized by the preamble to the Convention. Although women suffer more domestic violence than men — which may justify special legal treatment — evidence from international domestic violence surveys and studies does not, however, support men and boys being forgotten or not sufficiently recognized by our legislation.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ 25 November was marked by the United Nations as the International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women, which remains a widespread phenomenon in the Union. So far, the Istanbul Council of Europe Convention is the largest international agreement addressing violence against women and girls and gender-based violence from a holistic perspective. In March 2016, the Commission proposed that the Union accede to the Istanbul Convention. All Member States of the Union have signed it, but only 14 have ratified it. The oral question addressed to the Council and the Commission, as well as the JMR, aims to accelerate accession to the Convention and to convince Member States that have not ratified it as soon as possible, to know the status of the negotiation of the signature, the actions that the Presidency has taken to expedite the signature, the time required to conclude the accession of the Union to the Convention and the role of the European Parliament in monitoring the Convention. I think these are positive proposals and I therefore voted in favour.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as currently a third of all women in Europe have suffered physical or sexual violence. This resolution calls on the EU to step up its actions on combating violence against women through the adoption of EU legislation to strengthen our response and classify violence against women as a particularly serious crime within the EU Treaties.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: I voted in favour of this resolution because it calls on the European Union to accede to the Istanbul Convention, which is the first legally binding international tool to combat violence against women. For example, it makes it possible to criminalize physical and psychological violence, provide safe shelters for victims of violence, educate on gender equality, etc. In order to eradicate violence against women, governments and the European Union have their share of responsibility. We need to legislate in order to change the law and mindsets in depth. And in this struggle, our laws must be aligned with the Istanbul Convention. Of the 28 Member States that signed it, only half have ratified it. For its part, the European Commission proposed the EU's accession to this convention last March. But it is time to accelerate the step: the EU must accede and implement the Convention, and push Member States to do so as well. That is the message of this Parliament resolution, which I supported. A European approach is essential to protect women in the best and the same way, regardless of where they live in Europe.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. - 33% of European women have suffered some form of violence, family, sexual, harassment at work, etc. A society where half the population, women, is still at risk of being the victim of gender-based violence requires us all to assume responsibility and work to eliminate this injustice. I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that it is very important for the Union to accede to the Istanbul Convention as soon as possible, because it is the first legally binding instrument adopted and constitutes the most far-reaching international treaty to address violence against women as a grave violation of human rights. That is why it is also urgent for all Member States to ratify it. A Union legal act enabling legislative, preventive and corrective measures of the Istanbul Convention to become part of the legal system of the Member States is also necessary in order for the Court of Justice of the Union to have the power to deliver judgments. I am aware that legislating is not the only solution but the way to compromise and compel public institutions in the fight against violence against women.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I fully supported the joint resolution on EU accession to the Istanbul Convention on preventing and combating violence against women. This resolution reiterates its call on the Commission to combat violence against women, to submit a legal act providing a coherent system for collecting statistical data as well as a strengthened approach by Member States to the prevention and suppression of all forms of violence against women and girls and of gender-based violence, and to the making of low-threshold access to justice possible. Furthermore, it asks the Council to activate the passerelle clause, by adopting a unanimous decision identifying violence against women and girls as an area of crime listed in Article 83(1) TFEU.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour since I have no objections.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: in writing. - As a member of the liberal-conservative reformers, I am clearly opposed to any form of violence against women and support the positions of the Istanbul Convention in this regard. I am glad that Germany is one of the EU Member States that signed the Convention. I have expressed all this together with my group colleagues in an alternative ECR resolution. My abstention for the joint resolution is due to the fact that I respect national sovereignty and subsidiarity on this very important issue. It is not up to the EU to sign such an agreement on behalf of its Member States, irrespective of the accuracy of its content.

name: Филиз Хюсменова (ALDE)
text: in writing. Dear President, I support the EU's call for accession to the Istanbul Convention on preventing and combating violence against women and for its ratification by more Member States. The Istanbul Convention is the first instrument in Europe to establish a comprehensive legal framework to prevent and combat violence against women and domestic violence. It represents a call for more gender equality, which cannot be achieved while statistics show that one in three women in Europe has been the victim of physical violence at least once in their lives. This is a serious form of violation of fundamental rights caused by inequality between women and men. Among the solutions proposed by the Convention are the creation of accessible and protected sites for victims of violence, as well as the establishment of specialised help centres and a telephone line. I believe that broad awareness of the problem and accurate information will contribute to the proper and effective implementation of the Convention.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written. - I voted for the Motion for a Resolution on the EU's accession to the Istanbul Convention on the Prevention and Combating Violence Against Women, as violence against women and gender-based violence continues to be widespread within the EU on which the eradication needs to be effectively worked out. Gender equality is one of the EU's core values, and as a strategic objective, is crucial for achieving the overall objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy in the area of growth, employment and social inclusion. I supported this proposal which guarantees a harmonised European legal framework for the prevention and fight against violence against women, and in addition to better monitoring, interpretation and enforcement of EU laws, programmes and funds relevant to the Convention.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: I consider that the European Union has no diplomatic legitimacy to ratify such a convention and that this undermines, as usual, the sovereignty of the Member States. The ECR Group's motion for a resolution defends this sovereignty by simply reminding States of their responsibility in combating all forms of violence, including against men. So I voted against it.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report by my colleagues Anna Maria Corazza Bildt and Barbara Matera on EU accession to the Istanbul Convention. Adopted in 2011, the Convention establishes minimum standards for the protection of violence against women and aims to better protect victims by ensuring that perpetrators are properly prosecuted. This accession is not symbolic, it sends a genuine commitment by the European Union and parliamentarians to defend women's rights. With this accession, the Union will be able to encourage European countries to transmit data on violence against women and thus better combat this scourge. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution, which aims to urge Member States to ratify the Istanbul Convention on Preventing and Combating Violence against Women. The European Union must be a part of this first European tool to set legally binding standards to prevent gender-based violence, protect victims of violence and punish perpetrators.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution. All forms of violence against women and girls are strongly condemned here. It is also rightly noted that women are disproportionately affected by violence and abuse. Here, the political will of the Member States of the European Union to identify acts of violence against women will be an important measure to fight against them.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: in writing. - As a member of the liberal-conservative reformers, I am clearly opposed to any form of violence against women and support the positions of the Istanbul Convention in this regard. I am glad that Germany is one of the EU Member States that signed the Convention. I have expressed all this together with my group colleagues in an alternative ECR resolution. My abstention for the joint resolution is due to the fact that I respect national sovereignty and subsidiarity on this very important issue. It is not up to the EU to sign such an agreement on behalf of its Member States, irrespective of the accuracy of its content.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — It was my pleasure, together with my colleagues, to present a resolution on EU accession to the Istanbul Convention on the Prevention and Combating Violence Against Women. I believe that this is a very serious subject, as the statistics are truly formidable. Violence against women and violence based on gender is still a widespread phenomenon in the EU, given the European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights's 2014 survey on violence against women indicates that one third of all women in Europe have experienced physical or sexual acts of violence at least once in their adult lives, 20% of young women (aged 18—29 years) have encountered online harassment, one-fifth of women (18%) have encountered dangerous persecution (stalking), one-twentieth have been raped and more than a tenth have encountered sexual violence characterized by failure to show consent on their part or use of force. This survey also explains that most violent acts are not reported to the authorities, which shows that in addition to administrative statistics, they have a full picture of different types of violence committed on women the fundamental importance of the victimization inquiry. So I voted in favour of the resolution, further measures are needed to encourage women who are victims of violence to make their experience known and seek help.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against since we need a more immediate and effective instrument to fight against domestic violence than spending time and efforts in monitoring the Istanbul Convention ratification and most importantly implementation of the Istanbul Convention. Instead, we should work on drafting an EU directive on domestic violence.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: in writing. - I support the resolution on the EU's accession to the Istanbul Convention on preventing and combating violence against women. In the Treaties and the Charter of the European Union, gender equality is a fundamental value. We must not forget that the right to equal treatment and non-discrimination is a fundamental right. I stand firmly behind EU policy and the long-term action taken on violence against women and girls and the elimination of all forms of discrimination against them.

name: Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz (PPE)
text: in writing. — I support the resolution on the accession of the European Union as a party to the Council of Europe Convention on the Prevention and Combating Violence Against Women and Domestic Violence. This document, signed by 43 countries and ratified by 15, in 2013 at the United Nations session in New York was considered the gold standard of anti-overdrive policy. The main advantage of this convention, in addition to legislation on assisting victims of violence, as well as recognizing and punishing acts of violence for them, is the chapter on prevention. He says that the key to preventing violence is promoting equality, disseminating knowledge about women's rights, both among school youth and adult women and men. There is also talk about the dissemination of equality and sex education and corrective workshops for perpetrators of violence in order to prevent the repetition of preventative behavior. The Convention speaks of inclusion in the fight against violence of men because their impact on perpetrators of violence is very efficient and effective. I believe that this convention, as a vehicle for an effective, modern approach to the subject of violence, should be ratified as soon as possible in all EU countries, so I welcome the decision of the European Commission to join the EU-wide Convention. I am also proud that Poland is among the countries that have ratified the Convention and whose legislation is almost 100% coincident with the requirements of this important document.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Sadly, violence against women (gender-based violence) continues to happen everywhere, in every society and EU country, regardless of social background, whether at home, at work, at school, in the street or online. The EU tries to prevent it by protecting women and children through legislation and practical measures on victims’ rights; by co-funding campaigns run by national governments and non-government organisations; by organising exchanges of good practices among EU countries and by raising awareness about the phenomenon of gender-based violence. Unfortunately, little progress has been made in combating gender-based violence. I supported the resolution because we should welcome the EU’s decision to join the Istanbul Convention on preventing and combating violence against women and domestic violence, the first legally binding instrument at international level. The Istanbul Convention leaves no doubt: there can be no real equality between women and men if women experience gender-based violence on a large-scale and state agencies and institutions turn a blind eye. Importantly, the EU’s accession to the Istanbul Convention will enhance the EU’s accountability and its role in combating violence against women and gender-based violence on the international stage.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: I voted in favour of this resolution, because it recalls that ratification and application of this Convention are the sovereignty of the Member States.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: 25 November is the international day dedicated to combating violence against women. By tabling an oral question to the Council and the Commission, as well as this resolution, of which I am the co-author, we have wished to draw attention to this scourge, which spares no European country, an absolute shame. Of course, I voted in favour of this resolution, urging the European Union and all its Member States to ratify rapidly the Council of Europe Convention on preventing and combating violence against women and domestic violence. Beyond ratification by the Member States (half have not yet done so), it seems important to me that the European Union sends a strong signal to attest to its involvement. For example, the Convention makes it mandatory to introduce legislation criminalizing violence against women and providing for strong penalties against aggressors. It also implies that countries have strengthened budgetary and human resources to set up shelters and shelters for abused women, and to increase awareness in order to change behaviour.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the resolution on EU accession to the Istanbul Convention on Preventing and Combating Violence against Women. The Council of Europe Convention on Preventing and Combating Violence against Women is an international treaty adopted on 11 May 2011 in Istanbul. The purpose of this Convention is to eradicate all gender-based violence that leads to physical, sexual, psychological or economic harm or suffering for women. It imposes a binding legal framework for signatory States to prohibit forced marriage, female genital mutilation, coerced sterilization and sexual harassment.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: in writing. — Although the objective of this resolution is commendable, I consider that the European Union has no diplomatic legitimacy to ratify such a convention that it would impose on the Member States, to whom the decision should be taken. The European Union would once again override its rights and undermine the sovereignty of States, which is why I voted against the resolution.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: in writing. - As a member of the liberal-conservative reformers, I am clearly opposed to any form of violence against women and support the positions of the Istanbul Convention in this regard. I am glad that Germany is one of the EU Member States that signed the Convention. I have expressed all this together with my group colleagues in an alternative ECR resolution. My abstention for the joint resolution is due to the fact that I respect national sovereignty and subsidiarity on this very important issue. It is not up to the EU to sign such an agreement on behalf of its Member States, irrespective of the accuracy of its content.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: written. - Gender equality is a strategic objective key to achieving the overall objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy in the area of growth, employment and social inclusion. I consider violence against women to be a violation of fundamental rights and a serious criminal offence. We should fight violence against women by all means and to achieve full equality, but I have refrained from voting given the gender ideology that this report abounds, and which should by no means be a place.

name: Светослав Христов Малинов (PPE)
text: in writing. - On 24 November 2016, we called on the Council of the EU and the European Commission with an overwhelming majority to speed up negotiations and the final signing of the Istanbul Convention on preventing and combating violence against women. The Convention is the first instrument in Europe to establish a legal framework for preventing and combating violence against women and domestic violence in general. We must make it clear that such aggression is a serious violation of fundamental human rights and is a manifestation of gender discrimination, which we cannot allow to happen on a similar scale on our continent. According to the data from the aforementioned Convention, every third woman from the European Union has been a victim of violence at least once in her life. One of the main problems with preventing and preventing this type of crime is its difficult proving, due to the refusal by victims to share about it. I am convinced that we need to do more to resolve this pan-European problem and encourage victims to speak up in such violence, and, above all, to ensure their protection and the prevention of this type of aggression.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Convention will not fulfil its main task – to stop violence against women – if state authorities do not adopt supporting amendments in their legislation, and police, judges and other institutions do not ensure its realisation. I think it is important to share good practices between the Member States, because we do not need just talk about stopping violence against women, but real results.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing — All the advanced, democratic and modern countries of the world have naturally enshrined provisions in their legal order forming part of the Istanbul Convention on the prevention and fight against violence against women. If the governments of countries fully respect and implement these standards, exploit and implement good experience from other countries, take precautionary measures and ensure a rigorous and timely investigation of any violence and its proper legal punishment, they will do more than any statements and calls on this issue . Punishments must correspond to the evil performed, otherwise they lose their educational and preventive character.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing. - I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution on the accession of the European Union to the Istanbul Convention on Preventing and Combating Violence Against Women, for the reasons I explained in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg of 23 November 2016, as well as because this motion for a resolution is complete and documented.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: in writing. - I am in favour of all measures to combat violence against women and I agree with this resolution. These measures must be given a legal basis, as is required by this resolution by reinviting Member States that have not yet ratified the Convention.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour. I welcome the EU's accession to the Istanbul Convention on the Prevention and Combating of Violence Against Women. EU accession will ensure a coherent European legal framework to prevent, combat and protect victims of violence against women and gender-based violence. It will also ensure greater coherence, effectiveness of EU internal and external policies, and better implementation of EU legislation, programmes and funds related to the Convention.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: This 25 November marks the UN International Day for the Elimination of Violence Against Women. The 2011 Council of Europe Istanbul Convention is the first legally binding international instrument in this area. This resolution encourages the 14 Member States that have not yet done so to ratify it. It is a strong symbol because it requires the same rights to all in Europe, citizens, residents and refugees and asylum seekers. The resolution also calls for the top-level harmonization of statistics on violence against women, since some countries do not refer to certain types of violence. It also stresses the lack of adequate financial and human resources for the prevention and inclusion of gender equality in all public policies. I vote for.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: in writing. — The joint motion for a resolution calls on the Council and the European Commission to speed up negotiations with a view to acceding to the Istanbul Convention. It therefore calls on all Member States to ratify the Convention and allocate adequate financial resources to effectively combat violence against women. Moreover, this motion for a resolution emphasizes the protection of refugees and women seeking asylum. We consider that the European Union has no diplomatic legitimacy to ratify such a convention. This is once again an attack on the sovereignty of the Member States which will now be forced to ratify it. I therefore opposed this resolution. On the other hand, I expressed my support for the ECR motion for a resolution, which recalls that the ratification and application of this Convention is the sovereignty of the Member States.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: Gender equality is a fundamental value of the EU, enshrined in the Treaties and the Charter of Fundamental Rights, which the EU has committed itself to incorporating into all its activities. Gender equality is decisive, as a strategic objective, in achieving the overall goals of the Europe 2020 strategy for growth, jobs and social inclusion. The Istanbul Convention is the first legally binding instrument at international level for preventing and combating violence against women. I therefore agree with the EU's accession to the Convention. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion calling for EU accession to the Istanbul Convention because women who have fallen victim to violent acts must have access to better protection across Europe. One in every three women in the EU has experienced the trauma of physical or sexual violence, or both. This is unacceptable.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Istanbul Convention on preventing and combating violence against women is the first legally binding instrument in Europe on violence against women and in terms of scope it is the most far reaching international treaty to tackle violence against women as a serious violation of human rights. Three years after its opening for signatures in 2011, the Istanbul convention was entered into force on 1 August 2014. Today, all EU MS have signed the convention, but only 14 have ratified it. Therefore, I have voted in favour of this important report, which calls on Member States to ratify the Istanbul Convention.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. — The ECR Group is autonomous and the PPE, S&D, ALDE, GUE/NGL and Verts/ALE Groups have tabled a joint motion for a resolution. I voted for the latter.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: This joint motion for a resolution calls on the Council and the European Commission to speed up negotiations to accede to the Istanbul Convention on preventing and combating violence against women. They also call on all Member States to ratify the Istanbul Convention and allocate adequate financial resources to effectively combat violence against women. Moreover, this motion for a resolution emphasizes the protection of refugees and women seeking asylum. We consider that the European Union has no diplomatic legitimacy to ratify such a convention. This is once again an attack on the sovereignty of the Member States which will now be forced to ratify it.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: in writing. - Only States can legitimately ratify or not ratify a convention. I am voting against this text.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this text on EU accession to the Istanbul Convention on the Prevention and Combating of Violence Against Women. While all the countries of the Union have signed this text, not all countries have ratified it yet. The accession of the European Union as such will send a strong signal to countries that have not yet ratified this text at a time when, according to WHO, 30% of women are victims of domestic violence worldwide.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I fully support the motion for a resolution on the EU's accession to the Istanbul Convention on the Prevention and Elimination of Violence against Women and Domestic Violence, as it condemns and recognises all forms of violence against women and girls, that gender-based violence has a devastating effect on society as a whole.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this motion for a resolution regarding the EU’s accession to the Istanbul Convention that aims to protect women against all forms of violence and discrimination, and will promote substantive equality between women and men.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I voted for this report because it strongly condemns all forms of violence against women, which we also fought during the past tenure. I am deeply disappointed to see that violence against women continues to exist in many countries and takes multiple forms, such as physical, emotional abuse, threats, sexual abuse or use for manipulation of children or pets. Another important point in the report is the recognition of the essential work carried out by the various civil society organisations to prevent and combat violence against women, as well as to protect or assist victims of this type of violence. It is important to stress that, in this process of ending violence against women, assistance for both physical and mental recovery of victims is complementary to all prevention and combat strategies.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this motion. The appalling figures, which are increasing every year, should support all measures to combat violence against women.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported. Violence against women is a problem that concerns us all, given that every fourth woman suffers from violence against women in the EU. Violence against women is a large-scale human rights violation that the European Union must not bypass. EU Member States are all less or more regulated at legislative level to combat violence against women, but more can be done in many of these countries to protect women and bring criminals to justice. I am therefore pleased that the EU is joining the Istanbul Convention, which will allow harmonisation of relevant legislation at EU level and better statistics to be collected. It is extremely unfortunate that only 14 EU member states have ratified the Istanbul Convention so far. I also call on Estonia to move forward as soon as possible with the ratification process of the Istanbul Convention.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: in writing. Violence against women and gender violence continue to be widespread in the European Union. 33% of women in the European Union have experienced physical or even sexual violence since the age of 15. The European Union must act immediately. I voted in favour of the resolution calling on the Council and the Commission to speed up negotiations on the accession of the European Union to the Istanbul Convention, thereby ensuring a coherent European legislative framework for preventing and combating violence against women and gender violence and to protect victims of violence. Furthermore, the accession of the European Union will again put political pressure on the Member States to ratify this act. It is obvious that the European Union's efforts to eliminate violence against women and girls must be part of a comprehensive plan to combat all forms of gender inequalities. Through the resolution we are calling for a European Union strategy to combat violence against women and gender violence.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ I would vote in favour of the proposal because I believe that it is necessary to protect women's rights and to recognise equal rights, as it is set out in both the Community Treaties and the Charter of fundamental rights, that gender equality is a key value of the EU; its other key principle is non-discrimination. Unfortunately, violence against women is still a widespread phenomenon within the European Union, as a result the EU must protect women's rights and fight against them crimes, guaranteeing greater control to the protection of women. Therefore I would vote upvote.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. — 14 EU countries have not ratified the Istanbul Convention, among them Croatia. I therefore believe that instead of forcing the ratification of the Istanbul Convention, which is clearly not acceptable to everyone, an acceptable and effective solution should be found to combat violence against women. The only legally binding international act that so far contains the definition of gender is the Rome Statute and it explicitly states that gender refers to two sexes — male and female, however the Istanbul Convention adopts a completely different definition. Therefore, one other question is rightly raised: namely, if the EU ratifies the convention and with it becomes a part of the European legislation things that have not been so far — specifically the definition of gendered gender — that means that we will have to change the treaties and introduce this definition which is neither natural nor acceptable, and which will ultimately violate the rights of parents to raise their own children. This will also seek harmonisation of parts of national legislation and enter into the criminal legislation of the Member States. It is true that the Istanbul Convention brings with it many useful provisions that could really help victims of violence, but most of these positive measures already exist in the laws of the Member States.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ The European Parliament with this resolution, of which I am also among the signatories, supports the Commission and calls on the Council to quickly complete the process for EU accession to the Convention of Istanbul on the prevention and fight against violence against women. This is not a formal act: adhering to the Istanbul Convention means having the opportunity to allocate resources and to implement concrete measures to prevent gender-based violence. A few weeks ago I was in Calabria, to support a young woman forced to grow up quickly on bread, prejudice and fear.
