To support a 16-year-old girl who has been raped by a pack of nine boys since she was 13, in the silence of the community. Violence is not a private fact, but an evil to weed out, even when, as it happens in most cases, it happens in the family. To win this battle we need everyone, institutions, men and women and with this membership the EU would take a fundamental step forward. Parliament supports this position with a very large majority, and we hope that the Council will also find agreement on this as soon as possible.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: written. — 45% of all women in Europe were victims of gender violence. It has a huge impact on them and represents a great wound of our societies. A wound that we can't ignore anymore. Violence against women is too often considered a private issue and very easily tolerated. It is necessary to encourage women who are victims of violence to report what happened and seek help and ensure that providers can meet the needs of victims and inform them of their rights and existing forms of support. Research on victimisation, along with administrative statistics, is critical to obtaining a full picture of various forms of violence against women. Gender equality is one of the EU's core values and as a strategic objective is key to achieving the overall objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy in the area of growth, employment and social inclusion. However, only fourteen members have ratified the Istanbul Convention. I therefore welcome the Commission's proposal to sign and end EU accession to the Convention. The EU accession will guarantee a harmonised European legal framework for preventing and combating violence against women and gender-based violence and for the protection of victims. I call on the Council and the Commission to accelerate negotiations on the signing and conclusion of the Istanbul Convention and to cooperate with Parliament and make great efforts to fulfil their obligations.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Violence against women remains a widespread reality and with dramatic figures in the EU. The resolution recommends the EU's rapid accession to the Istanbul Convention as an important instrument in combating and preventing violence against women. It also calls on Member States to ensure their proper implementation and to allocate adequate financial and human resources for preventing and combating violence against women and protecting victims. It is not surprising, in the context of the EP, that the resolution does not link what are right-wing policies, attacks on social and labour rights or the austerity policies that the EU has imposed, and the increase in inequalities, poverty and social exclusion, high levels of unemployment, insecurity at work and how these phenomena affect women particularly and contribute to the increase in sexual and domestic violence, or to the increase of prostitution networks and trafficking in human beings. This is a reality that simply signing a Convention will not result in results unless it is also accompanied by social policies at other levels of intervention, namely concrete policies to combat poverty and social exclusion. Nevertheless, we voted in favour.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: in writing. — I am in favour of firmly combating violence against women, and Poland is the country with one of the lowest rates of this type of crime. At the same time, Poland cannot support a resolution that calls on the EU to join the Istanbul Convention and establish its own piece of legislation. Every EU state has laws to combat violence and additional provisions won't change anything. By contrast, they enter the competence of the States. I hereby did not support the resolution.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. — On the eve of the International Day against Violence Against Women, I voted in favour of this resolution to encourage EU accession to the Istanbul Convention on Preventing and Combating Violence Against Women. In Europe, one in three women has already been subjected to physical or sexual violence during her lifetime, it is our responsibility to ensure that this scourge ceases. This accession will allow us to improve the protection of victims and to further condemn aggressors.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D)
text: in writing. - Every other day, seven women are killed in Europe and one in three women is victims of physical and/or sexual violence at least once a lifetime. These figures are shocking, and action is urgently needed now. The Council of Europe's Istanbul Convention on preventing and combating violence against women and domestic violence in the EU has been signed by all 28 EU Member States, but only half have ratified so far. The expressions of the Member States alone are no longer sufficient here. Nor is it enough to point out the violence against women every year on 25 November, but to forget them for the remaining 364 days. The European Commission must also take action to ensure that a directive on the EU-wide protection of women against violence takes shape throughout Europe. Within the EU, there is still no comprehensive legislation to protect women from violence.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted in favour of the first ECR resolution and abstained on the second compromise resolution. Both were non-legislative and non-binding. The Istanbul Convention is a (non-EU) international convention that will create some legally binding and non-legislative measures which countries who ratify will have to bring in to national law. The UK is in the process of ratifying the Convention in its own right. UKIP voted in favour of the first ECR resolution as the wording was much better than the compromise resolution because it stressed: ‘that it is the sovereign right of a Member State to ratify and implement the Convention and its provisions’. UKIP abstained on the second compromise resolution because although on the one hand it called on the EU to sign up to Convention in its own right (UKIP cannot legitimise the EU signing up to international agreements in its own right) – on the other hand we don’t want to appear opposed to fighting violence against women.

name: Christine Revault D'Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D)
text: gender-based violence, which is widespread within the European Union, is often tolerated and rarely punished. In order to break the law of silence and give a voice to all victims, Parliament adopted a strong resolution reminding the urgency of addressing violence against women and girls. Fighting such violence means working towards equality between women and men. To that end, it is important both to prevent violence, protect victims and prosecute those responsible, with adequate resources, mobilized at all levels of society. The Istanbul Convention, a binding international treaty, takes this comprehensive approach. The Union's accession to this Convention will be a first step towards advancing the fight against violence against women. Beyond ratification, a European directive is the essential next step in strengthening the implementation of the Convention. In this context, I will continue to commit myself to ensuring that abortion can become a fundamental right recognised and protected by the Union. Denying this right is a violation of human rights and a marked violence against women. I regret that the text voted on ignores this reality.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. - Equality between women and men is a fundamental value of the EU and its Member States. Despite this, reality does not always reflect this commitment. While the European Parliament has played an important role in raising awareness of equality between women and men and women, it is the Member States that have clearly prevented the adoption of more ambitious targets in terms of human rights legislation. The myth of 'progressively acquired equality', which is still deeply entrenched in Europe, prevents equality from becoming an effective goal in the EU. If certain measures have been taken in one area or another, the lack of an overall strategy shows that gender equality is not taken seriously enough. Stereotypes and discrimination persist in all spheres of society. Signing and ratifying the Istanbul Convention is a necessary, albeit not sufficient measure, to try to counteract this state of affairs and raise awareness of changing mentalities. We need a legally binding instrument to prevent violence against women and put an end to it. Violence against women must not remain invisible and undervalued. The lack of harmonised laws and policies has significant consequences for women's resilience and survival.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: in writing. — In coincidence with the International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women on 25 November 2016, I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the accession of the European Union to the Istanbul Convention on Preventing and Combating Violence against Women. This resolution is part of the EU's objective of promoting equality between women and men and taking measures in favour of it. The EU's accession to this Convention will ensure a coherent European legal framework to prevent and combat violence against women and gender-based violence and to protect victims.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. - The question of EU accession to the Istanbul Convention on Combating Violence Against Women seems to be one of the least controversial. I am convinced that the EU, as a value community, does not have the right to depart from this issue and must become a party to this treaty.

name: Virginie Rozière (S&D)
text: in writing. - I supported this resolution calling for the early accession of the European Union to the Istanbul Convention. Violence against women remains a worrying reality in all Member States. In this context, the Union must accede as soon as possible to the Istanbul Convention, the first legally binding international instrument on preventing and combating violence against women. However, discussions on the subject in the Council are continuing. This resolution increases pressure on Member States to ratify the Convention and urges the Council to reach an agreement as soon as possible. It highlights the added value of the Union's accession to the Convention: measures to prevent and combat violence against women will be more uniform at European level, and action on gender equality, anti-discrimination and public health will be strengthened. Moreover, EU accession to the Convention will ensure better data collection on the extent and nature of violence against women. This resolution is a strong political message and a further step in the fight against gender-based violence.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. - The European Commission has announced a campaign to combat violence against women for 2017. One in three women has been the victim of gender-based violence during their lifetime. Although 96% of Europeans are aware that domestic violence is unacceptable, 27% still consider that sexual relations without consent may be justified in certain circumstances, according to a recent Eurobarometer survey. This motion for a resolution is in line with Article 2 TFEU and the Charter of Fundamental Rights, where the EU is responsible for ensuring, promoting and intervening in favour of gender equality, reinforcing the importance of EU accession to the Istanbul Convention with a view to adopting a European legal framework in preventing and combating gender-based violence. The resolution also aims to ensure better monitoring, interpretation and enforcement of EU legislation, programmes and funds relevant to the Convention, by enhancing accountability at international level. At the same time, we should not overlook the importance of the EU creating a strategy to combat violence against women and be part of a comprehensive plan to combat gender inequalities.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: I voted in favour of this resolution, which urges the European Union to accede to the Council of Europe Istanbul Convention on Preventing and Combating Violence against Women. A few days before the International Day to Combat Violence Against Women, it was crucial that the European Union demonstrate its commitment and determination to combat all forms of violence against women by acceding to this Convention. Accession to this Convention will enable the Union to collect comparable and up-to-date data from Member States on violence against women in order to combat violence against women more effectively. It is unacceptable that today, in Europe, one in three women has already been subjected to violence during her lifetime. It is crucial that the European Union and the Member States commit themselves fully to combat this scourge, protect victims and combat the silence surrounding this violence.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ 25 November was marked by the United Nations as the International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women, which remains a widespread phenomenon in the Union. So far, the Istanbul Council of Europe Convention is the largest international agreement addressing violence against women and girls and gender-based violence from a holistic perspective. In March 2016, the Commission proposed that the Union accede to the Istanbul Convention. All Member States of the Union have signed it, but only 14 have ratified it. The oral question addressed to the Council and the Commission, as well as the JMR, aims to accelerate accession to the Convention and to convince Member States that have not ratified it as soon as possible, to know the status of the negotiation of the signature, the actions that the Presidency has taken to expedite the signature, the time required to conclude the accession of the Union to the Convention and the role of the European Parliament in monitoring the Convention. I think these are positive proposals and I therefore voted in favour.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on the accession of the EU to the Istanbul Convention on preventing and combating violence against women. The Istanbul Convention covers a wide range of measures, including legal measures to criminalise various forms of violence. It is the first instrument in Europe to set legally binding standards to prevent gender-based violence.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: in writing. — The International Day Against Violence Against Women, which marks 25 November, should remind us again that violence against women is not only a marginal issue, but concerns millions Women — physical or directly sexual violence was experienced by every third woman during her lifetime. I therefore hope that the European Union will accede to the Istanbul Convention as soon as possible.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution, as it urges the Union and its Member States to accede to the Istanbul Convention on Prevention and Combating Violence against Women. Unfortunately, despite the fact that all the Member States of the Union have signed it, only 14 have ratified it. This is very serious, since a decisive reaction from the Union is essential to end sexist violence once and for all. Every second account, and, we need the European Commission and the States to agree and take this problem seriously with real political will. The Convention recognizes violence against women as a violation of human rights and is undoubtedly an enormous step that the Union must take to take political and judicial measures against sexist violence, in the face of the very serious events as in the Spanish State where 39 women have been murdered at the hands of their abusers that we have been this year.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I wholeheartedly support any move that would improve the situation between men and women. No one deserves to be a victim of violence. But instead of tackling the root causes of violence, the Istanbul convention bullies sovereign Member States to give over their judicial powers to a non-EU body (Council of Europe), in the vain hope that some forced group line would solve the problem. Women need help, but that won’t come through the EU forcing its Member States to give over their power to the Council of Europe. A better plan should be made.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: written. — The Istanbul Convention on the Prevention and Combat Against Violence Against Women is the first legally binding instrument of this type at international level, and defines the concept of violence as all acts of physical, sexual, psychological and economic violence occurring in the family between partners. All member states signed the Istanbul Convention, but half have not yet ratified it — among others Croatia. The accession of the European Union to the Istanbul Convention will provide greater efficiency and coherence in implementing measures that would contribute to the prevention of violence across Europe, while also ensuring better implementation of EU legislation, programmes and funds established to that end. This will contribute to the wider EU objectives in the area of gender equality, combating discrimination, public health and economic growth, and enhance the accountability of the EU as well as its role in combating violence against women and gender-based violence internationally. For the above reasons, I absolutely support the resolution of the European Parliament and hereby appeal for accession to the Istanbul Convention as quickly as possible, as well as the ratification of the Republic of Croatia so that equality between women and men is one of the fundamental values of the European Union emphasised in treaties and in the charter, protect and in the form of gender-conditioned violence.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing - Gender equality, together with the right to equal treatment and non-discrimination, constitute fundamental rights and values that are rooted in European society. In December 2015, the EU Presidency Trio, the Netherlands, Slovakia and Malta, agreed to speed up the adoption of the necessary measures to combat violence against women and girls. The issue of violence against women causes considerable societal but also economic damage. The EU's estimated cost of violence against women and gender-motivated violence for 2011amounts to €228 billion. I supported the resolution on accession to the Istanbul Convention because it applies a comprehensive approach to the issue of violence against women and girls. It focuses on preventing, combating discrimination, protecting children or criminal law measures to combat the impunity of violence, which is often tolerated in society, in fact a serious crime. The EU calls on Member States to ratify the Convention and to allocate sufficient resources to prevent and combat violence. At the same time, the proposal calls on the Commission to adopt a legal act ensuring a system for collecting statistics as well as a strengthened approach by Member States to the issue. It is necessary for the Commission, together with the Council, to speed up negotiations on the signing and conclusion of the Istanbul Convention and for the EU Presidency trio to accelerate the process.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: in writing. — In the European Parliament today, I voted in favour of adopting a motion for a resolution of the European Parliament concerning the accession of the EU to the Istanbul Convention on the Prevention and Prevention of Violence women and domestic violence. The EU should support Member States in their efforts and measures to deal with violence against women. Within the EU, the number of cases of sexual and domestic violence, whose victims are predominantly women, is not falling. I therefore welcome the legislative guarantees to combat violence against women provided for in the Istanbul Convention and its associated commitment to the adoption of practical measures. I have some reservations about the terminology that is fixed by this convention and further allows its use for so-called gender ideology. I understand gender equality as gender equality, and in that sense I support those measures that fulfill the concept. I think we should fight against every violence, against violence against children, including unborn children, on seniors, in short, every violence is evil. That is why I voted against the part of the resolution which calls for the definition of crime involving violence against women at European Union level and the substance of fact to be invoked into the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU, stating that legislation can be adopted in this area. I consider such a measure redundant and disproportionate to extend the powers of the European Union, since the Istanbul Convention itself is already a sufficient guarantee.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: in writing. - As a member of the liberal-conservative reformers, I am clearly opposed to any form of violence against women and support the positions of the Istanbul Convention in this regard. I am glad that Germany is one of the EU Member States that signed the Convention. I have expressed all this together with my group colleagues in an alternative ECR resolution. My abstention for the joint resolution is due to the fact that I respect national sovereignty and subsidiarity on this very important issue. It is not up to the EU to sign such an agreement on behalf of its Member States, irrespective of the accuracy of its content.

name: Jaromír Štětina (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of a resolution demanding that the EU accede to the Istanbul Convention concerning the prevention and prevention of violence against women and domestic violence. It is a Council of Europe convention covering all kinds of violence, including psychological violence. So-called. The Istanbul Convention is a key and at the same time the first legally binding international document that establishes the legal framework for the Contracting States. The aim of the document is zero tolerance for violence against women. The Convention introduces definitions of related crimes and calls for their criminalization. It sets penalties for perpetrators and measures to prevent violence and to help its victims. The Czech Republic is a signatory country to the Convention, but it has not been ratified together with many other countries of Europe. I hope that changes soon. In the Czech Republic alone, according to a 2014 survey by the EU Human Rights Agency, 32% of women over the age of 15 experienced physical or sexual violence. On the Union scale, it was 22%, which is not exactly a commendable result compared to the global 30%. I therefore appreciate the efforts of the EP and the Commission, headed by Commissioner Jourova, to adopt the Convention by the EU as a whole. Fighting violence against women should be a common theme to address. I believe that by working together and committing to common standards in this area, we would make tangible progress.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: in writing. - The EU, like a state, should accede to the Council of Europe Convention on Preventing and Combating Violence against Women and Domestic Violence (“Istanbul Convention”). The refusal of violence against women is a matter of course. No convention is needed for this. The rabbit lies somewhere else in the pepper. The Convention makes it compulsory that “gender” is a social construct: “The term “gender” refers to the societal roles, behaviour, activities and characteristics that a particular society considers appropriate for women and men” (Article 3 (c). And the Convention must be implemented without regard to biological or social sex, sexual orientation or gender identity (Art. 4.3). All MEPs of the CDU/CSU — except one —, FDP, SPD, Greens and Left have voted in favour. You can no longer rely on the politicians of the CDU and CSU. They too are now voting for gender ideology.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: written. — The Istanbul Convention represents a comprehensive international treaty on combating violence against women and domestic violence. In March 2016, the European Commission proposed that the European Union ratify the Council of Europe's Istanbul Convention. Every third woman in the EU has suffered physical and/or sexual violence. More than half of women since they were 15 have experienced sexual harassment. These figures are unacceptable. EU accession to the convention will encourage better EU-wide data collection on violence against women and the unification of legislation within the EU of members. The convention insists on protecting victims and prosecuting perpetrators. The Convention has been signed by all EU members and calls for ratification as quickly as possible in national parliaments by those Member States that have not yet done so. I support this Resolution, which is being voted on on the eve of the International Day against Violence Against Women. Victims of violence must be provided with assistance, and perpetrators should be punished. Women who are victims of violence need to be better protected in Europe.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: in writing. The Istanbul Convention recognises violence against women as a violation of human rights, which cannot be called into question. In addition to information and raising awareness in a national and EU context, measures are needed to prevent violence, protect victims and prosecute perpetrators.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Continuous social dialogue on violence against women is of paramount importance, as every third woman in Europe experiences these horrors. I therefore consider this motion for a resolution important and voted in favour of it. In addition to physical and sexual violence mainly occurring within families, psychological and economic violations against women are also general problems in Hungary. The statistics available in this field are not reliable, as their accuracy is largely determined by whether the stakeholders dare to talk about it, what they regard as violence at all. Along with what is stated in the motion, I welcome the Commission's proposal to sign and sanction the accession of the Union to the Istanbul Convention (because the Convention is a joint agreement which allows the accession of the Union in parallel with the accession of the Member States). At the same time, the negotiations within the Council are not moving at the same speed and I draw attention to the fact that the accession of the Union to the Istanbul Convention does not exempt the Member States from ratifying the Convention. A lot about the attitude of the Orbán regime to women and children is said by the fact that the government has still refused to ratify the Istanbul Convention, which would make the introduction of measures aimed at resolving these problems binding. We must strive to create a social unity and trust that provides security for all, even if this is contrary to the will of the regimes.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: in writing. — Violence against women is not a private matter. This is a serious crime and still a huge problem in Europe. Too often unfortunately violence against women is tolerated and it should be our duty to join forces to combat impunity and protect victims. So it's time to build a culture of respect for the dignity of women and girls, fight stereotypes and focus on preventing them. Unfortunately, in the European Union, one in three women have experienced physical or sexual abuse during their lifetime. It is therefore pleased by the decision of the European Commission, which proposed in March 2016 that the Union as a whole join the Istanbul Convention on Prevention and Combat Violence Against Women. However, it should be stressed that still some countries in the Community have not acceded to the Convention. Hopefully this situation will change anytime soon.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. - Equality between women and men is one of the fundamental values of the European Union. Unfortunately, violence against women continues to be a widespread phenomenon within the Member States, affecting one third of all women in Europe. At the same time, studies show that there are also acts of domestic violence against men. This unacceptable situation requires a combination of actions related to infrastructure, the judiciary, law enforcement, cultural, social, educational and health systems at European level. The use of violence in human relations is a reprehensible practice and is related to an obsolete historical stage. As Members of the European Parliament, we have a duty to combat the use of violence by any means available, particularly within the family, where the negative effects are multiplied on all its members and, in particular, on children. Given that all Member States have signed the Istanbul Convention of the Council of Europe on Preventing and Combating Violence against Women and Domestic Violence and 14 have already ratified the Convention, it is recommended that the EU accede to this much-needed Convention and application of its provisions. I support the adoption of this resolution more than necessary.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. — As Friday is the International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women, the European Parliament reaffirms today its absolute support for the Istanbul Convention. The Convention is crucial, as it would be the first legally binding instrument in history to prevent and combat violence against women at the international level. However, 14 countries have still not ratified the text, delaying the implementation of life-saving measures. In Europe, almost one in three women are victims of physical or sexual violence at least once in her lifetime: doing nothing is to be accomplice!

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU’s accession to the Istanbul Convention will reinforce the EU’s commitment to combating violence against women, reinforce its credibility and accountability toward its international partners, and consolidate the EU’s actions targeting violence against women through a coordinated international effort with the exchange of data and documentation among signatory states. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on EU accession to the Istanbul Convention because I believe the EU must do everything in its power to promote and better the combat against violence against women, both within the EU, as well as in third countries.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: in writing. — 25 November is the World Day to Combat Violence Against Women. This day should be an occasion to recall that thousands of women are victims of violence every year. This ranges from street harassment to sexual assault, domestic violence and sometimes to murder. According to a report by the European Agency for Fundamental Rights published in 2014, nearly 67% of women estimated that they had been victims of violence in the past year. The European Union's accession to the Istanbul Convention was therefore expected. Its objective is to prevent violence, protect victims, and punish those responsible, by providing adequate and adequate resources to implement a set of actions. The vote on this resolution shows that violence against women affects not only women but society as a whole, which must engage strongly and urgently against this scourge. This accession is only the first step in a comprehensive policy.

name: Ivica Tolić (PPE)
text: written. - I did not support the European Parliament's proposal for a resolution on the accession of the EU to the Istanbul Convention on the Prevention and Combat Against Violence Against Women. I fully support the fight against violence against women and believe that the European Union and all its institutions must activate all instruments to reduce the scope of violence against women. However, although the title of the convention does not suggest this, its content in several places highlights the notion of genus, i.e. gender-conditioned violence. I am of the opinion that in implementing the protection of women, it is not necessary to highlight the notion of genus whose content contradicts my beliefs and my worldview. This is the reason I did not support the proposal for this resolution.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - I have supported the proposal for a resolution of the European Parliament on the accession of the EU to the Istanbul Convention on the Prevention of Violence Against Women on Combating it to Oral Response Questions B8.1805/2016 and B8-1806/2016 in accordance with Article 128 (5) of the Rules of Procedure. Gender equality is a fundamental value of the EU. The right to equal treatment and non-discrimination is a fundamental right. General violence against women remains widespread - a third of all women in Europe at least once in adult life victims of physical or sexual violence, according to data from the Fundamental Rights Agency's survey on violence against women and other research. Violence against women is taken too much as private, so it is necessary to raise awareness on this subject so that we can reduce violence.

name: Yana Toom (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Istanbul Convention obliges states to act against gender-based violence against women: to prevent it, to protect the victims and take measures against the perpetrators. As long as these necessary steps are taken, gender equality is not possible. All EU Member States have signed the Istanbul Convention, but only 18 have actually ratified it. This is a complete shame. The European Union should set an example by ensuring that all Member States stand against gender-based violence.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ 25 November was marked by the United Nations as the International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women, which remains a widespread phenomenon in the Union. So far, the Istanbul Council of Europe Convention is the largest international agreement addressing violence against women and girls and gender-based violence from a holistic perspective. In March 2016, the Commission proposed that the Union accede to the Istanbul Convention. All Member States of the Union have signed it, but only 14 have ratified it. The oral question addressed to the Council and the Commission, as well as the JMR, aims to accelerate accession to the Convention and to convince Member States that have not ratified it as soon as possible, to know the status of the negotiation of the signature, the actions that the Presidency has taken to expedite the signature, the time required to conclude the accession of the Union to the Convention and the role of the European Parliament in monitoring the Convention. I think these are positive proposals and I therefore voted in favour.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR)
text: in writing. - As a member of the liberal-conservative reformers, I am clearly opposed to any form of violence against women and support the positions of the Istanbul Convention in this regard. I am glad that Germany is one of the EU Member States that signed the Convention. I have expressed all this together with my group colleagues in an alternative ECR resolution. My abstention for the joint resolution is due to the fact that I respect national sovereignty and subsidiarity on this very important issue. It is not up to the EU to sign such an agreement on behalf of its Member States. It is also a pity that, despite many good elements, the report supports gender ideology.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: in writing. — The Council of Europe Convention on Preventing and Combating Violence against Women is an international treaty adopted on 11 May 2011 in Istanbul. The purpose of this Convention is to eradicate all gender-based violence that results in physical, sexual, psychological or economic harm or suffering of a physical, sexual, psychological or economic nature. It imposes a binding legal framework for signatory States to prohibit forced marriage, female genital mutilation, coerced sterilization and sexual harassment. The joint motion for a resolution calls on the Council and the European Commission to speed up negotiations for EU accession to this Convention. They also call on all Member States to ratify the Istanbul Convention and allocate adequate financial resources to effectively combat violence against women. Moreover, this motion for a resolution emphasizes the protection of refugees and women seeking asylum. We consider that the European Union has no diplomatic legitimacy to ratify such a convention. This is once again an attack on the sovereignty of the Member States which will now be forced to ratify it. I voted against this text.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: in writing. — The joint motion for a resolution received broad support from the entire Parliament. The joint text explicitly called on Member States to ratify (and transpose into national law) the provisions of the Istanbul Convention so that the EU can accede to that Convention as an international entity. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ 25 November was marked by the United Nations as the International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women, which remains a widespread phenomenon in the Union. So far, the Istanbul Council of Europe Convention is the largest international agreement addressing violence against women and girls and gender-based violence from a holistic perspective. In March 2016, the Commission proposed that the Union accede to the Istanbul Convention. All Member States of the Union have signed it, but only 14 have ratified it. The oral question addressed to the Council and the Commission, as well as the JMR, aims to accelerate accession to the Convention and to convince Member States that have not ratified it as soon as possible, to know the status of the negotiation of the signature, the actions that the Presidency has taken to expedite the signature, the time required to conclude the accession of the Union to the Convention and the role of the European Parliament in monitoring the Convention. I think these are positive proposals and I therefore voted in favour.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I strongly condemn all forms of violence against women and girls; I note that violence and violence are experienced by a disproportionate number of women.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the motions for a resolution further to Questions for Oral Answer B8 1805/2016 and B8 1806/2016 pursuant to Rule 128(5) of the Rules of Procedure on the EU accession to the Istanbul Convention on preventing and combating violence against women. Gender equality is a core value of the EU which the EU has committed to integrating into all its activities. The resolution emphasises that the EU accession will guarantee a coherent European legal framework to prevent and combat violence against women and gender-based violence and to protect the victims of violence. I voted in favour because I believe that gender equality is essential, as a strategic objective, to achieving the overall Europe 2020 objectives of growth, employment and social inclusion.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Istanbul Convention recognizes violence against women as a violation of human rights and as a form of discrimination. On the basis of these bases, its objectives are to prevent such violence, protect victims, prosecute perpetrators and raise awareness among society as a whole in this regard. It includes physical, psychological and sexual violence as serious crimes and introduces a number of new criminal offences, such as female genital mutilation or harassment. Here, the European Parliament intends to support the Commission's proposal launched in March for the Union's accession to the entire Convention. Despite the fact that the signing of the parties was opened in 2011, Latvia, the Czech Republic and Bulgaria have yet to comply with it, and more than ten Member States have not yet ratified it. In recognition of the importance of this Convention, which is the first binding European instrument on violence against women, in addition to the widest international treaty to address this grave violation of human rights, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution, as it urges the Union and its Member States to accede to the Istanbul Convention on Prevention and Combating Violence against Women. Unfortunately, despite the fact that all the Member States of the Union have signed it, only 14 have ratified it. This is very serious, since a decisive reaction from the Union is essential to end sexist violence once and for all. Every second account, and, we need the European Commission and the States to agree and take this problem seriously with real political will. The Convention recognizes violence against women as a violation of human rights and is undoubtedly an enormous step that the Union must take to take political and judicial measures against sexist violence, in the face of the very serious events as in the Spanish State where 39 women have been murdered at the hands of their abusers that we have been this year.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because it emphasises that the EU accession will guarantee a coherent European legal framework to prevent and combat violence against women and gender-based violence and to protect the victims of violence. It also stresses that it will provide greater coherence and efficiency in the EU’s internal and external policies, will ensure better monitoring, interpretation and implementation of EU laws, programmes and funds relevant to the Convention, as well as more adequate and better collection of comparable desegregated data on violence against women and gender-based violence at EU level, and will reinforce the EU’s accountability at international level.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. — A report by the European Agency for Fundamental Rights (FRA) indicates that in 2014, one third of women experienced sexual or physical violence at least once in their lives in the European Union. It is remembered that in France, a woman dies every three days under the blows of her husband or companion. And ordinary machismo, the source of all evil, has beautiful days before him. In March 2016, the Commission proposed the EU's accession to the Council of Europe's Istanbul Convention — the first binding legal instrument in this field — which takes a holistic approach to violence against women and gender-based violence. This resolution encourages Member States that have not yet done so (14!) to ratify the Convention and supports EU accession — which would at least allow harmonization of statistics on violence against women by forcing states to postpone all incidents and strengthen their prevention. This accession is welcome, even if it is insufficient: a European Framework Directive would be needed. However, this is a step in the right direction, so I voted in favour.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Gender equality and the right to equal treatment and non-discrimination are fundamental rights of the EU. The resolution points to relevant facts, it does not deliberately ignore the social and political conditions in which they occur. And we can see why: because the violation of rights increases with austerity policies, with the dismantling of the social functions of the state and the widening of inequality and poverty.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: in writing. - On 4 March 2016, the Commission proposed the accession of the EU to the Istanbul Convention, the first legally binding instrument for preventing and combating violence against women at international level. (All EU Member States signed it, but only 14 of them have ratified it.) Victims of violence against women must be better protected across Europe. According to a 2014 survey conducted by the European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights (FRA), one third of all women aged 15 and over the age of 15 — approximately 62 million — have been victims of physical and/or sexual violence (these types: mental, physical and sexual violence, stalking, female genital mutilation, Forced marriage, forced abortion, forced sterilization and abuse of women on the Internet). Parties to the Istanbul Convention must improve the protection of victims of violence and ensure the prosecution of offenders. Other objectives include gender equality and non-discrimination. The appalling figures should support all activities aimed at combating violence against women. Financial and human resources are required to act faster and more effectively. That is why I supported this motion.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the accession of the EU to the Istanbul Convention on the prevention and fight against violence against women. Considering that violence against women is still a widespread phenomenon in the EU and that one in three women has suffered physical or sexual violence at least once in adulthood, the resolution acknowledges that the consequences of gender-based violence are devastating. It must be remembered that all 28 Member States signed the Istanbul Convention of the Council of Europe and that 14 Member States ratified that convention. EU accession will ensure greater consistency and efficiency of the Union's internal and external policies, ensure better control, interpretation and implementation of legislation, programmes and of EU funds relating to the Convention.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ As this resolution says, EU accession will guarantee a coherent European legal framework to prevent and combat violence against women and gender-based violence and to protect the victims of violence. I welcome the Commission’s proposal for EU accession to the Istanbul Convention. The Council and the Commission must speed up the process, sign and ratify the Convention without reservations. Member States who have not ratified it yet, including the UK, must do so, and the Convention must be implemented at national and European levels. Gender—based violence must be tackled holistically, from the perspective of it being a human rights violation, a safety and security risk, a criminal issue, as well as a health, and culture and education issue. These issues must all be tackled in a concerted effort to eliminate the violence that so many women and LGBTI people face daily.

name: Lieve Wierinck (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I decided to vote in favour of this motion for resolution because as a liberal I’m a strong supporter of liberty and human rights. Every women has to be treated fairly and should get the same opportunities. All forms of violence against women and girls are unacceptable, and usually they suffer also mentally after the physical violence occurred. Gender—based violence is really at high levels, especially in the domestic environment. Any type of study aimed to preventing this violence to occur is of course very welcome. I believe that is very important for Member States to work together to share best practices and exchange effective ways of preventing violence and protecting men and women from gender-based violence.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: in writing. - I did not vote in favour of the resolution calling for EU accession to the Istanbul Convention of the Council of Europe. As I pointed out in my speech in the debate on this item of the agenda, the fight against violence against women is the exclusive competence of the Member States. Unlike my colleagues and colleagues, I believe that we are not adhering to the problem of discrimination against women against men by the state. Criminal law in all Member States does not make a difference between victims of violence according to their sex. We are dealing with the application of these laws in practice, the functioning of the police and the courts, but also how to effectively prevent violence and how to protect its victims, including the potential ones. Moreover, the Istanbul Convention would bring into the EU legal system a definition of the term 'gender', which neither the Treaties nor the Charter of Fundamental Rights know. This would open a broad gateway for enforcing identity-based policies. I am seriously concerned that it is this way of thinking that society polarizes because it allows the narrative “we” versus “they” to penetrate every policy area. Today, however, we need the exact opposite: to focus on what unites us as Europeans and citizens, rather than what divides us.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: in writing. — The resolution spares no wishful words about women's rights or reports of condemnation of violence against them. However, the current issue of violence against women that appears on the territory of exploitative relations in the resolution is cut off from it, and the fight against it is approached by the logic of 'cost-benefit'. It is defiantly estimated that violence against women in 2011 was “costing” EUR 228 billion, EUR 45 billion corresponds to the “cost” of state services and EUR 24 billion in “lost economic production”, which also employs monopolies. The resolution gives NGOs and 'civil society organisations', that is to say, even employers and all kinds of mechanisms, responsibility for information, while the European Union and civil governments are exempted from taking measures to relieve women of what is tormenting them, as well as there is no reference to it. The Parliamentary Group of the Communist Party of Greece, which for the above reasons was placed in white, notes that no tolerance should be given by the working class and grassroots strata to the phenomenon of violence. They need to fight with a view to a society without human being being being exploited, in which the conditions for tackling violence against women and for resolving female inequality will be established.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: in writing. — I consider violence against women to be a serious offence and one of the burning problems of contemporary society. Often violence against women is overlooked and it is therefore our duty to bring attention to the problem, focus on prevention and combat stereotypes. I therefore support the accession of the European Union to the Istanbul Convention, which requires its signatories to improve the system for protecting victims of violence, ensuring the prosecution of perpetrators or, for example, providing extended psychological help. In addition, the Convention should also improve the system of collecting information regarding various cases of violence, which will help to better understand and combat this phenomenon.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing. - I did not support the joint text of the resolution calling for the rapid accession of the European Union to the Istanbul Convention on the Prevention and Combating Violence Against Women. On the one hand, the Istanbul Convention deals with an extremely important topic, the topic of combating violence against women. Although there are a number of initiatives and laws, violence against women is, unfortunately, still a widespread phenomenon in the states of the European Union. And against him it is necessary to fight with all his strength. On the other hand, however, the Istanbul Convention not only contains a significant harmonisation of the criminal law of the Member States, thus interfering with the principle of subsidiarity, but, after a closer look at the legal aspects of the Convention, the question arises as to how the Convention can be properly and in accordance with European Union law implement. My second serious reservation as to why I did not support this report is that this convention is unsoundly zideologized. Therefore, I think that while every possible initiative needs to be taken to prevent violence against women, I do not regard the Istanbul Convention as the right instrument. That is why I decided to abstain in the final vote.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: I voted in favour of the resolution on EU accession to the Istanbul Convention because I agree with the need for urgent action by the EU to combat violence against women. I would stress that the Istanbul Convention is the first legally binding instrument in Europe on this type of violence and, in scope, is the most comprehensive international treaty in combating violence against women as a serious violation of human rights. Therefore, under the Convention, States are obliged to adopt legislation towards zero tolerance for violence against women. Gender violence is therefore no longer regarded as a private issue, and states will therefore be obliged to prevent violence, protect victims and punish perpetrators.

name: Željana Zovko (PPE)
text: written. - I support the proposal for a resolution on the accession of the European Union to the Istanbul Convention on the Prevention and Combating Violence Against Women, as this document introduces a whole range of new definitions that require systematic changes to fundamental Union treaties and national laws. Without challenging the importance of existing efforts in combating and combating violence not only against women, but also against men, minority groups, refugees, asylum seekers and migrants, I believe that this resolution, but also the convention itself concretizes to a new extent the very instruments and mechanisms of protecting women and men from psychological, physical and sexual violence and establish credible elements of monitoring the implementation of the provisions of the convention at Member State level. In addition, the general position on violence reduction and zero tolerance towards all forms of violence is already embedded in the fundamental treaties and constitutional texts of the Member States. It is necessary to systematically implement an individualized approach to a particular problem and to combat it through the development of awareness of the harm of violence and through an educational process that must be aimed at accepting mutual differences that are characteristic of male and female members.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the European Parliament's resolution on the EU's accession to the Istanbul Convention on the Prevention of Violence between Women and the fight against them. The right to equal treatment and non-discrimination is a decisive fundamental right recognised in the Treaties on European Union. It is deeply entrenched in European society and is indispensable for the further development of society, and must apply in law, practice, case-law and in everyday life. The Strategy calls on Member States to ensure proper enforcement of the Convention and adequate financial and personnel resources to prevent and combat violence against women and violence on the basis of sex, and to protect victims.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: — I generally support the work of the European Ombudsman and think that the Ombudsman belongs to the concept of the rule of law and the concept of protecting the rights of the citizen against public authority. On the other hand, I ultimately did not support this report and I held back, for one simple reason, that is why I also come out with an explanation. The report is not just about what the ombudsman or ombudswoman held in the last year 2015, so it is not simply a description of the facts. I would have imagined the message. But there are a number of things in the report that go towards the fact that the position of this public authority should be changed. There should be a strengthening of the powers of the ombudsman, and some amendments have passed, which lead to the fact that the position of the notifier should also be changed, i.e. those who took the ombudsman flipping. I think these things are not meant to be the subject of an annual report on what the ombudsman has been doing in the last year. That's why I eventually abstained, and the abstention is unrelated to the ombudsman and is not against the authority itself.

name: Peter Jahr (PPE).
text: Mr President! I said in the debate this morning that the rapporteur on the Ombudsman's annual report could not resist the temptation to overload the report politically. He has therefore brought in things that are still in the European Parliament's decision-making process. It is true that we still need agreements on the European Central Bank, the Eurogroup, the ESM, the transparency offensive and also on whistleblower protection and conflict of interest. We should discuss this politically and then decide. He overloaded this report. However, after the vote, I can say that we have succeeded — and many thanks also to my fellow Members — in virtually purifying the report and to trim it to its original form. That is why, once again, thank all colleagues and, of course, a thank you to the Ombudsman, who has truly become an indispensable institution in the European Parliament. That is why I was finally able to vote in favour of the report.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ This report analyses the activity of the European Ombudsman, Emily O'Really, during 2015. Overall, the approach is to be considered satisfactory, especially where the European Ombudsman's contribution to the management of cases of maladministration reported by citizens in this regard is emphasized. the work of the institutions and bodies of the Union, as well as the steps concerning the need to strengthen the transparency of the institutions in order to ensure good general administration. It deserves a particular positive mention as expressed in relation to the problem of the lobbies and the contrast to any factor that may cause conflicts of interest in order to ensure credibility whole decision-making, both politically and technically. For these reasons, I voted favourably.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on the activities of the Office of the European Ombudsman. This office is the institution that brings citizens closer to the institutions, and the work it does to promote transparency in the Union is essential. Mrs O'Really is working tirelessly to solve the errors made by the institutions, to improve the service and responses given to European society. As a socialist, I believe that transparency and the proper functioning of the European Institutions must be ensured.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report congratulates the current European Ombudsman for her work during 2015, in which, in addition to responding to more than 17,000 European citizens who reported cases of maladministration, she decided to open eight strategic investigations on key issues such as lack of transparency in negotiations TTIP, the protection of whistleblowers, revolving doors, limitations on the European Citizens' Initiative or the violation of fundamental human rights resulting from forced deportations from Frontex. In fact, this report expresses concern about the flagrant case of revolving doors represented by former European Commission President José Manuel Durão Barroso, currently head of Goldman Sachs. I therefore believe that this is a positive report which calls for more transparency and I join her support for the work of the European Ombudsman.

name: Martina Anderson Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This report approves the 2015 report of activities presented by the European Ombudsman and congratulates her. It welcomes the continued efforts of the European Ombudsman to increase transparency and underlines eight of the strategic inquiries opened by the European Ombudsman on major issues, such as TTIP transparency, whistleblowing, the European Citizens’ Initiative, fundamental rights in the EU’s cohesion policy and her complaint on Frontex forced returns. It also focuses on the opening of six strategic initiatives (pursuit of important topics without an inquiry), among which are ECB transparency, post-term-of-office activities of former Commissioners, and the Asylum, Migration, and Integration Fund). Therefore, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2015, in which the European Parliament welcomes the continued efforts of the European Ombudsman to increase transparency in the context of negotiations on the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) agreement. I believe that this is an important area and the greater transparency of this agreement will lead to its successful outcome in the future. I welcome the Commission's step to publish a large number of TTIP documents, thereby promoting transparency as one of the three pillars of the new trade strategy. I believe that the European Ombudsman can make a significant contribution to broader efforts to preserve and strengthen the confidence of European citizens in the Commission's activities and the benefits of international agreements.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on the annual report on the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2015 because significant efforts have been made to improve the quality of services provided to citizens by European administrations.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: in writing. - The position of the European Ombudsman was created to provide EU citizens with a focal point for their complaints about any kind of maladministration in the activities of the European institutions, bodies, offices or agencies. Parliament's report on the Ombudsman's activities in 2015 commends his work and advocates the greatest possible level of transparency. It also calls for a revision of the Code of Good Administrative Behaviour and the development of a Directive on internal information. I support the report because I believe that the EU needs a high level of transparency and proximity to its citizens in order to further strengthen its democratic legitimacy. The role of the Ombudsman makes a very important contribution to this.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. — A lot of openness in terms of transparency, since the Commission gives only what it wants, whether in the field of TTIP, tobacco or EMIS (emissions in the automotive sector). As for aid to migrants, it itself justifies a vote against it. Following the launch of reform proposals for the European Network of Ombudsmen (ENO), this European network conducted a survey on the fundamental rights of deported migrants. Following this investigation, the Ombudsman made recommendations to Frontex to ensure that the human rights of migrants are respected (recourse). The European Ombudsman continues to work on behalf of migrants in 2015, as his office opened a strategic initiative on migration and asylum integration funds. Similarly, the fight against the “revolving doors” appears to be failing with Barroso's recruitment to Goldman Sachs. Therefore, I objected to this text.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst I am happy for EU bodies to criticise EU institutions, the Ombudsman is still part of the European Union mechanism, therefore I voted to abstain on this resolution.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report, because it is necessary to commend the quality of the work of the European Ombudsman. Its activity in favour of greater transparency is an essential factor for the trust and credibility of the European administration. In a climate of distrust of the institutions, it is therefore important to emphasize the effectiveness of these operations.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted against this report, which contains a number of points with which I disagree. To mention a few: smoke smoke at the level of transparency when the Commission reveals only what it wants, especially at the level of the TTIP, aid to 'migrants', hypocrisy compared to whistleblowers who are rented when the most famous of them, Julian Assange and Edward Snowden, have not been protected in Europe, etc. vote in favour of a text that legitimizes activities contrary to our national interests.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: in writing. — I endorsed this report, which underlines the quality of the Ombudsman's work and her continued work to improve the quality of service rendered to citizens by the European administration. Noteworthy is the high proportion of complaints about transparency, which places transparency at the top of the complaints. While it welcomes the Ombudsman's efforts to improve the transparency of TTIP negotiations by submitting proposals to the European Commission to improve the transparency of the TTIP negotiations, the report reaffirms that greater transparency is needed in the negotiations of international agreements, as many citizens demand.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: ‒ Today I voted in favour of the Marias report on the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2015. The text endorses the report presented to Parliament by Ombudsman O'Reilly, praising the excellent work done and the efforts made to improve the quality of services offered to citizens by the European administration. In the past year, complaints about transparency have been particularly frequent, which underlines how this issue represents a central element for citizens and a guarantee indicator for the good administration. In this framework there are the cases of so-called revolving doors, those situations in which EU officials have found themselves to occupy jobs in the private sector, within their competence, immediately after leaving previous institutional posts. These are worrying episodes, on which a supervisory supplement is needed, both for possible conflicts of interest and for the risks to the overall credibility of the institutions, It is the case of the recent appointment of Barroso as non-executive chairman of business bank Goldman Sachs International. Parliament also reiterated the importance of greater transparency of the ECB, particularly for its role as a member of the troika, and of the Commission's expert groups.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report on the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2015. The report reflects many of Mrs Emilly O'Reilly's positive actions, in which we highlight the importance of an institution such as the Ombudsman, to ensure the interests of citizens and safeguard their rights against possible bad practices in administrations. It is also important to know that Spain is far leading the number of complaints to the Ombudsman, as well as to the Committee on Petitions. The report also reflects efforts to achieve greater transparency in the TTIP and CETA negotiations, in decision-making, public access to documents; the problem of revolving doors, violations of rights by Frontex and Member States in the migrant crisis; or the rights of minority groups and urges it to safeguard citizens' rights and the interests of good administration vis-à-vis the ECB and the European Commission. That is why, although improved, we see positively the Ombudsman's accountability and the report that has been presented on how to improve her activities.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported this report on the activity of the European Ombudsman 2015. Mrs O' Reilly's work is remarkable and tireless in the effort to improve the quality of the service that the European Administration provides to citizens. Maximum transparency must be sought as a key element for building trust and good governance, as highlighted by the high percentage of complaints received in relation to transparency, which is higher than any other matter.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted against this report on the activities of the European Ombudsman. First of all, I would like to mention a few figures. The European Ombudsman has a budget of EUR 10,346,105. For what results? In 2015, he “helped” 26.7% fewer citizens than in 2014. These so-called successes, in particular the push of the Commission to more transparency in the context of the TTIP negotiations, remain very relative; the same is true for the Commission's relations with tobacco industry lobbyists, since the Commission still refuses detailed information on their joint meetings. Of course, the European Ombudsman may seem full of good will since he opposes the so-called “revolving doors” practice, that is to say, the fact that certain EU experts, lawyers or elites move from the public to the private and then from private to the public without any control. This did not prevent José Manuel Barroso from quietly offering himself a golden retreat at Goldman Sachs. Finally, who does the European Ombudsman claim to defend? European citizens? No, its top priority is to allow migrants to bring remedies against States when they find their human rights violated.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: In writing. ‒ The European Ombudsman is one of the few existing forms of control that European citizens have available to the European institutions. I believe that the European Ombudsman works in a positive way with other bodies working in the Member States in the defence of citizens, such as the European Network of Ombudsmen and the Petitions Committees and that activities carried out by it have thus far resulted in good results. For these reasons I wanted to support this text with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report, which assesses positively the work carried out by the European Ombudsman during 2015 to improve the quality of the service that the European Administration provides to citizens. The report particularly appreciates the Ombudsman's action in the area of transparency, as highlighted by the high percentage of complaints received in relation to it (22.4 per cent), higher than any other matter, as well as her continued efforts to increase transparency in TTIP negotiations, through the submission to the Commission of proposals for this purpose. In particular, he welcomed the fact that, as a result, the Commission had published numerous documents, including transparency as one of the three pillars of its new trade strategy. The Office of the Ombudsman conducted investigations into fundamental rights, in particular on hot returns. It also investigated how Member States spend money on projects financed by Union funds, namely projects related to persons with disabilities.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report because it assessed Parliament's activities of the European Ombudsman in 2015. Parliament approved the annual report on 2015 activities presented by the European Ombudsman and welcomes the continued efforts of the European Ombudsman to increase transparency during the TTIP negotiations by proposing proposals to the Commission to this end. Parliament supports the European Ombudsman's determination to make the activities of the European Central Bank (ECB) more transparent and in line with high governance standards, especially as he is a member of the Troika and the Quadriga Group, overseeing fiscal consolidation programmes in EU countries. Parliament also welcomes the fact that the European Ombudsman continues to investigate the cases of the 'rotary door' phenomenon in the Commission and acknowledges that, following these inquiries, the Commission provided more information on the names of senior officials who have switched to the private sector. Namely, Parliament expresses great concern at the fact that former President of the Commission, J. M. Barroso was appointed as a consultant and non-executive chairman of Goldman Sachs International.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: in writing. — I would like to express my appreciation to the Ombudsman for launching an inquiry into the extent to which Member States respect the Charter of Fundamental Rights when implementing actions funded by EU funds, for example, projects involving instead of integrating people with disabilities into society, they aim to accommodate them in institutions. I support the European Ombudsman in pursuing these inquiries in order to ensure the transparency and added value of projects. I welcome the cooperation between the Ombudsman and the European Parliament in the framework of the UN Framework Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, in particular their call to fully implement the Convention at EU level and to provide it with adequate resources. I support the Ombudsman's efforts to resolve issues relating to discrimination, the rights of minority groups and the rights of elderly people. In the light of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: in writing. - I approve and support the 2015 Annual Report submitted by the European Ombudsman. I am pleased with the excellent work and effort to improve the quality of services offered by the European Administration to citizens. I agree that transparency is a central element for gaining confidence in good administration. This fact is also demonstrated by a high proportion of complaints made in relation to transparency. The European Ombudsman's efforts to increase transparency in trade negotiations are also important. Among other things, I support its efforts to increase transparency in the functioning of the ECB, lobbyists and other important actors who have an indirect impact on the EU population.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: written. - I support this Report welcoming the work of the European Ombudsman and notes the main areas for 2015. The Office's role is to investigate complaints made by citizens about mismanagement of EU institutions or other EU bodies, which can also be investigated on their own initiative and aims to help make EU institutions more open and accessible to citizens.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on activities of the European Ombudsman in 2015 because I think Emily O' Reilly did a great job improving the quality of service offered to European citizens. Moreover, I welcomed the efforts made in order to increase transparency of the recent negotiations of trade agreements by approving this resolution. In short, I believe the Commission and the Member States should empower the European Ombudsman by recognising the need for transparency in the EU decision-making process.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ The European Ombudsman deals with cases of maladministration in the action of the Union institutions, bodies or bodies to the detriment of European citizens. In 2015, the Office of the European Ombudsman assisted 17,033 European citizens, offering advice on 13,966 of these cases (81.99%) through the interactive guide available on the European Ombudsman's website ; 2,077 cases (12.19%) were treated as complaints and 1,060 cases (6.22%) were requests for information to which the services of the European Ombudsman provided a response. Compared to the previous year, the number of citizens assisted in 2015 was significantly lower (there were 23,072 in 2014, a reduction of 26.17%); the amount of complaints remained the same but the percentage of complaints compared to the total number of cases was higher in 2015 (12.19%) than in 2014 (9.01%). Overall it is an active institution, which offers a useful service to citizenship, but which is still little known. It is important to support its action both in the field of transparency of the various EU institutions which take decisions that impact European citizens, and in the dissemination of knowledge and correct information on the laws and rights of citizens.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. - I welcome the Ombudsman's continued dialogue and close relations with a whole range of EU institutions, including the European Parliament and other agencies, with a view to ensuring administrative cooperation and cohesion. I believe that it is necessary for EU agencies to respect the same high standards of transparency, accountability and ethics as all other institutions. In this respect, I welcome the work carried out by the European Ombudsman in several agencies throughout the EU as extremely important, precisely in order to comply with these standards. I believe that Emily O'Reilly's work was aimed at improving the quality of the services provided to citizens by European administrations, which is why I expressed my favour in the report on the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2015.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on the activities of the Office of the European Ombudsman. This office is the institution that brings citizens closer to the institutions, and the work it does to promote transparency in the Union is essential. Mrs O'Reilly is working tirelessly to solve the errors made by the institutions, to improve the service and the responses given to European society. As a socialist, I believe that transparency and the proper functioning of the European institutions must be ensured.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of this report which reports the activities carried out by the European Ombudsman over the past year. The Ombudsman is an indispensable figure because, in addition to serving the public interest, he provides significant aid to the EU institutions in order to improve the quality of the services offered. The close cooperation over the last year with the EU institutions has helped to strengthen cohesion and administrative cooperation. The report highlights the efforts made, aimed at the greater transparency of negotiations (many proposals addressed to the Commission on TTIP and CETA) and lobbying activities. The Ombudsman also made proposals to improve the European Citizens' Initiative (ICE) in order to make it more effective by facilitating citizens' participation in defining EU policies.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP chose to abstain on this resolution because we feel that the Ombudsman is holding the institutions to account on transparency but is still not going far enough to ensure that all aspects of the EU are transparent and accountable.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ The report on the Ombudsman's annual activity highlights the contribution of the Ombudsman correctly in relation to cases of maladministration relating to the action of the institutions and the bodies of the Union. Particularly positive is the reference to the problem of lobbies, which calls for the amendment of Regulation No 1049/2001 on public access to documents of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, as well as the European Citizens' Initiative (ICE) and on the counter to sources of conflict of interest. I have expressed myself without doubt in favour.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The report on the annual report on the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2015 is a regular analysis and assessment of the work presented by this office.
