As the report approaches the issue with a critical eye, analysing the bad texts and proposing solutions, I think it contributes to improving the Ombudsman's work, and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ The work done by Emiliy O'Reilly is very good, therefore I voted in favour of the report tabled on the work of the European Ombudsman. This figure is charged with investigating complaints about cases of maladministration by EU institutions or other bodies. Complaints may be made by citizens or residents of the countries of the Union or by associations or companies with a European registered office. This is a nerve role, especially at this time of strong anti-Europeanism, to give confidence and ensure good administration, as evidenced by the high percentage of complaints about the transparency (22.4%). It does not raise any wonder, but I welcome the Ombudsman's continued effort to improve the transparency of the negotiations on TTIP by obtaining the publication of numerous documents on this matter. Similarly, it requires more than a mere mention of the ECB's much-longed publication of lists of meetings of members of the Executive Board, or the willingness for a less bland opening to this that happens during Eurogroup meetings. The Ombudsman has therefore been open to citizens in line with the objective of implementing the transparency set out by the Commission.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the Report on the annual report on the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2015.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. - The Ombudsman plays a key role, under the Treaties, in defending principles of good administration in the European institutions. Furthermore, having analyzed 48 840 complaints between 2005 and 2015, he is a well-known figure of European citizens (83% know that they can address the Ombudsman - Eurobarometer October 2015). It is therefore essential to preserve the independence of this figure in order to maintain the effectiveness of its decisions or recommendations. I welcome the rate of 90% compliance with the Ombudsman's decisions and recommendations in 2015 and the good diligence in handling all requests which, however, were lower than the previous year, which concerns me. Record that information and access to documents is the main subject of applications. I believe that this access should be as wide as possible in a safe manner. I would argue that these reports by Parliament should make an assessment of the subject matter of the Ombudsman's work and not seek to use the pretext for political attacks. I therefore depart from references to specific media cases which, in my view, do not fall within the scope of this report. This fact instrumentalizes the document and distances it from its objective. I therefore abstain from this report.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: ‒ I voted in favour of the report because it highlights the excellent work done by the European Ombudsman in 2015. The mandate of the European Ombudsman is contained in Article 228 TFEU and concerns the receipt of complaints about maladministration in the EU institutions, a mandate which allowed in 2015 to Ombudsman to assist about 17 thousand cases, of which 14 thousand through the interactive guidance provided by the website of the same, 2 thousand cases were treated as complaints and a thousand were the requests of information. The topics that were most at the heart of the Ombudsman's activities and its investigations were: requests for information and access to documents, institutional issues and political issues followed by Commission. The role of the European Ombudsman, in the current geopolitical environment, appears essential to bring citizens closer to the institutions and meet the growing demand for transparency.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ It is crucial to achieve good administration and ensure the credibility of political and technical decision-making.  For this purpose, I consider that particular attention needs to be paid at EU level, on the basis of high standards and concrete measures that leave no doubt regarding any conflict of interest in appointing candidates for positions in the Union’s institutions, agencies and bodies. Efforts to make lobbying more transparent are welcome; however, I regret the Commission’s reluctance to publish detailed information on meetings with tobacco lobbyists and urge the Commission to make its workings fully transparent so that the public acquires more trust in its work.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report congratulates the current European Ombudsman for her work during 2015, in which, in addition to responding to more than 17,000 European citizens who reported cases of maladministration, she decided to open eight strategic investigations on key issues such as lack of transparency in negotiations TTIP, the protection of whistleblowers, revolving doors, limitations on the European Citizens' Initiative or the violation of fundamental human rights resulting from forced deportations from Frontex. In fact, this report expresses concern about the flagrant case of revolving doors represented by former European Commission President José Manuel Durão Barroso, currently head of Goldman Sachs. I therefore believe that this is a positive report which calls for more transparency and I join her support for the work of the European Ombudsman.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. - The Ombudsman helps individuals, businesses and associations facing maladministration problems within an institution of the Union. In 2015, the European Ombudsman's Office helped 17 033 European citizens, of whom 13 966 cases (81.99%) were resolved by providing advice through the interactive guide on the European Ombudsman's website. It serves the public interest, helping the EU institutions improve the quality of their services. In addition to investigating complaints, the Ombudsman may also initiate inquiries on his own initiative. I voted for the continued transparency of European institutions and bodies. Identifying defective administrations is a European priority.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: in writing. — The European Ombudsman's office receives complaints about maladministration in the activities of the EU institutions, bodies and offices and helps individuals, companies and associations in connection with maladministration within the EU institutions in case of problems. In addition to investigating complaints, the Ombudsman can also launch inquiries on his own initiative. In 2015, the Ombudsman dealt with fundamental issues in 8 strategic inquiries, such as the transparency of the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership, abusive reporting, the European citizens' initiatives, fundamental rights within EU cohesion policy and deportation by Frontex. The report also deals with the initiatives and actions of the European Ombudsman, the use of social media to promote the Ombudsman's activities. The initial approach of the Parliament's report is different from what I believe should be taken with regard to the Ombudsman's office to formulate. As Vice-Chair of the Committee on Petitions, follow-up and cooperation with the Office are an integral part of my work. In agreement with my colleagues from the People's Party, it is necessary to eliminate non-objective discretion and to preserve the Office's real role as laid down in the Treaties.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the European Ombudsman's activity report by Mrs Emily O'Reilly for 2015. The report was presented in a clear and businesslike way. The report highlighted the main problems and assurances about the rich initiatives and actions of the European Ombudsman. The report was drawn up on the basis of specific information and detailed statistics approximating the nature of the Ombudsman's work and emphasising its importance. In 2015, the Office of the European Ombudsman helped 17,033 European Union citizens. The data presented underline the importance of this institution and the expediency of the action taken, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of this report as it recognises and endorses the work of the European Ombudsman, Emily O’Reilly, for 2015. The report encourages the empowerment of the European Ombudsman when it comes to matters of transparency and calls upon the Commission to empower the Ombudsman with the ability to issue a statement of non-compliance should an institution refuse to release public documents that do not endanger public safety or security or put the privacy and integrity of individuals at stake. The report also encourages the European Ombudsman to ensure that Europe’s institutions maintain the highest standards for our citizens and commends her efforts to introduce more transparency in the TTIP negotiations following concerns from citizens. Finally, the report also encourages her to do the same when it comes to CETA, to ensure that citizens are informed of the decisions being taken in their name.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. - Many European citizens are concerned about European policies and their implementation, and I think it is important that they petition when they are concerned. I therefore support the rapporteur's position on the need for more sustained and broader efforts to protect the trust of European citizens, particularly in the light of Regulation 1049/2001 on public access to European Parliament, Council and Commission documents, which states that transparency and full access to documents held by the EU institutions must be the norm to ensure that citizens can fully exercise their democratic rights.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: in writing. — This own-initiative report focuses on the European Ombudsman's work for 2015. The mandate of the European Ombudsman is described in Article 228 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (FEU Treaty), allowing his office to receive complaints about cases of maladministration in the activities of European institutions, bodies or bodies. Considering that the European Ombudsman has a key role in the activities of the European institutions and that the work of the current incumbent, Mrs Emily O'Reilly, is welcomed, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR)
text: ‒ N-VA voted in favour of this report which appreciates the work of the European Ombudsman. The N-VA is aware of the great importance of the work done by the European Ombudsman. Good governance, transparency and accessibility are essential if the EU maintain/restore its support. In particular, N-VA supports investigations of Commissioners who will work in the private sector after their term of office, and the N-VA supports — more generally — the demand for effective management of conflicts of interest, the call for greater transparency of lobbying activities and the protection of whistleblowers. N-VA is also very pleased with the full support for the full implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities at EU level. No credible Europe without the involvement of its citizens!

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ The European Ombudsman is a figure that serves as between individuals, associations and institutions in Europe. In a complex context as are the European institutions it is important to have a body that individuals, companies and associations can turn to in case they encounter problems of bad administration.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted against this text. In 2015, the European Ombudsman helped 17,033 Europeans. However, there are some deficiencies in the Commission's transparency, the revolving door system, which allows staff of Directorates-General to move successively from institutions to the private sector (law firm, etc.). Finally, we do not agree with the justification for the assistance provided to migrants.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. -I voted in favour of this report. The European Ombudsman presented his annual report at the meeting of the European Parliament's Committee on Petitions on 20 June 2016. The report is presented as the previous 2014 report, focusing on key issues and providing a wealth of information on the European Ombudsman's initiatives and actions, the use of social media to promote the Ombudsman's activities, as well as relevant actions by the European institutions. I, too, support the fact that the file addresses a number of key issues, such as poor governance in the functioning of the ECB as a result of conflicts of interest arising from its status as a monetary authority and a member of the Troika. Furthermore, I strongly support the calls for transparency in the European Stabilisation Mechanism (ESM) and the request for the continuation of investigations by the European Ombudsman in revolving door cases (the movement of staff between roles as legislators and regulators and industries, affected by legislation and regulation) in the Commission, such as that of former President of the European Commission Mr Barroso, who has been appointed as Advisor and Non-Executive Chairman of Goldman Sachs International.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: in writing. - We are voting in favour of the annual report on the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2015 of the Committee on Petitions, as we welcome the efforts of the European Ombudsman to consolidate transparency in the various institutions or bodies of the European Union, which take decisions by impact on European citizens, as they decide on economic and monetary issues (such as the Eurogroup) or offer funding to Member States under tough terms and memoranda of understanding (such as the European Stability Mechanism).

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2015. The report makes some strong points on the lack of transparency in some areas of the EU’s activities. It calls for a directive on the protection of whistleblowers, and also a reformed Code of Conduct for Commissioners. There has been interest in Wales in the position of Ombudsperson and I hope that we can build on the EU example.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: in writing. — Vote against: the report promotes whistleblowers, too often exposed to professional or even criminal retaliation (point N). But the best-known whistleblowers, Snowden and Assange, have not been protected in Europe, making it quite hypocritical to the good intentions shown about them.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The report addresses the work of the EU Ombudsman in 2015. It welcomes the Ombudsman's efforts to increase transparency in TTIP negotiations. It emphasises the need for transparency in the EU decision-making process and supports the investigation of informal negotiations between the three main EU institutions ('trialogues'). It regrets the fact that the European Commission provided only partial documentation to the Committee of Inquiry into the so-called 'VW scandal'. It supports the Ombudsman's determination to increase the transparency of the functioning of the ECB. It calls for greater transparency in Eurogroup meetings. Supports the Provider's efforts to increase transparency of lobe activities. Welcomes investigations into the cases of 'revolving door' in the European Commission. It takes a critical approach to the fact that former President of the European Commission, José Manuel Barroso, has been appointed consultant and non-executive chairman of Goldman Sachs International. We recognize the work of the Ombudsman, which includes some dimensions that we value. However, the content of the report itself highlights its character as a mere 'democratic' adornment of a profoundly undemocratic process, by the way in which it conditions the lives of millions of citizens, of the Member States and their sovereignty institutions every day, by imposing on them policies contrary to their interests.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the annual report of the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2015, because it provides complete and interesting data on the performance, initiatives and actions concrete work by the European Ombudsman, whose tasks are explained by consulting and direct aid to European citizens. I believe that the role of the European Ombudsman is necessary in order to implement transparency in decision-making processes at European level.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: In writing. ‒ I am voting in favour of the report: I agree to call for more transparency from the European institutions.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: in writing. - I am voting in favour of the annual report on the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2015 of the Committee on Petitions, as I welcome the efforts of the European Ombudsman to consolidate transparency in the various institutions or bodies of the European Union, which take decisions by impact on European citizens, as they decide on economic and monetary issues (such as the Eurogroup) or offer funding to Member States under tough terms and memoranda of understanding (such as the European Stability Mechanism).

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I fully endorse the great work of European Ombudsman Emily O’Reilly for 2015. Of special mention for the year in question was her work on transparency (TTIP negotiations, the ECB, EU decision—making, whistle—blowing rules, lobbying transparency, EU agencies); revolving doors and conflict of interests. The Ombudsman also did a great job in investigating respect for fundamental rights, in particular on the role of Frontex in forced returns; as well as when Member States spend money on projects financed by EU funds, for example on projects for disabled people (community—based care as opposed to institutionalisation). I also support the specific mention about former Commission President Barroso’s appointment as adviser and non-executive chairman of Goldman Sachs International.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report considering the important work it does, since the Ombudsman assists citizens, businesses and associations facing problems of maladministration of an institution of the Union. Similarly, the Ombudsman must ensure that all kinds of conflicts of interest within the Union are tackled, as it is key to ensuring their credibility. In this regard, it is necessary to revise the code of conduct that applies to Commissioners, to extend the period of incompatibility from 18 months to 2 years for former Commissioners and to 3 years for former presidents.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on the activities of the Office of the European Ombudsman. This office is the institution that brings citizens closer to the institutions, and the work it does to promote transparency in the Union is essential. Mrs O'Reilly is working tirelessly to solve the errors made by the institutions, to improve the service and the responses given to European society. As a socialist, I believe that transparency and the proper functioning of the European institutions must be ensured.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on the activities of the Office of the European Ombudsman. This office is the institution that brings citizens closer to the institutions, and the work it does to promote transparency in the Union is essential. Mrs O'Reilly is working tirelessly to solve the errors made by the institutions, to improve the service and the responses given to European society. As a socialist, I believe that transparency and the proper functioning of the European institutions must be ensured.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the annual report on the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2015 and I am very pleased with the Ombudsman's work European Emily O'Reilly because I think it is of fundamental importance for improving relations between the citizens and the European institutions. I believe that the figure of the European Ombudsman can be a direct and effective channel of contact between citizens and institutions, giving everyone the opportunity to point out any opacity inadequacies. In 2015, the European Ombudsman, for example, dealt closely with several issues such as the secrecy of the TTIP negotiations, the transparency of the lobbies and the major issue of conflicts of interests of members of the Parliament and the Commission. I firmly believe that the figure of the European Ombudsman may be even more important in the future, precisely because of the role it plays of adhesives between European communities and institutions, so that we can increase democratic control of citizens albeit by indirect ways.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report by my colleague Notis Marias on the 2015 Annual Report on the activities of the European Ombudsman. The European Ombudsman, together with her Strasbourg team, is doing a valuable job and has in recent years managed to put this office in the spotlight more than before.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: in writing. - The work of the European Ombudsman promotes transparency in the European institutions. In 2015, a total of 17,033 European citizens' submissions were addressed to the Ombudsman.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report. The report calls for increased transparency in TTIP negotiations and for the Ombudsman to take action and examine. While I wish for there to be greater transparency I also wish that there wasn't an EU Commission, ECB or other EU institutions that require examination!

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2015, given that Ombudsman Emily O'Reilly has done important work on increasing transparency in the context of TTIP negotiations, the work of the ECB, EU decision-making, whistleblowing rules and lobbying transparency. She has also been vital in addressing issues around revolving doors and conflict of interests. I moreover welcome that Ms O'Reilly investigated respect for fundamental rights, in particular on the role of Frontex in forced returns.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report on the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2015. The report reflects many of Mrs Emilly O'Reilly's positive actions, in which we highlight the importance of an institution such as the Ombudsman, to ensure the interests of citizens and safeguard their rights against possible bad practices in administrations. It is also important to know that Spain is far leading the number of complaints to the Ombudsman, as well as to the Committee on Petitions. The report also reflects efforts to achieve greater transparency in the TTIP and CETA negotiations, in decision-making, public access to documents; the problem of revolving doors, violations of rights by Frontex and Member States in the migrant crisis; or the rights of minority groups and urges it to safeguard citizens' rights and the interests of good administration vis-à-vis the ECB and the European Commission. That is why, although improved, we see positively the Ombudsman's accountability and the report that has been presented on how to improve her activities.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as Labour MEPs support the work and activities of the European Ombudsman, who has done essential work in increasing transparency in the context of TTIP negotiations, the work of the ECB, EU decision-making, whistleblowing rules and lobbying transparency.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on the activities of the Office of the European Ombudsman. This office is the institution that brings citizens closer to the institutions, and the work it does to promote transparency in the Union is essential. Mrs O'Reilly is working tirelessly to solve the errors made by the institutions, to improve the service and the responses given to European society. As a socialist, I believe that transparency and the proper functioning of the European institutions must be ensured.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted in favour of the report on the European Ombudsman as we recognise the efforts made to enhance transparency on such serious issues as TTIP, the European Citizens' Initiative, fundamental rights in the context of the European Cohesion Policy The Union's complaint against Frontex as well as the 'revolving doors' investigation, an issue that came back to the fore following the appointment of Barroso to Goldman Sachs.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I was happy to support the annual report on the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2015. The promotion of transparency is one of the three pillars of the Commission’s new trade strategy and as a member of the ITCO Intergroup (Intergroup on Integrity, Transparency, Corruption and Organised Crime) in the European Parliament, I think it is imperative that the institutions strive to uphold the ideals of transparency and integrity in all aspects of European policy. In that regard, the Ombudsman plays an important role in the functioning of the European Union and its institutions.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour since I have no objections.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written. - I voted for the Report on the annual report on the actions of the European Ombudsman in 2015 because the work of the institution proved to be excellent, as well as the annual report. The European Ombudsman, Mrs Emily O'Reilly, has received many praise for her work to improve the quality of services provided to citizens by the European administration. O'Reilly sees the importance of transparency as key components of trust gain and good administration. With its proposals, the European Ombudsman has prompted the Commission to increase the transparency of the TTIP negotiations, and on this basis the Commission has published numerous TTIP documents, thus putting transparency into one of the three pillars of the Commission's new trade strategy.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. — The Commission has not made the efforts I expected in terms of transparency, since the information it wants to reveal is carefully selected, as we see it in the field of tobacco or emissions relating to the automotive sector. The weaknesses of the report are manifested in the unacceptable assistance desired for migrants, the fight against “revolving doors” reduced to helplessness by Mr Barroso's entry to Goldman Sachs, and the theoretical protection given to whistleblowers. I voted against it.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of my colleague Notis Marias's report on the review of the European Ombudsman's activities in 2015. The European Ombudsman is a full-fledged institution which helps to establish a link between citizens, businesses and associations who are in difficulty in the face of maladministration of the European institutions. This approach was reinforced in 2015, thanks to the Ombudsman's efforts in the use and promotion of social networks. The main investigations conducted in 2015 concern issues of transparency, institutional issues and the Commission's policy as guardian of the Treaties. This vote is an opportunity to welcome the efforts of the European Ombudsman to strengthen the transparency of the European institutions, since he participates in improving the image of the European Union among citizens. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report, which highlights the central role of the European Ombudsman in building links between citizens and the European institutions. This text shows us the important role of the Ombudsman and its adaptation to the new challenges, since the use and promotion of social networks are at the heart of his work in 2015.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report as it advocates transparency in relation to the TTIP negotiations, with the European agencies and in the work with associations. The report rightly recognises that only a high degree of transparency legitimises confidence in elected representatives.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I supported the resolution of the European Parliament of 24 November 2016 on the annual report on the activities of the European Ombudsman for 2015 in the vote. Indeed, I appreciate the work of the European ombudswoman and appreciate that she seeks to increase transparency in the TTIP negotiations and makes proposals to the Commission for that purpose. As Vice-Chair of the EMIS Committee, I appreciated that the text of the resolution regrets that the Commission of Inquiry on the Measurement of Emissions in the European Parliament (EMIS) received an incomplete dossier from the Commission, lacking information deemed irrelevant by the Commission, calling on the Commission to ensure the greatest possible accuracy and full transparency in respect of the documents provided, fully in accordance with the principle of loyal cooperation in order to enable EMIS to fully and effectively exercise its investigative powers. I also welcome the European Ombudsman continuing to investigate cases of so-called revolving doors in the Commission and, like the resolution, I express great concern that the former President The Barroso Commission has been appointed as an adviser and chairman without executive powers with Goldman Sachs International, and I call on the Ombudsman to launch a strategic inquiry into how The Commission is handling Barroso's revolving door case, and to make recommendations for revising the code of conduct in accordance with the principles of good governance.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the annual report on the European Ombudsman’s activities, since she did a really great job in tackling many important challenges that Europe currently faces, such as whistleblower protection and transparency of ECB activities.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: in writing. - I supported the annual report on the activities of the European Ombudsman for 2015 as it highlights major issues and provides a wealth of information on the initiatives and actions of the European Ombudsman, the use of social media to promote the Ombudsman's activities, and relevant actions by the European institutions. The Ombudsman's inquiries for 2015 were: requests for information and access to documents, institutional and political issues, followed closely by contests and selection procedures, administration and officials regulations and, finally, awarding of tenders procedures or the granting of grants. I welcome the successes of the European Ombudsman, including the transparency of trilogue meetings and the disclosure of documents, increased transparency of the work of the European Council and the Council of the EU.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted against this report because, in terms of transparency, the Commission gives only what it wants, whether in the field of TTIP, tobacco or EMIS (emissions in the automotive sector).

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted against the report on the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2015. There is a great deal of openness, since the Commission gives only what it wants, whether in the field of TTIP, tobacco or emissions in the automotive sector. As for the immigrationist aspects of the report, they in themselves justify a vote against it. Similarly, the fight against the “revolving doors” appears to be failing with the recruitment of Barroso to Goldman Sachs. The report also promotes whistleblowers, too often exposed to professional or even criminal retaliation. But the best-known whistleblowers, Snowden and Assange, have not been protected in Europe, making it quite hypocritical to the good intentions shown about them.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted against this report, which contains a number of points with which I disagree. To mention a few: smoke smoke at the level of transparency when the Commission reveals only what it wants in particular at the level of the TTIP, aid to migrants, hypocrisy compared to whistleblowers who are rented when the most famous of them, Julian Assange and Edward Snowden, have not been protected in Europe, etc. vote in favour of a text that legitimizes activities contrary to our national interests.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on the activities of the Office of the European Ombudsman. This office is the institution that brings citizens closer to the institutions, and the work it does to promote transparency in the Union is essential. Mrs O'Reilly is working tirelessly to solve the errors made by the institutions, to improve the service and the responses given to European society. As a socialist, I believe that transparency and the proper functioning of the European institutions must be ensured.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on the activities of the Office of the European Ombudsman. This office is the institution that brings citizens closer to the institutions, and the work it does to promote transparency in the Union is essential. Mrs O'Reilly is working tirelessly to solve the errors made by the institutions, to improve the service and the responses given to European society. As a socialist, I believe that transparency and the proper functioning of the European institutions must be ensured.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support efforts of the European Ombudsman to increase transparency, especially to make the workings of the European Central Bank more transparent and compliant with a high standard of governance. I agree that the European Ombudsman should add to future annual reports a categorisation of complaints outside the mandate of the Ombudsman’s Office, since this would allow Members of the European Parliament an overview of problems affecting EU citizens.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing - The budget of the European Ombudsman's Office for 2015 was EUR 10 346 105. This amount is also a sufficient reason for the results of the Ombudsman's work to be treated with the utmost seriousness and respect. Its report should be the basis for the Commission to analyse areas where there are infringements of rights and obligations and, consequently, to take measures to prevent violations of the law and maladministration. The increased handling of complaints from 33.3% from 2014 to 52.3% in 2015, as well as the provision of assistance to 17,033 European citizens, shows a significant improvement in the Office's activities.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing. - I am voting in favour of the report on the annual report on the activities of the European Ombudsman for 2015, for the reasons I explained in detail in my speech at the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 24 November 2016, and because this motion for a resolution is complete and documented.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on activities of the European Ombudsman in 2015. Positively supporting the report means encouraging the Ombudsman to continue her noticeable efforts to improve the quality of service offered to citizens by the different European organizations. In addition, supporting the report means that we all believe in the importance of transparency, cooperation and negotiation, and good administration in order to both provide stability in the Member States and safeguard the trust of European citizens. Transparency, however, is one of the most important terms because, when combined with a full access to documents by EU institutions, it will comply with the bloc’s core value of allowing citizens to exercise their democratic rights.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: in writing. - I agree with the resolution's call for greater transparency in negotiations (e.g. TTIP), lobbying, agencies, etc.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour. The EP resolution on the European Ombudsman's activities in 2015 welcomes the continued efforts to increase transparency, but also draws attention to a number of areas where the Ombudsman's activities still need to be improved: the operation of the lobbyist register, the coordination of the public and private interests of Commissioners, Methods for dealing with complaints of infringements by the Commission, etc.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: Since her appointment, within the limits of her role, the European Ombudsman has been tracking down the breaches of democracy in the European Union. Last year, it responded to a large number of citizens' petitions and opened investigations on the lack of transparency of the institutions on its own initiative, in particular this unofficial body such as the Eurogroup, the ECB or in public health agencies where lobbying is raging to authorize GMOs and others. pesticides. This report supports its proposals. I regret that it does not go further, a fortiori in the light of recent slipper news, such as Mr Barroso, the former Commissioner in Goldman Sachs. However, the report “welcomes the fact that these (transparency) efforts have borne fruit, as the Commission has published numerous documents on TTIP and thus promoted transparency”. Whereas in practice, it is about going to consult in a “reading room” documents of hundreds of pages, which are not up to date, without pen or laptop, and to which citizens still do not have access! I would therefore prefer to abstain while welcoming some of the proposals in this report.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In terms of transparency, the Commission gives only what it wants, whether in the field of TTIP, tobacco or EMIS (emissions in the automotive sector). Moreover, aid to migrants is obviously problematic in itself. Similarly, the fight against the “revolving doors” appears to be failing with the recruitment of Barroso to Goldman Sachs. Finally, the report promotes whistleblowers, too often exposed to professional or even criminal retaliation, but the best known, Snowden and Assange, have not been protected in Europe, which undermines good intentions about them. I therefore voted against this resolution.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. - On 3 May 2016, the European Ombudsman, Emily O'Reilly, presented her Annual Report for 2015 to Martin Schulz, President of the European Parliament. The Ombudsman helps individuals, businesses and associations who face problems of maladministration in an EU institution. In addition to supporting citizens, the European Ombudsman serves the public interest by helping EU institutions improve the quality of their services. Alongside the investigation of complaints, the Ombudsman can also open own-initiative inquiries. In view of the important role played by the European Ombudsman, I voted in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because it clearly outlines the vital work carried out by Ombudsman Emily O’Reilly throughout 2015. The European Ombudsman is essential to combatting maladministration within the EU and upholding the rule of law and principles of good administration within the European Institutions and respecting fundamental rights.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing - The right to complain to the European Ombudsman is one of the fundamental rights conferred on citizens of the Member States in relation to their citizenship in the EU. The Ombudsman assists individuals, businesses and associations facing maladministration problems in the EU institutions. Emily O'Reilly submitted the Annual Report on her activities of the European Ombudsman for 2015. The European Ombudsman's budget for 2015 was EUR 10 346 105. The office helped 17,033 European citizens this year, the most complaints were made from citizens from Spain, then Germany, Poland, Belgium and the UK. The Ombudsman launched 261 complaints inquiries and 17 own-initiative inquiries, with 261 complaints and 16 own-initiative investigations closed. Of the institutions investigated by the Ombudsman, the European Commission (55.6%) is the first place, the EU agencies, the European Personnel Selection Office. Compared to last year, the number of complaints resolved and the number of cases in which maladministration was not detected increased significantly. On the other hand, the number of complaints for which further investigation was not justified has been reduced. The European Ombudsman has also initiated a reform of the European Network of Ombudsmen, which strengthens the cooperation of its members, offers them the opportunity to conduct parallel inquiries with the Ombudsman, discuss certain cases, and advise among themselves.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report because I fully endorse the great work of European Ombudsman Emily O'Reilly for 2015.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ European Ombudsman Emily O'Reilly presented her Annual Report 2015 to the European Parliament on 3 May 2016. In its report, the Committee on Petitions informs that in 2015 the office of the European Ombudsman provided assistance to 17,033 EU citizens. 261 inquiries were opened on complaints, 17 of them ex officio and closed them in the absence of an ex officio inquiry. 8 of them were strategic investigations addressing fundamental issues such as Transparency in the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership, Abuse Notification, European Citizens' Initiative, Fundamental Rights within the EU Cohesion Policy and Frontex deportation. In the case of the 145 inquiries closed by the Ombudsman in 2015 (52.3% of the total number), the case covered by the complaint was resolved by the institution concerned and a friendly solution was reached. 79 cases (28.5%) were not found, 59 cases (19.5%) were not warranted for further investigation and 30 cases (10,8%) of maladministration were found. 19 cases (2,2%) other measures were taken. The Ombudsman made a critical remark to the institutions in 19 cases, issued a draft recommendation in 11 cases, which was fully or partially accepted by the institution. Against this background, the Committee on Petitions has called for Parliament to approve the report presented for 2015. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: in writing. ‒ The report presents the comments of the European Ombudsman on 2015. There are many concerns about transparency, since the Commission gives only what it wants, whether in the field of TTIP, tobacco or EMIS (emissions in the automotive sector). As for aid to migrants opened by the Ombudsman, it itself justifies a vote against it. Similarly, the fight against the “revolving doors” appears to be failing with Barroso's recruitment to Goldman Sachs. The report also promotes whistleblowers, too often exposed to professional and even criminal retaliation. But the best-known whistleblowers, Snowden and Assange, have not been protected in Europe, making it quite hypocritical to the good intentions shown about them. Finally, the report intends to use petitions to encourage the Commission to go further in infringement proceedings, with half-word criticism for not always initiating such proceedings, particularly under the EU Pilot procedures. I voted against it.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. — With this report, we have a great deal of openness, since the Commission gives only what it wants, whether it be in the field of TTIP, tobacco or EMIS (emissions in the automotive sector). The update on aid to migrants is not acceptable. Similarly, the fight against the “revolving doors” appears to be failing with Barroso's recruitment to Goldman Sachs. The report also promotes whistleblowers, too often exposed to professional or even criminal retaliation (point N). But the best-known whistleblowers, Snowden and Assange, have not been protected in Europe, making it quite hypocritical to the good intentions shown about them. Finally, the report intends to use petitions to encourage the Commission to go further in infringement proceedings, with half-word criticism that it does not always initiate such proceedings, particularly under the EU Pilot procedures (point E, points 17 and 18). This is also not acceptable. I am voting against this report.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, which highlights the key work of the Ombudsman, who plays an important role in upholding democracy and fundamental rights across the EU. It is important that more efforts are made to strengthen democracy as well as accountability.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report on the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2015. The European Ombudsman, established in 2005 by the Maastricht Treaty, has investigated nearly 50,000 complaints from European citizens in 20 years of existence. Its mission is to investigate cases of maladministration in the institutions and bodies of the European Union. The text welcomes the work of the Ombudsman and encourages him to continue his efforts to introduce more transparency in the functioning of the Union.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: in writing. -I support the report and also the work of the European Ombudsman. Unfortunately, the work of ombudsmen is still less recognised in individual European countries, despite the fact that their work contributes greatly to protecting the democratic values of the countries. For example, the European Ombudsman, together with the European Parliament, is doing a great job of defending the rights of people with disabilities and minorities.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Ombudsman was established by the Maastricht Treaty in 1995 and investigates complaints about maladministration in the institutions and bodies of the European Union. I have voted for the 2015 annual report regarding the European Ombudsman, which states the office helped 17 033 European citizens.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I voted for this report because it encourages the European Commission, as well as the Member States, to empower the European Ombudsman with the power to issue a declaration of non-compliance with Regulation 1049/2001 regarding public access to European Parliament, Council and Commission documents, provided that such documents do not fall within the scope of Article 9 (1) of that regulation. The report also takes note of the Statute of the European Central Bank, both as a monetary authority and as a member with advisory status of the Troika and quadriparty. I welcome the fact that the report calls on the European Ombudsman to protect the interests of good administration of one of the most important financial authorities and the fact that it emphasises the right of citizens to have a say in the EU policy-making process.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report because it calls for more transparency in negotiations such as TTIP. It also calls for greater transparency in lobbying and agencies.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported. Ombudsman Emily O'Reilly has stood actively for better transparency in the institutions.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: in writing. - The report welcomes the work of the European Ombudsman and highlights the main areas of activity for 2015. The role of the European Ombudsman's office is to investigate complaints made by citizens about maladministration exercised by EU institutions or other EU bodies or may conduct inquiries on its own initiative, with the aim of making the EU institutions more open and more friendly to the citizen. This year specific reference was made to transparency (TTIP negotiations, ECB, EU decision-making, whistleblower and conflict of interest). The European Ombudsman also investigated respect for fundamental rights, in particular with regard to the role of Frontex, as well as the spending of money by Member States on projects financed by EU funds, for example on projects for people with disabilities.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ I would refrain from voting on my colleagues' proposal because I believe that the European Ombudsman is a very important figure because it helps individuals, companies and associations. This figure also solved problems of maladministration for which the European Union was responsible, and in 2015 it assisted 17,033 European citizens by advising 13,966 of these cases, So it also improves the quality of the services offered by the European Union. The European Ombudsman has a role that helps, too, the European Union with its institutions. However, at the same time because of the dangerous situations that characterize the Member States of the European Union, it may be imprudent to facilitate public access to documents from Parliament, the Commission and of the Council. Therefore I would abstain.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: written. - I support this report because I believe that the European Ombudsman has demonstrated through her 2015 Labour Report that she has carried out her duty conscientiously and effectively. The institution of the European Ombudsman is an important factor in the democracy of the European institutions, which is why I consider it extremely important that an adequate person is in this position, a person who will proactively work towards the satisfaction of the citizens of Europe and to improve the work of institutions. The Ombudsman helps individuals, businesses and associations faced with irregularities in the treatment of the institutions of the European Union, so it is extremely important for citizens to feel confidence in the Ombudsman institution and that he is making constant efforts to improve the quality of European administration and ensure that the Ombudsman transparency as a key participant in the work of institutions, as well as negotiating procedures and decision-making procedures. I consider particularly important efforts by the European Ombudsman to protect whistleblowers, as well as the investigation into compliance with the Charter of Fundamental Rights in implementing measures financed by European funds.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: written. - The right of citizens to hear their voice when making EU policies is more important than ever before, and transparency and full access to documents of institutions are a necessary prerequisite for the full exercise of the democratic rights of citizens. This is why the European Ombudsman's efforts to increase the transparency of TTIP negotiations to the Commission with its proposals and welcome the integration of transparency in the pillars of the Commission's new trade strategy. I also support the European Ombudsman's determination to make the work of the European Central Bank more transparent and aligned with high governance standards. The interests of good governance in one of Europe's most important financial bodies must be protected. I therefore also call for greater transparency of Eurogroup meetings. Lobbying should also be made more transparent and the Commission should make all information on the impact of lobbyists readily available to the public through a single centralised online database. I regret that the Commission has provided incomplete documentation to the Investigative Committee on Emissions Measurement in the Automotive Sector (EMIS) — it is necessary to fully respect the principles of sincere cooperation in the future. The European Ombudsman continues to investigate “roundgate” cases in the Commission, but I would like to remind that conflict of interest is a broader term than “roundgate” cases. I congratulate Mrs Emily O'Reilly on her excellent work with the aim of creating the European administration that all our citizens deserve.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The report welcomes a number of aspects on which we disagree. For us, there is no transparency and no transparency in the TTIP negotiations, let alone in the ECB. While recognising positive aspects such as the condemnation of the promiscuity between the European Commission and the major economic groups, particularly at the level of so-called revolving doors, we believe that the text continues to pass alongside the enormous democratic deficit of the whole process of integration of this EU.

name: Pavel Poc (S&D)
text: in writing. — The European Ombudsman is the body that any citizen of the Union may address in case he has a complaint concerning maladministration of institutions, institutions or other bodies The European Union. It functions essentially as an intermediate link between citizens and institutions that are often reluctant to interact with him in solving his problem. As this makes a significant contribution to increasing the transparency of a very comprehensive administrative system, I voted in favour of the adoption of this body's annual report. Emily O'Reilly, who heads this institution, has improved through its activity the quality of strategic inquiries required to improve the current situation. Personally, I am very pleased for the efforts made by the ombudswoman to address the issue of the non-public composition of the Commission's expert groups and for the pressure on the detailed disclosure of information on meetings with lobbyists . I am equally pleased for the fact that the ombudswoman is also dedicated to investigating cases where former Commission officials are moving into the private sector. The institution of the European Ombudsman increases the possibilities for ordinary citizens to comment on EU policymaking. This possibility is extremely important at the moment, with more and more people alienating themselves from the European Union and when we see a similar tendency in the institutions themselves. There must again be a link of European structures with citizens. They're primarily for those here.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: The right to file a complaint with the European Ombudsman constitutes one of the fundamental rights conferred on citizens of the Member States through EU citizenship. The Ombudsman helps individuals, companies and associations that are victims of maladministration by an EU institution. The European Ombudsman serves the public interest by helping EU institutions improve the quality of services offered, conducting investigations into complaints received and, in some cases, conducting investigations of own initiative. If an EU institution, body or body fails to respond satisfactorily to a draft recommendation, the Ombudsman may draw up and send a special report to the European Parliament . The special report is the Ombudsman's instrument of last resort and is the Ombudsman's final step in dealing with a complaint case. I therefore believe that the role played by this body is of great importance in ensuring greater transparency in the decisions taken by the various EU institutions and bodies. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: in writing. — The report raises a number of important issues, such as maladministration in the functioning of the ECB due to the conflict of interest arising from its status, as monetary authorities and as a member of the Troika/Quadryg. Moreover, he demands transparency in the operation of the European Stabilisation Mechanism (ESM) and finally asks the European Ombudsman about investigations into the so-called “revolving door” at the Commission, as in the case of former European Commission President José Manuel Barroso, who was hired , as an advisor and perhaps in the future chairman of Goldman Sachs International. I hereby supported the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on the activities of the European Ombudsman, whose task is to investigate cases of “maladministration” in the actions of the institutions, bodies and bodies of the European Union, in the event of complaints lodged by citizens, companies or associations. The European Ombudsman ensures respect for rights but also serves the general interest by helping the institutions of the Union to increase the effectiveness of public action at the service of European citizens.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP chose to abstain on this resolution because we feel that the Ombudsman is holding the institutions to account on transparency but is still not going far enough to ensure that all aspects of the EU are transparent and accountable.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on the activities of the Office of the European Ombudsman. This office is the institution that brings citizens closer to the institutions, and the work it does to promote transparency in the Union is essential. Mrs O'Reilly is working tirelessly to solve the errors made by the institutions, to improve the service and the responses given to European society. As a socialist, I believe that transparency and the proper functioning of the European institutions must be ensured.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the annual report on the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2015, whose activity, including strategic investigations, has identified the need for transparency in order to ensure good administration. At a time when many citizens are questioning the merits of trade treaties, it is essential to relay their concerns and provide them with any elements necessary to build their own opinion. Furthermore, we will not be able to re-enchant the European project unless we are able to investigate the cases of slippering of Commission officials, such as the former President of the Commission, Mr Barroso, now appointed as adviser and non-executive director of Goldman Sachs International. It is the role of the Ombudsman to make recommendations on the reform of the code of conduct for civil servants so that they are obliged — since common sense alone is not enough — to respect ethical requirements and principles of good administration.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. - I support the report on the activities of the EU Ombudsman. At the same time, I would like to stress that the text of the European Parliament resolution submitted to the vote is certainly not without flaws Its original version did not pay due attention to transparency issues related to the TTIP, problems such as the issue of neutrality of the European Central Bank, simultaneous participation in the Presidency troika, or problems related to the implementation of the Code of Conduct. I am also pleased that the document has been improved by proposals to give the Ombudsman more powers through the release of documents, a positive assessment of the Ombudsman's activities by examining the transparency of the activities of the Commission's expert groups, strengthening the activities of the lobbyist register, former President J. M. Assessing the compatibility of Barroso's activities with the Code of Conduct and currently working Commissioners such as M. A. Cañete or N. Kroes, problems of conflicts of interest.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. - In the presentation that the European Ombudsman - Emily O'Reilly - made on the Annual Report for 2015, she highlighted what is the mission and main functions performed by this European body at the service of citizens, listing the data set on complaints submitted, advice, investigations initiated and support for improving the quality of services provided by the European institutions. During the debate in plenary, a number of proposals for regulations concerning the reporting of irregularities, increasing the transparency of the ECB and the Eurogroup, as well as interest groups, with which I agree. The possible need to reform the Code of Conduct for Commissioners was also discussed. As I agree with the content of the report, I voted in favour of it.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution, which takes stock of the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2015. In 2015, the European Ombudsman, Emily O'Reilly, opened 278 complaints investigations. It should be recalled that the Ombudsman's task is to investigate complaints about cases of maladministration in the work of the European institutions. It also has the power to initiate investigations. I therefore supported this resolution, which underlines the crucial role of the European Ombudsman in ensuring compliance with procedural and ethical rules within the European institutions, thus avoiding any conflict of interest or maladministration. The European Ombudsman has an essential role in ensuring respect for fundamental rights and the principles of the rule of law in the action of the European institutions.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report on the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2015. The report reflects many of Mrs Emilly O'Reilly's positive actions, in which we highlight the importance of an institution such as the Ombudsman, to ensure the interests of citizens and safeguard their rights against possible bad practices in administrations. It is also important to know that Spain is far leading the number of complaints to the Ombudsman, as well as to the Committee on Petitions. The report also reflects efforts to achieve greater transparency in the TTIP and CETA negotiations, in decision-making, public access to documents; the problem of revolving doors, violations of rights by Frontex and Member States in the migrant crisis; or the rights of minority groups and urges it to safeguard citizens' rights and the interests of good administration vis-à-vis the ECB and the European Commission. That is why, although improved, we see positively the Ombudsman's accountability and the report that has been presented on how to improve her activities.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the Committee on Petitions report on the annual report on the annual activities of the European Ombudsman. In 2015, the European Ombudsman helped 17,033 European citizens. In particular, citizens' concerns will be addressed in the area of transparency of the European institutions, institutional and political issues and the receipt of information and documents.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report congratulates the current European Ombudsman for her work during 2015, in which, in addition to responding to more than 17,000 European citizens who reported cases of maladministration, she decided to open eight strategic investigations on key issues such as lack of transparency in negotiations TTIP, the protection of whistleblowers, revolving doors, limitations on the European Citizens' Initiative or the violation of fundamental human rights resulting from forced deportations from Frontex. In fact, this report expresses concern about the flagrant case of revolving doors represented by former European Commission President José Manuel Durão Barroso, currently head of Goldman Sachs. I therefore believe that this is a positive report which calls for more transparency and I join her support for the work of the European Ombudsman.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this. Whilst I do not agree that the EU should exist, at least the Ombudsman is trying to keep an eye on it.

name: Czesław Adam Siekierski (PPE)
text: in writing. — Enhancing the quality of services offered to citizens of the European administration should be a high priority of the European Ombudsman, who continuously undertakes efforts to improve the transparency of the TTIP negotiations and the provision of additional explanations based on dialogue with the European Commission. In order to build dialogue and cooperation between the European Parliament and civil society, it is very important for the proper functioning of democracy. Increasing public access to European institutions' documents can therefore help to improve the quality of this dialogue. Transparency is also very important in the context of lobbying and the appropriate justification of decisions made at European level which have an impact on the conduct of business by companies in the EU, and in particular the largest ones with a dominant position. Solutions in this respect should also be desired by the lobbyists themselves, and they will allow them to avoid any judgement of the prohibited practices of pressuring politicians. Important matters dealt with by the European Ombudsman also include streamlining the European Citizens' Initiative and more inclusion in the EU policymaking process, which will increase the credibility of European institutions. This Office considers more and more cases concerning various irregularities or compliance with fundamental rights within the framework of the EU Cohesion Policy.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: written. - I voted positively for this report, but this rationale of voting is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEPs solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the real quality and the amount of work, efficiency and most of all the success of the advocacy.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing - Transparency is one of the pillars of the European trade strategy and extensive information needs to be provided to citizens when negotiating international agreements such as TTIP or CETA. I supported the Annual Report because the Ombudsman's Office does a great job in improving the EU institutions. The European Ombudsman's Office helped more than 17 thousand citizens in 2015. Transparency of the administration helps European citizens gain confidence in the European Cooperation Project. With better access to information, citizens can better exercise their democratic rights. Citizens' right to comment on policymaking is currently a priority, and I therefore agree with the guidelines proposed by the Ombudsman on improving the functioning of the European Citizens' Initiative. The Commission is invited to increase transparency in the field of lobbying as well as in the work of the Commission's expert groups. I approve the EP's proposal to establish communication channels and procedures to condemn anti-social activity. I consider the introduction of the mechanism to complain to FRONTEX regarding violations of fundamental rights in carrying out returns of irregular migrants as a positive step, which, together with the Ombudsman's work in investigating compliance with the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union in implementing the EU-funded measures help preserve EU legal values. Dialogue is the foundation of a democratic society, and I therefore recognise the conduct of the Ombudsman's dialogues with the whole spectrum of the European institutions.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: in writing. - I support the European Ombudsman. Everyone benefits from their commitment to greater transparency. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution. For example, the Ombudsman is committed to making the activities of the European Central Bank more transparent, in particular as a member of the Troika/Quadriga, which oversees the politically motivated fiscal consolidation programmes in the EU countries, and to ensure that the ECB's accountability management structures are adhered to high standards. However, even MEPs are only allowed to view ECB documentation in special reading rooms under the supervision of security staff, without a smartphone or notepad and pen. MEPs should not be allowed to control the ECB at all. If we members already have problems dealing with the EU institutions, what is the flourishing of the citizens? I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The report approves the report on activities presented in 2015 and congratulates it. Welcomes the efforts to consolidate transparency in the various institutions and bodies of the European Union and underlines the 8 strategic inquiries launched on important issues such as transparency in TTIP negotiations, publication of documents, the European citizens, fundamental rights under the EU's cohesion policy and the complaint against Frontex. It also focuses on opening up the 6 strategic initiatives, including ECB transparency, former Commissioners' activities, and the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund. The report generally takes a critical approach on a number of important issues. That is why we voted in favour of it.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: in writing. - We welcome the European Ombudsman's efforts to consolidate transparency in the various institutions or bodies of the European Union, which make decisions with an impact on European citizens, as they decide on economic and monetary issues (such as the Eurogroup ) or offer funding to Member States under hard terms and memoranda of understanding (such as the European Stability Mechanism).

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the adoption of a report on the evaluation of the European Ombudsman's activities last year. I agree with the fundamentally favourable balance that the report presented to the EP on the results of Mrs Ombudsman's efforts, in particular the transparency of the activities of the EU institutions, conflicts of interest for EU officials, the fight against corruption, the lobby register and - Strengthening control, transparency in TTIP, CETA and other international negotiations at EU level, whistleblower protection and other issues affecting the credibility, authority and effectiveness of the EU in the eyes of a citizen. As a politician in regular contact with citizens, I am, of course, aware of the narrow barriers stemming from the legal basis of the European Ombudsman's activities, especially in the case of deficiencies, corruption and other abuses at Member State level, but the current report shows In the light of a positive direction and corrective proposals, I hope that this EP decision will also contribute to future legal and practical changes in the Ombudsman's work, which will also enable him to deal with such cases.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Ombudsman investigates complaints about maladministration in the institutions and bodies of the European Union. Its role is to help make EU institutions friendlier and more open to citizens. The Ombudsman investigates areas such as respect for fundamental rights, transparency, conflicts of interests, and so on. This report reviews the work of the European Ombudsman for the year 2015 and notes the main areas of work. I support this report and would like to praise the good work of the Ombudsman.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the text. It highlights the most important issues and provides detailed information on the initiatives and activities of the European Ombudsman, the use of social networks to promote the institution's activities and the actions taken by the other Union institutions in response to the Ombudsman's recommendations. It is accompanied by statistics that are as informative as detailed in the very same areas as in the previous year, making it easy to make direct comparisons. However, it was regrettable that the report was published only in English on the Ombudsman's website, which limits the number of potential readers until all other language versions were available.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The report on the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2015 focus on the successes of the Ombudsman in the promotion of transparency. The report cites the improvements in the quality of service offered to EU citizens by the European administration and its improved transparency. I voted in favour of the report because I believe in the importance of transparency as a core element in gaining the trust of EU citizens, a trust that should be ensured at all levels of the EU administration.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In an age when the very idea of the European Union is under attack by populists, transparency and good administration become even more fundamental in the eyes of European citizens . Only an efficient administration that knows not only to protect, but also strengthen, the rights of European citizens, can act as a levee against the advancement of forces that oppose the development of our own Union. The figure of the European Ombudsman, still unfortunately little known by the vast majority of citizens, is and must be increasingly the first levee against irregular actions or carried out in a manner illegitimate by any EU institution. I think the activity carried out in 2015 has been good. I call on the Commission to promote more and more, among its citizens, the European Ombudsman.

name: Ivica Tolić (PPE)
text: written. - I support the 2015 Report on the European Ombudsman's Annual Report on the Action of the European Ombudsman. Emily O'Reilly's activity as the European Ombudsman which connects to the network of the Ombudsman of the Member States successfully responds to the complaints of citizens of the Union. The above report is a reliable indicator of the exhaustion of the Ombudsman's work which helps individuals, businesses and associations facing irregularities in the treatment of EU institutions. In 2015, the Office of the European Ombudsman helped 17 033 European citizens and this information itself indicates the necessity of fostering the tradition of existence of the Ombudsman institution, both at the European Union and at the level of all Member States.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - I supported the European Parliament's proposal for a resolution on the annual report from the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2015. The report was similar to that for 2014. It summarised the main problems and provided key information on the activities of the European Ombudsman. The Guardian helps individuals, businesses and associations who face irregularities in the European Institutions. In 2015, the European Ombudsman's office helped 17,033 citizens. Little more than half of the problems the Guardian was dealing with concerned the European Commission. Most of all, more complaints or desire for help came from Spain. The Guardian's office has also issued quite a few reports on how to improve some procedures and what impact these improvements would have. The European Ombudsman works closely with the Member States. These include national and regional ombudsmen, petition commissions and similar structures. 2015 was groundbreaking in this sense because the Ombudsman started reforms to the entire system of ombudsmen (over 95 offices in 36 European countries).

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report on the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2015. The report reflects many of Mrs Emilly O'Reilly's positive actions, in which we highlight the importance of an institution such as the Ombudsman, to ensure the interests of citizens and safeguard their rights against possible bad practices in administrations. It is also important to know that Spain is far leading the number of complaints to the Ombudsman, as well as to the Committee on Petitions. The report also reflects efforts to achieve greater transparency in the TTIP and CETA negotiations, in decision-making, public access to documents; the problem of revolving doors, violations of rights by Frontex and Member States in the migrant crisis; or the rights of minority groups and urges it to safeguard citizens' rights and the interests of good administration vis-à-vis the ECB and the European Commission. That is why, although improved, we see positively the Ombudsman's accountability and the report that has been presented on how to improve her activities.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on the European Ombudsman 2015 report because despite attention paid in violations of certain EU citizens’ rights in several countries, in particular Hungary and Poland, she didn’t pay attention to what is happening in Catalonia: Spain’s judicial actions against Catalans and violation of fundamental democratic rights of the Catalans, including the right to decide their future in a referendum. Moreover when I requested a meeting with the EU ombudsman last year, she didn’t take the time to listen to me.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. — A lot of openness in terms of transparency, since the Commission gives only what it wants, whether in the field of TTIP, tobacco or EMIS (emissions in the automotive sector). As for aid to migrants, it itself justifies a vote against it. Similarly, the fight against slipper appears to be failing with the recruitment of Barroso to Goldman Sachs. The report also promotes whistleblowers, too often exposed to professional or even criminal retaliation (point N). But the best-known whistleblowers, Snowden and Assange, have not been protected in Europe, which makes the good intentions shown on them quite hypocritical. I therefore voted against this report.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: in writing. “The report is presented in an attractive way highlighting the main problems and ensuring the adequate initiatives and actions of the European Ombudsman. As last year, the presentation was accompanied by a number of information and detailed statistics approximating the Ombudsman's work, which allows for a direct and easy comparison. Unfortunately, the report appeared on the European Ombudsman's website in English only, which limits the scope of readers. I supported the resolution accepting the ERPO report.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report on the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2015. The report reflects many of Mrs Emilly O'Reilly's positive actions, in which we highlight the importance of an institution such as the Ombudsman, to ensure the interests of citizens and safeguard their rights against possible bad practices in administrations. It is also important to know that Spain is far leading the number of complaints to the Ombudsman, as well as to the Committee on Petitions. The report also reflects efforts to achieve greater transparency in the TTIP and CETA negotiations, in decision-making, public access to documents; the problem of revolving doors, violations of rights by Frontex and Member States in the migrant crisis; or the rights of minority groups and urges it to safeguard citizens' rights and the interests of good administration vis-à-vis the ECB and the European Commission. That is why, although improved, we see positively the Ombudsman's accountability and the report that has been presented on how to improve her activities.
