name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I support the Ombudsman's inquiry into the setting up of Commission expert groups and the transparency of their work; I note that the Commission is trying to open these groups to the public, and I stress the need for further action to ensure full transparency.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the annual report on the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2015. The resolution welcomes the continued efforts of the European Ombudsman to increase transparency in the TTIP negotiations through proposals to the Commission. Moreover, it supports the Ombudsman’s efforts to make lobbying more transparent. I voted in favour because I believe that effectively tackling all sources of conflict of interest is crucial in order to achieve good administration and ensure the credibility of political and technical decision-making.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report congratulates the current European Ombudsman for her work during 2015, in which, in addition to responding to more than 17,000 European citizens who reported cases of maladministration, she decided to open eight strategic investigations on key issues such as lack of transparency in negotiations TTIP, the protection of whistleblowers, revolving doors, limitations on the European Citizens' Initiative or the violation of fundamental human rights resulting from forced deportations from Frontex. In fact, this report expresses concern about the flagrant case of revolving doors represented by former European Commission President José Manuel Durão Barroso, currently head of Goldman Sachs. I therefore believe that this is a positive report which calls for more transparency and I join her support for the work of the European Ombudsman.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: — I voted in favour because the European Ombudsman's office has dealt with 48 840 complaints since 2005.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The report welcomes a number of aspects on which we disagree. For us, there is no transparency and no transparency in the TTIP negotiations, let alone in the ECB. While recognising positive aspects such as the condemnation of the promiscuity between the European Commission and the major economic groups, particularly at the level of so-called revolving doors, we believe that the text continues to pass alongside the enormous democratic deficit of the whole process of integration of this EU.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: in writing. - This report deals with the activities of the European Ombudsman for 2015, which presents various initiatives and actions of the European Ombudsman. The European Ombudsman's efforts to increase transparency in the TTIP negotiations are welcomed. The Commission is expected to publish a large number of TTIP documents. It is regrettable that the EP Committee of Inquiry on Carbon Measurements in the Automotive Sector (EMIS) was supplied by the Commission with only partial documents and therefore a lack of relative information. Calls for greater transparency in Eurogroup meetings. The introduction of a complaint mechanism for possible Fundamental rights violations by Frontex in connection with the forced return of irregular migrants will be supported. It also commends the inclusion of such a mechanism in the European Border and Coast Guard Regulation. Lobbying should be made more transparent. In particular, in the context of the Commission meeting with tobacco producers. As more transparency is generally called for, particularly in the many TTIP documents, Eurogroup meetings and lobbying, I supported this report.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the activity of the European Ombudsman in 2015. It is necessary to highlight the good work done by the European Ombudsman Emily O'Reilly in 2015 and that is why I think it is appropriate to extend the mandate of the Ombudsman, who is a central figure in bringing the Ombudsman closer to Europe to the citizens.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU Ombudsman does important work to guarantee the EU carries out its work to a high standard. I welcome the Ombudsman’s effort to promote greater transparency in EU decision-making, and wholeheartedly support her recent work in bringing about the investigation of Manuel Barroso for conflict of interests regarding his Goldman Sachs appointment.

name: Lieve Wierinck (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I decided to vote in favour of this resolution since I agree with the call to inquire into the establishment of ‘secure reading rooms’. I welcome the Frontex complaints mechanism and I commend the inclusion of such a mechanism in the new European Border and Coast Guard regulation. I believe that transparency here is again a crucial element. I support the European Ombudsman’s determination to make the workings of the European Central Bank more transparent and compliant with a high standard of governance. I agree with the call for greater transparency in Eurogroup meetings, beyond the steps already taken by its President following an intervention by the European Ombudsman. Since I care a lot about human rights, I welcome the introduction of a complaints mechanism for potential fundamental rights infringements. Finally, I support the Ombudsman's efforts in dealing with discrimination cases and the efforts to ensure impartiality in Commission decision-making on competition matters.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: in writing. — I am happy to support this report from Ombudsman O'Reilly, who, like last year, has done a great job in this position. The report contains a lot of interesting information about initiatives and actions related to its agenda. I consider the Office of the Ombudsman very important because the opportunity to address it is one of the fundamental rights of EU citizens. Moreover, I also appreciate that the European Ombudsman is, on the other hand, in close contact with EU institutions helping to improve the quality of services, but also with its counterparts in the individual Member States through a newly reformed and expanded European network of ombudsmen.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing. - I supported the resolution mapping the activities of the European Ombudsman for 2015. This was the follow-up of the Ombudsman's annual report, which she assessed in detail and proposed its approval. The report commended the Ombudsman for her excellent work and efforts and highlighted some of the most important points. These are undoubtedly the efforts to achieve as much transparency as possible within the institutions of the European Union and questions about the transparency of the lobby. The report also addressed conflicts of interest in the European Commission or complaints handling procedures. I also particularly appreciate the part of the report devoted to cases of discrimination and assistance for people with disabilities.

name: Željana Zovko (PPE)
text: written. - I support the resolution on the annual report on the work of the European Ombudsman in 2015. The resolution expresses congratulations to Emily O'Reilly for her outstanding work and efforts in acting as Ombudswoman with the aim of improving the quality of services offered to citizens by the European administration. This resolution continues to address the existing problems of the day-to-day functioning of the European Union, which continues to struggle with problems of low transparency, democratic deficit and a large share of informal negotiations unavailable to the public between the three main institutions of the European Union. The entire negotiation processes, to the extent permitted by the matter of negotiations, should be more open to the public, because the impression is that the decision-making process has been completely isolated and taken away from citizens and that the political interests of the negotiating parties are promoted. In good faith and hope in European institutions, it is important to raise awareness to citizens about activities, negotiations, agreements and to inform in detail about the changes that each decision or act has for the daily lives of citizens. The European Parliament should express its undoubted support for the work of the European Ombudsman, but also for national ombudsmen. The system must serve and be accountable to citizens.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing. - I supported the report on the annual report on the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2015 because I believe it represents a balanced assessment of the activities of the European Ombudsman. I agree that the right of EU citizens to participate in EU policymaking is now more important than ever. I therefore support the guidelines proposed by the Ombudsman to improve the functioning of the European Citizens' Initiative in order to make this initiative more effective. I believe that the greater involvement of citizens in EU policymaking will improve the credibility of European institutions.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: — Mr President, the Commission tells us that the new VAT collection system has reduced losses by more than EUR 40 billion. It's all about the taxes that have not been collected so far. I want to make a rational, absolutely necessary support for the European institutions and for each Member State... for the taxation of value added tax in all Member States... and, in particular, in the Directive on the protection of the Union's financial interests, that is, of our money, we must be defined as a crime. I know that many Member States oppose the definition of VAT fraud as a criminal offence. Must be felony. Most of the money is lost precisely thanks to the carousel of VAT on European funds. If we let this money go back into the pockets of cross-border thieves, who steal cross-border, we will not do anything, we will not save anything and we will not fight fraud at all. So, once again, VAT fraud must be a crime in all Member States in the new directive.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I supported this report on the fight against VAT fraud. Right now, Irish Revenue is carrying out an extensive examination and review of the flat-rate scheme for farmers and other players in the poultry sector. The Commission is also investigating the matter on the basis of a complaint that a colleague and I submitted, specifically in respect of Sicín Co-operative Society and the processor Carton Bros. In particular, Irish Revenue has said, in response to the Commission, that Ireland is aware there is a risk that manipulation of the price of feed sold by the processor to the Co-op, and then on to the members of the Co-op, could artificially increase the consideration charged by the member to the Co-op for his rearing services, thereby increasing the amount of the flat-rate addition in respect of the rearing services. In my view, when the price of feed is artificially increased it increases the price of flesh and artificially increases the amount of flat-rate VAT that can be claimed back. This basically means that it is taken out of the amount of VAT paid by ordinary citizens on their purchases and by businesses who do not have specific arrangements. We are all the poorer for it.

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE).
text: - Mr President! Once again, the old truth has confirmed that temporary solutions are the most durable. It will soon be a quarter of a century since the temporary VAT regime began to take effect under the single market. Everyone was aware at the time that it was imperfect, prone to fraud and manipulation. The Commission then undertook that it would quickly prepare final, improved regulations, but only now announces that it intends to propose by 2017. The assumptions put forward by the Commission indicate that it has adopted minimalist objectives. However, this should not be surprised, given that all Member States must agree to this piece of legislation. The gap in VAT payments in some Member States is close to 40%. This situation needs rapid improvement, it would be good to look at the solutions applied in some Member States and put them under discussion. One solution is to adopt so-called reverse VAT, and so the principle that the payer would be the consumer of the product and service. This solution allows, though, in part, to bridge many loopholes and make it difficult to bypass the law. At least such applications flow from countries where such a system has been partially introduced. The Union and its Member States cannot afford such huge losses in taxes, especially during a period of budgetary stability problems and increasing public expenditure. I therefore wish the Commission good luck and persistence in this topic and therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I am pleased to support this report, which seeks to curb widespread fraud involving VAT by establishing a reverse charging system, as excellently authored by my colleague, Werner Langen. Putting in place a definitive VAT system will help to close the VAT gap, which for Ireland was under 10% in 2014. This still equates to over EUR 1 billion in uncollected VAT revenue, which through the provisions contained in the report will hopefully be better channelled into meeting the exigencies of the country in the future. I think we are heading in the right direction, and I look forward to the evaluation of pilot programmes in other Member States, which highlight how knowledge sharing and systems of best practice are central elements to the success and development of the Union. The fight against fraud has to continue. During the week we also discussed fighting against money laundering and its impact on terrorist activities, etc. If we can close the gap there in a whole area of fraud, citizens would have to pay less tax and services could be improved.

name: Lars Adaktusson (PPE)
text: in writing. — Today the European Parliament voted on a report dealing with the Commission's ongoing work on revising EU VAT law. With a few minor updates, the EU has had the same VAT laws since the early 90s, and the system is so complex that it represents a real obstacle to small businesses operating in several European countries. The report therefore welcomes the review, which I am also doing. I therefore voted in favour of the report. However, I would like to emphasise that I assume that Sweden's possibility of VAT exemption for the non-profit sector and a lower cultural VAT is protected in future negotiations. Likewise, I would like to highlight the importance of exempting digital publications in the future from the common minimum level of VAT. The media industry is evolving, and it is important that VAT rules do not get in the way.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ This report intends to reform the VAT system by proposing to apply the principle of taxation in the country of destination of goods and services, replacing the current principle the country of origin, which has not proved effective enough in adequately protecting competition and preventing fraud. This new system is also being extended to cross-border operations. Although there are some positive proposals, some critical issues remain, such as the harmonization and total convergence of systems which are poorly reconcile with the values of justice and social fairness and growth sustainable and development. A transparent, public and digital single European register of companies is lacking, and no mention is made about greater empowerment of the banking system. For these reasons I abstained.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this own-initiative report which sets Parliament's position on the Commission's action plan to establish a single European VAT area. VAT is a tax that collects around EUR 1 trillion per year, in addition to being partly a Union's own resource. However, VAT fraud is estimated at EUR 170 billion, of which 50 000 is due to cross-border fraud. The various attempts to update the system have failed because of the lack of consensus in the Council. The report is generally positive, in calling for further harmonisation, while the proposal for the VAT Charge Reversal Mechanism between employers, which the S&D Group and Spanish socialists do not share. The PSOE also expects that the forthcoming revision of the VAT Directive will give effect to the proposal to create a European list of products and services which may benefit from the reduced and super-reduced rates.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against this report, although it contains many positive points, because it is not possible to talk about VAT without understanding its social and redistributive implications. The report contains a number of measures to be envisaged in the forthcoming 2017 VAT proposal; from the signalling of prioritizing research to major fraudsters, to many points on simplification absolutely necessary for SMEs. However, it is marked in this report that there is no consideration of the social impact of this tax, even in a context where the Commission 'recommends' to collect more through this type of indirect taxes. This absence is inexplicable when we are debating our political position on it, and that is why, despite the many logical proposals, I had to vote against this report.

name: Martina Anderson Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – While there were some positive aspects in this report, we voted against overall due to its infringements on national sovereignty in relation to tax, and its promotion of a regressive tax (VAT). The report supports a further transfer of powers on VAT to the Commission by calling for a single common EU VAT area. While we need to tackle VAT fraud across the EU, we also need to ensure decisions about VAT rates and exemptions are in the hands of locally accountable governments. For example, the Irish Government claims that EU rules don’t allow a lower rate on life-saving defibrillators. VAT, like all indirect taxes, has a regressive effect on distribution, and the poor lose the largest portion of their income. We should ensure our VAT systems include both luxury rates and reduced rates on essential items, and this report calls for a reduction in the items of VAT that can receive an exception or reduced rate, which we are opposed to.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: in writing. — Last April, as Socialists, we welcomed the presentation by the European Commission of an action plan on VAT, a necessary first step. The report adopted today in plenary allows us to go further. As a reminder, cross-border VAT fraud represents an annual loss of €50 billion for France. In total, more than €170 billion evaporates every year, while states need this money to invest, innovate and create jobs. The future VAT system must be based on the principle of destination: it must be paid where goods and services are consumed. I welcome the fact that all S&D requests have been taken into account in this report: The unanimity required to review the VAT system is the major difficulty, hence the importance for the Council to listen to the European Parliament. Finally, in parallel with this reform, I welcome Mr Moscovici's announcement of a specific proposal to align VAT rates for the e-book and online press with those of paper media.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on the establishment of a definitive VAT system and the fight against VAT fraud. VAT is a significant and growing source of EU revenue, with nearly 1 trillion in 2014. EUR. It accounts for about 7 percent. The EU's gross domestic product is also one of the sources of the EU's own resources. The existing VAT system has not been protected from fraud from the outset. Although various initiatives have been taken, the reduction of fraud has not yet been successful. The biggest obstacle to the reform of the VAT system is the unanimous agreement of the Member States. Until now, the implementation of fundamental reforms has been delayed or blocked due to Member States that continue to defend their old primary systems and do not adequately fulfil their duties and controls related to the fight against fraud. I agree with the rapporteur that the creation of a definitive VAT system will contribute to the fight against VAT fraud, and the extension and application of the proposed reverse charge system across the EU could benefit from a sustainable VAT system. This model would no longer require the full deduction and refund procedure, reduce distortions of competition and the financing and administration burden for entrepreneurs.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on 'Towards a definitive system of value added tax (VAT) and the fight against VAT fraud', because I believe it is important to improve the existing system and to carry out fundamental reforms in order to eliminate or eliminate significantly limit the problems it presents.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: in writing. - The EU's current common VAT system was established in 1993 as a transitional solution towards a definitive settlement. The report is the European Parliament's response to the Commission's VAT Action Plan presented in April. The current legal situation is very complicated, as there are many different VAT rates and exceptions. The action plan provides for the introduction of a simpler, fairer and definitive VAT system based on the principle of taxation in the country of destination of goods and services. Parliament welcomed this plan and called, among other things, for the goods and services to which reduced rates may be applied at EU level and for Member States to be allowed to determine the rates themselves as long as they are above a fixed minimum rate. I support Parliament's report because it is necessary to simplify the VAT system in order to guarantee the functioning of the digital single market and to improve the situation of cross-border SMEs.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In April, the Commission announced several initiatives to combat VAT fraud. The current system dates back to 1993 and was intended to be transitional, but not adapted to the digital age, creates numerous additional costs, particularly for SMEs and cross-border transactions, and promotes fraud. To remedy this, the Commission proposes the abandonment of the principle of taxation in the country of origin, short-term measures against fraud, greater flexibility for States to set rates and measures specific to electronic commerce. In particular, the report endorsed the abandonment of the principle of taxation in the country of origin to that of the country of destination. This is the measure most contested by professionals. Specifically, the supplier of goods or services will collect VAT from his customer and, if he resides abroad, applying the foreign rate. The main risk is a rapidly unmanageable system, since companies selling for export will have to juggle the 89 rates in force in the Union. The Commission could use this argument to better impose its ultimate solution, namely harmonization of rates. I abstained.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution because it calls for further EU-wide cooperation on VAT and will lead to further powers being handed to the EU Commission.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. — Reflection on the issue of VAT is important because it generated nearly a trillion euros in 2014, or around 7% of European GDP. Until now, nothing has been able to prevent fraud, which represents significant amounts. Reducing distortions of competition is therefore necessary to try to stem these fraudulent practices. The consolidation of the system is a priority and must be accompanied by new mechanisms. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: in writing. — The report concerns the road towards final value added tax (VAT) and the fight against VAT fraud. The VAT system, which has existed in the European Union since 1993, was designed to be a transitional regime, but it was at the mercy of fraud from the outset. Despite a number of initiatives, they have not yet been able to eliminate fraud. The Commission estimates that VAT loss across the EU is around €170 billion a year, of which only the disappearing merchant (carousel fraud) criminal organisations cause a loss of revenue of €40 to €60 billion a year. It is also a problem that the current coexistence of many different VAT rates causes great uncertainty for companies engaged in cross-border business. According to the report, the Commission will propose next year a final VAT system that will be simple, sufficiently stable and efficient and will provide less opportunities for fraud. However, Member States should be able to set their own rates as long as they correspond to the minimum rates applicable under the VAT Directive. Taxation is a national competence, but in this case the proposal seems justified, tax evasion is dragging huge money from the budgets of the Member States, which is why I supported the adoption of the motion.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: This report is based on an obvious observation, the need to combat fraud in order to arrive at a complex and unfinished project. It endorsed the abandonment of the principle of taxation in the country of origin to that of the country of destination. Specifically, the supplier of goods or services will collect VAT from his customer and, if he resides abroad, applying the foreign rate. The situation could soon become unmanageable and would give the Commission ammunition to carry out its plan, which is harmonization of rates. There are, however, significant positive points, including a reduction in the administrative burden on SMEs. I therefore abstained on this vote.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: VAT raised nearly €1 trillion in 2014. However, massive fraud is observed in most Member States. This corresponds to a loss of nearly €170 billion. In this report, we propose measures to improve the system of VAT collection, eliminate VAT fraud and reduce red tape. This text aims to simplify the business operations of SMEs and to underline the need for harmonisation at EU level in the field of tax policy. We also request a regular review of the Annex to the VAT Directive with the list of goods and services reduced in VAT. I would like to point out that VAT is an unfair tax which affects all categories of the population in the same proportion. Here too, it is the workers and pensioners who finance the tax reduction of the richest and the great fortunes.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ The VAT rules currently in force date back to 1993, they compose a system originally conceived as a transitional system which should therefore be subject to change in order to complete the common system of VAT. In Europe from the payment of this tax, about EUR 1000 billion is derived annually, corresponding to 7% of the continent's GDP. I voted in favour of the Langen report because I think it is necessary to proceed quickly to update the rules, not only to meet the needs of expanding companies and e-commerce but especially to reduce the number of scams and fraud that occur every year. The text provides for a reduction in the number of products exempt from VAT, simplification of the rules, the application of a rate which is as low as possible and the introduction of a system of payment of that tax based on the payment in the country of final destination of the good or service. The Commission is also invited to carefully study the consequences of the reverse accounting mechanism, to verify that this procedure actually reduces tax scams and simplifies really the situation for SMEs.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against this report, because I think it completely ignores the dimension and social impact of indirect taxes. I believe that there was a need for simplification in regulation, but that is not why the reduction of rates on luxury goods and other goods is not justified. Finally, the report ignores the role multinationals have played in promoting downward tax competition.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report on a definitive VAT system and combating VAT fraud. The current system was conceived in 1993 as a transitional system and the Commission's notice of April 2016 on the VAT action puts an end to the long wait to move towards a single VAT area indicating that the time for reforms has finally come. It's been too many years and it's time to have a performance that goes in that direction.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: in writing. - I abstained on this report, which has some positive elements unfortunately offset by other, more negative points. Indeed, everyone agrees that the current VAT system, which dates back to 1993, is no longer adapted to the realities of today's world, particularly in the face of the challenges posed by the digital age and the administrative and financial overburdens imposed by SMEs. According to the Commission, this inadaptation would amount to EUR 170 billion in annual shortfall and almost €50 billion in fraud. However, the solutions proposed by the Commission and, worse, the ECON committee report on this subject, completely miss the check mark of updating the system for the benefit of businesses. The abandonment of the principle of taxation in the country of origin to the country of destination is rejected by professionals. We know that behind this is a real strategy of the shock, as the Commission seeks to create a cacophony in order to better impose, in the long term, its system of harmonisation of rates and thus create a “European VAT”, which would deprive Member States of a significant part of their tax revenues (50% for the French budget).

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: In writing. ‒ The text of the Langen report analysing the own-initiative report on possible developments in VAT regulation does not convince me because it has steps that could open to strong future criticalities. That is why I did not intense to support this text with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this own-initiative report which sets Parliament's position on the Commission's action plan to establish a single European VAT area. VAT is a tax that collects around EUR 1 trillion per year, in addition to being partly a Union's own resource. However, VAT fraud is estimated at EUR 170 billion, of which 50 000 is due to cross-border fraud. The various attempts to update the system have failed because of the lack of consensus in the Council. The report is generally positive, in calling for further harmonisation, while the proposal for the VAT Charge Reversal Mechanism between employers, which the S&D Group and Spanish socialists do not share. The PSOE also expects that the forthcoming revision of the VAT Directive will give effect to the proposal to create a European list of products and services which may benefit from the reduced and super-reduced rates.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report because Parliament advocated the establishment of a definitive VAT system and the fight against VAT evasion. On 1 January 1993, the establishment of the common market led to the abolition of border controls in intra-Community trade and whereas the European Union value added tax has been in place since 1993 Under Articles 402 to 404 of the Value Added Tax Directive in force, the system is only a temporary and transitional procedure. The Commission is obliged to report every four years to the European Parliament and the Council on the functioning of the existing VAT system and, in particular, the transitional procedures. The existing VAT system — particularly when it is applied to cross-border transactions by large corporations — is not protected from fraud, tax avoidance strategies, VAT not collected in insolvency or incorrect calculation. Therefore welcomes the Commission's intention to present a proposal by 2017 for a definitive VAT system that is simple, fair, reliable, effective and more protected against fraud.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: in writing. — I agree with the intention to take additional measures against fraud and to support the further development of the existing system of value added tax therefore all my support for these proposals in the European Parliament. For this important improvement, we need thorough reforms to eliminate or at least significantly reduce the problems of collecting VAT in the EU. In my view, agreement on the definitive value added tax regime requires joint efforts by the Member States which can lead to a consensus on a better functioning VAT system. I also find it justified calls for a clearer vision of a simpler system with fewer exceptions and in conjunction with a pragmatic approach that will respect the interests of a rapidly evolving digital economy.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: written. — I support this Report, which aims to fix proposals to improve the VAT collection system, eradicate VAT fraud and reduce red ribbons. It also aims to simplify business and, most importantly, highlight the need for harmonisation at EU level on tax rules.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the establishment of a Valued Added Tax system and for strengthening the fight against VAT fraud by endorsing this resolution. As a matter of fact, the Commission will propose a VAT system by 2017 and in the resolution we stressed the need to have it less susceptible to fraud. In this regard, we urged the Commission to amend the VAT Directive with the aim of achieving further harmonisation between Member States’ systems.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Value added tax in the EU is a significant source of revenue; but its current system is vulnerable to fraud. However, the requirement for unanimity among Member States is an obstacle to the reform of the VAT system. In its action plan, the Commission will present a legislative proposal for a definitive VAT system based on the principle of taxation in the country of destination; moving away from the country's principle of origin. It will also present a proposal to modernise VAT on cross-border trade and to grant more freedom to member states, lifting the EU of unnecessary disputes. In general, the Commission is content with proposals for enhanced cooperation and hopes for greater confidence among tax administrations. A lasting VAT system could be the extension of the reverse accounting mechanism to the whole of the EU and for all operations between companies. With it, collection and reimbursement of input tax become redundant, distortions of competition would be reduced and entrepreneurs would enjoy huge relief in terms of funding and administrative obligations. It is therefore incomprehensible the Commission's reserve position for the use of this mechanism. It has already proved effective in some areas particularly vulnerable to fraud in certain Member States.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: This report aims to combat VAT fraud, valued at EUR 50 billion. To remedy this, the European Commission presented last April a project that included the abandonment of the principle of taxation in the country of origin, greater flexibility for Member States in fixing rates and measures specific to electronic commerce. However, this report is reserved for the effectiveness of these proposals, considering that they are based on the capacity of national governments to better coordinate each other. It is therefore called for the introduction of the generalization of self-liquidation for transactions between professionals. This will put the payment burden on the last link of the chain, making the system even more vulnerable to fraud. Furthermore, with the abandonment of the principle of taxation in the country of origin, our exporters will have to continuously juggle the 89 VAT rates in force in the Union, thus giving the European Commission an additional argument to impose on Member States a harmonization of rates. However, I abstained on this report, which attempts to provide concrete answers to the fight against this tax evasion.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. - The free movement of people and goods within the EU also entails illegalities committed by European citizens at a trans-phontaler level. For VAT fraud alone, annual losses of EUR 60 billion are estimated. Cross-border transactions involve high administrative costs, which are hard to bear for SMEs. In order to avoid these, more simplified rules are required through cross-border cooperation between authorities, which will reduce the administrative burden using a common digital reporting base. In view of the rapid evolution of e-commerce, it is necessary to identify measures aimed at increasing cooperation between Member States on digital transactions in order to implement an integrated and comprehensive strategy to combat e-fraud. To meet new challenges, tax authorities need to adopt new technologies so that transactions flow supervision can be carried out in real time. Connecting all payment terminals to an on-line system is a safe and effective way to combat VAT fraud. I have expressed myself in favour of this report, bearing in mind that late reporting is another obstacle to the fight against fraud, and national tax authorities must deal with facilitating the exchange of information with judicial authorities as a matter of priority, as well as with the authorities of Europol and OLAF.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this own-initiative report which sets Parliament's position on the Commission's action plan to establish a single European VAT area. VAT is a tax that collects around EUR 1 trillion per year, in addition to being partly a Union's own resource. However, VAT fraud is estimated at EUR 170 billion, of which 50 000 is due to cross-border fraud. The various attempts to update the system have failed because of the lack of consensus in the Council. The report is generally positive, in calling for further harmonisation, while the proposal for the VAT Charge Reversal Mechanism between employers, which the S&D Group and Spanish socialists do not share. The PSOE also expects that the forthcoming revision of the VAT Directive will give effect to the proposal to create a European list of products and services which may benefit from the reduced and super-reduced rates.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: in writing. — The Union has no power in matters of taxation except for indirect taxation: VAT and excise duties (alcohol, tobacco, petroleum). Part of the VAT revenue constitutes a Union's own resource, representing €17.667 billion of the European budget, or 12.27% of the total EU revenue. We need a European framework for VAT in order to prevent Member States from changing the VAT rate to lower the cost of goods or services and thus create unfair competition. That is why we have the VAT Directive, which establishes a minimum standard rate of 15%. However, we need to go further and create a real definitive VAT system that will offer more convergence while leaving Member States flexibility in defining their rates. In addition, a European system will help to fight VAT fraud more effectively. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ After careful consideration and debate in the Chamber I voted positive to the report on “Towards a definitive VAT system and fight against fraud against VAT”, as I believe that It contains a number of instances and programme points which can inspire and encourage an improvement in the current VAT system, as announced by the Commission in its Communication of 7 April. As is known, in fact, the detrimental effects of VAT distortions are negatively reflected on the basic principles of the Union, if the effects on free competition are considered, on the correct procurement of EU financial resources, on small and medium-sized enterprises, creating a distorted fiscal environment. These distortions are associated, with multiplicative effect, with those of tax avoidance and evasion, tax ruling, vulnerability to VAT fraud. First of all, the phenomenon of carousel fraud, the financial sap of criminal activities, which exploit information differences between the various Member States and generate up to EUR 53 billion of non-revenue of VAT each year.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report as I welcome in principle the Commission’s intention to propose a definitive VAT system by 2017 that is simple, fair, robust, efficient and less susceptible to fraud. Although ambitious, I believe it will aid the proper functioning of the digital single market and enhance cross-border trading.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I am convinced that the system of VAT in the EU needs modernisation and reform. We should aim at simplification of the system and development of mechanisms which can prevent frauds in VAT area. We also need to improve cooperation between the Member States and to enhance exchange of information.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We have voted on the report towards a definitive system of value added tax and the fight against VAT fraud, which contains some positive elements in the effort to ensure that legality is respected. However, this report fails to find sufficient solutions to cover the differences between Member States and, although the proposal to simplify VAT systems is correct, the proposed procedure is vague and incomplete. Therefore, I have decided to abstain.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I very welcome the Commission's intention to propose a final VAT system by 2017, provided that it is as simple, fair, robust, efficient as possible beyond that impregnable from fraud. Revenues from VAT revenue amounted to EUR 1 bln in 2014, however the system has vulnerabilities in many respects and, at the same time, requires fewer exemptions and derogations from the States members in order for proper functioning to be achievable. Therefore, unanimity will be a necessary premise for obtaining a more functional agreement. The definitive system is based on the principle of taxation in the country which is the final destination of goods and it will be up to the authorities of individual states to ensure that VAT is paid through simple ways and in favour of SMEs. Consequently, cooperation and the exchange of information between the individual tax administrations of the Member States must be enriched, also the weak activity of Eurofisc, the European platform of tax advice, requires development plans. Finally, I support the option proposed by the Commission to regularly review the list of goods and services eligible for reduced rates, provided that the list in question takes account of the priorities policies such as social, gender, health, environmental, nutritional and cultural aspects.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report ‘Towards a definitive VAT system and fighting VAT fraud’.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report because I support the introduction of a definitive VAT system, which is easy to apply, provides for little exception clauses, is fair and leaves little room for fraud. The current taxation in the Member State of origin has proved impracticable. For SMEs in particular, however, practical and understandable rules are needed to make cross-border transport easier. The same applies to the Digital Single Market.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ The fight against tax fraud is one of the main challenges in the field for Member States; each year VAT fraud costs countries almost 50 billion euros and consequently, European taxpayers. Not only that the protection of the Union's financial interests is a key element in strengthening and increasing the confidence of citizens. The idea of a new action plan on VAT is therefore fundamental to the establishment of a deeper and fairer internal market so as to achieve even more effectively tax justice, employment, investment and competitiveness. This is why the European Parliament has made specific demands: to take measures to strengthen the effectiveness of VAT systems to ensure better compliance with VAT rules; to minimize unnecessary administrative charges, in particular for SMEs; introducing a VAT free threshold to help start ups and micro-enterprises; extend the single electronic procedure for registration and payment VAT to cross-border online sales. Growth can start from here too!

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I agree that the Commission should propose amendments to the VAT Directive with a view to enabling a technologically neutral application of VAT rules that will ensure that the physical and digital versions of a given product are treated in the same way for e-commerce sales. The lack of harmonisation in the VAT threshold entails high transaction costs for SMEs operating in e-commerce activities and needs to be addressed. I favour greater transparency allowing for proper scrutiny, and the adoption of a more structured and ‘risk-based’ approach, since such are key to detect and prevent fraud schemes and corruption. I regret that administrative cooperation among Member States in fighting VAT fraud is still not efficient when it comes to coping with intra-EU VAT evasion and fraud mechanisms, or to managing cross-border transactions or trading.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ In this regard, my vote is abstention, it is neutral. Since, on the one hand, the report proposes positive developments in this area, thanks also to the amendments we have tabled and included, with regard to greater transparency, on the other hand, it has unfortunately not been able to respond adequately to other issues on this issue. For example: there is a lack of the creation of a single European register that is publicly accessible and consequently transparent, then no greater empowerment of the banking system is expected, Although we had tabled amendments to ensure that this should be taken into account.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against this report, although it contains many positive points, because it is not possible to talk about VAT without understanding its social and redistributive implications. The report contains a number of measures to be envisaged in the forthcoming 2017 VAT proposal; from the signalling of prioritizing research to major fraudsters, to many points on simplification absolutely necessary for SMEs. However, it is marked in this report that there is no consideration of the social impact of this tax, even in a context where the Commission 'recommends' to collect more through this type of indirect taxes. This absence is inexplicable when we are debating our political position on it, and that is why, despite the many logical proposals, I had to vote against this report.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: ‒ The amount of VAT collected is almost 1 trillion euros in 2014 and is a major source of revenue in the EU. It accounts for about 7% of the Union's GDP and provides some of the EU's own resources. From the outset, the current VAT system has been vulnerable to fraud and is now largely outdated. Despite many initiatives to remedy it, the problem remains, and the Commission considers fraud to be responsible for an overall 'VAT gap' of around 170 billion euros per year, of which at least 50 billions, due to cross-border fraud. We have made two important battles in this regard in the dossiers. The first concerns further simplification of business operations for SMEs by harmonising at European level with regard to fiscal policies. The second concerns the promotion of alternative models to reverse charge mechanism in order to ensure more serious and rigid policies on the fight against evasion. Given that both these two objectives were achieved in the final text, I vote in a positive way to these texts in order to make a major change in this regard towards a more united Europe.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. - The current European Union VAT system, established in 1993, was designed as a transitional regulation, generating an important and increasingly valuable source of revenue in the EU. It accounts for around 7% of the EU's gross domestic product and is also a source of the European Union's own income. The Commission estimates that VAT losses due to fraud amount to around €170 billion a year in total. A particular obstacle to the reform of the VAT system has proved to be the unanimity that must be achieved among the Member States. I voted to initiate a reform that would give Member States more freedom and draw up a model for a definitive VAT system. In this way, business burdens from a financial and bureaucratic point of view would be considerably reduced and fraud would be gradually eliminated.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing. — I voted against the reform of the European VAT tax system, in view of the possibility of interfering with competences belonging only to the competence of the Member States. I believe that current tax rules should not be harmonised. The European Union may use general guidance to countries in this regard. Tax rules constitute the exclusive competence of the Member States and it is up to the Member States to organise the rates and collection of VAT. In view of fears of too far-reaching interference in the state's internal affairs in this regard, I voted against.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it focuses on the creation of measures to simplify VAT, encourage trade and enhance the fight against VAT fraud. Furthermore, it looks towards measures which are simple, fair, robust, efficient and less susceptible to fraud while also recognising that it is the responsibility of the tax authorities in the various individual Member States to ensure that VAT is paid in a proper and simple way.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: This own-initiative report covers the communication from the European Commission on 7 April 2016 on the VAT Action Plan. In its action plan, the Commission announces that it intends to present a legislative proposal on a definitive VAT system. Indeed, the current EU VAT system has been in force since 1993, yet was conceived as a transitional arrangement, not intended to become definitive. I had been particularly involved in the issue of reduced rates and the list of activities that could benefit from these reduced rates. The existence of such schemes can sometimes contribute to the maintenance of economic and structuring activity in rural areas, such as those of equestrian centres. Even if there is a need to simplify the European VAT system and fight against fraud, I hope that this reduced rate system will remain flexible and efficient. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on 'Towards a definitive VAT system and combating VAT fraud. ' This report proposes several elements of reflection to simplify the VAT system and make it less susceptible to fraud, which today reaches €170 million a year. Not being able to direct us towards a system of taxation of VAT on goods and services in the country of origin, because it causes too much distortions of competition, we must simplify and secure the VAT system by strengthening cooperation between Member States.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ VAT is a consumer consumption tax and should not be charged as far as possible on undertakings. However, the European Commission estimates that fraud caused by the different taxes of VAT amounted to around EUR 170 billion per year. I believe that a definitive VAT system is also necessary for the competitive disadvantage posed by non-Community companies that are exempt from VAT for imports of small consignments. These reasons convinced me to vote in favour of the report.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing. — I abstained on this report. The current European VAT system dates back to 1993 and aimed at taxation in the country of origin: not adapted to the digital age, it creates many additional costs and the inadequate cooperation of the tax authorities favours fraud. The report is measured on certain Commission proposals, such as the generalisation of reverse payment. We have opted for a neutral position: indeed, while we are skeptical about abandoning the principle of taxation in the country of origin, administrative simplification, the fight against fraud and adapting to the digital economy seem desirable to us.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. - I abstained on the report on the final VAT system and the fight against VAT fraud because I believe that although it contains positive elements such as effective ways of combating tax fraud and good VAT practices, there are those that would rather lead to increasing the influence of the EU and withdrawing sovereignty from Member States. I do not agree with the call for more harmonisation at EU level of VAT rules, as well as the proposal for the Council to take decisions on measures to harmonise these rules.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: in writing. - For Greece the levying of high VAT is, among other things, a tool for budgetary subordination to creditors' claims. The existence of such VAT, which is borne by the final recipient of the goods or services, does not help to develop the economy. The rationalisation of VAT is the main issue, which this report deals with superficially and negatively with regard to economically weak countries.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: in writing. - Abstention: the report endorsed the abandonment of the principle of taxation in the country of origin to that of the country of destination. However, this is the measure most contested by professionals. Specifically, the supplier of goods or services will collect VAT from his customer and, if he resides abroad, applying the foreign rate.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: This own-initiative report is a response from the European Parliament to the Action Plan on VAT that the European Commission published in April this year. It provides for harmonisation of rates and increased rigidity in the establishment of lists with products subject to reduced rates, with which we disagree. It also provides for a new system of collection in international transactions with the payment of tax at the place of purchase. The report considers that the goods and services to which reduced rates may apply should be reduced. It considers that for some of the goods and services for which reduced rates may apply, this should be set jointly at EU level. For our part, we believe that minimum and reduced rates of VAT play a positive, redistributive role in a tax that is highly regressive and, for that reason, we do not accept the change, for the worse and in the name of reducing complexity and consequent obstacles to competition and the single market, how reduced and minimum VAT rates are defined.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: In writing. ‒ I vote against the report despite there are some positive and shareable points; I do not agree with the choice to accelerate the assumptions of VAT reform, especially if in the direction of a European harmonisation pushed.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: in writing. - For Greece the levying of high VAT is, among other things, a tool for budgetary subordination to creditors' claims. The existence of such VAT, which is borne by the final recipient of the goods or services, does not help to develop the economy. The rationalisation of VAT is the main issue, which this report deals with superficially and negatively with regard to economically weak countries. For these reasons, I am voting against the report on 'Towards a definitive system of value added tax (VAT) and the fight against VAT fraud'.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ VAT is a major and growing source of tax revenue in the EU, but however, the current VAT system is too vulnerable to fraud, too burdensome and complex for businesses that wish to expand beyond the Member State in which they are established. Therefore, I support the outcome of the report, which puts forward proposals to improve the VAT collection system, eradicate VAT fraud and reduce red tape, supporting the need to reform the VAT system with the aim of achieving a single EU VAT area that helps promoting employment, growth, investment and competitiveness.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report bearing in mind that the Commission submitted, on 7 April 2016, a communication on a VAT action plan, which puts an end to the long wait to move towards a single European VAT area. The collection of about EUR 1 trillion in 2014 makes VAT a major source of financing for the Union, amounting to 7% of GDP. However, the current VAT system was from the outset vulnerable to fraud, which the Commission estimates to represent around EUR 170 billion a year, at least 50 billion of which is solely due to cross-border fraud. The Commission states in its action plan that it will submit a legislative proposal with a view to establishing a definitive VAT regime which will be based on the principle of taxation in the country of destination of goods and services. We must put an end to the 23 years of interinity of the current system in order to make way for a more effective and common permanent system.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this own-initiative report which sets Parliament's position on the Commission's action plan to establish a single European VAT area. VAT is a tax that collects around EUR 1 trillion per year, in addition to being partly a Union's own resource. However, VAT fraud is estimated at EUR 170 billion, of which 50 000 is due to cross-border fraud. The various attempts to update the system have failed because of the lack of consensus in the Council. The report is generally positive, in calling for further harmonisation, while the proposal for the VAT Charge Reversal Mechanism between employers, which the S&D Group and Spanish socialists do not share. The PSOE also expects that the forthcoming revision of the VAT Directive will give effect to the proposal to create a European list of products and services which may benefit from the reduced and super-reduced rates.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this own-initiative report which sets Parliament's position on the Commission's action plan to establish a single European VAT area. VAT is a tax that collects around EUR 1 trillion per year, in addition to being partly a Union's own resource. However, VAT fraud is estimated at EUR 170 billion, of which 50 000 is due to cross-border fraud. The various attempts to update the system have failed because of the lack of consensus in the Council. The report is generally positive, in calling for further harmonisation, while the proposal for the VAT Charge Reversal Mechanism between employers, which the S&D Group and Spanish socialists do not share. The PSOE also expects that the forthcoming revision of the VAT Directive will give effect to the proposal to create a European list of products and services which may benefit from the reduced and super-reduced rates.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ 170 billion EURO: 7% of the EU's gross domestic product, slightly less than that of a member country such as Romania or the Czech Republic. This is the huge value of the “VAT gap”, which is the evasion of the payment of value-added taxes in Europe. Of these 170 billion, between 45 and 53 are attributable to intra-Community fraud, the so-called 'carousel fraud', while another 40-60 billion is directly attributable to the action of the groups Finally, 50 is the billions of EURO that such VAT fraud costs European taxpayers. Some 23 years have passed since the introduction of the VAT directive in Europe - a directive which should have been purely provisional. The Commission's initiative puts an end to a prolonged wait. In the Commission's words, the system should be “simple, fair, robust, efficient and less vulnerable to fraud.” Specifically, the proposal abandons the country of origin principle, that is, the rule for which the supplier of the good collects VAT from the customer only within the country of origin, leaving ample space cross-border fraud.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the EP resolution on the EC periodic report 'towards a VAT system and combating VAT fraud' because I believe it is time for the States Members, take a serious reflection on the functioning of the existing transitional system of VAT which entered into force with the internal market in 1993, in order to reach a definitive system capable of exceeding flaws of the current system, which has generated intra-Community fraud and avoidance of VAT for revenue calculated between 45 and 53 billion per year and ends the system of derogations which have caused fraud and circumvention. I therefore shared the EP's reminder to the Member States in order to facilitate the exchange of information with legal and law enforcement authorities such as Europol and Olaf, such as Europol and Olaf, as recommended by the European Court of Auditors. Finally, I agree with the Commission that the VAT system should be based on the principle of taxation in the country of destination of goods and services, just as I believe the action plan is necessary Single European VAT, which can support a more thorough and equitable single market, helping to encourage fiscal equity, sustainable consumption, investment growth and fair competition.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on 'Towards a definitive VAT system and combating VAT fraud'. As a member of the European Parliament of the Family Party, I advocate full tax fairness and transparency. This must also apply to companies in the case of cross-border VAT.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: in writing. — Since the existence of the VAT system in 1993, it has been considered provisional. It is in favour of the Commission submitting a proposal on the definitive VAT system, which should be simple, fair, robust, efficient and less susceptible to fraud than the current transitional regime. In contrast to the transitional arrangements, the definitive VAT system should be based on the principle of taxation in the country of destination of goods and services and not on the principle of origin.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the VAT report given it is a crucial instrument to address the loss of EUR 170 billion through the so-called ‘VAT gap’ each year. I welcome that the report provides for a review of the goods and services eligible for reduced rates, allowing the UK Government to bring an end to the sanitary tax and other unfair taxes. It moreover is important to reinforce help for small and micro-businesses in the UK by calling for a reintroduction of a VAT threshold.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against this report, because I think it completely ignores the dimension and social impact of indirect taxes. I believe that there was a need for simplification in regulation, but that is not why the reduction of rates on luxury goods and other goods is not justified. Finally, the report ignores the role multinationals have played in promoting downward tax competition.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the VAT report as it will help tackle the EUR 170 million lost through the so-called VAT gap each year. It also provides for a review of the goods and services eligible for reduced rates, allowing the UK Government to bring an end to the sanitary tax and other unfair taxes.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report, which aims to define by 2017 a fair and robust VAT system to fight fraud effectively. To do so, the Member States must simplify their national tax systems so that in the long run we can achieve tax harmonisation at European level and thus put an end to the VAT differentials between Member States. This is true of the proper functioning of the single market and the competitiveness of our companies.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this own-initiative report which sets Parliament's position on the Commission's action plan to establish a single European VAT area. VAT is a tax that collects around EUR 1 trillion per year, in addition to being partly a Union's own resource. However, VAT fraud is estimated at EUR 170 billion, of which 50 000 is due to cross-border fraud. The various attempts to update the system have failed because of the lack of consensus in the Council. The report is generally positive, in calling for further harmonisation, while the proposal for the VAT Charge Reversal Mechanism between employers, which the S&D Group and Spanish socialists do not share. The PSOE also expects that the forthcoming revision of the VAT Directive will give effect to the proposal to create a European list of products and services which may benefit from the reduced and super-reduced rates.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour since I have no objections.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: in writing. — It is an important objective to tackle cross-border VAT fraud. The proposal put forward in the report to introduce a reverse charge procedure for the international movement of services and goods in other areas is a good approach. The reverse charge procedure can drastically reduce VAT fraud in intra-EU trade. It is estimated that this will result in losses of EUR 170 billion per year. The process changeover can also result in considerable bureaucratic relief, especially for export-oriented small and medium-sized enterprises. I therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Gunnar Hökmark (PPE)
text: in writing. - We have today voted in favour of the report on a new VAT system in the EU. We are doubtful of the introduction of the reverse charge method as a pilot project in single member countries. It is important with a simple system that facilitates business. Therefore, countries systems must not look too different. It is important that the reverse charge method is analyzed and evaluated carefully before deciding whether to use it. Further, we are in favour of using the destination principle to take in VAT. However, whether it is the country of destination or country of origin to collect VAT needs to be evaluated before any decisions are taken.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written. — I voted for the Report on “Towards the final VAT system and the fight against VAT fraud” because I believe it is important to improve the existing system, and as the report says, to implement thorough reforms that will eliminate or at least significantly reduce the problems of the existing system, and particularly the problem of VAT collection in Europe. For the good functioning of the Digital Single Market, a simple VAT system requires fewer exceptions, so the Commission will, by 2017, present a proposal for a final VAT system that will be simple, fair, robust, efficient and less susceptible to fraud.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. — The current system needed to be overhauled because it was not adapted to modern and digital age. However, although I associate myself with the desire to combat cross-border VAT fraud and in favour of administrative simplification, there is a risk of a new system that is difficult to manage for exporting companies in view of the large number of rates in force in the Union. This could lead the Commission to take advantage of the situation to impose its views, i.e. harmonization of rates. I abstained.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this own-initiative report which sets Parliament's position on the Commission's action plan to establish a single European VAT area. VAT is a tax that collects around EUR 1 trillion per year, in addition to being partly a Union's own resource. However, VAT fraud is estimated at EUR 170 billion, of which 50 000 is due to cross-border fraud. The various attempts to update the system have failed because of the lack of consensus in the Council. The report is generally positive, in calling for further harmonisation, while the proposal for the VAT Charge Reversal Mechanism between employers, which the S&D Group and Spanish socialists do not share. The PSOE also expects that the forthcoming revision of the VAT Directive will give effect to the proposal to create a European list of products and services which may benefit from the reduced and super-reduced rates.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. — The current system of value added tax is imperfect and therefore it is argued that the Commission has submitted a draft VAT action plan. Modernisation and simplification of the system are needed. The existing system does not adequately prevent fraud and the scale of it is enormous. In the framework of measures against tax fraud, I consider it significant and almost necessary to apply the mechanism of delegation of the tax liability to the final payer. The wider implementation of the mechanism of devolution of tax liability represents the third pillar of tax management reform in the Czech Republic and completely eliminates the so-called carousel fraud for VAT. The European Parliament report also deals with this mechanism, which is why I voted in favour of it. Cooperation within the European Union, but also with third countries, is essential to a successful fight against fraud. First of all, the rapid and regular exchange of information in the field of the internal market is an effective tool. It is therefore necessary to equip our national authorities so that they can improve tax collection, scope of controls and communication with each other. Even in light of the numerous revelations of the link of VAT tax evasion to organised crime and serious crime, including the financing of terrorism, modernisation of the existing system is necessary.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report by Mr Werner Langen on a definitive VAT system and the fight against VAT fraud. By incorporating the Commission's VAT action plan, this report calls for a simplification of the current VAT system, particularly in view of the exponential number of rates applicable within the EU. This creates enormous legal uncertainty for businesses and constitutes a barrier to cross-border trade. The report provides for the establishment of a common list of goods subject to reduced VAT rates and to be based on the principle of taxation in the Member State of final destination of the goods rather than on the principle of country of origin. I support this initiative, which addresses some of the concerns of SMEs by reducing administrative barriers. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report to finally put in place a definitive VAT system. The new system provided for in this text will be simplified and the principle of taxation in the country of destination of goods and services is much more efficient, easier to implement and better combat fraud than the current country of origin principle.

name: Εύα Καϊλή (S&D)
text: in writing. VAT is an important income factor for those Member States that need these resources in order to finance a socially fair and functional standard of living. In the European Union, VAT is equivalent to 7% of the Union's GDP. However, it is estimated that there is a VAT income gap of around EUR 150 billion per year, which is mainly caused by transnational trade because of the different VAT system in the various Member States, some of which refuse to align themselves with the other Member States, thereby maximising the risks of tax avoidance or fraud. The financial gap is therefore returning to citizens either with poor quality services or with an increased tax burden on consumption. Member States that refuse to align themselves must do so immediately and the Commission must take initiatives that ultimately ensure that the possibility for Member States to set the level of VAT is also economically neutral, simple, transparent and functional.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: in writing. - The report focuses on strengthening cooperation between Member States to combat tax evasion and fraud. MS loses EUR 50 billion per year due to VAT fraud. In Austria alone, the “VAT gap” caused by fraud and tax avoidance is 2.9 billion euros. The aim of this report is to reduce VAT fraud and reduce the VAT gap without creating administrative overhead for SMEs, or to promote the growth of SMEs and to facilitate cross-border turnover. That is why I am voting in favour of this report.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: in writing. — It is an important objective to tackle cross-border VAT fraud. The proposal put forward in the report to introduce a reverse charge procedure for the international movement of services and goods in other areas is a good approach. The reverse charge procedure can drastically reduce VAT fraud in intra-EU trade. It is estimated that this will result in losses of EUR 170 billion per year. The process changeover can also result in considerable bureaucratic relief, especially for export-oriented small and medium-sized enterprises. I therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on a definitive VAT system and the fight against VAT fraud. A simplified VAT system is needed for the proper functioning of the Digital Single Market. I support the introduction of a single European area on VAT, which should be the backbone of a deeper and fairer Single Market and contribute to the promotion of tax fairness, sustainable consumption, employment, growth, investment and competitiveness, while limiting the possibility of VAT fraud. Furthermore, I believe that the Commission should closely monitor the functioning of national tax authorities and improve their coordination. I call for all proposals to be examined in order to limit the bureaucratic burden of turnover tax for SMEs to the maximum extent. In this respect, the Commission must examine international best practices, such as the gold card scheme applicable in Singapore and Australia, recognising that the risk of fraud by some suppliers is very low. I call on the Commission to continue to monitor the proceeds of criminal organisations through VAT fraud and to present a strategy to counter the business models of criminal VAT fraud organisations, including through joint investigation teams where necessary.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: in writing. - I abstained on this report. Of course, it is trying to fight VAT fraud, but it seems to be preparing for a unification of its rates.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Since 1993, the taxation of trade in goods and services between Member States has been governed by an arrangement, which is then provided for as a “transitional” arrangement. This system, which is now difficult to qualify as “provisional” since it has been applied for 23 years, is very complex because VAT rates differ from one State to another, with levels substantially unequal for the same products. The Commission announced in April 2016 that it intended to establish a definitive VAT system, aiming at harmonising existing schemes and rates. The level will then be freely set by the national authorities, provided that it respects a minimum rate in order to avoid unfair competition. I therefore supported this report, which proposes a simplification of existing rules and provides for the principle of taxation in the country where the property is used. This will, on the one hand, allow greater legibility for companies involved in international trade and, on the other hand, to remove the uncertainties created by this system, which make it more vulnerable to fraud.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: in writing. — I abstained on the report entitled 'Towards a definitive VAT system and combating VAT fraudure'. The current system is no longer adapted to the digital age, it creates numerous surcharges, especially for SMEs and cross-border transactions, and it promotes fraud due to insufficient cooperation from the tax authorities. The Commission puts forward the figure of 170 billion annual shortfalls, and about 50 billion fraud. The report recognises the need to combat cross-border VAT fraud. Same for administrative simplification, especially for SMEs. The report also endorsed the abandonment of the principle of taxation in the country of origin to that of the country of destination. However, this is the measure most contested by professionals. Specifically, the supplier of goods or services will collect VAT from his customer and, if he resides abroad, applying the foreign rate. The main risk is the result of an unmanageable system.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: This report is based on an obvious observation, the need to combat fraud in order to arrive at a complex and unfinished project. It endorsed the abandonment of the principle of taxation in the country of origin to that of the country of destination. Specifically, the supplier of goods or services will collect VAT from his customer and, if he resides abroad, applying the foreign rate. The situation could soon become unmanageable and would give the Commission ammunition to carry out its plan, which is harmonization of rates. There are, however, significant positive points, including a reduction in the administrative burden on SMEs. I therefore abstained on this vote.

name: Sander Loones (ECR)
text: — Next year, the European Commission will present a proposal for a definitive VAT system. In the run-up to this, the Commission already launched an action plan on VAT in April. The broad lines in it look good, but it is waiting for the concrete elaboration. It is important that we finally have a definitive VAT system based on the principle of taxation in the country of destination. It is also important that more attention should be paid to e-commerce and SMEs, that fraud be tackled and that Member States should be given greater freedom in terms of tariffs. The N-VA voted against this report, in which Parliament expresses its views, because it advocates less freedom for the Member States and more harmonisation. Unfortunately, Parliament goes against the Commission's good intentions to give the Member States a little more freedom.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this own-initiative report which sets Parliament's position on the Commission's action plan to establish a single European VAT area. VAT is a tax that collects around EUR 1 trillion per year, in addition to being partly a Union's own resource.
