However, VAT fraud is estimated at EUR 170 billion, of which 50 000 is due to cross-border fraud. The various attempts to update the system have failed because of the lack of consensus in the Council. The report is generally positive, in calling for further harmonisation, while the proposal for the VAT Charge Reversal Mechanism between employers, which the S&D Group and Spanish socialists do not share. The PSOE also expects that the forthcoming revision of the VAT Directive will give effect to the proposal to create a European list of products and services which may benefit from the reduced and super-reduced rates.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this own-initiative report which sets Parliament's position on the Commission's action plan to establish a single European VAT area. VAT is a tax that collects around EUR 1 trillion per year, in addition to being partly a Union's own resource. However, VAT fraud is estimated at EUR 170 billion, of which 50 000 is due to cross-border fraud. The various attempts to update the system have failed because of the lack of consensus in the Council. The report is generally positive, in calling for further harmonisation, while the proposal for the VAT Charge Reversal Mechanism between employers, which the S&D Group and Spanish socialists do not share. The PSOE also expects that the forthcoming revision of the VAT Directive will give effect to the proposal to create a European list of products and services which may benefit from the reduced and super-reduced rates.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: in writing. — It is an important objective to tackle cross-border VAT fraud. The proposal put forward in the report to introduce a reverse charge procedure for the international movement of services and goods in other areas is a good approach. The reverse charge procedure can drastically reduce VAT fraud in intra-EU trade. It is estimated that this will result in losses of EUR 170 billion per year. The process changeover can also result in considerable bureaucratic relief, especially for export-oriented small and medium-sized enterprises. I therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: written. — The existing VAT system is complicated, requires major administration at the level of entrepreneurs and tax administrations and leaves a lot of room for tax fraud. That is why I supported this Report and proposals to simplify the VAT system, but neither VAT reform, nor any other, can be successful without the community of all Member States. I do not agree with the full abolition of the minimum rate of VAT, but I believe that harmonisation at EU level is certainly necessary, therefore I support the compilation of a single European list of products and services to which a reduced rate applies. It is necessary that the Commission plays the important role it plays in harmonising the whole system. Already by better cooperation and exchange of information even without other changes, we would certainly reduce the number and the devastating financial impact of frauds. I urge everyone, for starters, as we work on a new simplified and harmonised VAT system, to take this first step and protect honest entrepreneurs and citizens from fraud.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The current VAT system, in particular as it is applied by large corporations to cross-border transactions, is vulnerable to fraud. According to a Commission study, MTIC fraud alone is responsible for a VAT revenue loss of approximately EUR 45-53 billion annually. The estimated 'VAT gap' amounts to around EUR 170 billion annually, and better digital technologies are becoming available to help close this gap. Administrative cooperation among Member States in fighting VAT fraud is still not efficient when it comes to coping with intra-EU VAT evasion and fraud mechanisms, or to managing cross-border transactions or trading. I support the call on the Commission to carry out more monitoring visits to Member States, selected on a risk basis, when assessing administrative cooperation agreements.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing — The current system of value added tax in the Union was introduced in 1993 as temporary and transitional. In doing so, VAT is a significant and steadily growing income of the budgets of the Member States and the EU's own resources. The ways of tax fraud are changing, and they often take advantage of insufficient legislation in this area. I therefore support the proposal for the Commission to present a definitive value added tax system by 2017, which is simple, fair, reliable, effective and flexible, so that it can respond to fraud, eliminate it and effectively investigate and sanction it. The practical experience of various forms of tax fraud must be the basis for the elaboration of more functional legislation in this area.

name: Louis-Joseph Manscour (S&D)
text: This report is part of the VAT Action Plan published by the European Commission last April, which aims to reform the VAT system set up in 1993. Indeed, VAT is a major source of the European budget, hence the need to fight resolutely against fraud in this area. Thus, this report proposes several measures to create a simple, efficient VAT environment adapted to current challenges and facilitate cross-border transactions. The reform of the VAT system is an important issue for the improvement of the single European market. Since this report is balanced in the proposed responses against fraud, I am voting in favour.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing. - I am voting against the report on 'Towards a definitive system of value added tax (VAT) and the fight against VAT fraud' for the reasons I explained in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 23 November 2016, as well as because due to report is not complete and documented.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on towards a definitive VAT system and fighting VAT fraud as its proposals show signs of strengthening cooperation, increasing mutual trust among tax administrations, and decreasing distortion of competition. Supporting the report means that a wide economic burden would be lifted off companies and accounting would become an easier process. On the other hand, the report also emphasizes that companies will not have to be responsible for a ‘pre-finance prior to VAT charges’ and finally, that cases of non-payment of VAT because of insolvency can be greatly avoided.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This report proposes changing the current transitional VAT regime in the European Union to a definitive system based on the principle of taxation in the country of origin of the supply of goods and services. In 2014, VAT reached a revenue of almost €1 trillion, corresponding to 7% of EU GDP, and is a major financial source of own resources for the EU. Unfortunately, the current VAT system has been, from the outset, subject to tax fraud and evasion. The Commission estimates that the 'VAT gap 'as a result of fraud amounts to EUR 170 billion each year, of which 50 billion is due to cross-border fraud. In this sense, a reform of this system, simplification of bureaucratic and administrative systems and a consequent reduction in regulatory costs, as well as greater coordination between Member States in the implementation and control of the system is urgently needed. Despite some shortcomings, such as the assessment of the social impact of these measures, this report presents some important steps towards implementing the amendment of the VAT system and combating fraud. I abstained.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: In writing. — Created in 1993, the VAT system was a first step, a transitional system. Fragmented, complex and expensive, it needs to be reformed to enable the European Single Market to provide businesses with a simple VAT environment. A reform will be launched by the Commission in 2017 on the subject (VAT/SME, e-commerce, administrative cooperation and Eurofisc). Ultimately, the aim is to achieve a harmonised European VAT system facilitating trade and ensuring fair competition. The Langen report prepares Parliament's position on this future reform. The reverse liquidation mechanism was at the centre of the negotiations. Some countries (Czech Republic, Austria) are very supportive of the general use of this system as it would, in their view, reduce VAT fraud - higher in these countries. As Socialists and as a French, we are formally opposed to it because it would only move the problem to neighbouring Member States. This is a non-cooperative solution for Europe. Finally, all the red lines and demands of the Social Democrats have been taken into account, in particular the financial services that must be subject to VAT and the need for convergence of VAT rates. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: in writing. - The report focuses on enhanced cooperation between Member States to combat tax evasion and fraud and to reduce the damage caused. This does not, however, entail an additional administrative burden for SMEs. I agree with this.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour. Cross-border VAT fraud costs around 50 billion each year for EU Member States and European taxpayers. EUR. I hope that the Commission's proposal will help to protect the VAT system more from fraud and that the tax collection system will be more reliable and effective.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — Since 1993, the VAT system in force in the European Union has been conceived as a transitional regime. 'Taxation of trade between Member States' must be replaced by a definitive regime based on the principle of taxation of supplies of goods and services in the home Member State. The Council shall adopt appropriate directives with a view to supplementing the common system of VAT and, in particular, gradually restricting or eliminating derogations from that system. With the aim of 'creating a single VAT area in the Union, which is a pillar for a deeper internal market'. This report follows this logic. It aims to strengthen this unfair tax system. It also proposes to “limit exceptions” to the standard rate of VAT, which amounts to restricting the exemption of basic necessities. I am voting against this deeply unfair text.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: in writing. — The Commission has presented a communication announcing several initiatives to combat VAT fraud. The current system dates back to 1993 and was intended to be transitional, and it was to result in taxation in the country of origin. It is no longer suitable for the digital age. It creates numerous additional costs, particularly for SMEs and cross-border transactions, and promotes fraud due to insufficient cooperation from the tax authorities. To remedy this, the Commission has presented a draft around four axes: the abandonment of the principle of taxation in the country of origin, short-term measures against fraud, greater flexibility for States in fixing rates and measures specific to electronic commerce. The report therefore recognises the need to combat cross-border VAT fraud. On the other hand, it is reserved for certain Commission proposals, considering them to be insufficient and overly based on confidence in the States to coordinate better. In particular, the report endorsed the abandonment of the principle of taxation in the country of origin to that of the country of destination. However, this is the measure most contested by professionals. I therefore abstained on this report.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. - The Commission Communication of 7 April 2016 on an action plan on VAT has put an end to the long delay on the road towards a single VAT area in the EU, drawing attention to the fact that the time has come to decide. The Commission has indicated that it is going to present a legislative proposal on a definitive VAT system, according to which this scheme should be based on the principle of taxation of goods and services in the country of destination. With this proposal, the Commission is definitively distancing itself from the principle of taxation in the country of origin originally requested, which is apparently not feasible due to a number of problems and distortions of competition. Specifically, this means that the tax provision whereby the supplier of goods charges VAT to the customer will extend to cross-border trade, thereby significantly reducing the opportunities for VAT fraud. I agree with the future amendments to be proposed by the Commission, which is why I am voting in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because it prioritises the reduction of VAT fraud. It is estimated that fraud is the reason for a ‘VAT gap’ of around EUR 170 billion annually.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report ‘Towards a definite VAT system and fighting VAT fraud’, because the report simply aims to put forward proposals to improve the VAT collection system, eradicate VAT fraud and reduce red tape. It furthermore aims to simplify business operations for SMEs and most importantly, highlights the need for harmonisation at the EU level regarding taxation policies. Having said that however, I do have some reservation on certain paragraphs, which are going out of the scope of this report and are not even envisaged in the VAT Action Plan.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. — The VAT system in existence in the European Union since 1993 has been designed as a transitional scheme. 'Taxation of trade between Member States' will be replaced by definitive arrangements based on taxation in the Member State of origin of the supply of goods or services. The Council should adopt appropriate directives aimed at completing the common system of VAT and 'in particular the gradual limitation or abolition of rules derogating from that system'. The Commission Communication of 7 April 2016 on the VAT Action Plan states that the time for reform has come to an end to the long procrastination on the road to a single EU VAT area. However, according to the report from the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, the proposed initiatives and timing are not a decisive breakthrough at all. Instead of a fundamental reform of a 20-year transitional system, the Commission is satisfied with proposals for enhanced cooperation, expressing the hope that the tax authorities will vote more confidence in each other, set up a timetable and carry out other assessments. According to the report, a permanent VAT system could be created by broadening the reverse charge charge to all business transactions in Europe. This procedure has already been successful in a number of Member States in sectors exposed to fraud, and it cannot be established that the scheme does not operate more widely. I voted in favour of the draft resolution.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. — The fight against VAT fraud is a major issue. The report on objectives and some proposals will be followed for the fight against VAT fraud, the need to adapt to the digital economy and reduce the administrative burden, particularly for SMEs. However, the report makes some poorly evaluated proposals, such as the generalization of reverse payment for transactions between professionals. This solution places the payment burden on the last link, making the system vulnerable to fraud and bankruptcy. In particular, the report endorsed the abandonment of the principle of taxation in the country of origin to that of the country of destination. However, this is the measure most contested by professionals. The main risk is a rapidly unmanageable system (89 rates in force in the Union). The Commission could use this argument to better impose its ultimate solution, namely harmonization of rates. It would probably be over with unanimity. Hence our abstention.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: in writing. — This report recognises the need to combat cross-border VAT fraud, particularly carousels, which everyone agrees. Same for administrative simplification, especially for SMEs. On the other hand, it is reserved for certain Commission proposals, considering them to be insufficient and overly based on confidence in the States to coordinate better. In particular, it proposes as an alternative solution the generalization of reverse payment for transactions between professionals. This solution places the payment burden on the last link, making the system vulnerable to fraud and bankruptcy. I therefore abstain from this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the VAT report as it will help tackle the EUR 170 billion lost through the so-called ‘VAT gap’ each year. The report also provides for a review of the goods and services eligible for reduced rates, allowing the UK Government to bring an end to the sanitary tax and other unfair taxes. The report also reinforces help for small and micro-businesses in the UK by calling for a reintroduction of a VAT threshold.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this text, which constitutes a response from the European Parliament to the action plan on VAT presented by the Commission on 7 April 2016. The plan provides for a legislative proposal, by 2017, for a definitive VAT regime, based on the principle of taxation in the country of destination of goods and services rather than in the country of origin, which cannot be put into practice due to numerous problems of distortion of competition and fraud. The report welcomes the Commission's commitment to implementing a definitive VAT system that is simple, fair, robust, efficient and less vulnerable to fraud, which will also be an asset for the digital single market.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ In order for any system to function well, periodic monitoring and evaluation is necessary. It is now about taxation of trade between Member States. The legislation currently used was adopted by the European Union in 1993 and planned only to be temporary. I am convinced that we will be able to develop a much more timely and effective regulation.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In 1993 the European Union VAT system was put in place as a provisional arrangement stating that the taxation of trade between Member States should be based on the principle of taxing goods and services in the country of origin. I have voted for this report that proposes to modernise VAT for cross-border e—commerce in order to try and eliminate competitive disadvantages of EU companies against third-country suppliers that can supply VAT—free goods to consumers in the EU under the exemption for imports of small consignments.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report because I consider combating tax fraud to be one of the main challenges that we must face in the context of this single market that we all want as correctly regulated as possible. In this respect, the report adopted today calls on the European Commission to create a definitive VAT system by extending the reverse taxation procedure to all commercial transactions carried out throughout Europe. The current pre-taxation procedure and repayment of excess amounts would no longer be necessary, thus reducing the risk of fraud. At the same time, by facilitating and improving the exchange of information between Member States and competent judicial authorities (OLAF, Europol), fraud related to transactions between States with different VAT regimes can be prevented and combated more effectively.

name: Cora van Nieuwenhuizen (ALDE)
text: ‒ The VVD opposes the establishment of a European Public Prosecutor's Office and the introduction of VAT for financial services providers, as proposed in the report on combating VAT fraud. However, given the importance of combating fraud in the EU, the VVD has decided to vote in favour in the final vote on the report.

name: Андрей Новаков (PPE)
text: in writing. The report points out that with almost €1 billion in 2014, VAT is one of the main sources of revenue in the EU and its contribution is growing. VAT accounts for around 7% of the Union's gross domestic product and provides part of the EU's own resources. According to the proposed report, cross-border VAT fraud leads to losses for Member States and European taxpayers of almost €50 billion per year. VAT fraud also leads to loss of revenue for Member States and therefore for the EU, create a distorted fiscal environment that is particularly harmful to small and medium-sized enterprises. The report notes the need to coordinate Member States' efforts to reach agreement on a definitive VAT system. The report also welcomes the Commission's intention to propose by 2017 a definitive VAT system that will be simplified and fair and which limits the possibilities of fraud. The proper functioning of the digital single market is also based on a simplified VAT system.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: in writing. - VAT, with sales of almost €1 trillion a year, is a significant and growing source of revenue for each Member State. Member States are losing EUR 50 billion due to VAT fraud. I therefore advocated enhanced cooperation between Member States and I am in favour of actively combating VAT fraud.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported. The resolution concerns the erection of a fair, fraudulent and effective VAT system. The fundamental change is that VAT is paid in the State which is the final destination of the product or service.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: in writing. - VAT had revenues of almost €1 trillion in 2014 and is a major source of revenue in the EU. It represents around 7% of the Union's GDP and provides part of the EU's own resources. From the outset, the current VAT system has been vulnerable to fraud and is now largely outdated. Despite numerous initiatives, to correct this, the problem remains. I voted in favour of this report, which puts forward proposals for improving the VAT collection system, eliminating VAT fraud and reducing red tape, with a view to further simplifying business activities for small and medium-sized enterprises and, most importantly, underlines the need for harmonisation at EU level on tax policy.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ I would vote in favour of the proposal by my colleagues because I believe that the system of value added tax, which has been in force in the European Union since 1993 has always been considered a transitional regime. The Council is obliged to adopt a directive, on the one hand, to complete the common system of VAT and, on the other hand, to gradually abolish derogations from the same system. Moreover, the current tax system is proving vulnerable to fraud, in fact, to date, the Commission estimates that “the VAT gap” due by fraud is €170 billion. Therefore I would vote upvote.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: written. - I support the proposal for a resolution on the creation of a definitive VAT system and combating VAT fraud. The aim of the new VAT Action Plan is a more comprehensive and fair internal market through the EU Strategy for the Digital Single Market and the European Single VAT Area. Tackling loss of VAT revenue and tax fraud should be a priority for the EU and Member States, it also highlights the need for a more comprehensive and fairer single market to foster tax justice, sustainable spending, employment, growth, investment and competitiveness. The new action plan should undergo a detailed impact assessment. VAT is a regressive tax and has the greatest impact on low income groups, so Member States should take this fact into account when setting rates for goods frequently used by low income groups. The expert opinion on which the Commission's proposals are based is a strong foothold for the VAT system.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Value added tax in the European Union represents an important and growing source of revenue, with revenue of nearly one thousand billion euros in 2014. It equates to around 7% of European GDP and generates part of the Union's own resources. Studies by the Commission, however, show that around €170 billion is lost to fraud each year, including at least 50 billion in cross-border trade. The system of value-added tax in the EU, which has been in place since 1993, was conceived as transitional and proved inadequate to tackle fraud. It is more than ever time to define a definitive regime that eliminates the loopholes that make this fraud possible and that, at the same time, eliminates bureaucratic lengthways, simplify accounting operations for SMEs and contribute to the harmonisation of fiscal policies at European level. I therefore voted in favour of the report so that the Commission is committed to this direction.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: written. - VAT is an important and growing source of income for Member States and contributes to the EU's own resources, but the existing system is subject to fraud, tax avoidance strategies and inability to collect. The types of fraud are diverse and cover a number of economic sectors. A swift adjustment of legislation is needed to make progress towards a more efficient VAT system that would put an end to tax revenue losses. VAT fraud distorts the fiscal environment, which particularly harms SMEs, and is used by criminal organisations exploiting existing legislative gaps between Member States. It is necessary to harmonise tax policies and introduce more effective exchanges of information relating to intra-Community trade. Therefore, the Commission should analyse the impact of the non-compliance of tax rates at Union level, in particular in the case of cross-border action, and consider ways to remove those barriers. I call for the urgent and complete inclusion of services in the new system and, in particular, call for financial services to be subject to VAT. We need a single European VAT area — a genuine support for a deepened and fairer internal market which will contribute to encouraging tax justice, sustainable spending, employment, growth, investment and competitiveness while reducing the possibility of committing VAT fraud.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: This own-initiative report is a response from the European Parliament to the Action Plan on VAT that the Commission published in April this year. It provides for harmonisation of rates and increased rigidity in the establishment of lists of products subject to reduced rates. It also provides for a new system of collection in international transactions with the payment of tax at the place of purchase. However, it considers that the goods and services to which reduced rates may be applied should be reduced and that for some to whom such rates may apply should be fixed jointly at EU level. We believe that minimum and reduced VAT rates play a redistributive role in a tax that is highly regressive, and therefore we do not accept changing, for the worse and in the name of reducing complexity and consequent obstacles to competition and the single market, the way in which rates are defined reduced and minimum VAT.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ The system of value added tax, which has been in force in the European Union since 1993, was conceived as a transitional scheme. In order to prevent European undertakings from suffering a competitive disadvantage, the 'taxation of trade between Member States' regime must be replaced by a definitive regime based on the principle of taxation of supplies of goods and services in the home Member State. The current situation sees non-EU suppliers selling VAT exempt goods to EU consumers through the exemption reserved for imports of small shipments. The Commission therefore undertook to present a proposal to modernise VAT on cross-border e-commerce, in particular for SMEs. The report welcomes the Commission's intention to propose a definitive VAT system by 2017 that is simple, fair, robust, efficient and less prone to fraud.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: in writing. “The aim of this report is to discuss the Commission's work on reforming the European VAT system and combating VAT fraud across Europe. The possible lines for reform are set out in more detail in the Commission's VAT Action Plan, which was published last spring. The European Parliament expects the Commission to submit a proposal for a final VAT scheme by 2017. Nevertheless, there are many records in the report aimed at harmonising tax policy between EU Member States. I also do not support the inclusion of financial services with VAT and the creation of another body, which would be an independent European Public Prosecutor's Office. I hereby did not support the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. — Value added tax fraud and non-collection of levies represent an estimated loss of €168 billion per year in the European Union. The current system in force dates back to 1993 and required reform in order to meet the challenges of cross-border trade and e-commerce. That is why I voted in favour of this report, which provides for the establishment of a definitive VAT system based on the principle of taxation in the country of destination of goods and services. This new definitive VAT system is simpler, fairer, more efficient and therefore less vulnerable to fraud.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this own-initiative report which sets Parliament's position on the Commission's action plan to establish a single European VAT area. VAT is a tax that collects around EUR 1 trillion per year, in addition to being partly a Union's own resource. However, VAT fraud is estimated at EUR 170 billion, of which 50 000 is due to cross-border fraud. The various attempts to update the system have failed because of the lack of consensus in the Council. The report is generally positive, in calling for further harmonisation, while the proposal for the VAT Charge Reversal Mechanism between employers, which the S&D Group and Spanish socialists do not share. The PSOE also expects that the forthcoming revision of the VAT Directive will give effect to the proposal to create a European list of products and services which may benefit from the reduced and super-reduced rates.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the theme 'Towards a definitive VAT system and combating VAT evasion ', because I think it contains interesting recommendations, particularly with a view to combating tax evasion. I am in favour of a better exchange of information between the tax authorities of the Member States. According to the Commission, no less than €160 billion in VAT revenues have been lost since September 2014 due to legal tax optimization, fraud, errors, inaccuracies and negligence, delays in payment or bankruptcy. Let us hope that the VAT package presented by the Commission will put an end to these ethically dubious practices at best, at worst fraudulent.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — VAT is one of the most important sources of tax revenue. And at the same time one of the most important sources of tax fraud. The creation of a unified system would therefore become an important step towards ensuring a more transparent management of public finances. The presented document is good. It can be improved by the inclusion of several amendments amendments which call for a reduction in the number of exceptions, strengthening cooperation between States and combating tax competition, thus avoiding parasitizing some Member States at the expense of others.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. - The Commission communication on an action plan on VAT, published in April this year, suggests new proposals and guidelines for a single VAT area in the EU. This tax is a major source of revenue in the Union as a whole, corresponding to 7% of GDP. Nevertheless, the current system is unreliable and highly susceptible to fraud. That is why I believe, like the rapporteur, that this proposal is insufficient and that it does not represent a fundamental reform, because to this end we should proceed with the application of a reverse charge system throughout Europe and to all trade between companies. This is a simpler, more unified and more durable system, with fewer revenue losses and less fraud. As a regime already in place in other Member States, it is not understood that the Commission should not allow itself to be more demanding and makes a more bold proposal to apply this scheme to all Member States in a uniform manner. In view of the above and because I agree with the rapporteur's comments, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against this report, because I think it completely ignores the dimension and social impact of indirect taxes. I believe that there was a need for simplification in regulation, but that is not why the reduction of rates on luxury goods and other goods is not justified. Finally, the report ignores the role multinationals have played in promoting downward tax competition.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on ways to a definitive VAT system and to combat VAT fraud. In 2016, the Commission presented an action plan setting out a legislative proposal for a definitive VAT system. The Commission is thus abiding from the requested country of origin principle, as this was unenforceable due to a wide range of problems and distortions of competition.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against this report, although it contains many positive points, because it is not possible to talk about VAT without understanding its social and redistributive implications. The report contains a number of measures to be envisaged in the forthcoming 2017 VAT proposal; from the signalling of prioritizing research to major fraudsters, to many points on simplification absolutely necessary for SMEs. However, it is marked in this report that there is no consideration of the social impact of this tax, even in a context where the Commission 'recommends' to collect more through this type of indirect taxes. This absence is inexplicable when we are debating our political position on it, and that is why, despite the many logical proposals, I had to vote against this report.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this due to the fact that it calls for a harmonised tax scheme.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the VAT Report as it will help tackle the EUR 170 billion lost through the so-called ‘VAT gap’ each year. The report also provides for a review of the goods and services eligible for reduced rates, allowing the UK Government to bring an end to the sanitary tax and other unfair taxes. The report also reinforces help for small and micro-businesses in the UK by calling for a reintroduction of a VAT threshold.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: written. - I voted positively for this report, but this rationale of voting is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEPs solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the real quality and the amount of work, efficiency and most of all the success of the advocacy.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing. - I supported the motion for a resolution because I consider the current VAT system, particularly when it is applied by large corporations to cross-border transactions, to be insufficiently resistant to fraud, avoidance strategies, non-collection of VAT due to insolvency; or Interpretation. Although the EU and its Member States are constantly taking measures to combat VAT fraud, we continue to see that the VAT revenue gap is still estimated ranging from less than 5% to more than 40% depending on the country concerned. For me, too, it is striking that Member States are losing EUR 40-60 billion of their annual VAT revenue as a result of the activities of organised crime groups (Europol estimates), thereby seriously disrupting their efforts to consolidate public finances. In this context, I therefore agree to make even greater efforts, to strengthen cooperation between Member States and to develop comprehensive and integrated anti-fraud strategies, in particular to the current EU budgetary constraints and the increase in e-commerce over the Internet, which has weakened territorial control over the collection of VAT.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: in writing. — It is an important objective to tackle cross-border VAT fraud. The proposal put forward in the report to introduce a reverse charge procedure for the international movement of services and goods in other areas is a good approach. The reverse charge procedure can drastically reduce VAT fraud in intra-EU trade. It is estimated that this will result in losses of EUR 170 billion per year. The process changeover can also result in considerable bureaucratic relief, especially for export-oriented small and medium-sized enterprises. I therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the VAT report as it will help tackle the EUR 170 billion lost through the so-called ‘VAT gap’ each year. The report also provides for a review of the goods and services eligible for reduced rates, allowing the UK Government to bring an end to the sanitary tax and other unfair taxes. The report also reinforces help for small and micro-businesses in the UK by calling for a reintroduction of a VAT threshold.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: in writing. - I did not agree with the European Parliament resolution on 'Towards a definitive VAT system and to combat VAT fraud'. The report supports the establishment of a single European VAT area. I think this is wrong, because we need competition within the EU when it comes to the design of VAT. The report also supports the general application of the destination principle for distance selling to private individuals. This means an undermining of tax competition, because in the age of the Internet and mail order, private individuals must be able to benefit from lower VAT rates in other EU countries. Finally, on all evil, the report calls for minimum VAT rates, which are also likely to affect competition in the tax sector.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: written. — The VAT system which has existed in the European Union since 1993 is conceived as a transitional system but has been in place for 23 years. By 2017, the Commission will present a proposal for a final VAT system that will be fair and less susceptible to fraud and stresses that a simple VAT system with fewer exceptions is needed for the good functioning of the Digital Single Market. We agree with the Commission that the final VAT system should be based on the principle of taxation in the country of destination of products and services as the implementation of the principle of the country of origin was not possible. We are for the introduction of a single European VAT area. We ask the Commission to analyse the impact of different tax rates in the EU as they create great uncertainty among SMEs operating outside their own country. I accept the report because changing the way tax is calculated and simplified will help reduce tax fraud and facilitate cross-border business within the EU especially for the fast-growing digital services market.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — Although the VAT system needs to be simplified to combat fraud, this cannot be done for more speculation by multinationals. Among other things, wealth must be taxed and the wealth generated should be redistributed fairer. The report does not touch on these issues at all. We have voted against the report.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: in writing. - For Greece the levying of high VAT is, among other things, a tool for budgetary subordination to creditors' claims. The existence of such VAT, which is borne by the final recipient of the goods or services, does not help to develop the economy. The rationalisation of VAT is the main issue, which this report deals with superficially and negatively with regard to economically weak countries.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on the road towards the final VAT system and the fight against VAT fraud. As mentioned in the report, VAT fraud represents an astonishing loss of revenue for the Union, of which cross-border fraud alone amounts to at least EUR 50 billion. Like the report, I believe that this situation can only be changed through the coordinated efforts of the Member States. I agree with the finding that cooperation and exchange of information between Member States' tax authorities has not been satisfactory in the past, and therefore it is essential to increase the effectiveness of the VAT information exchange system. From now on, in particular, in the interests of SMEs, there is a great need to simplify the VAT system in terms of administrative burdens and definitions. Another important element of the report, which I also support, is the call for Member States to enable the exchange of information with judicial and law enforcement authorities, such as Europol and OLAF, in line with the recommendation of the European Court of Auditors. I also support the creation of a single, strong and independent European Public Prosecutor's Office capable of detecting, prosecuting and prosecuting crimes affecting the Union's financial interests, including VAT fraud.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: in writing. — The VAT system under the European Union has been envisaged as a transitional solution since 1993. For it was to be replaced by definitive provisions based, in principle, on the taxation of the supply of goods and the provision of services in the Member State of destination. Unfortunately after 23 years, the system remains unchanged, which contributes to widening the VAT gap and significant cross-border fraud. In 2016, the European Commission finally decided to submit a legislative proposal that the VAT system is to be based on the principle of taxation in the country of destination of goods and services, rather than as the country of origin so far. The Commission also announced a proposal to modernise and simplify the VAT system for cross-border e-commerce. The essence of this solution is to introduce a comprehensive tax service point for the online sale of material goods to final consumers and to abolish the VAT exemption for imports of small lots of goods from third country suppliers. I believe that the Commission's proposal is moving in the right direction, will facilitate cross-border activities and help reduce the current VAT gap. At the same time, I am pleased that the European Parliament document clearly emphasises that Member States remain independent in setting a standard rate and reduced VAT rate.

name: Claudiu Ciprian Tănăsescu (S&D)
text: in writing. - The need for a definitive, easy and efficient VAT system to help combat VAT fraud is obvious because VAT is an important source of income, valuable but vulnerable to Member States. The world of business, developing the most unexpected tax avoidance strategies and models, and the digital age have facilitated this world, which is negative for citizens and responsible actors in European markets. In this context, Member States are called upon to develop integrated strategies to combat fraud, with simplified collection measures, using easy and transparent reporting tools, efficient tax models, appropriate databases and facilitating the flow of information between tax and customs authorities on imports, harmonised at European level. This approach at the level of each Member State must be monitored in terms of the performance achieved by national tax authorities and coordinated at European level. I definitely voted to facilitate the substantiation and operationalisation of integrated strategies to combat fraud by setting up a portal accessible to the general public and actors, with viable, detailed information on all aspects of VAT, agreeing that Member States should set up such public information systems necessary to inform final consumers.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. - Value Added Tax (VAT) is an important source of income for the Member States of the European Union, representing at least 7% of the EU's GDP in 2014. Unfortunately, separate regulations at national level lead to losses of EUR 170 million annually, of which 50 million from cross-border fraud. The EU aims to harmonise VAT rates at Union level as a medium to long term target, with a view to streamlining collection procedures, eradicating fraud and combating corruption in this area. This will be beneficial for simplifying the operations carried out by SMEs at European level and for generating sustainable economic growth. Despite numerous initiatives to remedy the situation, however, reform proposals are constantly blocked by certain Member States. This document comes with concrete proposals from the Commission regarding the taxation of goods and services in the destination country, the introduction of a one-stop shop mechanism for online sales, the broad application of the reverse tax procedure, the development of the Eurofisc network and improving cooperation between the specialised structures of the Member States. I believe it is necessary regulation and I support the adoption of this report.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this text denouncing the Commission's scared position. The proposed initiatives and the timetable are far from a particularly decisive step forward. Instead of fundamentally reforming a transitional system that came into force more than 20 years ago, the Commission is merely proposing greater cooperation, hoping for greater confidence between tax administrations, setting a timetable and carrying out further assessments of the situation. A sustainable VAT system could consist of extending the reverse payment mechanism to all of Europe for all transactions between professionals. In this model, there is no longer an upstream tax collection and refund. In the absence of financial flows, all risks of fraud disappear. Thus, distortions of competition would be significantly reduced. In addition, this would be a considerable relief for companies in terms of financing and administrative obligations. Billing would be substantially simplified. Entrepreneurs should no longer pre-finance input VAT.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The common Value Added Tax (VAT) system plays an important role in Europe’s Single Market. Intended to limit market competition distortion, today VAT represents a major and growing source of revenue in the EU. The report on ‘Towards a definitive VAT system and fighting VAT fraud’ outlines the Action Plan, which seeks to modernise current EU VAT rules, including key principles for a future single European VAT system, short—term measures to tackle VAT fraud, update the framework for VAT rates granting Member States greater flexibility in setting them, and the simplification of VAT rules for e-commerce in the context of the Digital Single Market (DSM) Strategy and for a comprehensive VAT package to make life easier for SMEs. I voted in favour of the report because I see the value of the VAT system for the EU and believe that by improving the framework, VAT can further contribute to a strong single market.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: VAT fraud represents EUR 170 billion a year in lost income for the Member States. It is therefore necessary to adopt tools to combat this fraud in a context of budgetary difficulties. An ambitious reform of VAT, as proposed in this own-initiative report, is therefore becoming urgent. All the requirements of the S&D group have been heard. Financial services must be subject to VAT and a convergence of rates between Member States must be established. Furthermore, the Commission must initiate a study on the cost of non-convergence. Finally, a revision of the list of reduced rates should be introduced taking into account social, health, environmental, nutritional, cultural and gender aspects. If the initial report highlighted the principle of the reverse payment mechanism, which shifts fraud in neighbouring countries, I welcome the fact that it has been reduced in the report we voted for. It is now up to the Commission and the Council to take over this subject, in an area where unanimity is needed.

name: Ivica Tolić (PPE)
text: written. - I support the Proposal for a Resolution under the final VAT system and the fight against VAT fraud, since it lays the basis for harmonising the VAT system when it comes to combating VAT fraud. For the prevention of frequent fraud, it is necessary to make an immediate adjustment to legislation that would establish a single system of VAT with as few exceptions as possible. I also welcome the call for Member States to set a level playing field for private and public enterprises in sectors where they compete with each other. The abolition of possible privileges to public companies greatly increases competitiveness and facilitates the starting position in the market for private enterprises.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - I have supported the proposal for a resolution of the European Parliament on efforts for the definitive VAT system and the fight against VAT fraud. In the EU, the VAT system was introduced in 1993 as a transitional regime. It was envisaged that the final solution should be postponed and replaced by temporary solutions. VAT tax is a tax on consumption which must be borne by the final consumer. It brought almost a trillion euros to the EU's coffers in 2014, so it is an important and growing source of EU income. The poorly regulated system of VAT interpretation within EU members resulted in monetary fraud and the grey economy. Therefore, it was all the more important to find a solution as quickly as possible on the valuation of VAT among EU members. The existing system is susceptible to fraud, which needs to be solved. It is necessary to specify within which Member States set the rates of VAT (more freedom, reduced judicial proceedings). Reliable and quality impact assessments need to be carried out in cooperation with researchers and tax administrations and EU companies in order to reduce bureaucratic problems. A permanent tax system could be created by extending the system of general reverse tax liability to all intra-EU transactions. This would make the refund and charging of VAT redundant, minimizing the chances of fraud.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against this report, because I think it completely ignores the dimension and social impact of indirect taxes. I believe that there was a need for simplification in regulation, but that is not why the reduction of rates on luxury goods and other goods is not justified. Finally, the report ignores the role multinationals have played in promoting downward tax competition.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR)
text: in writing. — It is an important objective to tackle cross-border VAT fraud. The proposal put forward in the report to introduce a reverse charge procedure for the international movement of services and goods in other areas is a good approach. The reverse charge procedure can drastically reduce VAT fraud in intra-EU trade. It is estimated that this will result in losses of EUR 170 billion per year. The process changeover can also result in considerable bureaucratic relief, especially for export-oriented small and medium-sized enterprises. I therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. — Last April, the Commission presented a communication announcing several initiatives to combat VAT fraud. An essential resource of the states (50% of the French budget's tax revenues), the Union's own resource (about 10% of the budget), VAT has been the subject of numerous texts at European level since 1970. To remedy this, the Commission has presented a draft around four axes: the abandonment of the principle of taxation in the country of origin, short-term measures against fraud, greater flexibility for States to set rates and measures specific to electronic commerce. The report endorsed the abandonment of the principle of taxation in the country of origin to that of the country of destination. However, this is the measure most contested by professionals. Specifically, the supplier of goods or services will collect VAT from his customer and, if he resides abroad, applying the foreign rate. The main risk is a rapidly unmanageable system, since companies selling for export will have to juggle the 89 rates in force in the Union. I chose abstention.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: in writing. “The aim of this report is to discuss the Commission's work on reforming the European VAT system and combating VAT fraud across Europe. Unfortunately, this direction does not guarantee an effective fight against VAT fraud, causing more chaos in the institutions responsible for the VAT system. At the same time, it should be added that Member States should make a measurable use of available measures to combat VAT fraud. That's why I voted against the resolution.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against this report, because I think it completely ignores the dimension and social impact of indirect taxes. I believe that there was a need for simplification in regulation, but that is not why the reduction of rates on luxury goods and other goods is not justified. Finally, the report ignores the role multinationals have played in promoting downward tax competition.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I welcome the latest 7 April 2016. the Commission communication and the intention to take further measures to prevent fraud and to help improve the existing VAT system.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report ‘Towards a definitive VAT system and fighting VAT fraud’. VAT is a major and growing source of revenue in the Member States and contributes to EU own resources, the EU’s total revenue from the VAT own resource standing at EUR 17 667 million and accounting for 12.27% of the total revenue of the EU in 2014. However, Member States differ in the effectiveness with which they are able to address VAT fraud and VAT avoidance, since the VAT gap is estimated to vary from less than 5% to over 40% depending on the country considered. The report emphasises that it is the responsibility of the tax authorities in the individual Member States to ensure that VAT is paid in a proper and simple way. It equally notes that the lack of comparable data and of adequate relevant indicators to measure Member States’ performance affects the effectiveness of the EU system in tackling intra-EU VAT fraud. I voted in favour because I believe that national tax administrations must take greater responsibility for ensuring tax compliance and reducing opportunities for evasion in the general implementation of the country-of-destination principle.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This report welcomes the Commission's intention to propose a definitive VAT system for 2017 that is simple, fair, efficient, solid and less susceptible to fraud. Its most ambitious aim is to implement a definitive system of taxation at destination (i.e. in the Member State where consumption of goods or services takes place). It gives significant value to the VAT Action Plan presented by the Commission in April, which in turn gives great importance to the strengthening of existing administrative cooperation and increasing the efficiency of national tax administrations. In the interests of improving the fight against fraud and modernising this Community VAT system, which was provisionally introduced in 1993, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against this report, although it contains many positive points, because it is not possible to talk about VAT without understanding its social and redistributive implications. The report contains a number of measures to be envisaged in the forthcoming 2017 VAT proposal; from the signalling of prioritizing research to major fraudsters, to many points on simplification absolutely necessary for SMEs. However, it is marked in this report that there is no consideration of the social impact of this tax, even in a context where the Commission 'recommends' to collect more through this type of indirect taxes. This absence is inexplicable when we are debating our political position on it, and that is why, despite the many logical proposals, I had to vote against this report.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the VAT report as it will help tackle the EUR 170 billion lost through the so-called ‘VAT gap’ each year. The report also provides for a review of the goods and services eligible for reduced rates, allowing the UK Government to bring an end to the sanitary tax and other unfair taxes. The report also reinforces help for small and micro-businesses in the UK by calling for a reintroduction of a VAT threshold.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: — I voted in favour, because VAT fraud is a very harmful practice that withdraws substantial sums from the budgets of the Member States and undermines their efforts to consolidate public finances.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This own-initiative report is a response from the European Parliament to the VAT Action Plan that the EC published in April this year. It provides for harmonisation of rates and increased rigidity in the establishment of lists of products subject to reduced rates. It also provides for a new system of collection in international transactions with the payment of tax at the place of purchase. However, it considers that the goods and services to which reduced rates may be applied should be reduced and that for some to whom such rates may apply should be fixed jointly at EU level. We believe that minimum and reduced VAT rates play a redistributive role in a tax that is highly regressive, and therefore we do not accept changing, for the worse and in the name of reducing complexity and consequent obstacles to competition and the single market, the way in which rates are defined reduced and minimum VAT.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: in writing. - VAT, with sales of almost €1 trillion a year, is a significant and growing source of revenue for each Member State. Member States lose EUR 50 billion per year due to VAT fraud. In Austria alone, the “VAT gap” caused by fraud and tax avoidance is 2.9 billion euros. The report focuses on enhanced cooperation between Member States to combat tax evasion and fraud. The aim of this report is to help limit VAT fraud and reduce the VAT gap without creating administrative overhead for SMEs, while promoting the growth of SMEs and facilitating cross-border turnover. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that the greatest criticality of the current taxation regime is its extreme vulnerability to fraud: about EUR 170 billion per year, of of which at least EUR 50 billion attributable to cross-border fraud alone. This report aims to make proposals to improve the VAT collection system and to combat VAT fraud. It aims to simplify business operations for SMEs, and above all, stresses the need to harmonize fiscal policies at European level. I agree with this report as a whole, and in particular it is worth pointing out a few key points: financial services must be subject to VAT and Member States are invited to agree increasing convergence of VAT rates.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the VAT report as it will help tackle the EUR 170 billion lost through the so-called ‘VAT gap’ each year. The report also provides for a review of the goods and services eligible for reduced rates, allowing the UK Government to bring an end to the sanitary tax and other unfair taxes. The report also reinforces help for small and micro-businesses in the UK by calling for a reintroduction of a VAT threshold. Fair taxation is a cornerstone of a progressive society as tax income is required to help fund state spending, ensuring that disadvantaged and vulnerable people can receive a basic level of support and that universal services such as the NHS remain FREE at the point of delivery.

name: Lieve Wierinck (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution since I believe that the existing VAT system should be improved, allowing for fewer exemptions. In my opinion an efficient VAT system is fundamental for the functioning of the single market. In order to reach a definitive VAT system, but also to detect VAT fraud, the efforts among Member States become fundamental. The current system is not totally bad, but it can be simplified, making Member States comply with minimum tax rates. Very important in my opinion is that VAT are equal for public and private companies. So even if tax-legislation is exclusive competence of each Member State, there is a need for higher harmonisation.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: in writing - There has been a transitional regime in the area of the value added tax system since 1993. This was to be replaced by a definitive system of taxation based on the principle that the supply of goods and services must be taxed in the country of origin. It must be realised that VAT represents a significant source of finance in the EU and accounts for 7% of the GDP of the whole Union. However, the system to date has often been abused for fraud, as confirmed by statistics, according to which EUR 170 billion per year is lost on tax fraud. Cross-border VAT fraud amounting to a total of EUR 50 billion a year represents a significant amount. However, political will is needed to adopt the new system for the reforms needed to combat fraud, reduce administrative burdens and reduce regulatory costs. The new VAT system could uniformly introduce tax liability on all transactions between economic operators across Europe, thereby strengthening competition rules. That is why I supported the report.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ According to this report, the new system value added tax must be based on the principle of taxation in the country of destination of goods and services, abandoning the current principle the country of origin, which is not effective enough in protecting competition and preventing fraud, in particular so-called carousel fraud. With the new system, moreover, the tax provision according to which the supplier of the goods collects VAT from the customer is extended to cross-border transactions, significantly reducing the possibility of fraud VAT. In the amendments I made a number of requests, then accepted, on greater transparency, accountability of national tax administrations and more cooperation. However, some issues remain, such as the creation of a single European list of goods and services at a reduced rate, as well as the harmonisation and total convergence of the various systems in the direction opposed to the values of justice and social equity, sustainable growth and development. Furthermore, the creation of a transparent, public and digital single European register of companies which better co-ordinates the VAT issue is lacking and there is no reference to greater accountability of the banking system, as I requested in the amendments instead. For these reasons I opted for an abstention.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: in writing. — I support this report because I think it signals the European Union's efforts to fight VAT fraud decisively and jointly. However, I also have considerable reservations about the European Public Prosecutor's Office. I don't think this office would be effective, plus it represents a significant financial cost to the EU budget. As far as taxes are concerned, it is clear that the current system is not sustainable in the long term, and therefore I would personally welcome more extensive changes than this report suggests. Indeed, only large-scale reform can bring efficiency and fairness to the current system.

name: Željana Zovko (PPE)
text: written. - I support the resolution on the report “Towards the final VAT system and combating VAT fraud”. Member States have different success in detecting tax fraud and tax avoidance, so that the difference in tax collected from real is between 5 and 40 per cent depending on Member States. Actors of tax fraud are individuals, legal and natural persons, but also companies and organised crime. High administrative costs in the existing tax system, particularly in cross-border transactions, can be significantly reduced for SMEs if simplification measures comprised of digital reporting tools and common databases are included. The lack of comparable data and adequate indicators that measure the impact of Member States affect the possibility and effectiveness of the European Union system in combating tax fraud within the Union itself. I therefore consider it important that this resolution invites the tax authorities to establish a common system of assessing the size of internal tax fraud in cooperation with the Commission and to create objectives of reducing the total amount of money contained in such illicit flows. The creation of the field of the final VAT system is a prerequisite for creating a deeper and more uniform single market led by tax justice, sustainable consumption, employment, growth, investment and competitiveness.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted for the Report on the way to a definitive VAT system and the fight against VAT fraud. The report is in response to the Commission's Communication of 7 April 2016 and its intention to take additional measures against fraud and support the further development of the existing system of value added tax. In the Action Plan, the Commission intends to draw up a legislative proposal for the definitive regulation of the VAT system based on the principle of taxation in the country of destination of goods and services. This marks a decisive shift from the originally envisaged principle of taxation in the country of origin, which has proved unworkable due to a number of cases of distortions of competition. As I believe that the Commission Action Plan will contribute to promoting fair taxation, sustainable consumption, employment, growth, investment and competitiveness while limiting the potential for VAT fraud, I supported the Report.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: — I was happy to endorse this report. I am pleased that in addition to protecting human rights and democracy, the protection of other living creatures of this planet is also included in the agenda of the EP, and that this report we protect and defy wildlife illegal and unethical trade in endangered wildlife. I am very happy that here we are clearly criticising the hunting of animals to win trophies, which has led to there being a critical threat to some species of animals, and I am also very pleased that we are in this text accepted support for a complete ban on ivory trade. I think that the EU is supposed to be a leader on these ethical issues, and it's a good thing that this kind of material has been accepted. Now everything needs to be done not only to stay with declarations, but to ensure prohibitions are also realistically followed. So it is necessary to fight smugglers and animal hunters.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: ‒ The report assesses the EU action plan against illegal trafficking in wild species drawn up as part of the EU's response to the 2030 Agenda (Sustainable Development Objective 15). This action plan will strengthen the Union's role in combating illegal trafficking in wild species by setting a number of priorities: prevention, application of the existing framework, cooperation and recognition of the European Union as a target market and as a point of origin and transit for products of wild species. In addition, it is required to establish a total and immediate ban at European level on trade, export or re-export to non-EU destinations for ivory and rhino horns. For these reasons I voted for it.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution which welcomes the EU action plan against wildlife trafficking presented by the Commission, as it emphasizes the need for coordinated action to address the causes of this trafficking, effectively implement and enforce existing rules , and to strengthen global cooperation among countries of origin, transit and destination. The text also calls on the Commission, the Member States, the European External Action Service, Europol and Eurojust to recognize that wildlife crime constitutes a serious and growing threat and to address them as urgently as possible. It also emphasizes the need for comprehensive and coordinated approaches between different policy areas. As the text also urgently calls for greater protection for areas designated as vulnerable marine ecosystems, ecologically or biologically important marine areas and Natura 2000 sites, my vote has been in favour, since it supports essential measures to protect and combat trafficking in species wild.

name: Martina Anderson Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this report on the EU action plan against wildlife trafficking, which has become one of the largest and most profitable forms of cross-border crime at the same time as global biodiversity is being severely threatened. The EU is unfortunately a significant destination market for illegally—traded wildlife.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on the EU action plan to combat illicit wildlife trafficking. Trade in wildlife has turned into a billion euro criminal industry led by organised criminal networks. The risk of being identified is small and the financial remuneration is huge, which attracts criminal groups to use illegally caught and removed wild animals to finance their criminal activities. I believe that the new Action Plan 2016-2020 will strengthen the EU's role in the global arena for combating illicit wildlife trafficking by implementing the following priorities: prevention, enforcement, cooperation, as well as recognising the EU's demand for wildlife products and products the market of destination and the point of origin and transit. I agree with the rapporteur that EU Member States must take common responsibility and make more efforts to cope with this task and to stop the rapid disappearance of some of the most protected species. By taking these actions, we will not only preserve biodiversity for future generations, but also improve and support the EU's security system, improve the lives of local communities, accelerate sustainable development and strengthen the rule of law.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on the European Union's action plan to combat illegal trade in wildlife, because I believe that this phenomenon, which has become a criminal industry worth millions of euros, must be tackled immediately.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: in writing. — I abstained on this text, which mixes highly commendable intentions for the protection of wildlife, as already called for by the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES Convention), with clear violations of State sovereignty. It calls on several occasions to increase the EU's financial resources or create international funds for this purpose. However, the European Union does not have to take such decisions, which fall within the competence of States, which are already parties to the CITES Convention. While it is important to support local initiatives in the countries concerned to find alternative income to those generated by trafficking, no interference should be accepted, as several African countries have recalled. In addition, recommendations on criminal law are problematic as they encroach on a major area of national sovereignty.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst I fully support the aims of this resolution, I fully believe these issues should be decided at a Member State level. I therefore voted to abstain on this resolution.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this text, which provides for strict measures to combat the growing trade in illicit wildlife products, which is destroying the planet's ecosystem. The crimes committed by traffickers have gone unpunished for too long. However, these are the fruit of often international and highly organized criminal organizations. It is now up to the Member States and the Commission to implement these measures as soon as possible.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Europe has been one of the biggest destination markets and transit points for illegal wildlife smuggling. Not only do these practices take many endangered species to the brink of extinction, but they also create a security problem in many countries. Because it is easy to harnessing, wildlife trafficking is preferred by many organized crime groups and terrorist organizations over smuggling such things as drugs, cigarettes or migrants. This action plan calls for three major goals and priorities. The first is start battling wildlife trafficking at its roots; this can be done through the many tools available to the European Union already, such as those focusing on combating corruption or awareness raising campaigns. Secondly, the action plan calls for more scrutiny and transparency when it comes to seizure information and data in Member States. The third point focuses on global partnerships and how we should amend trade deals and incorporate clauses in future ones about wildlife trafficking and measures to stop it.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: in writing. — The European Union is an important player in the fight against wildlife crime and flora, but is one of the main target markets for illegal products made from wild flora and fauna. This illegal trade has become a billion-dollar crime industry dominated by criminal organizations. The risk of exposure is insignificant and the financial gain is high. The efforts to combat environmental crime in a wider sense play a particularly important role in combating threats to peace and security. The 2016-2020 Action Plan reinforces the EU's role in the global fight against illegal trade in wild fauna and flora. The EU must curb the demand and supply of illegal wild flora and fauna products using the means available. It is the common responsibility of EU Member States to face this challenge and to stop the rapid destruction of certain highly cherished species in the world. This will not only preserve biodiversity for future generations, but will also improve and strengthen the EU security framework, improve the quality of life of local communities and strengthen the rule of law. Against this background, I supported the report.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: in writing. — I have decided to abstain on this text, which certainly contains very commendable intentions for the protection of wildlife, but undermines the sovereignty of States. This includes the desire to create international funds and increase the Union's budget, as well as recommendations on criminal law, all of which would infringe on the competence of States.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. - Wildlife trafficking is an international organized crime that brings about €20 billion a year to criminals and has a serious impact on biodiversity. This report, which I have approved, calls on the European Commission, the Member States, Europol and Eurojust to recognise that wildlife crime is a serious and growing threat and to combat it now with the greatest political will. The report emphasizes, inter alia, the need for comprehensive and coordinated strategies in the areas of action, adequate capacity and a permanent monitoring and evaluation mechanism to measure progress. It also stresses the need to provide assistance, guidance and training to authorities in countries of origin, transit and destination with regard to investigations, as well as criminal and judicial proceedings at the local, regional and national levels.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Every year wildlife traffic generates an estimated turnover of EUR 20 million. It is the fourth most lucrative criminal activity after drug trafficking, human trafficking and weapons. Rhinos, elephants, great primates and tigers are just some of the animal species most affected by poachers” action, with irreparable damage to the ecosystem and biodiversity. The Bearder report adopted today by Parliament, and I supported, calls for a complete and immediate ban at European level on the trade, export or re-export of ivory and horns rhino. The Union and its Member States must strengthen cooperation with the financial sector, dialogue with social media platform operators, search engines and trade platforms electronic and to step up controls to stop illegal wildlife trade on the internet. We need a precautionary approach, which also touches the import of hunting trophies obtained from protected species, but above all, new offences and penalties relating to the trafficking of species must be defined wild, an activity increasingly linked to forms of organized crime, money laundering and financing militias and terrorist groups.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report on the EU action plan against wildlife trafficking. Wildlife trafficking has become a multi-million dollar criminal industry set up by criminal groups. The Union action plan proposes a series of measures which I consider to be essential and which seek the cooperation of the actors involved (within the Union and outside). The report calls on Member States to increase the level of surveillance in this regard. In addition to supporting proposals included in the report as an appropriate item and human resources necessary for the implementation of the plan or monitoring the evaluation of the mechanisms carried out by States, we also support those that emerged from the ENVI committee and the GUE/NGL shadow, such as introducing a point on import of hunting trophies, ivory, and the participation of NGOs and civil society in this process.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I would like to thank Mrs Bearder for her work on this report on the EU action plan against wildlife trafficking.
