It, inter alia, calls for the total and immediate prohibition at European level of trade, export or re-export from the Union and to destinations outside the Union of ivory, including pre-convention ivory, and rhinoceros horns, and further calls for the establishment of a mechanism to assess the need for similar restrictions for other species threatened with extinction.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: in writing. — I preferred to abstain from this report on the European Union's action plan against wildlife trafficking. The text should be recognized as commendable intentions, including support for initiatives to promote the development of alternative livelihoods for communities living near wildlife. In this regard, I welcome the work of my ENL colleagues, members of the ENVI Committee, who have succeeded in integrating into the report the need for these initiatives to be carried out in consultation with the communities concerned, rather than in complete interference. It is also positive to recognize the UN Convention against Corruption as an appropriate framework for this fight. However, I find it damaging that once again, the European institutions are instrumentalising legitimate fighting in order to strengthen their power and influence over the Member States. It is proposed that the European budget be strengthened, whether the Commission monitors the action of the Member States or that the Union has illegitimate diplomatic power by concluding bilateral or multilateral agreements internationally. This is all the more regrettable because cooperation between sovereign nations has already proved its worth, particularly within the framework of the CITES Convention.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: ‒ The measure has shared passages and interesting ideas, but there are some critical issues that have prompted me to express myself with an abstention.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Illegal trafficking in species is a phenomenon whose scale has increased considerably in recent years. Poaching has reached unprecedented figures for some species such as elephants, rhinos, sharks, tigers, big apes, turtles, pangolins or corals, and their populations are being alarmingly reduced. The negative effects of this activity are not limited only to biodiversity, but also affect economic growth, law enforcement and, in some regions, its political stability due to the financing of militias with these activities. To combat these criminal activities, I supported this Action Plan (2016-2020) based on three pillars: prevention, implementation and cooperation, on the basis that the main legal instrument at international level and at Union level is the CITES Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Fauna and Flora Wild. The plan provides an overall view of everything Member States and the Commission can do, setting out a comprehensive set of measures that the institutions must take to meet the challenge of halting the rapid decline of some of the most valuable and appreciated species in the world.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report because Parliament advocated an EU action plan to stop illicit wildlife trafficking. On World Wildlife Day, UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon stated that “It's time to start taking wildlife crimes seriously”. This was a simple but strong statement that illicit wildlife trafficking poses a serious and growing threat not only to the survival of many species of flora and fauna, but also to the principles of the rule of law, human rights, global governance, the welfare of local communities and, most importantly, for the survival of world ecosystems. Trade in wildlife has turned into a billion euro criminal industry led by networks of organised criminals. The risk of being identified is small and the financial remuneration is huge, which attracts criminal groups to use illegally caught and removed wild animals to finance their criminal activities. Parliament called on the Commission, the Member States, the European External Action Service and the EU agencies, Europol and Eurojust, to recognise that wildlife crimes constitute a serious and growing threat and to take political decisions as soon as possible. It also welcomed the Commission Action Plan to combat illicit wildlife trafficking, highlighting the need for coordinated action to address the causes of illegal wildlife trafficking, effectively applying and implementing existing rules and strengthen global cooperation between countries of origin, transit and destination.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: in writing. - I supported the EU Action Plan to tackle illegal wildlife trade, as it is a form of organised international crime that has been on the rise in recent years. This type of crime has become one of the largest and most profitable forms of organised cross-border crime. The need for concerted action to address the causes that lead to this trade is clear. However, adequate financial and human resources should be organised in order to effectively implement and enforce the applicable rules and to strengthen global cooperation between countries of origin, transit and destination.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Illegal trafficking in wild species is one of the most developed and profitable cross-border organised crime, with an estimated turnover of over €20 million annually. This poses a serious and growing threat, with important negative repercussions not only on the survival of the world's ecosystems, but also on the rule of law and well-being of numerous communities local. The EU is a key player as a territory of origin, destination and transit of illicit trade in these species. I therefore support this report, which calls for an action plan at European level to combat the global fight against the trafficking of wild species. The EU must outline priorities and instruments, focusing on prevention so as to reduce both the demand and supply of these endangered species on the international market. It also underlines the need for a monitoring mechanism to ensure effective enforcement of existing rules and provides for well-defined and uniform penalties for traffickers.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the EU action plan against wildlife trafficking because I shared with my colleagues the idea that Europol and Eurojust have to recognise wildlife crimes as serious. In this regard, we called on the Commission to establish a dedicated Wildlife Trafficking Coordinator's office aimed at preventing wildlife trafficking and addressing its roots causes.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: in writing. — The purpose of this report is to put in place a Europe-wide action plan to effectively combat wildlife trafficking. Certainly, many proposals are in the right direction, such as the ban on trade in ivory and rhino horns in Europe, better prevention and consultation with the local communities concerned, and a fierce fight against corruption. Nevertheless, the text also calls for an increase in national and European budgets, with the introduction of a trust fund for the preservation of protected areas and a strengthening of the European Development Fund. Furthermore, the report calls on the European Union to strengthen its position on the international scene by concluding bilateral and multilateral agreements directly threatening the sovereignty of the Member States. Finally, it is requested to establish minimum rules on the definition of criminal offences. But we strongly oppose any embryo of European criminal law. For all these reasons, I abstained on this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. - Wildlife trafficking is a form of international organised crime of an estimated value of around €20 billion annually and has grown around the world in recent years, becoming one of the largest and most profitable forms of organised crime cross-border. It also poses an increasing threat to global security, political stability, economic development, local livelihoods and the rule of law and therefore requires a strategic, coordinated approach at EU level with the participation of all actors involved. In this respect, I welcome the Commission's Action Plan against Wildlife Trafficking, highlighting the need for coordinated action addressing the causes of wildlife trafficking in order to implement and ensure effective compliance with existing rules, and to strengthen global cooperation between countries of origin, transit and destination. I voted in favour of this report, bearing in mind the need to act, given that the European Union is both a point of transit and destination for trade and a source of illegal wildlife products protected under EU law.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the Bearder report for an action plan against wildlife trafficking, which includes a series of measures to be taken by the institutions of the Union and the Member States in order to strengthen synergies, with the aim of better combating wildlife trafficking throughout the Union and around the world. Illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing, for example, leads to trafficking in marine wildlife and thus poses a threat to the sustainable exploitation of living aquatic resources. It jeopardizes the health of the oceans. This comprehensive action plan strengthens the role of the European Union as a global player through specific measures and strengthened and more unified participation in international forums.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of this report because I believe it is necessary to make a greater commitment to combating illegal trafficking in wild species, which is a dangerous threat to survival of global ecosystems. The European Union must prove an important player in combating crime against wild species, as an essential transit point for trafficking from Africa, Asia and the Latin America. The report recommends all stakeholders interested in trafficking initiate multiple awareness campaigns targeting prevention, addressing the root causes. The Commission is called upon to take action as soon as possible, given the influence of the problem on the economic development of European coastal communities. Member States also face this challenge with a sense of responsibility, to foster sustainable development, to strengthen the rule of law, consolidate the EU security framework and preserve the biodiversity for future generations.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP abstained on the non-legislative report on wildlife trafficking. We in UKIP are aware that wildlife trafficking poses a serious and growing threat. However, we believe that national parliaments, not the unelected EU Commission, should decide with regard to updating and improving animal welfare

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. – I agree that the protection of wild flora and fauna is of paramount importance and by regulating trade in them significant progress can be made. We need to also resist trophy hunting as it contributed to large-scale decline in endangered species and urge the Commission and the Member States to establish a precautionary approach for the import of hunting trophies from species protected under the EU Wildlife Trade Regulations. I also call for the immediate ban at European level of trading in ivory and for the establishment of a mechanism to assess the need for similar restrictions for endangered species.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Wildlife trafficking has an estimated value of 20 billion euros per year and has recently grown, becoming one of the largest and most profitable forms of organized crime cross-border. I voted in favour of Mrs Bearder's resolution calling for a complete and immediate ban at European level on trade, export or re-export of ivory and horns rhinoceros and are calling for common sanctions at EU level against illegal wildlife trafficking.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: in writing. - We support the report and we are concerned to stress that illegal wildlife trafficking has become a billion-euro criminal industry controlled by organised criminal groups. Low detection risk and high profits attract gangs that exploit illegal wildlife trapping and transport to fund their criminal activities.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted on the report on the European Union's action plan to combat illegal trade in wild species. This report is a particularly important effort to protect species directly or indirectly threatened by illegal trade, while at the same time protecting the environment. I think this is a very positive initiative and I therefore voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ I welcome the report and the action plan presented by the Commission because I am very strongly convinced that illegal trafficking in wild species represents a real form of organized crime and not just a financing instrument thereof. It is necessary to remember that the estimated turnover amounts to around EUR 20 million per year and that it has trended horribly positive in recent years to become one of the forms of crime more extensive and profitable cross-border organized. Therefore, the planned action plan includes ways to prevent and address the causes of illegal trafficking, including in the first place of information campaigns. Secondly, to promote the development of sustainable and alternative livelihoods for communities living near wild species, to increase the benefits of measures conservation locally and a vision of wild species as a valuable source of income for communities is promoted. These initiatives, if taken in consultation with the communities concerned, will increase support for conservation and contribute to reconstitution, conservation and sustainable management of the populations of wild species as well as their habitats.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. - Trafficking in wild species is an international organised crime whose value is estimated at around EUR 20 billion per year, making it one of the most lucrative forms of cross-border organised crime in the world. Trafficking in wild species has major negative impacts on biodiversity, existing ecosystems, the natural heritage of countries of origin, natural resources and species conservation. I welcome the Action Plan against Wildlife Trafficking, which underlines the need for coordinated actions to address the causes of wildlife trafficking, to implement and enforce existing rules effectively and that adequate human and financial resources are necessary for the implementation of the plan in the Community budget and national budgets. It is also necessary to provide assistance, guidance and training to authorities in the countries of origin, transit and destination with regard to investigation, enforcement and judicial proceedings at local, regional and national level. For this reason, I supported this report.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report because the definition of the action plan will strengthen the role of the European Union in the global fight against environmental offences. The action plan covers three major priorities: the prevention of illegal trafficking in wild species, the implementation and enforcement of existing rules against organised crime, recognition of the EU as a market and as a point of origin and transit of products related to wild species. Through targeted interventions such as reducing global demand and supply within the EU of products derived from wild species, citizens' awareness, coordination by national and European authorities for an effective continuation of traffickers and the tightening of punishments for this type of offences, linked to active political support and technical assistance from part of the EU in relation to the countries of origin, transit and destination, will allow biodiversity to be preserved and refine the EU security framework.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ We need to acknowledge that wildlife trade has become a billion-euro criminal industry dominated by organised criminal groups. The risk of detection is low and the financial reward is high, attracting criminal gangs to exploit illegally caught and removed wildlife to fund their criminal activity. As the report clearly highlights, the identification and allocation of appropriate financial and human resources is essential for the implementation of the Action Plan.  It underlines the need to provide adequate financial resources in the EU budget and the national budgets to ensure effective implementation of this plan, which are realistic and enforceable. The links between wildlife crime and other forms of organised crime, including money laundering and the financing of militias and terrorist groups, are a reality.  For this reason, I consider international cooperation for the combating of illicit financial flows to be a priority and appropriate decisions need to be taken on aid for prevention activities and the investigation of irregularities in the supply chain when tackling wildlife trafficking, for example suspicious shipments and financial transactions.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: ‒ Illegal trafficking in wild species is a very profitable business for criminal organizations. First of all, the risk of being discovered is very low and then the profits are so high that they have allowed the development of a turnover of billions of euros. That is why the European Union has drawn up an action plan aimed at limiting and possibly eliminating this illegal trafficking through prevention and cooperation. This report also calls for a complete and immediate ban on trade in ivory and rhino horns within Europe's borders. Simply put ivory and rhino horns can neither enter nor leave nor transit from Europe. As a result, I express myself favourably towards a subject like this which often does not receive due attention.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution which welcomes the EU action plan against wildlife trafficking presented by the Commission, as it emphasizes the need for coordinated action to address the causes of wildlife trafficking, effectively implement and enforce existing rules, and strengthen global cooperation among countries of origin, transit and destination. The text also calls on the Commission, the Member States, the European External Action Service, Europol and Eurojust to recognize that wildlife crime constitutes a serious and growing threat and to address them as urgently as possible. It also emphasizes the need for comprehensive and coordinated approaches between different policy areas. As the text also urgently calls for greater protection for areas designated as vulnerable marine ecosystems, ecologically or biologically important marine areas and Natura 2000 sites, my vote has been in favour, since it supports essential measures to protect and combat trafficking in species wild.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. - Wildlife trade has become a sector of criminal activities that generates billions of euros in revenue, dominated by organised criminal groups. The European Union is an important player both in the fight against wildlife crimes and a transit point. I voted for the action plan valid until 2020, which aims to combat wildlife trafficking worldwide through a set of priorities: prevention, enforcement, cooperation. It is the joint responsibility of EU Member States to respond to this challenge and to stop the rapid decline of some of the world's most appreciated species. In this way, we will not only maintain biodiversity for future generations, but we will improve and strengthen the EU's security framework.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the European Union Action Plan against illegal trade in wildlife and flora. The adopted plan aims to fight and prevent crimes related to illegal trafficking within the EU. I believe that action should be taken to combat these proceders effectively. To this end, better coordination of cooperation should be established and more effective prevention systems are introduced. There is also a need to build comprehensive and coordinated actions by Member States in various policy areas. Also an important issue is the strengthening of EU rules governing imports into Member States of protected items under EU regulations. In view of the need to regulate these issues, I voted yes.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report calls for the EU and each Member State to address wildlife crime with the greatest political urgency and highlights the need for comprehensive and coordinated approaches across policy areas. Wildlife trafficking is worth an estimated €20 billion annually, which makes it one of the biggest and most profitable forms of organised cross-border crime. We require regular monitoring and evaluation mechanisms, stronger and better structured cooperation among Member States, tackling the potential illegal activities on internet, and EU support to third countries in fighting wildlife trafficking. For this reason, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome calls for tighter controls on the international trade in wildlife, wildlife products and wildlife trafficking; and to set standards applying to international trade in hunting trophies of species. The Commission’s action plan will strengthen the EU’s role in the global fight against wildlife trafficking and promote better coordination across Europe.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. - The European Union is, and must remain, an important player in the fight against wildlife offences. The main reason is that Europe is an important destination for illegal products derived from wildlife, but also a point of transit and often of origin for wildlife trafficking, especially between Africa, Asia and Latin America, but also within the EU. I therefore support the European Union Action Plan, which is part of the EU's response to the UN 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. It calls for urgent measures to put an end to poaching and trafficking in protected species and to combat the demand and supply of illegal wildlife products. I also support the organisation of information and awareness campaigns for citizens on the prevention of wildlife trafficking, addressing its root causes in order to reduce global demand and the supply of illegal wildlife products through the use of tools available.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: This own-initiative report presents Parliament's position on the European Union action plan against wildlife trafficking proposed by the Commission. This trade represents a very lucrative financial manna for criminal organisations, amounting to EUR 22 billion a year. Africa, Asia, Latin America and the European Union are transit points or origin of wildlife trafficking. MEPs are therefore calling for an end to poaching and trafficking in protected species. In support of these objectives, I voted in favour of the report. However, I voted against an amendment on hunting trophies, which merged with the authorised and duly supervised hunting practices in the European Union.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: I voted in favour of the report on the European Union action plan against wildlife trafficking. This action plan, published on 26 February 2016 by the European Commission, includes a number of measures that need to be implemented quickly in order to effectively combat wildlife trafficking, one of the most lucrative organised crimes that terrorist groups use to finance their activities. Cooperation between the public and private sectors must be effective and traceability mechanisms strengthened.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. — This report highlights three objectives that I believe are fundamental in the fight against wildlife trafficking: prevention, compliance with existing rules, and cooperation. This is the first step that must be taken to put in place an effective fight against criminal practices, and that is why I voted in favour of this report, which seems to me to be very balanced. I simply regret the mention made of trophy hunting. It is indeed a very special practice already framed by strict and specific rules. Because of this specificity, it has no place in this report, although illegal trophy hunting practices must indeed be combated. There is an urgent need for a coordinated fight against wildlife trafficking. The European Union must take its responsibility in this fight, because Europe is one of the places of origin, transit and destination of illicit products derived from this trade. To this end, it seems important to take more account of biodiversity and sustainable development in trade.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because illegal wildlife trafficking is an unacceptable practice that must be stopped. I think the ban should be immediate to preserve animal welfare and prevent the threat of extinction of animal species such as elephants and rhinos. I therefore urge the Member States to define the appropriate levels of penalties for offences relating to trafficking in wild species.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing. - I abstained on this text. Indeed, it contains positive aspects: combating corruption, trafficking in ivory, developing alternative livelihoods. Nevertheless, it also called for the creation of financial programmes or intervention plans, and constitutes a clear violation of State sovereignty.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. - We know that the European Union is constantly submitting new and, in most cases, unnecessary legislation, and I am trying to sift through those we really need. The topic of trafficking in wild fauna and flora excites me, I have worked on it as shadow rapporteur for the legal committee, and I believe that the end result of this resolution deserves our support. And I will quote one paragraph: “therefore calls on the EU to revise the existing legislative framework in order to supplement it with a prohibition on the provision and placing on the market, transport, buying and possession of specimens of wild fauna and flora which have been illegally acquired, or traded in third countries; in this context stresses that this legislation must ensure full transparency with regard to prohibitions on trade in animal species on the basis of the illegal nature of such trade in a third country, so as to ensure legal certainty for those involved in that trade; '; The non-legislative report further underlines the need for more comprehensive and coordinated approaches for all policy areas, including trade, development, foreign affairs and justice, and to insist on the timely implementation of all elements of the action plan of Commission of 26 February 2016

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: in writing. - We are voting in favour of the report of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety on the European Union action plan to combat illegal trade in wildlife, as the first priority of the action plan is to prevent illegal trade in wildlife. and addressing its root causes, the second priority of the Action Plan is to ensure the effective implementation and enforcement of existing rules to combat organised crime against wildlife, the third priority is to strengthen the global cooperation between countries of origin, consumption and transit to combat illicit trade in wildlife. And finally, the European Union itself is an extremely active market for the trade in illicit wildlife products. It is not only a transit point and a destination market, but also a source for illegal wildlife products protected under EU law.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on an EU action plan against wildlife trafficking. I know it is an issue about which my constituents in Wales feel very strongly because they have contacted me to ask for my support. Wildlife crime is extremely profitable globally, which is why it is so vital that the EU takes a lead in ending it.  I hope that all Member States, and particularly the UK, will now follow this example, and that the Welsh Government will play its part.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: in writing. - Abstention: this text combines the very commendable intentions of wildlife protection already contained in the CITES Convention with clear violations of state sovereignty.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Crimes against wildlife such as poaching, the illegal trade in species or the illegal transit of products and derived from wild fauna and flora have become a billion euro criminal industry dominated by organised criminal groups. The detection risk is low and the financial repercussions are high, attracting criminal gangs to exploit illegally captured, displaced and marketed wildlife to finance their criminal activity. The EU is an important destination for illegal wild products, as well as a transit point and often a source for wildlife trafficking, especially between Africa, Asia and Latin America, and is therefore responsible for combating this phenomenon. The EU Action Plan presented by the Commission lists a number of measures to be taken by the EU institutions or Member States. The measures are primarily aimed at improving cooperation between all actors, making more effective use of existing instruments and policies, and strengthening synergies between them, so that the fight against wildlife trafficking can be more effectively addressed throughout the EU and globally. We have voted in favour.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: — Illegal trafficking in wild species poses a serious and increasing threat, not only to the survival of numerous plant and animal species, but also to the rule of law, to the human rights, for global governance, for the well-being of local communities and, above all, for the very survival of the world's ecosystems. I voted in favour of the EU action plan against illegal trafficking in wild species, because it is a criminal industry dominated by organised crime groups with a ride business of billions of euros. Member States will be able to act on the forefront, with a comprehensive and coordinated approach, in order to reduce and prevent illegal trafficking in wild species by addressing the root causes.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: In writing. ‒ I abstain from the report: I agree on some things, but I am sceptical of harmonisation at European level of certain points.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: in writing. - I am voting in favour of the report of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety on the EU action plan to combat illicit trade in wildlife, as the first priority of the action plan is the prevention of illegal trade in wild species and the addressing its root causes, the second priority of the Action Plan is to ensure the effective implementation and enforcement of existing rules to combat organised crime against wildlife species, the third priority is to strengthen global cooperation between countries of origin, consumption and transit to combat illicit trade in wildlife. And finally, the European Union itself is an extremely active market for the trade in illicit wildlife products. It is not only a transit point and a destination market, but also a source for illegal wildlife products protected under EU law.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The need to protect our planet’s flora and fauna from the predation of transnational organised crime has become a major priority for the international community in recent years. I believe the EU has the duty to continue to lead the fight against wildlife trafficking, to take strong action to prevent these illegal activities and to better cooperate with third countries to face the dramatic surge we have seen in the last years. Wildlife trafficking has devastating consequences for the sustainable development and for the well-being of the local populations which are affected by it. Wildlife trafficking and poaching damage ecosystems and present great risks for rural communities, which are often threatened by heavily armed criminal groups, often acting on a transnational level. Moreover, its negative consequences for ecotourism harm local economies.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report considering that wildlife trafficking constitutes a serious and growing threat not only to the survival of many species of flora and fauna, but also to the rule of law, human rights and, most importantly, the very survival of the world's ecosystems. The action plan is part of the Union's response to the UN 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, and in particular to Sustainable Development Goal 15, which requires immediate action to end poaching and trafficking in protected species and addressing the demand and supply of illegal species products wild. From 2016 to 2020, the Action Plan will strengthen the Union's role in the global fight against wildlife trafficking through a number of priorities: prevention, law enforcement and cooperation, as well as recognition of the Union as a destination market and point of origin and transit for wildlife products.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ The black market of wild animals endangers the survival of numerous animal and plant species. International wildlife traffic has grown a lot in recent years, confirming itself as one of the biggest national and international emergencies: this is a business that, according to 2015, hovering between $8 billion and $10 billion. The world's wildlife has declined by 58% since 1970. The root cause that contributed to species decimation is human activity, and especially the wildlife trade. In order to deal with these crimes, strategic coordination of Member States' policies, as recently stated by the Commission, at the World Conference on Trade of wild species, which took place just over a month ago. So, well come the EU action plan against wildlife trafficking, launched in February, showing the commitment of the EU and Member States to tackle wildlife trafficking, countries of origin, in the transit phase and in the countries of destination, aiming to address the problem of corruption as well.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the EP resolution on the EU Action Plan on Trafficking in Wild Animal Species because I think it is important to tackle a criminal phenomenon that is continually occurring growth that counts a turnover of 20 billion euros per year. I strongly believe that an action plan involving all EU member countries is essential to ensure adequate protection of the natural ecosystems of the species concerned and effective control to prevent clandestine trafficking in these specimens posing a serious threat to the biodiversity of the fauna. Since the problem of the security of countries of origin is certainly linked to the demand for illegal trade, it is necessary to propose a collaboration of the European institutions with the partner countries through the United Nations Convention Against Corruption. The application of on-the-spot support policies, aimed at promoting the development of sustainable and alternative livelihoods for rural communities, may be the right way forward to direct drawing benefit from participation in the protection of wild species. To permanently counter the illegal market in protected species, I believe that more firmness is necessary against the perpetrators of illegal trafficking, to be implemented through strong penalties and law enforcement.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on the EU action plan to combat wildlife trafficking. Illegal wildlife trafficking is criminal — and the basis for millions of animal suffering, which must be stopped with all might.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: in writing. - I support the EU Action Plan, which contributes to combating wildlife trafficking. At the same time, such an action plan must not be directed against legal hunting, which is already very strictly regulated and contributes to biodiversity. I therefore voted against paragraph 56 of the action plan.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I am against the creation of new EU legislation on wildlife trafficking. However, I do agree with this wildlife tracking plan, if implemented at national level. This is why I abstained.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Wildlife trafficking is one of the major forms of organised crime, and the EU is one of the main markets. This has a detrimental impact on wildlife. Every year, there is an 8% decline in the elephant population through poaching. The picture for other iconic species is similarly gloomy. To stop these harmful practices, I voted in favour of an immediate EU ban on the trade of ivory and rhinoceros horn, and called for proper sanctions. I also supported a ban on wildlife which has been illegally harvested or traded in third countries.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report on the EU action plan against wildlife trafficking. Wildlife trafficking has become a multi-million dollar criminal industry set up by criminal groups. The Union action plan proposes a series of measures which I consider to be essential and which seek the cooperation of the actors involved (within the Union and outside). The report calls on Member States to increase the level of surveillance in this regard. In addition to supporting proposals included in the report as an appropriate item and human resources necessary for the implementation of the plan or monitoring the evaluation of the mechanisms carried out by States, we also support those that emerged from the ENVI committee and the GUE/NGL shadow, such as introducing a point on import of hunting trophies, ivory, and the participation of NGOs and civil society in this process.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on the EU Action Plan against illegal trade in wildlife and flora. The wildlife and flora trade is a billion-euro criminal business dominated by organised crime groups that, encouraged by high profits and low risk, have been destroying, often irretrievably, valuable species of flora and fauna for years. The European Parliament's Action Plan built around 3 priorities: preventing and combating wildlife and flora trafficking, ensuring effective implementation and enforcement of existing laws on the fight against organised crime against of wild fauna and flora and deepening global partnerships with countries of origin, transit and destination in the fight against the illegal trade in wildlife and flora is essential in my estimation to protect the nature and natural heritage of Europe and the world.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this action plan as wildlife trafficking represents a serious and endemic form of organised crime, and the EU is one of the main markets. I voted in favour of an immediate EU ban on the trade of ivory and rhinoceros horn, and called for proper sanctions. I also supported a ban on wildlife which has been illegally harvested or traded in third countries.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Illegal trade in wildlife has become a billion-euro criminal industry controlled by organised criminal groups. Low detection risk and high profits attract gangs that exploit illegal wildlife trapping and transport to fund their criminal activities. The Action Plan sets out some priorities for the period 2016-2020 that will strengthen the role of the European Union in combating wildlife trafficking globally: prevention, law enforcement, cooperation and recognition of the European Union as a market destination, source and transit point for products of wild species. That is why we voted in favour of this report.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I full supported this own-initiative report on the EU action plan against wildlife trafficking. Wildlife trade has become a billion-euro criminal industry dominated by organised criminal groups. The risk of detection is low and the financial reward is high, attracting criminal gangs to exploit illegally caught and removed wildlife to fund their criminal activity. There is a need to review the current EU legislation to close gaps concerning imports of illegally harvested wildlife and in particular to control imports of hunting trophies from protected species.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour since I have no objections.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ On 26 February 2016, the Commission adopted a Communication on the EU Action Plan (AP) against Wildlife Trafficking setting out a blueprint for joined-up efforts to fight wildlife crime inside the EU, and for strengthening the EU's role in the global fight against these illegal activities. The plan has three key strands – greater enforcement, better cooperation, and more effective prevention. The AP is to be implemented jointly by the EU (Commission services, EEAS, Europol, Eurojust) and the Member States until 2020. This non-legislative report sets out the Parliament’s response to the AP, calling for the EU and each Member State to address wildlife crime and its root causes with the greatest political urgency, highlighting the need for comprehensive and coordinated approaches across policy areas including trade, development, foreign affairs, and justice and home affairs, and insisting on the timely implementation of all elements of the AP. The final report includes 19 compromise amendments, all endorsed by the shadow rapporteur, as well as amendments from opinions delivered by the Committees on International Trade, Legal Affairs, Fisheries and Development. I voted in line with my Group.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written. - I voted for the Report on the EU Action Plan to tackle the illegal trade in wild fauna and flora because this trade has serious negative effects on biodiversity, existing ecosystems, native country natural heritage, natural resources and species conservation. In addition, the aforementioned trade has grown worldwide in recent years and forms one of the largest and most lucrative forms of organised cross-border crime, thus funding other forms of serious and organised crime. This report, which I voted for, calls on the Commission, the Member States, the European External Action Service and the EU agencies Europol and Eurojust to note that offences in the field of wild fauna and flora are a serious threat on the rise and that they need to be addressed urgently at a political level. There is a need for comprehensive and coordinated approaches in all policy areas as this trade is a growing threat to world security, political stability, economic development, local population income sources and the rule of law.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: The protection of wildlife is a noble goal, but should not be accompanied by attacks on the sovereignty of States. What the report calls for the increase or creation of funds is supposed to fall within the competence of the Member States, too often circumvented, alone. Support for local initiatives must be the only interference allowed, which some African countries have not failed to recall. I chose to abstain.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report by my colleague Catherine Bearder on the European Action Plan against Wildlife Trafficking. Considered one of the most lucrative criminal activities, wildlife trafficking is a threat to biodiversity; it also involves foreign policy considerations related to the rule of law, stability and good governance. Nevertheless, I have expressed my opposition to the provisions relating to trophy hunting, insofar as it is regulated and does not cause the massive decline of endangered species. However, I support this report, which was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report because the fight against wildlife trafficking is very important to me. We must coordinate our trade, development and foreign policies taking this into account. In particular, the report calls for measures to prevent trafficking in wildlife and address its root causes.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report because the European animal and plant population needs to be protected in a sustainable manner. Furthermore, the action plan to combat illegal international biodiversity trafficking is a challenge to terrorist groups, as terrorist groups are financed directly or indirectly, inter alia, through trade in wild animal and plant species.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — I supported the EU Action Plan to combat illegal trade in wild and wild species. The growing crime in the area is the result of modification of current organised crime, which is trying to find new resources, and so the trafficking of wild species has become the fourth The most profiting source of organized crime, which does not bring such risks precisely due to low political priority. Smuggling and poaching has particularly negative impacts on biodiversity, ecosystems, natural heritage and thus the fall of species conservation. And it is for these reasons that we are also dealing with this issue in the European Parliament. Indeed, we must remember that these kinds of crimes contribute to organised crime around the world. And that is why we have approved that each EU Member State should become more significant about this issue and elevate this type of crime to the level of other types of organised crime, thus falling to it prepared even adequate laws and their enforcement. It is also important to inform and educate the public on the issue.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour since the report is aimed at fighting wildlife trafficking by establishing, inter alia, the full and immediate ban of the trade of ivory at EU level.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: in writing. - I supported the report on the EU Action Plan against the trafficking of wild flora and fauna. I believe that the action plan is an important step in achieving the EU's objectives and policies relating to environmental protection and the regulation of international trade in endangered species of wild fauna and flora. It will also help to achieve the objectives adopted under the CITES Convention and the commitments made by the EU for sustainable development in the 2030 Agenda. The EU is a transit zone and a major market for much of the illicit trade and trafficking of wild flora and fauna specimens, so immediate legislative measures must be taken to end poaching and trafficking of protected species. Much of the illegal trade is carried out by illegal groups, through which they finance their illegal activities and jeopardise both the biodiversity of protected species of flora and fauna and damage the EU budget. I believe that the trafficking of specimens of wild fauna and flora should be regarded as organised transnational crime and all acts committed in contravention of the laws of the country of origin, transit and within the EU must be criminalised.

name: Cécile Kashetu Kyenge (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ It is with great conviction and sense of responsibility that this House has supported, with today's vote, the total and immediate call for the export or re-export of ivory and horns rhino, as well as common penalties against illegal wildlife trafficking. This is a particularly serious and ever-expanding trade, the value of which contributes to fuelling organised crime. The link between these crimes and other forms of organised crime, including money laundering and financing militias and terrorist groups, is now proven. We therefore urge the EU and its Member States to use all relevant instruments, including cooperation with the financial sector, to detect these links and break this chain with appropriate instruments, including severe sanctions, harmonised sanctions in all European countries. We also ask the Commission to adopt common rules on the definition of offences and penalties relating to the trafficking of wild species. A further commitment by the EU to review as soon as possible and the current regulatory framework to complement it with a ban on making available, placing on the market, transporting, acquiring and possess wild species obtained or illegally traded in third countries.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: in writing. - Good intentions are intertwined with violations of State sovereignty. The Union is using this issue of wildlife trafficking as a substitute for States in international action on the subject. That's why I abstained.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: in writing. - I abstained on the report on the European Union Action Plan against Wildlife Trafficking. This text combines highly commendable intentions to protect wildlife, already contained in the CITES Convention, with clear violations of state sovereignty. It calls on several occasions to increase the Union's financial resources or to set up international funds for that destination. However, the European Union does not have to take such decisions, which fall within the competence of States, already all parties to CITES. While it is important to support local initiatives in the countries concerned to find alternative income to those generated by trafficking, no interference should be accepted, as several African countries have recalled. In addition, recommendations on criminal law are problematic insofar as it encroaches on a major area of national sovereignty.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: I have decided to abstain on this text, which contains very commendable intentions for the protection of wildlife, but would undermine the sovereignty of States. There is indeed a desire to create international funds, to increase the budget of the Union, and the text contains recommendations on criminal law, all of which would infringe on the competence of States.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of Parliament's report on the Action Plan presented by the European Commission because it calls on the Union and each Member State to address wildlife crime with the utmost political urgency. Stresses the need for a structured and coordinated approach in all policy areas, including trade, development, foreign affairs and justice and home affairs. It presents a number of measures aimed at addressing its root causes, making implementation and compliance more effective and strengthening a global partnership. Only through improved means of cooperation among all stakeholders, in order to achieve better and more effective implementation and compliance with existing tools and policies, can a real reduction in wildlife trafficking be achieved. The Union and the Member States have a shared responsibility to meet the challenge of halting the rapid decline of some of the most valuable and appreciated species in the world. In doing so, biodiversity is preserved for future generations.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: written. - Illegal trade in flora and fauna has become one of the forms of international crime. The value of this activity is estimated at several billion euros, and what creates an even bigger problem is that this amount is increasing year on year. An additional problem is also created by the fact that other forms of organised crime, such as trafficking in human beings or drug trafficking, which also create problems in other areas. The European Union should approach this problem strategically, since illegal trade in flora and fauna can challenge world security and political stability, and economic development is also questionable. We may be noticing a decrease in biodiversity lately, which really leads us to question whether another wave of mass species extinction threatens us. Consciousness among people is not awakened, and this is a big problem when fighting the illegal trade in flora and fauna. In order to start working on it and awaken people's consciousness, political engagement is necessary. Also, in order to maintain the UN's Sustainable Development Goal, it is crucial to prevent further illicit trade in flora and fauna. The European Union must face this issue as soon as possible to prevent further decline in the number of these precious species, so I supported this report.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Wildlife trafficking has major negative impacts on biodiversity, existing ecosystems, the natural heritage of the countries of origin, natural resources and the conservation of species. It is a serious and growing threat to global security. I welcome the Commission action plan against wildlife trafficking.  We have to recognise that wildlife crime is a serious and growing threat and to address it with the greatest political urgency.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing - Trade in wild species has become part of international organised crime, which, in addition to financial and economic damage and non-respect for the rule of law, threatens the world's ecosystems. The Union is not only a transit destination in this trade, but also a destination. Moreover, the profits from this illegal activity also flow to the financing of other crime, including the promotion of terrorism, conflicts and power interests. We therefore ask the Commission and the Member States to adopt the necessary best practices to avoid such action. We also ask the governments of supply countries to stop such trading in their countries by rigorous investigations, proper punishment, eradication of corruption and the implementation of the rule of law.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing. - I am voting in favour of the report on the European Union action plan to combat wildlife trafficking, for the reasons I explained in detail in my speech to the plenary session of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 23 November 2016, and because this report is complete and documented.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on EU action plan against wildlife trafficking. Tackling wildlife crime is important because flora and fauna are not the only ones facing danger. Wildlife crime is considered a growing threat that may severely impact the rule of law, human rights, global governance, and the well-being of local communities. Trading of wildlife has proved to be a lucrative activity highly dominated by organized criminal groups, which thereby have an impact peace and security. Member States should address the ongoing wildlife situation because it is affecting many sectors of society. Hence, only by taking a hands-on approach will the EU be able to preserve biodiversity for future generations, improve the life of local peoples, and increase sustainable development.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: in writing. - The Austrian animal and plant population must be protected in the long term! However, by calling for a sometimes arbitrary restriction of trophy hunting, the report ignores the inestigable consequences for species protection in general. That's why I'm abstaining.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour. Illicit wildlife trafficking poses a serious threat to the survival of many species of flora and fauna and violates the rule of law. Networks of organised criminals generate billions of euros of income through illegal wildlife trafficking. For these reasons, it is necessary to take appropriate political decisions as soon as possible, to apply and implement the existing rules more effectively and to strengthen cooperation between the parties.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. — Wildlife trafficking is an international organized crime with an estimated annual value of around €20 billion per year. In addition, wildlife trafficking has a major negative impact on biodiversity, existing ecosystems, the natural heritage of countries of origin, natural resources and species conservation. The report welcomes the Commission's action plan against wildlife trafficking. It also calls on the Commission and Member States to further improve the protection of the habitats of targeted species and areas classified as “vulnerable marine ecosystems”, and also proposes to introduce more stringent and dissuasive sanctions for illicit trafficking. I am voting for this text.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. — This text combines the highly commendable intentions of protecting wildlife, already contained in the CITES Convention, with clear violations of state sovereignty. It calls on several occasions to increase the Union's financial resources, or to set up specific international funds. However, the Union does not have to take such decisions, which fall within the competence of the States, already all parties to CITES. While it is important to support local initiatives in the countries concerned to find alternative income to those generated by trafficking, no interference should be accepted, as several African countries have recalled. In addition, recommendations on criminal law are problematic insofar as it encroaches on a major area of national sovereignty. I thus abstained on this text.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. - What causes major breaks in endangered species is poaching. Trophies are usually an expression of legal and selective hunting which, being managed by the official authorities of the countries, contributes to the financing of species preservation and the protection of nature. The European Union must be relentless in combating illegal poaching.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. Wildlife trafficking is contributing to the steady decline of animal populations across the globe and to the endangerment and extinction of some species.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing — The trade in wild species is a criminal sector dominated by organised criminal groups. The attraction is particularly low risk of detection and high financial reward. The European Union is an important player in the fight against crime in wild species, on the other hand it is also one of the main markets for the disposal of illegal products from endangered species, as well as the place of transit and often the origin of illegal trafficking in these species. The EU and its Member States share a shared responsibility to prevent the rapid loss of some of the world's rarest species. The EU Action Plan against Illicit Trafficking in Wild Species is part of the EU's response to the 2030 UN Sustainable Development Programme, in particular Sustainable Development Goal 15, which requires not only to ensure an end to poaching and illicit trafficking in protected species, but also to deal with the demand for illegal products from wild species and their supply. The first priority of the EU Action Plan is to prevent trade in wild species and to address its causes. The second is to ensure the effective implementation and enforcement of existing rules to combat organised crime in wild species. A third priority is to strengthen the global partnership between countries of origin, consumption and transit to combat illicit trafficking in wild species.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report, which calls on the EU and Member States to have a shared responsibility to step up to the challenge of halting the rapid decline in some of the world's more valuable and cherished species. In doing so, we will be preserving our rich biodiversity for future generations, which is essential.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety states in its report that illegal trade in wild fauna and flora poses a serious threat not only to the survival of many species of flora and fauna, but also to the rule of law, human rights, global governance and local the welfare of communities, but most importantly the survival of the world's ecosystems. Illegal trade in wildlife and flora has grown into a billion-dollar crime industry dominated by criminal organisations. The risk of exposure is insignificant and the financial gain is high. The European Union is an important player in the fight against wildlife crime and flora, while it is one of the main target markets for illegal wild flora and fauna products, as well as transit and often origin, wild fauna and flora illegal trafficking. The Action Plan calls for immediate action to complete the capture of and illegal trade in protected species and to reduce the demand and supply of illegal wild flora and fauna products. It reinforces the EU's role in the global fight against illegal trade in wild fauna and flora through prevention, implementation and cooperation. I supported the adoption of this report.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. — This text combines highly commendable intentions for the protection of wildlife, as already called for by the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES), with clear violations of state sovereignty. It calls on several occasions to increase the EU's financial resources or to set up international funds for this destination. However, the European Union does not have to take such decisions which fall within the competence of States, already all parties to the CITES Convention. While it is important to support local initiatives in the countries concerned to find alternative income to those generated by trafficking, no interference should be accepted, as several African countries have recalled. In addition, recommendations on criminal law are problematic insofar as it encroaches on a major area of national sovereignty. Abstention.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. — This text combines highly commendable intentions to protect wildlife species, as already called for by the CITES Convention, with clear violations of state sovereignty. It calls on several occasions to increase the EU's financial resources or to set up international funds for this destination. However, the European Union does not have to take such decisions which fall within the competence of the States, already all parties to the CITES Convention. While it is important to support local initiatives in the countries concerned to find alternative income to those generated by trafficking, no interference should be accepted, as several African countries have recalled. In addition, recommendations on criminal law are problematic insofar as it encroaches on a major area of national sovereignty. I therefore abstain from this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which states that wildlife crime needs to be recognised as a major international issue, with profound implications for the environment, governance, local economies, and so on. It requires urgent attention in terms of political and financial support for the countries affected by it, as well as a more responsible approach to global trade.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this text, which proposes to ban trade in ivory and rhino horn and calls for the adoption of strengthened joint sanctions against wildlife trafficking. This traffic amounts to around €20 billion a year and becomes one of the main forms of transnational organized crime. So we need to equip ourselves with new tools to better combat it.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: in writing. - I fully support this report as illegal trade in wild fauna and flora has a significant negative impact on biodiversity, existing ecosystems, natural heritage of countries of origin, natural resources and species protection. I believe that trade and development policies should, among other things, serve to increase respect for human rights, animal welfare and the environment.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Wildlife crimes poses a real threat to biodiversity and is currently being regarded as a security issue in some source countries. I have voted in favour of this report that will put in place an EU action plan aiming to prevent wildlife trafficking and address its root causes.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the problem of wildlife trafficking is very large worldwide, with major implications and ramifications in all kinds of illegal activities. Cartels providing the flow of wild species into markets around the world are the same or closely related to those trafficking in human beings, drugs, firearms and ultimately support instability in certain states or regions through direct or indirect action, and even terrorist organizations. I welcome the fact that all EU Member States have committed themselves to fighting wildlife trafficking, because I believe that it must follow the same path and determination already demonstrated in the fight against IUU fishing. The Commission's proposed EU action plan on combating wildlife trafficking sets out the dimension of the problems we currently have at global and European level. I also support this report because in this document there are objectives and actions that will complement the strategies already existing in certain specific sectors.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: in writing. — I abstained from voting on this report because I believe that the Austrian livestock must be protected in a sustainable manner. Furthermore, an action plan to combat international biodiversity trafficking is a challenge to militias and terrorist groups, which are directly or indirectly financed, inter alia, by trade in wild animal and plant species.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — Wildlife trafficking is an industry that generates billions of euros and, in particular, allows the financing of criminal groups around the world. As the main player in the fight against this trafficking, but also the hub and target of it, the European Union had to have a worthy action plan. That is done with this report. The discussions were particularly rich and constructive, with the subject widely endorsed, and the amendments relating to hunting trophies and the definition of the financial and human resources needed to implement the plan have been satisfactorily integrated. I voted in favour of this report, in keeping with my position on this issue which I am defending in the ENVI Committee.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported. Survival of plant and animal species is essential to perpetuating the world's ecosystem. Coordinated action by countries is needed to combat organised international crime with wild species.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this action plan because the European Union is an important player in the fight against wildlife crime because it is a major destination for illegal wildlife products, as well as a transit point and often a source for illicit trafficking wild species, particularly among the countries of Africa, Asia and Latin America, but also the European Union itself. The Action Plan forms part of the European Union's response to the UN Agenda for Sustainable Development for 2030. The first priority of the action plan is to prevent illicit trade in wildlife species and to address its root causes. The second priority is to ensure the effective implementation and enforcement of existing rules to combat organised crime against wild species. The third priority is to strengthen global cooperation between countries of origin, consumption and transit to combat illicit trade in wildlife. Finally, the Member States of the European Union bear a common responsibility in tackling this problem and preventing the rapid decline in the population of some of the rarest wild species in the world.

name: Gilles Pargneaux (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this action plan against wildlife trafficking. With its 8 to 20 billion euros in profits per year, wildlife trafficking is the fourth most lucrative illicit activity after drug trafficking, human trafficking and arms trade. Large iconic animals such as rhinoceros, elephant and great apes are involved, which is not without an impact on the survival of these species. I therefore support the European Commission's action plan to combat these trafficking and also call for a total and immediate ban on trade in ivory and rhino horn in Europe.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ I would vote in favour of the proposal from my colleagues because I believe that already in 2015 the need to combat crimes committed against wild species as they represent a crime serious and, increasingly, growing, in fact trade in species involves a turnover of billions of euros. This action plan would be included within the framework of EU responses to the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development of the United Nations and, in particular, the Sustainable Development Objective 15, which calls for measures to be taken against poaching and trafficking in wild species. Moreover, the European Union has a key role in this fight because the European territory represents not only the transit point but also the origin of illegal trafficking. The Member States that make up the European Union cannot stand still because this illegal animal trafficking harms human rights, the welfare of the local community and the survival of the ecosystem world. Therefore I would vote upvote.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: written. - I supported the report on the EU Action Plan to tackle the illegal trade in wild fauna and flora. The report recognises all the challenges of the global world and warns of the threats posed to societies by illegal trade in wild flora and fauna. The report also recognises the position and importance of European space as a transit area and as a place of end destination and illegal trade. I welcome calls for improvement and all forms of combating this form of organised crime. That fight must be adequately funded. Member States, but also the European Union itself, must take care of ensuring the necessary administrative capacity and the stakeholders, regardless of their function performed in this fight, must be adequately substantially and competently trained. I also want to take the opportunity to acknowledge all assistance and support the activities of citizen NGOs undertaking in this fight against the illicit trade in wild fauna and flora both within the EU and in the area of third countries from which specimens come from. We have the appropriate legislative framework and will only improve in the coming time. It's time to consistently enforce it because there are no valid reasons not to do so.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Despite the increasing attention and sensitivity of the public, poaching and trafficking of wild animals continue to grow and have become one of the forms of crime organized more relevant and lucrative, with an estimated annual value of around 20 billion euros. Some studies reveal an unprecedented spike in the ivory and rhino horn trade. In addition to posing a serious threat to biodiversity, these trades are also a serious problem for the security of countries of origin. And Europe is one of the main outlet markets. I therefore agree with the report's call for the Union and each Member State to tackle these kinds of crimes as a genuine political emergency, improving cooperation between all actors involved and developing a coordinated approach of the various sectoral policies: trade, development, foreign affairs, justice and home affairs. Only in this way will it be possible to effectively combat wildlife trafficking and poaching. It is essential that everyone should work to stop the rapid decline of the most endangered animal species and to protect the wealth of biodiversity and the future of our children.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: written. - Illicit trade in wild fauna and flora is a form of organised international crime whose annual value is estimated to be around €20 billion and finances other forms of organised crime. I consider this type of trade as a serious threat to world security, political stability and economic development. It is necessary to more systematically investigate the links between the illicit trade in wild fauna and flora, as well as regional conflicts and terrorism. The EU must build a coordinated and strategic approach that encompasses all relevant stakeholders. I therefore welcome the Commission Action Plan highlighting the need for coordinated action aimed at tackling the causes, the effective application of existing rules and strengthening global cooperation between home, transit and target countries. The EU, third countries and civil society need to lead a series of campaigns to raise awareness in order to reduce demand for trade through genuine and lasting changes in the behaviour of individuals and society. The EU should also urgently address the problem of corruption and the shortcomings of international governance measures along the chain of illegal trade in wild fauna and flora. We must not be a generation that witnessed the sixth major extinction of species on our planet, to which the illegal trade in wild fauna and flora contributes without doing anything. Future generations deserve to see nature in all its riches as we know it.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Crimes against wildlife such as poaching, the illegal trade in species or the illegal transit of products and derived from wild fauna and flora have become a billion euro criminal industry dominated by organised criminal groups. The detection risk is low and the financial repercussions are high, attracting criminal gangs to exploit illegally captured, displaced and marketed wildlife to finance their criminal activity. The EU is an important destination for illegal wild products, as well as a transit point and often a source for wildlife trafficking, especially between Africa, Asia and Latin America, and is therefore responsible for combating this phenomenon. The EU Action Plan presented by the Commission lists a number of measures to be taken by the EU institutions or Member States. The measures are primarily aimed at improving cooperation between all actors, making more effective use of existing instruments and policies, and strengthening synergies between them, so that the fight against wildlife trafficking can be more effectively addressed throughout the EU and globally. We have voted in favour.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: ‒ The European Union represents an important player in combating crime against wild species as an important destination for wild species of illegal origin both as a point of transit for illegal traffic between Africa, Asia and Latin America. The action plan presented by the Commission lists a number of measures which the Community institutions and Member States must take in order to tackle illegal wildlife trafficking throughout the EU and in the world. I believe it is necessary to strengthen the global partnership between countries of origin, consumption and transit against illegal trafficking in wild species by offering political support and technical assistance to the main countries of origin, transit and destination. The EU should use its economic power to incorporate clauses in existing and future trade agreements that refer to the need to combat illegal trafficking in wild species. I fully agree with the solutions and ideas offered by the rapporteur in this document. That's why I voted for it.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. — Wildlife trafficking is one of the most lucrative forms of organized crime and is often used to finance the activities of terrorist groups. In addition, it undermines the balance of ecosystems and endangers many animal species. I have therefore decided to vote in favour of this report, which provides for the introduction of common sanctions against wildlife trafficking and also aims to completely ban the trade in ivory.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP abstained on the non-legislative report on wildlife trafficking. We in UKIP are aware that wildlife trafficking poses a serious and growing threat. However, we believe that national parliaments, not the unelected EU Commission, should decide with regard to updating and improving animal welfare.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: in writing. — The European Parliament responded this afternoon to the Commission's action plan to combat wildlife trafficking. A very lucrative trade, which produces between 8 and 20 billion euros each year and threatens the survival of many species (rhinos, elephants, great apes, tigers, but also pangolins and sturgeon). Two strong proposals are made: firstly, to prohibit in the territory of the Union any purchase of ivory and rhino horn. It is out of the question to ignore the reality of the figures: an elephant is killed every twelve minutes, and the ivory of its defenses yields more in Africa than drug trafficking! The Union must empower Europol to combat this criminal activity more effectively. Moreover, it is essential to harmonise criminal sanctions within the Union and ensure that they are truly deterrent. It is unacceptable that traffickers in some EU countries will only incur mere fines of up to EUR 15 000, while the rhino horn on the black market can reach the price of EUR 50 000. Defending large mammals and all endangered species is a moral duty for Europe and Europeans. This should be a priority.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. - The Action Plan is part of the EU's response to the United Nations 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, and in particular Sustainable Development Goal 15, which requires urgent action to put an end to poaching and trafficking in protected species, and to deal with demand and offer of illegal products of wild species. The trade in wild species has become a sector dominated by organized criminal groups, involving sums of billions. The risk of discovery is low and the financial return is high, attracting criminal groups to the illegal exploitation of wild species captured and withdrawn from the wild to finance their criminal activities. Worldwide, non-state armed groups, terrorist groups and others are increasingly involved in environmental crimes, taking advantage of the exploitation of natural resources, as they are easier to use than income from other forms of exploitation, such as illicit trafficking in drugs, cigarettes or migrants. We therefore advocate immediate measures to better protect endangered animals and plants, by banning their trade immediately and the application of appropriate sanctions.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Illegal trafficking in species is a phenomenon whose scale has increased considerably in recent years. Poaching has reached unprecedented figures for some species such as elephants, rhinos, sharks, tigers, big apes, turtles, pangolins or corals, and their populations are being alarmingly reduced.
