The negative effects of this activity are not limited only to biodiversity, but also affect economic growth, law enforcement and, in some regions, its political stability due to the financing of militias with these activities. To combat these criminal activities, I supported this Action Plan (2016-2020) based on three pillars: prevention, implementation and cooperation, on the basis that the main legal instrument at international level and at Union level is the CITES Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Fauna and Flora Wild. The plan provides an overall view of everything Member States and the Commission can do, setting out a comprehensive set of measures that the institutions must take to meet the challenge of halting the rapid decline of some of the most valuable and appreciated species in the world.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of Parliament's resolution on the European Union action plan against wildlife trafficking. On this subject, I wish to be very clear. The European Union must immediately and without exception ban trade in ivory and rhino horn within its borders. Moreover, I am in favour of harmonizing sanctions against those around these atrocities. The resolution also contains other recommendations that the Commission and the Member States should follow up in order to effectively combat trafficking in wild species.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — Combating illicit animal trafficking is an expression of both humanism and a responsible approach to environmental protection. It is to be welcomed that there is already an action plan to combat such trade. I support this initiative and even call for its improvement by focusing more on cooperation with third countries in this area, for example by extending the concept of development cooperation with some countries discussed above to include more aspects related to illicit trade animal reduction.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. - Trafficking in wild species is increasingly a serious threat to the survival of multiple species of fauna and flora, and it also represents an attack on the values of the rule of law, global governance, the preservation of world ecosystems and the well-being of local communities. The wildlife trade has proved to be a millionaire business, dominated by organized criminal groups that exploit wild species in a vile and totally illegal manner that are captured and removed from their natural habitat to make huge profits from them. I therefore welcome the adoption of this report, in which the EU plays an important role in the fight against wildlife crimes, which have on the continent of Europe a transit point, destination and often the origin of wildlife trafficking. This action plan represents a positive point in this fight, as it also incorporates the United Nations 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, notably with regard to the poaching pillar and trafficking in and trade in protected species. I broadly welcome the set of priorities set out in the Action Plan, and for that reason I voted in favour of adopting this report.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report, which calls for common policies and sanctions against wildlife trafficking. In particular, the text calls for the prohibition of trade, export and re-export of ivory and rhino horn. Wildlife trafficking is the fourth largest criminal activity and generates around €20 billion a year. There is an urgent need for the European Union to establish common rules for defining the offences and penalties related to this criminal activity. As such, trophy hunting, which is one of the causes of extinction of certain wildlife species, must be strictly framed and punished. Wildlife trafficking is often linked to other forms of organized crime, such as money laundering. That is why Member States must use all available means and instruments, including cooperation with the financial sector, in order to effectively combat this important criminal activity. Finally, I supported this text because it calls for greater cooperation between the European institutions and the Member States with online marketplaces to counter the phenomenon of illegal sale of wildlife products.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report on the EU action plan against wildlife trafficking. Wildlife trafficking has become a multi-million dollar criminal industry set up by criminal groups. The Union action plan proposes a series of measures which I consider to be essential and which seek the cooperation of the actors involved (within the Union and outside). The report calls on Member States to increase the level of surveillance in this regard. In addition to supporting proposals included in the report as an appropriate item and human resources necessary for the implementation of the plan or monitoring the evaluation of the mechanisms carried out by States, we also support those that emerged from the ENVI committee and the GUE/NGL shadow, such as introducing a point on import of hunting trophies, ivory, and the participation of NGOs and civil society in this process.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on an EU action plan to combat wildlife trafficking, which identifies concrete measures against wildlife trafficking in the EU. The Action Plan was issued by the Commission in February 2016. The main focus is on cooperation between Member States and the promotion of the effective use of existing instruments against wildlife trade.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution which welcomes the EU action plan against wildlife trafficking presented by the Commission, as it emphasizes the need for coordinated action to address the causes of wildlife trafficking, effectively implement and enforce existing rules, and strengthen global cooperation among countries of origin, transit and destination. The text also calls on the Commission, the Member States, the European External Action Service, Europol and Eurojust to recognize that wildlife crime constitutes a serious and growing threat and to address them as urgently as possible. It also emphasizes the need for comprehensive and coordinated approaches between different policy areas. As the text also urgently calls for greater protection for areas designated as vulnerable marine ecosystems, ecologically or biologically important marine areas and Natura 2000 sites, my vote has been in favour, since it supports essential measures to protect and combat trafficking in species wild.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: In writing. ‒ Illegal trafficking in wild species originates profits that are around €20 billion a year, establishing itself among the biggest and most profitable organised crime offences cross-border. The growth of such criminal activity over the last decade is strongly threatening the biodiversity and survival of endangered species. I have decided to support this report in the hope that the necessary measures will be taken to strengthen the overall partnership between Member States and third countries, to improve the effectiveness of existing instruments and to adopt common rules on sanctions relating to such illegal trade.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this issue, whilst I care deeply for the protection of animals. I also whole heartily believe that we should ban the illegal ivory trade. However, I cannot support the EU implementing this.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. – Today I voted in favour of the report on the EU action plan against wildlife trafficking. It is fully in line with Labour's initiatives in the field of wildlife protection and conservation as well as the tackling of wildlife crime. Wildlife crime needs to be recognised as a major international issue, with profound implications on the environment, governance, local economies, and so on.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution. Trade in wild species needs to be controlled. It is now dominated by various organised criminal groups taking advantage of the fact that the risk of detection is small and profits large. I welcome the EU Action Plan in this area, one of the priorities of which is to prevent trade in wild species, and it considers it essential to address its causes (e.g. high market demand for illegal products).

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: written. - Illegal trade in wild flora and fauna is a form of organised international crime, which, with its rise in recent years, points to a serious threat to world security, political stability, economic development and the rule of law. The European Union is on a regular route as a target market, transit route, but also a source of illegal trade in endangered European plant and animal species. If this practice continues, it is quite clear that the disappearance of endangered species will occur, so timely and targeted resolution of the whole situation, both within and outside borders, is extremely important for effectively stopping such actions. The problem of combating illicit trade in wild flora and fauna is covered by the EU Security Programme 2015-2020, which says this illegal action threatens biodiversity in the original regions, sustainable development and regional stability. Accordingly, it is necessary to mobilize and involve civil society with the aim of raising awareness of the cessation of purchase of products of suspicious origin. Likewise, the role of the transport sector should be emphasized due to the importance of introducing an early warning system and detecting criminal actions. I supported the European Parliament resolution aware of the scale of this growing problem to allow law enforcement to be applied, increase cooperation and prevention of criminal action, and to recognise the EU as a destination market, source and transit point for illegal trade.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing. - Illicit trafficking in wild species is among the most lucrative forms of illicit trafficking in the world in international crime. This is evidenced by the fact that the value of this trading is estimated at EUR 20 billion a year and has been increasing in recent years. I voted in favour of the resolution because I believe that, against illegal trafficking in wild species, we need to take measures that ensure the effective implementation and enforcement of existing rules and that strengthen global cooperation between countries of origin and transit; and the countries of destination. I also supported the Action Plan because I consider trafficking in wild species to be a very serious threat to global security, political stability and economic development. I believe that, like the EU and individual Member States will put in place national action plans on wildlife trafficking, detailing enforcement policies and sanctions against violators. In this context, I also expect that, in order to prevent wildlife crime, there will be better cooperation between agencies and stakeholders, both at European and national level.

name: Bart Staes (Verts/ALE)
text: ‒ Illegal trade in wild plants and animals by criminal organisations is becoming a growing problem. The link between the two lies in the fact that the proceeds are relatively easy to gain profits and are therefore an attractive source for criminals to finance their activities. The European Union has drawn up an action plan to minimise this type of trade as far as possible. Among other things, it states that prevention is better than cure and that, through campaigns, the first thing to do is to reduce the demand for and supply of wild animals and plants. The correct penalties of illegal traders can also diminish such practices. Close cooperation between countries of origin, marketing and transit of illegal smuggling is essential in this respect. Together with a shared responsibility of all Member States on these points, we can both save different species of animals and plants and ensure the preservation of our ecosystem. The Green Group supports this plan, but calls for radical additions. For example, there must be a ban on ivory trade, hunting trophies and the illegal hunting of wild animals in Europe.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Ι voted against this resolution. First and foremost this should not be an area in which the EU intervenes. However, this resolution also fails to grasp the nature of the problem. Just as with overfishing, the real problem with wildlife trafficking is that a tragedy of the commons combined with the high demand for certain products created from exotic animals contributes towards their potential extinction. The EU cannot really contribute a solution to this problem.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: written. — Offences in the field of wild flora and fauna are on the rise and threaten further loss of species. We urge the EU and third countries to implement campaigns aimed at changing the behaviour of individuals and society, which would lead to a reduction in demand for illegal wild flora and fauna. The illegal trade in wild flora and fauna has become an activity whose value is measured in billions of euros and in which criminal groups lead the main word, while helping finance terrorist groups as well. I accept the report as it highlights the common responsibility of EU Member States and the need to face the challenge of illegal trade in wild flora and fauna. This will not only preserve biodiversity for future generations, but also improve and strengthen the EU's security framework.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Illegal trade in wildlife has become a billion-euro criminal industry controlled by organised criminal groups. Low detection risk and high profits attract gangs that exploit illegal wildlife trapping and transport to fund their criminal activities. The Action Plan sets out some priorities for the period 2016-2020 that will strengthen the role of the European Union in combating wildlife trafficking globally: prevention, law enforcement, cooperation and recognition of the European Union as a market destination, source and transit point for products of wild species. For these reasons we have voted in favour of the report.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: in writing. - The first priority of the Action Plan is to prevent illicit trade in wildlife species and to address its root causes; the second priority of the Action Plan is to ensure the effective implementation and enforcement of existing rules to combat The third priority is to strengthen global cooperation between countries of origin, consumption and transit to combat illicit trade in wildlife.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: in writing. — It is the joint responsibility of the European Union and the Member States to combat the drastic decline in more valuable species in the world, for example by taking action against illegal trade in wild animals. In this way, we can preserve biodiversity for future generations, and in this light, I voted in favour of this report. The report describes that illegal trade in wild fauna and flora constitutes organised international crime with an estimated annual value of around EUR 20 billion and that this activity is closely linked to other forms of organised crime. This practice corresponds to the sixth wave of mass extinction of species and must be stopped. That is why I share the joy of this report with regard to the Commission's action plan against illegal trade in wildlife and flora. This Action Plan highlights the need for coordinated actions to address the causes of illegal trade in wild fauna and flora, effectively implement and enforce existing legislation and global cooperation between countries of origin, transit and destination in order to strengthen it. The report underlines the importance of identifying and allocating adequate financial and human resources for the implementation of the Action Plan and proposes the establishment of a coordinator office and a sanction system based on the model to be used to combat trafficking in human beings in the Member States.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: in writing. —In recent years, the world has seen an increase in crime against wildlife. Shocking photos became daily: rhinos and elephants bleeding to death, or birds, amphibians and reptiles being smuggled across borders and held in inhumane conditions. Moreover, the illegal trade in wildlife and flora has become one of the most lucrative forms of activity by organised crime groups, with the size of its turnover estimated at between €8 billion and €20 billion a year. Recent years have also seen a significant increase in global demand for animals themselves or their products, and the scale of trade is already so great that it now threatens the existence of very many of the most recognizable species on Earth. One factor that favors illegal trade in fauna and flora is the non-uniform legal system of individual states, resulting in international organised crime moving with sales to countries with low sanctions or low performance of the relevant services. The fight against this processor therefore requires a closer partnership between the countries of origin and transit and the countries of destination sales, as well as cooperation between regional actors. Without meeting this condition, I fear that soon we will see the extinction of very many valuable species of plants and animals in different countries of the world.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. - Wildlife trafficking is one of the main causes of the increase in the number of endangered species worldwide. The European Union is the main market for this kind of harmful trade, with revenues of billions of euros, including hunting trophies. In this context, it is necessary to regulate this practice properly, which is considered a threat to biodiversity at European level and to international peace and security, under the involvement of organised crime groups. Thus, for the period 2016-2020, an EU Action Plan was developed, in response to the UN 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, calling for urgent measures to eradicate poaching and trafficking in protected species. This document will strengthen the EU's role in combating wildlife trafficking worldwide by preventing the root causes of practice and implementing existing rules against organised wildlife crime. An important emphasis is also placed on strengthening the global partnership between countries of origin, consumer countries and transit countries. The EU and the Member States are responsible for preserving biodiversity for future generations. I support the adoption of this report.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Drug trafficking, human trafficking, arms trade: here are the three most lucrative activities in the criminal sector. At the foot of this podium, with up to €20 billion in annual profits, is the trafficking of wildlife, plants and objects derived from these illicit businesses. The situation worsens from year to year, leading to the disappearance of certain species. The horror: the more rare a species becomes, the higher the price of the products associated with these murders, causing the massacre to intensify. The European Parliament proposes an action plan and calls for exemplary sanctions to combat this scourge. Without biodiversity, there will be no more humanity.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Wildlife trafficking is the world's fourth-largest criminal activity, with rhino horns now worth more in weight than gold. The smuggling of wildlife goods is worth around 20 billion euros annually, with devastating effects on wildlife and biodiversity across the world. Further, trafficking has had major implications for the rule of law, security and the economic development of many countries. The EU, as an important destination and transit point, must urgently step up its efforts to combat this criminal activity, which is why I voted in favour of the report on the EU action plan against wildlife trafficking.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the report on the action plan against wildlife trafficking. There is little talk about it, yet this type of trafficking is the fourth most lucrative illicit activity after drug trafficking, human trafficking and arms trade. Parliament's own-initiative report supports an action plan presented by the European Commission in February 2016. As a member of the Committee on Fisheries, I am convinced that it is through the fight against this type of trafficking that we will be able to stem undocumented and unreported illegal fishing. Because it is often through on-shore controls that one can influence actions at sea. Specifically, for species such as eels, which are highly prone to poaching, the control should result in the implementation of traceability mechanisms, thus avoiding licit fishermen from paying the price of a bad reputation of the chain induced by frequent illegal acts.

name: Ivica Tolić (PPE)
text: written. - I support the Motion for a Resolution on the EU Action Plan to combat the illegal trade in wild fauna and flora. I believe that the motion for a resolution adequately addresses the establishment of prevention against illegal trade in wild fauna and flora, emphasizing the importance of its suppression for environmental conservation, but also to protect the rule of law and human rights system. I also believe that it is necessary to increase efficiency in tackling illegal trade in fauna and flora, which should be based on higher penalties and greater efficiency of state repressive apparatus. Since trade in wild fauna and flora is a global problem, in which the European Union is often a transit point, it is necessary to reach consensus at the level of the international community and strengthen the global partnership on this issue.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - I have supported the proposal for a resolution by the European Parliament on an EU Action Plan to combat illegal wildlife trade. On World Wildlife and Plant Day in 2015, UN Secretary-General Ban Ki Mun said it was time to start seriously addressing wildlife offences. The wildlife and plant industry has become a criminal industry worth billions of euros. There is a need to make efforts to curb this. The European Union is one of the main players to solve this problem, as it is one of the objectives of trade as well as the transit route. And not only that, Europe is itself the point of origin of this illegal trade. Therefore, it is necessary to prevent illegal trade and find its causes. Effectively it is necessary to implement and enforce the rules in force to combat organised crime linked to wildlife. We also need to strengthen the global partnership to facilitate prevention.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report on the EU action plan against wildlife trafficking. Wildlife trafficking has become a multi-million dollar criminal industry set up by criminal groups. The Union action plan proposes a series of measures which I consider to be essential and which seek the cooperation of the actors involved (within the Union and outside). The report calls on Member States to increase the level of surveillance in this regard. In addition to supporting proposals included in the report as an appropriate item and human resources necessary for the implementation of the plan or monitoring the evaluation of the mechanisms carried out by States, we also support those that emerged from the ENVI committee and the GUE/NGL shadow, such as introducing a point on import of hunting trophies, ivory, and the participation of NGOs and civil society in this process.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report on the EU action plan against wildlife trafficking. Wildlife trafficking has become a multi-million dollar criminal industry set up by criminal groups. The Union action plan proposes a series of measures which I consider to be essential and which seek the cooperation of the actors involved (within the Union and outside). The report calls on Member States to increase the level of surveillance in this regard. In addition to supporting proposals included in the report as an appropriate item and human resources necessary for the implementation of the plan or monitoring the evaluation of the mechanisms carried out by States, we also support those that emerged from the ENVI committee and the GUE/NGL shadow, such as introducing a point on import of hunting trophies, ivory, and the participation of NGOs and civil society in this process.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I welcome the Commission Action Plan to combat illicit wildlife trafficking, which highlights the need for coordinated action to address the causes of illegal wildlife trafficking, to effectively apply and implement existing rules.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the EU action plan against wildlife trafficking. Wildlife trafficking is an organised international crime which is estimated to be worth approximately EUR 20 billion annually and which has increased worldwide in recent years, becoming one of the biggest and most profitable forms of organised cross-border crime. The report welcomes the Commission’s action plan against wildlife trafficking, which highlights the need for coordinated actions to address the causes of wildlife trafficking. It calls for a targeted and coordinated series of awareness-raising campaigns by the EU, third countries, stakeholders and civil society with the aim of reducing demand related to the illegal trade in wildlife products. I voted in favour because I strongly believe that that wildlife protection must be a key element in the EU’s global poverty reduction strategies.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This EU Action Plan consists of 32 broad-spectrum measures designed to improve cooperation between different actors, make the use of existing tools and policies more effective and strengthen synergies between them, so that wildlife trafficking can be tackled globally. The problems linked to the phenomena of poaching and illegal trafficking have yearly profits of between EUR 8 000 and 20 billion euros, hence it has become one of the most lucrative organized illicit activities worldwide. These practices have a disastrous effect on biodiversity and pose a threat to the survival of some species such as elephants, rhinos, great apes or tigers. Moreover, especially in some regions of Africa they provide an incentive for corruption and therefore have a certainly negative impact on their economic development potential. In support of actions that strengthen border control, coordination and cooperation mechanisms, as well as provide technical support to countries of origin within the framework of international programmes, I have considered it appropriate to vote in favour of this text.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution which welcomes the EU action plan against wildlife trafficking presented by the Commission, as it emphasizes the need for coordinated action to address the causes of wildlife trafficking, effectively implement and enforce existing rules, and strengthen global cooperation among countries of origin, transit and destination. The text also calls on the Commission, the Member States, the European External Action Service, Europol and Eurojust to recognize that wildlife crime constitutes a serious and growing threat and to address them as urgently as possible. It also emphasizes the need for comprehensive and coordinated approaches between different policy areas. As the text also urgently calls for greater protection for areas designated as vulnerable marine ecosystems, ecologically or biologically important marine areas and Natura 2000 sites, my vote has been in favour, since it supports essential measures to protect and combat trafficking in species wild.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ With my Labour colleagues, I voted in favour of this report as it remains fully in line with our initiatives in the field of wildlife protection and conservation as well as the tackling of wildlife crime. Wildlife crime needs to be recognised as a major international issue, with profound implications on the environment, governance, local economies, and so on. It requires urgent attention in terms of political and financial support for the countries affected by it, as well as a more responsible approach to global trade.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: — I voted in favour because the illegal trade in wildlife and plants has become a criminal billion-dollar industry dominated by organised criminal groups.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: Trafficking in endangered wildlife species and their derived products violates State sovereignty and endangers entire ecosystems. It represents a substantial shortfall to the detriment of the populations concerned, especially in “developing” countries. It is often linked to other organized international crimes, including arms and drug trafficking. One can therefore only welcome the fact that the European Union is increasingly interested in taking into account the seriousness of these crimes. The report calls for deterrent penal sanctions and the human, financial and expertise necessary to effectively enforce these sanctions. I regret, however, that the text encourages the use of development aid for this purpose. It is imperative to use separate funds, such as fines imposed. I also regret the question of biopiracy is not mentioned once. The fight against poaching to luxury markets is of paramount importance, but trafficking in wildlife genetic data and their unscrupulous beneficiaries must not be forgotten. However, I voted in favour of this report, which is in the right direction.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Trafficking in wild species poses a serious and growing threat not only to the survival of numerous species of flora and fauna, but also to the rule of law, human rights, global governance, the welfare of local communities and, above all, the survival of ecosystems world. The trade in wild species has become a sector dominated by organized criminal groups, involving sums of billions. The risk of discovery is low and the financial return is high, attracting criminal groups to the illegal exploitation of wild species captured and withdrawn from the wild to finance their criminal activities. The European Union and the rich countries are responsible for these crimes insofar as they benefit from the chaos promoted by imperialism on the African continent, use the tax havens created by major financial centres, and finally they are the final destination of unlawfully obtained goods, whether in the form of skins, ivrins or other derivatives. Sufficient reasons not to whistle to the side and act as soon as possible in a determined manner.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: in writing. - The Member States are not only the market, but also the market of origin, for trade in endangered European animal and plant species. The Austrian livestock must be protected in a sustainable way — a structured exchange between Member States (including Europol) can make a significant contribution to this. Furthermore, an action plan to combat international biodiversity trafficking is a challenge to militias and terrorist groups financed directly or indirectly, inter alia, from trade in wild fauna and flora. One must be critical of the call for an unconditional and immediate ban on the trade in ivory and rhinoceros horn (including the legal state), with the option of a possible expansion to other endangered species. A categorical ban on hunting of certain animal species promotes poaching and illegal trade in, for example, hunting trophies, and therefore has the opposite effect than the EU action plan envisaged. It should also be refrained from the guise of the planned/revised legislation with the US Lacey Act, with its legal roots in the US case law. However, these objections are disproportionate to issues such as plant and animal welfare and the fight against terrorism. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report together with fellow Labour MEPs as it is fully in line with Labour's initiatives in the field of wildlife protection and conservation (at home and abroad) as well as the tackling of wildlife crime. Wildlife crime must be recognised as a major international issue, with profound implications for the environment, bio-diversity, governance, sustainable tourism, local economies, and so on. It requires urgent attention in terms of political and financial support for affected countries, as well as a more responsible approach to global trade. I would like to acknowledge the excellent work undertaken by civil society in raising awareness of the issue and helping to build public and political support. In line with my parliamentary work on this issue I have also taken personal action by sponsoring one of the threatened species, namely a young male Black Rhino called Lankieu.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted for the own-initiative report which welcomes the Commission's Action Plan against Wildlife Trafficking. Wildlife trafficking is a form of international organised crime that is estimated at around €20 billion annually and has increased worldwide in recent years, becoming one of the largest and most profitable forms of organised crime cross-border. This type of trafficking is closely linked to other forms of serious and organised crime that it finances. Wildlife trafficking has a major negative impact on biodiversity, existing ecosystems, the natural heritage of countries of origin, natural resources and species conservation.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: in writing. - The illicit trade in wild animals is a scourge inherent in the capitalist way of production, as it flourished in conditions where the hunt for profit is the criterion of any human activity either legally or illegally. The report proposes a number of measures (sanctions, specific references to trade contracts, exchange of information, financial support for awareness-raising actions in third countries) to be exploited as an opportunity for penetration and as a mechanism for indirect trade protection in favour of business. It entrusts repressive mechanisms, such as Europol, Eurojust, EEAS, with the implementation of European Union policy and known NGOs, another tool for penetration under the pretext of “raising awareness of local populations”. The European Union's involvement in illegal trade is part of the business competition to control market fields and is not intended at all to combat smuggling or to protect wildlife, since in the capitalist economy served by the European Union the conditions are created for such phenomena to perpetuate and everything is sacrificed on the altar of profitability. That is why environmental protection cannot be tackled irrespective of the motivation of production. Only a path of development with an organization of economy and society based on the social ownership of all natural resources with labour power can shape the conditions for environmental protection.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing. - I supported Mrs Bearder's report on an action plan against illicit trafficking in wild species. The EU Action Plan, which is to be fully implemented by 2020, aims in particular to combat these crimes and to strengthen the role of the European Union as a leader in the global fight against illegal activities against wild species. I agree with the objectives and the approach of this action plan. Wild species crime is a matter of transnational importance, and its negative effects on biodiversity, as well as the possible financing of further crime precisely through the proceeds of illegal commercial activities in wild species, must be clearly recognised. This is why states should regard this subject as a matter of political urgency and should choose a coordinated and effective approach to combat activities that threaten wild species.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: I voted in favour of the Bearder report because I believe that the EU and the Member States have a shared responsibility to halt the rapid decline of wild species. I welcome the Commission's action plan against wildlife trafficking, which underlines the need for coordinated action to address the causes of wildlife trafficking, to implement and enforce existing rules effectively, and to strengthen global cooperation between countries of origin, transit and Destiny. I would like to highlight the call on the European institutions and agencies to recognise that wildlife crimes are a serious and growing threat and to give the utmost political urgency to their approach. Only through a comprehensive and coordinated approach in policy areas such as trade, development, foreign policy, transport and tourism, justice and home affairs can we preserve biodiversity for future generations.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. — Wildlife trafficking has an estimated value of 20 billion euros per year and has recently grown, becoming one of the largest and most profitable forms of organized crime cross-border. We are facing the fourth largest organized criminal activity on the planet. Because the risk of being discovered is low, while profits are high, exploiting wild species caught or removed illegally to fund their own criminal activity is tempting to those criminal groups. It is really time for serious action and together with my colleagues at the M5S we have called for a total and immediate ban at European level on trade, export or re-export within the European level of the EU and to destinations outside the EU of ivory and rhino horns. We urged Member States to define the appropriate levels of penalties for offences against wild species and urged the Commission to work towards the adoption of common rules relating to the definition of offences and penalties relating to the trafficking of wild species. Sanctions against wildlife trafficking must be very severe to reflect the seriousness of this offence and must be equal across the EU. I therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted for the Report on the EU Action Plan to tackle illegal wildlife trafficking. Illegal wildlife trafficking is a form of organised international crime, which is thought to be worth around €20 billion a year, and has been growing worldwide in recent years, becoming one of the largest and most profitable forms of organised cross-border crime. As illegal wildlife trade has a very negative impact on biodiversity, existing ecosystems, natural heritage of the countries of origin, natural resources and species conservation, I support the allocation of the relevant financial and human resources necessary to effectively launch the Action Plan fight against illegal wildlife trade.

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE).
text: - Mr President! The topic addressed in this report is extremely important for numerous reasons. The paper focuses on the challenges companies face in the transport sector, and on recommendations on how to exploit existing potential. I would like to draw your attention today to an insanely important element that this document has sadly run out of. It's about clarity, the rule of law and predictability that allow businesses to grow and invest. Unfortunately, due to the actions taken in some Member States, like France or Germany, many traders providing cross-border services have been in a position of legal ambiguity. This situation for Germany has been going on since the beginning of 2015 (in a moment it will be two years) and has still not been clarified by the European Commission. I would like to make it very clear that the problem is not the introduction of a minimum wage — it is a very positive decision that needs to be considered and commended — the problem is the vague rules and the enormity of the administrative burden that will hit the smallest companies. The situation in the transport sector has a huge translation into the competitiveness of the whole European economy, even because of the level of transport costs. I would therefore like to once again call on the European Commission to clarify the doubts surrounding the application of the minimum wage for various transport services as soon as possible.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I was pleased to vote in favour of this report on unlocking opportunities for small transport businesses. The sharing economy’s potential to create jobs and wealth and to tap into underused resources, its collaborative function, and even its vision for improved resource consumption, make it a good fit for modern-day society. However, the report acknowledges the impact that the take-up of digital technologies in the sector can have on working conditions. It is termed the ‘gig economy’ for a reason. Our efforts are rightly focused on improving the wage-earning opportunities and ensuring competition for small transport businesses. It is important to make the economy more inclusive in this regard. Ireland is in the vanguard of embracing opportunities within collaborative business models, according to a recent Eurobarometer poll. I therefore welcome the recommendations offered in this report on how to ensure that the collaborative transport sector, as popularised by Uber, works for everyone involved.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ This report aims to analyse the reality of small transport companies in Europe, especially in the light of the new opportunities offered by digitisation and models of collaborative economics. The main objective is to amend the current rules on international transport and cabotage, in order to overcome the serious disruption to the national transport markets that occurred as a result of the introduction of Regulation (EC) No 1072/2009 of the European Parliament and of the Council, such as social dumping and unfair competition by undertakings from eastern Europe in particular. Specifically, it calls for improved access to credit for small businesses, to introduce a modernized multimodal regulatory framework that promotes innovation and competitiveness, the protection of consumers and their data and the protection of workers' rights. For these reasons I voted favourably.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against this report because I believe that the collaborative economy, on which the report is focused, is not a new opportunity, but a label that distracts attention from the changes experienced in the sectors concerned. The technological opportunity offered by new technological developments should not be confused with their use to precarious work in the respective sector and avoid existing fiscal and social obligations, for example in transport: a reality that should not be hidden or disguised.

name: Martina Anderson Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – While this voting list offered many new opportunities for small transport businesses, it made no differentiation between a transport company and those transport sharing services operating in the collaborative economy. There were elements of the file that were in essence the thin end of the wedge to allowing for recognition of Uber, etc. More so, it calls for a single European transport area, to which we are opposed.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted against this report on the digital economy and transport, as it has been diverted from its objective. The development of digital platforms in transport must be framed, and I can only regret that this report contains elements that aim to limit the ability of states to regulate platforms like Uber. This contradicts the message sent in favour of a modernized regulatory framework, particularly to defend workers' rights. I strongly support innovations that clearly fall under the collaborative economy, fundamentally based on sharing, such as BlaBlaCar in the transport sector. But it's better when saying it: Uber and its clones don't belong to the collaborative economy! Those who claim it are going wrong! It is more an economy of digital platforms for which regulation is essential. My responsibility as a socialist is to fight against forms of social and tax dumping in order to guarantee workers' rights, to combat the precarization of routes, to ensure the training of drivers and to promote fair competition for the benefit of small businesses in the face of large companies.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on new opportunities for small transport undertakings. The lack of important statistics makes it difficult to understand the real situation of small transport enterprises in Europe. Small transport undertakings are difficult to assess because they are of a very different nature depending on the mode of transport, the country, the type of services provided and the competitive structure of the market in which they operate. However, these companies play an important role in the transport of both passengers and goods and facilitate the mobility organised by historically large enterprises. By better understanding the subtleties of the local market, being closer to customers and/or often being flexible and capable of innovating, small enterprises have developed individual transport, especially the remaining last miles in densely populated areas. Unfortunately, legal uncertainty in the definition of 'transport service providers' hinders fair competition and reduces the ambitions of many small businesses, while the diversified public aid available to small businesses at EU and national level is not always easy to use, deadlines do not correspond to innovation cycles. I agree that Europe needs to be more attentive to small businesses and to take more action to create a single European transport area and to harmonise the application of legislation, to improve consumer protection and to promote fair competition and to better harmonise local authorities and small transport actions by enterprises to improve urban mobility, which will lead to less carbon emissions in the future.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on new opportunities for small transport enterprises, including cooperative business models, because I consider these enterprises to be an integral part of mobility in Europe.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted against this report, which aims to improve the performance of small transport companies, particularly because of the importance of the internet in placing orders for delivery or transport of passengers. Challenges for small transport companies are defined fairly accurately. The problems of social dumping, the distribution of profits between freight or passenger control platforms are addressed. But, once again, European ideology blinds the recommendations. The main one, aimed at enabling the harmonious and competitive development of small transport enterprises, would be the integration of the transport market by standardizing legislation. Clearly, once again, a levelling down in the countries of Western and Northern Europe... Here, as in most European reports, certain guidelines are constantly coming back, including a standardization of the legal framework (except for wage, social and tax burdens), increased liberalisation and rejection of the subsidies in general, and cosmetic considerations: the reduction of pollution and the fight against social dumping, which are the logical and immediate consequence of the two preceding points, but which serve only for political signage.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution as the United Kingdom is already investing heavily in small transport and the over-regulation that this resolution talks about is caused by the EU itself.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this text: it is necessary to take into account the challenges faced by transport companies. With often limited means, they face a growing demand for mobility under the constraint of limited infrastructure and environmental requirements. In fact, action must be taken to complete the Single European Transport Area taking into account the specificities of the various actors in the sector.

name: Inés Ayala Sender (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this own-initiative report because it presents a number of recommendations for transport SMEs to benefit from the potential of new forms of a collaborative economy. In addition, it reflects the need to fill several of the gaps in Union legislation, especially in tax and social matters, which are being used to ensure that some undertakings, even if they are small at the moment, escape national regulations in such important matters as social security, consumer law, as far as to the quality of service and safety. I support innovation in the transport sector and more efficient transport initiatives that enable SMEs to benefit from new technologies. However, I do not agree on deregulation and the “everything goes” to offer a cheaper service to the detriment of workers' rights, business taxation and transport safety. I will therefore be attentive to the measures announced by the European Commission next year.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. — Whereas the interest of the subject is real, the report is undermined by an ideological and Europeanist point of view; between standardization of the legal framework, outrageous liberalisation and rejection of subsidies, all barely masked by pseudo-ecological considerations, this report would certainly draw the countries of Western and Northern Europe towards the bottom. I voted against it.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. — All the companies in question play a crucial role in the transport of passengers and goods by putting oil in the cogs of mobility historically structured by the “big”. With a thinner local market knowledge, greater proximity to the customer and/or often agility and ability to innovate, small businesses improve individual passenger transport, especially during the fateful last mile in densely populated areas. Similarly, in landlocked areas where the construction of a railway infrastructure or the organization of public transport would be too expensive, private cars are often the only means of movement possible for certain categories of the population. Small transport companies are therefore consubstantial to European mobility. Yet they are full of talents that need a supportive environment to deploy. This is where the regulator can and must accomplish its mission by providing the most favourable regulatory, social and fiscal environment. Thus, small transport companies will be able to transform into opportunities the many challenges facing them today, first of all, the ICT revolution.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of the Riquet report on new opportunities for small transport companies, including models of collaborative economy. This is an important text that analyses the difficulties and opportunities for SMEs, microenterprises and start-ups, in the transport sector, maintaining as reference the new commercial models and the context of collaborative economics. The growth of the digital economy and the emergence of platforms are profoundly changing the environment in which small transport companies find themselves operating, with new challenges also stemming from development of connected and self-guided vehicles. Complex realities requiring new instruments and commitments at European level to promote fair growth and proper competition in the emerging market. The approved text underlines the need to produce a clear legal framework, in particular for platforms, which will allow the creation of a true single European transport area, with measures for address anti-competitive practices, to encourage European start-ups and to ensure adequate investment. The European approach is the only possible to create a true integrated mobility system and to support the emergence of new business models.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I have decided to vote against this report, because I understand it is not sufficiently strongly positioned in the face of the risks posed by the uncontrolled emergence of some digital platforms in the transport sector. I understand that the emergence of new operators on the market should not undermine the rights of operators already present, nor the ability of the competent public authorities to define their mobility strategies.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: Unfortunately, this report is another example of the ability of the European institutions to recognise the consequences of a situation they themselves have created, but to propose solutions that will only repeat this destructive pattern. For example, Mr Riquet's text sets out the good findings concerning the challenges faced by small transport companies: social dumping or the distribution of profits between transport control platforms, which often take place at the expense of small businesses or self-entrepreneurs to the benefit of large companies. However, the remedies proposed are intended to be lethal, since again and again the recommended solution requires harmonisation of national legislation; as usual, their reasoning is as follows: the EU is dysfunctional? So we need more EU! Standardization of legislation, particularly in the field of safety and training, would in fact lead to a levelling down, preventing national industries from being competitive, in the name of sacrosanct fight against distortion of competition. Because I believe in the know-how and potential of French transport companies, I voted against this report.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: In writing. ‒ Although I have the text sharable cues, there are unclear passages that could give rise to future criticalities, I therefore expressed myself with a vote of abstention.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report because it expressed Parliament on the situation of small transport undertakings in Europe. Small transport undertakings play an important role in ensuring smooth mobility in Europe, but they often find it difficult to enter or survive this market, especially because of monopolies on this market. Small businesses provide additional benefits in particular to remote and densely populated areas, as they are well aware of the local market, are close to customers and/or viable and are capable of innovation. Small businesses can also provide tailored services and help fight social exclusion, create jobs, economic activities, improve mobility management and contribute to tourism development. Transport companies face challenges to respond to the growing need for mobility in the context of underdeveloped infrastructures and increasing environmental requirements. All vehicles are under pressure to provide safe, sustainable and highly competitive solutions that would be environmentally responsible under COP21 and reduce congestion, but it is harder and more expensive for small businesses to cope with this. This is why Parliament calls on Member States to abolish excess regulation, which is often associated with reflexes of protectionism and corporativism, which promotes fragmentation, complexity and rigidity of the internal market and increases inequality.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: in writing. — Small and medium-sized transport enterprises play a significant role in managing traffic on European roads and make a significant contribution to the EU economy and job creation. The report we are voting on the opportunities and challenges faced by these companies, therefore it is very important that it is on the plenary agenda. Unfortunately, however, I feel contrary to this positive line point 37 of the report, which calls into question the derogation for light vehicles on the grounds that they have an unreasonably high presence in international traffic. However, we must point out that there is no reliable data on this and if these carriers are to comply with all the requirements for vehicles above 3.5 tonnes, this may impose a disproportionate financial and administrative additional burden on them. That is why I cannot support this point in the report. Overall, however, I agree with the report and voted in favour of it.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: in writing. - I accept the need to provide new opportunities for small transport companies and I have supported the report as they face major challenges in responding to growing mobility needs amid limited infrastructure and increasing environmental requirements. They are also hampered by current legal uncertainty, unequal playing field and difficult access to developing and offering new services. It is therefore necessary to support the new opportunities provided by small transport companies and new collaborative and business models. However, obstacles caused by the unequal application of EU rules between Member States need to be eliminated to ensure greater competitiveness and level playing field for all.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ With the development of new economic models, European small and medium-sized enterprises especially in the transport sector face significant challenges to respond to an increasing demand for mobility, with the constraint of limited infrastructure and increasing environmental requirements. All these companies play an essential role for passenger and freight transport, just where the “big” transport networks do not come to provide their services. To meet this need, the sector has proved to be a fertile ground for the collaborative economy, a system able to optimize the meeting between supply and demand on the market, but often putting in SME difficulties in terms of price and competitiveness. I therefore support the report tabled by the European Parliament because it contains proposals aimed at translating these many challenges into as many opportunities for SMEs. This means accelerating efforts in order to complete the single European transport area by putting an end to disparities in the application of law on this issue. The interest placed in the analysis of new models of collaborative economics aimed at encouraging a convergence between traditional economy and collaborative platforms to promote innovation , consumer protection and fair competition within a flexible and harmonised legislative framework.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution as it suggested how to transform current challenges into new opportunities for small transport businesses. First of all, I consider that a more integrated European mobility system is the best way to offer a better and competitive environment to all companies. Last, I think new forms of service provision in the goods transport sector need to be taken into consideration looking at the potential of new technologies.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: ‒ Small transport companies in Europe are more difficult to evaluate because their profiles differ, according to the country, the type of service provided and the competitive structure of the market in which they operate. They are found: family-owned businesses, SMEs, micro-enterprises, craft enterprises and newly created enterprises. They all play an essential role for the transport of passengers and goods, thanks to a finer local market knowledge, greater proximity to the customer and/or agility and capacity for innovation. New technologies, accessible for small businesses, optimizing the meeting of supply with demand, introduce a radical upheaval, which poses, for small businesses, the challenge of taking advantage of from the digital transition. There is also an urgent need for the transport sector, to reduce its carbon emissions. Finally, the problems in the application of law are important, so small businesses suffer more from the lack of a single European transport area. It is therefore necessary to accelerate efforts to complete this single space, to promote innovation, consumer protection and fair competition; and to organise better concertation between the authorities Local and small transport companies to improve urban mobility.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: This report aims to contribute to the development and increase the performance of small transport enterprises. Instead of tackling real threats to industry professionals such as social dumping in the European Union, exacerbated by the Posting of Workers Directive, or the problem of unequal distribution of profits with order platforms, this report takes advantage of this topic to spill propaganda usual of the European Union. Indeed, there is a need to standardize national legal frameworks, and to complete the liberalization of these activities, inter alia, by rejecting all national subsidies. However, the first measure will promote social dumping with social harmonisation down of social protection systems, while the second will weaken companies supported through economic patriotism. That is why I voted against this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are the main engine of the European economy, accounting for 99.8% of all enterprises in the non-financial sector in 2014. In recent years, job-creating SMEs are mainly found in the service sector, playing a key role in the smooth functioning of mobility in Europe. Unfortunately, they often face difficulties in accessing and maintaining the market, especially because of the presence of monopolies. I have expressed myself in favour of this report because I believe that a regulatory and administrative framework is needed to encourage investment and access to finance while ensuring sustainable growth and quality jobs in small businesses in the transport sector.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of this report, which provides for new development opportunities for small transport companies and promotes the quality of services offered. Increasing demand for mobility and the resulting pressures to deliver safe and sustainable solutions are a difficult challenge for small businesses, especially in terms of costs. In this regard, the European Fund for Strategic Investment (EFSI) can be a useful tool to contribute to the development of innovative mobility solutions for SMEs operating in the field of transport. It is vital to improve urban mobility, through greater collaboration between local authorities and small businesses, especially in anticipation of future changes related to the transport sector. The aim of the report is to translate these challenges into concrete opportunities by implementing the single European transport area and promoting a convergence between the traditional economy and platforms, in such a way as support innovation.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The UK is already investing in the future of small transport businesses. In 2013, UK competitiveness recovered in comparison to the rest of the EU and the world. The report calls for Member States to put an end to over-regulation. However we know through the EU’s REFIT programme that they admit to over—regulation themselves.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I believe that time is ripe for the Commission to present a road map on connected cars, and to analyse the potential effects that the widespread use of this technology could have on the European transport sector. One of the big challenges for the future is to create a positive business environment for entrepreneurs in the collaborative economy. The proposed measures/recommendations need to help attain a level playing field, reduce bureaucratic burdens, ensure sufficient workers and consumer rights whilst at the same time laying the foundations for enterprises to take advantage of all available opportunities to grow.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: In writing. ‒ The report aims to analyse Europe's small transport business sector, which is very difficult to trace, in the light of the new opportunities offered by digitisation and by collaborative economics models. Some important proposals for development are therefore made in this regard. Among them: the request for revision of Regulation 1072/2009 (the introduction of which has created disruption in national markets) which regulates current standards on international transport and cabotage; establishment of cooperation structures between small transport companies, scientific research institutes and local and regional authorities to promote sustainable mobility; the identification of a regulatory framework Modernized multimodal promoting innovation and competitiveness, the protection of consumers and their data, the protection of workers' rights. I certainly voted for it.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: ‒ European transport companies face significant challenges to respond to increased demand for mobility and increasing environmental requirements. These challenges can and should be turned into opportunities. In particular, I believe that the development of collaborative business models can make a great contribution to optimizing vehicle and infrastructure use, weakening monopoly positions existing and also allowing small businesses to emerge in these areas. However, many remain open issues regarding collaborative economics and transport, both at national and European level. I believe that Member States should put an end to the phenomenon of excessive regulation, which fragments the internal market and does not guarantee clarity to providers and users of transport services. At the same time, the Union is called upon to create a clear and multimodal legal framework, which promotes innovation and competitiveness, as well as the protection of consumers and their data. I considered voting in favour of the report because I believe that the completion of the single European transport area is essential for the functioning of the internal market, but it is also a great deal development opportunities for small and medium-sized enterprises in Europe.

name: Ole Christensen (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Social Democratic Party is for platform economics and fully recognises the gains that online platforms in the transport sector can bring in terms of, for example, less climate and environmental pressures and increased flexibility. That is why we are concerned with ensuring fair terms for the platform economy. At the same time, it is crucial for us to maintain the orderly conditions of the Danish labour market in order to prevent social dumping and unfair competition. We insist that online platforms that provide services and generate profit meet their obligations over worker rights, tax deposit and security for consumers. The report expresses criticism of regulation and of cooperation between government, folketing and social partners, which works well in Denmark and other countries. We have therefore abstained from voting in favour of the report.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: in writing. - We support the report and stress that small transport enterprises are an integral part of mobility in Europe. In addition, they have plenty of talents that need a favorable environment to express themselves. So this is the task that the legislator can and must carry out: to create the most favourable regulatory, social and tax conditions possible. This is the only way that small businesses will be able to turn into opportunities the numerous challenges they face today, and above all the challenges arising from the ICT revolution.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The report on new opportunities for small transport enterprises, including cooperative business models, is an effort to revitalise and boost the transport business sector, focusing in particular on small and medium-sized enterprises. Although it contains positive elements, certain references to employment issues find me against it, and that is why I have decided to abstain.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ The role of small and medium-sized enterprises in Europe is singular to say the least: they represent 99.8% of all companies in the non-financial sector and are responsible for two-thirds of all posts work. They represent a reality that, combined with the fundamental and growing weight of logistics and transport, requires ad hoc measures to develop in full. I therefore support the report with the confidence that new opportunities for small transport companies blossom. This is a very complicated sector and, therefore, the challenges are many such as the increasing demand for mobility with the constraint of limited infrastructure and increasing environmental requirements to which it is difficult to do forehead. However, we need to turn challenges into opportunities by making efforts to complete the single European transport area and by establishing regulations imposing new requirements on small businesses more suitable for their conformation and their needs, in particular in tax matters. Jointly, it calls for the effective use of the European Strategic Investment Fund, and it must therefore be accelerated in its implementation in order to increase its assistance for small businesses and start up in the preparation of innovative projects based on the development of new mobility solutions.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the Report on new opportunities for small transport businesses, including collaborative business models.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. - All companies play a crucial role in the transport of passengers and goods. Thanks to a more specific knowledge of the local market, closer customer proximity and capacity to innovate, small businesses improve individual passenger transport. Small transport companies are therefore inherent in European mobility. New technologies dramatically modernise the mobility economy. These platforms, particularly those linked to the collaborative economy, while optimising the allocation of supply and demand, introduce a radical change in the transport landscape. In the face of the arrival of new entrants, the legal uncertainty regarding the definition of transport service providers prevents the creation of fair competition and hinders many ambitions of small businesses. I support the need to speed up efforts to complete the single European transport area by putting an end to disparities in the application of the law. We must encourage convergence between the traditional economy and platforms, and their collaborative economy models, in order to promote innovation, consumer protection and fair competition. For this reason, I support this report, which will contribute to improving urban mobility, which will be entirely low-carbon in the future.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: ‒ I voted in favour because the measure encourages a convergence between the traditional economy and the new platforms - including collaborative economy models - so as to encourage the innovation, consumer protection and fair competition between small transport companies which today play an essential role in the transport of passengers and goods making it easier to historically articulated mobility for “large” companies thanks to a more accurate local market knowledge.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Sustainable development and the revolution in the field of information and communication technology have created unprecedented opportunities and challenges for firms of all sizes in terms of responding to the increasing demand for sustainable mobility within the constraints of limited infrastructure. This is a reality and we need to combat anti-competitive practices by large integrated groups to tackle discrimination and market access restrictions. I agree with the rapporteur who calls for integrated and coordinated European mobility system as the best way of properly integrating all companies offering all modes of transport into a common dynamic process in which digitisation and promoting innovation from within the transport sector is most effective method of ensuring that customers have a single coherent system and that professionals are best placed to add value. Consumer expectations seek easily accessible, convenient and flexible ways to use transport services while prices are maintained reasonable.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against this report because I believe that the collaborative economy, on which the report is focused, is not a new opportunity, but a label that distracts attention from the changes experienced in the sectors concerned. The technological opportunity offered by new technological developments should not be confused with their use to precarious work in the respective sector and avoid existing fiscal and social obligations, for example in transport: a reality that should not be hidden or disguised.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: ‒ Small transport companies play an essential role in the transport of passengers and freight, thanks to a finer local market knowledge, greater proximity to the customer and often an agility and capacity for innovation. Therefore, I believe it is important to define a regulatory, social and fiscal environment as favourable as possible, especially in the light of technological developments that see a very high ground in this area fertile. In this respect, it is important that Member States develop a structured collaborative business response, which promotes competitiveness. To this end, I believe that the completion of a single European transport area, accompanied by measures to tackle anti-competitive practices, is the key to encouraging the development of start-ups and to ensure that EFSI funds are also made available in the transport sector.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. Small transport undertakings bring together all those undertakings which provide passenger or freight services. All this plays a decisive role in passenger and freight transport, facilitating mobility. The importance of information and communication in transport has made this sector naturally a fertile ground for the digital economy, and the first challenge for these businesses is the digital transition. Whether they are active participants or not, they must adapt to avoid decline. Currently, due to differences in application and its non-compliant use, economic and social distortions of the market remain widespread, while small businesses are severely affected by the absence of a single European transport area. I voted in favour of speeding up efforts to complete the Single European Transport Area, thus putting an end to irregularities arising from legislative gaps.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: in writing. — Small and medium-sized transport enterprises play a significant role in managing traffic on European roads and make a significant contribution to the EU economy and job creation. The report we have voted on is about the opportunities and challenges facing these companies. It points out that all transport undertakings are under pressure to offer safe, sustainable, highly competitive, innovative, COP21 compliant, environmentally conscious solutions. It believes that the EU needs more innovative start-ups and young entrepreneurs in the transport sector. It notes that new technologies and drones represent enormous potential in the freight sector. It also invites the Commission to cooperate with Member States to develop cooperation and communication platforms. However, I do not agree with what is stated in point 37 of the report, because it calls into question the derogation for light vehicles on the grounds that they have an unreasonably high presence in international traffic. Firstly, reliable data on this is not available, and if small and medium-sized enterprises had to comply with all the requirements for vehicles above 3.5 tonnes, this would impose a disproportionate financial and administrative additional burden on them. I therefore did not support this point in the report. Overall, however, I agree with the report and voted in favour of it.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The transport sector faces many challenges and possibilities in the emergence of the collaborative economy. A coherent European approach is needed to support the emergence of new business models and SMEs and to provide services with and alongside existing operators on the market. I am in favour of this own-initiative report which identifies both the challenges and opportunities for small businesses in the transport sector while also encouraging the completion of a single European transport area.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to abstain on this item because, whilst the report makes many admirable conclusions and I welcomed the attack on protectionist barriers in transport, I could not support the claims and implications of ‘social dumping’ also contained in the report. The report claims new business models such as Uber can create distortions in terms of pay and social security systems, thereby leading to ‘social dumping’ and then goes on to suggest that a coordinated multi-modal European regulatory framework is the best way these new businesses have of outcompeting established firms in the market.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. Small and medium-sized enterprises play a decisive role in passenger and freight transport, facilitating mobility, traditionally structured by the 'big actors'. They have the advantage of getting better acquainted with local markets, are closer to customers and bring significant benefits in densely populated areas, but also in remote areas where building railway infrastructure or public transport would be too expensive and the car is often the only possible means of transport for certain categories of the population. I therefore support supporting these businesses - family businesses, SMEs, micro-enterprises, craft enterprises or start-ups - because they operate in a well-defined market segment and often depend on large enterprises, without necessarily pursuing exponential growth. In addition, they make an important contribution to ensuring the mobility of citizens at European level.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ The collaborative economy is actively contributing to the development of more efficient and sustainable forms and models of business, particularly in the field of transport and urban mobility. A real important resource that often benefits consumers, who have greater choice at lower costs, and improve connectivity in outlying, mountain and rural regions.
