On the other hand, as stated in the text of the Riquet report on new opportunities for small transport enterprises, including models of collaborative economy, market self-regulation or current regulatory fragmentation at national level, sometimes even regional or local, do not guarantee an adequate regulatory environment for the development of small European businesses and start-ups Innovative in the transport sector. The real challenge ahead, in fact, will be to establish a field of actions and rules coordinated at European level, which will ensure the full development of these new collaborative business models, but which at the same time be fair to actors in the traditional economy, who must not be unfairly penalised by unfair competition or the lack of legal certainty about it by a precise definition of service providers in the transport sector.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: This own-initiative report contains several proposals aimed at transforming many challenges into opportunities for small transport companies. Among these proposals are those aimed at accelerating efforts to complete the Single European Transport Area, ending disparities in law enforcement, encouraging convergence between the traditional economy and intermediation platforms, including collaboration models, and finally organising a better coordination between local authorities and small transport companies in order to improve urban mobility, which should be decarbonized in the very near future. Considering that these measures are effective means of promoting innovation, protecting consumers and fair competition, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: I voted in favour of this report on new opportunities for small transport companies. This report provides credible recommendations to ensure that small businesses, as a source of innovation, in the transportation sector do not succumb to the anti-competitive practices of large groups. In this context, it seems to me particularly important for the European Union to encourage coordination between local authorities and SMEs in order to improve the quality of transport offers.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: in writing. — Small and medium-sized transport enterprises play a significant role in managing traffic on European roads and make a significant contribution to the EU economy and job creation. The report we are voting on the opportunities and challenges faced by these companies, therefore it is very important that it is on the plenary agenda. Unfortunately, however, I feel contrary to this positive line point 37 of the report, which calls into question the derogation for light vehicles on the grounds that they have an unreasonably high presence in international traffic. However, we must point out that there is no reliable data on this and if these carriers are to comply with all the requirements for vehicles above 3.5 tonnes, this may impose a disproportionate financial and administrative burden on them. That is why I cannot support this point in the report. Overall, however, I agree with the report and voted in favour of it.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR)
text: — Small transport companies with a diverse profile, from family businesses to SMEs, from craft businesses to innovative start-ups, play a major role in the transport of both goods and passengers. Because they usually know the local market better and are closer to their customers, they often provide very valuable services, including and especially in the fine-meshed transport network. As new information and communication technologies have now become accessible to these small transport companies, the sector can fully modernise, with not only the supplier and the customer better off, but also the positive effects for the sustainable use of the limited capacity of our transport infrastructure. It goes without saying that it is very important that European policy does not hinder this evolution by poorly adjusted rules which are tailored only to the larger companies. This report strives for the most favourable regulatory, social and fiscal environment for small transport companies, so that they too can adapt and respond to the opportunities offered by these new technologies. That is why the N-VA MEPs support this report.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I come from a country such as Italy, where small and medium-sized enterprises are crucial for territorial development. The collaborative economy, which I am convinced advocate, sets in motion the digital economy that small and medium-sized transport companies can access for optimizing vehicle use and reduction of costs. In addition, the small size of SMEs often have the advantage of being more competitive in the territory they cover, both in densely populated and more isolated areas, for their knowledge of local market, greater proximity to the customer and innovation capacity.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted against this text. This text aims to improve the performance of small transport companies. Social dumping and the problem of the distribution of profits between freight and passenger control platforms are the main difficulties encountered by the latter. The solutions proposed to these real difficulties are nevertheless unsatisfactory, since the text proposes the establishment of a single market involving, inter alia, standardising the legal framework and limiting public aid. We cannot therefore support this report.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. I supported the opinion on new opportunities for small transport enterprises, including joint business models. The report underlines that Member States must tackle over-regulation and anti-competitive behaviour, which leads to fragmentation of rules and creates difficulties for small businesses. It calls for harmonisation of rules on access to regulated professions and activities that will facilitate the development of new operators and services related to digital platforms.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: in writing. - Today, because of divergences and failures in the application of the law, economic and social market distortions continue to exist, while small enterprises are even more affected by the absence of a genuine single European transport area. We are voting in favour of the report, as we agree with the rapporteur and his proposals, in order to turn the numerous challenges into opportunities for small businesses.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: in writing. — Small and medium-sized transport enterprises play a significant role in managing traffic on European roads and make a significant contribution to the EU economy and job creation. The report we are voting on the opportunities and challenges faced by these companies, therefore it is very important that it is on the plenary agenda. Unfortunately, however, I feel contrary to this positive line point 37 of the report, which calls into question the derogation for light vehicles on the grounds that they have an unreasonably high presence in international traffic. However, we must point out that there is no reliable data on this and if these carriers are to comply with all the requirements for vehicles above 3.5 tonnes, this may impose a disproportionate financial and administrative burden on them. That is why I cannot support this point in the report. Overall, however, I agree with the report and voted in favour of it.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: in writing. ‒ Vote against: the interest of the subject is real but the report is flawed by its Europeist, utopian and falsely eco-social apprehension.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This report aims to focus on the need to boost the transport market at the level of small and medium-sized enterprises, with a special focus on companies in the so-called collaborative economy. Indeed, the aim is to launder the ongoing processes of deregulation of the sector and to clear the way for the multinationals who want to dominate it. The report diagnoses the reality of the sector, with references to the existence of monopolies (which would not be good for its development), the great flexibility brought about by digitisation, in contrast to the overregulation, protectionism and corporatism that jeopardize the internal market. The report welcomes the emergence of new models of the collaborative economy, which the EU should support (considering the opportunities opened by the EFSI and bearing in mind that most of those operating in the internal market are American) and criticises the fragmented response of Member States to growth of these models, which would be inconsistent with the potential and benefits of the sector and contrary to consumer expectations. The report also supports flexible working models, which would be beneficial to workers. The report conceals the lack of support for public transport policies and public mobility strategies. Its goal is another: to promote the UBER of this life. We voted against it.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution because I think it is necessary to support the role of small and medium-sized enterprises, but also start-ups, which operate in the transport sector. In particular, I welcome the request for regulatory simplification measures, linked to a clear and proportionate legal framework for small transport companies, together with the need to regulate rules European the increasing use of light vehicles for the international transport of goods.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: In writing. ‒ I abstain because from a certain point of view it is a positive report that criticises too much legislation and bureaucracy in this matter, but on the other it has some too neoliberal passages.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: in writing. - Today, because of divergences and failures in the application of the law, economic and social market distortions continue to exist, while small enterprises are even more affected by the absence of a genuine single European transport area. I am voting in favour of the report, as I agree with the rapporteur and his proposals, in order to turn the numerous challenges into opportunities for small businesses.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. – The report criticises anti-competitive practices which can lead to serious distortions such as social dumping. It notes the importance of flexible working models as negotiated with social partners, while also emphasising the opportunities in increased digitalisation in monitoring driving time and rest time. It warns of the dangers of a concentration of data by a limited number of platforms. It also notes the importance of decarbonisation in the sector, and the role of public transport in rural and remote areas which should be maintained. The transport sector faces many challenges and possibilities in the emergence of the collaborative economy. A coherent European approach is needed to support the emergence of new business models and SMEs and to provide services with and alongside existing operators on the market.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report bearing in mind that small transport companies are particularly difficult to assess, since their profiles are very varied depending on the mode of transport, the country, the type of service provided and the competitive structure of the market in which they operate. Thanks to their more thorough knowledge of the local market, its greater proximity to the customer, and often their agility and ability to innovate, small businesses improve the transport of individual passengers, especially in the areas furthest from large urbanizations. These companies need to take advantage of the digital transition and respond environmentally friendly to growing mobility needs. However, from the Union institutions, we must accelerate efforts to launch the Single European Transport Area in order to help create a more competitive and efficient sector.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this own-initiative report because it presents a number of recommendations for transport SMEs to benefit from the potential of new forms of a collaborative economy. In addition, it reflects the need to fill several of the gaps in Union legislation, especially in tax and social matters, which are being used to ensure that some undertakings, even if they are small at the moment, escape national regulations in such important matters as social security, consumer law, as far as to the quality of service and safety. I support innovation in the transport sector and more efficient transport initiatives that enable SMEs to benefit from new technologies. However, I do not agree on deregulation and the “everything goes” to offer a cheaper service to the detriment of workers' rights, business taxation and transport safety. I will therefore be attentive to the measures announced by the European Commission next year.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. I supported this own-initiative report because it presents a number of recommendations for transport SMEs to benefit from the potential of new forms of a collaborative economy. In addition, it reflects the need to fill several of the gaps in Union legislation, especially in tax and social matters, which are being used to ensure that some undertakings, even if they are small at the moment, escape national regulations in such important matters as social security, consumer law, as far as to the quality of service and safety. I support innovation in the transport sector and more efficient transport initiatives that enable SMEs to benefit from new technologies. However, I do not agree on deregulation and the “everything goes” to offer a cheaper service to the detriment of workers' rights, business taxation and transport safety. I will therefore be attentive to the measures announced by the European Commission next year.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ Small, medium and micro-enterprises make up 99% of European enterprises. Some 21 million SMEs are numbered, which employ around 133 million people. In parallel, in addition to being a key sector of the economy, transport contributes decisively to economic development (4.8% in total gross value added for the 28 EU countries) and create more than 11 million jobs in Europe. SME active in the transport sector make mobility easier where it is too articulated for large enterprises (airlines, naval and rail) both for the transport of people and goods. Thus, small transport companies are an integral part of European mobility. In a Europe that envisages the involvement of SMEs in technological development through different financing measures, small transport industries must also be included. Finally, individuals who create start ups in the transportation industry can be regarded as freelancers. Freelancers, in Europe, number 4 million and correspond to 11 million jobs. Even in the case of the transport sector, we must continue to fight to ensure that their activity is recognised as equal to those of SMEs.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the 'Report on new opportunities for small transport companies, including those pursuing collaborative business models', because I believe that there may well be modern alternative models to bus, train and taxi. However, the report explicitly calls on Member States to identify problems, such as tax fraud, and to develop legal solutions from the challenges.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: in writing. - I support the desire to create new opportunities for small transport companies as the transport industry has changed in the face of technological innovation, new business models and digitalisation. There is a need to establish a coherent and sustainable environment in which innovation, consumer protection and fair competition are ensured.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The UK is already investing in the future of small transport businesses. In 2013 the UK competitiveness recovered in comparison to the rest of the EU and the world. This report called for EU Member States to put an end to over-regulation, however, we know through the EU’s REFIT programme that they admit to over-regulation themselves: so who is to blame here? I voted against this resolution.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ President, I voted in favour of this report which underlines the necessity to support transport SMEs at European level. Investing in these businesses and deploying synergies between different Member States is vital for developing the single European transport area in a manner that benefits passengers. With more detailed knowledge of the local market, greater proximity to the customer and in many cases agility and ability to innovate, small businesses are instrumental in improving transport for each individual passenger.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I have decided to vote against this report, because I understand it is not sufficiently strongly positioned in the face of the risks posed by the uncontrolled emergence of some digital platforms in the transport sector. I understand that the emergence of new operators on the market should not undermine the rights of operators already present, nor the ability of the competent public authorities to define their mobility strategies.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: in writing. - As shadow rapporteur for the Committee on Transport and Tourism, I voted for this report thanks to concrete proposals to improve the situation of small transport companies by creating new opportunities. Transport SMEs have to face many challenges to withstand the market. The European and national institutions must support them. In the report, I proposed that the Member States and the Commission take appropriate measures to combat the anti-competitive practices of large integrated groups related to large carriers. We also called for a roadmap on the release of data on publicly funded transport, to ensure transparency. In addition, the report also calls for the establishment of cooperation structures between small transport enterprises, research institutes and local and regional authorities with the aim of organising urban and interurban mobility.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which underlines the necessity to support transport SMEs at European level. European Member States will benefit hugely from improving the European transport area. This will be of great benefit to small businesses and to passengers.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. I supported this own-initiative report because it presents a number of recommendations for transport SMEs to benefit from the potential of new forms of a collaborative economy. In addition, it reflects the need to fill several of the gaps in Union legislation, especially in tax and social matters, which are being used to ensure that some undertakings, even if they are small at the moment, escape national regulations in such important matters as social security, consumer law, as far as to the quality of service and safety. I support innovation in the transport sector and more efficient transport initiatives that enable SMEs to benefit from new technologies. However, I do not agree on deregulation and the “everything goes” to offer a cheaper service to the detriment of workers' rights, business taxation and transport safety. I will therefore be attentive to the measures announced by the European Commission next year.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The report is written in order to represent the interests of multinational transport undertakings in order to create a stable legal framework for efforts aimed at promoting the development of the cooperative economy and, in the name of this legal framework, considers that safety is used as a pretext for creating artificial barriers. This report defends entrepreneurship, but not workers' rights, calling for more flexible working and working time relationships. It also defends the Single European Transport Area, which is the European way to promote the privatisation of the sector. The report does not mention a strong public transport network, it does not explain why public transport is low in use and growth in some areas. There is also no mention of any objective of reinvesting in public transport, strengthening public networks, but it says: 'SMEs are an important complementary element'. It is for these reasons that we consider it appropriate to vote against.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution on new opportunities for small transport business. Transport business across the EU faces considerable challenges in order to respond to the increasing demand for mobility in a sector that is particularly complex concerning safety and environmental regulation. Small transport businesses are finding it harder and more expensive than ever to remain in this competitive market due to over-regulation, in particular regarding access to the profession, the marketing of transport services and subsidisation. This resolution calls on the Member States to end this over-regulation and specifically to improve the serious disruption that has occurred on national transport markets in several states since the introduction of regulation EC No 1072/2009.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour since I have no objections.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ This report deals with the issue of small transport undertakings that are particularly hard to evaluate because of varied profiles depending on the mode of transport, country, type of service provided and the competition structure of the market in which they operate. There are family businesses, SMEs, micro-businesses, craft trades and start-ups. As they all fall to a greater or lesser extent within the interstices of the mobility system, they each require a differentiated Approach. I voted in favour.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written. - I voted for the Report on New Opportunities for Small Transport Businesses, including cooperation-based business models because SMEs are the main driver of the European economy, and should be helped to turn the challenges put before them in this Report into opportunities. All transport companies are under pressure to offer safe, sustainable and highly competitive solutions that simultaneously protect the environment under the COP21 agreement and limit congestion. It is harder and more expensive for small businesses to face these and many other challenges, so this Report considers that any regulation, which imposes new conditions on small businesses, among other things in tax, social and environmental issues, must be proportionate, simple and clear, must not brake their development and, where necessary, must reflect the regional and national characteristics of individual Member States.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. — This report contains a number of very fair remarks on the problem of social dumping or the distribution of profits, but the whole is tarnished by European ideology in its recommendations for the integration of the transport market through standardization of legislation. Despite the real interest of the subject, the rest of the guidelines call for a more assertive liberalisation and a falsely ecological and social interest, ultimately leveling from the bottom. I voted against it.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of my colleague Dominique Riquet's report on new opportunities for small transport companies. The aim of this text is to establish a favourable normative framework and to put an end to legislative disparities that impede the development of new transport enterprises, particularly those emerging from the collaborative economy. I support this text, which seeks to highlight the consequences of these disparities which lead to serious distortions, such as dumping, which must be heavily combated. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report because it contains a number of proposals aimed at creating opportunities for small transport companies: accelerating efforts to complete the Single European Transport Area, ending national disparities, encouraging convergence between the traditional economy and platforms in order to promote innovation, protect consumers and promote fair competition or to organize better coordination between local authorities and small transport companies to improve urban mobility with a view to sustainable development.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: in writing. - The report deals with small transport companies — micro-enterprises and family-owned enterprises. Such small transport companies are essential for mobility in the European MS, but these companies are currently suffering disproportionately from the lack of a single European transport area. The rapporteur is therefore trying to create the most favourable regulatory, social and tax environment and to provide the benefits that SMEs currently enjoy to these micro-enterprises in order to enable them to operate across borders. That is why I am voting in favour of this report.

name: Jeppe Kofod (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Social Democratic Party is for platform economics and fully recognises the gains that online platforms in the transport sector can bring in terms of, for example, less climate and environmental pressures and increased flexibility. That is why we are concerned with ensuring fair terms for the platform economy. At the same time, it is crucial for us to maintain the orderly conditions of the Danish labour market in order to prevent social dumping and unfair competition. We insist that online platforms that provide services and generate profit meet their obligations over worker rights, tax deposit and security for consumers. The report expresses criticism of regulation and of cooperation between government, folketing and social partners, which works well in Denmark and other countries. We have therefore abstained from voting in favour of the report.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: in writing. — Small and medium-sized transport enterprises play a significant role in managing traffic on European roads and make a significant contribution to the EU economy and job creation. The report we are voting on the opportunities and challenges faced by these companies, therefore it is very important that it is on the plenary agenda. Unfortunately, however, I feel contrary to this positive line point 37 of the report, which calls into question the derogation for light vehicles on the grounds that they have an unreasonably high presence in international traffic. However, we must point out that there is no reliable data on this and if these carriers are to comply with all the requirements for vehicles above 3.5 tonnes, this may impose a disproportionate financial and administrative burden on them. That is why I cannot support this point in the report. Overall, however, I agree with the report and voted in favour of it.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained from voting on this report since while I am sharing many points that the rapporteur has presented here, the report as a whole lacks clarity and requires further research especially when it comes to the differentiation between SME and collaborative business models.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: in writing. I supported the creation of new opportunities for small transport companies as they are more or less integrated into the mobility system and each of these businesses requires a differentiated approach. Small and medium-sized enterprises benefit from a range of aids, operate in a well-defined market segment and often depend on large enterprises, while start-ups in most cases create their own markets through the use of an idea, are distinguished by greater flexibility and often have the potential needed to develop at international level. Thanks to a more detailed knowledge of the local market, greater customer proximity and/or frequent ability to respond quickly and the ability to innovate, small businesses improve individual passenger transport in densely populated areas. Similarly, in remote areas where building railway infrastructure or organising public transport would be too expensive, a light car is often the only possible transport vehicle for certain groups of the population. It is here that the legislator can and must carry out his mission by creating the most favourable regulatory, social and tax environment possible. In this way, small transport companies will be able to turn into opportunities the many challenges they face today.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Demand for transport in the EU is growing and undoubtedly SMEs and in particular small transport businesses will play an ever increasing role in meeting this demand. It is important to note that the EU is supporting the development of transport SMEs through a range of programmes, notably through the executive agency for SMEs (EASME) and programmes such as COSME and the SME instrument within the Horizon 2020 framework programme, thus stimulating market access for innovative SMEs. However, in order to unleash the full potential of small transport business the EU should try to remove the barriers SMEs face when applying for EU subsidies. The EU should also support innovation in the sector by enhancing a supranational European approach towards collaborative business models and by completing the single European transport area.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: I voted against this report because it is perverted by integrationist ideology, which makes it unacceptable.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: in writing. — I voted against the report entitled “New opportunities for small transport enterprises”. Challenges for small transport companies are defined fairly accurately. These include: the problem of social dumping, the problem of the distribution of profits between freight or passenger control platforms (to the benefit of platforms and to the detriment of small businesses, especially single-person, family or self-contractors, which unlike large companies cannot fight for a better distribution of value added to their benefit). Unfortunately, once again, European ideology most often blind the recommendations: the main of them would be the integration of the transport market, by standardising legislation, particularly as regards safety requirements and training, which are seen as a means of distorting competition. In plain, once again, a leveling from below in the countries of Western and Northern Europe. Too bad: the interest of the subject is real, but the report is flawed by its Europeist, utopian and falsely eco-social apprehension.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. — Whereas the interest of the subject is real, the report is undermined by an ideological and Europeanist point of view; between standardization of the legal framework, outrageous liberalisation and rejection of subsidies, all barely masked by pseudo-ecological considerations, this report would certainly draw the countries of Western and Northern Europe towards the bottom. I voted against it.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on new opportunities for transport SMEs, because it aims to optimize the use of vehicles and infrastructure, making transport more sustainable, the promotion of a more consumer-oriented market, takes into account business opportunities for SMEs, makes a indirectly criticizes the strict regulation to which part of the transport sector is subject (number of licences, exclusive rights) which are in some cases misused as “unjustified barriers” and criticizes the adoption of unilateral unjustified measures that some countries and others have not taken on the legality of the platforms. The report also calls for a clear distinction between profit-making intermediaries and self-employed intermediaries, those who have a dependency relationship and must therefore operate as wage earners and respect social security obligations, contributions, unemployment etc.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: written. - Small transport companies in Europe improve individual passenger transport and play a key role in the transport of passengers and goods. For good knowledge of the local market, customer connectivity and ability to innovate, small transport companies are a key element of European mobility and contribute to increasing the quality of individual passenger transport. The report offers several proposals to turn many challenges into opportunities for small businesses, such as strengthening European transport space, eliminating differences in the application of rights, encouraging convergence between the traditional economy and platforms including business models based on cooperation and strengthening coordination between local authorities and small transport companies in order to improve mobility. With new business models, digitalisation and technological discoveries significantly alter the transport sector and have a strong impact on traditional business models as well as working conditions and employment in the sector, I supported this report.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Transport businesses face considerable challenges in order to respond to the increasing demand for mobility within the constraints of limited infrastructure and increasing environmental requirements. We have to develop cooperation and communication platforms in order to advise and train SMEs with regard to different funding schemes, grants and internationalisation and to promote innovations in the sharing economy.

name: Louis-Joseph Manscour (S&D)
text: This report follows a communication from the Commission on the collaborative economy and deals with the recent development of platforms in the transport sector (e.g. Uber, Blablacar, Heetch...). This text highlights uncertainties about the legal status of these platforms without however resolving the issue. The CJEU's opinions on the various cases between “Uber” and several Member States will be decisive in deciding on the legal nature of the platforms. It also highlights the risks associated with the emergence of monopolies in this sector and calls for healthy competition between platforms for the benefit of small and medium-sized enterprises. Nevertheless, this text does not provide the necessary guarantees for social protection and the rights of workers, guarantees to which the Socialists and Democrats are particularly committed. Therefore, I am voting against this report.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing. - I am voting against the report on new opportunities for small transport enterprises, including cooperative business models, for the reasons I explained in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 23 November 2016, as well as because this report is not complete and documented.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I expressed a favourable vote for the report on new opportunities for small transport businesses, including collaborative business models. Currently, there are a variety of circumstances hindering the establishment of fair competition and growth of small businesses. In order to manage and improve these situations, the report has proposed a list of ideas, which seem to have a positive impact on small businesses by bringing opportunity and change. By supporting the report, we can look forward to providing even safer, more sustainable, and more competitive small businesses.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: in writing. — The creation of a single European transport area can eliminate the divergent application of legislation which currently makes it very difficult for small transport companies to operate across borders. Small transport companies must be given the same benefits as SMEs, as the former make an important contribution to mobility in the Member States. That is why I agree with the present version.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour. Small transport undertakings are difficult to assess because they are of a very different nature depending on the mode of transport, the country, the type of services provided and the competitive structure of the market in which they operate. However, these companies play an important role in the transport of both passengers and goods and facilitate the mobility organised by historically large enterprises. By better understanding the subtleties of the local market, being closer to customers and/or often being flexible and capable of innovating, small enterprises have developed individual transport, especially the remaining last miles in densely populated areas. Unfortunately, legal uncertainty in the definition of 'transport service providers' hinders fair competition and reduces the ambitions of many small businesses, while the diversified public aid available to small businesses at EU and national level is not always easy to use, deadlines do not correspond to innovation cycles. I agree that Europe needs to be more attentive to small businesses and to take more action to create a single European transport area and to harmonise the application of legislation, to improve consumer protection and to promote fair competition and to better harmonise local authorities and small transport actions by enterprises to improve urban mobility, which will lead to less carbon emissions in the future.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — This report follows the logic of strengthening the single European market in the transport sector and thus in the breakdown of public service and liberalisation. Thus, it supports the continuation of efforts to complete the Single European Transport Area. It calls on Member States to “assess the need to adapt their labour laws to the digital age, taking into account the characteristics of the models of the collaborative economy and labour law of each Member State”. Which is equivalent to support companies like UBER, which I fight. I am voting against this text and, on the contrary, support public transport services.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. — The purpose of this report is to lay down for the Commission a framework for intervention to improve the performance of small transport undertakings, particularly in view of the importance of the Internet in placing orders for delivery or transport of passengers. The challenges faced by small transport companies are quite accurately defined. Thus, the problem of social dumping and the distribution of profits between freight or passenger order platforms are well targeted. However, the report is criticised on several points: standardization of the legal framework, increased liberalization and a falsely environmentally friendly approach. I therefore voted against this report, bearing in mind the real need to support our small transport companies and the real measures needed to safeguard them.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. - In the absence of relevant statistical data, the reality of small transport companies in Europe is difficult to assess. If the finding that their importance varies from one way to another (with road, inland waterway and sea transport being heavily targeted, rail and air modes a little less), nothing makes it possible to know precisely their number, their share in employment or their proportion of the wealth created within the Union. Small transport companies play a key role in the smooth functioning of mobility in Europe, but often face difficulties in accessing or staying in the market, particularly because of the existence of monopolies in that market. It is time for us to do something to change these situations and help these companies develop more properly and effectively. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. Transport-related businesses are crucial for EU cohesion and keeping citizens connected and ensuring the EU economy grows.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Report on New Opportunities for small transport businesses, which analyses challenges and opportunities for small businesses in the transport sector, particularly in the context of the collaborative economy and new business models. The growth of the digital economy and emergence of platforms is changing the way small transport businesses operate, and is challenging the existing operators. Collaborative economy is a new model of economic activity empowering consumers to capitalise on their own property and skills and providing a new range of opportunities for micro-entrepreneurship. This makes it difficult to establish sometimes who is the consumer, who is the employer and the employee, and who is the entrepreneur and the business. Therefore, we need to look very closely at the dynamics of change so as not to stifle economic benefits emerging from these new economic models, whilst at the same time safeguarding existing employment rights, high quality working conditions and social welfare schemes, and ensure that a real level playing field in the single market is maintained.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. — According to the report of the Committee on Transport and Tourism, small transport enterprises are essential for European mobility. Thanks to better knowledge of the local market, proximity to customers and/or often dynamism and innovative ability, they improve individual passenger transport, especially within densely populated zones, on the 'fatal last kilometer'. The report considers that the situation has never benefited the development of sustainable solutions which, despite the limited capacity of transport infrastructures, allow environmentally friendly response to increasing mobility needs. (While emissions in other sectors of the European economy have been falling comprehensively over the last ten years, the transport sector continues to grow and currently accounts for about a quarter of the total EU emissions.) The 21st Conference on Combating Climate Change confirmed that the transport sector should take its part in the transition to a decarbonised economy as soon as possible. 80% of the population will live in cities in 2050, in a short time. The importance of urban mobility will therefore be even greater and the development of multimodal, clean and integrated transport will become inevitable. The report proposes to make many challenges for small businesses an opportunity. I supported its adoption.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. — The purpose of this report is to lay down a framework for the Commission for intervention to improve the performance of small transport undertakings, particularly in view of the importance of the Internet in placing orders for delivery or transport of passengers. Unfortunately, once again, the European ideology most often blind the recommendations: the main of which aims to allow the harmonious and competitive development of small transport companies (particularly important for the last kilometers) would be the integration of the transport market, standardizing the legislation, particularly with regard to security requirements. The leitmotiv in favour of increased liberalisation means that it is not possible to support this text.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: in writing. — This report is outrageously Europeanist and falsely eco-social. I vote against it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Small transport businesses are particularly hard to evaluate because of their varied profiles depending on the mode of transport, country, type of service provided and the competition structure of the market in which they operate. Thanks to their more detailed knowledge of the local market, greater proximity to the customer and in many cases agility and ability to innovate, small businesses can improve transport for each individual passenger. This report underlines the necessity of support for SMEs at European level, in order to face the considerable challenges they are constantly confronting. Investing in their development and deploying synergies between different Member States would assist in building the single European transport area for the benefit of passengers.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this report on new opportunities for small transport companies, including collaborative business models. In particular, the text calls on Member States to put an end to their transport surregulation, which prevents small businesses from accessing the market. It denounces the social dumping practiced in this sector at intra-European level and makes numerous proposals to support the activity of transport SMEs.

name: Luigi Morgano (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ The world of transport, both of goods and passengers, is a reality involving a very large number of small and medium-sized enterprises, of which, however, very often cannot define the profile. These SMEs, in general, integrate into the mobility system by operating in a specific sector and exploiting the greater knowledge of the local market and proximity to the customer. This allows them to have a huge advantage in offering their services. The advent of the digital economy and brokerage platforms has fostered the proliferation of small and micro enterprises, especially start ups, in the sector, creating the ideal ground for the development of so-called collaborative economics. This process, intended in the coming years surely to accelerate, calls the legislature to find suitable and ideal solutions for this area. There are two main challenges that we are facing: on the one hand, ensuring that the digital transition benefits SMEs and micro-enterprises; on the other hand, pushing for the development of the sector transport budgets environmental friendliness and mobility needs. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this important initiative.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Small transport undertakings in Europe are strongly represented in road, river and marine transport, and less so in railways and aviation. I have voted for this report that will identify new opportunities for small transport businesses and how they can better take advantage of the digitalisation transition.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: in writing. - I supported Mr Rikke's resolution because I believe that the development of small and medium-sized enterprises, which are the main driver of the European economy, by engaging two-thirds of all jobs, must be our priority. In recent years, small and medium-sized enterprises, particularly in the service sector, have been the ones that create jobs. Supporting the development and operation of small transport companies will contribute to the proper functioning of mobility in Europe. Bulgaria is one of the countries that are starting to develop more and more services provided by the sharing economy, and end users expect the use of fast and quality transport services. Bearing in mind that only 1.7% of EU businesses benefit fully from advanced digital technologies, we must focus on developing new opportunities in the transport sector so that we can improve existing traditional models and working conditions and employment in the industry. The creation of new mediation platforms must be combined with strengthening enforcement, which will at the same time create a market focused on consumer demand but also provide the necessary legal framework for fair competition. Within the EU, there must be more innovative start-ups in the transport sector, but also to encourage greater support for them.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report because I believe that small and medium-sized enterprises are the main drivers of jobs in the service sector, but also the main engine of the European economy. In this respect, the report adopted today calls on Member States to put an end to the phenomenon of over-regulation, which increases inequalities. At the same time, I welcome the idea of inviting Member States and the European Commission to consider pooling small transport enterprises, which would facilitate the development of partnerships between them.

name: Андрей Новаков (PPE)
text: in writing. The report recalls that small and medium-sized enterprises are the main driver of the European economy and account for 99.8% (figures from 2014) of all enterprises outside the financial sector. Two thirds of all jobs are concentrated in them. Small and medium-sized enterprises creating jobs in recent years are predominantly in the service sector. Small transport companies play a crucial role in the proper functioning of mobility in Europe, but often find it difficult to enter or retain their place on the market. The report notes that EFSI was created to contribute to highly innovative market projects and is therefore an important tool for supporting SMEs in the transport sector in the development of new mobility solutions, and calls on the Commission and Member States to speed up its implementation and increase the assistance provided to SMEs and start-ups in the preparation of such projects.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this report because I believe that any regulation that imposes new requirements on small enterprises must be proportionate, clear, simple and unambiguous. Furthermore, the development of the company must not be hindered.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. — The purpose of this report is to create new opportunities for SMEs involved in transport. It is proposed to involve SMEs in future “soft transport” and low-polluting urban projects, combating social dumping or improving self-contractor status. Only, beyond this benevolent rhetoric, the report distinguishes a desire to liberalise the European transport market and to obstruct public service. This is evident, for example, by the incentive of Member States to take the necessary measures to 'combat the anti-competitive practices of major integrated groups in order to combat discrimination and market access restrictions'. I do not think that is what European citizens need, which is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported. The demand for transport is growing and small businesses play an important role in covering the transport needs of suburban areas and low traffic times, so it is important to ensure fair standards for them in order to stay competitive. Supportive measures are therefore needed to help businesses accompany digital services, to meet sustainable development objectives and to implement the necessary safety standards.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D)
text: in writing. - The report criticises anti-competitive practices, which can lead to serious distortions, such as social dumping. Small transport companies are therefore an integral part of mobility in Europe. In addition, they have plenty of talents that need a favorable environment to express themselves. Regulatory, social and tax conditions must be created as favourable as possible, because this is the only way that small businesses will be able to turn the many challenges they face today into opportunities. The needs of the transport sector in the fields of information and communication are so important that this sector becomes a fertile ground for the digital economy and, most of all, for mediation platforms. New technologies, which have become accessible to small businesses, significantly modernise the mobility economy. The first challenge for small businesses is to be able to benefit from this digital switchover. Secondly, we are at the best possible time to develop sustainable solutions which will enable us, despite the limited capacity of transport infrastructure, to meet in an environmentally friendly way the growing mobility needs. For all these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ I would vote in favour of the proposal by my colleagues because I believe that, despite the fact that these small businesses are difficult to assess because they act in different areas, they play a fundamental role both for the transport of strollers and for that of goods. In fact, in the absence of statistical data, it is impossible to understand the reality of small transport companies in Europe with regard to: the precise number, jobs and the wealth it guarantees the European Union. These enterprises, as they are very close to the customer, improve their individual transportation service particularly in the last mile of travel. Since they are very important for the European Union, it is necessary to establish a new positive regulatory, social and fiscal environment, which would allow an effective convergence between traditional economy and platforms in order to promote greater consumer protection and the implementation of fair competition at the same time. As a politician, I also think it is appropriate to incentivise and invest in small businesses because, very often, they are composed of people living only on this activity. Therefore I would vote upvote.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: written. - I support this report on new opportunities for small transport companies. It is clear the view of all leading economic and financial institutions that sustainable economic growth is possible only if there is strong entrepreneurial activity, especially in the SME sector. This report contains several key proposals that make the challenges faced by small transport companies want to turn into opportunities. For example, the report calls for accelerating efforts invested in creating a single transport or transport area that would end all disparities and dispartities between states. Furthermore, this report also calls for consistent application of laws, especially those governing competition and anti-rust policies. The advantage and incentive given by this report is particularly evident in the momentum related to fostering the convergence between the traditional economy and transitional contemporary activities that require business models based on cooperation and the establishment of a framework in which all economic operators will participate in ensuring the existence of quality infrastructure and investment in society. The organization of better coordination of local authorities and small transport companies is a prerequisite for the establishment of quality urban mobility, which in the future will be the carrier of passenger and freight transport that will be friendly to the environment.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report because it provides a number of important recommendations to promote fair and balanced growth in the transport sector, taking into account the new conditions determined by the emergence of the collaborative economy and paying the necessary attention to SMEs. I agree that the completion of a common European transport area is crucial, together with the need to ensure a clear legislative framework, which guarantees fair conditions because all of them companies can compete on an equal footing. In fact, the report also criticizes the most common anti-competitive practices that can lead to serious distortions, such as social dumping, while at the same time, emphasizing the importance of models Flexible work negotiations between the social partners and the opportunities created by computer technologies. It recognises the importance of public transport for rural areas and finally recalls the relevance the sector has to environmental issues, proposing legislation and funding that promote mobility totally free of harmful emissions, in a short time. The transport sector faces many challenges and opportunities, thanks to the emergence of the collaborative economy. A coherent European approach is necessary to promote SMEs and new business models, in an integrated manner with those already on the market.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: written. - Small businesses are a key element of European mobility and abound with talent who need a stimulating environment to develop. Namely, they often encounter difficulties in entering the market and retaining their position on it, primarily due to the presence of monopolies on that market. Thus, due to the current legal uncertainty regarding the definition of service providers and in the transport sector, fair competition cannot be established. The Commission and the Member States should take action to combat practices that distort competition by large pooled undertakings. A potential solution is to bring together small transport companies, foster partnerships and find useful services that consumers demand. Reducing transaction costs and the importance of the physical location of providers, which is made possible through new technologies and digital tools, we need to know how to make the most possible use. A modern multimodal regulatory framework is needed to encourage innovation, competitiveness and consumer protection and worker rights. This is why it is necessary to complete the Single European Transport Area as fostering an integrated and coordinated European mobility system is the best way to create common dynamics in order to offer safe, sustainable and highly competitive solutions that at the same time protect the environment in line with agreement COP21 and limits crowds. We need “more Europe” in this sector as well.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This report aims to focus on the need to boost the transport market at the level of small and medium-sized enterprises, with a special focus on companies in the so-called collaborative economy. Indeed, the aim is to launder the ongoing processes of deregulation of the sector and to clear the way for the multinationals who want to dominate it. The report diagnoses the reality of the sector, with references to the existence of monopolies (which would not be good for its development), the great flexibility brought about by digitisation, in contrast to the overregulation, protectionism and corporatism that jeopardize the internal market. The report welcomes the emergence of new models of the collaborative economy, which the EU should support (considering the opportunities opened by the EFSI and bearing in mind that most of those operating in the internal market are American) and criticises the fragmented response of Member States to growth of these models, which would be inconsistent with the potential and benefits of the sector and contrary to consumer expectations. The report also supports flexible working models, which would be beneficial to workers. The report conceals the lack of support for public transport policies and public mobility strategies. Its goal is another: to promote the UBER of this life. We voted against it.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: ‒ The report contains a number of proposals that seek to turn many of the current challenges into opportunities for small transport companies. I believe that it is necessary to increase efforts to complete a single European transport area, putting an end to disparity in law enforcement, dumping and encouraging convergence between traditional economics and brokerage platforms, including collaborative business models, so as to promote innovation, protect consumers and fair competition. Therefore, I voted in favour of approving this report.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: in writing. “The report addresses the issues of small transport undertakings which are particularly difficult to assess because of the varying profiles of activities depending on the mode of transport, the country, the type of services provided and the competitive structure in the market in which they operate. Among them are family companies, SMEs, micro-businesses, craft businesses and start-ups. Since they all fall to a greater or lesser extent within the scope of the movement system, each requires a varied approach. The report supports new business models and calls for a clear and proportionate legal framework for small transport companies. I hereby supported the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: in writing. — Small transport companies play an important role in the functioning of mobility in Europe and are highly job-creating. However, they are experiencing many difficulties in accessing and developing the market. I voted in favour of this report, which encourages the development of an appropriate regulatory framework, the completion of the single European transport area and the establishment of more fair competition to enable these companies to unleash their potential.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The UK is already investing in the future of small transport businesses. In 2013 the UK competitiveness recovered in comparison to the rest of the EU and the world. The report calls for Member States to put an end to over-regulation, however we know through the EU’s REFIT programme that they admit to over regulation themselves.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. - It is important that we look at the challenges and opportunities posed to small businesses in the transport sector, particularly in the context of a collaborative economy and new business models, particularly in the context of SMEs, micro-enterprises and start ups. We must also take into consideration the digital economy and its influence on changing the way small transport companies operate.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this European Parliament resolution on new opportunities for small transport companies, including collaborative business models. If there are several interesting elements in this resolution, I would like to emphasize paragraph 37 in which the European Parliament expresses concerns about whether there continue to be any reasons to exempt light commercial vehicles from the application of a number of European rules, given the increasing use of light commercial vehicles in international freight transport. I ask the Commission to look into this matter without delay. The use of these small trucks without a significant number of rules leads to extremely harmful distortion of competition and deplorable working conditions for the drivers of these vehicles.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. - A resolution on new opportunities for small transport businesses is a necessary and well prepared document. Proper regulation in this area would help create many new jobs and better meet customer needs.

name: Virginie Rozière (S&D)
text: I voted against Dominique Riquet's report on the digital economy and transport. First of all, it is characterized by a major contradiction: while it claims to lay the foundations for a modernised regulatory framework adapted to transport platforms, it calls on Member States not to overregulate this sector. Moreover, it absolutely does not respond to the challenges raised by the rise of these platforms in terms of worker protection. While the report raises the risks of social dumping caused by the inadequacies of existing regulations, it ignores the risks of precarization of the professional paths of drivers using the platforms and impoverishment of the latter, in the absence of adequate social protection. The report also evade the issue of driver training. Finally, it does not qualify these platforms as real transport companies, while they simply offer a private transport service via a digital tool. Therefore, this report on digital platforms in the transport sector is far from meeting the challenges posed by the upheavals in this sector.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. - This initiative report deals with new opportunities for small and medium-sized transport companies, including collaborative business models. It stresses that small transport companies are in fact essential to a strong, dynamic and economically profitable digital economy, and therefore there must be collaborative business models that create new business opportunities for these types of companies, which are often faced with legal and bureaucratic complexity, as well as unfair competition, created by national protectionist mechanisms, creating legal uncertainty. The new collaborative business models should therefore be focused on technological innovation, based on greater legislative and procedural debureaucratization, which provides more justice, greater balance and capable of generating greater competitiveness and efficiency for small transport companies, so that they can also promote greater interconnection between consumers and producers and thus assist in the process of economic, social and territorial cohesion in the regions. With regard to the digital platforms that have revolutionised the transport sector, I agree that the logic must be to open up innovation and fair competition in order to cooperate and standardize the regulation of these innovative segments with traditional sectors.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I have decided to vote against this report, because I understand it is not sufficiently strongly positioned in the face of the risks posed by the uncontrolled emergence of some digital platforms in the transport sector. I understand that the emergence of new operators on the market should not undermine the rights of operators already present, nor the ability of the competent public authorities to define their mobility strategies.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Social Democratic Party is for platform economics and fully recognises the gains that online platforms in the transport sector can bring in terms of, for example, less climate and environmental pressures and increased flexibility. That is why we are concerned with ensuring fair terms for the platform economy. At the same time, it is crucial for us to maintain the orderly conditions of the Danish labour market in order to prevent social dumping and unfair competition. We insist that online platforms that provide services and generate profit meet their obligations over worker rights, tax deposit and security for consumers. The report expresses criticism of regulation and of cooperation between government, folketing and social partners, which works well in Denmark and other countries. We have therefore abstained from voting in favour of the report.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the report on new opportunities for small transport companies, including Community business models. The report contains some suggestions on how to turn challenges for small transport companies into new opportunities. This calls for an acceleration of the completion of a single European transport area.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against this report because I believe that the collaborative economy, on which the report is focused, is not a new opportunity, but a label that distracts attention from the changes experienced in the sectors concerned. The technological opportunity offered by new technological developments should not be confused with their use to precarious work in the respective sector and avoid existing fiscal and social obligations, for example in transport: a reality that should not be hidden or disguised.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: ‒ Small transport companies are quite difficult to evaluate due to the variety of types - family, small and medium-sized enterprises, micro-enterprises, handicrafts and start ups - of the country in which they operate and the type of service they provide. Small medium-sized enterprises account for around 55% of employment in the transport sector, and thanks to technological innovations and new collaborative business models, demand for this type of transport is destined to grow. I think it is important for the European Union and the Member States to address existing over-regulation and support SMEs in order to turn current challenges into new development opportunities for the transport sector in Europe. I therefore decided to vote in favour.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this as it calls for the Member States to deregulate transport which I find hypocritical. Also it calls on the commission to legislate.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. – Today I voted in favour of this report. Small transport businesses are particularly hard to evaluate because of their varied profiles depending on the mode of transport, country, type of service provided and the competition structure of the market in which they operate. Thanks to their more detailed knowledge of the local market, greater proximity to the customer and in many cases agility and ability to innovate, small businesses can improve transport for each individual passenger. This report underlines the necessity of support for SMEs at European level, in order to face the considerable challenges they are constantly confronting. Investing in their development and deploying synergies between different Member States would assist in building the single European transport area for the benefit of passengers.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour. Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are the main engine of the European economy. I think that supporting an integrated and coordinated European mobility system is a good way to properly integrate all businesses offering all modes of transport into a common dynamic process. SMEs in the transport sector would be a good idea to involve, for example, in the plans of an integrated European ticketing system, enabling them to be developed. I also support the exchange of information and experience between large actors and SMEs, which can lead to very beneficial synergies in the area of creating an efficient transport network in Europe.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: written. - Small and medium-sized transport companies are a major driver of the European economy due to their key role in mobility across Europe. They are an important complement to the public transport network in city hubs especially during heavy crowds, and also in remote and densely populated areas where they contribute to reducing social exclusion, job creation and tourism development. Considering that today's transport needs to be integrated, multimodal and digitised, there is a worrying figure that as many as 41% of companies do not use advanced digital technologies at all. Digitisation of the transport sector is crucial to maintain and increase competitiveness, so it is necessary to reiterate the important role it plays in today's modern world. Very soon, as early as 2050, 80% of people will live in cities, which means that urban mobility will become an extremely important factor in everyday life. As the transport sector is responsible for one-quarter of total emissions of noxious gases, its role in the transition to a carbonised economy under the COP21 agreement is of great importance. I supported the European Parliament resolution aiming to invest further efforts to complete the European Single Transport Area, contributing to the further growth and development of small and medium-sized transport companies offering safe, sustainable and highly competitive solutions.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the resolution because I see small transport undertakings as a significant complement to the public transport network at urban hubs and agree that these businesses play a key role in the area of mobility in Europe. As a person coming from the region of Eastern Slovakia, I consider it particularly important that small transport companies provide added value especially in remote and densely populated regions thanks to excellent knowledge of the local market, proximity to the customer and adaptability and ability innovate. Although in my region, as in other regions, the transport sector has opened up, in many cases working conditions and employment have deteriorated. I am particularly sorry that the profiles of small transport undertakings vary greatly depending on the type of transport, the country, the type of service provided and the structure of competition in the market in which they operate. I am particularly concerned that there is still inequality in the application of EU rules in individual Member States, particularly with regard to wages and social security systems. I therefore expect the proposed measures to speed up the efforts to complete the single European transport area and to help eliminate disparities and apply the law.

name: Bart Staes (Verts/ALE)
text: — SMEs play a tremendously important role in our society. In terms of passenger and freight transport, they fill the gaps that cannot be closed by the larger players. Just think of areas that you can only reach with a passenger car. This is a concrete example of how small transport companies can respond to the needs and needs of citizens. However, for SMEs it is often more difficult than for larger players to make the necessary efforts to do so in an environmentally friendly and financially viable way. Opportunities must therefore be created for these smaller enterprises. The report was initially highly market-oriented, but under the influence of the Green Group it has become more social, sustainable and environmentally friendly. Some of our additions include a combination of collaboration models that focus on sustainability and the environment, the need for a regulatory framework for collaborative platforms, connecting to sustainable urban mobility plans and finally devising alternatives for the use of the car. The Greens therefore agree with this, but also want a distinction to be made between non-profit companies and those that are focused on maximising profits.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Small transport businesses are particularly hard to evaluate because of their varied profiles depending on the mode of transport, country, type of service provided and the competition structure of the market in which they operate. Thanks to their more detailed knowledge of the local market, greater proximity to the customer and in many cases agility and ability to innovate, small businesses can improve transport for each individual passenger. This report underlines the necessity of support for SMEs at European level, in order to face the considerable challenges they are constantly confronting. Investing in their development and deploying synergies between different Member States would assist in building the single European transport area for the benefit of passengers.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: in writing. - I did not agree with the European Parliament resolution on new opportunities for small transport companies, including those pursuing collaborative business models. The report calls for the implementation of COP 21 and the reduction of CO2 emissions. It welcomes the opportunities created by the EFSI. It calls for the establishment of an integrated European ticket distribution system. Finally, the report calls for all possible and impossible forms of harmonisation of legislation and interferes with the social and labour law of the Member States.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: written. - Small transport companies play a key role in the good functioning of mobility in Europe, but often encounter difficulties in entering the market and performing their activities. In order to address the challenges in this activity, it is necessary to፦ increase efforts to create a single European transport space and to eliminate differences in the application of various rights - to encourage the approximation of traditional transport models and new models, such as platforms for” sharing transport for a fee”, to encourage innovation, consumer protection and fair competition - to organise better coordination between local authorities and small transport companies in order to improve urban mobility which will be fully decarbonised in the near future I accept the Report as it highlights the necessary changes that need to be implemented to ensure that small transport companies are as best prepared as possible for the future bringing platforms for “freight sharing for a fee” and decarbonised mobility.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: in writing. — Today I voted in favour of the report on new opportunities for small transport enterprises, including business models based on closer cooperation. The report includes a number of proposals seeking to promote opportunities for small and medium-sized transport companies. It supports appropriate measures to combat the anti-competitive practices of large integrated groups to address discrimination and restrict market access. The EU needs to develop more innovative start-ups in the transport sector and encourages increased support for these firms, especially with regard to professional training for young entrepreneurs in this field. This report also seeks to eliminate over-regulation. Regulation should be proportionate, simple and clear, it should not disrupt the development of small and medium-sized enterprises. Among other things, it also supports new technologies for the emergence of new forms of service in the transport of goods, such as drones, which are already a very effective tool for working in challenging conditions.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - The report seeks to represent the interests of multinational transport companies, paves the way for strengthening monopolies, calls for more flexible working and working time relations and promotes privatisation. Nor does it set any targets for reinvesting in public transport by strengthening public networks. As the report is therefore entirely in line with the interests of the multinationals and neglects the public interest and the development of central public transport services in the Member States, we have decided to vote against the report.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: in writing. - Because of divergences and failures in the application of the law, economic and social market distortions continue to exist, while small enterprises are even more affected by the absence of a genuine single European transport area.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The report states that the lack of relevant statistical data makes it difficult to assess the real situation of small transport enterprises in Europe. However, it is certain that the transport sector also faces serious challenges and opportunities through the emergence of a collaborative economy. This is why the report sets out proposals that are an opportunity for these businesses. As I consider small and medium-sized enterprises important, I voted in favour of this report. I agree with the need to accelerate efforts to create a single European transport area and to eliminate the differences in the application of law.
