Existing exemptions and controls should be harmonised and anti-competitive practices should be abolished, since social dumping, for example, can lead to serious distortions. I also consider the need to encourage convergence between traditional economies and new business models, including Community economic models, in a way that favors innovation, consumer protection and fair competition.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: in writing. — Small and medium-sized transport companies are instrumental in ensuring proper mobility in Europe, but they often face significant difficulties in gaining access to or staying on the market, mainly because of existing monopolies. Through more accurate knowledge of the local market, closer contact with the customer or — often — flexibility of operation and ability to innovate, small businesses improve individual passenger transport, in particular at the difficult final stage of commuting in areas densely populated or heavily isolated. That's why their support is so vital. Particular attention should therefore be paid to the continued reduction of existing bureaucratic handicaps or the fight against monopolies, as well as technological support and the development of the sharing economy for SMEs. It is necessary to promote convergence between the traditional economy and new platforms that support the innovation of SMEs. In order to achieve this goal, a more transnational, European approach should be developed on a collaboration-based business model.

name: Claudiu Ciprian Tănăsescu (S&D)
text: in writing. - The engine of the European economy is given by SMEs, those that create jobs and generate innovation and creativity, i.e. an effective manifestation of entrepreneurship, those that promote social inclusion and respect the principles of equality of opportunities and gender. SMEs represent contexts conducive to the implementation of effective management methods and tools. Known is that it is the service sector that attracts SMEs, especially due to low market entry costs, generating socio-economic development. Obviously, I agree that SMEs in the transport sector contribute to making mobility more efficient in the EU, but they need to create contexts generating new opportunities for sustainable development, precisely because of the complex nature of the sector (e.g. incoherence of service providers, use and marketing of transport services, safety and security, etc.) and its governance system. Especially since the digital economy has created challenges in all aspects, for all businesses, regardless of size and field of activity. Collaborative economy models can be successfully applied in the development of SMEs in the transport sector if Member States comply with European rules on social and working conditions (salaries and social security systems) and fundamental freedoms of the EU.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. - The spectacular growth of the digital economy and the emergence of platforms will radically change the transport market, especially if we are talking about small businesses. They come with new services and a degree of flexibility difficult to match by traditional players. They also raise the issue of maintaining a balance between innovation and protecting social rights. The European Parliament proposes a realistic approach, anchored in the certainty that technology is moving forward and things are changing. We must mobilise ourselves to act before we are overwhelmed by the complexity of the new conditions. We need a modern transport system as well as new services that meet the growing demand of our citizens. This report is a good opportunity to start the discussion on how the European institutions can create a legislative framework that will drive Europe at the forefront in terms of innovation and quality of transport services.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. — All the companies in question play a crucial role in the transport of passengers and goods by putting oil in the cogs of mobility historically structured by the “big”. With a thinner local market knowledge, greater proximity to the customer and/or often agility and ability to innovate, small businesses improve individual passenger transport, especially during the fateful last mile in densely populated areas. Similarly, in landlocked areas where the construction of a railway infrastructure or the organization of public transport would be too expensive, private cars are often the only means of movement possible for certain categories of the population. Small transport companies are therefore consubstantial to European mobility. Yet they are full of talents that need a supportive environment to deploy. This is where the regulator can and must accomplish its mission by providing the most favourable regulatory, social and fiscal environment. Thus, small transport companies will be able to transform into opportunities the many challenges facing them today, first of all, the ICT revolution.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report: SMEs in the transport sector play a major role in delivering effective mobility services to passengers and businesses, including at local level and in less-populated areas where they can rely on their knowledge of the market. In recent years, digitalisation and the emergence of the collaborative economy businesses contributed to blur the lines between the traditional transport operators, passengers and new business models. Digital tools open unprecedented opportunities for companies in the transport sector, including for SMEs, provided that the framework in place leaves room for innovation. Those new opportunities aim at delivering better-fit services and I believe that passengers’ interests should always be the aim of the transport policies. Our role is therefore to ensure that the legislative framework provides adequate regulatory and fiscal safeguards without hampering innovation or protecting individual interests.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: In writing. — Digital technology offers real opportunities in a context where the use of technological innovations is endless. However, social regressions should not be accompanied by social regressions. Digital platforms in the transport sector pose serious problems, including the lack of social protection for those who work there. Strong regulation is therefore essential to combat forms of social dumping in order to guarantee workers' rights, combat the precarization of routes, ensure the training of drivers and promote fair competition for small businesses. While the report highlights uncertainties about the legal status of platforms, it does not resolve this issue and deferred to Member States' compliance with the Services Directive. I regret that the amendments highlighting the risk of precarization of the career path and the impoverishment of independent drivers who do not or little benefit from social protection have been rejected. If we are to strongly oppose Uber's maneuvers to use European legislation to prevent Member States' regulation of its activity, we must value platforms that rely on the collaborative economy, such as Blablacar.

name: Ivica Tolić (PPE)
text: written. - I support the Motion for a Resolution on New Opportunities for Small Transport Enterprises. I believe it was necessary to recognise at European Union level the importance that small transport companies, whether they transport goods or people, have in the economy of the European Union. I also support the call for the Commission and the Member States to take appropriate measures to combat practices where large mergers distort competition in order to address the problem of discrimination and restricted market access regardless of the size or type of undertaking. I also believe that additional administrative burdens and additional costs should be created for small transport companies, but that legislation should be adjusted that will strengthen their operations and make them more competitive.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - I supported the proposal for a resolution of the European Parliament on new opportunities for small transport companies, including collaborative business models. The lack of relevant statistics makes it difficult to create a realistic picture of small transport companies in Europe. The term transport companies in this context means enterprises engaged in the transport of goods and people. It is difficult to determine the exact profile of raspberry transport companies but they all play an important role in ensuring mobility, one might say they are a key element of European mobility. Technology needs in the transport sector are high and represent fertile ground for the digital economy. For little transport companies, this will be a challenge to how to exploit this transition. Small businesses need to address some of the problems that big transport companies do not have, as they are financially stable enough. Even in the implementation of the law, there are frequent economic and social distortions experienced by smaller undertakings. It is therefore necessary to accelerate efforts to complete the Single European Transport Area in order to address inequalities in the implementation of legislation and to ensure better coordination between small businesses.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I have decided to vote against this report, because I understand it is not sufficiently strongly positioned in the face of the risks posed by the uncontrolled emergence of some digital platforms in the transport sector. I understand that the emergence of new operators on the market should not undermine the rights of operators already present, nor the ability of the competent public authorities to define their mobility strategies.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. — The purpose of this report is to lay down for the Commission a framework for intervention to improve the performance of small transport undertakings, particularly in view of the importance of the Internet in placing orders for delivery or transport of passengers. Challenges for small transport companies are defined fairly accurately and include the problem of social dumping, the problem of the distribution of profits between freight or passenger control platforms. Unfortunately, once again, the European ideology most often blind the recommendations: the main one of them aimed at enabling the harmonious and competitive development of small transport companies would be the integration of the transport market, by standardizing legislation, in particular with regard to safety requirements, training, requirements that are seen as a means of distorting competition; standardization of the legal framework (except as regards wage, social and tax burdens); increased liberalisation and rejection of subsidies in general; cosmetic considerations: reducing pollution and combating social dumping which are yet the logical and immediate consequence of the two previous points, but which serve only for political signage. I voted against this report.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: in writing. “The report addresses the issues of small transport undertakings which are particularly difficult to assess because of the varying profiles of activities depending on the mode of transport, the country, the type of services provided and the competitive structure in the market in which they operate. Among them are family companies, SMEs, micro-businesses, craft businesses and start-ups. Importantly, the report supports new business models and calls for a clear and proportionate legal framework for small transport companies; stresses that Member States should address the phenomenon of overregulation and anti-competitive behaviour that lead to fragmentation of rules and cause difficulties for small businesses; calls for harmonisation of rules on access to regulated professions and activities, which would facilitate the development of new entities and services linked to digital platforms and the sharing economy; addresses the problem of increasing use light vans (LCV) in international transport of goods. I supported said resolutions.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I have decided to vote against this report, because I understand it is not sufficiently strongly positioned in the face of the risks posed by the uncontrolled emergence of some digital platforms in the transport sector. I understand that the emergence of new operators on the market should not undermine the rights of operators already present, nor the ability of the competent public authorities to define their mobility strategies.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I welcome the new opportunities offered to small transport companies and new cooperative business models.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on new opportunities for small transport businesses, including collaborative business models. Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are the main engine of the European economy, representing, on 2014 figures, 99.8% of all undertakings outside the financial sector and accounting for two out of three of all jobs. The report calls on the Member States to put an end to over-regulation, which is often linked to protectionist and corporatist instincts that give rise to fragmentation, complexity and rigidity within the internal market, thus increasing inequality. It welcomes the new opportunities afforded by small transport businesses and new collaborative business models. I voted in favour because I believe that collaborative business models constitute a major resource for the sustainable development of connections in outlying, mountainous and rural regions, and offer indirect benefits for the tourism sector.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I voted against this report because I believe that the collaborative economy, on which the report is focused, is not a new opportunity, but a label that distracts attention from the changes experienced in the sectors concerned. The technological opportunity offered by new technological developments should not be confused with their use to precarious work in the respective sector and avoid existing fiscal and social obligations, for example in transport: a reality that should not be hidden or disguised.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour because small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are the main driver of the European economy and because in 2014 they represented 99.8% of all companies outside the financial sector and created two out of three jobs.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Digitisation and the services of the so-called collaborative economy have interesting benefits from the user's point of view that cannot be neglected. What the report omits, however, is the policy of privatisation of transport services and the depletion of public transport services, which reduces quality of service to users, deregulates labour relations and makes policy-makers free of responsibility for mobility strategies - increasingly linked to the market and to an on-demand, individualized logic. Because this report conceals the lack of support for public transport policies and public mobility strategies, and because it focuses on direct competition between so-called collaborative companies outside the EU and those that could be set up in the EU (forgetting the contradictions that, for example, Uber promotes from the point of view of taxation or the application of labour law), not in its regulation, we cannot support it.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: in writing. — The rapporteur intends to bring the benefits that SMEs currently enjoy (subsidies, defined market segment) to small transport companies. Since small transport companies are essential for mobility in the European MS, the rapporteur intends to create the most favourable regulatory, social and tax framework to ensure the flourishing, growth and prosperity of the aforementioned transport companies. Europe should therefore pay more attention to the “little ones”. I supported this approach.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution on new opportunities for small businesses providing transport services for passengers and goods. This own-initiative report analyses the challenges and opportunities for small businesses in the transport sector, particularly in the context of the collaborative economy. The growth of the digital economy and the emergence of platforms must be seen as great opportunities to foster growth, fair competition within a clear legal framework. The two major challenges for SMEs are to be able to adapt to the changes in place and to respond to the needs of society through sustainable solutions that take account of respect for the environment.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted on the own-initiative report on new opportunities for small businesses in the transport sector, including models of collaborative economy. Transport SMEs play a key role in the smooth functioning of mobility in Europe, but often face difficulties in accessing and maintaining the market, especially because of the presence of monopolies in this market. By transport undertakings, the rapporteur means those undertakings which provide passenger or freight services.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: in writing. — I support this report, as from my point of view it contains a number of appropriate measures supporting small and medium-sized transport enterprises. These societies are currently burdened by complex regulations, national protectionism and, in many cases, unfair competition. I believe that the European Union needs competitive and efficient transport firms. For this reason, I welcome that the report seeks primarily to eliminate excessive regulation. From my perspective, small transport businesses can play a substantial role in new business models for the future. Already today, for example, we can see how Uber or Deliveroo is changing transportation in cities in many ways.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing. - I supported the motion for a resolution on new opportunities for small businesses in the transport sector. In fact, small enterprises operating in the transport sector are a very diverse group of enterprises with diverse needs. That is why it is difficult to summarize them under a single policy or initiative. However, the fact is that these businesses play a key role for mobility in Europe and provide new opportunities, but also lower costs for consumers, for example. Yet they face more difficulty than big businesses. That is why, in the resolution, we stressed the need to combat over-regulation as well as anti-competitive behaviour. We also looked at the possibilities of using new technologies and the possibilities of financing small businesses through funds at European level. I also welcome the fact that the report did not bypass the current challenges related to the models of the resource sharing economy, which can be beneficial precisely in relation to small transport undertakings.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: I voted in favour of the Riquet report because I agree with a coherent European approach to support the emergence of new business models for small transport companies. I would like to highlight the call on the Commission to take account of the difficulty of penetrating new collaborative business models into rural and non-urban areas when drawing up guidelines on this subject. I also stress that the opportunities arising from the development of connected and self-piloted vehicles (cars, ships, drones, platooning) should lead the Commission to present a roadmap on connected and automated vehicles and analyse the potential effects this technology may have on the sector European transport, especially in small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Željana Zovko (PPE)
text: written. - I support the proposal for a resolution on new opportunities for small transport companies, including cooperation-based business models. SMEs are the main drivers of the European economy and provide two-thirds of jobs, especially in the service sector. The demand for transport services, for persons as well as for goods and the conditions under which they are provided differ significantly and the reduction in mobility is out of the question. Technology breakthroughs significantly alter the transport sector and affect traditional business models, as well as working conditions and employment in the sector. Self-employment services can be a good way of self-employment and promoting entrepreneurial culture. This resolution calls on the Commission and the Member States to consider bringing together small transport companies, which would encourage the development of partnerships among them and help consumers find the necessary services of small transport companies depending on their needs. The resolution encourages the competent institutions to make additional efforts to complete the European Single Transport Area and the proportionality of new conditions in tax, social and environmental issues.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted for the Report on new opportunities for small transport companies, including collaborative business models. Transport companies face huge challenges in responding to growing mobility needs amid limited infrastructure and increasing environmental requirements. All transport companies need to provide safe, sustainable and highly competitive solutions that will be environmentally friendly and at the same time reduce congestion. In particular, small businesses that are the main driver of the European economy make it harder and more expensive to meet these expectations. I therefore consider that any legislation laying down new requirements for small enterprises, in particular measures in the tax, social and environmental fields, must be proportionate, straightforward and clear, must not inhibit their development and should reflect, where appropriate, the regional and national characteristics of the different Member States.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: — I supported this draft resolution because it falls exactly within the human rights agenda that EP often addresses and rightly so that we are a body that perceives and patrols the state of human rights and beyond territory of the EU. The reason I subscribed to the explanation, and why I myself personally find this report particularly important, is the subject of capital punishment. I have tried in my political position in the Czech Republic, but also here I always engage against this inhumane punishment, which is in principle irreversible. In the event that a judicial error is committed and the death penalty is carried out on someone, then in short the execution of such a sentence can never be reversed. I am so glad that we call on Belarus in that resolution, we urge it directly to stop applying the death penalty, because it is more or less the only country in Europe that this inhumane punishment carries out. It must therefore be fought against it. Besides, I agree with other parts of the resolution, but I personally am most interested in capital punishment, and I find it important to fight against it.

name: Jacek Saryusz-Wolski (PPE).
text: - Mr President! It is very good that we have adopted as a European Parliament such a critical resolution on Belarus, but it is not as expressive as it should be. Somewhere still in the background we nurture illusions about President Lukashenko. It wasn't an election in Belarus, it was a nomination. The situation of human rights and opposition has not changed. Didn't the Union in this matter make a mistake? It seems to me that yes, and implicitly how this election went, and that it is this election (in quotation marks of course) so unsatisfying, that is our fault for two reasons. First, we lifted sanctions too soon. If it had to be done, it wasn't until after the election — we stripped ourselves of the instrument of pressure. Secondly, we gave — we, the West — a loan to the International Monetary Fund, also taking off any pressure from Belarus in thinking, which I think is wrong, that something is due to Belarus because it was the organizer of the so-called Minsk talks on Russia's war against Ukraine. We violated the principle of “more for more” against Belarus, because they actually got more for less. I believe that it is up to the European Parliament to keep a close eye on the European Union's critical line towards Belarus.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE).
text: - Mr President! I'm taking the floor as the author of this resolution by making two comments. The first is thanks — thanks to those MEPs who submitted various amendments beyond the text of the resolution, but at the end they withdrew both from those who appeased the resolution and those who made redundant things to the resolution. Thank you very much, because the resolution makes it more readable. And the second note is related to the need to maintain a consistent policy towards countries such as Belarus. My impression is that, from time to time, resolutions go their way, and the practice slightly different. For me, it is very important that consistency in this matter is indeed at the highest level.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution notes the shortcomings found during the 2015 presidential elections and the 2016 parliamentary elections and calls on the Belarusian authorities to resume the activities of electoral reform within the framework of a wider democratisation process and in collaboration with international partners. Belarus is also urging, as the only country in Europe to still apply capital punishment, to join the global moratorium on the execution of the death penalty as a first step towards abolishing it definitive. Finally, concern is expressed at the security concerns raised by the construction of the Belarusian nuclear power plant in Ostrovets, less than 50 km from Vilnius, Lithuania's capital, and close to the border Polish; underlines the need for complete international supervision of the implementation of the project in order to ensure its compliance with international safety requirements and standards nuclear and environmental. However, there are many points on which more clarity should be made, and that is why I have decided to abstain.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution on Belarus is a direct intervention in the country's internal affairs, which constitutes a violation of the basic principles of international law, calling for political and financial support from the “independent” opposition, the media and Belarusian civil society. In addition, he states that no free and fair elections have been held in Belarus since 1994 and focused on denouncing the repression of the opposition, regardless of the fact that since the last parliamentary elections there were members of the opposition represented in Parliament. The sovereignty and independence of countries must be recognized in order to define the political, economic and social system that best responds to the interests and aspirations of their people. Furthermore, I regret that Belarus's potential is not used to overcome the confrontation between Russia, Ukraine and the Union, but that the logic of confrontation with our neighbouring countries is continuing. That is why I voted against this resolution.

name: Martina Anderson Lynn Boylan and Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The motion for a resolution on Belarus was not critical enough of the human rights breaches that happen in that country and it also tried to criticise other countries adjacent to Belarus for the issues in that country. It was not as balanced as it should have been and in places it was unduly lenient towards the last remaining dictatorship in Europe.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the resolution on the situation in Belarus. This is an important document, especially after the recent parliamentary elections, in which the international community has seen many shortcomings and irregularities. It is clear that democracy and human rights in Belarus are not the most important, as are the health and safety of citizens. In this area, we must constantly raise security issues regarding the Belarusian nuclear power plant built in Astrave — less than 50 km away from Vilnius, the capital of Lithuania and close to the Polish border. This project requires careful international supervision to ensure that it meets international requirements and standards for nuclear safety and environmental protection, including the application of the UN Espoo and Aarhus conventions. The Commission must therefore include safety and transparency issues of the nuclear power plant under construction in its dialogue with Belarus and Russia, given that its construction is financed by Russia and that it uses Rosatom technology. The construction of the Astravo nuclear power plant is of particular concern, and I hope for active intervention by the Commission and the use of all the tools and instruments available to ensure the most transparent results and maximum security.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE)
text: in writing. - In its resolution, the European Parliament takes stock of the parliamentary elections in Belarus on 12 September 2016. The situation in Belarus with regard to respect for human rights is very worrying and therefore I support Parliament's resolution, which criticises the situation in Belarus. The shortcomings raised include the shortcomings in the elections identified by international observers and the presence in Parliament of only two representatives of the opposition, whose election is more likely to be an appointment. The European Parliament also calls for comprehensive electoral reform, the release of political prisoners and respect for democratic principles and human rights.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. — Located between Russia and Poland, Belarus is a major transit route between the European Union and Russia. The country has been governed since 1994 by Alexander Lukashenko. He put an end to the reforms of liberalization of the economy begun by his predecessor Shushkievich, and established strong presidential power, thanks to the referendums of 1994 and 1996. Tensions with the EU begin in 1998. Due to the continuation of the death penalty, Belarus had its application for membership in the Council of Europe suspended in 1996. The EU has imposed increasing economic sanctions and visa bans from 2002, and from 2008 it directly funds NGOs and opposition media to Belarus, such as the Belsat channel that broadcasts from Poland. After the events in Ukraine in 2014, the US and the EU have turned over in their relations with Belarus, bringing the country into the Eastern Partnership, lifting sanctions against cosmetic advances in the country's democratization. I abstained on this report, which endorses the lifting of sanctions against Belarus, but contains numerous interference in Belarusian political and economic affairs.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to abstain on this resolution because I do not believe that the European Union should be getting involved in the matters of other Member States.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In view of the shortcomings observed by independent international observers during the presidential elections in 2015 and 2016 parliamentary elections, I think it is necessary to call on the Belarusian government to guarantee respect for democratic rights, human rights and fundamental freedoms. In fact, comprehensive electoral reform, as part of a broader democratization process, must be initiated. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: I abstained on this report, which, while it approves the lifting of sanctions against Belarus, unfortunately contains numerous interference in the political and economic affairs of that country of Europe.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this text. I believe that any country that establishes a nuclear force must adhere to the international criteria and principles of nuclear and environmental security, and that the Government of Belarus, which assumes full responsibility for the safety and security of nuclear facilities on its territory, must comply with its obligations, both to its own population and to neighbouring countries. The establishment, operation and dismantling of nuclear facilities must be guided by the principles of openness and transparency. We recognize Belarus's progress in comparing the 2016 parliamentary elections with previous elections. We see that the opposition will have two representatives in the newly elected parliament. However, we can only regret that these elections do not comply with several basic international standards for free and democratic elections and that they do not conform to the electoral code of the country!

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ More than twenty years after the fall of the Soviet Union, the continent of Europe is living with a reality that has been repeatedly defined as the last dictatorship in Europe: Belarus. Since 1994, no democratic elections have been held in the country, since 2000 there has been no new political parties and new tools have been introduced to incarcerate and harass opposition. The resolution passed today, and I supported, calls for the government to end persecution and promote, as a first step, a comprehensive moratorium on the death penalty. The European Parliament continues to support the pro-democratic aspirations of the Belarusian people and calls on the Commission and the European External Action Service to strengthen support for the organisations of the civil society in Belarus and abroad. The text also calls for international supervision of the construction of the first Belarusian nuclear power plant in Ostrovets, less than 50 km from the Lithuanian capital Vilnius. We need assurances on nuclear and environmental safety standards, which is why the Council and the Commission must push for Belarus to conduct stress-tests on its nuclear site.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted abstention on this motion for a resolution on the political situation in Belarus, which was not supported by our parliamentary group, because I believe that, even though we agree with certain issues relating to the protection of human rights and civil liberties, the resolution raises questions that imply changes in the national legislation of that country, which is clear interference by the Union and does not resolve the issues raised by the resolution itself.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution on the situation in Belarus, but I voted deferred in the vote on Amendment No 3 of the ECR group, which I supported. I believe that the Belarusian Government's policy of using special forces to interfere in the internal affairs of civil society organizations, including those representing national minorities, such as the independent NGO Union of Poles of Belarus must be strictly condemned.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: I have preferred to abstain on this report, which, of course, endorses the lifting of sanctions against Belarus, but continues to be a subject of purest Eurofederalist interference. Blackmail is being carried out against the Belarusian authorities, who would be allowed to participate in the parliamentary assembly of the Eastern Partnership, but if and only if Belarus decided to move away from its Russian partner. In addition to criticism of the diplomatic choices of this sovereign State, political groups also allow themselves to teach it economic policy lessons, even though Belarus has the best HDI among the member states of the Commonwealth of Independent States. Finally, since the list would not be complete without that, the resolution also criticizes the Belarusian institutional system by denying, in particular, the efforts, although recognized by the OSCE, to achieve political openness.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: In writing. ‒ I do not totally agree with some of the passages of this resolution, so I decided to cast a vote of abstention.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: I voted in favour of the resolution. Belarus violates human rights on many points, as proved, for example, in the Amnesty International yearbook of clear examples. In order to support a development towards democracy, it is important that democratic trade union and popular movements are given opportunities to operate freely and support their activities. The EU, but also popular movements in EU countries, can play an important role in contributing to such development. I have voted for the sharp criticism of Belarus's participation in Russia's military exercises that also included simulated attacks on Sweden. However, I would like to emphasise that in order to create detente and common security in Europe, NATO military exercises, and Swedish participation in them, must also be criticised.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Belarus has reexecuted death sentences, being the only European country to apply them. There were four convictions in 2016 and 400 since 1991, the date of their independence. This uninterrupted application contradicts the State's declared intention to introduce a moratorium on the use of the death penalty, a commitment that Belarus had made with the Union and in response to the universal periodic report of the UN Human Rights Council. In the September elections, OSCE observers appreciated clear efforts to resolve problems in the electoral process: this is the first time since 2000 that the opposition won representation, two seats out of 110. However, a large number of recommendations from the Council of Europe and the OSCE itself have not been implemented. Electoral reform is necessary as part of a broader democratization process. Belarus must move towards the total abolition of capital punishment. There is a systematic violation by the Belarusian State of the right to life, as well as the right to independent legal defence. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of this resolution because Parliament advocated the situation in Belarus. The 2016 elections showed positive trends, such as the fact that the authorities did not create significant obstacles to collecting signatures for appointing candidates and campaigns, and that cases of abandonment to register the appointed groups and candidates accounted for only a small percentage. Based on the assessment of the mission of the OSCE Office for Democratic Institutions and Human Rights, the 2016 parliamentary elections were organised effectively. However, there have been long-term systemic deficiencies, including restrictions on the legal basis of political rights and fundamental freedoms. Parliament therefore recognises Belarus's progress in the 2016 parliamentary elections compared to the previous elections and notes that the opposition will have two representatives in the newly elected parliament. Regrets, however, that the elections did not comply with many of the basic international standards for democratic and free elections or national electoral legislation. Highly stresses that not all candidates had equal access to public media, election commissions were not impartial, administrative resources were abused in favour of candidates supporting the government, that there were a number of cases where voters were forced to participate in the prior in the vote, and for observers some procedures seemed to be opaque.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: in writing. — The report urges the Belarusian authorities to review the policy that international financial assistance to the Belarusian non-governmental sector continues to be subject to heavy taxes. It condemns the policy of the Belarusian Government to use special forces to intervene in the internal affairs of civil society organisations, including organisations representing national minorities, such as the 'Union of Poles Belarus', an independent non-governmental organisation. In the light of the above, I supported the adoption of this report.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: in writing. - I support the resolution on the situation in Belarus because I am quite well aware of the situation in this country and remain concerned about the shortcomings detected by independent international observers during the 2015 presidential election and the 2016 parliamentary elections. Attempts to improve the condition are also detected, which, alas, are not enough. I am concerned about the fact that there will be only one representative of the opposition party and one representative of the non-governmental sector in the newly elected parliament. I find it hard to believe that this is a reflection of the actual situation in the elections, so I welcome the EU's calls for Belarus to pursue comprehensive reform of the electoral system without delay as part of a wider democratic process.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: written. —I support this Report on the State of Belarus, noting that the situation in that country should continue to be closely monitored.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The resolution on the situation in Belarus highlighted the fact that since 1994 no free and fair elections have been conducted in the country. Thus, I voted in favour of this resolution because it called on the Belarusian authorities to resume work on a new electoral reform and to ensure respect for democratic principles, human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ Belarus is a non-democratic state where the death penalty, the systematic repression of dissent and the vexation of opposition still apply. Since its independence from the Soviet Union to today there have never been free elections in the country, which has always been governed by Alexander Grigoryevich Lukashenko. In recent years, there has been a moderate improvement in living conditions and respect for human rights in the country, thanks to constant pressure from the European Union and international bodies. This progress is not enough, however, and Belarus still remains subject to authoritarian and nationalist government. The European Union must continue its cultural, political and diplomatic efforts to help the Belarusian people progress along the path of democracy and integrate peacefully into the scenario international.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. - The progress made by Belarus over the past two years has contributed to improving EU-Belarus relations. Specifically, it concerns Belarus's proactive participation in the Eastern Partnership and the mid-term consultation on modernisation issues, the resumption of the EU-Belarus human rights dialogue, and the start of negotiations on visa facilitation agreements and readmission and on a Mobility Partnership. Unfortunately, however, the welfare of Belarusian citizens is jeopardised by certain policies that do not serve society as a whole, but only certain groups. In this context, we are talking about the violation of freedom of expression and that of the media, the limitation of civil and political rights, but also the stagnation of the economy for more than 20 years, the important sectors are still state-owned. It should also be noted that Belarus is the only European country still applying the death penalty, inhumane and degrading treatment. I voted in favour of this resolution in the hope of better treatment for citizens, a state that respects democratic values, but also for a dynamic civil society that can contribute to the social and economic well-being of this country.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ My vote in favour of the motion for a resolution on the situation in Belarus because the Belarusian one remains the only parliament in Europe which has not had an opposition for twenty years. The elections, held in 2010, were defined by the OSCE as “neither free, nor impartial.” According to the OSCE/ODIHR assessment, there are also a significant number of procedural irregularities and lack of transparency as regards elections held in 2016. In my view, although attempts at dialogue must be facilitated, at least in order to mitigate the difficult political situation and to ease its weight on its citizens, Belarus remains an authoritarian regime and the Human rights violations pose difficult problems for the EU to overcome. We must remind ourselves that the EU remains a community of values which has as its main concern respect for democratic principles, civil liberties and human rights.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Belarus is often referred to as “the last dictatorship in Europe”. Its president, Alexander Lukashenko, continues to be elected with incredible majorities of votes since 1991, while in Parliament his party regularly wins 110 out of 110 seats. Belarus is also the only country on the European continent that still enforces the death penalty: at least four people have been sentenced to death since February and some 400 people have been executed since the country gained independence in 1991. I abstained on the final vote.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I fully supported this report as I believe there is a need for a strong, continued pressure on Belarus and its official representatives when it comes to the elementary principle of democracy, rule of law and good governance. Despite some improvements and openings on the side of Belarus, there are still serious shortcomings, which should be addressed. Being the only European country with a death penalty is one of the most critical.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: in writing. - We support the joint motion for a resolution and call on the Belarusian authorities to continue without delay work on a comprehensive reform of the electoral system in the context of the wider democratisation process and in cooperation with international partners.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - We voted on the motion for a resolution on the situation in Belarus. Although this proposal contains positive proposals for improving democratic and social mechanisms, I do not agree with its strong focus on foreign policy and international relations. That's why I decided to abstain.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the motion for a resolution on the situation in Belarus.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. - The EU has an important role to play in the democratisation effort of Belarus, a country of fundamental geostrategic importance. I am opposed to the application of the death penalty under any circumstances, so I cannot accept that it has been applied four times this year alone. I agree with the call for Belarus to join the international moratorium, but I advocate, in principle, its abolition. I share the concern about the transparency of electoral acts, considering the difficulties of the 2015 presidential and parliamentary elections in 2016. I believe that a thorough electoral reform should be undertaken which facilitates the formation of parties and promotes the participation of citizens. The EU cannot admit political imprisonment. I advocate the immediate restitution of all civil rights to freed political prisoners and a comprehensive reform of the administrative and penal codes that preserve freedom of expression and of the press. I see with concern the construction of a nuclear power plant in Ostrovets, near Lithuania and Poland. I believe that any decision on visa facilitation should consider respect for fundamental rights on the part of the Belarusian authorities. Considering all these dimensions, I support the motion for a resolution.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution because, among other things, it calls on the Belarusian authorities to resume work on complete electoral reform and calls for rehabilitation of all prisoners issued politicians and the complete restoration of their rights by continuing on a constructive and positive path in favor of the entire Belarusian people that can lead to upholding their legitimate aspirations and pro-democracy initiatives needed to help create a stable, democratic and prosperous future for the country.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution on Belarus is a direct intervention in the country's internal affairs, which constitutes a violation of the basic principles of international law, calling for political and financial support from the “independent” opposition, the media and Belarusian civil society. In addition, he states that no free and fair elections have been held in Belarus since 1994 and focused on denouncing the repression of the opposition, regardless of the fact that since the last parliamentary elections there were members of the opposition represented in Parliament. The sovereignty and independence of countries must be recognized in order to define the political, economic and social system that best responds to the interests and aspirations of their people. Furthermore, I regret that Belarus's potential is not used to overcome the confrontation between Russia, Ukraine and the Union, but that the logic of confrontation with our neighbouring countries is continuing. That is why I voted against this resolution.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: ‒ I share the concern about the shortcomings found in Belarus by independent international observers during the presidential elections. I therefore welcomed this resolution urging the Belarusian authorities to take measures that could help overcome a number of systemic deficiencies, including restrictions on the framework legal policy for political rights and fundamental freedoms. I consider it very important and I look forward to Belarus's accession to AP Euronest, in accordance with the act of incorporation, as soon as the political conditions are met, since that accession would be the natural continuation of Belarus's participation in the multilateral cooperation framework of the Eastern Partnership.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: in writing. — I support the Commission's statement on the situation in Belarus and the need to adopt a joint motion for a resolution to that end. The next parliamentary elections in Belarus, held on September 11, 2016, were conducted in flagrant violation of the principles of democratic elections and devoid of the desired transparency. Although observers noted signs of improved standards relating to electoral rules (easier registration, better media access, no mass crackdown and the election of two opposition members to the 110-member parliament), they were nevertheless a facade character and the process of emergence MPs proved adulterated. In this case, it is therefore impossible to view the Belarusian parliament as a representative of the will of the people. In view of the above, I voted in favour of the procedure.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of this resolution as it calls upon Belarus to set up its game in assuring human rights, while also noting the improvements made on freedom of speech and freedom of the media. The resolution calls for the Government of Belarus to abolish the death penalty, and reminds Belarus that accession to the EU cannot be considered with the death penalty in place as it goes against the EU’s Charter of Fundamental Rights. The resolution encourages Belarus to tackle these issues and more, and for this reason I voted in favour of this report.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: in writing. — This resolution deals with the political situation in Belarus. It should be noted that progress in promoting democratic values remains insufficient: new political prisoners, harassment of the democratic opposition and the use of the death penalty are the daily lot in Belarus. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the resolution on the situation in Belarus. Promoting good electoral practices and combating human rights abuses are part of European external action. In these respects, Belarus's efforts are not enough. We call, with even greater insistence, for the European Union to use its full influence to engage the Belarusian authorities in the international moratorium on the execution of the death penalty.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR)
text: ‒ Today, the N-VA delegation adopted a motion for a resolution denouncing the situation in Belarus. On 11 September, elections were held in Belarus which were far from democratic and transparent. Despite some negligible reforms in the organisation of these elections, the newly elected parliament cannot be seen as a democratic reflection of the Belarusian people. The situation in the country remains worrying for the rest. We call on Lukashenko to steer his foreign policy more towards the West and insist on democratic reforms.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: in writing. - I abstained on this text. Belarus, governed by Alexander Lukashenko since 1994, has been subjected to successive restrictions by the European Union, particularly economically in 2002. In addition, the European Union directly finances NGOs and opposition media in power. Liberalizations of the political system enabled the country to integrate the Eastern Partnership and led to a relative warming of relations with the United States and the European Union in 2014. This report still contains additional requirements, including European scrutiny over the construction of the plant and unrestricted openness to foreign media and NGOs.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: in writing. — Abstention on the joint resolution: the joint motion has a positive aspect, in that it acts and supports the process of restoring dialogue and lifting sanctions. But on the other hand, it cannot be supported because it makes political and geopolitical overbid both towards the Belarusian regime and its relationship with Russia.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This resolution continues a line of interference and external interference with the political and social situation in Belarus, which we consider unacceptable. The resolution addresses Belarus' rapprochement 'to the EU, which has led to the lifting of some of the sanctions previously applied, in a process that imposed changes, which the resolution states were made reluctantly. The electoral process in Belarus is criticised, while other electoral processes, such as Georgia, are praised, all depending on the interests that the winners are (or are not) available to serve. Two standards, two measures. The resolution develops the EU's vision of the situation in Ukraine. He wears considerations about what the Belarusian people want or desire. It advocates interference in the internal situation of Belarus through support for 'civil society organisations'. It makes critical considerations regarding Belarus's energy policy options. Regardless of what opinion or position we have with regard to the Belarusian government, reservations or reasons for detachment, the line of interference that this resolution develops is unacceptable. It is up to each people to define the political, economic and social system that best meets its interests and aspirations. It is not up to the EU to make such decisions. We voted against it.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Commission's statement on the situation in Belarus. Recent parliamentary elections in Belarus have largely shown that the democratisation process is still not effective, only to observe the lack of transparency in the last electoral process. Considering the somewhat delicate economic and geopolitical situation of the country, I hope for greater commitment by the Belarusian government in relations with Europe, but above all in the implementation of Rule of law, an essential value for us Westerners.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: In writing. ‒ I abstain from the resolution which contains good intent, but then falls into the usual anti-Russia rhetoric.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: in writing. - I am voting against the resolution on the situation in Belarus. It would be good if the European Union and the United States interventions in the Constitution of independent States remain at a more discreet level. Belarus is a state that is trying to recover and needs substantial help and not suggestions as to how it should function as a nation.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The continuing use of the death penalty in Belarus, the only country on the European continent that still applies the death penalty, is to be deplored. I strongly support the call on the authorities of Belarus to commute the remaining death sentences and establish without delay a formal moratorium on executions as a first step towards abolition of the death penalty. The introduction of the moratorium would be a decisive step in bringing Belarus closer to the pan-European legal standards. It is important to increase cooperation in the areas of legal and labour migration; asylum and the protection of refugees; prevention and combating of irregular migration and on maximising the development impact of migration and mobility. However, we cannot forget that the situation in Belarus is not improving from a political rights and social freedoms point of view. The repression of democratic opposition and of independent civil society activity has to be condemned by all means.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the resolution considering that, according to the OSCE's assessment of the 2016 parliamentary elections, these were organized efficiently, although old systemic deficiencies persisted, including restrictions imposed by the legal framework on political rights and freedoms fundamental, numerous procedural irregularities were found with regard to early counting and tabulation and were not transparent. Therefore, we must call on the Belarusian authorities to resume without delay work on the comprehensive reform of the electoral system within the framework of a process of global democratization and to ensure respect for democratic principles, human rights and fundamental freedoms in all circumstances.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the European Parliament's joint motion for a resolution on the situation in Belarus because unfortunately, Belarus still today, despite the many calls from the communities international, it still remains an authoritarian and illiberal regime. In fact, the Belarusian Parliament is the only Parliament in Europe that has no real opposition for over twenty years: the last elections in 2010 were defined as “neither free nor transparent”. I am very concerned by the absence of political pluralism and political democracy in Belarus, where no new parties have been registered for 16 years. I therefore call for all restrictions on this issue to be abandoned and that all political parties can carry out their political activities without hindrance. There are also strong concerns about the establishment of the death penalty and the fate of political prisoners, which is the cause of harsh international criticism. I firmly believe that attempts at dialogue must be facilitated, because diplomacy is our main weapon to try to ease the pressure on citizens' freedoms, by the regime . I reiterate my call on the Belarusian authorities to ensure, in all circumstances, respect for democratic principles and fundamental freedoms, in accordance with the Universal Declaration of Rights of man.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of the resolution on the new situation in Belarus, as I also see the problems there in a global and geo-strategic context. The EU is well advised to play a deliberate and active role here.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: in writing. - Due to the prevailing shortcomings identified by independent international observers in the 2016 parliamentary elections in Belarus, the resolution is to be supported. The political grievances must be eliminated. There is a need for comprehensive electoral reform. It is also necessary to rehabilitate the released political prisoners and to rerecognise their full citizenship rights. I also urge the Republic of Belarus to join the international moratorium on the death penalty.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ There have been two major developments in Belarus. First, there has been the resumption of death sentences carried out after a two-year pause. The EU considers the death penalty a major sticking point in diplomatic and economic relations. It had recently unfrozen the assets of 150 major figures in Belarus following this pause and the release of some political prisoners. The second concerns the planned development of a nuclear plant near the border with Lithuania. There have been questions raised over the planning processes’ compliance with international safety standards and other requirements of the Belarusian Government through its membership of the International Atomic Energy Agency.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on Belarus, which expresses grave concern about the shortcomings observed by independent international observers during the 2015 presidential and 2016 parliamentary elections as well as harassment of media and journalists. Belarusian authorities need to implement measures outlined in the report to improve respect of fundamental freedoms, the rule of law and democracy as a matter of urgency.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted abstention on this motion for a resolution on the political situation in Belarus, which was not supported by our parliamentary group, because I believe that, even though we agree with certain issues relating to the protection of human rights and civil liberties, the resolution raises questions that imply changes in the national legislation of that country, which is clear interference by the Union and does not resolve the issues raised by the resolution itself.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on Belarus which expresses grave concern about the current situation there, including the harassment of media and journalists.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this motion. I am deeply concerned by the shortcomings observed by independent international observers during the 2015 presidential and 2016 parliamentary elections. The Belarusian authorities should ensure, in all circumstances, respect for democratic principles, human rights and fundamental freedoms, in accordance with the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the international and regional human rights instruments ratified by Belarus. This is essential for the security of the region and it should be imperative upon the Union to advance the cause of human rights, democracy and rule of law throughout the world, most of all in our immediate region.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour since I have no objections.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: in writing. – On 11 September 2016 parliamentary elections took place in Belarus, the first parliamentary elections after the EP delegation visit to Belarus in 2015. Given the geopolitical situation in the region and a very difficult economic situation of Belarus, there were some expectations that the election process would have been more transparent than in the previous elections. Although some signs of improvement have been noticed (easier registration, better access to media, no mass persecutions and, finally, two opposition members elected to the 110-member Parliament), it is clear that the elections were very far from being conducted in a democratic and transparent way. The Belarusian Parliament thus cannot be seen as representing the will of the Belarusians. Yet it is also clear that Lukashenko hopes not to disrupt his relations with the western world, which have substantially improved in the last two to three years. I have voted in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: written. - I voted for a Resolution on the situation in Belarus since, despite some improvements, progress in that country is taking into account earlier reports from the European Parliament. In particular, this concerns the reform of electoral legislation, and a number of shortcomings were observed during the 2015 and parliamentary 2016 presidential elections. There are insufficient advances in respect of political rights, freedom of speech and freedom of opinion, freedom of the press, the activities of the non-governmental sector. Despite improvements, the government of Belarus is being urged to rehabilitate and release political prisoners. The development of cooperation between the EU and Belarus on the economic front should be continued. It is necessary to call for a moratorium and the subsequent abolition of the death penalty, which is still being enforced in that country.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. — Beyond a positive protrusion in favour of lifting sanctions against Belarus, this report promotes too many interference in Belarusian internal affairs to gain my support. So I abstained.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: I voted in favour of my colleague Bogdan Zdrojewski's resolution on the situation in Belarus. The adoption of this text was an opportunity to express our concern about the deterioration of the political situation in Belarus. The European Parliament condemns the harassment and imprisonment of political opponents and, through the assistance of the European External Action Service, supports all pro-democratic initiatives. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution on Belarus, which takes stock of the last parliamentary elections in September. We are concerned about some shortcomings noted by international observers, call for resumption of work on comprehensive electoral reform and call for the rehabilitation of the liberated political prisoners.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: in writing. — I abstained on this motion for a resolution. This motion for a resolution is largely balanced, but it calls for interference in the internal affairs of a sovereign state.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: in writing. - I support the European Parliament resolution on the situation in Belarus. Undemocratic laws and practices continue to be observed in the country, making the entire electoral process opaque and undemocratic. Belarus continues to be a centralised and autocratic state governed by a “soft dictatorship” where human rights continue to be systematically violated by state authorities, especially against persons expressing dissent or protesting against the country's rule. Worrying is the ongoing construction of a nuclear power plant in Ostrovets, Grodno region funded by Russia and using Russian technology, which will lead to Belarus' further dependence on Russia in terms of energy security. I do not support the policy of the Belarusian Government of using special forces to intervene in the internal affairs of civil society organisations.

name: Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the resolution on the situation in Belarus, prepared by the President of the European Parliament's Delegation for Relations with Belarus, recognising its content and appeals. The resolution notes that changes in Belarus, however slowly, are taking place successively, and supports a policy of gradual exit from the policy of isolation. But given still far from international standards electoral procedure, the resolution upholds the policy of so-called critical engagement. Among the positive changes, the election of a representative of the political opposition and one independent candidate to the Palace, an opening to observers during the election and a change of attitude that gives hope for legislative change. Belarus is the only country in Europe where citizens cannot know the results of elections in their respective circuits, as the published results are highly aggregated. This takes away from citizens a sense of influence on the shape of parliament, as they do not see the effects of their local activity in the context of elections, but also prevents analysis of results and civic control of elections. Despite these irregularities and slowness of change, I believe that the current direction of the EU opening up to Belarus, particularly in the economic area, is appropriate. Belarus is a potentially important partner for the EU and we should intensify dialogue and cooperation with our eastern neighbour not only in the field of economics but also human capital, education, culture and social innovation.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Earlier this year, President Lukashenko released the last of the country’s political prisoners, prompting the EU to lift sanctions in place since the 2010 crackdown against the opposition. Furthermore, in recent parliamentary elections in the country, the Belarusian authorities allowed the democratic opposition to register, participate and even to win seats in the parliament. Unfortunately, these signs of democratisation have persuaded the EU to maintain the fiction that the Belarusian regime is changing. In fact, President Lukashenko’s 22 years autocratic rule continues to be repressive. It is not surprising, therefore, that Belarus has a crumbling Soviet—style economy and a despicable human rights record. Belarus continues to be the only country in Europe which has the death penalty. Moreover, the Belarusian authorities continue regularly to harass and arrest human rights activists, journalists, and opposition and civil society leaders. Clearly, this is contrary to European values and norms. For that reason, I urge the EU not only to increase its support for the opposition and civil society in Belarus but also to seek a deeper human rights dialogue with the Belarusian authorities.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: I abstained on this report, which, while it approves the lifting of sanctions against Belarus, unfortunately contains numerous interference in the political and economic affairs of Belarus.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because it sets out the current situation in Belarus, which has reexecuted death sentences. This application contradicts the State's declared intention to introduce a moratorium on the use of the death penalty. That is a commitment Belarus had made with the Union and in response to the universal periodic report of the UN Human Rights Council. Belarus was the only European country that applied capital punishment, and must introduce a moratorium while moving towards total abolition. Human rights organizations denounce the widespread use of torture and medical treatment to force defendants to self-incriminate, without access to legal defence. It is described that there is a systematic violation of the right to independent defence. The families of convicted persons are subjected to great stress: they are not informed of the date of execution; bodies are not handed over to them. The places of burial of those executed are kept secret.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR)
text: in writing. — We know that Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov was in Minsk. We also know that Aleksandr Lukashenko will be welcomed in the Kremlin by Putin. That is why we cannot fail to look at the positive developments of the recent period in Belarus. The September elections were held more democratically than other times: they were more transparent, and opposition members were able to register more easily and had access to the media. However, Parliament does not represent the will of Belarusian citizens, since after 20 years only two opposition politicians won a seat in parliament. On the other hand, Belarus is currently building its first nuclear power plant in Ostrovets, on the EU border. We demand that this plant strictly comply with international nuclear safety and environmental requirements. The Belarusian government must rehabilitate freed political prisoners and fully restore their civil and political rights, as well as stop political harassment of the independent press. Only under these circumstances can the EU further develop relations with Belarus, a state which has proved, moreover, extremely important in the peace process in Ukraine.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Relations between the European Union and Belarus need to be revised. Belarusians have to do their work on democratisation, human rights and open elections. But the European Union also has much to do on the path to normalisation of our relations. The EU’s attitude to Belarus is symptomatic. Often it was a mix of ignorance and arrogance. One shining example is the question of participation of the Belorussian parliament in Euronest. There are still deep discussions in the European Parliament on whether to invite the newly—elected Belorussian parliament representatives to take part in Euronest meetings or not. I think that the Commission approach of critical involvement is strategically right. Involvement, not arrogance, will give us positive results.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing - In order to be a fully respected democratic country, Belarus must proceed to a fundamental reform of civil and political rights and freedoms, respect for the rule of law, reform of electoral law and abolish the death penalty. The European Union must provide Belarus with maximum support on the road to democracy so as to prevent, as a matter of priority, possible internal or external conflict in this locality.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing. - I do not support the joint motion for a resolution on the situation in Belarus, for the reasons I explained in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 26 October 2016, and because this joint motion for a resolution is not complete and documented.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: in writing. — As I am very sceptical about interference in the internal affairs of a sovereign state, I am abstaining in this vote.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour. I support the provisions set out in the resolution on violations of democratic principles and intolerable human rights in Belarus. The resolution also raises the issue of the problems that arise at the Astrava nuclear power plant being built. This issue must be relevant not only for Lithuania, but also for the entire European region because of the potential risks to the environment, human health and public safety.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Belarus just held elections in September. For the first time in 12 years, members of the opposition are represented in Parliament. As the OSCE points out, “clear efforts have been made”, but it is also true that “a number of systemic gaps persist, leading to a restrictive legal framework for political rights and fundamental freedoms”. The resolution is concerned at the lack of respect for human rights, such as the death penalty still applied. But, above all, she asks to support “radio and television broadcasting in Belarusian from abroad”. Radios responsible for “promoting the values on which the Union is based and its objectives as an international actor”. Again, the independence of the media is a relative principle and interference is a key word. This position of Parliament is in opposition to that of the Commission, which has just lifted sanctions against that country in order to re-establish dialogue. This Chamber chooses a vindictive and conditional approach that is incapable of doing what it wants: to promote human rights. Under these conditions, I abstain.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: The joint motion has a positive aspect in that it acts and supports the process of restoring dialogue and lifting sanctions. However, it cannot be supported because it makes political and geopolitical overbid both towards the Belarusian regime and its relationship with Russia. I therefore abstained on this issue.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. - The Belarusian authorities should resume work without delay on a thorough reform of the electoral system within the framework of the wider democratisation process, in cooperation with international partners. Belarus must ensure, in all circumstances, respect for democratic principles, human rights and fundamental freedoms, in accordance with the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and international and regional human rights instruments ratified by Belarus. The EU is committed to working in the interests of the Belarusian population, supporting their aspirations and initiatives for democracy and contributing to a stable, democratic and prosperous future of the country. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. Fundamental freedoms and political rights in Belarus remain undermined, while opposition and political dissent continues to be stifled. It is unacceptable that these conditions persist.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the resolution because it is important that Parliament remains attentive and is closely following the latest evolutions in Belarus, after two election years (presidential in 2015, parliamentary in 2016) in what has been called ‘the last dictatorship in Europe’.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted against this resolution on Belarus, which uses inappropriate language for Russia which only results in the sterile escalation of reciprocal sanctions. There is an urgent need to re-establish dialogue with Russia, which is the largest in the world, in order to put an end to the daily sanctions imposed on European producers and farmers and, on the other hand, to coordinate the indispensable fight against the Islamic State.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: in writing. — Following the adoption of the motion for a resolution on Turkey, Belarus was also on the agenda. It is true that the resolution has become a little critical, and we have very much welcomed the wind of positive changes. Belarus has set its way in the right direction and we hope that it will continue on this, in compliance with the European Parliament's proposals.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this motion for a resolution that stresses the shortcomings observed during the 2015 presidential elections and the 2016 parliamentary elections, calling on Belarusian authorities to begin work on a comprehensive electoral reform as part of a broader democratisation process.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: in writing. — I abstained from voting here because the bottom line of the motion goes beyond the masses and interferes in the internal affairs of a sovereign state.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing. - I supported.
