Previous presidential and parliamentary elections in Belarus have raised concerns as the Belarusian opposition disregards practices inherent in the rule of law and there continue to be many human rights violations in the country. It is necessary to continue to carry out government reform, ensure that democratic principles are respected, fundamental freedoms are respected and the death penalty must be banned.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: In writing. ‒ I would vote in favour of the proposal from my colleagues because I believe that, despite the Belarusian Government's commitment to link up relations with the West and to try to comply with the demands of the European Union, we can note that there is still a long way to go. Consequently, the European Union must reaffirm its commitment to work in the interests of the Belarusian people, supporting their aspirations and initiatives for democracy and contributing to a future stable, democratic and prosperous for the country. Therefore I would vote upvote.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: written. - I support the adoption of a resolution clearly setting out the position of the European Union on the political and socio-economic life of Belarus. It is a country that is regarded as the last dictatorship on the European continent. Any form of economic cooperation must not be achieved unless respect for human rights is set as an absolute priority as a prerequisite for such cooperation. The last elections held in Belarus confirmed, unfortunately, that this state still has no intention of moving on the path of democratic reforms. It is necessary to carry out screening of the Belarusian political system and identify shortcomings and in future cooperation to set up a reform plan as a prerequisite for further cooperation. The protection of human and civil rights is the basis of the European Union and action on the foreign policy agenda must reflect what the Union is at its core — the space for the highest protection of all rights. An additional problem also arises the death penalty, the procedure and sanction that the modern world has rejected. Democratization and building democratic institutions must be the absolute priority of the European Union when it comes to Belarus. Securing basic freedoms and protection against any persecution, especially political ones, must be the path Belarus will take, if it wants to make any ties with the European Union. This message must be clearly sent.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: written. - The progress achieved should be welcomed, but I note that it is still not enough. For the first time in a long time, the democratic opposition will have representatives in the Belarusian parliament, but two independent members of parliament cannot be expected to assume the role of genuine opposition. Critical voices from the country itself condemned the recent elections and found that again they were not a credible reflection of the will of the citizens. The Belarusian authorities should proceed without delay to work on comprehensive electoral reform, which is part of a wider democratization process, with cooperation with international partners. Our policy of “critical engagement” towards the Belarusian authorities should continue and therefore I urge the Delegation for Relations with Belarus and the Commission to closely monitor legislative initiatives and monitor their implementation. Belarus is the only country in Europe that continues to carry out the death penalty and the authorities have not stopped treating political opponents in a repressive manner. It is necessary to lift restrictions on the leadership of political parties and take the first steps towards the abolition of the death penalty. It must rehabilitate freed political prisoners and restore all civil and political rights to them. I also want to point out that I am concerned about the security issues around the Ostrovec nuclear power plant in close proximity to the EU borders. The comprehensive international oversight of the implementation of this project is necessary to ensure its compliance with international security conditions and standards.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - This resolution continues a line of interference and external interference with the political and social situation in Belarus with a view to its internal change, in line with the interests of the European Union. Despite identifying what they identify as a rapprochement of Belarus with the EU, the resolution continues with a weep of considerations, recommendations and demands which are absolutely unacceptable in a logic of institutional relations with a sovereign state and which violate international law. It calls for reforms for the Belarusian electoral system talking about democratization of the country. It makes considerations about the judicial system and the principles of the rule of law in that country. It promotes external support to organisations and sources of information, so-called independent, which, of course, stand in direct confrontation with the Belarusian government. It presents criticisms of the country's development model aimed at its conditioning. Apart from considerations regarding the economic, social and political model of development in that country, we consider it unacceptable that the EU will remain in the face of third countries, daring to teach lessons and interfere directly where it does not have to interfere, promoting destabilisation of states. It is up to each people, within the framework of its supreme sovereignty, to decide the direction and path of development of their country. We voted against it.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this resolution, which condemns Belarus's actions that run counter to democratic principles, fundamental freedoms and human rights. Currently, Belarus is increasing political arrests, particularly in the ruling opposition. Moreover, it remains the only European country that still applies the death penalty. Beyond that, the construction of the country's first nuclear power plant, whose compliance with nuclear safety and environmental standards remains to be proven, is a matter of concern.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this non-legislative and non-binding report. Whilst we are concerned about the state of democracy in Belarus, we cannot support the development of EU foreign policy or the potential for EU action.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. - The European Parliament expressed its concern about the shortcomings identified by independent international observers during the 2015 presidential elections and the 2016 parliamentary elections. It acknowledged that efforts have been made to improve the situation, but that these were not sufficient. The Belarusian authorities must resume, without delay, work towards a thorough reform of the electoral system in the framework of the wider democratisation process, in cooperation with international partners. We also call on the Belarusian authorities to ensure respect for democratic principles, human rights and fundamental freedoms, in accordance with the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and ratified international and regional human rights instruments for Belarus.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Belarus has reexecuted death sentences, being the only European country to apply them. There are four convictions so far in 2016 and 400 since 1991, their independence. This uninterrupted application contradicts the State's declared intention to introduce a moratorium on the use of the death penalty. That is a commitment Belarus had made with the Union and in response to the universal periodic report of the UN Human Rights Council. On the other hand, during the September elections, OSCE observers appreciated clear efforts to solve problems in the electoral process: this is the first time since 2000 that the opposition won representation, two seats out of 110. However, a large number of recommendations from the Council of Europe and the OSCE itself have not been implemented. Electoral reform is necessary as part of a broader democratization process. Belarus must move towards the total abolition of capital punishment. There is a systematic violation by the Belarusian State of the right to life, as well as the right to independent legal defence. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the situation in Belarus, convinced that Belarus has insufficient progress in upholding democratic values. By signing this resolution, I associate myself with the European Parliament's commitment to 'work in the interests of the Belarusian people, supporting their aspirations and democratic initiatives and contributing to the country's stable, democratic and prosperous future'. Together with my colleagues in the European Parliament, we also urge Belarus, a country that still applies capital punishment, to “join in a global moratorium on the application of the death penalty and thus to set the first step towards its definitive abolition”.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. — Belarus is an important neighbor of the European Union. The situation in this country cannot be overwhed by us. Especially when some progress can be seen in the field of human rights, although there are grounds for fear, it can only remain declarative, as has already been repeatedly. Now that Belarus is looking for opportunities for relations with the EU, we have a great opportunity to remind its authorities that long-term stability and prosperity are only possible in well-managed, democratic, market-economy countries. At the same time, it is important to draw attention to the irresponsible behaviour of Belarus. Only a few kilometers away from the EU's external borders, this country, or rather Russia, builds a dangerous nuclear power plant in this country. We have heard a lot about the “safety culture” of the main construction contractor Rosatom. The bad flair is strengthened by both modified design solutions, such as construction outside the water body, intentions to pump water from a river several dozen meters below and several kilometers away, as well as news about accidents - from the fall of walls to the fall of the reactor body, or the facts that the Belarusian authorities refuse to carry out resistance tests. In other words, a delayed bomb is being built in an authoritarian country, which can harm more than 100 million Europeans. That is why I tabled a draft amendment to this resolution, which calls on the Commission to pay great attention to this construction. Of course, it would be best if Belarus refused this meaningless construction at all. That is what I urge you to do.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. - Belarus has been making efforts to deepen and improve its relations with the West, although there are still some problems within its legal framework, particularly as regards political rights and fundamental freedoms. The EU has lifted certain restrictions imposed on Belarus as a gesture of goodwill to encourage Belarus to improve the situation regarding human rights and democratic principles. However, cooperation between the two needs to be strengthened in a number of areas. In addition to the interest in ensuring the general reform and democratisation of the Belarusian system, together with international partners, the EU also wants to promote the rehabilitation of liberated political prisoners, abolish the death penalty, in what is still the only country in Europe that applies it, and to accompany the construction of the nuclear power plant in Ostrovets, through international oversight to ensure compliance with international nuclear and environmental safety requirements and standards. As I believe that these efforts should take account of the interests of the Belarusian population, supporting their aspirations and initiatives for democracy and contributing to a stable, democratic and prosperous future of the country, I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: in writing. - I supported this resolution, which considers Belarus's efforts to respect and defend democratic values inadequate. In early 2016, Belarus committed itself to improving the political and human rights situation. This commitment has not been fulfilled. The Belarusian regime continues to imprison political opponents, muzzle political protests and resort to the death penalty. This resolution urges the establishment of a moratorium on the application of the death penalty in Belarus. On the other hand, the text calls for the establishment of international monitoring of the construction of the first Belarusian nuclear power plant, just 50 kilometres from Vilnius. This project must be carried out in accordance with international standards of nuclear safety and respect for the environment.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted abstention on this motion for a resolution on the political situation in Belarus, which was not supported by our parliamentary group, because I believe that, even though we agree with certain issues relating to the protection of human rights and civil liberties, the resolution raises questions that imply changes in the national legislation of that country, which is clear interference by the Union and does not resolve the issues raised by the resolution itself.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the situation in Belarus, which takes stock of this year's parliamentary elections. Among other things, the EPP was able to introduce in the report the call for Belarusian authorities to rehabilitate all released political prisoners and to uphold democratic principles such as human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution on Belarus is a direct intervention in the country's internal affairs, which constitutes a violation of the basic principles of international law, calling for political and financial support from the “independent” opposition, the media and Belarusian civil society. In addition, he states that no free and fair elections have been held in Belarus since 1994 and focused on denouncing the repression of the opposition, regardless of the fact that since the last parliamentary elections there were members of the opposition represented in Parliament. The sovereignty and independence of countries must be recognized in order to define the political, economic and social system that best responds to the interests and aspirations of their people. Furthermore, I regret that Belarus's potential is not used to overcome the confrontation between Russia, Ukraine and the Union, but that the logic of confrontation with our neighbouring countries is continuing. That is why I voted against this resolution.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this as I do not wish the EU to get involved in foreign affairs.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: written. - I voted positively for this report, but this rationale of voting is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEPs solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the real quality and the amount of work, efficiency and most of all the success of the advocacy.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing. - I supported the resolution on the situation in Belarus because I believe in the added value of the dialogue between the EU and the Belarusian Government. The position adopted by the European Parliament in this text is in particular a response to the September parliamentary elections held in Belarus. To some extent, the election results sparked hope because two opposition MPs were elected to the Lower House for the first time. On the other hand, observation missions revealed concrete evidence of large-scale nationwide attempts to increase overall participation. Despite the shortcomings highlighted by observers, I hope that the two newly elected opposition MPs will not only be considered politically appointed MPs, but will act as a genuine opposition. The EU has an interest in good relations with Belarus, as is due to the recent abolition of most restrictive measures against Belarusian officials in February 2016. With the Belarusian economy experiencing more than a twenty-year period of stagnation, improving relations with its western neighbours could greatly help the Belarusian people. However, the regime there will have to step up respect for fundamental rights. Belarus should join a global moratorium on the implementation of the death penalty, and it is equally important for a healthy society that independent media is not pursued politically. I am of the opinion that Belarus should accede to the Euronest Parliamentary Assembly, where there would be enough room for the disputed issues to be clarified.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: in writing. - The situation in Belarus is far too complex for the European Parliament to be able to find a balanced position on this issue. That's why I abstained here.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: written. — The resolution refers to recent parliamentary elections in Belarus. Concerns are being expressed about electoral irregularities spotted by independent observers. It calls on Belarus to proceed with the reform of the electoral system. It is necessary to rehabilitate freed political prisoners and restore all civil rights to them. We encourage Belarus to introduce a moratorium on the death penalty. We call on the Commission to take the necessary measures to simplify the visa regime with Belarus. The Belarusian authorities must in all circumstances guarantee respect for democratic principles, human rights and freedoms. The population of Belarus should be helped to develop democracy. I support this Resolution in the hope that it will result in positive shifts in Belarus. The resolution follows a good example of the Resolution, adopted by the European Parliament after last year's presidential election in Belarus.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: in writing. - Interventions by the European Union in the Constitution of independent States must be within limits before they become “raw”. Belarus is a state that is trying to recover and needs substantial help and not suggestions as to how it should function as a nation.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the proposal for a resolution, in the conviction that the attention of the European institutions, including similar previous reports and political resolutions of the European Parliament on the internal situation in Belarus, has contributed substantially to the fact that the The current analysis of the situation can report on a number of aspects of improving human rights, the rule of law and political opening-up. I believe that the Belarusian society and political elite have led to the appreciation of European standards and the recognition and lessons of the dangers of building exclusive relations with Russia by Moscow's aggressive expansion in the region, including the actions that violate Ukraine's sovereignty, the Crimea violent annexation. I consider it important in the report to acknowledge the positive role of the EU played by Minsk in international efforts to achieve peace in Ukraine. I consider that the report and the resolution, while acknowledging positive developments, duly highlighted the remaining serious deficiencies in the rule of law in Belarus (death penalty, overshadowing opposition, the problem of electoral rights, the situation of the independent press, etc.) and well identifies the On the part of the European Union, the directions and frameworks of our further relationship with this important partner country is appropriate, critically supportive, and based on conditioning.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: in writing. — After more than 20 years, the Belarusian opposition finally has its representatives in parliament elected by universal elections. Although this is to be seen more in terms of political nominations than the actual outcome of the election, we should see this gesture from the Belarus authorities. However, it cannot be overestimated and the Union's response must be carefully balanced. Both during the 2015 presidential election and the recent 2016 general election, we faced a number of irregularities. The Belarusian authorities should immediately proceed to work on a comprehensive reform of the electoral code as part of a wider process of democratization of the state. Respect for democratic principles, human rights and fundamental civil liberties as well as rehabilitation of released political prisoners are a condition of sine qua non further progress in EU-Belarus relations.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. - The situation in Belarus has evolved significantly in recent years, although it is still far from meeting the Union's standards in terms of democracy and the rule of law. Following the release of the last political prisoners at the end of 2015 by the Minsk regime, the EU lifted sanctions against the Belarusian state and started a critical dialogue with it. Legislative elections of 11 September 2016 marked the election of two independent opposition MPs to the lower house of the Belarusian Parliament. It is a step forward, although the democratic opposition forces in Belarus have condemned these elections as incorrect. Economically, the Minsk regime needs financial resources to overcome the current difficult situation. The EU can offer these resources, but only in return for the sustained democratisation of the Belarusian state structures and the renunciation of dictatorial and authoritarian leadership methods. The main objective of the Union must be to promote its values in Belarus, the important state in its eastern neighbourhood, and a better economic situation for Belarusian citizens. I support the adoption of this resolution.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: in writing. — I voted in favour of this text. I believe that any country that establishes a nuclear force must adhere to the international criteria and principles of nuclear and environmental security, and that the Government of Belarus, which assumes full responsibility for the safety and security of nuclear facilities on its territory, must comply with its obligations, both to its own population and to neighbouring countries. The establishment, operation and dismantling of nuclear facilities must be guided by the principles of openness and transparency. We recognize Belarus's progress in comparing the 2016 parliamentary elections with previous elections. We see that the opposition will have two representatives in the newly elected parliament. However, we can only regret that these elections do not comply with several basic international standards for free and democratic elections and that they do not conform to the electoral code of the country!

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the situation in Belarus, which speaks out against the undemocratic nature of the 2015 and 2016 parliamentary elections in Belarus and criticises the Belarusian government for not carrying out electoral reforms as part of the democratisation process. Further, the resolution urges Belarus to release its political prisoners and observe international laws on human rights and freedom of expression. Lastly, the resolution expresses concern over the construction of the Russian-sponsored Belarusian nuclear power plant in Ostrovets, less than 50 km from Vilnius, and fears for EU security as a result.

name: Ivica Tolić (PPE)
text: written. - I support the proposal for a resolution of the European Parliament on the situation in Belarus. OSC/ODIHR recommendations should be implemented on time, before local elections in March 2018 I believe that this is the key to achieving the desired improvement of EU-Belarus relations. I believe that the Belarusian government should rehabilitate liberated political prisoners and restore their civil and political rights.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing. - I have supported the proposal for a resolution of the European Parliament on the situation in Belarus. In Belarus, the government still called the last dictator of EuropeAlexander Lukashenko. He has already won five presidential elections in 2015 and has been in power since 1994. In its desire to converge with the West, Belarus took a major step by following certain recommendations by the OSCE/ODIHR (Office for Democratic Institutions and Human Rights) and the Council of Europe's Venice Commission (Council of Europe Advisory Body on Constitutional Issues) for the 2016 parliamentary elections. According to their estimates, the elections were done effectively, but despite everything, there are still systemic errors and restrictions on political freedoms. Since 1994, these are the first free elections to Belarus. The democratic opposition will also be represented in parliament for the first time since this year. Belarus played a constructive role in ceasing the fire in Ukraine, possibly also for fear of Russia. In any event, cooperation between the EU and Belarus needs to be strengthened. But Belarus needs to continue electoral reform as part of a broader process of democratisation and eliminate mechanisms that shorn democratic principles, human rights and fundamental freedoms. Rehabilitation of political prisoners and the return of civil and political rights would be needed. The EU should continue with its policy of “critical cooperation”, which it cultivates towards Belarus.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted abstention on this motion for a resolution on the political situation in Belarus, which was not supported by our parliamentary group, because I believe that, even though we agree with certain issues relating to the protection of human rights and civil liberties, the resolution raises questions that imply changes in the national legislation of that country, which is clear interference by the Union and does not resolve the issues raised by the resolution itself.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ A parliamentary election was held in Belarus on 11 September 2016. This was the first parliamentary election following the visit of the EP delegation to Belarus in 2015. With regard to the geopolitical situation in the region and the difficult economic situation of Belarus, the election process was expected to be more transparent than in previous elections. Although there were some signs of improvement, however, the way the election was conducted was far from democratic and transparent. On the other hand, it is also clear that President Lukashenko does not want to deteriorate his relations with the West, which have improved significantly in the last 2-3 years. I supported the motion for a resolution.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted abstention on this motion for a resolution on the political situation in Belarus, which was not supported by our parliamentary group, because I believe that, even though we agree with certain issues relating to the protection of human rights and civil liberties, the resolution raises questions that imply changes in the national legislation of that country, which is clear interference by the Union and does not resolve the issues raised by the resolution itself.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on situation in Belarus. Since 1994 no free and fair elections have been conducted in Belarus. Its attempts to make progress during 2015 presidential and 2016 parliamentary elections were insufficient.  Key sectors of the Belarusian economy are still under state control, no new political party has been registered since 2000 and new ways to harass or even jail the opposition are being found. Moreover, Belarus is the only country in Europe still applying capital punishment. The resolution calls on Belarus to stop these developments and reiterates the European Parliament’s commitment to support the pro-democratic aspirations of its people. I voted in favour because I believe that Belarus should join a global moratorium on execution of the death penalty as a first step towards permanent abolition.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The presentation of this motion for a resolution is preceded by the good example that last year was the adoption of a similar resolution by the European Chamber following the presidential elections in Belarus. In this case, the motion responds to the observations collected after the parliamentary elections, which took place on 12 September. The text expresses Community concern about irregularities noted by independent international observers and calls on the Belarusian authorities to carry out actions aimed at electoral reform, as well as the rehabilitation of all liberated political prisoners, fully reinstating their rights. Belarus was also urged to sign the international moratorium on the death penalty and called upon its authorities to respect democratic principles, human rights and fundamental freedoms. I therefore considered it appropriate to vote in favour.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution on Belarus is a direct intervention in the country's internal affairs, which constitutes a violation of the basic principles of international law, calling for political and financial support from the “independent” opposition, the media and Belarusian civil society. In addition, he states that no free and fair elections have been held in Belarus since 1994 and focused on denouncing the repression of the opposition, regardless of the fact that since the last parliamentary elections there were members of the opposition represented in Parliament. The sovereignty and independence of countries must be recognized in order to define the political, economic and social system that best responds to the interests and aspirations of their people. Furthermore, I regret that Belarus's potential is not used to overcome the confrontation between Russia, Ukraine and the Union, but that the logic of confrontation with our neighbouring countries is continuing. That is why I voted against this resolution.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour because, according to the assessment, the 2016 parliamentary elections were organised efficiently by the OSCE/ODIHR, but there are still a number of long-standing systemic deficiencies, including limitations in the legal framework for political rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: According to data from the United Nations report, Belarus, a socialist country that was part of the former Soviet Union, has been raising its quality of life. Despite the economic sanctions of the European Union and the oppression imposed by the EU-NATO states, this country, which has refused to apply the pure and harsh revenues of the IMF and maintains a close relationship with Russia, and which is therefore labelled “undemocratic”, unlike the other Baltic republics, maintains a high level of public social coverage, and decided not to break with its socialist past. Having said that, we consider all the measures aimed at improving relations between the EU and Belarus as positive, and we believe that the lifting of sanctions should develop towards their complete annulment, respecting the sovereignty of those countries and their right to decide on their future freed from any external pressure. .

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: In writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the situation in Belarus. In order to build better relations with the West, the Belarusian authorities allowed opposition democratic parties to register more easily than in previous elections and Foreign observers benefited from better access to vote counting. The resolution nevertheless reiterates its appeal to the Belarusian authorities to ensure that democratic principles, human rights and fundamental freedoms are respected in all circumstances, in accordance with the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and international and regional human rights instruments ratified by Belarus. It is then called on the Belarusian government to rehabilitate freed political prisoners and fully restore their civil and political rights and to join the global moratorium on the execution of the death penalty, as a first step towards its ultimate abolition.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Together with my colleagues, I welcome the EU’s action to promote democracy and the rule of law in Belarus. I join the call for all political prisoners in the country to be immediately released, and for legitimate political opposition and civil society to be allowed to operate freely. I echo my colleagues’ concerns about the construction of the Belarusian nuclear power plant in Ostrovets, and support international action to address the problem. I also welcome the ongoing work of Nuclear Transparency Watch, which provides an important platform for civil society scrutiny of the nuclear industry.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: in writing - Belarus is the only country in Europe to carry out the death penalty. President Lukashenko's controversial regime continues to be criticised mainly in respect of the rights of political opponents, respect for fundamental human and civil rights and democratic principles. That is why I supported this report because it reflects well the current reality in Belarus and responds to current security issues such as the construction of a nuclear power plant in Ostrovets close to the border with Poland and Lithuania. In order to alleviate regional tensions, the implementation of this project needs to be subject to strict and comprehensive international supervision. It is necessary to ensure compliance with international requirements and standards in the field of nuclear and environmental safety. With regard to ensuring the functioning of democratic principles in the country, the report calls for the competent Belarusian authorities to resume work on comprehensive electoral reform. I support the call for the release and rehabilitation of political prisoners in the country and the restoration of their civil rights. Since 2000, no new political party has been registered in the country. Free political competition is one of the main attributes of a functioning democratic society.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: in writing. - I supported the resolution on the situation in Belarus. This resolution analyses the situation after the September parliamentary elections, which, despite some recent progress made in the country, was still far from being transparent and democratic. We therefore expressed our concern in the resolution about the organisation of the elections, as well as the fact that only two opposition Members have reached Parliament. At the same time, we have called for democratic reforms and respect for fundamental human rights. Nor did the fact that Belarus is the only country in Europe still carrying out the death penalty go unnoticed, and we called for an immediate moratorium and subsequent permanent abolition.

name: Željana Zovko (PPE)
text: written. - I support the resolution seeking to encourage the Belarusian authorities to implement systematic democratization of the entire socioeconomic and political life in the state. Belarus is the last authoritarian system in Europe and the European Union must act actively to allow democracy to penetrate into that state. In Belarus, a whole range of violations of democratic principles, human rights and fundamental freedoms is visible. The prerequisite for any economic cooperation between the European Union and Belarus and any financial assistance and investment arrangements must be conditioned by comprehensive electoral reform, democratisation, release and rehabilitation of freed political prisoners and the return of all civil and political rights, the free process of registration of political parties and the abolition of the practice of misdemeanor prosecution and arbitrary application of the law enabling the persecution of independent media. The European Union must stand firmly behind the values on which it originated and nurtures and must not presuppose any economic interests to respect human rights and fundamental freedoms in third countries.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: in writing. - I voted for the European Parliament Resolution on the situation in Belarus. I agree with the EU's call to maintain the momentum for further normalisation of relations with Belarus. I believe that EU cooperation in dialogue with Belarus, its citizens and civil society, as well as with parliament and different political parties, will bring tangible results. Close diplomatic relations can contribute to a more consistent adherence to the principles of the rule of law, respect for human rights and the welfare of the country.

name: Bogdan Brunon Wenta
text: deputising for the author. – Mr President, having electricity at home, at work, and virtually everywhere, is so obvious that we rarely give this any thought, but more than a billion people live without electricity and still more only have unreliable access. This is but one aspect of the shocking gap between living conditions in our world, but it has a number of consequences for people’s health and safety, education, well—being and chance to earn a living; for women who carry out the difficult, time—consuming and sometimes risky task of collecting firewood and have to use unhealthy and hazardous cooking methods; for the development progress – or lack thereof – of communities and countries; for the preservation of vegetation, forest and biodiversity; for local climates and for the global effort to limit climate change and handle its consequences; and of course sometimes also for peace and security, as the energy issue can spawn conflict. Access to energy is a key driver of development. Ensuring access to affordable, reliable, sustainable and modern energy for all is one of the SDGs adopted in the United Nations last year. This goal should be achieved by 2030. Getting there will take truly huge efforts but it is possible and necessary. How, then, should it be done? What is the EU’s contribution and what progress is being achieved with this contribution? These are the core issues of the oral question to the Commission and the motion for a resolution prepared by the Committee on Development. Our Parliament has been emphasising for years that the focus should be on the small-scale production of renewable energy, local networks and off—grid solutions. Such solutions produce the biggest contribution to development and are best at avoiding negative impacts on the environment. We have also seen that the regulation on the Development Cooperation Instrument prescribes this orientation of EU development policy in the energy area. Not least, we note in our scrutiny of the draft development assistance programming documents that the prescription is being followed. The potential for renewable energy production is particularly great in Africa, which is also where electrification is least developed. Solar and wind power generation should be expanded faster. Insufficient and hazardous traditional use of biomass, such as firewood and charcoal, currently dominates Africa’s energy consumption. A cautious approach to more modern types of bioenergy is necessary since such energy production can come at the cost of food production, affect land use rights, cause deforestation and degradation of land and reduce the availability of water for other purposes. Energy poverty is most widespread in rural areas, but providing access to energy in rapidly growing cities is also a massive challenge. The unsatisfied needs are particularly extensive in Africa. In fact, the number of people without electricity on this continent is increasing, while population growth is faster than the progress of electrification. Climate finance provided by developed to developing countries is another important source. Together with technology transfer, it also affects Africa leaders’ wish to focus on renewable energy sources and industrialisation processes. In parallel with public funds, more private money must go into energy investment. Public-private partnerships can be useful and the general trend in EU development policy towards providing grants, loans, subsidies and other incentives for private investment is particularly strong in the area of energy investment.  The EU has recently launched an electrification financing initiative, ElectriFI and facilitating energy investment is also among the central aims of the European External Investment Plan proposed by the Commission. Development effectiveness principles should always be followed. The EU can be proud of the scale of its work to extend energy provision in developing countries. In the period 2014—2020 we are spending EUR 3.5 billion on development assistance in the energy area. The Commission proposal for a new European consensus on development rightly points to the crucial role of energy for development and in climate action. In 2012 the Commission set out to provide access to sustainable energy for an additional 500 million people in developing countries by 2030. We are now asking the Commission to tell us about the general state of progress, the main challenges encountered and the outlook for the continued implementation of development assistance in the energy area. We would also like to know what proportion of the funds engaged is going to local renewable energy projects and how we can achieve the target of EUR 500 billion. I look forward to listening to the Commission’s reply.

name: Neven Mimica
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, I would like to thank the Committee on Development and its Chair, Mrs McAvan, for putting energy high on the development agenda. European Union development cooperation in sustainable energy is supporting developing countries to advance towards economic growth powered by sustainable, affordable, reliable and modern energy for all. The three objectives of our energy and development engagements are to address the lack of energy access, to increase renewable energy generation and to contribute to the fight against climate change while ensuring sustainable use of resources. Specific attention is given to sub-Saharan Africa. Half of the global population without access to energy lives in this region and demographics aggravate the issue, with repercussions for political stability and migration to Europe.  In order to achieve our ambition, three factors are critical for success. First is policy ownership at the highest level. The promotion of energy, in particular renewable energy, must be owned by the partners. In the current financial framework, energy is a focal sector in about 30 national and regional indicative programmes. The Commission has signed, on behalf of the European Union and together with several Member States, 21 joint declarations on enhanced energy cooperation with developing countries’ partners. Second is the creation of an enabling environment. Through our technical assistance facility, the Commission provides support to partner countries on improving governance, legal and regulatory reforms and capacity building. Third is sufficient capital. The Commission has advanced considerably in generating more funding from banks and the private sector. It is estimated that, through blending, EUR 3.7 billion allocated for energy cooperation in the current multiannual financing framework period will leverage investments of EUR 15 to EUR 20 billion, or even more.  Earlier this year, the electrification financing initiative, the so—called ‘Electrify initiative’, which is an innovative mechanism to leverage investments, generated through its first invitation for applications 290 proposals requiring EUR 800 million of financial support to leverage a potential total investment amount of EUR 8.5 billion. This illustrates the significant contribution it can make to reaching universal access to energy.  The proposed external investment plan would be one more important step in this direction. Our vision cannot be implemented by governments and the private sector alone. There is also an important role for the participation of civil society, as organisations with a long presence and relationships of trust with local populations can be excellent partners in the energy sector. Likewise, women need to play a major role in the integration of renewable energies in local economies and everyday life. A gender window has been created in ‘Electrify’ to stimulate and exploit further this potential. There are still important risks impeding the investments which are necessary to meeting Sustainable Development Goal No 7 – among others political instability, current fluctuations and insufficient market sizes. The Commission is working together with all stakeholders to set up the right conditions in order to mitigate such risks.  Finally, let me address one specific issue. As regards the 11th EDF national indicative programme for Eritrea, the preparations for the implementation of a solar mini-grid programme with a pro-poor focus are underway. They are fully in line with the preconditions and principles defined by the Member States at the EDF Committee meeting in November 2015. I am fully aware of the Parliament’s concerns. Let me reconfirm that no 11th EDF projects in the energy sector will be presented as long as there is not a substantial project in support of the implementation of the UN-led universal periodic review recommendations for Eritrea under the governance sector. Progress in the field of human rights will have to be seen for the European Union to engage further in Eritrea by committing funds under the 11th EDF.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — Mr President! First, I will start with a sad constatation: we talk about energy, about opportunities to give developing countries better access to sources, including renewable sources, while we have only a dozen people in the hall. And they are overwhelmingly speakers. Unfortunately, during this meeting of Parliament, it was confirmed that a great number of topics not related to the main competences of Parliament appear earlier, and only later or at the end, those topics that I consider to be crucial. On this occasion, the push for economic, financial, transport, educational, creative industries to be preferred in this mainstream. Now I'm moving on to the essential topic, the question of today. We have two prospects here. The first shorter, six-year, financial. This is where specific amounts come in. Three and a half billion — that is the increase in the expenditure on this issue we are talking about, and 2030, which is what is related to the Paris Convention and the programme for expanding energy access opportunities for developing countries. These two perspectives in both the question and the draft resolution have been correctly formulated, so it can be said that the question has produced an effect in the form of a good, complete, understandable, consistent resolution. What do I want to look out for? First, the need to take into account the diverse possibilities of individual states, those countries that are developing, because they are not equal. The need to apply a variety of policies is so important that there are states that can't cope, but can cope, and there are states that can't cope with this problem, because such opportunities for various reasons simply do not have. The second thing also contained in the motion for a resolution is the variety of costs of electricity production depending on the sources used. I point out that in Africa alone, energy renewability is quite high, but the use on example of the capabilities of solar batteries — extremely modest. Third element — flexibility of the deployment process. According to my assessment, the more efficiently we manage new technologies, the better we take care of them, we will have higher efficiencies and lower costs for the project itself. Fourthly, I want to draw attention to the need to take into account also security, broadly understood security, that is related to the production itself, transmission, use of various energy sources and protection against random events. And fifth, using the satellite navigation system or satellite systems, primarily Copernicus, to diagnose, inventory, observe all that is related to energy consumption. This system that we are building in Europe, as the only civilian world, is designed to give us a chance to do some projects more specifically, know more and get better at doing it. I also want to point out one of the points of the resolution: the need to inform. There is such a demand that Europeans, but also recipients of our policy, have greater and better knowledge, more up-to-date knowledge of these tasks. I will also point out three slightly less relevant, but quite important issues related to the resolution itself. We are talking about the need to support local markets, the need to build also energy production capabilities based on small entities. It must be remembered that dispersal, this urban dispersal in developing countries, must also be taken into account. And another thing — sharing technologies. The technologies we can take advantage of are very many. We have to use them all, but importantly — we have to do better. At the end of these 18 paragraphs of the draft resolution, I will quote passage 11. It concerns, above all, the guidelines of the World Commission on Water Dams: “in particular, it is emphasised that the planning of any dams should be assessed in terms of five values: fairness, performance, stakeholder decision-making, sustainable character and accountability.” It seems to me that the third member of this point can be addressed to the totality of the problem.

name: Gilles Pargneaux
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (FR) Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, finally, we have this debate in plenary of the European Parliament on the most important foreign policy issue for our continent, namely Africa and its access to energy, because the figures are eloquent: out of more than 1 billion Africans, 700 million do not have no access to electricity. By 2030, if nothing is done, this figure could rise to 1.3 billion. In other words, it is the world's most populous future continent that will have the least access to electricity and light. Can we decently accept this for a continent that is separated from ours only about ten kilometres and with which we share so much, whether historically or culturally? I don't believe, we don't believe it. To that, of course, we must add the demographic perspective of a continent that will have nearly 2 billion inhabitants by 2050 and will undergo full climate change, with all that implies in terms of food security, access to energy or tensions around agricultural land use. That is why with some 40 of my colleagues first, and then through the Committee on Regional Development chaired by Linda McAvan, we wanted to have this debate in plenary this afternoon in the European Parliament. I thank them for supporting me in this process. Our message is simple: let's go, it is high time to help developing countries, especially Africa, to increase their access to energy. The stakes are enormous: education, economic development, but also migration, stability and security in a continent plagued by terrorism. This is what lies behind access to energy. Ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, much is now happening, because the African continent has understood the enormous opportunities that are facing him. Morocco has thus developed the world's largest thermal solar power plant in Ouarzazate, which will provide clean energy from 2018 to more than 1 million Moroccans. I take another example, Kenya, where only a third of the inhabitants have access to electricity and which has developed the Lake Turkana wind farm. It is expected to generate 20% of Kenya's energy by summer 2017. More generally, the water basins of Central Africa, the Rift Valley fault and the sunshine enjoyed by the continent in general are sources of water, geothermal or solar power that is not matched in the rest of the world. At present, however, only a tiny part of this potential is exploited (only 7% of hydraulic capacity and less than 1% of geothermal capacity) and photovoltaic initiatives are still too embryonic. We feel the first fruits of a continent that could become a pool of renewable energy if we accompany it properly, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. For this, the continent needs unconditional support from us and on your part. Yet, despite the urgency and consensus on the subject, there is a feeling that the machine is struggling to get started. Of the €10 billion pledged last year at COP21 — of which I was rapporteur for the European Parliament — to the African Renewable Energy Agency, only half was provided by the most developed countries. Yet the European Commission, in the European Parliament, the Member States or civil society do not lack good will. I am thinking in particular of the enormous work done by Jean—Louis Borloo with his “Energy for Africa” initiative. It is now time to pass the course and implement this great Marshall plan for access to energy in Africa, as called for by Jean—Louis Borloo and its foundation — in this way, i fully associate myself with his fight. That is the raison d'être of our parliamentary action today: to help transform undeniable political will into concrete actions. The COP22 last week, which just ended in Marrakech, carried a similar message. Africa is the crucial issue in the coming decades. Also, after decisions, action! With this great Marshall plan for energy access, we have the opportunity to implement this great and beautiful action in favor of the development of our neighbour. In this context, I welcome the launch by the European Commission of the External Investment Instrument. It seems to me to be absolutely necessary for such an instrument to focus on access to energy and be ready as soon as possible, especially before the forthcoming EU-Africa summit in autumn 2017, as proposed by the European Commission. Marshall Plan for the Electrification of Africa, external investment instruments, support for the African Renewable Energy Agency: this is how, Commissioner, we can, in a very concrete way, help the development of access to energy on a continent that needs it so badly. I expect you to give us the perspectives and the answers so that we can be in this way in concrete action, Commissioner. This is how we will put Europe in fact at the centre of the international scene, given the many ramifications that depend on African development. In a nutshell, Commissioner, let us go and let us not waste any more time!

name: Czesław Hoc
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — Mr President! Electric current is defined as the ordered motion of electric charges. If mother nature has so precisely ordered electricity, why can the modern world not or want to sort out and sustainably provide access to electricity to all regions of the world? Some countries therefore have far too much electricity, some not enough, and many countries don't have it at all. Close to 2 billion people in the world have no access to grid electricity at all, and after all, each of us knows that the power grid is a condition for the economic and civilizing development of the world. Moreover, there is a close link between poverty and lack of access to modern electrical services. The electrification rate for Central African countries reaches just 23% and 500 million Africans lack access to electricity. On the one hand, the Union is undertaking a development energy initiative to provide access to sustainable energy to an additional 500 million people by 2030, and at the same time accepts that by 2030 the share of gas flowing through Gazprom's pipelines will increase to 50% of all European gas supply, which is to be confirmed by the agreement between the German company and the Russian Gazprom. Thus, the Union is unlikely to balance access to energy, rather it calls for an element of political impact of electricity. Moreover, the Union promotes and even forces electricity-rich countries to produce biofuels, which, moreover, do little good for the climate and energy policies of these countries. And the same Union reduces and puts barriers to biofuel production in developing countries where the cost of biofuels is much lower and it is easier to do so. There is also a provision in the proposed resolution restricting the subsidies to fossil fuels gradually, a provision that disturbs the energy policy of certain Member States of the Union, for example, Poland, in which the primary source of energy is fossil fuel — coal. In the conclusion, it is very good that the European Union is betting on ensuring access to sustainable energy in developing countries, including sub-Saharan Africa or the Eritrean programme, because it requires a sense of solidarity with all countries in the world and skill sharing richer with poorer ones. Migration policy considerations also require this. It would be even better if the Union's policies in this regard were rational and balanced, without the characteristics of protectionism, and would not interfere with the energy policies of the Member States of the Union. And the question — can the Commission present its own assessment of the global conditions for achieving Sustainable Development Goal 7 and express its opinion on issues of new and urgently necessary actions, and can it initiate and implement opinions? How much has the Union come closer to the goal of access to sustainable energy for 500 million people?

name: Jozo Radoš
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. — Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, a large part of the problems facing the world today, and also the European Union, is the problem of underdevelopment. A large gap in the underdevelopment of countries causes poverty, misunderstanding and conflict. And one of the important elements of how one can and should reduce the development gap is of course energy policy. And that is why I welcome the initiative of fellow MEPs as well as the European Parliament Development Committee who have raised this issue on access to energy in developing countries. I would also like to thank Mr Commissioner Mimica for the explanations he has given regarding what difficulties the Commission is facing and what the Commission seeks to do further with regard to the implementation of this programme. It is a very ambitious program, that not energy but only electric current, which is the most elementary form of energy policy, is brought to 500 million people by 2030, which is in itself, even if it is an elementary, not a real approach to energy in all aspects of action , one very ambitious goal and it is important that it is set. It is equally important that we in the European Parliament ask how this objective has been realised. This is just part of the overall development cooperation that the European Union has with the whole world. It should be noted that the countries of the European Union in terms of development cooperation give more than the whole rest of the world together, about 60 billion euros per year, and this is due, as I said, to reduce this gap in development, or poverty, which is the cause of this crisis. It is important to note that the modern energy policy of the European Union is essentially a new European policy because it is increasingly difficult to access energy, due to new clean energy requirements and it would be good that these new European policies in this form as modern and modern can be implemented in those countries that are energy-poor. Therefore, here is the most talk about how to bring electric energy, but Mr. Commissioner Mimica also talked about other aspects of energy cooperation that are much more serious than just bringing electricity to a village in Africa. A particularly important dimension of this project, namely the whole idea, is the fact that it is directed towards Africa, the continent in the most difficult position, and especially the fact that half of these thirty projects concern Sub-Saharan Africa, our neighbourhood, the space exposed to instability and from which they actually threaten and come to Europe big migration waves. Therefore, for all these aspects, I again welcome the initiative of colleagues from the Development Committee and the Commission's efforts in this regard.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — Mr President, access to sustainable energy is one of the goals of the UN Sustainable Development Goals, and that is because access to sustainable energy is a key part of the achievement of people's basic rights. Energy poverty is a global problem. One billion people suffer from it in the developed world, and also in Europe, where, according to the Commission itself, 11% of the population suffers it. In Spain, more than five million people are cold in winter; the electricity bill has risen 73% in eight years; and, according to the Academy of Environmental Sciences, a year there are more deaths from energy poverty than traffic accidents. In Europe, we see that energy poverty stems from the deregulation of a strategic sector that has been left to the unlimited greed of the private sector. That is why we must learn from our own experience and not prescribe in Africa the measures that have led Europe to this drama. To ensure access to energy, it is essential that the State maintain its political space to regulate and ensure effective access to energy by all citizens. That is why instruments such as budget support and the promotion of public investment are the avenues to overcome energy poverty in developing countries; not to increase the role of the private sector through combined finance, because we will be exporting an energy model that is proven ineffective and which is also indecent.

name: Florent Marcellesi
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — Mr President, I was at COP 22 last week, and there we clearly recall, at this Summit on Climate Change, that access to energy is central to the countries of the south, especially given that one billion people right now — and half of them in Africa — do not have access to the energy. But here we are not talking about any kind of access to any kind of energy, because we know perfectly well that there are types of energy that we cannot afford right now, both for poverty reduction and for the fight against climate change. And here we refer, for example, to large projects, large infrastructures, land grabbing and, for example, monocultures of agrofuels: these mean displacement of people, populations; they mean violations of human rights, more poverty, more armed conflict. If we talk about access to energy in the countries of the south, we need to talk above all about access to energy that is sustainable; to energy that is clean; to energy that fights for social justice; that fights for climate justice; that struggles to meet people's basic needs; and, also, that fights for rights human beings, starting with women, who are really the first to suffer from climate change. That being said, we are happy with this resolution, because what it does is also talk about a different type of energy: energy that is decentralised; energy that is small-scale, disconnected from the grid. That is, energy that is really tailored to the needs of these populations, especially in Africa. I would also like to go back to two important points. One is funding, and here we are quite critical of the tools of cooperation between the private and public sector, because experience shows us that most of these funds go mainly to large projects, large infrastructures that are not at all sustainable. On the other hand, we would also like these funds, at least if there is a private-public relationship, to be funds in line with the sustainable development goals and in line with the Paris climate agreements. We also agree on another point: we have to divest all fossil fuels as soon as possible, and that money will be put as soon as possible in the fight against climate change and, moreover, in favour of the sustainable development goals. Finally, I would like to conclude by recalling one phrase in this resolution: that policies to combat climate change have to be sustainable and must be above all consistent with trade policies; or, rather, we need to have coherence between agreements such as CETA and agreements such as Paris. And I would like this to be the general tonic of all European Union policies. May this resolution and what you have said, Mr Mimica, would be the tone of all policies, whether those of that resolution or economic policies of the European Union.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, let me begin by telling you about my experience. When I was head of the energy sector in Alsace — this was my first civil servant position — I wanted to do something for Africa. I did not have the support of the regional council at the time, and I had obtained a million francs. Thanks to this sum, in Sanaga-Maritime, Cameroon, we did rural electrification and, from this rural electrification, we launched farms, a small carpentry and we also put around the infrastructure that goes with development, i.e. water and health. Electricity is therefore an indispensable means for development. It is a necessary condition, but it is not a sufficient condition — I will come back to it. First of all, I would like to underline all the support our group gives to this initiative. 3.5 billion at Union level is good. One billion for France is also good. All this for targets that remain modest for 2020 — because I will not tell you about 2030 with 300 gigawatts. Let's first with these 10 gigawatts, which is quite possible. 1 gigawatt is around a billion. Let me give you a methodology. For 20 years, I devoted myself to the development of Africa, in a private capacity, apart from my other professional occupations at the Regional Cooperation Institute of the Alsace Region and the European Institute of Cooperation. First, it is about building on African local initiatives. I think that Youba Sokona's initiative with the African Development Bank, AFD, KFW (Kréditanstalt für Wiederaufbau) is really what we need to do, namely that we have development agencies at home and we have potential in Africa. We have to work together. We should not create new structures. I like Mr Borloo very much, but I am opposed to my colleague. Secondly, we must have a multilateral approach, not just a European approach. We must be aware that it is very good to associate the United Arab Emirates, the United States, China and Russia. All available funding means must be used with the coherence of African initiatives at the local level. Thirdly — and here I am addressing you, Commissioner, what I am going to say is very important and I do not know if your ear will hear it: we must avoid levers! Leverage will not work! You need to invest where there are people and not necessarily where there is the most money and profitability, if you want to do rural development and if you really want to develop Africa. Where it is profitable, it will be done anyway on its own. So we must have an approach like that of the Marshall Plan. This plan started from the idea of loans and ended in more than 90% of donations. We must have an approach where we are investing new money in rural electrification and rural development. I would like to say that even colonial France was able to invest without the prospect of return on investment when it developed, for example, the entire sanitation system in Douala or when it created the train linking the South to the North of Cameroon. We were able to have a long-term vision. Fourth, electricity is a necessary but not sufficient condition. Electricity is a way, like the road. It's not because you have electricity or you have a road that you create wealth. This is a necessary condition, but not sufficient. There is a real need to build development programs around electricity. I would like these programmes to be carried out as a priority in those countries that need it the most. I am thinking of the sub-Saharan region of the Great Lakes, where there is still some stability, in Cameroon, the Central African Republic and then in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, with its full potential. I am also thinking of the Maghreb, Egypt and Algeria. But I come back to what we need, namely a real Marshall plan of donations by money creation, like France, which financed its power plants after the war. It did so through monetary creation. These are advances from the Treasury made to Électricité de France that allowed this. It was monetary creation, pure monetary creation. All of this, we must do so from a developmental perspective around industries so that we can truly highlight rural development and local development.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: — Dear colleagues! Mr Commissioner! One of the objectives of sustainable development is to provide all people with access to affordable, reliable, sustainable and modern energy services. African countries are facing huge constraints in energy supply at the given moment, which significantly puts a brake on its development. The African continent is booming and surviving a demographic explosion. Together with the weak education and health system, undeveloped energy supplies form a vicious circle of poverty from which Africans find it very difficult to get away. Colleagues, even relatively small investments in energy supply can bring a huge economic breakthrough and substantially, significantly improve living and working conditions for many of the inhabitants of the African continent. On the European side, it's not just a charity. Sustainable development of Africa will help soften the migration crisis and create new opportunities for our business in the future. The European Union's Energy Development Initiative aims to provide access to sustainable energy for another 500 million people by 2030. Half a billion people! And will allocate EUR 3.5 billion for energy development aid from 2014 to 2020. We have goals and money. So it is important that the envisaged 30 programs work accurately and efficiently. Here, Parliament, I mention the European Parliament and the Commission, must work together to fix the problems and coordinate our efforts to achieve the objectives. That is why it is important for MPs to get the Commission's vision and learn about the difficulties of implementing programmes in a timely manner.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: Mr. President, I will draw one parallel. You know very well where I come from - I come from Croatia, from Istria and you know that in Croatia I have been engaged in politics for a very long time, more than 20, about 25 years, that I have acted a lot in Istria and that I have done a lot for rural development of Istria. I can say that in the early 90's, when we started building infrastructure in Istria, electricity and water were key things. People were leaving the village in Istria, which is the westernmost and, by some criteria, perhaps the richest Croatian region, to towns by the sea. They simply did not want to live in a country where there is neither electricity nor water. It was only 25 years ago, which is not that long ago. I draw that parallel because we have the same situation a little more globally - we have the fact that we have no energy or water. If we don't have energy and water, we have no development. Then what do we have? Migrants coming to Europe. That symbolism, the parallel I want to draw is very simple, very banal and we all understand it very well. What to do in a situation like this? I am an advocate for the synergy of joint action of all key actors on the world stage. First of all I think of us, the European Union which is the most gifted of all partners on our planet anyway, but I also think of those who have interests in Africa, such as the US, China, Russia, and possibly someone else. I think sincere cooperation from all key actors should all be the goal to save the situation in Africa and enable people in Africa to come up with energy, water and everything they need in key infrastructure projects. If we approach it in such a way, we can resolve much of the problem we face today. It is likely that individual efforts will yield some results, but I'm sure not as synergy, if politically possible, because Europe is the only key political factor that can bring together perhaps some incompatible elements and make significant, rapid and strong steps in Africa. The other thing I would like to suggest is that maybe you should not give too much money directly to the African state. Maybe more money should be given, but indirectly. By investing in infrastructure where, after all, our European industry will have goals and benefits and thus we can avoid something that knows how to happen, which is a matter of corruption. In African and unfortunately, European countries it is ubiquitous and we know this very well. I am also inclined to talk about more resources that would be invested in energy in African countries, such as sun and wind energy, and not to make, which is my last and third message, those mistakes that we have made in energy development in Europe. So, that as much as we go towards renewable energy sources and even those local sources that won't be networked. And this is a good path for the development of rural areas in the territory of Africa. With these ideas, Mr. Commissioner, I want to congratulate you on your efforts and your work, and I believe that you will certainly pledge that at least some of it is accomplished.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, we welcome the fact that the resolution tabled promotes European development policies for the fight against energy poverty in impoverished countries, but the truth is that this is of little value while maintaining the current economic and trade policies of the European Union. It is of no use if we continue to export the European model of turning a basic need — access to energy — into a business and leaving a strategic sector such as energy in private and European hands. Here we have, for example, what happened in Peru: the gas available to Peruvians was cut in favor of the export of the resource by multinationals, such as Repsol, who get better prices on the international market. This is the way European companies act around the world. We are not in the European Union to give lessons about virtually nothing, but less on the fight against energy poverty. Without going any further, last week an 81-year-old woman died in Reus (Catalonia) because her apartment burned down by candles, because she had been cut off her electricity two months ago. In the European Union, the number of people suffering from energy poverty is increasing. For example, in Spain, since 2008, people in energy poverty have tripled and there are already about five million people, while energy companies have astronomical benefits. The three major Spanish electricity companies have earned more than 56 billion during the toughest years of the crisis: while the electricity receipt rose by more than 52%, electricity companies earned 20 million euros a day in profits. They were doing business with our rights here and plundering natural resources in impoverished countries. And clearly, as in all types of poverty, women are the most hit. Of the one three hundred million people in the world without access to electricity, 70% are women. It is the result of combining the policies of plunder with oppression.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, access to energy by people in developing countries is a priority in our view. Energy is a right and is necessary for life as much as water; therefore it is a global responsibility to guarantee it. For many years, developing countries have been sought to travel the same path as the West over the centuries: to start their development with a highly polluting industrial era and low in labour rights to gradually become more technologically advanced industries and societies, and, in principle, fewer broadcasters of CO2. And I say in principle, because the West is still far from this goal. Fortunately, the consensus is that we must move directly to fair and low-emission developed societies on a global basis, in order to meet international objectives, such as the Paris Agreement, which set the goal of avoiding global temperature rise above two degrees. It is therefore universal justice and climate justice that developed countries collaborate in the development of the global south, ensuring, among others, access to energy through clean and renewable sources, but also by providing tools for adaptation to climate change. The opportunity to do so was Marrakech and it has passed. Developed countries do not want to accept and constantly dilute shared but differentiated responsibility. And this should not be an invitation to open the door to multinationals and the private sector. A clear example is the effect of biofuels or hydroelectric plants in Latin America. Multinationals use the pull of renewables to violate human rights, as is happening in Brazil and Central America with hydroelectric dams. In the Baixo Iguazú region in Brazil, the subsidiaries of Iberdrola, a company based in my country, in Spain, have expelled more than 1,000 families of their lands, without any alternative. The protests of these families in the face of this situation were responded with police brutality and tear gas, both adults or boys and girls. Energy is not renewable, ladies and gentlemen, if it is stained with blood.

name: Indrek Tarand (Verts/ALE).
text: — Mr President, thank you for calling my modest personality important. If you allow we to speak in Estonian it will be even more important. Most of today's consumption is related to electricity, and if we wish the developing countries good, we will do everything to help them produce renewable energy, mainly from the sun, but also more and more wind, taking into account climate change. All this in the aggregate can also help us, in the so-called rich world, helping to launch our too slowly developing economies, creating jobs and reducing greenhouse gas emissions. As Mr Schaffhauser mentioned, we can both unleash Africa's potential by engaging Saudi-Arabia, China and Russia. Absolutely, this is the point of the Paris Climate Agreement, international cooperation is the point of it, and I believe that just accidentally Mr Schaffhauser did not name the US and his newly elected President Donald Trump, who are also very important in this cooperation. Thank you.

name: Neven Mimica
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the European Commission is committed to the goal of assisting developing countries in providing energy access for 500 million people by 2030. This is of course a target that cannot be achieved by the EU funds alone; the contribution of all global actors will be required. Today we estimate that the projects supported with EU funds under the current multiannual financial framework by 2020 will contribute to provide on-grid and off-grid access to energy for up to 40 million people, generate 6.5 gigawatts of renewable energy capacity and save 15 million tonnes of CO2 per year in our developing country partners. I would like to thank the Parliament for its full support and I am pleased to see that our visions of this subject are aligned.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I have received one draft resolution submitted in accordance with Article 128 (1) of the Rules of Procedure I'm closing the debate. The vote will take place during the later monthly session.
